title: North Carolina Beaten By Kentucky in Bowl
China's Year of Disorder

title: Strike Threatened Today By Interns and Residents At Brooklyn Methodist
description: Interns and residents at Brooklyn's Methodist Hospital threatened to strike today because of the hospital's refusal to recognize the Committee of Interns and Residents as their bargaining agent.

title: American Dance Festival To Stay in Connecticut
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Dec. 3IThe American Dance Festival will return to Connecticut College for the 1977 summer season, according to a temporary agreement reached today on a financial dispute between the college and the festival.

title: U.S. Approval of the Westtvacy Seen Tuesday Amid Opposition
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The expected approval next Tuesday of the Westway Interstate System highway by William T. Coleman Jr., United States Secretary of Transportation, will find a coalition of opponents ready to resume their legal and political battles against the superhighway on Manhattan's West Side.

title: The Orange Bowl: Clash of Conferences
Puerto Rico at a Glance
description: GEOGRAPHY  Puerto Rico is 50 miles east of Hispaniola (Haiti and the Dominican Republic) in the outer Caribbean, about 1,000 miles southeast of Florida. The island commonwealth consists of 3,423 square miles, less than onethird the size of New Hampshire. The climate is semi tropical with temperatures ranging from 63 degrees to 96 degrees Fahrenheit. There are 10 ports, with San Juan, the capital on the northern coast, Ponce and Mayaguez; the leading ones.

title: A TwinEngine Plane Crashes in Queens, Severely Injuring 4 Persons
description: twinengine private plane crashed minutes after taking off from Flushing Airport in Queens yesterday afternoon .seriously injuring the pilot, his 12yearold son and two other passenger

title: 3 Top Tuna Fishermen Talk About Leaving U.S.
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 31 (UPI)  Three leading American tuna fishermen, saying they cannot survive under this country's porpoisesaving law, are preparing to move to other nations to put their boats under foreign flags.

title: In Japan and Korea, It's Year of Snake
description: TOKYO, Dec, 31 (AP)The Year of the Dragon gives way tonight to the Year of the Snake in Japan and part of South Korea. It means 12 months of bright, proud and beautiful babies, say Japanese soothsayers.

title: Christopher, Los Angeles Lawyer, Gets No. 2 State Department Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31Warren M. Christopher, a prominent Los Angeles lawyer, was named today to serve as the No. 2 State Department official in the Carter administration.

SVEN NIELSEN
description: PARIS, Jan. 31 (AP)Sven Nielsen, a Danishborn publisher who controlled nearly 40 percent of France's general book production and published authors such as Simenon and Taylor Caldwell, died here Thursday night. He was 76 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed.

title: Strike Fails to Hamper Miami Area Hotel Parties
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 31 (UPI)  A strike by union maids barteataers, waiters and bellhops against eight of the area's leading hotels failed today to dampen New Year's celebrations or slow the inflow .of tourists.

title: F.B.I., in Worst Crisis Ever, Looking to Its Next Director
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31With public confidence in its rectitude undermined by disclosures of illegal activity, internal corruption and abuse of power, the Federal Bureau of InveStigation that the Carter administration will inherit Jan. 20 is in the midst of its worst internal crisis ever.

description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 (AP)Security forces killed 27 suspected leftwing guerrillas today in separate clashes, police sources said, marking a grim end to a violencewracked year for Argentina.

title: Mrs. Mondale to Aid Cunningham Troupe
description: Mrs. Walter F. Mondale, wife of the Vice Presidentelect, and the sculptress Louise Nevelson, will be honorary leaders of an openingnight champagne supper to benefit the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. Mr. Cunningham brings his troupe to the Minskoff Theater on Jan. 18 for a sixday run.

title: Offbeat Piano
description: Pianists in cocktail lounges tend to lean toward a repertory of pop and show tunes performed either with a bland, superficial tinkle or with as much jazz inflection as the room will allow. Neil Wolfe, who is playing piano in the lounge in front of Les Mareyeurs, a restaurant on Madison Avenue at 77th Street, draws on the standard cocktail pianist's repertory, but What he does with these tunes is far from typical.

title: Vorster Attacks the West
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 31 (UPI)Prime Minister John Vorster told South Africans today that the nation would have to face any Communist attack alone. He called the west weakwilled and said it had lost its strength and initiative.

title: 9Mile Zigzag Paint Job Ousts
Tighter RegulatiOns Sought
description: FALMOUTH, Mass., Dec. 31 (AP) Federal panel will recommend on Jan. tighter regulations for oil tankers, Mr. Coleman said, but he added that it could be far longer before tougher rules take effect.

title: Presidential Race Cost Government $72 Million; WASHINGTON, Dec 31 (UPI)  The Federal Government spent $72 million to finance the 1976 Presidential election and has almost $24 million left as a base for building a new fund for the 1980 elections, rederal records show.
description: Since taxpayers started checking off $1 contributions on their income tax forms in 1972, the Government has set aside $95,802,374 to pay for the elections, according to the Federal Election Commission.

title: SmithPledges to W eighNew Plans For Rhodesia, but Issues Warning
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 31Prime Minister Ian D. Smith pledged tonight to give careful consideration to new Rhodesian settlement proposals that will be laid before him by Ivor Richard of Britain, chairman of the Geneva conference, who arrives here tomorrow.

title: PALESTINIANS SAID TO SHELL LEBANESE CHRISTIAN TOWNS

description: Harry Reems used to perform in pornographic movies and Edward Gurney used to perform in the Senate. Now both are federally created paupers. Mr. Gurney went broke at the courthouse defending himself against Justice Department charges that he didn't perform fair and square in the Senate. After two trials, he was ac quitted and ruined.

title: Smile, Nola, Smile
description: New Year's Day provides so obvious a psychological point to pivot on that readers and playgoers may wonder why its emotional potential has seldom been exploited in popular art. One use did indeed occur the old Noel Coward movie, Cavalcade, which extracted extra sentimental juice from family crises by playing them against a musical background of Londoners singing Auld Lang Syne. An equally rare New Year moment in the theater that may apply more forcefully in New York occurred in that nowvenerable American operetta, Show Boat.

description: They call it El PuebloThe Townand, in the mostly Hispanic Mott Haven section of the South Bronx yesterday, the opinion among residents and shopkeepers was pretty much divided over whether Puerto Rico should, or indeed would, become a state of the Union.

description: Officers and crewmen of the oil tan. Argo Merchant ended a week of testimony yesterday for a hearing designed to determine why the ship ran aground near Nantucket Island on Dec. 15.

title: Spanish Red Calls Release Move to Legalize Party
description: ROME, Dec. 31 (UPI)  Santiago Carrillo, the Spanish Communist Party leader, said in an interview for Italian television today that his release from a Madrid jail was the first step toward legalizing his party in Spain.

title: `Music is Ran 14 Preview's And 8 Performances
description: Music Is, the musical based on Shakespeare's Twelfth Night, ended its Broadway run at the St. James Theater last Sunday, after 8 performances and 14 previews.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)A record of 14.2 percent of all births in this country in 1975 were illegitimate, the National Center for Health Statistics said today.

title: A Philosophy of the Center
description: PARISWhile, at present, French politics are being increasingly polarized between right and left, with the leftwing SocialistCommunist coalition attaining a lead in opinion polls, there is no doubt in the mind of President Giscard d'Estaing, symbol of centralism, that regardless of possible changes in the parliamentary majority, he will remain in office until 1981, the end of his designated term as chief of state.

title: Peabody to Affilliate With Johns Hopkins
description: The Peabody Institute, a major American music conservatory, will become affiliated with Johns Hopkins University next July. In the new relationship between the two Baltimore organizations, Peabody will keep its corporate identity, but supervision of its daytoday management will be the university's responsibility. The conservatory will be known as the Peabody Institute of the Johns Hopkins University.

title: Guarded Support From Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 31 (Reuters)Zambia today gave a guarded pledge of support to a southern African peace shuttle by the chairman of the Rhodesia conference, Ivor Richard. President Kenneth D. Kaunda told Mr. Richard when the two opened talks today that if he were satisfied with the Briton's proposals, we can work together to bring peace in wartorn Rhodesia.

title: Bomb Blast in Belfast
'By John B. Oakes'
description: From out front, we know, an editorial page appears to be a Chorus without a face, a booming but disembodied Voice, a We that represents no discernible I. We work hard at that illusion. When borne aloft by a great news machine, an editorial page speaks louder than any individual could, or should; that is why we speak anonymously. But the authority and vision of such page can never be greater than the force and perception of the people in charge, the actors behind the institutional drape. That is why the curtain must be lifted on rare occasions to acknowledge a guiding spirit.

title: SUIT CHARGES ANESTHESIA LEFT WOMAN IN A COMA
Elite Favor French Alpine Resort, for Its Privacy
description: MEGEVE, France, Dec. 26As they do every winter, many of the elite of France and a smattering of royalty and celebrities from abroad drift into the icecream hills around this Alpine village as naturally as the snow the townspeople call white gold.

title: NorthSouth Rail Link Reopened in Vietnam
description: I BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 31 (UPI) Vietnam reopened the railroad between the north and south today, linking the two halves of the country after 22 years of separation, the official Vietnam News Agency reported..

title: M.I.T. Made a Sea Grant College By Richardson for Oceanic Activity
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 31 (AP)Massachusetts Institute of Technology has been named the sea grant college for Massachusetts by Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Commerce.

description: Dr. S. Stanley Schneierson, a microbiologist, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 525 East 86th Street.

title: bptics at Chartres Reported Ruined
description: PARISIn the flood of Christmas cards let loose at this time of year, doubtless there were some carrying reproductions of th,e stainedglass windows of the Chartres Cathedral. Americans reared in veneration of these glittering 12thcentury monuments will be interested to learn that three of those that illuminate the west facade  the rose windoiv exceptedhave been, according to observers, irretievably altered by cleaning and conservation. title: No Early Action Over Statehood Seen in Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31Congressional staff members said today it was unlikely that Congress would adopt any time soon President Ford's recommendation that Puerto Rico be made a state.

title: Miss Meier Sings Marguerite In Faust for First Time at Met
description: Thursday night's performance of Faust at the Metropolitan Opera was newsworthy for the first appearance there of Johanna Meier in the role of, Marguerite. The soprano, a mainstay of the New York City Opera, made her debut with the larger company last season in the title role of Straus''s Ariane auf Naxos as an emergency replacement, and was successful enough to justify her singing other roles there.

title: Cups and Cups and Cups and Cups o Kindness
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.I got drunk last night. Not pleasantly high. Kneewalking. I was tipsy by three in the afternoon, kept the buzz on until after sundown, began with Beefeaterontherocks at six, and ended with bourbon and branch water. I brought in the New Year with a holler, a taste of champagne, and a kiss from my sweet wife's lips.

title: Districting Bid Lost
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected a move by a group of black leaders in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn to bar the implementation today of new community district lines voted by the Board of Estimate on Dec. 23. In an unusual hearing at his home in Forest Hills, Queens, Chief Judge Jacob Mish. ler of Federal District Court in Brooklyn said he would asign a judge to hold a hearing Monday morning on request for a preliminary injunction to keep the new district lines from becoming permanent.

title: FASTER FORECLOSURE SET IN NEW YORK CITY
description: A new law calling for faster propertytax foreclosures could result in as much as $200 million in accelerated revenue for New York City. Or it could cause a still greater drain on the city's finances and further erode its troubled tax base.

title: 70 India Communists Reported Held
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 31 (AP)The Communist Party of India said today that some of its workers had been arrested on the eve of a planned New Year's Day national protest against Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government.

title: PHILIP HONIG FISHER
description: Philip Honig Fisher, who retired in 1954 as a tax law expert assigned to the Appellate Division of the United States Internal Revenue Service in New York City, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 50E Jefferson Oval, Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

description: Percy Selden, a Houston real estate investor, died Thursday in a balloon accident near that city. He was 70 years old.

title: Preminger to Produce and Direct Movie of Dayan's Autobiography
description: Otto Preminger, who scored with the ? depicting the founding of Israel, is preparing to make a movie about subsequ'nt momentous events in that nation's history. The producerdirector has acquired rights to Moshe Dayan's autobiography, Story of My Life, published by William Morrow, and reports that Mr. Dayan has agreed to be story adviser as well as consultant on the feature, titled, The First 25 Years: Dayan's Israel.

Queens Youth Charged in Slaying Of Transit Policeman Driving Cab
description: A 16yearold Queens youth was charged yesterday in the murder of Carlos King, a Transit Authority patrolman who was fouita shot to death on a quiet street in Queens Village, Queens, on Dec. 20 in the medallion cab he was driving while on vacation.

title: 19 Million Will Pay More In 77 Social Security Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Millions of Americans will pay as much as S70.20more in Social Security taxes in the new year.

title: ISABEL ROSE JONES
description: Isabel Rose Jones, who retired in 1962 as owner and director of the Starlight Summer Stock Theater, which she helped found in Pawling, N.Y., in 1934, died last Sunday in Sebring, Fla., where she had winter home. Miss Jones, who also lived ea South Quaker Road, Pawling, was 72 years old.

description: ALBANY, Dec. 31 (AP)Robert F. Sullivan, Acting Director of the State Division of Probation, died yesterday in St. Peter's Hospital here after an apparent heart attack. He was 52 years old.

description: MOSCOW, Dec. 31It could have been Fifth Avenue. A fashionably and expensively dressed woman stood outside a toy store on Moscow's Kutuzovsky Frospekt this afternoon, watching aristocratically as two large rocking horses were loaded into her chauffeurdriven black sedan. Obviously she was well connectedan official herself, perhaps, or the wife of someone high in the Government bureaucracy.

description: New York City's financial statement for November indicates that the city will do a little better than we originally expected to in reducirfg its budget deficit during the current fiscal according to Deputy Mayor Jh:m C. Burton.

Four masked and armed men released the driver and his helper several hours later from a car near New Calvary Cemetery . . . .  A 26yearold Brooklyn man, the victim of a robbery at 150 Lafferts Avenue, died after being shot and apparently thrown from a window by five masked men. He was identified as Winston McDonald, 26 years old, of 1075 Hancock Street .. . A 24yearold man, Larry Tribble of 4 West 116th Street in Manhattan, was found dead from bullet wounds in his apartment yesterday morning. The police said there was no apparent motive and no suspect . . . . The Citibank branch at Park Avenue and 53d Street was robbed of $3,272 by a man who passed a threatening note to a teller. The Chase Manhattan Bank branch at 1701 Church Avenue in the Kensington section of Brooklyn held up by three men with toy gu;s who took $3,830. description: PEKING, Dec. 31 (Reuters)Political strife has led to civil war and serious loss of life in China's vast southwestern province of Szechwan, according to a local radio report.

description: LISBON, Dec. 31The United States has agreed to make a $300 million emergency loan to Portugal to save the fivemonthold Socialist Government from a severe financial crisis.

description: LONDON, Dec. 31Britain, banned from the rich cod and haddock waters around Iceland, will retaliate with a 200mile fishing limit around all the British Isles as of midnight tonight.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 (AP)  The Liberian tanker Olympic Games was escorted today by the Coast Guard to an anchorage in the Delaware River, where she spilled 134,000 gallons of oil last Monday.

description: PRAGUE, Dec. 31 (AP)A gas explosion trapped 45 miners in a coal mine at Chlebovice in northern Moravia, the Czechoslovak press agency CTK said today, and unofficial reports said there was little or no hope that they survived.

title: Little Effect Is Found in Utility Deposits and Penalties
Cola Price War Begun In Eastern Illinois Area
description: MATTOON, Ill., Dec. 31 (UPI)Shoppers at stores in this part of eastern Illinois yesterday loaded up on popular soft drinks priced at only 49 cents for an eight pack of I6ounce bottles.

title: 3 Youths Held in Vandalism of a South Bronx Library
description: Three youths were arrested last night and charged with the vandalism of a South Bronx branch of the New Yorke Public Library over the Christmas weekend. Another suspect, who is reportedly a member of a gang known as the Bachelors was still being sought by the police.

title: Plummer Signs to Star In Assignment Film
description: Christopher Plummer has been signed to star in The Assignment, a Swedish film based on the 1962 novel by Per Waldo, author of The Laughing Policeman. The Assignment is now being filmed in Serpa, Portugal, under the direction of Mats Aram, whose only previous film, Maria, reportedly is a hit in Sweden.

title: Vienna Abuzz as Opera Ball Nears, Highlight of City's Social Season
description: VIENNA, Dec. 31A hundred dressmakers are wielding scissors and needles, between glances at highfashion sketches from Paris or Rome, to get gala gowns ready in time for the Opera Ball.

title: Redressing the Balance
description: In frustration, citizens often feel that the governments with which they have to deal are institutions designed mask human responsibility of any kind. But occasionally, events occur for which there is clear and singular responsibility and which illuminate the character of the person wielding power.

title: Mrs. Graham Ends Her Effort to Control New York Magazine
description: The Washington Post Company ended its efforts yesterday to buy the controlling stock of the New York MagazineCompany, apparently leaving Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, as the lone bidder.

title: Lab Tests Lead To Arrest
description: After waiting sinlest two years fot. Medical Examiner's report, the police have arrested an Enfield, Conn.. youth in the death of a 14yearold boy. The youth, Gregory P. Gutska, 19, was held in $5,000 bond, the police said, after being charged in the March 15, 1975, death of William Buynicki, also of Enfield.

title: ALAN ROSENSWEIG
description: Alan Rosensweig, president of the Ameray Corporation, an investment concern in Randolph Township, N.J., until 1969, died in Dover (N.J.) General Hospital Wednesday of injuries suffered last Sunday when an aircraft he was piloting crashed on takeoff at Flanders Valley Airport. He was 49 years old.

title: Botanical Garden Faces New and Unexpected Cuts in Funds
description: Its gardens and vistas already compromised by a dwindling budget, the worldfamous New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx now faces new and unexpected cuts in revenues from the state.

title: Long Holiday Work Break in Britain Draws Fire at Home and Abroad
description: LONDON, Dec. 31The Great British Christmas Break seems to have gotten out of hand. At least four out of 10 workers are staying home nearly two weeks, factories are closed, businessmen are complaining, government offices are halfempty, the roads and trains are quiet during the rush hour and the country seems to have closed down.

title: MARY AMES HART BRIGGS
description: Mary Ames Hart Briggs, a retired Methodist missionary, died Monday at her residence in Heath Village, Hackettstown, N.J. She was 97 years old.

description: TOKYO (AP)The Tokyo office of Warner Bros. said that it has annunced that it would terminate the showing of the movie Victory at Entebbe La major Japanese cities because of poor attendance.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)With Marine Corps bugle fanfare, the Bicentennial Parade of American Music concluded a yearlong salute to the nation's composers today and placed in a 100year time capsule a sampling of two centuries of their music.

description: BOSTON Dec. 31The Coast Guard sank the battered hull of the wrecked tanker the Argo Merchant today with 12 shots fired from a 20millimeter gun.

description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission will hold a public hearing Tuesday at the Roosevelt Hotel on a 13 percent fare increase request by the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade. Moses L. Kove, commission chairman, said the testimony would be limited to proponents of the increase, A hearing for opponents will be scheduled later. The present taxi rate is 65 cents for the first onesixth mile and 10 cents for each addiional onesixth of a mile and $6 per hour for waiting time.

On Wednesday at the 55th Street City Center Theater, he performed the title role in Petrushka for the first time, and, lo and behold, he faded very correctly into the ballet.

description: A 13yearold Staten Island girl who disappeared Thursday afternoon was found stabbed and beaten to death in snowcovered woods late yesterday morning about 200 yards from the Prince Bay station of the Staten Island Rapid Tratisit line.

title: Goethe's Faust
description: Randall Jarrell was one of the large and looming figures of American poetry to appear during or soon after World War II. Others were Theodore Roethke, John Berryman and Robert Lowell, the lone survivor. They correspond perhaps to Hemingway, Scott Fitzgerald, E.E. Cummings after World War I and have perhaps even greater claims to be called a tragic generation. They were ambitious, much admired, famous men who nevertheless had about them an air of deep resentment at not being recognized. They felt perhaps that, in them, American poetry itself was not recognizedor was only recognized by Academia, which came to the same thing as not being recognized. Randall Jarrell's famous essay, The Age of Criticism, delivered before a large audience at Harvard University, is an impassioned, extremely witty diatribe

Margaret Thomson Wed To Kerry Hayes in Maine
description: Margaret Thomson, who teaches at the Lyc6e Francais de New York, was married yesterday to Kerry Hayes, a photographer. The ceremony was performed at the home in Biddeford Pool, Me., of the bride's father, Alan Ronaldshay Thomson. who also has a home in Westmount, Montreal. Mr. Hayes is a son of Shirley Hayes of New York and the late James Hayes of Weston, Conn. The Rev. David Corbett of the Biddeford Pool Unitarian Church officiated.

title: OPEC's PriceSplit Mixed Blessing
description: The twotier world crude oil pricing system, established two weeks ago at the meeting in Qatar of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was the surprise of 1976. Everyone had expected a repetition of the bynow familiar compromise on one price. But this time, Saudi Arabia, OPEC's largest producer, was unwilling to go up by more than 5 percent for 1977. It was joined by the United Arab Emirates. The 11 other OPEC members insisted on a 10.3 percent rise for the first half of 1977 and provided for an automatic further percent increase for the second half.

title: Diane McCabe Married To Dannell T. Maguire
description: In St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church here yesterday afternoon, Diane Michele McCabe, an investment officer with the trust and investment division of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, was married to Dannell Thomas Maguire, who is with the government bond department at Morgan Guaranty. The Rev. William J. Downes performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Trail of the Front Row Kid
description: Every year at Halloween my class at the Graeme Stewart Elementary School in Chicago had its picture taken in costume. Every year but one (in which I was, for reasons best known to an earlier and less scrutable self, dressed as an elephant), I appeared in that annual class picture clad as a cowboy.

title: New Year Reckonings
description: We rioted a frontpage advisory from Internal Revenue the other day that we must recalculate our life's worth this New Year's to protect our heirs against the latest tax reform. We then racked up the champagne with which to celebrate the anticipated paper profits, when along came two of our favorite historians with the most jarring holiday message in memory. Grow up and sober up, they said, you're 201 now.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Iconclude two things about George C. Scott: (1) He likes to work, and (2) he likes to be kept entertained while working. To satisfy the first thirst, he has agreed to roar, swagger, and contentedly smirk his way through two parts in Sly Fox, doing swan dives into canopied beds as the trickster who pretends to be dying in order bilk his equally mercenary friends out of their wives and fortunes (yes, playwrightgagman Larry Gelbart is fiddling around with Ben Jonson's Volpone), and riding herd on an unruly courtroom as a judge with a passion for throwing the book at people (he does throw it at one poor culprit, and big fat volume it is). To satisfy the second craving, he bas surrounded himself with a small menagerie of character comedians who might as well have their Tonys mailed to them right now and who undoubtedly would keep Mr. Scott in stitches if he weren't so infernally busy that he's left with little time to look at them. Maybe he got his kicks watching them. mug during rehearsals.

title: Fashion

title: DANCE VIEW

The occasion was prOvided byAmerican Ballet Theater and Mikhail Baryshnikov, whose production of The Nutcracker was having its world premiere. There are three fullevening Tchaikovsky ballets in the dance repertory'Swan Lake, The Sleeping Beauty and The Nutcracker. Now, Ballet Theater has all three. It also has Giselle and Coppelia, to say nothing of a version of La Fille Mal Gardee, Raymonda and, a very respectable La Sylphide. The pattern of Ballet Theater is distinctly changing.

title: Preventing Cold Weather Roof Leaks

title: The American cocoon in the Sinai
description: SINAI PENINSULA. Along a ribbon of road that bisects this awesome desert, a solitary Bedouin flags down lone car. He smiles warmly, displaying a gold incisor that glints fiercely in the raging morning sun. A hitchhiker? No. He reaches into the folds of his robe, pulls out a cigarette and pops it into his mouth at the jaunty angle favored by F.D.R., only the nomad has no jutting holder. He mimes a striking motion. He wants a match. Cigarette lighted, he smiles again and resumes sitting at the roadside in the middle of nowhere, staring at the endless expanse of sand. He is visible for a long time in the rearview mirror as our car moves south past desert people and their camels moving over ancient routes. Out here, camels, those bricabrac comic assemblages of creation's leftover parts, look noble  their humped backs and curving necks mirroring the rise and slope of distant barren hills.

title: 1977: The Charter Revolution Is at Hand
description: A revolution in air travel is at hand. Its effect will be to change the way millions of Americans take their vacations. Many executives of airlines, hotels and the companies that package tours now foresee the day when virtually all vacation travel by airboth within the United States and to foreign destinationswill be by cutrate charter rather than scheduled flights. These charters are expected to open up whole new worlds for the average American in this era of increasing leisure time, but there are pitfalls to be avoidedsnags and snarls that could ruin an eagerly awaited vacation. (A list of suggestions to guard against them is presented later in this article.) A year ago the Federal Government began a progressive easing of the regulations governing charter flights, making them increasingly available to the general public. Since then charters have proliferated. In the year just ended, according to airline industry estimates, about half the travelers from the East Coast to Las Vegas and more than 30 percent to Hawaii went by charter. Of the 10 million or so transAtlantic air passengers last year, 26.5 percent were on charters, and the proportion is expected to climb sharply this year because of new regulations that allow further reductions in price.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The Samuel Webb Junior High School in Weth ersfield, Conn., made a dreadful mistake. asked Washington officials about the legality of its boys choir. The Department of Health, Education and Welfare consulted Reg. 45CFR, Part 86, Sec. 901, Title XI of the Higher Education Act and made a ruling. A boys choir was clearly illegal without girls. Discrimination you know. So Samuel Webb was faced with two choices: disband the choir (thus losing $70,000 grant from HEW) or put girls into the chorus. Samuel Webb bit the bullet. There now are girls in the boys choir.

title: 30.000 Observe First Ni4ht on Boston Common
description: BOSTON, Jan. 1Tens of thousands of people gathered on the Boston Common at the stroke of midnight last night to welcome in the new year with candles, fireworks, painted faces, costumes and artworks set amid the snow.

title: The Portfolio of Felix G. Rohatyn
description: It's tax time again. Not yet the paying part, of course, but the part where it's all been earned and the totting up begins. And it's a landmark year, for the rich especially.

title: Frank A. Hostage, 71, Operated Paramount Travel Service Till 74
description: Frank A. Hostage of the Transland Travel Bureau in Hartsdale, N.Y., died Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 7 Peter Cooper Road.

title: Rosemary D. Potz Becomes Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernhardt A. Potz of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosemarie Dorothy Potz, to Michael Edward McGerr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald C. McGerr of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Roland Hayes, 89, Concert Tenor, Son of a Former Slave, Is Dead
description: BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP)Roland Hayes, the son of a Georgia slave who became an internationally acclaimed concert tenor, died yesterday. He was 89 years old.

title: DINING OUT
description: THIS reviewer could easily devote every week of the next 50 exclusively to northern Italian restaurants without exhausting the possibilities afforded by this immensely popular species. By local definition, northern Italian signifies restaurants of some elegance that go lightly on the marinara, serve fettuccine, tortellini and scampi and do not feature meatball or pizza. More of Italy must be northern than meets the eye.

title: RICHARD SEES SMITII ON RHODESIAN ISSUE
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 1Ivor Richard of Britain, chairman of the Geneve, conference on the future of Rhodesia, met for two hours today with Prima Minister Ian D. Smith, emerging with statement suggesting that they made little progress toward a formula for transferring power to the black majority.

title: Akron's Nanchoff Brothers Achieve a Rare Distinction
description: For the first time in nearly 30 years of formal allAmerica selections by the National Soccer Coaches Association, two brothers have been named to the first team in the same ,year. They are George and Louie Nanchoff, both forwards from the University of Akron. George, who was a firstteam selection last year as well, is a senior and Louie is a sophomore. They have been the whole offense for Akron the last two years, Klaas de Boer, the coach of Cleveland State, said about the Nanchoff brothers. Last year they set each other up very well and scored a lot of goals, de Boer said. This year George set up Louie more, he said.

title: $1 Billion in Food Fish Taken By United States Vessels in 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI)Commercial fishermen made their biggest landingsin .a decade, including a record $1 billion morth of food fish in 1976, accord ing tothe Commerce Department. It estimated the catch at 5.2 billion pounds, percenthigher than last year's and the bismest.since 1966.

title: Peneuins 6, Sabres 3
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 1 (AP)  Greg Balone scored two goals and Jean Pronovost added one and set up two more as the Pittsburgh Penguins snapped ninegame Buffalo winning streak with a 63 victory over the Sabres tonight.

title: 1977:The Rubens Year in Antwerp
description: With a gracious sweep of its right hand, the huge statue of the Flemish artist Peter Paul Rubensruling Antwerp's central square, Groenplaatsannounces proudly, Welcome. This is my city. Nearby, deep in the labyrinth of the 16thcentury Town Hall, the Coordination Committee of International Rubens Year 1977 concedes the point, planning festivities for the most ambitious birthday party ever given a single artist, marking Rubens's 400th year. The observances will include the largest exhibition of Rubens paintings ever assembled, daily sound and light drama and dance.

description: 3 envelopes dry powdered yeast

title: Lebanon Cabinet Announces Plan To Impose Censorship of the Press
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 1The Governtalent decided today to impose censorship on the press under a decree adoptd by the Cabinet at a fivehour meeting headed by President Elias Sarkis. The censorship will be applied by a special section of the Police Department.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONA law has just gone into eftect that is intended to cope with one of the major issues facing modern societyhow to assure the safety of all the myriad substances generated by industry that flow into the human environment.

title: An Expert Insists Nuclear Power Is Here to Stay
description: PUBLIC SERVICE'S proposed nuclearpower plant orr tne New Jersey coast will lead to another round of discussions about nuclear power in general. That will actually be unnecessary. Americans have already decided to go nudear Although our dialogue may sometimes be confusing, our deeds give clear evidence that nuclear power is going to stay and grow.

title: ITALY SEEKS TO EASE SHORTAGE OF HOUSING
description: ROME, Jan. 1The Italian Government is pushing through a measure to try to increase the number of housing units by increasing rents.

title: Leafs 3, Capitals 1
description: TORONTO, Jan. 1 (AP)Darryl Siltler set up goals by his linemates, Errol

title: The View Since Black Tuesday
description: Once upon a time, before the onrushing change of recent years, the New York Stock Exchange was unquestionably the world's premiere arena for trading securities, the pride and joy of the American capitalist system.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: The ABC's of a Game For Bored Motorists

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The American Numismatic Society (A.N.S.) is considered No. 1 by collectors pursuing scholarship, the same rating given to the American Numismatic Association (A.N.A.) by collectors interested in seeking fellowship. It's not that the A.N.S. (headquartered in upper Manhattan) is pompous while the A.N.A. (headquartered in Colorado Springs, Colo.) is frivolous; it's more a matter of emphasis. Collectors had a chance to observe the A.N.A. in action at its huge and hectic 85th annual convention in the Americana Hotel here last August.

title: If You Go . .
description: . . . to Antwerp, for Rubens Year, remember that trains run between Brussels and Antwerp (both directions) every half hour. The round trip cost is about $4. Aside from the sites linked with Rubens, the city has several other places well worth a visit. One is the Antwerp Zoo. one of the world's finest and largest, with 6,700 animals of some 1,270 species. Clean and welltended. Another is Middelheim Park (Middelheim 61) on the southern outskirts of Antwerp, an openair sculpture museum with a rich modern collection. It contains works by every important sculptor from Rodin to the present (open daily 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.). The diamond merchant section of Antwerp is along Pilikaanstraat, near the Central Railway Station. The permanent exhibition , Antwerp World Diamond Center, at Jezusstraat 28.30, is open. Mondays through Fridays from 10 to p and on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays from 10 to 6. It shows the diamondmaking process from extraction to gem. The showrooms of the .Antwerp Diamond Industry, at Hoveniersstraat 1620, 40 and 53, is open weekdays 1011:30 A.M. and 24 P.M., but entrance is permitted only on introduction by the City Tourist Office.

title: Headliners
description: Yunich in Surprise: He Quits

title: Heal the Physician
description: MEDICAL care in New Jersey is suffering from an economic cancer that is threatening to kill the physician as well as the patient. Healthcare delivery is endangered by the liability crisis that now exists in the state.

title: Upset in Eastern Juniors
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1Jeff Tupper, an unseeded player from Huntington, toppled sixthseeded Tim Downey of Greenwich, Conn., 63, 63, and moved into the boys 18 final of the Eastern indoor junior tennis championships at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today.

title: Michigan Falls, 146
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1The University of Southern California had the quarterback, Vince Evans, who could do everything today, and Michigan did not. That was the difference in the 63d Rose Bowl game, won by the Trojans, 146, before the largest football crowd of the season, 106,182.

title: Dantley Star As Braves Topple Nets
description: BUFFALO, Jan, 1 (AP)  Adrian Dantley scored 23 of his 30 points in the second half, pacing the Buffalo Braves to a 10287 victory over the New York Nets tonight in a National Basketball Asspciation game.

title: Future Events
description: Not a Pig in a Poke

title: Ship Out of New York Celebrates St. Eustatius Bicentennial Event
description: The last Bicentennial observance by the port's maritime industry took place on Friday some 1,600 miles southeast of New York at the tiny Netherlands Antilles island of St. Eustatius. St. Eustatius. eight sauare miles in

title: Blues 3, North Stars 1
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1 (AP)Claude Larose and Ted Irvine scored goals in the first 3 minutes and paced the St. Louis Blues to a 31 victory over the Minnesota North Stars, tonight.

title: Princeton Puts Lasers to Use
description: PRINCETON LASERS. In the 16 years since they were first developed, scientists have focused them on the detection of air pollution, the transmission of telephone calls and the guidance of the Army's socalled sn.art bombs.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE exceptionally cold weather that Long Island residents have been experiencing during the last two months has made many homeowners more than ever aware of how fast heating fuel is being consumed this year. This, combined with recent announcements from the Middle East that indicate that still higher prices are in the offing for the near future, should cause homeowners to pay increasing attention to methods to cut down heating costs.

title: Tabula Rasa at $3.95 and Up
description: A lot of folks are making a big deal out of, well, nothing.

title: Supporting the Government Difficult While Representing Workers
description: LONDONThe relations between Britain's powerful labor unions and Prime Minister James Callaghan's Labor Party Government can be described as follows: It is not so much a matter of keeping up with the Joneses as it is of keeping up with Jack Jones, the country's most influential union leader.

title: ART VIEW
description: Everyone who follows the current art scene knows that there is a great deal of representational painting being done these days, that larger and larger numbers of young artists are electing to work in one or another figurative tradition, and that tradition itself has ceased to be the bugbear it was in the days when every ambitious art student (it seemed) dreamed of making it big as a sensational new votary of the avantgarde. The very notion of an avantgarde is now suspect, if only because the term seems to belong more to the realm of commerce than to esthetics, and young artists are no longer shy about openly defying the oncesacred injunctions of modernist theory.

title: Margaret Rose Golieb Engaged to Jay Axelrod
description: Margaret Rose Golieb and Jay G. Axelrod, candidates for J.D. degrees at dig National Law Center of George Washington University, plan to be martied in August.

title: Bruce Silberman, Accountant, Is Fiance of Pamela Goldman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Julius Goldman of Charlotte, N. C., formerly of New Milford, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Goldman, to Bruce Irwin Silberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Silberman of Statesville, N. C. A wedding in early March is planned.

title: TV VIEW
description: Sitting in the front seat of his patrol car, the policeman muses about reporters and television crews who regularly rush through his precinct in search of a feature story that can be labeled a day in the life of a cop. He sums up the usual end result with an obscenity. This particular policeman is part of a documentary that can seen tomorrow on Channel 13 at 10 P.M. The Police Tapes was made over three monthsin April, May and June 1976 in a 1.2squaremile area of the South Bronx that has the highest crime rate in New York City. The 90minute program, edited from about 40 hours of videotape, provides a valuable perspective on the state of both video technology and television journalism. The makers of The Police Tapes are Alan and Susan Raymond, filmmakers who, as they put it, recently have gravitated toward video for a further extension of our special approach to cinema verite. The Raymonds are perhaps best knoWn for their filming of public television's An American Family. Their newest project turned out to be the most difficult documentary we have made. Among the reasons they cite: mastering a special lightsensitive camera; gaining the trust of the policemen, a highly guarded group of distrustful men; and the emotional effect it had on us after being exposed to the raw or darker side of human nature.

title: Events in Michigan Revive Concern Over Effect of PBB in Mothers Milk
description: DETROIT, Jan.1On Aug. 26, the Michigan Department of Public Health sent to the state's physicians a twopage advisory, with a disturbing message: A highly toxic chemical called polybrominated biphenyl had found its way into the state's general food supply in sufficient quantities for it to appear in the milk of mothers who were breastfeeding their babies.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: The State of New Jersey has unwittingly provided a textbook example of why Presidentelect Jimmy Carter and the Republican Administrations before him have felt that the Federal Government has grown too large and unwieldly.

title: The Joy of Handel on Disks
description: There is something irresistibly joyous about the music of George Frederick Handel. Partly it's the Messiah connection. But in general Handel's works have a sturdy, allembracing generosity of spirit that sounds sunnier than almost any musician you can mention.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 2, 1977

title: Criminals At Large
description: First novels: they are always opened with a sense of anticipation. Can the author write? Can he organize? Is a new Macdonald or Stout on the way? Sometimes it is not hard to guess. Talent is immediately apparentand so is lack of talent. Some new authors, inexperienced though they may be, are natural storytellers. Or they use the English language in a precise fashion, avoiding clichs. Or they have good ideas. The converse is also immediately apparent. For some new writers there can be no hope at all.

title: Conflicts Between Church and State Sharper Now Than Ever
description: RIO DE JANEIRODuring the four centuries following the arrival of Spanish and Portuguese conquistadores in the New World, the Roman Catholic church was considered part of the traditional ruling triumvirate that also included the military and wealthy landowners.

title: State Removing ManMade Structures, Including Fire Towers, From Adirondack Park Wilderness
description: ALBANY, Dec. 29 The State Department of Environmental Conservation is removing all manmade structures from the wilderness areas of the Adirondack Park in an effort to restore them to what they were before man first set foot there.

title: ART
description: Do you fear old age when the body atrophies into a puckered, sere travesty of its former vital self? Do you dread physical deformity of a kind that plunders the flesh, leaving only a gruesome distortion of bones, dislocated features in a state of total helplessness? Do you cringe at the thought of losing your mental faculties and turning into a tormented vegetable?

title: Coleman Suggests Cutting Rail Passenger Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1A toppriorityundertaking for the next administration should be a conclusive study of the Government's subsidies of rail passenger travel, Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. says.

title: Women's Net Tour Opening Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI)Chris Evert, who passed the $1million career earnings mark last year, is the topseeded player for next week's $100,000 Virginia Slims of Washington, the opening stop on the 1977 women's tennis tour.

title: Teachers Salaries Rank High
description: TEACHERS salaries in the state rank in the top quarter of such salaries across the country, according to a survey just released by the New Jersey Education Association. The association represents the teachers in contract negotiations.

title: Concert: Versatile Carol Neblett
description: Carol Neblett decorated the New York Philharmonic's New Year's Eve concert at Avery Fisher Hall with bouquets of vocal works by Viennese composers. This was a special nonsubscription event led by Andre Kostelanetz, and the conductor's theme for it was New Year's Eve in Vienna.

title: An Uneasy Policy
description: Oddly, Presidentelect Carter's promise for a strong energy policywhich we surely needmay be our next Vietnam. As the war in southeast Asia escalated, its annual costs were on the order of a roughly estimated $25 billion. For years, while the war was not going well in Southeast Asia, it fared much better in Washington. Time and again it won, hands down, the contest for additional appropriations, leaving shortchanged scores of domestic programs. It became one reason many Great Society reforms did not take off.

title: EGYPT EXPECTING CARTER TO MEET SADAT IN SPRING; CAIRO, Jan. 1 (UPI)Jimmy Carter will have his first meeting with President Anwar elSadat next spring in West Germany, the magazine Rose El Youssef said in an edition scheduled for publication tomorrow.
description: The magazine quoted informed circles in Bonn for its report and said Egyptian officials refused to confirm or deny it.

title: Joyce Gorman Engaged To W. N. Fitzpatrick Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter 3. Gorman of Baltimore, formerly of Armonk, N.Y.. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joyce Johanna Gorman, to William Norwood Fitzpatrick Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Fitzpatrick, also of Baltimore.

title: Hollywood Is Having an Affair With the AntiHero
description: Wen King Kong, searching for his tiny morsel of comfort, upends an elevated train, fishes out a blonde, sees that she isn't the .right one, and throws her awayfatallythe audience laughs and applauds. When he bats down a helicopter they cheer. When he dies they groan. The movie is unreservedly proape.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: FOR years, I've wanted to live up to New Jersey's nickname. One of these days. I'll make it. What's holding me back is the state of my garden.

title: Ice, Frigid Winds Delay Start of Frostbite Regatta
description: When Peter Dobson wakes up this morning, he undoubtedly will head for the waterfront. But chances are he'll find more of the same ice and frigid winds that caused the first day of the annual Manhasset Bay Frost

title: FILM VIEW
description: Talk to any producer long enough and he'll eventually tell you that nobody ever sets out to make a bad film. Which means that no producer ever sets out to lose money. In HollyWood, good films are the ones that make money and lousy films are the ones that flop at the box office. The terms good and bad have nothing to do with artistic expression and everything to do with economics, which is why film producers are genuinely, sincerely puzzled by whatever it is that critics think that critics should do. Who needs critics when there are plenty certified public, accountants around? Theirs is the only criticism that means anything.

title: Hamming It Up on TV
description: PLAINVIEW LATER this month, when the Long Island Mobile Amateur Radio Club unveils the first amateur television repeater in the New York area, hams on the island will add a visual dimension to their hobby.

title: W. J. Clark Jr. to Wed Kimberly McAlpine
description: Kimberly L. McAlpine and William J. Clark Jr., graduates of the University of Denver, plan to be married in September.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: Liberian Ships And Oil Spills
description: For the second time in two weeks, Liberian tanker has accidentally dumped oil in American waters, raising anew the long controversial issue of ships that fly foreign flags of convenience and do not meet United States standards.

title: Red Bank Says Yes to a School
description: A SMALL miracle occurred in Red Bank on Nov. 30. A referendum enabling the Board of Education to spend $1.5 million to remodel an unused school into a modern, middleschool facility was passed by a vote of more than two to one.

title: Article 4  No Title
Mary Ann Brennan Sets April Wedding
description: Mary Ann Brennan and Winthrop Holbrook Newcomb, who are with the First National Bank of Boston, will be married in April. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Brennan of Winchester, Mass. Mr. Newcomb is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Newcomb of Andover, Mass.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: The nation's financial and commodity markets have just completed another banner year on an upbeat note and with optimism high in Wall Street that 1977 will prove to be another good, if not vintage, period. While there is, of course, some dissent on the outlook for the markets, the prevailing view is that the economic fundamentals and political scene are both favorable enough to augur better days ahead for the stock and bond Marketsand perhaps even for the highly volatile foreignexchange markets. Commodities, too, seem headed for another active year in a lessinflationary environment

title: GARDENING
description: THOUGH they may survive, plants not suited to their planting site are often attacked by insects and diseases that are normally warded off by healthy, thriving plants. A wet site, obviously, calls for plants that will tolerate moisture, while a dry site demands plants with minimal moisture requirements.

title: Picture Credits
description: IROGER B. SMITH

title: Yonkers Racing
description: RESULTS

title: The road from Rome
description: Some of us who have remained both Roman Catholic and liberal during the past 30 years have occasionally sustained our faith and hope with the exaggerated fantasy that there were really two Catholic churches: theirs and ours. Theirs was institutional and Roman, founded by Pope Pius IX at Vatican I in 1871, and now controlled and largely populated by clod, dering monsignors who expended their emotional and intellectual energies thinking up new titleslike Mediatrix of All Gracesfor the Blessed Virgin Mary and writing Latin condemnations of sex, Communism and liturgical experimentation. The Pope of their church thought he had to be infallible and, trapped in some misunderstanding of its natural law theological tradition, had to publish Humane Vitae, the encyclical against birth control, in 1968. .

title: SHOP TALK
description: OUR a shopping mall and read the signs on the windows: The Purple Tree, The Mustard Seed, Sugar Plum, Butternut... Chances are the name has nothing to do with the merchandise. The signs are like riddles: Guess what's inside.

title: ART
description: TWO painters, Christine Jordan and Bruce Rigby, who are the subject of an exhibition at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton, are eminent proof that artists do not win exposure in discriminating museums without having already made a worthy mark. Although both are relatively young, these two artists have been busy at their esthetic enterprises for several years, developing their sensibilities and visions, and both have had to work their way up through the ranks.

title: Old Man Released From Noisy Jail
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP)A 101yearold man jailed on a bootlegging conviction was released today after complaining that noisy youths in the lockup gave him no peace. Johnny White, who says the key to his long life iswomen and drinking, went home with a minister in this northwest Florida community after a county judge ordered his release after three nights in jail.

title: Promissory Note
description: Presidentelect Carter has given Mayor Beame and, indirectly, New York City's present and future creditors, a declaration of intention that is opposite to the position taken by the Ford Administration: He will not permit a New York bankruptcy, Mr. Carter declared last week, and he will make certain the city can borrow what it needs in the future.

title: Phyllis Gangel Bride Of Bernard E. Jacob
description: Phyllis Rosner Gangel and Bernard E. Jacob, both lawyers, were married at noon yesterday at the bride's home in Manhattan by Acting Justice Budd G. Goodman of the State Supreme Court.

title: A Widow Responds
description: IDID NOT presume to speak for all widows and widowers, I spoke out of my own experience. spoke from my vantage point of a long and remarkable marriage. I know there are other widowed persons who enjoyed a close and envied relationship. I have received many letters from widowed persons. I seem to have echoed their feelings.

title: Flyers 7, Barons 2
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 1 (AP)Rick MacLeish and Gary Dornhoefer each scored a pair of goals to propel the Philadelphia Flyers to a 72 victory over the Cleveland Barons tonight, extending their unbeaten string to 20 games.

title: CANADA ESTABLISHES WIDER FISHING ZONE
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 1Foreign fishing Tap. sets except those of the United States and France now need licenses to operate within 200 miles of the Canadian coast:

title: A Gamble to Bail Out the City
description: The City, and State of New York have been tapping the gambling public for millions of dollars annually with off track betting and various lotteries. But these methods only scratch the surface (no pun intended) of the vast pool of funds available from gambling.

title: Country Monarch Wins
description: BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP)Country Monarch took over at the head of the stretch and easily won today's $10,000 New Year's Day Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

title: Argentina's Terror: Army Is Ahead
description: BUENOS AIRESTerrorism of the left and right, by guerrillas, the Government and Governmentsanctioned death squads, has afflicted Argentina for years. Under the ninemonthold military junta, however, the balance terror has tilted heavily in favor of the Government, which is pressing a ruthless campaign against leftwing activists.

title: After Paying a Price for Their Views, Some Radical Professors Are Back at Their Jobs: Others Have Better Ones
description: The 1960's and early 1970's spawned an activist student generation with concerns dramatically raised from innocent levels, such as dormitory visiting hours and parkinglot privileges, to issues of war and peace and social justice in the community and the world. Also spawned, or at least made more visible, was a sizable body of radical professors and graduate students, many of whom helped energize student activism, intellectually and sometimes by personal leadership. Many paid severely for their involvements, some even losing their jobs. But for most, this is a better day.

title: Jean Lahey Plans Bridal To David S. Johnson Jr.
description: Jean Ellen Lahey of New York and David Starr Johnson Jr., manager of field operations in New York for Avon Products, plan to be married Feb. 26 in New York.

title: Abduction Suspects In SchOol Bus Case Cited in Jail Fight
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 1The three suspects in the Chowchilla school bus kidnapping became embroiled in a jail disturbance here, allegedly led by William Harris of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army, jail officials say.

title: SADOWSKY MOVING UP IN COUNCIL HIERARCHY
description: In the aftermath of recent resignations and changes in committee chairmanships, Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky, Democrat of Queens, has emerged as second in the power hierarchy of the New York City Council and the heir apparent to the post of majority leader, according to Council sources.

title: Three Men From Eastern Europe Who Helped Transform the Goals of the American Labor Movement
description: Alex Rose was one of those who came out of the ghettos of Poland and Lithuania in the early years of the century and worked in the sweatshops of New York and Chicago. They were graduates of the soapbox, forging a politically oriented labor movement in the needle trades.

title: PUERTO RICO'S STATUS REVIVED AS AN ISSUE
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 1On the eve of the inauguration of a new prostatehood Government in Puerto Rico, President Ford's surprise proposal that this island commonwealth become the 51st state was being widely regarded here as a wellmeaning but perhaps misinformed gesture that could prove politically embarrassing for the new Governor.

title: Nat'l Hockey League

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I have a brick fireplace which smokes slightly when the kindling first ignited. After three to five minutes this stops. I keep the damper fully open and it is unobstructed as far as I can tell. Do you know how I can improve the draw? Will glass doors help?S.L.A., Newark, Del.

title: 200 Fight Peekskill Fire
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Jan. 1Eleven fire companies, some from as far south as Tarrytown, joined in fighting a general alarm fire here today that destroyed small branch of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Hospital, a furniture store and three homes. A garage was damaged.

title: Laura S. Forgeron Plans To Wed John C. Warren
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry V. Forgeron of Baldwin, LI, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Susan Forgeron, to Jahn C. Warren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Warren of Charlotte, N.C.

title: Pitfalls and Pratfalls

title: H. A. Martuscello Fiance Of Kathleen C. Kennedy
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Kennedy of Dumont, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen C. Kennedy, to Henry Anthony Martuscello, son of Associate Justice M. Henry Maruscello of the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division and Mrs. Martuscello.

title: Billy Graham at Mayo Clinic
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., Jan. 1 (UPI)The Rev. Billy Graham, 58 yeirs old, was flown to the Mayo Clinic for observation last night from Urbana, Ill., where he complained of pains in the left leg while attending a meeting of college students. spokesman for the Intervarsity Missionary Convention said that a doctor had exe amined him at Urbana and that tests had been administered at a hospital, with tentative diagnosis of phlebitis. It was decided he would enter the clinic for a thorough checkup.

title: MILDRED LEE WATTS, 67, OF THE LEES OF VIRGINIA
description: Mildred Lee Watts, a direct descendant of the Lees of Virginia and the Carrolls of Maryland and for many years head of volunteers at the Washington Hospital Center, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Baltimore after a long illness stemming from advanced arthritis. She was 67 years old and lived in Washington at 1513 28th Street, N. W.

title: Night Skiing Becomes Good Business in the Berkshires
description: NEW ASHFORD, Mass., Jan. 1It used to be that skiing was strictly daytime sport. Diehard enthusiasts would arrive at a winter resort in time to get on the milk run (when the lifts start operating in the morning) and

title: YOSHIMURA LETTER TELLS TRIAL OF RIFT
description: OAKLAND, Calif, Jan. 1A letter describing the demise of an underground group just before the arrest of Wendy., Yoshimura and Patricia Hearst was among the last pieces of evidence presented this week by the prosecution as it completed its case in Miss Yoshimura's trial.

title: 4 Freeze to Death in St. Louis Area
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1 (AP)  Four men were found frozen to death in the St. Louis area as temperatures fell to 10 below zero yesterday. A fifth man was in critical condition, suffering from exposure, as the area recorded its coldest day since Jan. 23, 1963, when the mercury fell to 11 below.

title: An Aide Tells How Westchester County Got Federal Funds
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 1The Amtrak express that was carrying John J. McLaughlin to Philadelphia on Dec. 3 came to a halt between stations south of Rye and he tried to get off so he could take a taxi to La Guardia Airport and get a plane. But the trainman refused to let him disembark.

title: Article 1  No Title
Sale of New York Magazine Stock To  Murdoch Stayed by U.S. Judge
description: Clay S. title: Berggasse 19
description: In June of 1938, a few days before the Freud family was to leave Vienna for London, August Aichhorn, an intimate of Freud asked a young photographer friend, Edmund Engelman, to take pictures of Freud's place of residence so that there would be a visual record of the surroundings in which psychoanalysis came into being. The plan was that the photographs should be taken without Freud's knowledge, sc as not to further disturb the old, gravely ill man at a moment when he was deeply worried about the Nakis harassment of himself and his daughter and their impending departure. But by chance Freud encountered Engelman while he was taking the pictures and agreed to sit for some portraits that

The suit could have significant implications for the state, and it could determine whether the Legislature can require local governments to hold down public spending and whether the recently enacted state income tax is to remain in force.

title: What's Doing in the LAURENTIANS
description: SKIING FRENCHThe Laurentians, Nat across the border in French Canada, are the world's oldest, mountains, but they offer the American winter sports enthuaiast something new  skiing with a French accent. To hear Canadians tell it, no one skied the Laurentians for millions of years until tha 1920's, when winter resorts were established in the area. Today millions of skiers are flocking to the slopes to make up for that lost time., Situated an hour north of Montreal via superhighway, or roughly 400 miles from New York, the Laurentians become one big international ski festival for five months of the year, from December to the end of April, when snow blankets the slopes and resort operators (albeit with snowmaking machines in the wings) give barely a  passing thought to early thaw. The Laurentian ski country actually begins about 40 miles north of Montreal at the town of SaintSauveur and extends north for another 40 miles to SaintDonat, encompassing towns with such names as Ste. AgathedesMonts, Val Morin and St. Jovite. There are no fewer than 150 resotts in a 35mile radius (some with lighting for night skiing), and the ambience is strictly French, with the emphasis on haute cuisine, smatt boutiques and joie de vivre. Even if one does not ski, there are mike of crosscountry trails for snowshoeing, scores of ponds for ice skating, backcountry roads without end for quiet rides on horsedrawn sleighsand plenty of

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to the Thames Valley you'll find that it has had plenty of rain since last summer's drought. The grass is green again and the river is high. Here are some pubs, inns and eating places in villages and towns within a 20mile radius of South Stoke and some information about local events. Among recommended inns is Ye Olde Leatherne Bottel, near Goring. The Bottel's title is not coyparts of this inn are almost 500 years old. It has an excellent river front and, at this writing (The Bottel may be changing hands), the best food in Oxfordshire. It is relatively smallonly four double rooms and two singles but has a fine diningroom, diesel and refueling pumps for boats and a lively crowd of patrons who pubcrawl up the river on summer nights. Rates for the double rooms are about $13 a night. Dinner costs about $5 a person. The 18room Beetle and Wedge in Moulsford has gardens sloping down to the river, moorings for boats, and an impressive history as the occasional setting for H. G. Wells's The History of Mr. Polly and as Bernard Shaw's favorite spot for river bathing. Looks across the river to South Stoke. Has fishing rights. A double room goes for about $19; dinners are about $6. Also attractive are The George and The White Hart in Dorchester; The George, Pangbourne; The Miller of Mansfield,

title: Reporter Who Refused to Disclose His Source Faces Questions Anew
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 (UPI)William T. Farr, a reporter who served 46 days in jail for refusing to disclose where he got information for an article he wrote about the 1970 trial of Charles M. Manson, has been ordered again to answer questions about his source.

title: Tilting Against Oil Drills
description: IN 1973, the Suffolk County Legislature authorized County Executive John V. N. Klein to join with Nassau County officials in litigation to block petroleum and naturalgas drilling in the Atlantic Ocean off the Island. That authorization represented a philosophical statement of opposition, on behalf of Suffolk's 1.3 million residents, to oil drilling in Suffolk's oceanic backyard, and it generated lawsuit that is still pending in the courts.

title: Big Sports Day in Britain Spoiled by Bad Weather
description: LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters)Britain's big newyear sports day was spoiled today as snow, frost, ice and heavy rain forced the cancellation of soccer, rugby and racing events.

The plant that thrives in seaside garden on Cape Cod will not always be its best in the northern hills of New Jersey. Everywhere, soils differ, climates have wide temperature ranges and regional planting customs vary.

title: They Hope To Heat Up Shaw's `Caesar

Rex Harrison, as the graying Caesar, believing himself alone in the desert, addresses at length the Sphinximprovised out of three straightbacked chairsuntil he is interrupted by Elizabeth Ashley, as Cleopatra, who is hiding in the statue's stone paws: Old gentleman! Climb up here quickly, or the Romans will come and eat you.

Robinson might have had trouble mastering Leinsdorf's trumpettongued Viennese English, but the rest of the character would have fallen easily into place, particularly the maestro's mercurial moodiness: Suave, witty, gemiitlich and sophisticated, he has charmed multitudes; arrogant and tyrannical when in a snit, others think of him in terms of Little Caesar.

title: Brenda McAdoo Plans a Court Career: She'll Work on Cases, Not Jump Shots

title: John Cullum Will Be Playing It Straight
description: John Cullum doesn't look like a star and he knows it. I've got a big, long nose, he agrees, and hawkish kind of face. He also has yellow, thatchedroof hair and irregular teeth, and he is 46 years old. Nor does he live like a star. He and his wife, dancer Emily Frankel, and his son, 11yearold John David, live in a converted loft at the top of a fourstory walkup lost in a soothued warehouse district. His sunless living room is filled with small pool table, three teeming aquariums, a tall wire cage containing a stunning white pigeon, and a Ihasa apso. (I don't know how it happened, he says. We're not animal people.) Corners of the apartment have been improved as money has been available, but it still looks only halffinished. His current delight is a spanking new trash compactor which saves him daily treks down five flights to dump the garbage. The Tony award he won for Shenandoah is nowhere in sight.

title: Cracking the Hieroglyphic Code Was Only the Beginning of Egyptology
description: The art world is experiencing a sudden growth of interest In ancient Egypt. Museum activity seems chiefly responsible. In October, the Metropolitan Museum of Art opened its new Egyptian galleries to great acclaim. Over the next two years, a total of 23 refurbished galleries will be revealed, culminating in the fall of 11)78 with the arrival at the Met of the Tutankhamun show (now on tour at the National Gallery in Washington), and with the opening of the reconstructed Temple of Dendur, a gift from the people of Egypt in appreciation for the help America gave to save the temples of Abu Simbel. In October, 1077, the Brooklyn Museum will unveil a major show entitled Africa in Antiquity which will include a number of the museum's masterpieces from ancient Egypt.

title: The Business of Radar Evasion

title: World Harvest at 4Year High, but Africa Is Still Big Problem and Progress Against Hunger Is Slow
description: ROME, Jan. 1 (UPI)World food supplies are at their highest level in four years, but agriculture experts warn that the dream of eliminating hunger in less developed countries is far from being realized.

title: CHIPPEWAS GIVEN RIGHTS ON GREAT LAKES FISHING
description: BAY MILLS INDIAN RESERVATION, Mich., Jan. 1Fishing rights in the Great Lakes granted to Chippewa Indians in an 1836 treaty have been upheld by the Michigan Supreme Court.

title: The Gentle Boss
description: He would, of course, object vehemently to the term boss applied to himself. Yet it would be a genial fiction to suggest that the Liberal Party has been a pure democracy. Although the party in its deliberations observes the strictest democratic and legal procedures, one of its membersa softspoken, bespectacled old gentleman named Alex Rosealways seemed somehow to be more equal than everybody else. When the stormy debates had ceased and the angry press releases had been forgotten, the Liberal Party members usually wound up doing what Mr. Rose counseled them to do.

title: JOHN EDWARD MEYER
description: John Edward Meyer, chairman of the Meyer Hotel chain died yesterday at Beautfort Hospital near his home in Green Pond, S.C. He was 58 years old and lived in Green Pond.

title: Carter's Energy Plans May Be a Lot. Like Ford's
description: WASHINGTONEven before he has taken the oath of office, Presidentelect Carter appears to be shaping an energy policy that will resemble President Ford's in several important respects.

title: Erving Back Home To Oppose the Nets
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 1 For the first time since he was sold by the New York Nets to the Philadelphia 76ers in October, Julius Erving will return to Nassau Coliseum tomorrow to play against his former teammates. The game will begin at 1 P.M.

title: Thomas C. Doyle Fianc Of Janet Ritth vom Lehn
description: Janet Ruth vom Lehn, private secre. tary to the Consul General of Japan in New York, and Thomas Charles Doyle, a businessdevelopment representative in New York for Credito Italiano, the Milan bank, plan to be married next June.

title: My Parents
description: It's a wise child, etc., and one wonders with what wisdom James Roosevelt undertook to produce (I use the word produce advisedly) yet another volume in the already voluminous series of books about his celebrated parents whom, by his own admission, he scarcely knew. With what wisdom, and with what tastein view of the fact that the parents are no longer around to defend themselvesdid he convince himself that this was really a good idea? Items: the author goes to great, and to me painful and unnecessary detail describing his father's physical suffering as a result of his bout with poliostruggling, perspiring, in the agony of leg braces, nearly falling, making his way up the aisle to the speaker's platform to nominate Al Smith for President. F.D.R. handled his pain manfully and gracefully, realizing that pain is a private affair. Now the pain is spread

title: 3 Americans Advance in Aussie Open
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 (AP) Charlie Pasarell led three Americans into the second round of the $200,000 Australian open tennis championships today. but Vic Amava was ousted.

title: Espadas Wins in 7th, Keeps Title
description: TOKYO, Jan. 1 (UPI)Duty Espadas of Mexico battered Jim Takada of Japan at will today and retained his Worl pan at will today and retained his World Boxing Association flyweight title with a seventhround knockout in a scheduled 15round fight. The 22yearold champion took control in the third round when he floored Takada with a left hook to the jaw for a mandatory 8 count.

title: Linden Haverneyer Is Fiancee Of David S. Wise, a Law Student
description: The engagement of Linden Havemeyer to David Scott Wise has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Havemeyer of New York and Islip, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Wise of Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Residents Are Divided on Rebuilding of Teton Dam
description: REXBURG, Idaho, Dec. 29A visitor turned to her Idaho friend as they stood at the observation point overlooWng the remains of the Teton Dam, which collapsed in June, killing 11 persons and causing $400 million in property damage.

title: Kings fare
description: Alhough in the United States the New Year's weekend signifies the end of the Christmas season, in Europe and South America festivities continue until Jan. 6, the day known as Twelfth Night, Epiphany or Three Kings Day.

title: Knicks Turn Back Cavaliers, 121110
description: The Knicks mixed the best of Earl Monroe, who made all of his 10 shots from the field, with a dose of scoring power from Bob McAdoo and Torn McMillen last night and overwhelmed the Cleveland Cavaliers, 121110, before another capacity Madison Square Garden crowd of 19,694.

title: Kissinger Legacy
description: WASHINGTONOne of the foreign policy legaciesand difficultiesthat will be inherited by the Carter Administration is the rising cost of maintaining foreign military bases so the United States can project its power around the world. It is a legacy handed down by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, who in his final year in office went on a spending spree in pledging money in return for keeping the bases.

title: Lowa Class Session Taped by Principal;  Student Is Expelled
description: MANNING, Iowa, Jan.1The secret taping of a class by the high school principal has caused a controversy in this western Iowa town of 1,450 people.
