title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market closed 1976 on a bullish note last week, with the Dow Jones industrial average ahead 19.03 points to 1,004.65 at the close Friday.

title: Preservation Hall
description: Virgil and Tracy are a Bloomingdale's market researcher's dream: they are young, successful, sexy, rich and chic. They are also callow and selfindulgent, and they know it. Tracy, secure in memories of a happy childhood, longs to be tested, as though maturity were a matter of getting an A in Real Life. Virgil, though, has already tried real life, and he hated it: as a motherless child sharing the shabby nomadic existence of his avantgarde composer father, Earl, he was frightened and humiliated by Earl's poverty and failure. Virgil clings to his expense account and custommade shirts as though they were talismans warding off a disaster that he is sure will strike nonetheless. And sure enough: on a New. Year's visit to the Maine country house they have named Preservation Hall, Virgil and Tracy

title: POLITICS
description: THE gubernatorial races in both parties should begin to show some signs of life in the next two weeks, what with the expected entries of Paul T. Jordan and Joseph A, Hoffman, Democrats, and Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean, a Republican. What follows in the weeks thereafter could be the biggest list of candidates, both political pro and amateur, that state voters have seen.

title: It Could Always Be Worse
description: Not much space. Not much to say anyway. Just wanted to do justice to the lastbut not the leastof the good books of 76. The plot? About a oneroom but filled with adults, crying, quarrelling children to which are added, on the rabbi's advice, rooster, goose, chickens, cow, goat, which results in honking, crowing, clucking, butting, pushing, tramplingand feathers in the soup. Oh, but look it in Sholom Aleichem. Important here are Margot Zemach's illustrations, which show all the rumpus and ruckus, all the accouterments of Old World peasantry. Life. The colors are stronger, bolder than those the illustrator has done for Duffy and the Devil, The Judge, any of her others. It could always be worse, indeed. But never before has it been done better.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Jan. 4Long Island Triumph Association meeting at Hideaway Inn, Route 107, North Massapequa, L.I. (north of exit 29 from Southern State Parkway). Information: phone Roy (516)7856957 or Hank (516) 8838538.

title: Dr. Norman R. Stoll, 84; ParasiteDisease Expert Taught at Rockefeller U
description: Dr. Norman R. Stoll, a medical researcher and, from 1952 to 1973, a consultant on parasitic disease to the World Health Organization, died Thursday at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived at 256 Snowden Lane in Princeton, N. J.

title: Gov. Grasso's Row With General Assembly Over as New Session Nears
description: HARTFORDFor Gov. Ella T. Grasso, her appearance Wednesday before Connecticut's newly elected General Assembly will be a visit to the scene of some of the unhappier skirmishes she has been through in the two years she has been in office. But this one promises to be a more pleasant encounter.

title: PHILIP HONIG FISHER
description: Philip Honig Fisher, who retired in 1954 as a tax law expert assigned to the Appellate Division of the United States Internal Revenue Service in New York City, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 50E Jefferson Oval, Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

title: `He Runs Like Water
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1He runs like water is how Tony Dorsett is described by Jack Butler of the Blesto scouting firm for several National Football League teams. And today Tony Dorsett of Pitt hurried through Georgia like the Chattahoochee River does. In the 273 victory ha set Sugar Bowl record with 202 yards

title: Pancho Carter Confident Of AutoRacing Stardom
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 (UPI)Lurking in the shadows of such big names as A. J. Foyt, Johnny Rutherford and Gordon Johncock, Pancho. Carter is confident it's a matter of time bef6re he's a superstar, too.

title: BOGUS ADDRESS GIVES SCOFFLAW A SANCTUARY
description: The Transportation Administration's January list of the 10 mostwanted scofflaws includes a man whose registered address, if it existed, would be somewhere between Roosevelt Island and Astoria. Queensin the East River.

title: New Pots For Plants Tend Themselves
description: What will the plant gadgeteers think of next? Now there are selfwatering pots for plants. Indoor greenery will be left to grow on its own. This development could have serious implications for those who like to talk to their plants. For automatic care will just about eliminate those daily rounds and friendly morning chats. One suspects that the new pots were designed by lazy gardeners, or at least by those who are only halfhearted about plant tending.

title: Determined Cashier  Ends Theft Attempt
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. I (UPI) David Leash of St. Louis got more than he bargained for on New Year's Eve from a cashier at a local cafeteria, according to the police.

title: Sharon D. Alperin Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Alperin of Dix Hills, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Dale Alperin, to Stephen Mark Baron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Baron of Boston. The wedding will take place in the spring.

title: U.S. Appellate Court in New York Called Nation's Most Productive
description: Judges of the United States Court of Appeals sitting in New York City were he most productive in the nation during the last fiscal year, Irving It Kaufman, chief judge of that court said in a yearend report released last week,

title: The Red Baron Would Approve
description: FIRST there is a muddy parking lot with huge holes. Then a few old railroad ties beyond which are parked a dozen or two small planes, each tied down by ropes leading to hooks sunk in the ground. Off to the left is a rundown building whose walls are hung with charts and yellowing pictures of early aviators,.and where the smell of motor oil lingers. And off into the horizon leads a narrow strip of grass, mud and, occasionally, patched concrete, flanked by woods, and ending either in more woods or an occasional house.

title: Kerry Reid Triumphs
description: SYDNEY, Jan. 1 (UPI)  Rain postponed the men's final in the $100,000 New South Wales open tennis tournament today. Tony Roche won the first set, 63, from Dick Stockton, but was trailing, 25, in the second when an electrical storm broke.

title: Janet Schramm Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Janet Schramm to Richard Reissman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sid Reissman, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Max Schramm. The couple's parents reside in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Jai Alai Betting Tops $80 Million in Conn.
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 1 (AP)Bettors wagered more than $80.7 million during World Jai Alai's first season in Connecticut, officials said after last night's closing performance. Total attendance for the season, which began last May 20, was 1,369,739, officials added.

title: Whole Hog
description: We have from David Wagoner a wonderful book of poems and another bad novelnot bad, of course, in any serious sense, merely embarrassing: coy, preachy, yukky. It's no crime to write bad novels. We see clodpoles doing it all the time. But it's a pity when a firstrate poet does it. A sentimental, morally simpleminded, linguistically sappy novel like Whole Hog makes us doubt what we'd never have dreamed of doubting otherwise, the authority of the same writer's

title: Here Come the Carradines
description: Tahri Carridine, veteran of Such vintage films as The Grapes of Wrath and Stagecoach, who was seen earlier this season as the tour guide in The Last Tycoon, plays an aged guardian of Hell in The Sentinel, a horror film due here in the spring, top. Meanwhile, two of the character actor's sons are emerging as stars. Keith Carradine, bottom left, woripraise for his roles in Thieves Like Us and Nashville and will soon appear as a jaded composer in Welcome to L.A. David Cariadine, at right, plays Woody Guthrie in Bound for Glory, which recently opened to critical acclairitRObert,Carradine, center, youngest of the clan, will appear in the forthcarnhig films Porn Porn Girls and Joyride.

title: BIPARTISAN HOUSE STUDY OF WELFARE IS PLANNED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP)Anextensive study of how to reform the present welfare system will be undertaken by ten bipartisan members of the House late next month.

title: Humphrey's Last Race
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1Hubert Humphrey's service to his country has been so durable and faithful, his feelings for the poor and afflicted people of the world so sincere, and his spirit so full of bounce and mirth that even those who disagree with his policies hate to see him seek and lose the majority leadership of the Senate.

title: Mayor Apologizes for Intoxication,
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 1 (UPI) Mayor Richard A. King has apologized. about an incident of drunkenness and says it will not happen again. The episode began Wednesday night at a resturant and lounge, Mr. King was Wentified as an intoxicated patron who had been asked to leave and did, only to return and take six customers coats. Mr. King told the police Thursday he did not remember what had happened Yesterday the Mayor went to the office of the Independence Examiner and said, I would like to apologize to everyone directly involved in the incident and to the people of Independence in general.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Berstone Knitting Mills Inc., has purchased the former John Wanamaker warehouse building at 726 Broadway between East Fourth Street and Astor Place from Jack Rapaportt for more than $1.4 million. The company has relocated from 524 Broadway and is occupying one of the seven floors in the 245,000 square foot building. Stephen N. Ifshin and Martin Schwartz of N. Peter Burton & Company and David Berley of Walter & Samuels were the brokers.

title: CHESS
description: fter the interzonal tournament in Biel, Switzerland, two of the participants, Grandmaster Mikhail Tal of i atvia, a foriner world champion, and Grandmaster Boris Gulko of Moscow, went on to Geneva to play an exhibition game. Not only did they give the crowd something to remember in Tal's sacrifice of his queen for a forced mate, but they also used an opening variation that is bound to stir new controversy.

description: Clay S. Felker won a temporary restraining order against a sale of New York Magazine Company stock to Rupert Murdoch, the Australian pub; fisher. Details on page 46.

title: Construction Still Lags in State
description: DESPITE a modest upturn in building activity in 1976both residential and nonresidential employment in New Jersey's severely depressed construction industry was at the lowest level on a monthly basis since 1950.

title: Law Goes Into Effect in California Giving the Terminally Ill the Right to Die by Barring Medical
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 1California today became the first state with a law that establishes medical, ethical and legal standards covering terminally ill patients rights to die.

title: This Year, Fashion Casts Its Vote for Freedom
description: Remember the advertising executive in the salt and pepper beard wearing the peace medallion on his tiedyed Tshirt? The industrialist arriving at the blacktie affair with his dinner jacket buttoned over a white turtleneck? And the insurance broker at the same party with a chest full of blue ruffles?

title: Kim E. Greene Engaged To Francis Sheehan Jr.
description: Kim Elisabeth Greene and Francis E. Sheehan Jr., graduates of Colgate University, class of 74, plan to be married Juhe 25 in West Dennis, Mass., where Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey A. Greene of I archmont, N.Y., parents of the bridetobe, have a summer home.

description: Stephanie Lueders and Daniel Stephen Rich, graduates of Harvard College, class of 73, plan to be married June 19 in Cambridge, Mass.

title: STAMPS
description: Happy New Year, Year of the Snake. It is the year of Jongsa, according to the Oriental zodiac, and renditions of the serpent on stamps from Asian countries provide a philatelic welcome to 1977.

title: 770,000 Women Turned Down in 1975
description: It was in January 1973 that the United States Supreme Court handed down its landmark decision invalidating most state antiabortion statutes. The ruling established the right to abortion, at least in the earlier stages of pregnancy, and it appeared at the time that the abortion issue was settled.

title: All Thumbs? Try Quilting
description: EAST BRUNSWICK QUILTING, which has become increasingly popular in recent years, reached a point of virtual frenzy during this Bicentennial year. From Maine to California, needles have been flying as dedicated volunteers have contributed their talents to commemorative quilts in a rich variety of designs.

title: Nancy Nadel to Wed in June
description: Nancy Sarah Nadel, who is studying for her master's degree in counseling at the University of Miami, will be married in June to Bruce David Frank, an accountant with Eisner and Lubin, certified public accountants in Miami. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Norman A. Nadel of Scarsdale, N. Y. Mr. Frank's parents rale in North Miami,

title: PEOPLE
description: A word of advice for anyone who enrolls in the course in ,contemporary developments in criminal justice next semester at Adelphi University in Garden City: Don't mess around with the teacher. The onesemester course will be taught by Sanford Garelik, who started as a New York City policeman in 1940, became the department's Chief Inspector and now is head of the New York City Transit Police Department.

title: Pravda Assails Western Press
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 1 (Reuters)The Communist Party newspaper Pravda today accused Western journalists writing about the Soviet Union of gathering Philistine gossip and writing base slan ders.

title: Laurel Finale to Favorite; LAUREL, Md., Jan. 1 (AP)Chesapeake Bugeye took the lead on the final turn and drew off to win the $10,000 New Year's Day Purse, the feature race on Laurel Race Course's closingday card today.
description: James Moseley held the favorite off the early pace set by Queen Ribot and Shark's Jaws, relying on his mount's late speed to claim the top prize.

title: Of lines, point spreads and middles
description: For many years, the illegality of betting on people was matched only by its popularity. In its quietly clandestine way, betting on people has become an entertainment bigger than Broadway, bigger than the entire American film industry. It has been estimated by Federal sources that illegal betting on major team sports (football, basketball, baseball) amounts to $29 billion a year or moresome say much more. So much money is now involved that many politicians and overburdened taxpayers are eager to take it over from the bookmakers: three states have already legalized gambling on sports and more, including New York, are thinking about it. The coming week is the zenith of the sportsbetting year. No single day is bigger than Suner Bowl

title: Notes: Outlook For 1977
description: After all the hoopla attendant upon last yea''s Bicentennial celebration, including such extravaganzas as Operation Sail and the Freedom Train, travel industry experts are being cautiously optimistic about the prospects for tourism in the months ahead. What they hope is that 1977 won't go down in history as the year of the big letdown.

title: NotSoModern Times
description: IN the name of humanity and by virtue of the authority delegated to me by August Compte, I pronounce you married, said the officlant at the 1857 ceremony in Modern Times.

title: Design
description: Rekindled interest in the home hearth has led to the rediscovery of such fireplace accessories as the fireback, an iron plate that radiates heat back into the room, and the coal grate, for burning coal in place of wood. Tending the fire also calls for toolstongs, poker, broom that have always been popular in traditional styles. Now, these accessories are also available in sleek, modern designs.

title: Customs Men Increase Seizure Of Narcotics and Drugs by 40%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1United States customs inspectors seized restricted drugs and narcotics in 1976 with an estimated potential value of more than $600 million, nearly 40 percent more than the value of similar seizures in 1975, the Commissioner of Customs, Vernon D. Acree, said yesterday.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE COMPOSITE INDEX of leading Indicators rpsif in November, the Commerce Department re. ported, confirming that the pause in the economy has dna way to renewed expansion. . . . Prices farmers receive for raw products rose 3 percent in the month epded Dec. 15, the Agriculture Department said. Prices for hogs, cattle, corn, soybeans and eggs rose, but prices for milk, wheat and vegetables were lower.

title: The Long Search for Peace
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 1 (UPI)The hands of the chiming clock in Londonderry's Guildhall Square stand at 3:33 P.M.the moment British troops rolled into Northern Ireland on Aug. 14, 1969, to keep the peace between the Roman Catholic and Protestant communities.

title: Motel Fire Kills Nine In Eastern Pennsylvania
description: SHAMOKIN, Pa., Jan. 2 (AP)An early morning fire at a motel here killed nine persons today, including the owner, who was trapped in an elevator, the authorities said. Two persons were injured.

title: Air Force's ExIntelligence Chief Fears Soviet Has Military Edge
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The man who has played a central role in swinging the United States intelligence community toward a more grim estimate of Soviet strategic objectives says he believes that the Soviet Union has already achieved military superiority over this country.

title: Archibald Breaks His Foot, Out 2 Months

title: West End Funeral Chapel Moved
description: The West End Funeral Chapel, formerly at 4511 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, is now at 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. Edward Weinstein, vice president, said yesterday that the chapel had been moved from the other building, where its place has been taken by the Shomrei Hades Chapel, which held services Dec. 21 for three rabbis killed in an automobile accident.

title: Young Expects New Administration to Be Aggressive in Advancing Majority Rule in Southern Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (Reuters)Andrew Young, named by Presidentelect Jimmy Carter as representative to the United Nations, said today that he expected the new United States administration to be more aggressive in helping to advance majority rule in southern Africa.

description: The New York Rangers survived bewildering variety of obstacles last night and still registered a 53 victory over the Vancouver Carmelo at Madison Square Garden.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The United States Treasury has attacked, in terms that sometimes approach the scornful, the argument of some other industrial countries that floating .currencyexchange rates can produce a vicious circle of inflation, declining exchange rates, more inflation and still more exchangerate depreciation.

title: To Our Readers
description: A new schedule for economic commentary takes effect today. The Economic Scene column will be written by Leonard Silk on Monday in addition to Thursday. Thomas E. Mullaney will continue to write the column on Tuesday and Friday, as well as Sunday. The Labor Scene column by A. H. Raskin, which previously appeared on Monday, will appear each Wednesday.

title: Ashe Paces U.S. Advance In Aussie Open
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 (UPI) Arthur Ashe ended a series of disappointing losses with a quick firstround victory in the $216,000 Australian open tennis championships at the Kooyong grass courts today. Ashe, who won the title six years ago, posted a 63, 60, 62 triumph over Peter McNamara of Australia.

title: New Power of Local Boards to Be Put to Test in Queens
description: The power of community boards in New York under the new City Charter will be tested this year in a middleclass world of homeowners and gardenapartment dwellers in eastern Queens, where blacks and whites are trying to prove that integration can work.

title: Briton Strikes a Positive Note After Talks With Ian Smith
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 2Ivor Richard of Britain left here today for South Africa, saying he expected to return in about 10 days to continue his quest for a breakthrough in the deadlocked negotiations over a peaceful transition to majority rule in Rhodesia.

description: KEENE, N.H., Jan. 2 (UPI)  I'm Francis Albert Sinatra, known the world over as the voice of WKBK, 1220 on your dial in Keene, N.H., the garden snot of the universe.

description: Marion Brown, an alto saxophonist from Atlanta who made a name for himself in New York during the 1960's, has been writing music inspired by the prose poetry of Jean Toomer for several years. Mr. Toomer, a black Georgian, celebrated the Southern landscape and recounted the trials of black Southerners.

title: Tennessee Indian Dig Threatened By Flooding With Closing of Dam
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 2They call it the Russian front of archeology. In the morning the ground is frozen solid, but before the day is over it has turned to ankledeep mud. Tons of earth have to be screened with chilling water and often workers have to lie on the ground while painstakingly unearthing a skeleton or artifact.

title: SUFFOLK PARTY CHIEF CALLED CAREY CHOICE FOR STATE CHAIRMAN
description: Governor Carey has settled on Dominic J. Baranello, the Suffolk County Democratic leader, as his choice for Democratic state chairman, persons close to both men reported yesterday.

title: Betty Ford Indicates She Opposes Amnesty
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP)Betty Ford indicated tonight that she does not favor blanket amnesty for Vietnam War draft evaders and deserters, but she said that she had not advised her husband about what to do on the issue.

title: North Takes a Big Lead, Then Stops South, 2120
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP)The North stormed to a threetouchdown leadln the first half today, then held off a late surge by the South for a 2120 victory in the ninth annual Americ4n Bowl before a crowd of 14.207.

title: Thanks to SnowMakers, New England Skiing Booms
description: BOSTON, Jan. 2The Rocky Mountains loss this winter has been New England's gain. While ski slopes in the Western states remainedwell, rockybecause of an unusual drought of snow, New England ski areas were having booming holiday week.

title: C.I.A. Aides Report Security Watch On Staff Is Lax After Clearance
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Security specialists of the Central Intelligence Agency said today that Edwin G. Moore, a former agency employee, had been able to smuggle large amounts of secret materials out of the headquarters building because, once given a security clearance, employees of the agency were seldom subjected to future checks.

title: Two Arrested in Arson at Bronx Club That Killed 25
description: A 40yearold man described as a jealous suitor and a 17yearold friend were arrested yesterday and charged with setting the fire last Oct. 24 that killed 25 persons in a Bronx social club and injured 24.

title: Erroll Garner, Jazz Pianist, 53; Composed `Misty, That's My Kick
description: Erroll Gamer, the jazz pianist, died yesterday afternoon when he suffered a cardiac arrest in an ambulance going to Cedars Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. Mr. Garner had been receiving treatment for emphysema since March, 1975, when he collapsed while performing at Mr. Kelly's in Chigaco. He was 53 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Justice Department prosecutors investigating alleged corruption in the Federal Bureau of Investigation are reported to have decided that they cannot bring major criminal charges against anyone.

title: Breaking Into a New Year by Breaking World Records
description: Ronald Champlain, better known as Master Chi, lay dowi for a quick nap yesterday, sandwiched between two beds of nails and under 1,410 pounds of weight. It was no joke. His back bore nail marks when he got up, but Mr. Champlain, one of several aspiring recordbreakers whii had gone to the Guinness World Records Exhibit Hall to seek a place in history, had set mark for the feat.

title: Chess:
description: Mark Diesen, an 18yearold master of Potomic, Md., and the United States representative in the World Junior Championship, won the second New York futurity tournament, held at the Manhattan Chess Club.

title: Peking Official Says Soviet Wants to Enslave Asia
description: PEKING, Jan. 2 (Agence FrancePresse) Deputy Prime Minister Li Hsiennien tonight denounced what he described as a sinister intention of the Soviet Union to enslave South Asia.

title: MURDOCH SET TO BUY NEW YORK MAGAZINE
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher who took over The New York Post last week, announced, last night that he had reached agreements with about dozen major stockholders to buy slightly more than 50 percent of the New York Magazine Company, which publishes New York and New West magazines and The Village Voice.

title: Music: Staples
description: Andre Kosteanetz always gives titles to his New York Philharmonic pop concerts, but it's a little difficult to see what he was driving at Saturday night in Avery Fisher Hall with singularly unfestive program of overplayed warhorses labeled Salute to 1977. Perhapt the whole affair was simply meant to be an easily digested antidote for exhausted New Year's Eve revelers.

title: Hayes Talks of Football and Other Things
description: MIAMI, Jan. 2Wody Hayes, who has an answer for everything from football to Farah FawcettMajors, had his own assessment of the signific.aike of Ohio State's.2710 victory over,the Big Eight Conference's Colorado in the 43d annual Orange Bowl Classic last night.

title: Travelers Get Armed Guard On a Road Vital to Rhodesia
description: FORT VICTORIA, Rhodesia, Dec. 29 There have been no incidents since we began the convoys in April, said the sec lcn leader as he gathered his drivers around him in the shade of a huge baobab tree. Still, should we have a contact, just put your foot down and keep going.

description: International

title: U.S. Program on Pesticide Safety Found in Chaos in Senate Report
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The Government's program for assuring the safety of pesticides is in a state of chaos that raises doubts about the protection of the public from traces of dangerous chemicals, according to a Senate staff report made public today.

title: Hindsight on Swine Flu
description: For the moment, we seem to have a consensus on the thorny issue of vaccination against swine influenza. was expressed in an expert commission's recommendation a few days ago that the present moratorium on flu vaccinations be continued while further study is made of the link between these shots and the miniepidemic of paralysis from the GaillainBarre syndrome, whose victims have been disproportionately concentrated among vaccinated persons. If unexpectedly the oncefeared outbreak of swine influenza should occur in the weeks ahead, the vaccinations probably would be resumed.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: In a recipe for preparing a coconut cream pie, the technique recommended for cracking a fresh coconut gave anxiety to Copeland Marks, a friend in Brooklyn.

title: EDWARD M. M'DERMOTT, IRISH FIDDLER, DIES AT 81
description: Edward M. McDermott, who after retiring from the New York City Parks Department gained recognition as an Irish fiddler, died Saturday in the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune; N.J. He was 81 years old and lived. in the Atlantic Hotel, Asbury Park, N.J.

title: Military School Bars Women Next Term; Says Too Few Apply
description: ROSWELL, N.M., Jan. 2The statesupported New Mexico Military Institute, which had been directed by the Attorney General to end its allmale enrollinent policy, has decided not to admit girls.this spring semester because of a lack of sufficient female response.

description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 2 (AP)  The Vermont Sunday News, owned by William Loeb, announced today that it would temporarily stop publication.

description: BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP)The spreadini slick of oil spilled by the wrecked Argo Merchant could be drawn into the Gulf Stream within two days, the Coast Guarc reported today.

title: Stay or Leave? Pressures In Balance at PaineWebber
description: At the brokerage firm of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, time is no longer measured in minutes but in microseconds. Print and paper are being replaced by electronic signals, and computers can display desired information on screens at the touch of a key. Even as branches mushroom all over the country, they have meshed electronically with headquarters on Wall Street so that all the'firm's 1,800 stockbrokers have the same information available to them instantly all over the country.

title: 12 Injured as Basques ,Battle Police in Spain
description: BILBAO, Spain, Jan. 2 (Reuters)About 12 persons were injured today when hundreds of stonethrowing Basque demonitrators fought a twohour battle with the Civil Guard In the streets of Algorta near here.

title: Islanders Play to 33 Tie
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 2The Islanders began their return trip from the doldrums tonight by tying the Buffalo Sabres, 33, on just 16 shots.

title: No Word of Czechoslovak Mihers
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 2 (UPI)The 45 miners trapped in a coal mine near Ostrava in northern Czechoslovakia have apparently been given up for dead, sources closeto rescue officials said today. The lack of any official word on the rescue effort was seen as an indication that attempts were fruitless. The miners were trapped by an underground gas explosion late Thursday.

title: Advertising
description: The Bicentennial. Ho hum. The Olympics. Yawn. The Presidential election. Zzzzzz. The boom in the advertising business. Whoopee! Hurrah! Right on!

title: Two Arrested in Arson at Bronx Club That Killed 25
description: A 40yearold man described as a jealous suitor and a 17yearold friend were arrested yesterday and charged with setting the fire last Oct. 24 that killed 25 persons in a Bronx social club and injured 24.

title: Enter Majority Rule
description: For the first time in eight years, a Democraticcontrolled Congress convenes this week with a President of its own partyand ah elected President at thatabout to occupy the White House. This will be a novel experience for many members. More than half of the House of Representatives and approximately a third of the Senate were elected during the NixonFord years. These members have never known what it is to have major legislative programs formulated in the executive branch departmentslet alone a Presidential agenda for Capitol Hill. Policy stalemates and Government by veto can now no longer be blamed on the Republicans.

title: Aqueduct Reopens Today
description: Aqueduct reopens for the new year today, and the feature race is the $35,000 added Rosetown Stakes at six furlongs for 3yearold fillies. There will be 120 days of racing through May 21, before the action returns to Belmont for 60 days. The $50,000 added Paumonok Handicap for yearolds and up at six furlongs is the first Saturday stakes race of the year at Aqueduct this week. Post time daily is 12:30 P.M.

title: SAN FRANCISCO'S SHERIFF ON TRIAL IN EVICTION CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2The sheriff of San Francisco may find out this week whether he is in contempt of court in an eviction case that has taken on political overtones.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Federal Government has been notified of a leak of water with low levels of radiation from the Public Service Electric and Gas Company nuclear plant in Salem County, a company spokesman said in Newark. The water leaked New Year's Eve from the nuclear unit under construction in Lower Alloways Township along the Delaware River, the spokesman said. The adjacent nuclear generating unit already in operation was not affected. The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission was informed of the leak of water from the system, which cools the nuclear unit, now 60 percent cornolete.

title: Texas Aggies Triumph, 3714, Over Florida
description: EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 2 (AP)Tony Franklin, a barefooted placekicker, booted three field goals and George Woodard, a fullback, scored three touchdowns .today as Texas A. & M. trounced Florida, 3714, in the 42d Sun Bowl Classic.

title: West's Latest Rustlers Round Up Cactuses
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 31Cattle rustlers seldom paid notice to the majestic saguaro cactus as they herded their stolen beef across the desert. Dodging in and out among the cactus and looking over their shoulder for lawmen, they were too busy changing cattle brands underneath its candelabralike arms to pay much attention to this symbol of the Old West.

The play is a coproduction of the New York Shakespeare Festival and the Manhattan Theater Club.

description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 2 (AP)Presidentelect Carter evoked memories of his childhood in a nearly allblack community today as he took the son and daughter of a black bishop to worship services at the Plains Baptist Church.

description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 2 (AP)Tomorrow will bring the end of a long and troubled winter vacation for 70,000 Ohio schoolchildren locked out of classes after voters rejected tax increases.

description: CAIRO, Jan. 2Abie Nathan, an Israeli advocate of peace between the Arabs and Israel, headed his pirate radio ship through the Suez Canal today after gaining permission from Egypt.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 2 (AP)The Rev. Jacqueline Means celebrated communion today as the first regularly ordained woman priest of the Episcopal Church in the United States. Attendance was down at the service at All Saints Church.

Jarman as chairman and chief executive office of the Genesco Corporation, one of the nation's major apparel manufacturing and retailing organizations, will be presented by six dissident directors at a special board meeting in Nashville, Tenn., this morning.

title: Warren J. Freeman, 76, Dies; Headed General Bronze Corp
description: Warren J. Freeman, who retired in 1968 as president of the General Bronze Corporation, maker of aluminum windows and building panels, died Saturday at his home in Hallandale, Fla. He was 76 years old.

description: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 2Claudine Longet, the Frenchborn entertainer, is scheduled to go on trial here tomorrow on manslaughter charges resulting from the shooting death last March, 21 of Vladimir Sabich. the professional skier.

description: If Presidentelect Carter wishes to become immediately popular with almost anyone over 65, he will tackle at once, and with the greatest vigor, one of the most grossly unfair Federal laws the one that says you cannot earn a decent living after your 65th birthday and get your welldeserved Social Security at the same time.

Sessions on Friday resulted in the selection of two jurors, bringing the total to seven.

title: Mummers Brave Cold In Philadelphia Parade
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP)Philadelphia's Mummers were out in force today, braving subfreezing temperatures to parade up Broad Street in their extravagant regalia. The freezing cold and blustery winds forced postponement of the New Year's Day parade yesterday. The parade has been a Philadelphia institution since 1901.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 2The second battle of Trenton, a daylong military action that set the stage for Gen. George Washington's most daring military maneuver of the Revolution, was reenacted today as several,hundred uniformed British and American troops took part in the battle that occurred 200 years ago today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A fire broke out early Sunday in the offices of the Russian language newspaper Novoye Russkoye Slovo at 243 West 56th Street, the police reported: Andrei Sedych, chief editor of the 66 yearold journal, which appears daily except on Mondays, said that damage from the blaze had been limited to his desk and files, which contained confidential papers and subscribers checks and money orders for about $50,000.

title: Bible Group Takes Message to Porno House
description: PASSAIC, Jan. 2 The Capitol Theater, which specializes in burlesque shows, pornographic movies and rock concerts, was the setting here this weekend for an oldtime spiritual meeting that concentrated on respect, religion and recollection.

They are the work of Ens. John C. Roach of the Naval Reserve, artist and ship designer who spent six months researching, painting and sketching the famous frigate for detailed and panoramic authenticity.

title: West Beats East, 3014, On Coast
description: STANFORD, Calif., Jan. 2It rained on the Shriner? parade today, but their 52d annual EastWest college allstar game was undimmed by the weather. The West scored a 3014 victory on the strength of three field goals by Mike Michel of Stanford and an 81yard punt return for a touchdown by Gary Green, Baylor's defensive back.

title: Breakup of Four  Superagencies Urgedby Beame to Spur Efficiency
description: Mayor Beame, in a move he said was aimed at putting more economy and efficiency into New York City's government, yesterday proposed the dismantling of four socalled superagencies. To replace them, the Mayor recommended the creation of smaller, more manageable departments.

title: Furloughs for` 10,000 City Workers Termed Possible by Deputy Mayor
description: First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti last night raised the possibility of furloughing 10,000 more municipal workers next year to balance New York City's budget if various municipal unions and banks failed to agree to a fiveyear deferral of all payments of principal on Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds that they own.

She heads what is known as the Arts and Humanities Cluster of the 133meniber paid transition team set up to advise the Presidentelect on issues that will confront his fledgling administration.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP)  The Federal Aviation Administrator, John L. McLucas, praised the nation's air carriers today for their safety record in 1976, calling it one of the safest years since commercial aviation began in 1927.

title: Quitting Is Not Acquitting
description: The troublesome thing about private clubs, in law and in fact, is that they are by definition private and discriminating, or downright discriminatory. Yet if all of us are to retain the right to choose our friends and golfing companions freely, then even those of us who would routinely exclude all blacks or whites or women or Jews must remain legally free to do so.

title: EMILIEN MAURY DIES; PUBLISHER IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Jan. 2Emilien Amaury, one of France's major newspaper publishers, the man in the center of a twoyear conflict with the labor unions that led to several major national newspaper strikes, died today of injuries received when he was thrown from a horse near his home north of Paris.

title: Multivolume Dance Encyclopedia Urged by a Conference of Experts
description: There is a need for a multivolume dance encyclopedia, the first of its kind, that Would be comparable to Grove's Dictionary of Music, an international conference of scholars, editprs and dance experts has oancludedarter weeklong meetings at the FordFoundation in New York.

title: British Soldier Is Slain In Ulster Ambush
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 2A British soldier was shot dead and two were wounded when a patrol was ambushed today in Crossmaglen, County Armagh, near the Irish border, as people were leaving church.

title: Weak Peso Drives Mexican Cattle to U.S.
description: COLUMBUS, N.M.An eagerness to exchange Mexican beefonthehoof for solid United States dollars has created a cattle jam at the border crossing here. Behind the stampede is the second devaluation of the peso in three months.

title: `Something Old, Something New  Starts Broadway Year Weakly
description: A comedy  it was claimed by Henry Denker opened at the Morosco Theater Saturday night, the first of January 1977. Let us be generous and give it one superlative. Something Old, Something New was the worst comedy  so far  of 1977. Had it been a day earlier it would have done the same favor for 1976.

They waited with autograph books and scraps of paper in their hands for Julius Erving's first appearance here since he was sold last Oct. 21 to the 76ers.

description: HONOLULU, Jan. 2Hawaii's sugar induttry, already suffering from depressed prices because of foreign competition, is facing crucial wage negotiations this !month. A strike after Jan. 31 is a strong Possibility.

description: Raw steel production in the United States rose 11.4 percent to 130 million tons in 1976. the strongest increase among all the world's major steel producers.

title: Kuhn Suspends Turner, Braves Owner, for Year in Matthews Case
description: Ted Turner, the flamboyant, outspoken owner of the Atlanta Braves, was suspended yesterday for one year by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for his actions in his contractlual pursuit of Gary Matthews, a freeagent outfielder.

title: Right on Red Lags
description: New Jersey motorists were given the chance for the first time yesterday to turn right at most red lights, but the opportunity apparently went unnoticed by many drivers unfamiliar with the new regulation. A spot road check by United Press International showed motorists frequently were unaware of the opportunity to turn right at red lights not specifically marked with No Turn on Red sizns.

title: Free Park Passes for Elderly
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI)Elderly people may now apply for 1977 Golden Age Passports, which allow them free entrance to national parks. The lifetime passport is issued without charge to persons 62 years old or older. It also provides 50 percent discounts for use of some park facilities for which there are charges.

title: SUFFOLK PARTY CHIEF CALLED CAREY CHOICE FOR STATE CHAIRMAN
description: Governor Carey has settled on Dominic! J. Baranello, the Suffolk County Democratic leader, as his choice for Democratio state chairman, persons close to both men reported yesterday.

title: U.S. Program on Pesticide Safety Found in Chaos in Senate Report
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The Government's program for assuring the safety of pesticides is in a state of chaos that raises doubts about the protection of the public from traces of dangerous chemicals, according to a Senate staff report made public today.

title: Purchasing Agents Find Outlook Better Now Than 2 Months Ago
description: Business prospects for the new year look brighter than they did two months ago, and economic signs indicate a significant rate of improvement that will be felttoward midyear, E. F. Andrews, a leading spokesman for the nation's purchasing agents, said over the weekend.

title: Puerto Rico Inaugurates Barcelo; He Ignores Ford's Statehood Plan
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 2Carlos Romero Parce16 of the prostatehood New Progressive Party, ignoring President Ford's proposal to make this island commonwealth the 51st state and stressing instead the populist theme that gave him an upset electoral triumph, was inaugurated today as the fifth elected Governor of Puerto Rico.

Mr. Graham, who is 58 years old, was flown to the clinic Friday night from Urbana, Ill., where he complained of pains in his left leg.

title: Suspensions of 2 Jockeys Set Aside Until Hearing

title: Brothers Finish 1,2 In Ski Race
description: EBNATKAPPEL, Switzerland, Jan. 2 (UPI)Heini Hemmi of Switzerland, the Olympic champion, made good his New Year's resolution today when he sped to victory ahead of his brother, Christian, in a World Cup giant slalom event today.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 2Beginning tomorrow, the daily drawing of the winning number in New Jersey's extremely popular Pick It lottery will be televised on the state's four public television stations.

title: Not Above the Law?
description: BOSTON, Jan. 2In two years as Attorney General, Edward H. Levi has done much to restore public confidence in the rule of law. He has imposed the first real check cn national security wiretapping, for example, and begun the overdue task of regulating F.B.I. practices. President Ford has given him great independence, and I think the Justice Department record will be seen as a premier achievement of the Ford years.

title: Bush Is Silent on Assessment of Soviet Aims
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2George Bush, Director of Central Intelligence, today refused to say whether the United States intelligence Community now believed that the Soviet Union was aiming for strategic superiority over the United States.

title: Chesapeake, Va., Confident Volvo Plant Will Be Built
description: CHESAPEAKE, Va., Jan. 2In this sprawlingcity where black bear and bobcats still roam, the planned March opening of the Volvo automobile assembly plant here was eagerly awaited as a welcome boost to the economy.

description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 2A. L. Winegar, president of the Business Arts Foundation, would like to see symphony orchestras perform in the Meadowlands Sports Complexmaybe not in the middle of the big stadium, but possibly in some bright new facility devoted to the cultural arts within the highly successful complex.

Inquiry on Alleged F.B.I. Corruption Reported Dropping Major Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Justice Department prosecutors investigating alleged corruption in the Federal Bureau of Investigation are reported to have decided that they cannot bring major criminal charges against anyone.

title: Penalties Are Reduced in N.H.L. But Goal Production Is the Same
description: The National Hockey League reaches its halfway point sometime this week, so it's a good time to put some scoring statistics into their proper perspective. For example, a total of 2,301 goals have been scored in the first 348 games of this season. Last year? One goal less, or 2,300. Give the N.H.L. a gold star for consistency. The biggest change from last season shows up in penalty minutes. Prob ably because of the stricter rules invoked this year to curb violence, players behaved more cautiously this season, and fewer penalties were called. This amounted to 1,259 fewer minutes served in the penalty box than last season.

title: Nixon Gets Invitation To Carter Inaugural
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI)The Inaugural Committee said today that former President Richard M. Nixon had been invited to Jimmy Carter's inauguration as a matter of protocol. There was no indication if Mr. Nixon would attend.

title: Liberals, Despite Humphrey Ties, Are Expected to Elect Byrd Today
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 3Hubert H. Humphrey the other day ran into a fellow Senate liberal who had already declared his support for Hobert C. Byrd to become majority leader.

title: Bridge Display of ESP by Partner Can Foster False Security

But when partner obliges, displaying admirable ESP. there is a dangerous tendency to ralax. And the defenders can suddenly find that their breakthrough has availed them nothing.

description: Sarah Campbell Caldwell, a high school teacher in Akron, Ohio, who was president of the National Education Association in 195253, died Thursday in Jacksonville, Fla., where she was living in retirement. She would have been 72 on Friday.

title: Two Employees Are Shot In EarlyMorning Holdup Of a Times Square Store
description: A young holdup man shot and wounded two employees and robbed the manager and another employee yesterday at a clothing store in the Times Square area. The robber escaped.

title: Big A Draws 15,105, Fewest for Opener
description: With piles of snow dotting the parking fields and both infield ponds slick sheets of ice, the year's thoroughbred racing campaign started at Aqueduct yesterday under overcast skies with a disappointing crowd of 15,105 on hand. This was the smallest firstday crowd at

title: Marquette 63, Ga. Tech 45
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 3 (AP)Butch Lee pumped in 18 points, sinking seven of his first 10 shots, as 12thranked Marquette conquered Georgia Tech, 6345, tonight. After a slow start, Marquette, with an 82 record, sank six of seven shots over Georgia Tech's zone in a run of 12 successive points and took command at 144.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 3 (AP)Pakistan said today that it would go ahead with plans to purchase a nuclear reprocessing plant from France despite opposition from the United States and Canada.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Environmental Protection Agency issued final rules today banning or limiting the discharge of five toxic pesticides into the. nation's waterway.

title: Bank Drops Suit That Challenged M.A.C. Legality
description: The Flushing National Bank yesterday dropped its court challenge to the constitutionality of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, thereby removing a major source of the resistance by banks to helping New York City pay off its shortterm notes.

title: I.M.F. GRANTS BRITAIN RECORD 2YEAR LOAN TOTALING $3,9 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The International Monetary Fund approved today a loan to Britain in various currencies totaling about S3.9 billionthe largest single credit in the fund's 30year history.

title: Felker's New West Magazine Is Running in the Red
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3After nine months of publishing in California, Clay S. Felker, the New York journalist, appears to have found a tentative niche here for his New York Magazine formula of consumer tips, a preoccupation with people who have money and talent, and an occasional piece of investigative journalism. But he hasn't found any profits yet for New West, his westernized version of New York.

title: Blast Said to Kill 25 At Office in Beirut Of Rightists Party
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 3 (UPI)A huge bomb exploded tonight outside the cast Beirut headquarters of the Christian rightist Phalangist Party, inflicting heavy casualties.

title: World Military Situation Confronting Carter Shows Changes Have Favored Soviet
description: The global military situation that will confront Jimmy Carter as he takes office Jan. 20 differs significantly from that faced by any of his predecessors since 1945. The difference arises from the growth of Soviet military strength and the relative decline of American power over the last 10 years.

description: DETROIT, Jan. 3  American auto manufacturers are scheduling output of 787,700 cars this month, up 17.9 percent from the 668,300 autos built in January, 1976, according to auto analysts.

title: Boxes as Art Form Shown At a Retrospective in Paris
description: PARIS  Cases, transparent and opaque, are very much the point at the Musee d'art Moderne of the City of Paris, where the first retrospective ever devoted to the box as an art form has just opened. There are hundreds of them, full or empty, wooden or metal, comic or tragic, verbose or silent, strewn in indescribable disorder along the floors and walls of the museum's winding halls.

description: Mino David Badner, an art historian and associate professor of fine arts at Rice University in Houston, died there on Saturday of a heart attack. He was 38 years old.

title: Cahadiens End Flyer Streak, 64
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (AP)Jacques Lemaire scored one goal and assisted on two othersall in a span of minutes 22 seconds of the third period tonight to rally the Montreal Canadiens to a 64 National Hockey League victory over Philadelphia, ending the Flyers unbeaten streak at 20 games.

title: Len Cariou Will Star In Peter Handke Play
description: Len Cariou, who recently completed his role opposite Elizabeth Taylor in A Little Night Music,. which was filmed in Austria, has returned to New York to star in A Sorrow Beyond Dreams, a play by Peter Handke. The Phoenix Theater will offer the work by the Austrian author of The Ride Across Lake Constance at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, starting Jan. 13. The run will last through Jan. 23.

title: COURT BARS SEX BIAS IN HIRING BY CONGRESS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 (AP)A constitutional prohibition against discrimination cannot be violated by members or Congress, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today.

title: Many Leaders Seeking to Impose Tough New Reforms on Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  Many Congressional leaders, stung by the public's perception of Capitol Hill in the light of recent scandals, are determined to impose tough new reforms in the 95th Congress, which convenes tomorrow.

title: Another Reason to Grow
description: Our nation's apparent economic revival might mislead us into imagining a comparable resurgence throughout the industrial West (if the Japanese will sit still for that designation). Sadly, the latest analysis of the 24nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development finds the nonCommunist North (same area, if Australia will allow) to be experiencing the slowest postwar recovery, analogous to but not so deep as the depressed 1930's.

title: The State of Puerto Rico
description: President Ford endorsed statehood for Puerto Rico as if the thought occurred only as he was packing to leave the White House. There is no indication that he consulted anyone in San Juan or, indeed, in Washington. On the contrary, the newly inaugurated Governor of Puerto Rico felt compelled to ignore the gesture, even though he is the island's main proponent of statehood.

In less than a year, it has grown from its four partners to a firm of 25 employees, with expansion so rapid that it is searching for new office space after only five months at its present site.

title: China's Railroad Troops Are D ispatched to Major Transport Center
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 3In a further move to end factional troubles in China's provinces, the nation's leaders have imposed military authority over a key railroad junction in north China, a provincial broadcast disclosed today.

Felker. New York's publisher, reportedly announced that he would seek an accommodation with Mr. Murdoch.

description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 3 (UPI)A landmine explosion yesterday killed a Thai reporter for ABCTV and seriously injured a South Korean photographer in the same group, which was covering Cornmunist insurgent activity in southern., Thailand.

description: H. Woodruff Tatlock, who retired in 1969 as vice president and treasurer of the Prudential Insurance Company, Newark, died Sunday in Morristown (N. J.) Memorial Hospital after a long illness. His age was 72.

description: The American Stock Exchange, like most institutions on Wall Street, has traditionally been a man's domain. But recently it installed two women in jobs that make them highly visible to the outside world.

title: Policeman Shot in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA Jan. 3 (AP)A policeman was shot and wounded today after he stopped a man he suspected of stealing a car, the authorities said. The plainsclothes officer, Gary Madeline, 24 years old, stopped the car on the street in north Philadelphia and the driver got out and fired at Officer Madeline, the police said. He was treated for a superficial head wound at Temple University Hospital and released.

title: Student Rescued From a Pit
description: BONNIEVILLF.. Ky., Jan. 3 (UPI)A rescue late yesterday ended an eighthour ordeal for a University of Louisville student who fell 60 feet into a pit while exploring a cavern at Mammoth Cave. Leo Dolata, 30 years old, who suffered broken thigh tone in the fall, was brought to safety on a rope ladder.

title: Search Is Launched For Missing Tanker
description: BOSTON, Jan. 3 (AP)The Canadian and United States Coast Guards launched a search today for a missing tanker carrying eight million gallons of heavy fuel oil from England to Providence, R.I.

title: Rosenbaum Checks a Revoli by G.O.P. Chairmen
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3 Republican State Chairman Richard M. Rosenbaum headed off a rebellion among Republican County chairmen today at a meeting here with 44 chairmen or their representatives.

title: Redcoats Lose Again in Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 3By the time the Redcoats marched out onto Princeton Battlefield this morning, they had already been outmanned and outflanked. Their doom was foretold by the modernday, wellconcealed deployment of Washington's Continentals on the eastern edge of the broad, snowy plain.

title: W heat and Corn Up On Reports of Snow And Rain for Fields
description: Snow and rain over large areas or the Middle West over the weekend helped relieve a lack of moisture that has been bothering winter wheat growers. As a result, wheat futures prices tumbled under some heavy selling yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The March delivery closed at $2.74, down from 52.77 a bushel.

title: Manhattan Plaza Plan Gains

title: Notes on People
description: Another United States Senator has separated from his wife and plans divorce. In Washington yesterday, during his first day on the job as success sor to the late Senator Philip A. Hart, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, announced that he and Meredith Riegle were ending their marriage of five year:. Our decision is a very personal one, arrived at amicably, Mr. Riegle said. During his campaign for the Senate last year, it was disclosed that Mr. Riegle, then a United States Representative, had had art extramarital affair in 1969, while he was married to his first wife. After he admitted the affair, the present Mrs. Riegle made a public show of support at a news conference. The Riegle separation is the third involving a Senator in less than a week. Last week Senator Herman E. Talmadge of Georgia and Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut were separated from their wives with a view toward divorce.

title: 8 Schools in Jersey Are Closed To Check AsbestosFiber Levels
description: HOWELL TOWNSHIP, N.J., Jan. 3The eight elementary schools of this Monmouth County community were closed today while scientists. hired by the State Department of Environmental Protection, made tests to determine if there were dangerous levels of asbestos fibers present in the corridors and classrooms. The local Board of Education ordered the schools closed at an emergency meeting late last night after parents of some of the 4,500 elementary school children threatened to boycott classes until asbestoscontaining materials coating the ceilings and corridors of four of the schools were removed. Two of the other schools have similar materials coating the ceilings of the cafeteria or entrance to the building.

title: Chinchilla by Day,
description: CHINCHILLA, that softasfeathers, dappled fur, once conjured up diamond chokers, orchid corsages and box at the opera. It used to cost $70,000 and nobody wore it in broad daylight. These days, if it isn't exactually for football games, it's becoming another little fur toss over slacks when a woman is out shopping. A recent cold day brought out a number of shoppers decked in chinchilla: a woman in a rare, natural brown chinchilla cape, a couple of others, booted and scarved against the wind, wearing the gray variety, and several in chinchilla jackets or little capes. Other evening furs have been gradually making daytime appearances. White mink emerged in the 1960's, sable in the early 1970's. Now chinchilla, which used to be called Empress, is out there as casually as raccoon.

title: QE2,Neatly Docked,Undergoes Repair in Bayonne

A number of militant and members of the underground press have been seen in town and on the campus of Rutgers University here.

description: The approval of Westwaythe city's proposed replacement for the West Side Highwayis a fine Federal New Year's present for New York. And as a generous stocking gift, the Federal Government has added a $78.5 million masstransit grant, the largest single sum for transit operating assistance that the Department of Transportation has ever made. The conditions set by Secretary Coleman for over $1 billion in Federal funds for the highway's constructionnostrike provisions, affirmative action guaranteed by the unions and a substantial construction commitment by the private sectorcan only, strengthen the project.

description: Kuwait announced yesterday that would reduce production of crude oil in 1977 because its customers are cutting their purchases, possibly to switch to lowerpriced Saudi Arabian supplies.

description: NBCNEWS spends three hours this evening examining Violence in America From 8 to 11, the survey, produced by Stuart Schulberg, bombards its audience with statistics, special polls; newspaperheadlines, film features, footage from movies and television shows and cautious speculation. The result is vague on possible solutions, but specific in establishing the existence, and continued growth, of violence in this country.

title: Make Theirs Manhattan
description: There are people who are not compelled to visit Vail, Palm Beach, Barbados or Lyford Cay, and who do not feel necessarily deprived because they stay in New York. We are talking about people who could, if they chose to easily rid themselves Of the city, but instead decide to remain here over the holidays and even beyond them. Happily they lunch at Le Cirque;. eagerly they belly up to the bar at Quo Vadis. They prove that the East Side still lives.

title: Judge Bari Plea to Drop Finley Suit Against Kuhn
description: CHICAQQ, Jan. 4The eighth day of the trial in Charles 0. Finley's $3.5. million suit against Commissioner Bowie Kuhn was like a dull baseball game that plodsalong for eight innings until someone suddenly electrifies the crowd by lashing a gamewinning, insidethepark home run in the ninth inning.

title: Warner Lifts Coke Share
description: The CocaCola Bottling Company of New York said it was advised by Warner Communications Inc. that Warner had increased its holding of CocaCola Bottling common stock to 1.98 million shares, or about 12 percent of the total outstanding. Warner previously held about 7 percent of the stock.

title: Murdoch Seems to Be the Victor In Fight for New York Magazine
description: Rupert Murdoch, who was installed as a member of the board of directors of the New York Magazine Company during a stormy sixhour session Monday night, appeared yesterday to have acquired a controlling Interest in the company.

title: CHINA GIVES NEW DETAILS OF UNREST IN THE SOUTH
description: PEKING, Jan. 4 (Reuters)The Chinese press today published more details of recent unrest in the strategic southern province of Fukien but said rival groups were settling their differences.

title: Explosion Rocks Las Palmas
description: LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, Jan. 4 (AP)An explosion rocked offices of South African Airways in this Atlantic island port last night. The police linked the blast to an organization seeking independence from Spain for the islands. Damage was estimated at $3,000. No one was injured because the offices were closed when the bomb went off, the police said.

title: U.S. OPPOSING PLAN OF 3 TO BUY COMPETING ROAD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI)The Justice Department announced today that it imposed a proposal by three Midwestern railroads to acquire the Green Bay and Western Railroad, a small competing carrier operating mainly in Wisconsin.

title: Freed Spanish Red Joins in Talks

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Bette Midler is bound with cord and gagged like the heroine in an oldfashioned melodrama, or maybe just the artist's wishful thinking Mae West is bulging in all the right, and some of the wrong, places Barbra Streisand looks as though she has feet of clay. You may not agree with Murasan's interpretations of wellknown personalities but they're bound to cheer up your day. Marlene Dietrich, Salvador Dali and Elizabeth Taylor are some of the other 6 or 7foothigh figures on display at Murasan Ltd. at 715 Madison Avenue (63d Street.) The soft sculptures, all in silk, can be carted away for anywhere from $2,000 to $4,000 each and there's no extra charge for delivery. For the less affluent, the silk cushions with handpainted funny faces, funny cats and fairly normal mushrooms, clouds, sunsets and shells, can be had for $28 to $85. The shop also has wall hangings and scads of silk clothes.

title: City Plans the Sale of $500 Million In M.aC. Bonds to Pay Off Notes
description: In a shift of strategy, New York City fiscal planners moved yesterday to pay off the city's shortterm notes through a public tale of as much as $500 million in Municipal Assistance Corporation bondsnearly twice the amount that had been thought possible only a few weeks

title: Book's of The Times
description: I remember reading, when I was in school, a psychological study of autobiographical documents that concluded that in writing about their lives most people tended to skip over the serene times and concentrate on the troubled or dramatic. It seems to me that this was once true of many autobiographical books, but that we are seeing a gradual change. People are becoming more grateful for the ordinary in lifein fact, they seem to be developing a positive nostalgia for it. I lived, therefore I am, seems to be the dominant note in these new books.

title: Center Faculty Votes to Strike
description: The 200member faculty at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University, voted overwhelmingly yesterday to strikes Jan. 31, the start of the spring semester if the administration does not make satisfactory contract reopener offer. Paul Siegel, professor of English and chairman of Local 1460 of the United Federation, of College Teachers, said that the over riding issue in dispute was insistence by his local on salary parity with other branches of the university.

title: 2 TeenAge Girls and a Woman Fatally Stabbed in 3 Separate Incidents
description: Two teenage girls and a 31yearold woman were stabbed to death in three separate incidents here last night, accordmg to detectives. An arrest was made in one of the homicides, the detectives said, and they were seeking a suspect in another. They admitted they were completely baffled by the third.

title: Chile Cuts Ties With Andean Pact On Foreign Investment and Tariffs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 4 (Reuters)The Chilean Government published today a decree revoking the Andean Pact common market rules on foreign investment and customs tariffs, thus formally cutting the country's last links with the pact.

title: ACHILLE CAMPANILE
description: ROME, Jan. 4 (AP)Achille Campanile, author, playwright and television critic, died at his home near Rome today. He was 76 years old. Mr. Campanile began his writing career in the 1920's as journalist. He later wrote many successful novels and plays, most of them marked with humor and some mocking the bourgeoisie.

title: Illnesses Linked To Chemical PBB
description: A medical study of more than 1,000 Michigan residents has revealed that nearly onethird of those examined suffered adverse health effects possibly caused by a toxic chemical called PBB, which accidentally contaminated the state's farm products in 1973.

Robert Walsh, senior vice presidentconsumer information of Y. & R.

title: Dividends
it's Called Chili, and Everybody Is an Expert
description: That Americans love to argue about food, there can be no question. New Englanders can expound for hours on the virtues or vices of a wellmade or poorlymade clam chowder or pot of Boston baked beans. Arguments as to the merits or demerits of using lard, Crisco or butter as the proper fat for frying chicken are sufficient unto themselves to render asunder close ties in the South. In Pennsylvania Dutch country, one man's Schnitz un Gneppe may very well be anathema.

title: Columbia Moves to Attract Adults; Focus'of Graduate Program Shifted
description: In a major shift in academic policy, Columbia University has begun to move seriously into the adult education market and to restructure its graduate programs around parttime and master's degree students rather than those seeking doctorates on a fulltime basis.

title: French Leader Expects June Summit in Britain
description: PARIS, Jan. 4 (Reuters)President Valry Giscard d'Estaing said today that he expected the next Western economic summit meeting to be held in Britain in June.

title: FastFood Chains Expecting an Even Bigger Bite of Sales
description: Out on gut row, as it's called in Greenville, S.C., more than 30 fastfood outlets crowd together in a single stretch of highway not far from the center of town.

title: Bicentennials Announce Move to the Yale Bowl
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 4 (UPI)In an effort to increase attendance, the owners of Connecticut's North American Soccer League franchise announced a move today from Hartford to the spacious Yale Bowl in New Haven. The team name also was changed from the Hartford Bicentennials to the Connecticut Bicentennials.

title: Council Unit Votes, 8 to 0, To Delay Implementation Of Bargaining Regulation
description: Charging that a new City Charter provision would create chaos in current municipal labor negotiations and do irreparable harm to the city's fiscal plans, a City Council committee yesterday voted out a bill to delay implementation of the new regulation.

title: LA ON OPTICIAN ADS CALLED UNENFORCED
description: NEWARK, Jan. 4A Bergen County optician said today that the State Attorney General and the State Director of Consumer Affairs were violating New Jersey law by.riot prosecuting opticians who illegally advertised eyeglass prices.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS PICK BYRD AS LEADER; G.O.P. ELECTS BAKER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4Robert C. Byrd, a West Virginia Democrat, was chosen majority leader of the Senate without opposition today, while the Senate Republicans in a surprise move elected Howard H. Baker Jr; of Tennessee as their minority leader.

title: Regional Cookbooks At Their Best
description: Looking at the hundreds of cookbooks on sale in any of the city's wellstocked bookstores, one may find it hard to believe that there are still hundreds more that never come to the New York marketplace at all. Anyone who travels around the country and pursues an interest in food, repeatedly comes across cookbooks that are published locally and that are at least as interesting, and often more so, than many turned out by the big national publishers.

title: Puerto Rican Aide Sees Statehood Hurt by Ford
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 4President Ford probably hurt the cause of statehood by proposing that it be granted to Puerto Rico without previously consulting island opinion, Baltasar Corrada del Rio, the official who will represent the new prostatehood government in the United States Congress, said yesterday.

title: Former Convict, 36, Sworn In as a Judge in California
description: AUBURN, Calif., Jan. 4This morning Bob Young was sworn in as judge of the Justice Court of Loomis, Calif., a community of 23,000. Sixteen years ago Mr. Young was in jail at Lompoc Federal Prison. The Judicial Council of California, the American Bar Association and the National Center for State Courts say that as far as they know Mr. Young is the only exconvict to become a judge.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Chile's Cost of Living Up 174.3%
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 4 (AP)The cost of living in Chile rose 174.3 percent last year, the government said today. But the rise was a marked contrast to 1975, when prices rose by 340.7 percent.

title: HOLDINGS REDUCED BY BOND DEALERS
description: The credit markets declined fairly sharply yesterday as Wall Street dealers decided to lighten their inventories of fixedincome securities acquired late last year at lower prices. No particular news developments caused the drop in prices miler yesterday or on day, but the twoday move dissipated some of the enthusiam for bidding aggressively today for the Public Service Company of Indi

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4Presidentelect Carter has chosen Lucy W. Benson as the State Deportment official charged with controlling arms sales abroad and curbing proliferation of nuclear arm. if she is confirmed by the Senate, Mrs. Benson will be the highestranking woman in State Department history.

title: A 5Course Meal on a French Express
description: ABOARD TRAIN 3890, somewhere between Poitiers and ParisThe French are not yet obsessed with keeping time records on trivia, even gastronomic, but the record for Frenchmen eating a fivecourse meal may well have been set in the dinnig car. So here, from notes taken in jagged ballpoint pen scratches on a gravystained notebook, is an account of that dinner. Such a meal would normally take even a nervous Frenchman at least three hours to eat:

title: Jets Name Michaels Head Coach
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 4The most available job in sports was filled for the fifth time in 15 months today when Walt Michaels was named as the New York Jets head coach.

title: VIOLATION OF LAW IS LAID TO ELECTION PANEL'S HEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)A Federal Election Commission staff investigation concluded that Vernon W. Thomson, chairman of the commission, apparently violated the law by telling former Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird of a pending commission investigation.

title: The Times Names 3 New Members To Editorial Board
description: The appointments of three new members of the editorial board of The New York Times were announced yesterday by Max Frankel, editor of the editorial page of The Times.

title: The Coldness of Private Warmth
description: A society's greatest illusions are expressed in its morals. Today, the reigning belief is that close personal relations are morally good. We have code words far secular evil: distant, cord, impersonal. Personality itself has become a moral categorysomething inconceivable to a medieval monk, who believed morality to come from God rather than Man, and inconceivable as well to the worldly philosophers of the Jeffersonian age, who felt that people derived dignity from the Nature they shared in common rather than from the peculiarities of individual feeling,

title: Cooking With Betty Friedan...Yes, Betty Friedan
description: I AM considering making soup from scratch next summer. Putting zucchini or avocado or watercress and yogurt and spinach in a blender. That Spanish soup with 20 cloves of garlic and a raw egg. Fish soup with saffron and a little white wine. I wonder how you make aioli. I'll buy a big tureen and some large bowls. And then with bread and salad and cheese and wine, I could have people over to dinner again. It can't be

title: `All the President's Men Makes It 2 in a Row
description: All the President's Men, the film based on the bestselling Watergate book by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, was named the best film of 1976 by the National Society of Film Critics at its annual meeting yesterday at the Algonquin Hotel. Participating in the voting were 27 critics who represent newspapers and magazines in New York, Boston, Chicago, Washington, Los Angeles and San Francisco.

title: Soviet Plans to Raise Some Prices To Reflect Higher Production Cost
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 4The Soviet Government today announced a series of price changes that will, among other things, make travel by plane, boat and taxi more expensive.

title: PENNSYLVANIA MOVE SPURS NOW ACCOUNTS
description: Savings bank depositors in Pennsylvania may soon by able to write checks against special accounts, joining savings bank customers in neighboring New Jersey and New York in the exercise of this relatively new consumer banking procedure.

title: 4 Killed in Second Attack in 2 Days In a Christian District of Beirut,
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 4Another attack was staged today on a Christian area here as Christians in east Beirut went on strike to protest the huge explosion set off yesterday in front of the security headquarters of the rightwing Phalangist Party.

title: CARTER ISSUES GUIDE FOR AIDES ON CURBING CONFLICT OF INTEREST
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Jan. 4Presidentelect Carter issued broad guidelines today designed to limit conflicts of interest in his administration and at the same time announced that he would attempt to avoid any personal conflicts of interest by placing the bulk of his financial holdings in a trust.

title: Dibbss Racquet Booms, but Wheres Applause; Miamian Is Hardly Known Despite Steady RiseExpects a Breakthrough Soon
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 4Sol Goldman, his coach, says Eddie Dibbs is better known in Europe than in the United States. Harold Solomon, his closest friend, says Eddie Dibbs wins all the wrong tournaments.

title: New Faces of the Senate
description: In choosing their new Senate leadership, the Democrats favored a sober, gray image, turning from spellbinder Hubert Humphrey of Minnesota to superclerk Robert Byrd of West Virginia. The Republicans, however, rejected the lowkeyed Robert Griffin of Michigan in favor of the telegenic Howard Baker of Tennessee, his party's star in the Senate Watergate hearings. The embattled minority chose between two centrists and will probably benefit from a more aggressive and articulate public presence. But there seems to be no reason to seek motives of policy or personality in the Democrats selection.

title: Rep. Richmond Says Major Coffee Producers Exploit Shortage and Calls for Congressional Investigation
description: Representative Frederick W. Richmond yesterday accused the world's coffee producing nations of unfairly exploiting the global shortage of the bean by increasing export taxes and tariffs.
