title: CLARENCE H.. BARBER, 57, OF TRINITY COLLEGE DIES
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 4Prof. Clarence H. Barber, the chairman of the department of music at Trinity College since 1966, died Monday in Winter Park, Fla He was 57 years old.

title: Disks: Oscar Hammerstein Revisited
description: Oscar Hammerstein Revisited the 16th in the series of collections of lesser known songs by the more celebrated contributors to the musical theater that Ben Bagley has produced On the face of it, it would seem the least promising because Mr. Hammer. stein, although he was a painstaking craftsman as a lyricist, was not noted for the light touch that has enlivened Mr. Bagley's better revisiteds. Moreover, many of Mr. Hammerstein's less

title: Dollar Continues to Drop On Most Europe Markets As Price of Gold Rises
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 4 (UPI)The United States dollar was generally lower on European money markets today, with continued weakness against the major Continental currencies. The British pound rose about half a cent. The price of gold rose $1.25 an ounce in London to $135.8750 and $1 an ounce in Zurich to the same $135.8750.

title: Closed End Funds
description: Week ended Dec. 31, 1976

title: Suicide a New Blow to Rabin Party And a Cause for AntiPress Furor
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 4The suicide yesterday of Israel's Minister of Housing, Abraham Ofer, raised many questions here today, ranging from the fate of the fragmented but stillentrenched Labor Party to the proper role of the Israeli press in ferreting out allegations of misdeeds on the part of public officials.

title: Earth Tremor in Missouri
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4 (AP)A moderate earth tremor registering 3.6 on the Richter scale struck a twocounty area in southeast Missouri yesterday, according to Sean T. Morrissey, director of the St. Louis University Geophysical Observatory. However, sheriffs deputies in Perry and Cape Girardeau Counties said that they had received no reports of damage, although many residents called to inquire about the tremor. The initial quake at 4:57 P.M., had its in Appleton, Mra Morrissey said. He said there were three aftershocks.

title: Drama: A Bad Trip
description: DOYOU REMEMBER when they did plays about boxers on their way down? Well, perhaps, you don't, it was a long time ago. Poets on their way down had a vogue once. During the slump we even had depressed businessmen taking the long way down from high buildings. Those jumps turned up more in films than plays. But boxers, poets or businessmen, the course was all down. Now we have a failing stockcar racer. The theater, like a tortoise, moves with the times.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: A Solved Murder Case in Paris Is Erupting Into a National Scandal
description: PARIS, Jan. 4The murder of Prince Jean de Broglie on Christmas eve is erupting into a national scandal, just a week after the administration of President ValGiscard d'Estaing announced that the case had been solved and all the persons involved arrested.

description: Slack Star/Tod Covell

title: Two Party Whips in the Senate
description: Master of nosecounting and negotiationunofficial whip of the liberals . . . Democratic senior Senator from California has 100 percent rating from Americans for Democratic Action . . . not doctrinaire . . . worked out compromise on extension of Voting Rights Act and change of filibuster rule . . tall, thin, baldish 63yearold . . . athletic . . . hobby is running, and is believed to hold world record for 55yearolds with 100 yard dash tin 12.6 seconds . . . was newspaperman and magazine writer . . . once sued by Hitler for editorial comments in an'unauthorized version of Mein Kampf . . . covered England, Germany, Italy and Ethiopia for International News Service was playwright, real estate developer national president of United World Federalists from 1949 to 1952... entered politics as founder and first president of liberal California Democratic Council . . .elected California state controller in 1958 and reelected in 1962 . . .elected to Senate in 1968. chairman of Health and Hospitals Subcommittee of Veterans Affairs Committee.

title: Vikings Page, Raiders Upshaw Indulge in Super Bowl Bantering
description: IRVINE, Calif., Jan. 4The Minnesota Vikings and Oakland Raiders, all 86 of them, put on the!. game uniforms today and stood still for photographs and interviews here and at nearby Long Beach in the opening event of Super Bowl week. Alan Page and Gene Upshaw, who will play nosetonose in the pit of the scrimmage line on Sunday at the Rose Bowl, helped out by generating a feud that perhaps is real and perhaps is hyperbole.

title: 85 Freshman Legislators Find Their Thrill on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4With their Young children running through the aisles and their spouses and parents beaming from the galleries, members of the 95th Congress took the oath of office today.

title: Down to Defeat
description: THE TRIP BACK DOWN, by John Bishop. Directed by Terry Schreiber; setting by Hat Tine; costumes by Pearl Somner: lighting by Richard Nelson; production stage manager, Mortimer Halpern. Presented by Philip Rose, Gloria and Louis K. Sher. At the Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street..

title: Private Lives
description: WHENDmitri went berserk, his family, familiar with his frenzies, knew exactly what to do. They lowered him from the rafters, laid him out on the rug, folded him up in sections, like an American flag, and gave him a washrag soaked in sour mash to chew on. While hot and cold running daughters sang madrigals and quoted Pasternak, Dmitri was heard through the washrag to shout: Ecrasez l'infdme!

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A State Supreme Court justice in White Plains upheld as reasonable the maximum 7 percent rent rise allowed for this year in Westchester County. The justice, Robert Trainor, ruled yesterday that the county's Rent Guidelines Board, which set the limit last June. fulfilled its statutory mandate and was not subject to judicial abrogation. The guidelines affect 50,000 apartments in 11 communities. The Builders Council of Suburban New York had challenged the guidelines, charging that slipshod calculations led to what it called the board's arbitrary, capricious and illegal action.

title: Jets Name Michaels Head Coach
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 4The most available job in sports was filled for the fifth time in 15 months today when Walt Michaels was named as the New York Jets head coach.

title: Notes on People
description: ON THE Hawaiian island of Maui today, Lowell Thomas, the 84yearold news broadcaster and author, plans to marry a widow, Marlin Munn, 49. The wedding is to take place at the Holy Innocents Church in Lahaina, with reception following at a golf club. Mr. Thomas's son. Lowell Thomas Jr., the Lieutenant Governor of Hawaii, is to be on hand, along with his wife, Mary, the bridegroom's first wife, the younger Mr. Thomas's mother, died in 1975 after 58 years of marriage. Mr. Thomas and his bride will visit the island of Hawaii briefly to have a look at the volcanoes, then fly to Washington where Mr. Thomas will receive the Medal of Freedom Award from President Ford on Jan. 10. Later there'll be a roundtheworld honeymoon.

title: Accounts
description: The Celanese Plastics Company, division of the Celanese Corporation, to Gilbert, Whitney & Johns, Morristown, N.J.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP)The Massachusetts branch of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church has purchased a mansion on Beacon Hill near the State House for about $500,000.

description: Marisa Redanty, a singertobe from East Rochester, tugged her skirt and suppressed an anxiety attack.

title: The Prophet In His Tent
description: TRIPOLI, Libya The last time was received in a tent by a chief of state was thirty years ago when King AbdulAziz Um alSaud, founder of Sandi Arabia, welcomed me in what was then known as a tent city outside Mecca

title: RADIATION RULED NO PERIL TO AMERICANS IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (UPI)Blood tests carried out ever eight months on American diplomats and their families living in Moscow have shown that onethird of those tested have abnormal blood counts, United States officials Said today.

title: Living Abroad: Tokyo
description: NEWYEAR'S DAY in Tokyo is not a day. It is a state of mind. And it consumes all 112 million Japanese for weeks on end. Only now are some people beginning to come out of it. But the warm, hopeful feelings that New Year's Day generates in Japan will endure a while longer. So too will its booming business, its special symbolic decorations, its changing traditions and, this time, a few tragedies as well.

title: Adolfo and His Batwings: Perfect
description: You know what you do the week after New Year's Day, when winter has settled in and the snow lies graying at the curb? You slip into your furs and go see Adolfo so you can plan what you're going to wear when you go south, when you come back and spring looms, and, later on, when the summer sun is high. It's a tradition.

title: DR. GOODWIN WATSON; TAUGHT AT COLUMBIA
description: Dr. Goodwin Watson, a leading psychologist, longtime professor at Teachers College at Columbia University and founder of the Union Graduate School of the Union for Experimenting Colleges and Universities, died last Thursday at a nursing home in Xenia, Ohio. He was 77 years old and had a home in Longboat Key, Fla.

title: Sadat Hints Arab Boycott Of Geneva Talks If P. L. O. Does Not Get an Invitation
description: CAIRO Jan. 4 (UPI)President Anwar elSadat has implied an Arab boycott of Middle East peace talks at Geneva unless the Palestine Liberation Organization invited to attend.

title: Freehplders Raise Is Upheld
description: TRENTON, Jan. 4 (AP)The Appellate Division of State Superior Court has upheld $3,000 salary increases the Essex County Board of Chosen Freeholders voted for itself a year ago. The court ruled yesterday that the freeholders had not complied with certain statutes regarding specific time limits between the introduction and adoption of a resolution, but the deficiencies had been corrected later, making the pay raises legal.

title: Brewers Said to Vie Fiercely for Emerson's Busines
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4A report based on detailed investigation into corruption at Emerson's Ltd. disclosed today that the restaurant chain's beer suppliers engaged in fierce competitive rebating to obtain Emerson's business.

description: The best news of the year to date in the New York art world is the fact that, as of May, Christie's of London will hold sales on Park Avenue at 59th Street in what was until recently the main ballroom at Delmonico's.

title: DR. PAUL F. GEMMILL
description: Dr. Paul F. Gemmill, emeritus professor of economics at the University of Pennsylvania, died last Thursday at his home, a retirement facility in Broomall, Pa. He was 87 years old.

title: Captain of Tanker in River Spill Did Not Know About Buoy's Shift
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4  The captain of the Liberianregistered tanker that went aground last week and spilled 134,000 gallons of oil into the Delaware River said today that he was unaware that his ship was in shallow water outside the river channel because he did not know that a key buoy had been moved.

title: Material to Make 50 Bombs Found. By Police in Brooklyn Apartment
description: A large cache of bombmaking material was uncovered in a Brooklyn apartment yesterday by the police, who had gone there to arrest a suspect in connection with the murder of the owner of a candy store.

title: Penn State Star Sidelined
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa, Jan. 4 (UPI)  Chris Erichsen, Penn State's top rebounder and scorer, will be sidelined at least three weeks with a stress fracture of a bone in his right foot. Erichsen, a 6foot6inch forward who is the only senior among the Nittany Lions top 10 players, suffered the injury in practice last week.

title: Big Board Seat Price lip $2,000
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $82,000, up $2,000 from the previous sale on Monday, the Big Board reported. Seats are quoted at $75,000 bid, $85,000 asked.

Byrd of West Virginia, who was elected Senate majority leader today, and Representatives Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.7of, Massachusetts

description: LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP)British Petroleum said today that it had bought a 10 percent share in an international deepsea mining venture managed by the Kennecott Copper Corporation of the United States.

description: Job prospects for executives look bright this year, but how bright is matter of opinion.

title: Israel Hails Peace Ship After Voyage in Suez
description: ELATH, Israel, Jan. 4 (AP)Scores of vessels blew their horns in welcome and hundreds of Israelis cheered today as Abie Nathan, and his Peate,Ship arrived at this Red Sea port After having passed through the Suez Canal.

title: U.S. COURT REJECTS BRAINDAMAGE CASE
description: A Federal Judge has ruled that no Constitutional issue was involved in the alleged lack of proper medical care for a braindamaged boy in state and foster care in New York City. The case, he said, did not belong in the Federal courts because it involved only a single individual, not a group of plaintiffs.

title: Two More Bodies Found At Brooklyn Fire Scene; Hunt for Others Continues
description: Two more bodies were recovered yesterday from the shell of the commercial building at Fulton Street and Hanover Place in downtown Brooklyn that was destroyed by a threealarm fire Dec. 22. This brought the total to seven.

description: A litttle Florida burrowing owl, half frozen and starved, has, been found in Cedar Beach, L.I., by bird watchers who said only two others have ever been reported officially in New York State.

description: MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (UPI)Soviet authorities searched the apartments of three dissidents today and asserted that they had found evidence that the activists were directed from abroad.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 4State Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran said today that automobile Insurance companies doing business in New Jersey would have to submit detailed statements as to their overall financial positions to back up any requests for rate increases.

title: GOOING OUT Guide
description: HANDIWORK Two smallscale exhibitions of art exotica have opened quietly, for those interested in something a little different. One show is a multimedia collection of metal and wood sculptures, collages and ink on paper by Wolfgang Roth, on view Tuesday through Saturday (10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.) until Jan. 22 at the Touchstone Gallery, 118 East 64th Street.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4Robert C. Byrd, a West Virginia Democrat, was chosen majority leader of the Senate without opposition today, while the Senate Republicans in a surprise move elected Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee as their minority leader.

description: Eric Schnierti, an arbitrator and professor of law, has been appointed a fact finder in the contract dispute between the Metropolitan New York Nursing Home Association and Local 144 of the Hotel, Hospital and Nursing Home Union.

title: Irans Vast Purchases of Weaponry Strain Ability of Country to Absorb It All
description: TEHERAN, IranSince early 1972 Iran has spent more than $15 billion on military equipment ranging from sophisticated aircraft to tanks, and concern is growing about the ability of the nation's armed forces to absorb so much new equipment.

title: Leonia's New High School Opens Following Several Postponements
description: LEONIA, Jan. 4This Bergen County community's new $4.5 million high school opened todayafter repeated postponements since September. Some parents and students had feared it might never open.

title: Bond Profit Is Made New York State
description: ALBANY, Jan. 4Further evidence of New York State's improving financial condition was described today by Comptroller Arthur Levitt. The Common Retirement Fund, which came to the state's rescue last year by buying bonds the private financial market did not want, was able to resell $15 million worth of New York bonds at a $1.228 million profit through competitive bidding.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The body of a wealthy 74yearold woman whose throat apparently had been slashed with a broken vase was found yesterday in her English Tudor home here, the police reported. The woman, Adele Martini, put up quite a struggle before she died, according to Dr. Thomas Lynch, an assistant Bergen County medical examiner.

title: Unsmiling Bowie and Talkative Ted
description: If Bowie Kuhn runs to form, Ted Turner will be back in active command of the Atlanta Braves by the AllStar break. The baseball commissioner suspended George Steinbrenner, chief owner of the Yankees, for two years for violating the laws of the land, and forgave him after one season. Considering that the Great White Father of the Braves hasn't broken anything lately except a bylaw of the baseball lodge, the principle of equal justice for all would seem to dictate that his oneyear exile be cut in two. To sure, although Turner has never faced a possible six years in the simmer, he did sin grievously in an area where Steinbrenner has been blameless. Proposing Stan Musial for commissioner recently, Turner said: Bowie Kuhn? The hell with, him. He

title: Teaching a Child to Cook Means Learning, Too
description: If I had to teach my 8yearold daughter only one thing in the world, I would teach her to cook. Why? Because cooking is important. It's an art that has to do with nourishment, one of the great survival arts. It's an art that I as a woman have enjoyed and wilt continue to enjoy as long as live. Never mind that it's not fashionable for women to be in the kitchen. The art of the culinary spoon is mightier than the sword. And cooking, in my opinion, has to be desired. It's not a feminine art or a masculine art but one that anyone can enjoy regardless of sex, race, or age.

title: WESTWAY PLAN WINS FINAL U.S. APPROVAL; BOON TO CITY IS SEEN
description: The Westway, the controversial project to replace the collapsing West Side Highway with a $1.16 billion Interstate highway south of 42d Street, won its final goahead from the Federal Government yesterday, as expected.

title: Cosell to Speak for G.E.
description: Howard Cosell, identified by the General Electric public relations department as the most famous mouth in America, has signed to be spokesman for G.E.'s line of Citizens Band radios. Grey Advertising is the agency.

title: FORD ASKS CONGRESS FOR TAX REDUCTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4President Ford, with just 16 days left in office, proposed today a permanent $10 billion cut in per sonal income taxes, a corporate tax reduction of $2.5 billion and an increase in the. Social Security tax rates.

title: More Miniaturization
description: The technology column tells of advances in miniaturization, with bigger memories in still smaller spaces. Page D3.

title: Best Buys
description: THEworld's a pretty topsyturvey place, but did you ever think you'd live to see the day when the week's bargains would turn out to be sirloin steak and coffee? Coffee, you remember, used to be bargain. It was what panhandlers always said they were thirsty for, even you suspected otherwise, because it was likely to separate you from a nickel.

title: New York Assembly Democrats Back Steingut as Speaker, 854
description: ALBANY, Jan. 4The Democratic majority in the New York State Assembly, rejecting a challenge from four insurgents, today overwhelmingly endorsed Stanley Steingut for a second term as Speaker.

title: Ad Course Rolls Up 36%

description: The Pillsbury Company has managed to lure a senior McDonald's Corporation executive to head up Burger King, its fast food restaurant subsidiary.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission authorized I.T.T. Domestic Transmission Systems today to establish and operate a digital data communications network in the contiguous United States.

title: BRITON SAYS AFRICAN TALKS YIELD IDEAS ON RHODESIA
description: GABORONE, Botswana, Jan. 4 (Reuters) Ivor Richard, the British chairman of the Geneva conference on Rhodesia, said today that his southern African shuttle tour was beginning to give him a clearer idea of the role Britain should play in an interim administration leading Rhodesia to black majority rule.

title: WESTWAY PLAN WINS FINAL U.S. APPROVAL; BOON TO CITY IS SEEN
description: The Westway, the controversial project to replace the collapsing West Side Highway with a $1.16 billion Interstate highway south of 42d Street, won its final goahead from the Federal Government yesterday, as expected.

description: Five students from the Island Trees school district in Levittown, L.I., filed a lawsuit against their school board yesterday to have such books as The Fixer, by Bernard Malamud, and Slaughterhouse Five, by Kurt Vonnegut Jr., returned to the school library shelves.

description: Federal approval to replace the rotting, closeddown lowerManhattan part of the West Side Highway with a truckscarrying Interstate System segment has brought new outcries that the roadway will add to the city's air pollution. Yet the assessment of officials who put their stamp of approval on the $1.16 billion project yesterday is that vehicular pol

title: Two Top Scorers Quit Fordham's Rebuilding Team
description: Dick Stewart, who was brought in to try and revive the faltering basketball program at Fordham, saw two of his players defect over the weekend. They were his top scorers, Stan Frankoski and.. Kevin Fallon, seniors who were averaging 10.4 and 10.3 points, respectively. However, Stewart was undaunted as he prepared his Rams to face 19thranked Syracuse at the Rams Rose Hill gyin tonight.

title: Negotiations Under Way For Sale of Sporting News
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4 (AP)Negotiations for the sale of The Sporting News, a weekly newspaper first printed nearly a century, ago, were confirmed today by C. C. Johnson Spink, the president.

title: Make Theirs Manhattan
description: There are people who are not compelled to visit Vail, Palm Beach, Barbados or Lyford Cay, and who do not feel necessarily deprived because they stay in New York. We are talking about people who could, if they chose to, easily rid themselves Of the city, but instead decide to remain here over the holidays and even beyond them. Happily they lunch at Le Cirque;. eagerly they belly up to the bar at Quo Vadis. They prove that the East Side still lives.

description: Owners of taxi fleets presented their case yesterday for a 13 percent fare increase with which to meet mounting operational expenses and the added costs of a new union contract.

description: Harold Weston Jr. of New York City, the secondranked welterweight in the world, and Emile Griffith, a fivetime world champion, will appear in different bouts on a card of three 10rounders scheduled for Madison Square Garden on Monday night, Jan. 31.

title: Howard Henry Baker Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Minutes after being elected Senate minority leader today, of Tennessee dropped into a chair in his suite at the Dirksen Senate Office Building, unlaced one highly polished black shoe, scratched an itchy instep, then turned and smiled up at a large oil portrait that dominates the room.

title: Illnesses Linked To Chemical PBB
description: A medical study of more than 1,000 Michigan residents has revealed', that nearly onethird of those examined suffered adverse health effects possibly caused by a toxic chemical called PBB, which accidentally contaminated the state's farm products in 1973.

title: Robert Carlyle Byrd
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4In his long and arduous scramble to the pinnacle of the Democratic hierarchy in the Senate, Robert Carlyle Byrd has consistently been taken for granted and underestimated by colleagues with larger national reputations and ambitions. Six years ago he successfully challeaved Edward M. Kennedy for the majority whip's job. Today it was Men In the News Hubert H. Humphrey's turn to suffer humiliation at the hands of the shrewd and driven parliamentarian from West Virginia who was a butcher and grocer when he started off in politics 31. years ago.

title: Personal Finance: Home Improvements
description: SAVING Sare pouring into thrift institutions at such a brisk clip that interest rates on mortgages are beginning to soften a bit, and there is much more money available for homeimprovement loans.

title: PROFIT TAKING CUTS DOW 1188 TO 9E87 AS TURNOVER RISES
description: The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled nearly a dozen points yesterday as the rush to take profits in early 1977 gathered force on Wall Street.

description: The acquisition off the Anaconda Company by the Atlantic Richfield Company, already approved by shareholders, is awaiting a decision by the Appeals Court in Virginia. It was erroneously stated in yesterday's Times that Anaconda was already a subsidiary of Arco.

description: LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 4 (UPI)Lance Van Zandt, assistant coach and defensive coordinator at Kansas the last two seasons, was appointed today to the Nebraska football coaching staff. Van Zandt will coach the defensive secondary'and serve as defensive coordinator.

title: Personal Health
description: SORE throat, one of the most common plagues of man (especially during cold weather), also one of the most frequently mistreated ailments. A sore throat is not a disease but a symptom. To say your throat is sore is no more informative about its cause than if you complain of a pain in your stomach or head.

title: News Summary
description: Iran's spending on armaments. in excess of $15 billion since early 1972, is raising concern about the ability of its armed forces to absorb so much new equipment. Foreign critics find the heavy arms purchases excessive and illadvised. Iran has allocated $200 million for the training of air force ground personnel by American experts, and plans have been made for 1,000 Americans to help maintain the advanced F16 fighterbombers now on order. (Page A8, Columns, 16.]

In the case of largescale buildings like hotels and office towers, an individual client or patron is not

title: JOINT ATOMIC PANEL STRIPPED OF POWER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4The House of Representatives gave the 95th Congress a reformminded start today by stripping the 30yearold Joint Committee on Atomic Energy of its jurisdiction over legislation.

description: ARMONK, N.Y.It was 22 years ago that Edward a Lashens bought the old Armonk airport as a land speculation. For a few years he left the airport undisturbed, all the time expecting that growth moving northward would some day mandate a more profitable use for the land.

The criticism of the law, which goes into effect Monday, came in interviews with officials of New York City municipal and voluntary hospitals.

title: Makers Shipments Rose in November; Inventories Steady
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4Manufacturers shipments surged in November while inventories were almost flat, the Commerce Department reported today. The result was a sharp drop in the key ratio of inventories to sales, whose upward creep in recent months had begun to cause concern.

title: Market Place

The roaring bull market of January 1976 and a smart bull rally late in the year brought stocks generally to levels substantially higher for the most part than they have been at any time in many years. And the mutual funds generally participated in the gains.

description: Representatives of performing artists and residents of the Clinton neighbourhood west of Times Square said yesterday that they would continue to press for their own version of a performers housing plan for the Manhattan Plaza housing project, and not for the version approved Monday by the New York City Planning Commission.

description: BOSTON. Jan. 4A widespread air and sea search by the United States and Canadian Coast Guards continued today in the Atlantic Ocean between Cape Cod and Nova Scotia for a missing Panamanianregistered tanker with 38 Taiwanese crewmen aboard and a cargo of eight million gallons of heavy fuel oil.

title: Track Stars Gather in City, Discuss Plans For Upcoming Indoor Season and Beyond
description: Moscow in 1980? Neither Steve Williams nor Ed Moses, the Olympic gold medalist, can tell you what they will be doing by then. But both runners were in town yesterday to say they will be in New. York City on Feb. 12 for the Vitalis Olympic invitation track meet at Madison Square Garden. The meet will be televised nationally by NBC as a delayed tape the same night.

title: FORD ASKS CONGRESS FOR TAX REDUCTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4President Ford, with just 16 days left in office, proposed today a permanent $10 billion cut in personal income taxes, a corporate tax reduction of $2.5 billion and an increase in the Social Security tax rates.

description: CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP)Mickey John son pumped in 20 points and Norm Van Lier and Tom Kropp combined for 28 tonight to lead the Chicago Bulls to an 8880 triumph over the New York Nets in a National Basketball Association game. The Bulls, leading by as many as 16 points in the fourth quarter, made numerous turnovers and only a rugged defense saved Chicago from suffering its fifth straight setback.

With the campaign in its fifth week, donations reached $704,934.14. Among the donors were a Manhattan couple who said they had always

title: Moynian Takes His Senate Seat, but Doesn't Sit Still Long
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4Pinkfaced, and with a cherubic grin, Daniel P. Moynihan took his seat in the United States Senate today, casually draped his arm over the back of his chair and surveyed the proceedings as if he had been there for a quarter of a century.

title: Child'sWorld
description: OF COURSE, an artist's medium Is an imporant part of creative expression. But, with children, unless you stop to think about it, you don't realize how large a part of the message the medium Is. Sometimes it almost dictates the message.

Dance: Cynthia Gregory Returns Triumphantly
description: One hardly knew whether last night's audience at the City Center 55th Street Theater was welcoming back the American Ballet Theater or its always lively production of Copplia. What was certain was that, transcending anything else, it was relishing the return to New York of Cynthia Gregory, after her much publicized premature retirement a year ago.

title: Frances Fox Field, 64, Writer, Painter and Dancer, Dies at 64
description: Frances Fox Field, a writer and painter died Tuesday in her home in Manhattan She was 64 years old.

title: MRS. GRASSO PRESSES CONSOLIDATION PLANS
description: HARTFORD, Jan 5Gov. Ella T. Grasso today asked for a consolidated, reorganized administration for public higher education in Connecticut, a single agency for budget planning, a single agency for revenueproducing activities, the means for more closely overseeing the state's various forms of legal gambling and better tools for controlling organized crime.

title: The U.N. Today
AMEDEE J. COLE
description: Amedee J. Cole, a retired advertising executive, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 70 years old.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 5 (UPI)Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto today announced a series of agrarian reforms expected to improve his party's chances in the March elections.

title: 20,000 Homeless in Bolivian Flood
description: SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia, Jan. 5Twenty thousand people have been made homeless by floods that swept this city and the surrounding countryside, officials said today. At least three people were known to have died as floodwaters rose in the city to nearly five feet, destroying some 200 homes.

title: Mets Sign Harrelson and Milner
description: The New York Mets, who sat out the recent race for millionaire free agents, announced yesterday that they had signed six of their players to contracts, including Bud Harrelson and John Milner.

title: Solace for Humphrey: Senate Democrats Give Him a $7,450 Pay Rise, a Chauffeured Limousine and New Title
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5Senate Democrats today gave Hubert H. Humphrey a $7,450 raise, a chauffeured limousine, entree to White House leadership meetings and a new title: Deputy President pro tem of the Senate.

title: A PoliceRun Store  Leads to 6 Arrests
description: Management of a Times Square bookstore by undercover policemen has resulted in the arrest of six men accused of selling obscene movies, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday.

title: Harry G. Hoffmann, Political Columnist, Dies in W. Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 5Harry G. Hoffmann, who recently retired as editor of The Charleston Gazette and who was one of this state's best known and most influential political writers, died at his typewriter yesterday of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: Miss Norton Scores Upset
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP)Chris Evert scored an easy victory tonight and advanced to the quarterfinals of the $100,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament, the first of the 1977 tour. She defeated JoAnne Russell, 63, 64.

title: Cincinnati 61, Temple 46
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 5 (AP)Secondranked Cincinnati, celebrating its highest poll perch in 13 years, came alive in the second half behind its 6footl0inch center, Robert Miller, to down Temple tonight, 6146.

title: CARLWERNER GRONEWALDT
description: CarlWerner Gronewaldt, a retired civil engineer, died Tuesday in West Berlin of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and a resident of Cooperstown, N. Y.

title: World News Briefs
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Jan. 5The Government today invoked emergency laws as the 20day railroad strike threatened to spread to postal workers and other civil servants.

title: Nathan's Famous Moves to Shaller
description: After about a year at Warren, Muller, Dolobowsky and some six months at Martin Landey/Arlow Advertising, Nathan's Famous restaurant chain has changed agencies once again. This time it is Shaller Rubin Associates and the client is saying that it will spend more than $1 million for advertising.

title: North Selects CoCaptains
description: MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 5 (AP)North squad captains were picked today as drills for Saturday's. Senior Bowl football game moved into high gear, with National Football League observers outnumbering the players. Picked by the North team as cocaptains of the offense were Steve Pisarkiewicz of Missouri, a quarterback, and Tony Hill of Stanford, a wide receiver. Terry Beeson of Kansas, a linebacker, was chosen defensive captain.

title: Britain's Reserves Plunged 20% In December, but Optimism Shows
description: LONDON, Jan. 5Britain's official reserves plunged 20 percent in December, the Bank of England disclosed today. It was an extraordinary loss of vital funds that governments use in managing their economies and the consequences of the severe pressure on the pound through most of the year.

title: Australia's Embattled Marsupials Bounce Back
description: MELBOURNE, AustraliaThe tide appears to have turned for the embattled marsupials, from the strapping kangaroos to cuddly koalas and tiny planigales, whose young are no larger than a rice grain.

title: Article 3  No Title
Indiana Public Service Top Bonds Offered at Lowest Yield Since'73
description: A highgrade utility bond issue was offered to investors yesterday at a yield of 7.625 percent, the lowest rate of return on such securities since June 1973. The bonds marketed in the midst of a modest recovery throughout the credit markets, were reported to be 40 percent sold at the end of the afternoon. The milestone $85 million financing was done by the Public Service Company of Indiana, an electric power company that is generally regarded in Wall Street as one of the most creditworthy utilities rated Aa by Moody's and AA by Standard &Poor's. Only two weeks ago, Aarated utility bonds were being offered for sale in the secondary bond market at prices to yield 8:10 percent.

title: BEAME TO SEEK RISE IN REAL ESTATE TAX AND MORE JOB CUTS
description: Mayor Beame is proposing to overcome a budget deficit of at least $585 million in the next fiscal year by raising the New York City real estate tax, pressing for increased Federal and state assistance and reducing the work force by 8,200 more employeesincluding 1,500 police officersby attrition and without resorting to layoffs.

title: U.S. Skiers Dominate Start Of Series With Canadians
description: HUNTER, N.Y., Jan. 5 (AP)United States ski team members dominated the competition today as the CanadianAmerican Ski Trophy series got under way at Hunter Mountain with a giant slalom event.

title: Books of The Times
description: If you find yourself thinking of Richard Nixon when you consider the title of Richard Sennett's new book, you will not be too far off the mark. The Fall of Public Man does touch upon the problem of Mr. Nixon, as well as many other recent political leaders who seem to have undermined our faith in public life. But Professor Sennett's brilliant book is so much more than a comment on contemporary political life that its timeliness is rendered almost incidental: Professor Sennett's real interests are sociology and social psychologyhe is professor of sociology and director of the Center for Humanistic Studies at New York University, as well as the author of Families Against the City (1970), The Uses of Disorder (1970), and (with Jonathan Cobb) The Hidden Injuries of Class'(1972)and what he is arguing is that Mr. Nixon, and other leaders who have violated the public trust, are really symptomatic of our general loss of interest in public life.

title: Proposed Transit Cuts. No Way! Protesters Say
description: Periodically shouting No cutsno way, hundreds of angry New Yorkers voiced, and at times screamed, their opposition yesterday to proposed cutbacks in subway and bus service at a hearing called by the New York City Transit Authority.

title: Bicentennial Prompts Sharing With Needy
description: The Year of the Bicentennial has passed but its benefits are still being harvested. Among them are gifts from donors to the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Group Says It Planted Bombs
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 5 (UPI) A group calling itself the Lolita Lebron Puerto Rican Liberation Command said today that it was responsible for placing two highpowered bombs in the Reserve Officers Training Corps at the University of Puerto Rico. The bombs were disarmed 15 minutes before they were set to go off on Monday. A caller said that the bombs were mean to destroy the [R.O.T.C.] building because it is a school of fascism and death.

title: An ElectricChair Heist
description: I find myself thinking repeatedly about an incident from my recent youth. This story is not told often; people tend not to believe that it is true. Members of my family, though, still shake their heads remembering the night the electric chair suddenly turned up in the basement of our comfortable suburban home.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP)The intelligence division of the Chicago police compiled secret dossiers on thousands of Chicagoans, including some of the city's most prominent lawyers, scholars and clergymen, court documents showed today.

title: The Moment for a Mandate in Israel
description: Do we dare implore the Israelis to look beyond domestic scandal to the international stakes in their coining election? They are agitated by suspicions of fraud and bribery in high places, demands for electoral reform, inflation, and the redistribution of political power that the voting in May will bring. All this when the United States and other interested nations are awaiting a government strong enough to test the chances of active negotiations between Israel and her Arab neighbors.

title: Cabaret: Ballroom Series Back
description: If it were left to Larry Grossman to sing the songs that he and Hal Hackady have written for a handful of musicals since they became a team in 1969, the pair might appear to be two of the most outstanding collaborators in the current musical theater. Mr. Grossman and Mr. Hackady are showing their wares this week at the Ballroom, West Broadway near Houston Street, where the Broadway at the Ballroom series is being resumed after a holiday hiatus.

description: A three hour mediation session failed yesterday to resolve the 23day orchestra strike that has shut down the New York City Ballet.

title: Rabin, at Funeral, Defends Aide Who Was a Suicide
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 5Housing Minister Abraham Ofer, who committed suicide on Monday, was given a state funeral today, and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin said in a eulogy that he believed the minister to have been innocent of the embezzlement charges linked to him in newspaper reports.

title: Panel Clears I.R.S. on Miami Inquiry
description: A Federal grand jury has reported that Intelligence agents of the Internal Revenue Service did not violate the civil rights of taxpayers during a highly publicized sex and drinking investigation in Miami known as Operation Leprechaun.

title: Most Producers Increase Prices For Lead by c a Pound to 26.5c
description: The price of lead rose yesterday to 26.5 cents a pound, an increase of  cent a pound for most producers and of one cent a pound for Asarco Inc.. Which had been quoting lead at 25.5 cents a pound.

title: DR. IRVING M. DERBY, 81, RETIRED PATHOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Irving M. Derby, pathologist at Brooklyn State Hospital from 1929 to 1942.when he did preliminary bloodbank research, died yesterday In Veterans Administration Hospital at Canandaigua, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
MISCALCULATION LAID TO TANKER OFFICER
description: A mathematical error resulted in a serious miscalculation about the position of the oil tanker Argo Merchant shortly before the ship ran aground, according to testimony yesterday by Capt. Georgios Papadopoulos, the shin's master.

title: Villanova 64, Notre Dame 62
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 (AP)Keith Herron scored 19 points and his brother Larry had 11 tonight as Villanova upset Notre Dame, 6462. It was the third consecutive loss for the eighthranked Irish.

title: Electronics, Not the Piano, Is David Tudor's Muse Today
description: Throughout the 1950's and into the 60's, David Tudor, a virtuoso of extraordinary keyboard and organizational facility, devoted himself to avantgarde music of the day and performed it with devotion and authority.

title: Rural Medicine
Duke 102, Davidson 51
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C. Jan. 5 (AP)Davidson led for eight minutes tonight, then collapsed and was routed by Duke, 10251.

title: Barry Likely to Retire; Finds Fault With N.B.A:
description: Rick Barry says he'll most likely retire after this season, according to an Associated Press report, and he's not happy about the game he is leaving.

title: Article 1  No Title
SeaLand to Pay U.S. $4 Million As Rebate Fine
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5SeaLand Service Inc. agreed today in a settement with the Federal Maritime Commission to pay a $4 million penalty for making more than $19 million in rebates to customers. It was the largest civil penalty ever assessed by a transportation regulatory agency in the United States.

title: 54 Hurt in British Road Collision
description: RAINWORTH, England, Jan. 5(AP) Two school buses and a truck collided today in Nottinghamshire, killing the truck driver and injuring 54 persons, mostly children, the police said. Sixteen children and the driver of one of the buses, were hospitalized, six of them in critical condition. The accident happened as the children were being taken to school at this Midlands town.

title: Exit Routes Closing for Indochina Refugees
description: SONGKHLA, Thailand, Jan. 1One day late this month, the captains of four small Vietnamese fishing boats plan to set out from this southern Thai port with 80 to 100 refugees for a 3,000mile voyage across the South China Sea to Australia.

title: Saudi Arabia Is Stepping Up Arms Purchases in the United States
description: Saudi Arabia's multibillion dollar arms purchases from the United States have expanded to include some of the most advanced weapons such as shiptoshore or shiptoship missiles, high speed laserguided bombs and antiradar missiles.

title: Brazil, in 76, Doubled 75 Coffee Earnings
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 5 (AP)Brazil more than doubled its coffee export earnings in 1976 although the volume exported increased only by about 7 percent, according to figures announced today.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Notes on People column yesterday, Lowell Thomas Jr. was erroneously identified as the Lieutenant Governor of Hawaii. He is the Lieutenant Governor of Alaska.

title: Radio
description: 102 WMCA: Sally Jessy Raphael. Mimi Sheraton, restaurant critic for The New York Times; Juan Metzger, of Dannon Yogurt.

title: Assassination Panel Is Warned on Its Techniques
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5The chairman of the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Civil and Constitutional Rights has warned that some of the proposed investigative techniques of the House Select Committee on Assassinations would be wrong, immoral and very likely illegal.

title: L. I. U. 81, Canisius 57
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 5 (AP)Greg Winston and Kim Malcolm scored 17 points each to spark Long Island University to an 8157 victory over Canisius tonight.

title: Vietnam Reports Record Rice Yields
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 5 (Reuters)State farms in North Vietnam achieved record rice yields last year, the Vietnam press agency reported today. It said tea, tobacco and corn yields also set records and the state farms had met all the main goals of the state plan for 1976. The northern farms are to assist farms in the south this year, the agency said.

title: Chicago Tribune Editor Honored
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Jan. 5 (UPI)  Clayton Kirkpatrick, editor of The Chicago Tribune, was named today to receive the 1977 National Award for Journalistic Merit from the William Allen White Foundation.

title: Wall Poster Backing Teng,Ousted Leader, Is Put Up in Peking
description: PEKING, Thursday, Jan. 6A wall poster defending Teng Hsiaoping, the former Chinese Deputy Prime Minister who was ousted last year under pressure from party radicals, was displayed today on Peking's main street.

title: Schlosser Gets Top NBC Post
description: Herbert S. Schlosser, president and chief operating officer of the National Broadcasting Company since April 1974, yesterday was named chief executive.

title: Bangladesh Leader Leaves Peking
description: PEKING, Jan. 5 (Agence FrancePresse) The Bangladesh leader, Gen. Ziaur Rahman, left Peking today after signing the first cooperation agreements between his country and China. The agreements cover economic and technical cooperation, and trade and payments between the two countries.

title: Tanner Tops Roche; Ashe Also Victor
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 5 (AP) Roscoe Tanner beat Tony Roche and Arthur Ashe eliminated the surprising Hank Pfister in the $216,000 Australian open tennis championship today. Both winners reached the quarterfinals.

title: MOB CHIEF'S NEPHEW INDICTED IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Jan. 5A. Avram Apter, director of the Philip Apter and Sons Funeral Home in Maplewood, N.J., has been indicted on charges of attempting to defraud two insurance companies of more than $800,000 in a fake jewelrobbery scheme, the Essex County Prosecutor's office said yesterday.

title: Banned South African Journalist Flees Across Botswana Border
description: GABORONE, Botswana, Jan. 5 (Reuters) Eric Abraham, a South African journalist who was declared a banned person and placed under house arrest in Cape Town last November, arrived in Botswana today after escaping across the border.

title: Faulty Valve Blamed
description: PHILADEPHIA, Jan. 5The chief and second engineers of the Liberianregistered Olympic Games testified today that a malfunctioning valve caused a loss of maneuvering power a few minutes before the tanker veered shoreward and went aground off Marcus Hook, Pa., last week, spilling 134,000 gallons of oil into the Delaware River.

title: BIRD KILL IN CAPE MAY ATTRIBUTED TO POISON
description: TUCICAHOE, Jan. 5State wildlife experts said today that the death of more than 1,000 birds in a cornfield in Cape May County could have been caused by a poison spread on the ground to rid the area of blackbirds.

title: Soweto Schools Are Reopened And Boycott by Students Eases
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan 5 (Reuters)Schools in the black African township of Soweto reopened today, six months after bloody rioting began in protest over teaching practices.

title: Hotel Strike Talks Falter
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 5 (UPI)Representatives of striking hotel workers walked away from the bargaining table toray after only a brief resumption of contract negotiations to settle a 12day walkout. The talks were resumed after nearly a week without formal efforts to end the strike at eight hotels. After union negotiators left the meeting, which lastd about an hour, they moved into another office in the same building. A Federal mediator said that he would attempt some shuttle diplomacy to get the two parties back together.

title: Baker Credits Freshmen Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5For Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. the turning point in his surprising election yesterday as Senate minority leader came at a breakfast meeting Monday with most of the eight freshmen Republican Senatorsa meeting to which he had not been officially invited.

title: Democrats in House Fill Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP)Irvine H. Sprague was named today to be executive director of the House Democratic Steering and Policy Committee. For five years, Mr. Sprague headed the staff of the House majority whip. Previously he had ben deputy director of finance for the State of California, special assistant to President Johnson and a director of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The steering committee is the principal executive body of the Democratic Party in the House.

title: Chief Operations Officer Named At Times Syndication Sales Corp.
description: J. Willard Colston has been named executive vice president and editorial director of The New York Times Syndication Sales Corporation. Mr. Colston, who is 40 years old, will be chief operations officer of Syndication Sales, the syndicate affiliate of The New York Times Company.

title: SeaLand to Pay U.S. $4 Million As Rebate Fine
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5SeaLand Service Inc. agreed today in a settement with the Federal Maritime Commission to pay a $4 million penalty for making more than $19 million in rebates to customers. It was the largest civil penalty ever assessed by a transportation regulatory agency in the United States.

title: Manhattan Beats Brown, 8168; Grant Sets Pace With 31 Points
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 5 (AP)Steve Grant hit a career high of 31 points and grabbed 17 rebounds tonight in leading Manhattan to an 8168 basketball victory over Brown.

title: Alabama 83, Florida 71
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP)Robert Scott scored 6 straight points to give fourthranked Alabama breathing room over Florida and the Crimson Tide went on to an 8371 Southeastern Conference victory tonight.

title: BOARD OF EDUCATION ACCUSED OF COVERUP
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn accused the Board of Education yesterday of having tried to cover up the payment of nearly $70,000 in fictitious overtime to a substitute teacher in Community School District 23, in the Ocean HillBrownsville area of Brooklyn.

title: CARTER BACKS MOVE FOR EUROPE PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5State Department officials said today that Presidentelect Carter has informed President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France that he agreed in principle with his proposal for a summit meeting among leading Western economic powers but that no time or place has been set.

title: Frank Wright's Saxophone Warms Ali's Alley
description: Frank Wright, who is making a rare New York appearance this week at Ali's Alley, 77 Greene Street in SoHo, seems to invest his entire being in his tenor saxophone solos. The jazz he plays was sometimes referred to as energy music during the 1960's, and although the term is vaguemusicians who play other types of music also invest a great deal of energy in their workit is appropriate in Mr. Wright's case. The saxophonist sometimes seems to get so caught up in the physicality of his playing that he breaks into little dance steps in the middle of a solo.

title: Syracuse 87, Fordham 68
description: Syracuse surged in the second half last night to defeat Fordham, 8768, at the Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: S.E.C. Gives No Recommendations In Study on Banks Stock Activities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5The Securities and Exchange Commission published today a preliminary report of its staff's inquiry into the securities activities of commercial banks. The report, which makes no legislative recommendations, consists of statistical analyses of four bank activities similar to services offered by brokers.

title: Advertising
description: Leaving his family, friends and even his advertising agency behind, Michael A. Cohen will soon be traveling far (over 4,900 miles) for the company he loves, Mutual of New York. And he'll do it without any complaining because that's the kind of a guy he isloyal, trustworthy and true.

title: Alice Dutcher Performs Song Cycle by Pouhne
description: Alice Dutcher, a mezzosoprano who made her New York debut in 1974, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night for another recital. Accompanied by Max Walmer, she offered songs by Rossini and Wolf, J. F. Pouhne's The Amorous Line, which is a cycle of sonnets by Edna St. Vincent Millay, and, with the additional assistance of the Primavera String Quartet, Chausson's Chanson Perpetuelle.

title: Soviet Announces Grain Harvest Set Record in 1976
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 5The Soviet Union announced today that its 1976 grain harvest had totaled a record 223.8 million metric tonsa dramatic rebound from the drought and crop failure of the previous year.

title: Bullet to Be Tested
description: DALLAS, Jan. 5 (AP)A bullet discovered two years ago near the site of President Kennedy's assassination in 1963 will be compared with those fired from the rifle that the Warren Commission said was used to kill President Kennedy, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Rutgers 89, Penn State 72
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 5 (AP) James Bailey poured in a careerhigh 28 points to lead Rutgers to an 8972 rout of Penn State tonight.

title: 2 A.M.C. Officers Got Raises Despite Loss
description: DETROIT, Jan. 5 Despite a substantial increase in losses for the 1976 fiscal year, the two top executives of the financially shaky American Motors Corporation received pay raises for that year, according to the company's stockholder proxy statement, released today.

title: Vikings and Raiders Map Strategies To Shorten Road to the Super Bowl
People in Sports
description: Fans of the Yomiuri Giants can relax. Sadaharu Oh, Japanese baseball's homerun king, signed his 1977 contract yesterday with the Tokyo club.

title: A TAX SHELTER BAN IS VETOED BY SIMON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5A proposed new regulation that would have eliminated a major tax shelter enjoyed by builders was ordered withdrawn today by the Secretary of the Treasury only hours after it was published by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson 64, Iona 62
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 5  Jay Jorgensen, a 6foot5inch forward, scored 24 points tonight to spark Fairleigh Dickinson University to a 6462 triumph over Iona.

title: Australia's Embattled Marsupials Bounce Back
description: MELBOURNE, AustraliaThe tide appears to have turned for the embattled marsupials, from the strapping kangaroos to cuddly koalas and tiny planigales, whose young are no larger than a rice grain.

title: TV: WNET Showing Haunting Gardener's Son
description: A few years ago, Richard Pearce, a film documentarian whose credits include those of associate producer and cameraman on Hearts and Minds, the Academy Awardwinning examination of the Vietnam war, came across a biographical footnote about a young man who murdered an industrialist in a South Carolina village of the 1870's. Pursuing the story, he found that the incident, lacking clear motivation, had become a legend in the tiny mill town.

title: Executive of Colgate Is Due to Be Named Seagram President
description: The Seagram Company Ltd., the world's largest distiller, is expected to announce today the election of Philip E. Beekman, president of the ColgatePalmolive Company's international division, as president and chief operating officer of Seagram, the parent company, and of Joseph R. Seagram & Son Inc., the American subsidiary.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: California: DivorceYourself Brings a Backlash
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5Lynn and David wanted an inexpensive divorce, so they decided to do the legal work themselves.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Last Fugitive Captured

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 6, 1977

title: Latitude Predicted In New Restrictions On Foreign Doctors
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he believed that the Department of Health, Education and Welfare would use restrictions on the recruitment of foreign medical school graduates as interns and residents for hospitals in this country.

title: John J. P. Murphy, an Executive With Stock Brokerage Concern
description: John J. P. Murphy, who retired five years ago as vice president, general manager and partner of Laird, Bissell & Meeds, stock brokers in New York City, died of a heart attack Monday at his home at 1035 Park Avenue. He was 78 years old.

title: Iran Sees 10% Sales Lag Because of Its Costlier Oil
description: The National Iranian Oil Company reported yesterday that it expects sales in 1977 to run about 10 percent below expected levelsequivalent to $6 million per day in lost revenueafter the decision by Saudi Arabia to impose a more moderate price increase.

title: Notes on People
description: Bernard Bergman, the nursing home operator, is back in his West Side apartment, after his quiet release Monday from a minimum security Federal prison in Allenwood, Pa. His troubles stemming from a multimilliondollar Medicaid fraud are not ended, however.

title: Holdings of Vatican And Taxes It Pays Stir Dispute in Italy
description: ROME, Jan. 5A lively dispute has erupted here over the vast realestate holdings of the Vatican, which has been accused of owning 25 percent of the city of Rome and earning immense taxfree profits through property speculation.

title: Chilly Rain Hits Phoenix For Start of 77 Golf Tour
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 5While much of the country is coping with ice, snow and record low temperatures, the 1977 tour of the Professional Golfers Association43 events for more than $9 million in pursesis ready to start here tomorrow.

title: Carter's Agenda: Africa
description: BOSTON, Jan. 5 If one looks around the world today with an eye for what could become areas of danger to the Carter Administration, the most likely trouble spot may well be southern Africa. The clashes of race and ideology there, already violent, have about them the feeling of inevitable escalation.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation, which reluctantly agreed to sell the Peabody Coal Company under threat of Federal fines for delaying a courtordered divestiture, is now being sued by a shareholder who charges Kennecott with fraudulently denying shareholders the right to vote on the plan.

title: North Carolina 91, Clemson 63
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Jan. 5 (AP)With Coach Dean Smith watching the entire second half as a spectator, sixthranked North Carolina routed Clemson

title: New York City Funds Are Denied For Mental Rehabilitation Center
description: Acting on strong neighborhood protests against a rehabilitation center for former mental patients on 86th Street near Central Park West, the New York City Board of Estimate moved last night to deny city funds to the center while it remained at the controversial location.

title: Justice Department Taking Look at Murdoch's Magazine Takeover
description: The Department of Justice is taking a preliminary look at the proposed acquisition of the New York Magazine Company by Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, sources in the Federal department said yesterday.

title: Gold Prices Drop on Rumors of Heavy Selling by Peking and Moscow
description: Persistent rumors that both Peking and Moscow were selling gold to European dealers in largerthannormal quantities melted prices of gold futures in all markets yesterday, and tended to drag down silver values as well.

title: Snow Cancels Bowie Racing
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 5 (AP)Bowie canceled today's thoroughbred racing card because of snow.

title: About New York
description: Mr. Laws tells spellbinding stories about the night the rats danced in the street outside the old Ruppert brewery. And a nimble man named Lucky lobs ratpoison briquets into the gutted tenements like a grenadier in wartime Berlin. And Mr. Davis has to use a pickax to crack into backyard piles of airmailed garbage four and five feet deep where the rats despoilgreat blankets of organic matter, a slum of manna for the rats.

title: State Funds to Help Children's Theater
description: To stimulate the writing of plays for young peoplean area in the theater that the New York State Council on the Arts finds lackingthe council is offering a series of cash grants to theater groups to use to commission new works by playwrights.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTON  A lengthy catandmouse game between the country's largest banks and their Federal regulators is threatening to become a fierce fight over the banks rights to what is, for them, relatively new and unguarded territory.

title: News Summary
description: Some Vietnamese refugees in Thailand are planning a 3,000mile voyage in fishing boats to Australia because they have little hope of any other way to a new life in a Western country. Escape from Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia is increasingly difficult, and countries that have been accepting refugees are increasingly reluctant to do so. [Page 1, Columns 24.]

title: Seton Hall 81, Bucknell 68
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 5Greg Tynes, with 25 points, led Seton Hall University to an 8168 victory over Bucknell University tonight. Tynes had seven field goals and 11 free throws in 13 attempts. The Bisons were led by Bob Barry's 22 points.

title: John T. Howell, 85, a Pediatrician
description: Dr. John Taylor Howell, for 56 years a leading pediatrician and teacher in New York City, died Tuesday in Huntington (L.I.) Hospital after a short illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Murdoch's Purchase of Magazine Made With New York Post Funds
description: Rupert Murdoch used assets of The New York Post to pay for the major part of what he calls his controlling interest in the New York Magazine Company.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Westway Approval Will Be Reviewed In Carter's Term
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5The incoming Carter Administration says that it will review the $1.16 billion Westway highway project for Manhattan, which was approved yesterday by President Ford's Secretary of Transportation, William T. Coleman Jr.

title: Extortionist Chinese Youth Gangs Said to Peril Queens Restaurants
description: Chinese gangs, whose members range in age from the low teens to the upper 20's, are extorting money from owners of Chinese restaurants in Queens, District Attorney John J. Santucci said yesterday.

title: Sullivan Areas, the First Snowmakers, Are Flourishing in a Season of Scarcity
description: SOUTH FALLSBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 5 This has been a season in which skiers enjoying the sport at some of the giantsized areas in New England and upper New York have cause to thank this southern Catskill Mountain countryoften joshingly referred to as The Banana Belt. For it was in this Sullivan County region that machinemade snow was first produced, on a practical basis more than two decades ago. This innovation was begun on the modest slopes of Kiamesha Lake's Concord Hotel. Soon, nearby Grossingers was in the ski business on a similar basis.

title: Army to Let Ousted Cadets Return, But Not Under Borman's Formula
description: WEST POINT. N.Y., Jan. 5West Point cadets ousted in last year's cheating scandal will be permitted to return, but not until this summer, Army Secretary Martin R. Hoffmann said today, thereby rejecting the major recommendation of the Borman Commission that the cadets be readmitted as soon as possible.

title: ONSLOW STEVENS, CHARACTER ACTOR
description: Onslow Stevens, whose stage and screen career spanned more than three decades, was found dead yesterday in a Van Nuys, Calif., nursing home, where he had been a patient. He was 70 years old. The Los Angeles coroner's office said the cause of death was under investigation.

title: Rich Schools, Poor Schools
description: Superior teachers may occasionally do more for children in ramshackle schools than incompetent teachers in educational palaces. And yet, the romanticor miserly notion that money makes no difference does not stand the test of reality. When, as currently in New York State, some school districts can barely afford $1,000 a year per pupil, while others spend more than $6,000, not even the best teachers can overcome the handicap.

title: Carter's First Step to Prohibit Conflict of Interest in Government
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Jan. 5All through his campaign for the Presidency, Jimmy Carter promised that if elected he would issue strict guidelines prohibiting conflicts of interest to end what he termed a sweetheart relationship between the Federal regulatory agencies and the industries they regulate and to restore the confidence of the American people in public officials. The guidelines issued here yesterdaywhich his aides called a first step toward fulfilling that promiseare broader and stronger than those that now exist and were applauded by John Gardner, the head of the public affairs lobby Common Cause, as a major breakthrough in the fight to eliminate conflicts of interest in the executive branch.

title: Former TrainerHandler Exchanges Leash for Reins
description: In our daytoday experiences, we often hear of someone going to the dogs, but seldom do we hear of someone going from the dogs to the horses. For four decades, Lois Meistrell thoroughly enjoyed many phases of the dog show world while she was living on Long Island, but she never seemed to have enough time for riding her horse. Now that her Dalmatian and dachshund champions have passed on from old age, she's ,enjoying the Green Mountain trails in Vermont with her gelding, Uncle, and is a member of the Bennington County Mounted Posse Drill Team.

title: Famous Last Words
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5An observer on a planet 200 lightyears away may at this momentview the American Revolution. In the same way, Westerners watching China aretodaylearning what happened last year at the start of what Chinese broadcasters are calling a civil war.

title: Money
Maccabiah Tennis Trials Start Here on Monday
description: Tennis players from many parts of the country are coming here for the qualifying tournament to represent the United States at the Maccabiah Games in Israel next July.

title: Traffic Toll Record Is Best in 12 Years
description: TRENTON, Jan. 5 (AP)New Jersey had its best highway safety record in 12 years in 1976, Governor Byrne said today.

title: Solace for Humphrey: Senate Democrats Give Him a $7,450 Pay Rise, a Chauffeured Limousine and New Title
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5Senate Democrats today gave Hubert H. Humphrey a. $7,450 raise, a chauffeured limousine, entree to White House leadership meetings and a new title: Deputy President pro tem of the Senate.

title: Knicks Lose To Rockets By 108107
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 5Walt Frazier slumped in front of his locker, head buried in his palms. For one of the few times in his career, he refused a request for an interview.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Congress Plans New Legislation to Curb Oil Spills
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5Members of Congress from coastal states, amid growing concern over a series of oil spills and accidents involving Liberianflag tankers, are proposing new legislation aimed at curbing spills and are scheduling hearings on the Argo Merchant disaster.

title: DR. THOMAS W. HOPKINS, A RETIRED EDUCATOR, 82
description: Dr. Thomas W. Hopkins, who retired in 1958 as principal and director of cardiac and orthopedic education at the A. Harry Moore School in Jersey City, died Tuesday in Alexian Brothers Hospital in Elizabeth, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived at 440 Jersey Avenue, Elizabeth.

title: Panel Clears I.R.S. on Miami Inquiry
description: A Federal grand jury has reported that intelligence agents of the Internal Revenue Service did not violate the civil rights of taxpayers during a highly publicized sex and drinking investigation in Miami known as Operation Leprechaun.

title: A Lebanese Leader Sees Communist Role In Bomb Death of 40
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 5 (Reuters)Camille Chamoun, a former President of Lebanon, said today he suspected that Communists were behind a carbomb explosion that killed more than 40 people in Christian east Beirut, according to the Phalangist Party's radio station.

title: Exit Routes Closing for Indochina Refugees
description: SONGKHLA, Thailand, Jan. 1One day late this month, the captains of four small Vietnamese fishing boats plan to set out from this southern Thai port with 80 to 100 refugees for a 3,000mile voyage across the South China Sea to Australia.

title: Economists Find Pause Ending; Growth Projections for'77 Raised
description: The recent advance of several important economic indicators has convinced many private American economists that the socalled pause in the nation's economic recovery from the deepest recession since World War II is now ending and that growth this year may be somewhat stronger than they had expected earlier.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON Jan. 5The New Jersey Register, an official monthly state publication that sets the record straight on government red tape, set a record this month.

title: Latin Playwrights Get Foothold
description: For weeks Carla Pinza, the actress, has been nursing new plays through their growing pains at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater on the Lower East Side. But they are plays with a difference. They are plays that have a lot riding on them because, if everything goes well, Miss Pinza says with her fingers crossed, gifted Latino playwrights will have a chance to get their work before the public and, hopefully, produced.

title: Lagos Hairstyles Reflect African History (and the Afro Is a PutOn Wig)
description: LAGOS, NigeriaWhen a woman says One Nigeria these days, she is not repeating a political sloganshe is giving instructions to her hairdresser.

title: Environmental Factors in Cancer Are Hinted in Atlas on Nonwhites
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5The evidence linking environmental factors with cancer appears to be strengthened by a new atlas showing variation in cancer death rates from region to region among nonwhites.

title: Campisi's Nephew Indicted in Jewelry Theft Fraud
description: NEWARK, Jan. 5A. Avram Apter, a director of the Philip Apter and Sons Funeral Home in Maplewood, N.J., has been indicted on charges of attempting to defraud two insurance companies of more than $800,000 in a fake jewelrobbery scheme, the Essex County Presecutor's office said yesterday.

title: Carter a Trilateralist
description: The Trilateral Commission, a research and policy group that calls itself a group of private citizens of Western Europe, Japan and North America whose aim is to foster closer cooperation among those three regions, has had as members Presidentelect Carter and some of his key advisers. Page 41.

title: Leading Moscow Dissident Is Questioned
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 5 (Reuters)The leader of a dissident group set up to monitor Soviet observance of the Helsinki accords was seized on the street today and questioned for seven hours by justice officials.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Notes on People column yesterday, Lowell Thomas Jr. was erroneously identified as the Lieutenant Governor of Hawaii. He is the Lieutenant Governor of Alaska.

title: British Push Rhodesia Plan, Salisbury Keeps. Talking, but Still the Solution Recedes
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 5When Ivor Richard of Britain sat down at the weekend to discuss a Rhodesian peace settlement with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, it was not long before the two men became embroiled in what Mr. Richard calls a good verbal punchup over the role that Britain is playing in negotiations over majority rule.

title: Webb Wilson Dies on L.I.; Retired Banker and Executive
description: Webb Wilson, a retired investment banker, died Tuesday at Southampton, L. I., Hospital. He was 77 years old and a resident of East Hampton, L. I.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT BUFFALO

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Justice Department Issues Curbs To Bar Crimes by F.B.I. Informers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5The Justice Department today issued formal administrative guidelines designed to prevent future abusive and illegal acts on the part of undercover informers controlled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and to balance the use of informers against the possibility that their presence might stifle free speech and association.

title: My Name's John Madden, I'm the Coach
Group to Remap Council Districts
description: A ninemember independent, nonpartisan commission to redraw councilmanic lines for the next election was formally selected yesterday by the New York City Council.

title: Carey Calls for Altered Formula For Financing Mental Health Care
description: ALBANY. Jan. 5Governor Carey today complemented his call for continued fiscal caution with a reaffirmation of his interest In aiding persons legitimately in need of government assistance and outlined new proposals for dealing with the mentally disabled juvenile delinquents and the aged.

title: Shell and Esso Give Britain Rights To Obtain 51% of North Sea Oil Find
description: LONDON, Jan. 5Britain's Department of Energy released today the agreement by which it plans to become a 51 percent owner of North Sea oil production now belonging to Shell U.K. Ltd. and the Esso Petroleum Company. The arrangement; expected to be complted within three months, is similar to settlements reached with other oil companies and is aimed at reserving supplies of North Sea oil to Britain.

title: Goldwater Bars G.O.P. Fund Role
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI)President Ford and three other Republican leaders split today over selection of a new national party chairman, while the 1964 Republican Presidential candidate, Senator Barry Goldwater, withdrew his future fundraising support because he was left out of the meeting.

title: Companies and Their Reports of Earnings
description: For periods ended Nov. 30 unless otherwise indicatd. (N) indicatos stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) over the counter.

title: In Memoriam
description: REUBENMortimore F. Beloved husband of Beatrice, devoted father and grandfather who left us 8 years ago today, but who lives in our hearts always. Beatrice Reuben and Family.

title: Panamanian Ship Feared Lost
description: BOSTON, Jan. 5The prospects of finding the missing Panamanian tanker Grand Zenith diminished today as the United States and Canadian Coast Guards expanded the air and sea search to a 100,000squaremile area in the Atlantic Ocean east of Cape Cod and south of Nova Scotia.

title: Ceilings of Asbestos Are Ordered Removed in Six Schools in Howell
description: HOWELL TOWNSHIP, Jan. 5Potentially hazardous coatings. of insulating material containing asbestos, a possible cancercausing agent, were ordered removed today from ceilings in six elementary schools here, as state officials sought to determine how many other schools and public buildings built after 1950 contain similar coatings.

title: Blank Checks and Fearful Fantasies
description: In principle, there are now sound reasons for the House of Representatives to go forward with its investigation of the assassinations of President Kennedy and Martin Luther King. The murder in Dallas has generated a whole folklore of blurred figures and shadowy conspiracies. Disclosure last fall that the F.B.I. and C.I.A. withheld information from the Warren Commission has raised new questions. In the case of the King assassination, there has been no public investigation at all.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 5, 1977

title: Lead Price Raised
description: The price of lead increased to 26.5 cents a pound yesterday, a rise of  cent a pound for most products. Page 43.

title: Miss Yoshimura Cited by Judge For Contempt
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 5  Wendy Yoshimura testified in her defense today and was cited five times for contempt of court for refusing to answer questions about her life in the underground.

title: Not Guilty Pleas Entered by Two In Mandel JuryTampering Cases
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 5 (AP)  Walter Weikers and Charles E. Neisswender have pleaded not guilty to separate jurytampering charges in connection with alleged efforts to influence the outcome of the political corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel. A mistrial was declared.

title: Hamilton Wins Speaker's Post, Overcoming an Unusual Challenge
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Jan. 5William J. Hamilton, a 44yearold lawyer and the majority leader of the New Jersey Assembly, weathered a challenge by three other Democrats tonight to win in all but a formal sense the post of Assembly Speaker.

title: CAREY ASKS TAX CUT AND A NEW BOND ISSUE FOR WORKS PROJECTS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 5Governor Carey surprised the Legislature today by asking for an immediate $200 million cut in the state's personal, income tax and a $750 million bond issue to finance jobproducing construction projects starting next year.

title: Music: Boulez Leads Takemitsu
description: Pierre Boulez, in last night's Avery Fisher Hall concert of the New York philharmonic, took care to surround a fairly controversial work with two breadandbutter pieces. Toru Takemitsu's Arc for piano and orchestra was surrounded by Haydn's Symphony No. 104 and the Beethoven Fifth. That at least kept most of the customers in their seats. There was none of the paniclike exodus that so often occurs when an avantgarde work is programmed.

title: Carter Aide Ruled Out for Key Post
