description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 5A valued young assistant to Presidentelect Carter who had been expected to become the White House appointments secretary will not he given the post because a routine security check by the Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed that he., might have been involved in financial irregularities, a Carter spokesman said tonight.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, Jan, 5, 1977

title: 2 CHEMISTS RETRACT PEST CONTROL STUDY
description: After exhaustive study, two young chemists have retracted the highly controversial conclusion of an earlier investigation that disrupted a major new area of pest control research.

title: Syria Said to Promise It Will Ease Restrictions on Jewish Community
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5Syrian authorities have promised a significant relaxation of discriminatory restrictions against the 4,500 Jews in their country, a Democratic Congressman from Brooklyn reported today.

title: A TAX SHELTER BAN IS VETOED BY SIMON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5A proposed new regulation that would have eliminated a major tax shelter enjoyed by builders was ordered withdrawn today by the Secretary of the Treasury only hours after it was published by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: EAST BERLIN VISITORS NOW MUST PAY A FEE
description: EAST BERLIN, Jan. 5Mehmet Soglaclu, a Turkish migrant worker in West Berlin, got an unpleasant surprise this morning when he crossed the border into East Berlin to visit his friend and have lunch.

title: New Legislator's First Day Is Like Beginning of School
description: ALBANY, Jan.5The opening of a legislative session is very like the first day of school, and one of the freshest freshmen in Albany yesterday was Assemblyman Clifford E. Wilson, a 30yearold DemocratLiberal of Queens. His mother cried, he buttoned up the vest of his new brown suit wrong and his wife got very nervous about meeting the Governor.

title: FORD APPROVES EXCHANGE OF PAN AMT.W.A. ROUTES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP)President Ford approved today an already implemented route swap agreement between Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines.

title: Martin of N.Y.A.C. Wins Mile at Armory
description: Bill Martin, one of the top halfmilers in the country last year while a freshman at Boston College, has switched his allegiance to Iona College and the New York A.C. this year. Last night he also switched distances at the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior indoor track and field championships and the result was a victory for him in the mile run.

title: Caso Wins Two Small Skirmishes In Naming of an Acting Attorney
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 5County Executive Ralph G. Caso, who is fighting his party for political survival, won two small skirmishes today in his efforts to name an acting county attorney.

title: Sales of New Cars Surged 17% in 1976
description: DETROIT, Jan. 5Newcar sales in the United States rebounded to 10.1 million last year, up 17 percent from 8.6 million in 1975, reports from the domestic and imported auto makers showed today. Sales last year were the fourth best for the automakers and were 1.3 million behind the 1973 record of 11.4 million.

title: Car Sales Aided by Easy Terms; Loans Range Up to 48 Months
description: With sales of new carsdomestic and importedup 17 percent in 1976 to 10.1 million, some of the credit, it appears, must be shared with the suppliers of credit.

title: Robert M. Holley Sr., 63, Dies; Executive of Advertising Agency
description: Robert M. Holley Sr., president of Holley, Thomas Inc., an advertising agency in Williston Park, L.I., and a former cartoonist for Esquire magazine, died Tuesday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L.I., after a sudden illness. He lived at 10 Ridge Road, East Williston, and was 63 years old.

title: Aquarium Whale Is PregnantPerhaps
description: Amy Lou, the youngest and newest of the New York Aquarium's four white whales, is believed to be about midway in a pregnancy that could produce a 50orsopound calf next May to July.

title: Dow Down 9.81 As Stocks Drop On Broad Front
description: Stock prices dropped sharply across a broad front yesterday in steppedup trading, with particularly sizable losses in many of the bluechip and glamour issues.

title: Bridge:
description: American representation in the world team championship, scheduled in Manila next October, will depend on the result of two matches being played in Houston. In the first match, which began last night, four reigning world champions may be fighting an uphill battle.

title: J. RANDOLPH DIES IN TOKYO; NEWSMAN COVERED 2 WARS
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 5 (AP)John Robert Randolph, a longtime foreign correspondent and a former news executive of The Associated Press, was found dead in his Tokyo apartment today. He was 57 years old.

title: Economists Find Pause Ending; Growth Projections for77 Raised
description: The recent advance of several important economic indicators has convinced many private American economists that the socalled pause in the nation's economic recovery from the deepest recession since World War II is now ending and that growth this year may be somewhat stronger than they had expected earlier.

title: Spare Tires Missing On Many New Cars
description: DETROIT, Jan. 5Over half a million new car and lighttruck owners around the country are still without spare tires even though the fourmonth rubber industry strike ended list summer, an auto industry survey showed today.

title: MRS. GRASSO PRESSES CONSOLIDATION PLANS
description: HARTFORD, Jan 5Gov. Ella T. Grasso today asked for a consolidated, reorganized administration for public higher education in Connecticut, a single agency for budget planning, a single agency for revenueproducing activities, the means for more closely overseeing the state's various forms of legal gambling and better tools for controlling organized crime.

title: Why Single Out Teachers?
description: When it comes to taxes, one person's sound social policy may well be another's loophole. Thus, there is a strong temptation to discount the outcry in the academic community against a change in regulations proposed by the Internal Revenue Service. The I.R.S. wants to start collecting income tax on the value of the free or reduced tuition traditionally given children of college faculty members. Some 27,000 students now attend college on such scholarships; these are worth about $20 million.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Welter Reade Organization, Inc., a motion picture theater operator, announced yesterday that it had filed in New York a petition for an arrangement under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act.

title: Future Shaky at Hall of Fame
description: The winter wind courses through the Hall of Fame for Great Americans high above the Harlem River, whistling past 95 bare heads cast in bronze and one with a hat, William Penn. All the rest is silence in the open, 630foot GrecoRoman colonnade on the old University Heights campus of New York University, now occupied by Bronx Community College.

title: A Light Snow Puts Capital On the Skids
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5When it snows it rains troubles on Washington, a Southern city in clime and temperament that has never learned to cope with such Northern caprices as today's twoinch snowfall.

title: British Envoy Expresses Hope Botswana Backs Rhodesia Plan
description: GABORONE, Botswana, Jan. 5 (Reuters) Ivor Richard of Britain, chairman of the Geneva conference on Rhodesia, said today he might have won the approval of Botswana's President for what would be designed as a steadying British presence in Rhodesia during the transition to black majority rule.

title: Gas From a Leaky Main Explodes and Kills Woman
description: FAIRVIEW, Jan. 5An explosion and fire caused by a leaking gas main destroyed a small embroidery shop in this commercial community of Bergen County today, killing the wife of the owner and critically injuring him.

title: CAREY ASKS TAX CUT AND A NEW BOND ISSUE FOR WORKS PROJECTS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 5Governor Carey surprised the Legislature today by asking for an immediate $200 million cut in the state's personal income tax and a $750 million bond issue to finance jobproducing construction projects starting next year.

title: Garden Boxing Date Shifted
description: A boxing program scheduled for Madison Square Garden on Jan. 31 was changed yesterday to Wednesday, Feb. 2. The card of three 10rounders matches Harold Weston, Jr. against Wilfredo Benitez, Emile Griffith versus Christy Elliott and Pedro Soto against Pedro Agosto.

title: BEAME TO SEEK RISE IN REAL ESTATE TAX AND MORE JOB CUTS
description: Mayor Beame is proposing to overcome a budget deficit of at least $585 million in the next fiscal year by raising the New York City real estate tax, pressing for increased Federal and state assistance and reducing the work force by 8,200 more employeesincluding 1,500 police officersby attrition and without resorting to layoffs.

title: Hofstra 100, St. Francis (Pa.) 91;
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 5Rich Laurel, Ken Rood and John Irving combined for 77 points to lead Hofstra to a 100to91 victory over St Francis of Pennsylvania tonight in the Fairfield invitation tournament. The Dutchmen held a 4443 lead at the half but scored 11 straight points to put the game away with 13 minutes remaining. Laurel scored 22 of his gamehigh 32 points in the second session. Nick Leasure scored 31 points for St. Francis.

title: Calif. Quarterback Fights Malignant Growth Again
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 5 (AP)Joe Roth, the University of California quarterback, selected for three bowl games, has confirmed that he is fighting cancer for the second time in three years.

title: Rangers, Flyers in Tie (44) For Third Tithe in 3 Meetings
description: John Bowie Ferguson, the source of the New York Rangers emotional fervor this season, clenched his fist in frustration at the Philadelphia Flyers, who last night tied his club, 44, for the third time in three meetings this season. If it takes one hundred years, the Ranger coach vowed, I'll find a flaw there. Somewhere I'm gonna get them.

title: Peacemaking Patrolman Shot
description: BLOOMFIELD, NJ., Jan. 5 (AP)A patrolman was shot here yesterday while attempting to settle a domestic dispute between a Newark police officer and his wife, the police said Patrolman Joseph Livecchi, 29 years old, was shot when the Newark officer's service revolver went off as Patrolman Livecchi's partner, Patrolman Paul Ott, attempted to wrestle the gun from the officer's wife, the police said. Patrolman Livecchi was reported in good condition at Mountainside Hospital after an operation to remove a bullet from his left shoulder.

title: Soviet, Czechoslovakia Banned
description: LONDON, Jan. 5 (UPI)Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union were banned from tournaments today by the international Lawn Tennis Federation because they had not paid all the fines levied against them for withdrawing from the Federation Cup in Philadelphia last September.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Writes a Key Critic Saying Differences Can Be Resolved
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 5Prime Minister. Indira Gandhi, making a significant gesture, has written one of her leading political opponents expressing the hope that it would not be impossible to find solutions to the problems between opposition and Government.

title: $57 Million Tentative Settlement Drafted in Equity Funding Fraud
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5Stock and debenture owners who lost millions of dollars when Equity Funding, a Los Angelesbased financial services company, was destroyed by a securities fraud in 1973, are expected to receive a settlement totaling more than $57 million.

title: Leonard Silk
description: The Carter Administration will face two critical tasks on the international economic front: holding back a rising tide of protectionist barriers to trade, and building safeguards against international financial decay that could result from continuing balanteofpayments deficits by the weaker oilimporting countries. The people Mr. Carter has chosen as his principal international economic advisers and operators are strong believers in a liberal trade policy.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: News Summary
description: International

title: About Real Estate
description: The Internal Revenue Service was going about its business tightening up the tests for whether a business entity is truly a partnership rather than corporation. Then the housing people heard what was going on and in the last few days telephone wires started burning across the country, as one outsider put it.

title: LISBON COURT ACTION PROTESTED BY CROWD
description: LISBON, Jan. 6An angry crowd of workers and intellectuals protested today against the indulgence shown by the military courts toward the political police of the former Portuguese dictatorship.

title: HANSLUKAS TEUBER IS DEAD IN CARIBBEAN
description: A memorial service will be held Jana 19 for Dr. HansLukas Teuber, head of the department of psychology at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and leading authority. on the relationship between the brain and behavior, who disappeared Tuesday while swimming in the waters off Virgin Gorda in the British Virgin Islands.

title: TOP U.S. HEALTH AIDE WILL NOT BE KEPT ON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Despite heavy support from Democrats and special interest groups, Dr. Theodore Cooper has been told that he cannot keep his job as Assistant Secretary for Health in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare when the Carter administration takes over on Jan. 20.

title: China Reports Oil Production Up 13% Last Year
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 6China's oil production increased 13 percent last year, the Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, said today, a claim that analysts here calculate gave China a total output of 625.8 million barrels.

title: World Bank Team Goes to Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The World Bank has sent its first mission to Vietnam since the reunified country was accepted as a bank member in September, spokesman said today.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises 16.4%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 12.4 billion tonmiles, up 16.4 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 354,431, 12.9 percent above last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 15.7 percent from last year.

title: A. T. & T. ASKS A BAN ON TRIAL IN COURTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked the Supreme Court today to rule quickly that the courts have no jurisdiction in the Justice Department's antitrust suit against the Bell System.

title: Is It True What They Say About British Cooking? Not So, Two New Books Say
description: LONDON  Pithcaithly bannock. Figgie hobbin. Sweet marag. Inky pinky. Priddy oggies. Spotted dog. Cullen skink.

title: Guerrillas Opening New Front in North Against Rhodesia
description: KAPIBA Rhodesia. Jan. 6 (AP)Barely 60 miles from this lakeside resort town. where vacationers laze beneath the sun alongside swimming pools, scores of black nationalist guerrillas have been crossing into northern Rhodesia from Zambia to press their fight for racial majority rule.

title: Federal Judge Interrogates Captain On Course Before Nantucket Spill
description: Judge Thomas P. Griesa interrogated the captain of the oil tanker Argo Merchant yesterday as the first round of testimony about the tanker ended in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: My Two Legs Got to Stay On
description: My name is Otis Simmons and my two legs got to stay onI won't have the operation, I got to cure my own self, a 58yearold Alabamaborn derelict said at a bedside hearing called by Justice Hilda G. Schwartz of State Supreme Court, at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday.

title: Experience Is Best Teacher For Long Island City Quintet
description: Long Island City's nickname is the Stars, but it is experience and not star power that has brought L.I.C, to the top of its Queens division in basketball this season. Coach Floyd Bank has three starters and the first substitute returning from last season's team, which reached the Public Schools Athletic League semifinals.

title: Airline Offers Reward
description: Eastern Airlines is offering a $15,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of the murderer of a stewardess whose body was found in Bucks County, Pa.

title: People's Inaugural Will Include Solar Heating, But Not for Many
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6A block down Pennsylvania Avenue, a bank sign kept winking that it was 26 degrees this morning as construction workers stamped frigid feet outside the White House and prepared to install four solar heating units in the reviewing stand where Presidentelect Carter will watch his inaugural parade.

title: Top Republicans Unable to Agree On Filling Two Major Party Posts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The Republican Party still riven by factionalism, has made little or no progress toward choosoing nerd leaders in the two months since the 1976 election.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Jan. 6, 1977 Polition filed by:

title: Greek Primate Notes Epiphany With Old Ritual
description: A centuriesold ritualthe breaking of St. Basil's bread on Epiphanywas celebrated yesterday by Archbishop Iakovos, Primate of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America, before youngsters attending Holy Trinity Cathedral School.

title: House Pays Tribute to Rayburn
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI)The House paused briefly at the opening of today's session to pay tribute on his birthday to the late Speaker Sam Rayburn of Texas. Mr. Rayburn, born 95 years ago, died in 1961 after serving 48 years in the House, 19 as Speaker.

title: ONEMAN POLICE CARS PLANNED FOR SPRING
description: The New York City Police Department is planning to begin using oneman radio car patrols this spring, Commissioner Michael J. Codd disclosed yesterday.

title: Grand Jury Resumes Hoffa Investigation
description: DETROIT, Jan. 6 (UPI)A Federal grand jury has resumed its investigation of the disappearance in July 1975 of James R, Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, amid reports. that investigators are aiming for a public resolution of the case by next summer.

title: British Program to Lower Inflation And Provide New Jobs Is Outlined
description: LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP)A plan to cut inflation from 15 to 5 percent a year by mid1978 and to provide more than half million new jobs was outlined today by the Confederation of British Industry.

title: Notes on People
description: The new Soviet chief delegate to the United Nations presented his credentials yesterday, then called a news conference and answered questions in American English. Which was understandable, for the diplomat, Oleg Troyanovsky, spent his teenage years in the United States, when his father was the first Soviet Ambassador here, and attended a Quaker school in Washington. Complimented on his nearAmerican accent, Mr. Troyanovsky smnea and said he thought he had a Japanese accent as his last overseas assignment was a nineyear stint as envoy to Tokyo. At the mention of dtente, the diplomat laughed and said, Since the elections are over here, that is a word I suppose can be used again.

title: Art People
description: BECAUSE IT SEEMS to be losing a long tax battle with the Federal Government, the Frick Collection, that elegant mansion of masterpieces on upper Fifth Avenue, is charging admission for the first time in its 58year history. Last Tuesday, adults began paying $1; students and senior citizens 50 cents, for the privilege of gazing on the peerless works by Rembrandt, El Greco, Vermeer, Van Dyck & Co. that they had long admired for free.

title: Antiques
description: THE CONTRIBUTIONS of Connecticut's citizenry in enriching the decorative arts heritage of the nation has become apparent in: recent years as the state's museums, historical houses and societies have increasingly investigated the past.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Exxon Seeks LowerCost Saudi Oil
description: In a statement aimed at Venezuela's Mines Minister, the Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it was trying to use more lowercost Saudi Arabian oil to reduce reliance on higherpriced oil from Venezuela and 10 other oilproducing countries.

title: Miami News Attacks Grand Jury Report
description: MIAMI, Jan. 6 (AP)Howard Kleinberg, editor of The Miami News, branded as ludicrous today the contents of a still secret Federal grand jury's report on the Internal Revenue Service's intelligence operations here, as described in The New York Times.

title: Mitterrand Attacks Handling of Paris Murder Case
description: PARIS, Jan. 6The Socialist leader, Francois Mitterrand, attacked the administration of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing today for its handling of the case of the murder on Christmas Eve of Prince Jean de Broglie, a onceprominent political figure and supporter of Mr. Giscard d'Estaing's public career.

title: Paramount Broilers To Richard K. Manoff
description: Yesterday Dick Manoff happily Called fowl. And, why not. Cargill Inc., of Minneapolis has just assigned Richard K. Manoff its Paramount Broilers and Honeysuckle White Turkeys and announces at the same time that it plans to spend over $1 million for advertising this year. Green Dolmatch Inc. has been the Paramount agency.

title: Companies and Their Reports of Earnings
description: For periods ended Nov. 30 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) over the counter.

title: GENETIC RESEARCH BAN EXTENDED BY CAMBRIDGE
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 6 (UPI)The City Council has voted to extend a ban on genetic research for another month.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The nation's two largest steel companies appeared yesterday to be at least cautiously optimistic about this year's steel production.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
William Leonard, 64, Columnist; Worked on Chicago Newspapers
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (UPI)William Leonard, Chicago Tribune nightlife columnist, died today, in Augustana Hospital where he was admitted Dec. 28 suffering from a suspected stroke. He was 64 years old.

title: Article 5  No Title
Uganda Building At U.N. to Exceed That of the U.S.
description: Uganda has begun excavation work in Manhattan for a 15story headquarters for its United Nations delegation that would be three floors higher than its nextdoor neighbor, the building of the United States Mission.

title: Skiing Provides a New Lift For a 71YearOld Beginner
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Jan. 4Two weeks ago, 71yearold Alex Nessen, former owner of a nearby bungalow colony, strolled into Holiday Mountain's base lodge and told Vic Gordon, the area's manager, he wanted to learn

title: McGee Believed Set for O.A.S.Job; Favors Ending Panama Canal Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Presidentelect Carter has selected former Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, to be the United States representative in the Organization of American States, high Latin American diplomats said today.

title: RESULTS; (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)
description: (OTB payoffs sublect to 5% State tax) FIRST$4,000, pace, mile.

title: Haywood Hopes To Play for Knicks Tonight
description: Spencer Haywood learned how to use a new protective shield for his left leg yesterday in the doctor's office and in a workout at the West Side Y.M.C.A. Tonight the Knick forward will find out how well it works in the battles under the backboards. The Knick forward flew to Chicago to join the team for the game against the Bulls after being examined by Dr. James Nicholas, the team doctor.

title: Carter Ponders the Final Details Of Program to Spur the Economy
description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 6Presidentelect Carter considered the final details of an economic stimulation program today after one major Carter adviser expressed hope that it would not cost more than $15 billion so as to avoid, distressing public opinion as a result of massive additions to the budget deficit.

title: CapitalsWings Rescheduled
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 6 (AP)Sunday's National Hockey League game between the Washington Capitals and the Detroit Red Wings has been rescheduled to Monday to avoid a conflict with the Super Bowl, the N.H.L. office announced today.

title: 2 Works, 14 Debuts At Ballet Theater
description: For a company that was recently criticized for its heavy reliance on guest stars, American Ballet Theater is offering a highly democratic season at the City Center 55th Street Theater this month. During this weekend alone there will be six debuts in leading roles by the company's regular members.

title: Some widely expected events that did not happen
description: 1. Financial or economic collapse of Italy or Britain; the bankruptcy another really big United States company or bank (in addition to W. Grant and the Franklin Bank)such bankruptcies really shake the world's markets.

title: Coffee Price Rise Reasons: Sensible to Silly
description: One line from an old song keeps popping into mind when the chatter aL cocktail parties or bridge games gets around to the current topic of the day, the recent stratospheric rise in the price of coffee. It was a popular number in the 1940's, and the windup line was: They've got an awful lot of coffee in Brazil. No doubt they still do, because that South American country remains the world's largest supplier of this nation's favorite beverage, but, for the moment anyway, Brazil ain't what she used to be as a coffee producer. And that's one of the chief reasons why American consumers are now paying double or even triple what they paid for a pound of coffee only a year or two ago.

title: OneMan Mural Revival
description: IT HAS BEEN a long time since a serious painter working in the Realist tradition has been invited to undertake a major mural project for a Government building, especially a mural on the theme of the American worker. But this unusual eventlong associated with the Work Projects Administration programs of the 1930's, and distant indeed from the recent interests of the art worldhas now occurred. The startling result of this dramatic artistic turnabout will be on temporary exhibition in New York, starting tomorrow and every afternoon from 1 to 6. (including Sundays) through Jan. 16, at 85 Walker Street.

title: City U. Merger Opposed
description: A special commission appointed by Governor Carey said yesterday that it was opposed to the merger of the City University of New York and the State University into a single statewide system with a central administration and one board of trustees.

title: Suffolk Legislature Will Study Offshore Oil Drilling
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Jan. 6The Suffolk County Legislature's leadership today formed a committee to investigate the effects of oil drilling off the county's South Shore, but backed off from its earlier proposal that such a committee sever negotiations with oil companies that want to drill there.

title: Bishop Hanns A Lutheran Leader, Is Dead in Germany
description: HANOVER, West Germany, Jan. 6 (AP). Bishop Hanns Lilje, former president of the Lutheran Church's world movement and a noted German theologian, died in a hospital today. after a heart attack. He was 77 years old and had retired in 1969.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT CLEVELAND

title: Martins Bows as Director
description: Look, the usually selfconfident Peter Martins said with a shy smile. I'm very nervous and don't know what to say right now.

title: Empathies and Memories Inspire Donors to Neediest Cases
description: Staff members of Coed Magazine, church choir in Port Jervis, N. Y., and the Aloha Study Club of Manhattan were among the donors yesterday to the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Article 4  No Title
Liberals Scrap a Proposed Panel on Mayoral Race
description: Meeting for the first time since the death of Alex Rose, Liberal Party officials last night scrapped his last legacy, a special committee to look into the party's role in the mayoral race, for fear that such a committee would be too divisive at this time.

title: Trouble at Trotters: Too Few and Too Slow
description: Often these nights, the wind comes down the stretch faster than the horses at Yonkers Raceway and the Meadowlands. It is the winter of discontent in local harness racing.

title: Reserve Report
Commodity Price Index Increases 1.3 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 203.2 from 201.9 last week.

title: Namath Says He Wants Rams
description: Joe Namath said last night that he wanted to continue in professional football, but only if he could play for the Los Angeles Rams. The New York Jets quarterback, on NBC's Tonight Show, said, I hope it works out, if I do play the only place I'd play is Los Angeles. As for the Jets and their rebuilding program Namath said: I can't play under those circumstances . . . It would have to be here [Los Angeles] or that would be it for pro football.

title: People's Inauguration to Include Solar Heating, but Not for Many
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6A block down Pennsylvania Avenue, a bank sign kept winking that it was 26 degrees this morning as construction workers stamped frigid feet outside the White House and prepared to install four solar heating units in the reviewing stand where Presidentelect Carter will watch his inaugural Parade.

title: Schmidt Meets Premier And Opposition in Spain
description: MADRID, Jan. 6 (ReutersShancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany met Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez for the first time tonight after being briefed by the Spanish opposition on demands for amnesty and recognition of all political parties.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: RADIO
description: Music

title: Snow, Not the Longet Trial, Is the Major Topic in Aspen
description: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 6Aspen is not talking as much about Claudine Longet as it is about snow. The other night, when diners at the Ute City Banque Restaurant saw the first tentative flakes in weeks begin to fall, they broke into spontaneous cheers.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: ONEMAN POLICE CARS PLANNED FOR SPRING
description: The New York City Police Department is planning to begin using oneman radio car patrols this spring, Commissioner Michael J. Codd disclosed yesterday.

title: New Bond Issues
Death, Toll Now 10 In Brooklyn Blaze
description: The toll in a fire that destroyed a linen and giftware store in downtown Brooklyn on Dec. 22 rose to 10 yesterday as two additional bodies were found in the rubble.

title: BEAME OFFERS PLAN TO CLOSE THE DEFICIT IN 19771978 BUDGET
description: Mayor Beame formally presented yesterday his program to close New York City's remaining budget deficit, saying it would not sap the city's ability to deliver vital services, despite a projected reduction of an additional 7,500 employees through attrition rather than through layoffs.

title: Radio Data Using Vikings on Mars Further Confirm Einstein Theory
description: The most accurate longdistance measurements ever made, by means of radio signals between the Viking spacecraft on Mars and antennas on Earth, have produced new confirmation of Einstein's theory of relativity, a Viking project scientist reported yesterday.

title: The Sweet Science Is Alive and Well
description: Now that Muhammad Ali has bailed himself out of wedlock for $2 million, formal announcement that he has agreed to fight George Foreman can be expected any day. As a matter of fact, in a newsletter to the membership of the North American Boxing Federation, Robert L. Turley of Sacramento, Calif., president, reports that on Dec. 10 Herbert Muhammad, Ali's manager, told Jose Sulaiman, president of the World Boxing Council, that the champion would defend his title against Foreman before May 30 and several days later Muhammad All met with President Sulaiman personally and reconfirmed that fact. Pending reconfirmation, it is privilege to report that there is a lot more life left in the Sweet Science than some people think. The fact that Don King's

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (millions of dollars)

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Jan. 6Governor Byrne and State Education Commissioner Fred G. Burke urged today in a letter to all 607 school districts that all asbestos fibers be removed from the state's 2,500. public. schools as a health measure.

title: Three Kings and Santa Vie for Puerto Rican Favor
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 6Puerto Rico's children received their Christmas presents today as a controversy went on over the steady encroachment being made by Santa Claus into the role of the Three Kings.

title: Restaurants
description: ALTHOUGH many restaurants lay claim originality in the dishes they serve, all too often, the only original features of such specialties are their names. It is, therefore, a pleasant and encouraging surprise to come upon a restaurant with a cuisine that is truly original, inventive and delicious, and that is, as a bonus, moderately priced, That is exactly the combination one finds at the EastWest Restaurant on East Ninth Street near Park Avenue South.

title: Four Harps Without a Glissando
description: What I wanted was to eliminate this ghastly idea that the harp only plays glissandos with the orchestra, or only arpeggios, explains Aristid von Wurtzler. I was looking for a new image.

title: Charlotte Bronte: Evolving Feminine Awareness
description: Charlotte Bront's star has been on the rise in our day for reasons other thin her novelistic gifts. Favored neither with the bright wit of Jane Austen (who preceded her) nor the psychological depth of George Eliot (who followed her), her fame has long rested on a single novel, Jane Eyre, and on the haunting romanticism that the Bronte family evokes. But now that news feminists like Kate Millett have discovered her, Charlotte is being touted as a writer of contemporary relevance, with her two later novels (Shirley and Villette) confirming her evolvine feminine consciousness.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: For the Woman 9118

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 6, 1977

title: Management
description: More and more companies have renamed the head of their personnel departments, and it appears to be more than cosmetic. The new title involves the term human resources, perhaps vice president of human resources, perhaps director of human resources. The HewlettPackard Company, the Bendix Corporation and the Brunswick Corporation are among those to have made the move.

title: Big Store Chains Report Strong Sales in December
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $1.31 billion, up 41 percent from the yearearlier $929 million. Total retail store sales were $13.12 billion, up 9 percent from $11.98 billion.

title: 50 Jurors Chosen To Screen Entries For Pulitzer Prize
description: The appointment of 50 jurors for the Pulitzer Prize awards in journalism for work published in 1976 was announced yesterday by Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University.

title: Fire Razes Chilean Shanties
description: VALPARAISO, Chile, Jan. 6 (Reuters)A thousand people were left homeless today after a forest fire destroyed shantytown buildings on the outskirts of Valparaiso, according to fire officials.

title: Liquor Authority Gets Injunction And Opens Drive Against 200 Clubs
description: The State Liquor Authority, declaring that it had begun a fullscale crackdown againstunlicensed speakeasies, said yesterday that it was seeking its first court injunction to close an unlicensed bottle club in New York City.

title: Soviet Again Refuses to Give ExitVisa to American's Wife
description: MOSCOW: Jan. 6In a sparsely furnished room of a drab Moscow communal apartment, irMa Astakhora McClellan waits, as she. has for 28 months. She is waiting to join her husband, an American professor in Virginia, and her prospects in 1977 look as bleak as in 1976.

title: Uganda Building At U.N. to Exceed That of the U.S.
description: Uganda has begun excavation work in Manhattan for a 15story headquarters for its United Nations delegation that would be three floors higher than its nextdoor neighbor, the building of the United States Mission.

title: People and Business
description: Dr. Sidney Harman, president of Harman International Industries, who was nominated yesterday by Presidentelect Carter to be Under Secretary of Commerce, and suddenly found himself and the high fidelity audio systems manufacturing company he heads thecenter of a flurry of interest on Wall Street.

title: Elizabeth Swados Writes Cantata for Cabaret
description: Elizabeth Swados is a rare bird. Only 25 years old, she has composed scores for such avantgarde theatrical directors as Andrei Serban and Peter Brook. She is now writing the music for Mr. Serban's first two Lincoln Center ventures with Joseph Papp, The Cherry Orchard and Agamemnon. And she has conceived, composed and directed Nightclub Cantata, a new musical revue that opens Off Broadway Sunday night at the Village Gate.

title: Getting Well With Governor Carey
description: Governor Carey' s annual message to the Legislature was clearly intended to be heard as well outside the Capitol as within. He announced that New York State has emerged from the intensive care unit and can be fairly described as convalescent from what might have been a terminal disease two years ago. Since survival no longer seems in question, the Governor devoted himself to describing how the still emaciated state economy can be made to walk and put on weight.

title: Management
description: The Federal Government is urged to help in improving the allocation of human resources as a way to reduce unemployment. Page D7.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: FIRST$4,020, pace, cl., mile.

title: At the Movies
description: THERE is no war in our movie until the very end, said Bruce Dern from Hollywood, where he is starring with Jane Fonda and Jon Voight in Coming Home, one of the most ambitious of several new films dealing with the impact of, the Vietnam conflict on various civilians and members of the military. You will see me in combat, the only problem being that the combat is in Malibu Canyon. What happens is that I become disillusioned with the war and with the Marine Corps, and I start collecting weapons and turning my house into one big locker room, with my wife serving as den mother to a bunch of veterans. I can't make it with my wife any more, or with anybody else, and when things start piling up on me, I combat flashback. I think I'm still in Vietnam, and I go off into the hills, taking some hostages with me. I don't hurt anybody, but they end up hurting me.

title: New Curbs Asked on Shoe Imports; Move Is Least Costly for Consumer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The United States International Trade Commission voted today to recommend to the President a new form of import restraint on foreign shoes, but the commission chose the mildest remedy, with the lowest estimated cost to the consumer, of the several proposals before it.

title: Opera: Cavalli's Giasone, A Comic Antique, Is Restored
description: MONTEVERDI, although the greatest of 17thcentury opera composers, was not the only successful one by any means. Probably because of the attention that his few surviving stage works have been enjoying in recent years, an investigation of his contemporaries has been going on, with Cavalli getting the most consideration. L'Ormindo and La Calisto have been produced and recorded, and Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall Newell Jenkins conducted what he believes is the American premiere of Cavalli's comic opera, Giasone.

title: Defector Says Soviet Pilots Have Suicide Order
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Jan. 6 (AP) A Soviet fighter pilot who defected to the West told American interrogators that Soviet combat pilots were under orders to make suicide attacks rather than bail out in wartime emergencies, according to the illustrated magazine Stern.

title: Asbestos Removal Urged
description: In New Jersey, Governor Byrne and the State Education Commissioner, Fred G. Burke, urged that all asbestos fibers be removed from the state's 2,500 public schools as a health measure. On Monday, schools in Howell Township, Monmouth County, were closed after parents of some children, concerned over reported links between cancer and asbestos, threatened to boycott classes until asbestoscontaining coatings were removed from ceilings and corridors. The material is being removed.

title: The Staff of New York Magazine Stages a Walkout to Back Felker
description: The staff of New York magazine marched off the job yesterday in a show of support for Clay S. Felker, editor of the magazine, and his attempts to prevent a takeover by Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher.

title: Jewelry Worth $110,000 Stolen From Two Rooms at the Plaza
description: Jewelry valued at $110,000 was stolen from two different rooms on the fifth floor of the Plaza Hotel yesterday. More than $100,000 in jewelry was taken from the hotel suite of Ravi Tikkoo, a 44yearold shipoWner who heads and owns the Globtik Group of Companies based in London.

title: Cabaret: Michael O'Haughey
description: The prospect of an evening with the performer who, billed as M. O'Haughey, plays Mary Sunshine, a transvestite reporter, in the musical Chicago, might seem to be of limited appeal. But the actuality, as presented at Barbarann, 349 West 46th Street, through Sunday evening, is absolutely dazzling.

title: Article 2  No Title
What Kind Of America?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6President Ford's skislope invitation to Puerto Rico to become the 51st state was the most sudden and surprising notion he has had since he liberated Eastern Europe from the Soviet Union, but it has certain possible advantages.

title: FinkIs Appointed Majority Leader As Steingut Decides on More Shifts
description: ALBANY, Jan. 6At least one shakeup in a major committee chairmanship was reported today as Stanley Steingut, the Speaker of the Assembly, chose Stanley Fink to be majority leader, as had been expected, and began the process of reorganizing the Assembly's expanded Democratic majority.

title: Bond Prices Slump for 3d Decline In 4 Days as Financing Plans Rise
description: Credit markets dropped sharply yesterdaytheir third decline in the last four daysas a large volume of new corporate financing was announced. Sears, Roebuck & Company disclosed plans to sell $300 million of debentures and almost $300 million of other new bond issues were reported. Corporate and Government bonds fell, as much as one full point or perhaps a little more, and taxexempt issues, which had held up better than the rest of the market earlier this week. also declined.

title: Honduras Said to Shift Officers to Bar Coup
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Hondouras Jan. 6 (AP)A proGovenment newspaper said today that several high military officers had bee assigned to new positions this week to avoid a coup planned by young leftist officers and civilians.

title: Stage: Hartford's Souffl Anouilh
description: JEAN ANOUILH's comedy The Waltz of the Toreadors seems to b emerging, as it were, as one of the most substantially insubstantial of his plays. It new production by the Hartford Stage, Company, in Hartford, confirmed all its scatterbrained charms and philosophical simplicities.

title: Rituals for Super Bowl Leave Vikings Few Timeouts
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 6It rained and rained here today at Blair Field, but Coach Bud Grant never even thought about canceling, postponing or shifting practice for the Minnesota Vikings three days before the Super Bowl game against the Oakland Raiders. The rain lessened to a drizzle and the Vikings worked hard for two hours. Thursday is always a big day in the week of a pro football team preparing for a game on Sunday.

title: Teton Dam Disaster Laid to Design
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6An investigative panel has found that the Teton Dam in Idaho burst last June 5 because of deficiencies in design and instrumentation that were rooted in a failure to anticipate the many possibilities for trouble inherent in the situation.

title: Tugboats Play Starring Roles In South St. Seaport Exhibition
description: For Rembrandts, the Metropolitan. For Picassos, the Museum of Modern Art. For fire engines, the Museum of the City of New York. For arrowheads, the Museum of the American Indian. But for tugboats? The South Street Seaport Museum, naturally.

title: For Children
description: Young People's Concert

title: College Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: McGee Believed Set for O.A.S Job; Favors Ending Panama Canal Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Presidentelect Carter has selected fOrmer Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, to be the United States representative in the Organization of American States, high Latin American diplomats said today.

title: 30YearOld Branch of Bloomingdale's Will Be Closed Down in New Rochelle
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 6Bloomingdale's has decided to close its 30yearold store on Main Street hereits largest suburban branchlargely because of competition from one of its newest and largest branches, several miles away in White Plains.

title: Art: Larry Rivers Then and Now at Marlborough
description: NOT LONG ago10 years, or less  technology was supposed to be going to put hand made art out of business. Even where paint and canvas were still in use, an impersonal execution was mandatory. Ideas came to the artist readymade and complete and their execution was best entrusted to others:

title: Soviet Bars Fund to U.N. Peace Unit
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 6The Soviet Union has sent Secretary General Kurt Waldheim a note that United Nations officials interpret as a warning to the incoming Carter administration against continuing to discourage Soviet diplomatic participation in Middle East peacdmaking efforts.

title: Brown Vows to Veto Death Penalty Bill
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 6 (AP)Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said today that he would veto any death penalty bill sent to him by the California Legislature.

title: Regalado 66 Leads By a Shot in Phoenix
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 6For Bob Gilder, this is where it all began a year agoone of the most successful rookie seasons on the professional golf tour.

title: Public Service Told to Cut Rates Of Its Major Users of Electricity
description: NEWARK Jan. 6The State Board Public Utility Commissioners today ordered the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, the state's largest power company to implement, for the first time in New Jersey, a reduced electric rate for major users in an attempt to attract new industry.

title: 2 ExF.P.C. Members Barred as Witnesses
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Two former members of the Federal Power CommissionLawrence J. O'Connor Jr. and John A. Carver Jr.have been denied permission to testify as witnesses for natural gas producers in case before the commission.

title: The Pop Life
description: NEW YORK AND LOS ANGELES have become firmly established as the world capitals of pop music, headquarters of the major record companies, recording studios and music publications and homes of many of the artists. Nashville continues to hold its own as the center of the country music industry. But Memphis, which was the prime source for soul music 10 years ago and the birthplace of rockandroll during the 1950's, has been ominously quiet. Last year saw final dissolution of Stax Records, the Memphisnased company that had been the label of Otis Redding, Sam and Dave, Isaac Hayes and other soul stars of the 60's. The popularity of Al Green, the city's principal soul artist of the 1970's, has continued to slip. Even. Elvis Presley, the most successful pop artist to emerge from Memphis and probably the most successful pop artist of all time, seems to be in decline.

title: 800 Learn How to Become Ministers In an Effort to Get Tax Exemptions
description: LAKE CARMEL, N.Y., Jan. 6More than 800 disgruntled taxpayers squeezed into a roadside restaurant in northern Putnam County tonight to find out how to become taxexempt ministers.

title: Dow Up 1.83 to 979.89 as Market Lists First 77 Gain in Slow Day
description: The stock market, aided by strength in some of the recently depressed bluechip and glamour issues, posted its first gain of the year yesterday in slower trading.

title: Landlord Alters Policy
description: A Morris County apartment complex, sued for alleged sex discrimination, agreed in Federal Court in Newark to count a woman's income when considering a rental application from married couple. Cambridge Village in ParsippanyTroy Hills, owned by Bender Realty Inc., signed a consent order to uphold New Jersey's civil rights statutes. The consent order does not constitute admission of any wrongdoing.

title: family/style
Husbands and Wives To Get Phone Listing
description: ALBANY, Jan. 6The New York State Public Service Commission has approved the New York Telephone Company's proposal to publish joint husbandandwife entries in its directories, but the Commission stipulated that there be no charge for such listings.

title: Judge in Brooklyn Court Indicted On Perjury and Contempt Counts
description: A judge of Civil Court in Brooklyn was indicted yesterday on charges that he lied to a special grand jury about his participation in a series of illegal loans before and during his tenure on the bench.

title: Spy Case in Prague Being Used to Mount AntiU.S. Campaign
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 6The recent arrest of a former Czechoslovak official on espionage charges is being linked in official accounts with renewed allegations of United States intelligence activity against Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union.

title: Ford's Show of Activity
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6President Ford was uncharacteristically snappish when somebody asked him recently why he had not left the delicate issue of Puerto Rican statehood for the incoming President, Jimmy Carter, to handle.

title: From the Police Blotter:
description: A suspect in a Christmas Day homicide was found dead of a shotgun blast in the head at 989 Columbus Avenue at 108th Street in the tenement next to the one in which he lived, at 987. He was identified as Bernaldino Santana, 33 years old. . . Two deputy United States marshals pursued a man by car and foot, capturing him at 43d Street and Fifth Avenue after they saw him being chased by an unknown man at 42d Street and Madison Avenue in the vicinity of the City Bank at 330 Madison Avenue. Their prisoner, Daniel Cross, 23, of 1460 Bronx River Avenue, the Broni, reportedly tried to cash a bogus $1,100 check in the bank, grabbed some money and ran..... An unidentified man about 18 years old was shot and critically wounded after he was robbed of a nylon ski jacket by two youths at Clifford Place and Walton Avenue in the Morrisania section of the Bronx. One of the youths, 15 years old, was taken into custody later by two police offiCers from the 44th Precinct, who had questioned him when they saw him running with a ski

title: Cavaliers, on 4614 Burst, Trounce Warriors, 129100
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 6 (AP)Austin Carr sparked a secondperiod spree tonight as the Cleveland Cavaliers ended Golden State's four  game winning string with a 129100 National Basketball Association triumph over the Warriors.

title: Canadiens Extend String With 92 Rout of Sabres
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 6 (AP)Guy Lafleur scored his 32d, and 33d goals of the season to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 92 victory over the Buffalo Sabres in a National Hockey League game at the Memorial Auditorium tonight.

title: How Murdoch Mobilized His Money
description: Rupert Murdoch said yesterday that the $30 million he used to buy The New York Post came from a combination of cash and borrowings in London, New York and his native Australia

title: The Enduring Significance of Nonevents of 1976
description: CROTONONHUDSON, N. Y.Perhaps the biggest single story of 1976 consists of nonevents: the 25 events listed in the box accompanying this article.

title: Comecon to Help Cubans Build a Nuclear Plant
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (Reuters)The Communistbloc economic association, Comecon, has announced plans to build a nuclear power station in Cuba, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: Sanderson Is Placed On Waivers by Blues
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP)Derek Sanderson, the flamboyant center, was placed on N:H.L. waivers today by the St. Louis Blues, apparently a result of a personality clash with the Blues coach and general manager, Emile Francis.

title: WEEK'S CAR PRODUCTION EXPECTED TO RISE 17.1%
description: DETROIT, Jan. 6American automobile plants are scheduled to build 181,089 cars this week, an increase of 17.1 percent over a year ago, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: House as a Synagogue Brings Village Dispute
description: NORFOLK, Conn.Is a Jew less Jew if, on a warm summer sabbath in the hills of northwestern Connecticut. he happens to go for a swim?

title: TV WEEKEND
description: In terms of major productions this weekend, there's the football Super Bowl, Sunday afternoon at 3:30, and Raid on Entebbe, Sunday evening at 8, both on NBC. Entebbe, the site of last July 4's daring Israeli rescue of 103 hostages from a skyjacked airliner, has now provided all three networks with programming fodder.

title: Market Place
description: One investment approach recommended for individuals is the purchase of shares of small, wellmanaged companies that are strategically situated in areas of rapid growth.

title: A Country Family Plays the City.
description: The McLain Family Band has played in 40 foreign countries, not counting Greenwich Village, where it will play tomorrow night.

title: Syria Hangs 3 Convicted in Bombings and Charges Rival Iraqi Regime with Complicity in Terrorism
description: By The Associated Press

title: Malikov of Soviet Union Is Victor in Speed Skating
description: INZELL, West Germany, Jan. 6 (AP)Andrei Malikov of the Soviet Union skated the 500meter event in 38.08 seconds today and set a record for the distance on the Inzell artificial ice course. Malikov, a 22yearold soldier, also was timed in 1:18.49 for the 1,000 meters and won a fourevent competition with 155.94 points.

title: Miley, Angels Infielder, Is Killed in Auto Mishap
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 6 (UPI)Mike Miley, a utility infielder for the California Angels, was killed today in a onecar accident near the Louisiana State University campus. Investigators said Miley, 23 years old, was thrown from his car and run over by the vehicle. He was alone in the car at the time and the police are investigating the accident.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT DETROIT

title: Singles in the Suburbs: Safety vs. Loneliness
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y.  Outside Maryanne Fishberg's appartment at the Wildwood housing complex in Hartsdale, the tricycles are lined up three deep. In the parking lot below, a husband unloads, groceries from the back of a station wagon while his wife walks a few feet ahead, pushing a stroller. This is station wagon country, nursery school country and, most of all, wedding ring country.

title: Puerto Rico's ExGovernor Hints Statehood Plan Is Linked to Oil
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 6The former Governor of Puerto Rico raised the possibility yesterday that President Ford's proposal to grant statehood to the island may have been instigated by the Department of the Interior in an effort to gain control of oil deposits that may be off the island's north coast.

title: Pound Shows Drop In Light Day Dollar Firms But Is Uneven
description: LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) The pound fell almost a half cent on the London foreign exchange market today. Dealers deScribed trading as relatively light.

title: TELEVISION TODAY
description: Morning

title: HEATING OIL INVENTORIES DECLINE AT SLOWER PACE
description: Helped by record production of heating oil last week, the sharp decline in inventories of heating oilknown as distillates abated somewhat, the American Petroleum Institute renorted yesterday.

title: SETON HALL RECEIVES ARCHDIOCESE PAPERS
description: NEWARK, Jan. 6Letters from the late Bishop John Neumann, who was approvedfor sainthood last month, and the 19th century diaries of Archbishop k James Roosevelt Bayley, first Bishop of New Jersey, were among the items from the archives of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark formally turned over today to Seton Hall University for their care and maintenance.

title: U.S. Aide Seeking to Ease Curbs. On Alien Doctors in This Country
description: Dr. Theodore Cooper, the Assistant Secretary for Health of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, said yesterday that he would recommend easing new restrictions on the immigration of foreign medical school graduates to prevent a threatened disruption of hospital care in this country.

title: Kean Files Forms in Preparation For Primary Drive for Governor
description: TRENTON, Jan. 6The Assembly minority leader, Thomas H. Kean of Elizabeth, filed the necessary forms with the State Election Law Enforcement Commission today to establish the campaign organization for his coming bid for the Republican gubernatorial nomination. Mr. Kean, 40 years old, who was Chairman of Mr. Ford's successful New Jersey campaign, will become the second major Republican contender for the, gubernatorial nomination when he formally announces his candidacy, possibly next week.

title: Syria Hangs 3 Accused in Bombings
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 6Two Syrians and a Palestinian were put to death by hanging at dawn today a few hours after Syria announced that the three had been convicted in a series of bomb attacks carried out with the complicity of Iraq.

title: Civil War Massacre Haunts Spanish Communist
description: PARACUELLOS DEL JARAMA, Spain, Jan. 5Tucked away near the airport in the anonymous, halfrural eastern fringes of Madrid, the deserted cemetery and its withered memorial wreaths seem irretrievably locked in the past.

title: HOW TO ASSIST THE FUND FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: Checks shouldbe made. payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Judge Strikes Testimony In Yoshimura Trial
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 6The judge in the trial of Wendy Yoshimura instructed the jury today to disregard all testimony Miss Yoshimura gave when she took the stand yesterday.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday Film

title: Fines Imposed for Strike
description: The Mineola (L.I.) Teachers Association was fined $12,000 and 11 officers and members of the association were fined $250 each for criminal contempt in refusing to obey an order from the State Supreme Court to end a sevenday strike that started last Oct. 6 over a contract dispute. Justice Alexander Berman, who imposed the penalties, said the defendants would be committed to jail for five days if they failed to pay the fines.

title: Antiquarian Books On View March 31
description: The International Antiquarian Book Fair, which meets on alternate years in New York City, will be held this year from March 31 to April 3 at the Plaza Hotel. More than 90 dealers from Europe, Canada and the United States will show rare books, fine bindings, manuscripts, autographs, maps and prints. Prices will range from. $5 to $250,000.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
Reserve's Targets On Money Growth Achieved in 1976
description: Figures released by the New York Federal Reserve Bank yesterday showed that the Federal Reserve Board had achieved or exceeded its targets for the growth of the nation's money supply during 1976.

title: 2 Big U.S. Tuna Boats Switch to Foreign Flags
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 6 (AP)Two of the largest vessels in the United States tuna boat fleet are switching to foreign flags in the face of a Government ban on killing porpoise while fishing for yellowfin tuna.

title: BIG BOARD APPROVES OPTION MARKET IDEA; AMEX CHIEF CRITICAL
description: The New York Stock Exchange made its first move yesterday in the direction of establishing an option market.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: IMAGINE in the middle of winter strolling through a lush garden, the air scented with jasmine, camellias in bloom and goldfish swimming in a pond flecked with lily pads. Bermuda? Cuernavaca? A dream? NoNew Jersey. Only 36 miles from New York City, the Duke Gardens in Somerville, N.J., offer winterweary metropolitan area residents a remembrance of springs past without the accompanying cost that getting away from it all usually requires.

title: Boy Struck by Puck Dies
description: DENVILLE, N. J., Jan. 6 (UPI)A 12yearold boy who was struck on the head with a hockey puck on Christmas Day died yesterday without regaining consciousness. The boy, Todd Johnson of Indian Lake, was injured while playing hockey with his 16yearold brother on a lake near their home.

title: Sixth Child Dies After Fire
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 6 (UPI)Charles Edward Brown Jr., 11 years old, critically burned in a fire that killed two of his brothers and three of his sisters, died today at St. Mary's Burn Center. His father and two other brothers escaped from their burning home early yesterday. Their mother was visiting relatives in Chicago at the time of the fire, authorities said.

title: Bridge:
description: A sextet of California and Texas stars held a substantial advantage in the second quarter of play in the international team semifinal playoff in Houston yesterday.

title: Singles in the Suburbs: Safety vs. Loneliness
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y.  Outside Maryanne Fishberg's appartment at the Wildwood housing complex in Hartsdale, the tricycles are lined up three deep. In the parking lot below, a husband unloads, groceries from the back of a station wagon while his wife walks a few feet ahead, pushing a stroller. This is station wagon country, nursery school country and, most of all, wedding ring country.

title: PARROT FEVER HINTED AS LEGION AILMENT
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 6A Federal laboratory reported today that blood sam ples from three victims of an unknown illness that struck an American Legion convention in Philadelphia last summer showed signs of recent infection by chlamydia, the group of infectious agents that includes psittacosis, popularly known as parrot fever.

title: No Rest for the Weary at Yonkers: Pacer Races Twice in Five Nights
description: Local harnessracing handicappers have been confronted this winter with this type of form frequently: a cheap horse coming back to the races only four days after his last start.

title: Coffee Group Starts Worldwide Promotion
description: LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP)The International Coffee Organization announced today that it was starting a worldwide campaign to sell coffee at a time of spiraling prices and an organized boycott.

title: HELEN O'DONNELL
description: BOSTON, Jan. 6 (AP)  Helen O'Donnell, wife of Kenneth O'Donnell, the former White House chief of staff, died at her home Tuesday. She was 50 years old.

title: The Behemoths at Sea
description: Through sea changes in weaponry, in the balance power and in the number and nature of potential adversaries, our Navy has designed itself for 50 years around 15 mighty capital ships, the ceiling that emerged from the Washington Naval Treaty of 1922. Capital once meant battleships, eventually attack carriers.

title: The Enthusiasts Are Off Again
description: At 2:30 this Sunday afternoon an undetermined number of assorted New Yorkers, some of them old friends but some unknown to the others, will assemble near the change booth at the BMT subway exit at Seventh Avenue and 55th Street.

title: Advertising
description: If you're the kind of a woman who'd like to receive a surprise package occasionally containing $14 worth of supermarket products for $5.98 (plus $1.75 for shipping and handling) then the G.R.I. Corporation has a deal for youmembership in S.A.V.E.

title: Eve Queler of the Dauntless Baton
description: IT'S A GOOD THING that Eve Queler is a conductor rather than a singer. Four days ago she came down with laryngitis. All she could do was whisper. Communicating was bad enough with the chorus that she was rehearsing for Smetana's Dalibor, which she will present with her Opera Orchestra of New York in Carnegie Hall on Sunday night. To get the singers to attack correctly the unfamiliar consonant clusters in the opera, she needed both an authority on Czech pronunciation and a fullvoiced deputy.

title: Of Laws, Men and the F. B. I.
description: The mounting interest in who will now head the Federal Bureau of Investigation obscures a prior question: What should rule the F.B.I.? Just how committed is the new Administration to impressing the framework of law on an institution that has for years been placed beyond the reach of the law by Presidents, by Congress and by the founding director, J. Edgar Hoover.

title: Tennis Council Ponders Conduct Point Penalties
description: The next time a professional tennis player hits a ball at a linesman, throws a racquet or arrives late for a match at Forest Hills, he may receive more than a casual warning.

title: POLICE CAPTAIN FINED $51,500 FOR BRIBERY
description: A police captain was fined a record $51,500 yesterday after he pleaded no contest to charges of taking bribes for overlooking gambling violations in Harlem between 1967 and 1971. However, he was permitted to retire with a pension of $25,000 a year.

title: House Assassination Panel Unlikely to Get 6.5 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6, (AP)  House leaders said today that they doubted the committee investigating the assassinations of President Kennedy and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr, would get the $6.5 million firstyear budget it requested

title: 2 Convicted in Bronfman Case Get Minimum Terms of 3 and 4 Years
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 6Mel Patrick Lynch and Dominic P. Byrne, who were convicted last month of extorting $2.3 million from Edgar M. Bronfman but acquitted on charges of kidnapping Mr. Bronfman's son, Samuel 2d, were sentenced today to serye at least four and three years, respectively.

title: Rural Caucus. Names Breckinridge
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI)Representative John B. Breckinridge, Democrat of Kentucky, has been reelected chairman of the Congressional Rural Caucus, his office said today.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$6.00, pace, mile.

title: Northwestern Routed, 10265, By Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 6 (AP)Rickey Green scored 20 points and John Robinson 18 as. they led fifthranked Michigan to a 10265 drubbing of Northwestern in their opening Big Ten Conference game.

title: 8% Ceiling to Stay On Mortgage Rate At Cadman Towers
description: The New York City Board of Estimate voted by a narrow margin last night to retain an 8 percent ceiling on the mortgage interest paid by residents of the Cadman Towers cooperative complex in Brooklyn Heights.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high lide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook lime.

title: School Bus Safety
description: New safety standards for thousands of school buses have been adopted by the New Jersey Board of Education. The board has approved rules requiring the installation of extra padding on seats in 3,000 buses now in service and seat fastenings in 6,000 buses.

title: Rockland Electric Rate Request Assailed by Jersey Customers
description: NEWARK, Jan. 6 (AP)Lawyers representing Rockland Electric Company's 49,000 customers in northern New Jersey told the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners yesterday that the company's request for a $7.9 million rate increase was too high.

title: ITALIAN UNION CHIEFS SPURN PREMIER'S BID
description: ROME, Jan. 6The Italian Government failed today to persuade union leaders to agree to curb wages, now rising here faster than in any other European nation.

title: Beame's Budget Cuts Deepest for Police and Schools
description: Mayor Beame's new package of budget cuts to take effect during the coming fiscal Year will have the sharpest impact on the city's Police Department, Human Resources Administration and the Board of Education, according to projections released yesterday.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Tonight is opening night at the opera in the Bronx. The 10yearold Bronx Opera, which has. developed quite respectable reputation for itself, will perform La Traviata at 8 P.M. at the Bronx High School of Science, 75 West 205th Street. It will be in typical Bronx Opera stylea full production, in English, with orchestra and chorus.

title: No Peril Seen After Nuclear Leak
description: ATHENS, Ala., Jan. 6 (UPI)The Tennessee Vally Authority said today taht it had been unable to detect any increase in levels of radioactivity as a result of the leakage of a small amount of radioactive material from the Brown Ferry Nuclear Plant into the Tennessee River. The leak occurred Tuesday night or early yesterday morning, with the material escaping through a faulty tube in a heat exchanger that was circulating cooling water from a generating unit that was shut down for maintenance.

title: F.D.A. Proposes Restrictions On Use of Impurity in Saccharin
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 6 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration proposed today a crackdown on an alleged impurity in saccharin, the last artificial sweetener still allowed in food.

title: Australia Beats Pakistan By 348 Runs in Cricket
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 6 (Reuters)Australia took just half an hour today to wrap up the second cricket test against Pakistan in the threematch series.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: People in Sports
description: Bruce Jenner, who set a world record of 8,618 points in winning the decathlon at the Olympic Games in Montreal last summer, was named yesterday as male athlete of 1976 by The Associated Press.

title: Carter Ponders the Final Details Of Program to Spur the Economy
description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 6Presidentelect Carter considered the final details of an economic stimulation program today after one major Carter adviser expressed hope that it would not cost more than $15 billion so as to avoid distressing public opinion as a result of massive additions to the budget deficit.

title: On Airline Regulation
description: WASHINGTONDefenders of current aviation regulation warn of naive and dangerous idea: reforming the 1938 Federal regulatory laws to make air transportation more competitive.

title: A Jazz Flutist at Carnegie
description: Hubert Laws, a jazz flutist who has spent most of his career staying out of the spotlight, will be right in the middle of it tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall where he is giving concerts at 8 P.M. and at midnight with Earl Kiugh, the guitarist, and Lonnie Liston Smith and the Cosmic Echoes.

title: A Useful Guide to Backgammon
description: The great wave of enthusiasm stirred by Prince Alexis Obolensky and the other high rollers seems to have passed, but the rattle of dice cups is still loud in the land. The people who claim to keep track of such things say that 20 million Americans are now regular backgammon players, which, if true; means the game is at least on a par with chess if not quite to the level of popularity of bridge.

title: U.S. Panel Hears Soviet Dissident
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Andrei A. Amalrik, the Russian dissident, told United States commission today that Presidentelect Jimmy Carter should use the Soviet desire for American technology, credits and grain to force the Kremlin to comply with the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki accord on EastWest relations.

title: CURB ON TRADE SCHOOLS PROPOSED IN F.T.C. STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI)A Federal Trade Commission study today called for a crackdown on false, deceptive, and unfair schemes used to promote vocational and homestudy schools to which two million Americans pay more than $2.5 billion in tuition ,each year.

title: Ellis Wilson, Artist, 76; Painted Harlem and Haiti, Was Guggenheim Fellow
description: Ellis Wilson, a widely known artist who was a Guggenheim Fellow in 1944 and 1945, died Sunday in French Hospital after an illnesS of two weeks. He was 76 Years old and lived at Cornish Arms Home for Adults, 315 West 23d Street.

title: House as a Synagogue Brings Village Dispute
description: NORFOLK, Conn.Is a Jew less Jew if, on a warm summer sabbath in the hills of northwestern Connecticut, he happens to go for a swim?

title: 2 Convicted in Bronfman Case Get Minimum Terms of 3 and 4 Years
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 6Mel Patrick Lynch and Dominic P. Byrne, who were convicted last month of extorting $2.3 Million from Edgar M. Bronfman but acquitted on charges of kidnapping Mr. Bronfman's son, Samuel 2d, were sentenced today to serve at least four and three years, respectively.

title: A Composer's Life Set to Music
description: Music Magic: A Musical Odyssey is the newest presentation at the BedfordStuyvesant Restoration Corporation's Billie Holiday Theater, which is not only Off Off Broadway, but off all traditional theatrical tracks as well.

title: Jersey to Tax Oil Companies for Future Cleanups
description: GLOUCESTER, N. J., Jan. 6Governor Byrne went to the site of last week's Delaware River oil spill today to sign the most comprehensive state legislation in the country on cleanup of spills and compensation for damages.

title: Venezuelan Cabinet Quits To Facilitate Changes
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 6 (AP)The Venezuelan Cabinet resigned today to allow President Carlos Andrs Prez to reorganize his administration.

title: Investigator Seeks Information
description: SYRACUSE, Jan 6Peter D. Andreoli, a special deputy attorney general ordered by Governor Carey to investigate allegations of illegal fundraising by political parties in Onondaga County, held his first press conference here today. He offered no details about his inquiry, and appealed to local citizens to bring him information.

title: Ford Names 4 as Ambassadors, sohiect to Congress and Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)President Ford today nominated four new ambassadors, including Malcolm Toon, for the Soviet Union, Jack B. Olson, the Bahamas, Lowell Bruce Lanigen, Malta, and Donald R. Norland, Lesotho, Botswana and Swaziland.

title: Sports
description: Friday

title: Deaths
description: BAYLYBarhara Downey, on Thursday. Jan. 6, 1977, Barbara Downey Barb', beloved wife of John H. Barly, Jr., devoted mother of Anne Louise Barly, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. William S. Downey, formerly of N. Y. C., sister of Richard Morgan Downer), of Washington, D.C. Friends may call at Joseph Gawier's Son, 5130 Wisconsin Ave. at Harrison St., N.W., parking on premises, on Friday, anytime after 2 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church, EastWest Highway at Pearl St., Bethesda, Md., on Saturday, Jan.  8, at 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: U.S. Plans Solar Electric Plant
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI)The Government said today that had picked Barstow, Calif., as the site for the country's first solar power tower electric generating plant.

title: Some Recommended Titles
description: In his study of children's books, Dr. Edward F. Ansello of the Center on Aging at the University of Maryland found a number that he described as providing reasonably wellrounded, generally favorable characterizations of the elderly. He offered this list:

title: And some good things that failed to happen
description: 1. Serious energy programs by the United States and the International Energy Agency.

title: Theater: Boucicault's Forbidden Fruit Revived
description: THE NO SMOKING Playhouse, an intimate and unpretentious Off Off Broadway theater, specializes in new plays and new old plays, such as its current production, Dion Boucicault's Forbidden Fruit, a relic that has been dusted off and adapted by George Wolf Reily, (who also plays a minor role). Do not be deceived by that lascivious title. This is an ingenuous, romantic comedy about mistaken identity and aborted infidelity. The hero is a happily married young lawyer who attempts to daily with a sexy circus performer.

title: Alexander Tops Ashe, Vilas Wins in Tennis
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 6 (Reuters)Topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina moved into the semifinal round of the $200,000 Australian open tennis tournament today by eliminating Ross Case, 64, 75, 16, 63. His powerful display dispelled any doubts about his ability to handle grass. courts.

title: NewYork Is a Jazz Festival
description: Any weekend in New York is potential jazz festival, but this weekend offers an abundance of riches for the jazz lover, with every stylistic persuasion well represented.

title: Gas Rate Hearing Set
description: The New York State Public Service Commission will hold a public hearing next week on Consolidated Edison's application for a $34.2 million increase in its natural gas rates. The hearing will be held Wednesday in Hearing Room 1 on the 24th floor of Two World Trade Center, from 1 to 5 P.M., and then will resume at 7 P.M. The increase would raise gas rates by 11.8 percent for the company's approximately 1.1 million customers who use gas for heating and cooking.

title: New Radiation Limit Proposed by E.P.A. To Protect the Public
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today a lowering of the amount of radiation the general public can receive from intentional discharge of radioactive material by nuclear power production.

title: Camden Gets Sludge Site
description: A Federal court has ordered the City of Camden to dump its sewage sludge farther out in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Cape May, instead of near the Maryland coast, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said. The agency had originally ordered the city to stop using the ocean and to find a land disposal site. but the city said it had not worked out the problem and would have to start dumping waste in. the Delaware River if it could not use the ocean.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of post positions

title: Reports of Ski Conditions in the East
description: (Reports supplied by resort owners.) NEW YORK

title: Zaire to Recognize Angola
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Jan. 6 (Agence FrancePresse)Zaire is to give formal recognition to Angola and will establish diplomatic relations with it at ambassadorial level, President Mobutu Sese Sekc announced here today. Zaire backed the defeated proWestern Angolan Nationa Liberation Front in the civil war, which led to the installation of a people's republic by the victorious Cubanaided faction.

title: Jamaica Gunmen Raid Sarah Churchill Home
