description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 6 (AP)Four gunmen kicked in the door of Lady SpencerChurchill's resort home today, threatened the niece of the late Sir Winston Churchill with a knife and shot a guest, the police had reported.

title: Tibet Radio Says the Gang of Four Should Be Put on Trial Tomorrow
description: HONG KONG, Friday, Jan. 7The Tibet radio said today that Chiang Ching and three other disgraced members of the Chinese Politburo should be put on public trial tomorrow on the first anniversary of the death of Prime Minister Chou Enlai for having persecuted him to death.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Books of The Times
description: I HEARD someone say that he was tired of Iris Murdoch, that she writes too any novels and they are all the same. The assumption behind this remark seems to be that, having mastered her particular form and style, Miss Murdooh should find cone less congenial to her talents and struggle with it in the name of progress. All too often, this is exactly what does happen to authors: they write one good book of a certain kind and then go on and write several bad ones of different kinds.

title: Book Critics Circle Announces Prizes In Four Categories
description: The outstanding books published in 1976 in four categoriesfiction, poetry, nonfiction and criticismwere selected yesterday in a meeting at the Algonquin Hotel by the National Book Critics Circle, a 250member professional organization of fulltime book critics and editors.

title: Soybean Prices Are Up Sharply After Slow Start
description: Soybean futures prices ended sharply higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after a slow start.

title: Opera: Debut in Die Zauberflote
description: Edlta Gruberova, a Czech soprano, made her Metropolitan Opera debut on Wednesday night as the Queen of the Night in Mozart's Die Zauberflte. She proved her competence by negotiating the coloratura of the arias securely and with clear articulation. Her top notes were in place and in tune.

title: BEAME OFFERS PLAN TO CLOSE THE DEFICIT IN 19771978 BUDGET
description: Mayor Beame formally presented yes terday his program to close. New York City's remaining budget deficit, saying it would not sap the city's ability to deliver vital services, despite a projected, reduction of an additional 7,500 employees through attrition rather than through layoffs.

title: Mozambique Leader Raises Hopes Of Peaceful Settlement in Rhodesia
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 6 (Reuters)President Samora Machel of Mozambique, whose country is the main springboard for nationalist guerrilla attacks on Rhodesia, was reported today to have expressed his readiness for peaceful solution in the breakaway British colony.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Books. With young children especially, it is supposed that they can do good, helping to mold valued views of life. And it is supposed that they can do harm. Parents concerned about the books preschoolers and gradeschool children look at and read have already been alerted to the racism and sexism in some of them. Now comes ageismthe degrading of old people through stereotypes.

title: Broadway
description: IT HAS NOT BEEN a good season for new musicals. In the last season or two, depending on how you measure your seasons, we have had A Chorus Line, Chicago, The Wiz and a few others that you may think of with pleasure. This season, among other things that happened. Baker's Wife died out of town, while Music Is died here, and Going Up hardly hung around at all. The Robber Bridegroom, no matter how much you may like it; is not really a new musical, and Godspell certainly isn't either. At least one man who votes for the Tony Awards says he will forget about voting for the best new musical because there isn't any, and that the only things around are the revivals. Now, however, he may find hope: A new show by Cy Coleman and Michael Stewart will open late in March.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly stated in The Times yesterday that Rupert Murdoch used assets of The New York Post to pay for the major part of his interest in the New York Magazine Company. The funds came from the City Post Publishing Corporation, the newly created parent company of The Post. The Post is the only operating entity of the corporation.

title: Dart Industries Sells U.S. Rexall Drug
description: Dart Industries announced in Los Angeles that it had sold its United States Rexall Drug Company to the Rosshall Corporation of Palo Alto, Calif., and a group of investors including Howard K. Vander Linden, president of Rexall, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Korean Dissidents Said to Be in Isolated Cells in Spartan Conditions
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 7Imprisoned political dissidents, some of whom began jail life last spring with 10 days of nonstop interrogation, are being subjected to a spartan life of solitary confinement in small cells with meager, monotonous meals and no furniture. Their woodenfloored cells are said to be so cold during the bitter Korean winter that eggs and milk brought by relatives freeze solid.

title: About New York
description: Jack Bigel, the labor consultant, was in the midsweep of his speech, making the rhetorical equivalent of a slamdunk shot through a basketball hoop at the expense of City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, when Governor Carey called timeout.

title: Article 6  No Title
Aqueduct Snowed Out
description: Aqueduct and four other race tracks in the Northeast canceled their programs yesterday because of snow.

title: California Judicial Panel Recommends Removal Of State Supreme Court judge Because of Senility
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7The California Commission on Judicial Performance recommended today that 82yearold Justice Marshall F. McComb be removed from the state Supreme Court on the ground that he was senile and unable to perform his duties.

title: Running Style Overwhelms New Yorkers
3 Sets of Senate Hearings Expected On Soviet Might and Strategic Aims
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7The Senate will hold at least three sets of hearings on Soviet military ability and strategic objectives this winter, Congressional aides said today.

title: Appeals Court Asked To Overturn Verdict Against Miss Hearst
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan, 7 (AP)Attorneys for Patricia Hearst asked a Federal appeals court today to overturn her bank robbery conviction on grounds that the trial judge had made errors which all but dictated the verdict of guilty.

title: Italian Cameraman Found Dead In Garage of His Apartment House
description: ROME, Jan. 7(AP)Ennio Jacobucci, a photographer and cameraman who had worked in Indochina for the Italian television network, was found dead today in the garage of his Rome apartment house, the police reported.

title: HUGHES MINE CLAIMS TO BE SOLD OR LEASED
description: TCNOPAH, Nev., Jan. 7 (AP)The late Howard R. Hughes's Summa Corporation wants to sell about 1,500 claims to Nevada mines, many of them famed gold producers. Mr. Hughes spent nearly $20 million on the claims, the company said.

title: Struck Hotels Bleak in Miami Despite Winter Sun
Cuban Exile Leader Slain in Miami; 7th in 3 Years
description: MIAMI, Jan. 7Juan Jose Peruyero, former president of the Cuban Bay of Pigs Invasion Brigade Veteran Association, was shot to death here today by unidentified assailants.

title: Worried Bonn Looks to Carter to Help Economies of West
description: BONN, Jan. 7  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is showing an uncharacteristic anxiety about the economic future and his fears are shared by some of his top advisers and West German industrialists. With increasing urgency, a number of them say they are counting on the Carter administration to take immediate steps to keep the Western world from sliding into a new recession.

title: Meadowlands Panel Racing Time To Keep Aid for Trash Compactor
Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Issue and Debate
description: This is the age of overlap in sports, once a series of tight little islands of free enterprise. Here are some recent developments:

title: Meadowlands
description: Meadowlands Drivers

title: U.S. Says World Bank Visit to Hanoi Doesn't Reflect Gains on Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7The State Department today discounted the notion that the sending of a World Bank team to Hanoi reflected any progress toward normalizing relations between the United States and Vietnam.

title: Bridge:
description: Two teams composed largely of West Coast players began a twoday playoff match in Houston last night, battling for the right to represent North America in the 1977 world team championships.

title: CBS Buys Fawcett Publications for $50 Million
description: CBS Inc. yesterday announced the company's acquisition of Fawcett Publications, one of the last familyrun publishing giants, for $50 million in cash. A CBS spokesman called the sale one of the largest cash transactions in publishing history.

title: TransAtlantic Phone Tie Restored After 50 Years
description: Rose DePalma, dialing directly from New York, talked again yesterday with another retired telephone operator, Isabel Ivy Baker, in London. Fifty years before, they had been among the first operators to establish commercial telephone connections across the Atlantic.

title: Carey Asks $216.7 Million More
description: ALBANY, Jan. 7Citing increased costs for welfare, Medicaid, student loans and other state programs, Governor Carey asked the Legislature today to appropriate $216.7 million to meet expenses he said had not been expected when the current state budget was enacted last March.

title: Byrne Discounts Asbestos Peril
description: TRENTON, Jan. 7Governor Byrne and other New Jersey officials said today that while asbestos materials flaking from the ceilings of schools and other buildings posed a potential health hazard and should be removed, people exposed to the fibers for relatively short periods of time should not be alarmed.

title: Lisbon Is Moving to Curb Fascism
description: LISBON, Jan. 7Portugal's Socialist Government announced measures today to curb the revival of fascism here.

title: The Rev. Robert Howell Schumann, English Teacher and Episcopal Priest
description: The Rev. Robert Howell Schumann, chairman of the English department at the McBurney School, 15 West 63d Street, and a priest at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West 46th Street, died in Roosevelt Hospital yesterday after a short illness. He was 56 years old and lived at 103 West 69th Street.

title: Diane Naue Williams Is Bride of Philip Vey
description: Diane Naue Williams, daughter of Lillian Naue Williams of Glen Ridge and Spring Lake, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Philip Theodore Vey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Vey of Panther Valley, N.J., and Stowe, Vt.

title: De La Roche Arraigned
description: Harry De La Roche, 18 years old, pleaded not guilty to charges of murdering his parents and brothers at their Montvale home during his Thanksgiving leave from a South Carolina college. His lawyer then contended that Mr. De La Roche's chance for a fair trial was diminished by newspaper publication of a purported confession. The defendant did not speak during the fiveminute arraignment in Hackensack before Judge Fred C. Galda of the Bergen County Superior Court. His attorney, John R. Taylor, entered not guilty pleas to four charges of firstdegree murder.

title: Miss Vodorezova Keeps Title
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 7 (UPI)Thirteenyearold Yelena Vodorezova defended her title as the top Soviet woman figure skater today at the national championships in Vilnius, Lithuania. The 85pound Moscow schoolgirl collected 184 points for an easy victory over the 1975 women's champion, Lyudmila Bakonina, who earned 169.66 points.

title: Caso and Supervisors End Dispute, By Agreeing on a County Attorney
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 7  A bitter controversy involving Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, and the Board of Supervisors was resolved amicably today when both sides agreed on the appointment of former Judge William Gitelman of Nassau County Distrct Court as the new County Attorney.

title: Safety Panel Urges Ban on Big Bins
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP)Citing five deaths and several injuries, the Consumer Product Safety Commission today proposed a ban on largesize refuse bins, which can tip over on children playing around them.

title: Flammable Negatives Destroyed
description: TRENTON, Jan. 7 (AP)Several boxes of historic nitrate photographic negatives were destroyed because the material had deteriorated into a highly flammable condition, state library officials said. Army bomb experts from Ft. Dix destroyed the negatives yesterday, including ones of police photographs from the Lindbergh kidnapping, officials said. However prints of all the destroyed negatives have been made.

title: News Summary
description: American and European banking officials will meet in Basel, Switzerland, tomorrow and Monday to discuss, according to American and British officials, a novel and possibly lasting solution to the longstanding problem of Britain's sterling balances. Agreement is expected but is not certain. Details have been kept secret, but the new proposals are known to be significantly different from the type of arrangement occasionally and unsuccessfully used in the past. [Page 1,Cols. 56.]

title: House Speaker O'Neill Is Hospitalized Briefly
description: ALBANY, Ga., Jan. 7 (AP)House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, was taken to a hospital here today after meeting with Presidentelect Carter at nearby Plains.

title: Dividends
NEW YORK IS ADVISED TO DELAY COMPLYING WITH BANK DEMANDS
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, advised top city and state officials yesterday to reject, at least for the time being, the latest demands laid down by the banks as a condition for their helping New York City to balance its budget and pay off its shortterm notes.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Princeton Five Routs Harvard In Ivy Opener
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 7Bob Roma, a sophmore center, scored 23 points, including 13 in the first half, to lead the Princeton basketball team to a 7745 rout of Harvard in their Ivy League opener at Jadwin Gym tonight.

title: CARTER AND PARTY LEADERS REACH ACCORD ON TAX CUTS AND SPENDING; ALL TAXPAYERS TO GET 77 REBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7Presidentelect Carter, in the first major policy decision of his coming administration, has taken an eclectic approach to the problems of stimulating a faster recovery from the recent recession. His eco nomicstimulus package, announced today in Plains, Ga., embodies some aspect of nearly every plan that has ever been offered to him, with one notable exception. There is no tax incentive for businesses to increase their purchase of new machinery and equipment.

title: L.I. Dog Bites Children and Guard
description: EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., Jan. 7A 50pound Alaskan malamute attacked and bit two children on their way to school this morning. A school crossing guard who went to their aid was also bitten.

title: Israeli Suspends Scrutiny Of Minister's Finances
description: TEL AVIV, Jan, 7Minister of Police Shlomo Hillel Said today the investigation into allegations of questionable financial dealings by a Cabinet colleague who committed suicide this week were being suspended.

title: Cocoa Futures Climb Sharply; Coffee Declines the Daily Limit
description: Cocoa futures jumped sharply yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. March contract closed at $1.48 a pound, up the 3centsapound limit.

title: Notes on People
description: An outofcourt settlement is said to have been reached between Ken Kesey, author of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, and the producers of the movie version of the book in a legal action brought by Mr. Kesey over royalties due him. The settlement would give the writer 2.5 percent of the net profits from the film, winner of the Academy Award for best picture, and champion box office attraction of 1976. The picture has grossed nearly $6 million in the United States and Canada alone, according to the latest figures compiled by Variety. Mr. Kesey had contended that Michael Douglas and Saul Zaentz, producers of the movie, breached a contract entitling Mr. Kesey to 5 percent of the film's gross.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 7 (AP)The Argentine Government reported the release of 27 political prisoners today, bringing the total freed in the last two months to 709.

title: Honeywell and Pentax End Photo Unit Talks
description: Honeywell Inc. announced that negotiations for sale of its United States photographic products business to the Pentax Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Asahi Optical Company of Japan, were being terminated.

title: Jury Is Picked for Longet Trial; Friends of Sabich Are Included
description: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 7 (AP)A jury of seven men and five women was selected today to decide whether Claudine Longet, the singeractress, is guilty of reckless manslaughter in the shooting death of her lover, professional skier Vladimir Sabich.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: PROF. ODED REMBA, 64, EXPERT ON MIDEAST OIL
description: Oded Remba, professor of economics at the College of Staten Island and an authority on Middle East oil and energy problems, died Thursday at University Hospital. He was 64 years old and a resident of Cranford, N.J.

title: Southern Pacific Files New Plan To Buy Part of Rock Island Road
description: The Southern Pacific Company said it had filed an amended application with the Interstate Commerce Commission seeking authority to purchase portions of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad. It wants its subsidiary, the Southern Pacific Transportation Company, to buy about 300 miles of the Rock Island's main line between St. Louis and Kansas City, Kan., about 600 miles of main line between Topeka, Kan., and Santa Rosa, N. M. and a branch line of about 30 miles between Bucklin and Dodge City, Kan.

title: 4Alarm Warehouse Fire
description: A spectacular fouralarm fire in a sixstory warehouse on the West Side of Manhattan sen clouds of smoke across a large area of midtown last night. There were no reports of injuries in the blaze, which was fed by wind gusts of up to 45 miles an hour.

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold prices Friday.

title: NEW YORK IS ADVISED TO DELAY COMPLYING WITH BANK DEMANDS
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, advised top city and state officials yesterday to reject, at least for the time being, the latest demands laid down by the banks as a condition for their helping New York City to balance its budget and pay off its shortterm notes.

title: Perilous Day for Bettors
description: All week long, during the countdown to Super Bowl Sunday, Eddie has been pumping it in on Oakland.

title: Letters
description: The Two Types of PleaBargains

title: Office Curb in East Bloc Handicaps West's Trade
description: VIENNA, Jan. 7In Eastern Europe, it's not unusual to find a major American corporation doing business out of a hotel room. The scarcity of office space for foreign business is a major handicap to EastWest trade.

title: At Riviera Resort, a Debate Over Flower Pots and Image
description: ST.TROPEZ, France, Jan. 3There are three kinds of people at the tip of this little peninsula jutting into the Mediterranean halfway between Nice and Marseilles. Some were born here, some make it their secondary residence, which means they earn their living elsewhere and consider the town their special, untouchable preserve, and some just come to stare and have an expensive fling.

title: Bank Officer Sentenced
description: A former bank operations officer who was convicted of embezzling $46,000 in bank funds over a twoyear period was sentenced to spend 180 nights in the community treatment center at the Bryant Hotel, 54th Street and Broadway.

title: Cardinal Cooke Donates $250 To Aid Neediest
description: A personal contribution for $250 has been received from Terence Cardinal Cooke for the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Ford Said to Bar Blanket Amnesty To War Resisters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7President Ford has ruled out a blanket amnesty for military deserters and draft evaders but is considering granting relief to a few limited categories of offenders in the Vietnam War era, White House officials disclosed today.

title: LARRY VINCENT
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 7 (AP)Larry Vincent, a songwriter, died Wednesday at the age of 76. His biggest hit was If I Had My Life to Live Over.

title: Itek Unit Gets Order
description: The Itek Corporation announced that its Applied Technology division had been awarded a $12.8 million Air Force contract to provide power management receiver systems. The receivers are used in radar warning and other electronic systems.

title: William Stuckey, 67; Built Candy Store Into National Chain
description: EASTMAN, Ga., Jan. 7 (AP)William Stuckey, who built a chain of candy shops and restaurants from a $35 pecan business, died yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: Accord Is Expected On Plan for Sterling By Central Bankers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7Central bankers of the United States and the other leading industrial countries are expected to reach agreement on Sunday and Monday in Basel, Switzerland, on a novel solution of the longstanding problem of Britain's sterling balances, according to American and British officials.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT CLEVELAND

title: Leaders in New Rochelle Pledge To Support Redevelopment Plan
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 7The closure of Bloomingdale's oldest branch store, in downtown New Rochelle, appeared today to have prompted new support for a redevelopment plan linked, in part, to the department store.

title: SUTTON TELLS BERME HE'LL RUN FOR MAYOR
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan told Mayor Beame and fellow members of the Board of Estimate yesterday that he would announce his candidacy for the Democratic mayoral nomination later this month.

title: Koehring Raises Its Quarterly Dividend
description: The Koehring Company, which received an acquisition offer valued at about $56 million on Thursday from the Fruehauf Corporation, has raised its quarterly dividend to 20 cents a share from 15 cents.

title: Elt Plans Name Change
description: Elt Inc. plans to submit to shareholders a proposal to change the company's name to Dutch Boy Inc. at a special meeting to be held on or about Feb. 3. Elt acquired substantially all of the assets of the Dutch Boy paint division of NL Industries for cash late last month.

title: First Chicago Predicts Loan Loss Provision
description: The First Chicago Corporation, a bank holding company, expects a provision for possible loan losses of $41 million for the fourth quarter. It includes a special increase of $12.5 million over the $28.5 million provision charged to earnings in each of the previous three quarters.

title: Cabaret: Dick Hyman, Pianist, Evokes Jazz Mood of 1930's
description: Dick Hyman, the jazz pianist who has made a specialty of exploring the works of such early jazz keyboard men as Scott Joplin, James P. Johnson and Jelly Roll Morton, has now moved ahead chronologically to the music of the 1930's. A quintet he is leading at Michael's Pub is, according to the club's advertisements, featuring the 1930 sounds and music of the little bands of Fats Waller, Louis Armstrong, John Kirby, etc.

title: Knicks Lineup
Ford Said to Bar Blanket Amnesty To War Resisters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7President Ford has ruled out a blanket amnesty for military deserters and draft evaders but is considering granting relief to a few limited categories of offenders in the Vietnam war era, White House officials disclosed today.

title: Bausch & Lomb Settles Disputes Over Contact Lenses
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said yesterday that it had settled all its longstanding disputes with the National Patent Development Corporation over rights to soft contact lenses.

title: Elections in Pakistan To Be Held in March
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 7 (AP)Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan announced today in the National Assembly that general elections would take place March 7. Mr. Bhutto said the Assembly would be dissolved Monday to pave the way for election of a 216member house for the next fiveyear term.

title: 3to6Inch Snow Slows Travel And Closes Schools in Suburbs
description: A blustery winter storm frescoed the New York City and suburban landscapes with 3 to 6 inches of snow yesterday, closing hundreds of schools in outlying areas and generating scattered but occasionally lenghty dealys for highway, rail and airline travelers.

title: Port Agency Asks for Funds
description: TRENTON, Jan. 7 (AP)New Jersey members of the Delaware River Port Authority asked the state to finance the yearly $1.2 million operating cost of the authority's World Trade Division, which promotes commerce on the river. They told Governor Byrne yesterday that they were unable to continue financing the division because of a $5.5 million deficit.

title: Article 5  No Title
Welfare Fraud Alleged
description: Herbert L. Johnson, 40 years old, of 37 Quincy Street, Brooklyn, was arrested on charges of defrauding the city's Social Services Department of more than $33,000 by receiving public assistance checks under 11 aliases. He had applied for assistance under a program which grants aid to persons eligible for employment but unable to find work. While picking up one check under one of his aliases, he was recognized by a city clerk who knew him by another name, according to Nicholas Scoppetta, the City Investigation Commissioner.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed In order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Maps Should Not Read: The Atlantic Oil Drum
description: Before winds blow the Argo Merchant from our minds, it is time to examine the circumstances that make such accidents increasingly probable and to consider measures to reduce their occurrence

title: Senators Cordial to Adams at Confirmation Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7Representative Brock Adams, the first of Presidentelect Carter's Cabinet selections to appear for a Senate confirmation hearing, was greeted today by the Senate Commerce Committee with the special warmth that members of Congress reserve for their colleagues.

title: Article 4  No Title
Of Pans, Pain and Tire Chains
description: In the NBC special on violence the other night several network wizards argued that their nocturnal production of mayhem is a simple case of giving people what they want. The trouble with this argument is that it assumes that people know what they want.

title: Probation in Road Fatality
Ford Aide Named to U.S.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP)President Ford today appointed H. James Field Jr., a White House staff assistant, to the board of governors of the United Service Organizations for a twoyear term. Mr. Field, of Providence, R. I., Will succeed Waller Taylor 2d, whose term has expired.

title: Oil Workers Union Signs New Contract With Gulf
description: DENVER, Jan. 7 (UPI)The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union signed a contract today with the Gulf Oil Company, averting by seven hours a nationwide strike against the nation's fuel industry.

title: 6 Jailed for Demonstration Against Nuclear Weapons
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 7 (AP)Jail terms were meted out today to six persons convicted of chaining themselves to the doors of the Pentagon or splashing blood on the Pentagon's walls in an antinuclear weapons demonstration.

title: FORD ASKS CONGRESS TO MOVE PROMPTLY ON ADEQUATE ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7President Ford sent Congress today a lengthy message on the nation's energy situation, asking for quick action to assure an adequate and secure supply of energy at reasonable prices.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7An electronic license plate for cars and trucks has many possible uses, including identification, exchange of messages, collision avoidance and tracing stolen vehicles. Fred Sterzer, director of the microwave technology center at the RCA laboratories in Princeton, N.J., was granted Patent 4,001,822 for the invention this week. Users of the tags and their connected radar equipment would include police as well as owners of private cars.

title: Pate's 67134 Leads by 2 at Phoenix Open
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 7Nearly every event on the Professional Golfers Association Tour has its anonymous youngster who flashes briefly in the sun with a hot round, takes the lead for a day and then disappears, unheard of for the next few days. His prospects of winning a tournament are dim because he doesn't have the staying power, desire or determination.

title: Joint CostCutting Venture Brings Cargoes of Steel Back to the Port
description: ELIZABETH, NJ., Jan.7The first major shipload of foreign steel products to arrive at the New JerseyNew York part area in six years was at dockside here today as the result of an unusual venture in costcutting operations by, labor and management in the shipping industry and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: I Don't Need a Super Bowl Ticket
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7He's always at the Super Bowl or World Series, and it's as if he were invisible. He blends into the scenery. He even moves past the ticket takers without them asking for a ticket or even asking questions.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: N.Y. Electric & Gas Plans 3for2 Stock Split
description: Directors of New York State Electric and Gas Corporation have recommended that stockholders authorize a 32 stock split at the company annual meeting in May.

title: Parole Decision Delayed
description: The United States Parole Commissioners have failed to agree on a parole for former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark, who is serving 10 years for accepting bribes and permitting extortion on city contracts. The three national commissioners and a regional commissioner cast a 2to2 vote, a pokesman said. They now must obtain a tiebreaking vote from a second regional commissioner. That normally takes about two weeks, he said.

title: Companies and Their Reports of Earnings
description: COMPANY REPORTS

title: Marcos Denies U.S. Report On Rights Violations
description: MANILA, Jan. 7 (AP)President Ferdinand E. Marcos today branded as provocation a State Department report that human rights had been violated by his martiallaw regime in the Philippines. President Marcos also said treaties with the United States could be terminated if they were no longer in his country's best interests.

title: UNITED AIRLINES ASKS C.A.B. TO REALIGN ITS US. ROUTES
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP)United Airlines has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to realign its domestic route system and eliminate a number of restrictions on service the carrier considers outmoded.

title: BARBARA DOWNEY BAYLY
description: Barbara Downey Bayly, an executive assistant to Representative Edward I Koch, Democrat of Manhattan, died of cancer Wednesday at her Bethesda, Md., home. She was 32 years old.

title: A Carter Statement On Foreign Policy Due
description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 7 (UPI)Presidentelect Carter will issue a statement on international affairs at 10 A.M. tomorrow at his home here and then take a few questions from reporters, a Carter spokesman said tonight.

title: Critic and Symphony Out of Tune
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7Los Angeles, which prides itself on having developed a worldclass symphony orchestra in the last decade, is now enjoying a firstclass oldfashioned war between critic and musical entrepreneur.

title: Court Voids Carey Disclosure Rules
description: ALBANY, Jan. 7Governor Carey's effort to compel full financial disclosure from all toplevel state employees received a setback today when Justice Harold J. Hughes of State Supreme Court declared unconstitutional the Governor's conflictofinterest regulations.

title: Accord Is Expected On Plan for Sterling By Central Bankers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7Central bankers of the United States and the other leading industrial countries are expected to reach agreement on Sunday and Monday in Basel, Switzerland, on a novel solution of the longstanding problem of Britain's sterling balances, according to American and British officials.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COMMON WEALTH The 50 original prints by contemporary Puerto Rican artists on view until Feb. 15 at the Jamaica Arts Center, 16104 Jamaica Avenue in Queens, represent established artists and newly recognized printmakers, with woodcuts, etchings and screenprints by such designers as Lorenzo Homar, Myrna Baez, Rafael Tufino and others.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly stated in The Times yesterday that Rupert Murdoch used assets of The New York Post to pay for the major part of his interest in the New York Magazine Company. The funds came from the City Post Publishing Corporation, the newly created parent company of The Post. The Post is the only operating entity of the corporation.

title: Minnesota, Its Fuel Oil Dwindling Is Placed Under an Energy Watch
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 7The State of Minnesota, facing a colderthannormal winter and dwindling: fuel oil reserves, was placed under an energy watch today. The state warned that some heavy fuel consumers might have to cease operation in the near future.

title: Deaths
description: ANSISMillie, devoted mother of Sylvia Cooper, Leo and the late Jules cherished grandmother and greatgrandmother. Services at The Boulevard Chapels, 1901 Flatbush Avg., corner of Avenue L, Brooklyn, Sunday at 12:45 P.M.

title: High School on Coast Is Closed As Racial Fights Leave 17 Injured
description: SAN CARLOS, Calif., Jan. 7 (UPI)A high school in this affluent suburb of San Francisco was closed today because of two days of racial fights that left 17 students injured and resulted in six arrests.

title: Happy New Year for Chinatown's Banks
description: As the Year of the Dragon gives way next month to the Year of the Snake, residents of New, York's Chinatown will be hurrying to their neighborhood banks to send gifts of money to friends and relatives in less prosperous parts of the world.

title: William Gropper, Artist, 79, Dies; WellKnown LeftWing Cartoonist
description: William Gropper, a widely known radical cartoonist and leading artist of the American social realist school, died Thursday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., of a heart ailment He was 79 years old and had been painting actively until he fell ill last year.

title: Down East Woolens Are Woven by Hand
description: Hand work is becoming increas ingly rare in any form of clothing, because the skills involved in it are vanishing and the time required to the price prohibitive. Still there is occasional surcease from machines, as people find ways to merchandise successfully a handmade product.

title: Personal Investing
description: One of the best investments the Chicago Mercantile Exchange made last year, was the time and energy it put into establishing a futures market in 90day United States Treasury bills.

title: Reading & Bates Purchase
description: The Reading & Bates Offshore Drilling Company said it had signed an agreement with the International Mining and Petroleum Company of Detroit to buy International's Belva Coal Company unit for $12.5 million in cash. Belva is mining an average of 30,000 tons of coal a month from properties in Logan County, W. Va.

title: Disability Isn't Beautiful
description: URBANA, Ill.The law barring Federal agencies and holders of Federal contracts from discriminating against the physically handicapped has not been actively enforced during its three years of existence. And though the handicapped are legally entitled to the same protection other minority groups, they continue to be a target of discrimination while the Government acts as if they were different from other minorities.

title: CARTER FILLS SIX JOBS AT STATE DEPARTMENT
description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 7 (UPI)Presidentelect Carter today named one woman and five men to top positions in the State Department. Mr. Carter also nominated a Columbia University law professor. Richard N. Gardner, to be Ambissador to Italy. renlacine John A. Volpe.

title: MIRIAM Y. HOLDEN, 83, ACTIVIST AND COLLECTOR
description: Miriam Y. Holden, a campaigner for the rights of women and members of minority groups, died yesterday at her home after a long illness. She was 83 years old.

title: Takeover of Unions Planned in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 7 (UPI)The military Government plans to take control of all organized labor in Argentina in reprisal for union criticism of its economic policies, Government sources said today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Feldman Faces A.B.C. Charges In Bribery Case
Treason in Spain
description: MADRIDI am a firm supporter of the regime of July 18the date of the national rising led by Generalissimo Francisco Franco in 1936whose major goal is the idea of unity and national solidarity in the face of Marxism, with its dogma of class struggle and liberalism, which triggers the mechanics of class struggles among political parties.

title: Murdoch Wins Magazine Fight As Felker Settles
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher who acquired The New York Post last week, gained control of the New York Magazine Company yesterday after reaching an outofcourt settlement with Clay S. Felker, the founder of the magazine.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Rheem to Build Plant
description: The City Investing Company announced that its Rheem air conditioning division would build a $20 million plant in Milledgeville, Ga. The 520,000squarefoot facility will produce residential central air conditioners and heating equipment and will eventually employ about 50 persons. The plant is expected to start production by January 1979.

title: Italian ExAide Denies Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7Former Italian Defense Minister Luigi Gui said in an interview here today he could disprove official charges that he received $50,000 or more in connection with the 1971 sale of 14 Lockheed Aircraft Corporation cargo planes to the Italian Air Force.

title: Sinatra's Mother on Jet Missing And Presumed Crashed on Coast
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP)A rescue team struggled through a rugged canyon today in search of a missing private jet carrying the 82yearold mother of Frank Sinatra.

title: The Even Interest of All the People
description: Jimmy Carter is rushing to make some payments on the moral mortgage he gave the electorate concerning ethics in government. This week, he issued complex guidelines for new appointees on conflicts of interest. within hours after his inauguration, he is to issue an executive order on the subject.

title: Russian Christmas in a Long Island Town: A Family Relives Its Traditions
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., Jan. 7Amid snow and song, ancient rites and sumptuous food Christmas came last night to the Russian Orthodox community here.

title: Music
description: Electronic music is such an unexplored world of sonic possibilities that composers are often tempted into sheer aural sensationalism  the mindless wallowing in spectacular effects without much concern for musical logic.

title: Air Force Academy Finds No Evidence of Theft Ring
description: BOULDER, Colo., Jan. 7 (UPI)No evidence was found to, support charges by a New York lawyer, that a theft and forgery ring was operated by cadets at the Air Force Academy, a spokesman for the school said today.

title: From the Police Blotter:
description: Police Officers Robert Fornal and Louis Petrella of the 78th Precinct reported that they had arrested Gehart Maier, an illegal alien, as he was robbing a checkcashing office at 84 Flatbush Avenue in downtown Brooklyn of $5,600. Mr. Maier, address unknown, allegedly pointed a gun at the officers but then dropped it Two bank officers, Richard Shields, 52 years old, and Gumars Cimbulis, 51, of the Tremont Savings and Loan Association at 3445 Jerome Avenue in the Mosholu section of the Bronx were robbed of $11,500 by two men a few steps from their bank. They had just drawn the money from the branch of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company across the street at No. 3408. A 19yearold Brooklyn man was stabbed to death in the secondfloor hall of his home at 11 Dewey Place in the Bedford Stuyvesant section. The motive for killing the man, identified as Herman Whetston, was unknown.

title: Golf
HEAD OF RHODESIA PARLEY WINS TANZANIAN SUPPORT
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 7 (UPI)Ivor Richard of Britain, chairman of the Geneva negotiations on Rhodesia, won backing from President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania today for direct British participation in the interim government designed to pave the way for black majority rule in Rhodesia.

title: Lady Sarah to Leave Jamaica After Gunmen's Attack in Home
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 7 (AP)Lady Sarah SpencerChurchill, a Vanderbilt heiress, is reported planning to leave Jamaica following a raid on her resort home near Montego Bay in which four gunmen shot a house guest and attacked her.

title: Music: Vocalists
description: Michael Henderson and Vicki Sue Robinson, two vocalists who are performing with their groups at the Bottom Line through this evening, are expanding the frontiers of discodance music in different but complementary ways. Neither of them seems capable of turning in a performance that pleaces the head and heart as much as the feet, but together they suggest that the disco idiom, a blending of soul, rock and jazz styles with pop production touches and the rhythmic sophistication of AfroCaribbean and Latin music, is growing into one of the most significant pop syntheses of the 1970's.

title: Islanders Set Back Flames, 54
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 7The Islanders arrived at the crossroads tonightand took the high road.

title: 2.4 Million Tandy Shares Accepted for Exchange
description: The Tandy Corporation said that about 2.4 million shares of its common stock were accepted in its recent exchange offer of new 10 percent subordinated debentures due 1991. The total face amount of the new issue would be about $97.1 million.

title: TwoYear Package of $30 Billion Aims for 800,000 New Jobs
description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 7Presidentelect Carter and Democratic Congressional leaders said today that they were in general agreement on an array of programs to stimulate the economy by increased spending to create jobs, changes in the income tax system to lower payments by persons of low and moderate income and for businesses and by a oneshot tax rebate for all taxpayers in 1977.

title: Chou, 12 Months After His Death, Emerges as a Folk Hero to Chinese
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 7Since hiS death last Jan. 8, Chou Enlai has emerged as the real folk hero of China, and has triumphed over his longtime antagonists and tormentors, the leftist group around Chiang Ching, the widow of Mao Tsetung.

title: Raymond International Bids for Kaiser Engineers
description: Raymond International has submitted a bid for the purchase of Kaiser Engineers, a subsidiary of the Kaiser Industries Corporation of Oakland, Calif

title: Strengthened Dollar Regains Its Losses; Gold Price Gains
Natalia RoslavleVa, A Dance Historian In Soviet, Dies at 69
description: Natalia Roslavleva, a leading Soviet dance historian and critic whose writings are well known in dance circles in the West, died of cancer Monday in Moscow. She was 69 years old.

title: Relics of Tragedy Haunt Brooklyn Store Fire Site
description: The orange glass vase looked like the kind that costs about 69 cents, the kind a person might put a plastic rose into, or balance on a window ledge to catch the light.

title: SUTTON TELLS BEAME HE'LL RUN FOR MAYOR
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan told Mayor Beame and fellow members of the Board of Estimate yesterday that he would announce his candidacy for the Democratic mayoral nomination later this month.

title: Rosewall Conquers Edmondson, Plays Tanner in Semifinals Today
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 7 (AP) Secondseeded Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., and 42yearold Ken Rosewall, the oldest man in the fourthseeded Aussie, downed the semifinals of the Australian open tennis championships at Kooyong.

title: Open Interest
The Night the Luxury Tenants Toasted Their Strike Victory
description: There's something about a rent strike that helps people to get to know their neighbors, according to tenants of a luxury East Side building.

title: A Day in CourtBut Not a Decade
description: Cheers greeted the announcement of the approval of Westway by the Federal Department of Transportation. So did threats, threats to renew and intensify the lawsuits brought in December, 1974, against the draft statement of the highway's environmental impact and, more recently, against the proposed demolition of the derelict West Side Highway.

title: Planned Parenthood Organization Asserts Yellow Pages Censors It
description: Planned Parenthood of New York City accused the New York Telephone Company yesterday of arbitrary and discriminatory censorship for refusing to let the organization list its services fully in an advertisement in the 1977 Manhattan Yellow Pages.

title: Music: Authentic Regal Baroque
description: Concert Royal's program in Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night was, to say the obvious, fit for a king. The sevenmember ensemble is named after the type of chambermusic suite that Couperin composed for 18thcentury French court musicales. Specializing in music of the 17th and 18th centuries, the group uses instruments from that period, or their copies. Whatever it performed in this, its New York debut, emerged as regally rich and elegant. The small hall was jammed with Baroquemusic fans and specialists, who seemed thoroughly happy with what they heard.

title: Carter Economic Plan Disappoints Some Businessmen and Scholars
description: Presidentelect Carter's plan to stimulate the economy caused disappointment in the business community and among economists last night because of the size of the package and because it emphasized higher Federal spending rather than a permanent tax cut.

title: Coast Guard Believes Oil Tanker Missing in the Atlantic Has Sunk
description: BOSTON, Jan. 7The Panamanian flag tanker Grand Zenith sank in the Atlantic Ocean off Cape Cod, the Coast Guard said today. Two life jackets from the vessel were found.

title: Meadowlands Results
Behavior of Kangaroo Is Studied to See If It Can Survive
description: FOWLERS GAP FIELD STATION, New South WalesFor eight hours every dayDr. David Croft lurks among the mulga scrub and saltbush near here, watching a group of kangaroos socializingafter their own special fashion.

title: 16 Hurt in Fire in Class
description: KINGSTON, Pa., Jan. 7 (AP)A fire today in a high school chemistry laboratory sent a teacher and 15 students to the hospital with minor burns. James Ferris, principal of the Wyoming Valley West High School, said it appeared that phosphorus might have caused a minor explosion that preceded the fire.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT PHILADELPHIA

title: Consumer Credit Rose in November, But Pace Slowed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI)Consumers increased their debts by $1.24 billion in November for the slowest growth in personal credit since February, the Federal Reserve Board said today. Consumer credit is considered a barometer of economic activity. The reluctance of consumers to increase debts in November occurred during a period when questions were being raised about the strength of the economy.

title: Danneberg Captures Ski Jumping Tourney
description: BISCHPFSHOFEN, Austria, Jan. 7 (AP)Walter Steiner of Switzerland won the last event of the fourhill ski jumping tournament yesterday, but Jochen Danneberg of East Germany emerged as overall victor after a dramatic finish.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Rebozo Agrees to Pay $52.474 in Back Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon's close friend Charles G. Rebozo has settled a dispute with the Internal Revenue Sevice by agreeing to pay Federal income taxes of $52,474 plus interest for 1970 and 1971, court records show.

title: 76ers Top Cavs, 11696 As McGinnis Does It All
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 (AP)George McGinnis scored 33 points, grabbed a careerhigh of 22 rebounds and handed out seven assists tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers trounced the Cleveland Cavaliers, 11696, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Dr. Nancy Acton Is Married
description: Dr. Nancy Acton, a research associate in chemistry at Columbia University, was married yesterday morning to Ronald Roth, a professor of chemistry at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va.

title: Elderly Woman Killed In Bergen County
description: Bergen County authorities yesterday were investigating the fatal beating of an elderly woman, the second such death in two days.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Jan. 7The power of the State Commission of Investigation to delve into organized crime in New Jersey was strengthened today when Judge George Y. Schoch of Trenton ordered Angelo Bruno back to prison despite the reputed mob leader's serious physical condition.

title: DR, HARRY GOLDBLATT, BLOOD RESEARCHER
description: Dr. Harry Goldblatt, a widely acclaimed pioneer in blood pressure research, died Thursday in a Rochester hospital of pulmonary edema. He was 86 years old and lived in Rochester.

title: News Production Group to Meet
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 7 (AP)About 900 newspaper production officials from five states and Ontario will meet here tomorrow through Tuesday for the 32d annual Great Lakes Newspaper Production Conference. For the first time, the meeting will include workshop sessions. Members; of the conference represent 219 newspapers.

title: DECEMBER'S SALES UP ONLY MODESTLY FOR STORES IN CITY
description: Sales of New York City's major department stores last month showed only a moderate gain from the level of December 1975, reflecting a sharply erratic trend in consumer buying. The rise appeared small in view of the Sunday store sopenings.

title: Soviet Alien Arrested in Jersey on Spy Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation tonight arrested Ivan N. Rogalsky, a Soviet alien living in Jackson Township, N.J., on charges of conspiring to commit espionage on behalf of the Soviet Union.

title: State Dept. Asks Court to Shield Boeing Agents Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP)The State Department has asked an appeals court to keep secret the names of 18 men, including government officials, who serve as agents or consultants overseas for the Boeing Company.

title: Article 2  No Title
People in Sports
description: The chances of Derek Sanderson becoming a Ranger again were estimated at onetenth of a percent yesterday by a spokesman for the National Hockey League team. But you can't blame the flamboyant center for trying to rejoin his old club.

title: Southern Railway Plans Record Spending
description: The Southern Railway System announced a record capital expenditures budget for 1977 of more than $200 million. W. Graham Clayton Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, said the 1977 budget eclipsed the previous record of 1974 when expenditures totaled $164 million.

title: Texas Oil Acquiring Dow's Well Interests
description: The Texas Oil and Gas Corporation announced yesterday that it had acquired the Dow Chemical Company's interest in 151 gas and oil wells and approximately 63,000 undeveloped leasehold acres for $15.25 million.

title: Royal Opera Loses Vickers as Tannhauser
description: LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP)Britain's Royal Opera House has announced the withdrawal of the celebrated Canadian tenor Jon Vickers from its planned revival of Wagner's opera Tnnhauser because he felt he could not come to grips with the title role.

title: Man Guilty of Threatening Ford to Get a New Trial
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 7 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circult ordered today a new trial for a man convicted of making threats against President Ford and Vice President Rockefeller.

title: A Lone and Varied Career
description: A man with a flair for supersalesmanship and high adventure, William Douglas Pawley led a life that could have been the substance of several oldtime dime novels.

title: Asbestos Union and Manufacturer Fund Occupational Cancer Study
description: In an unusual display of cooperation over an ordinarily divisive issue, labor and industry jointly awarded half a milion dollars yesterday to Mount Sinai Medical Center here to finance an attempt to find a cure to an occupationally caused cancer.

title: AFTERNOON NEWSPAPER CLOSING IN CONNECTICUT
description: MERIDEN, Conn., Jan. 7 The Journal, which has been the afternoon. newspaper for this city of 55,000 since 1886, will go out of business tomorrow because of financial problems, its publisher announced today.

title: Topics
description: The mission of a fire department is easily defined: put out fires quickly, with least cost in suffering and money. It is therefore not astonishing that a muchheralded, littleunderstood fiscal crisis program to improve New York's municipal service  Management by Objectiveshould score its first success in the Fire Department.

title: Prague Detains Five Dissidents After Human Rights Manifesto
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 7At least five dissident Czechoslovak intellectuals have been detained for questioning in the last 24 hours, and the Communist Party newspaper Rude Pravo warned other dissidents that those who lie on the rails to stop the train of history must expect to get their legs cut off.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday.

title: Staley to Expand Vegetable Oil Refinery
description: The A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company announced plans for a major expansion of its vegetable oil refinery in Decatur, Ill., including construction of a new facility for hydrogenating table oils.

title: Ga. Tech, Clemson End Series
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 7 (AP)  Georgia Tech and Clemson University will not compete against each other in football after 1977, ending a series that began in 1898, Doug Weaver, Georgia Tech athletic director, announced today. He said the decision was made because of a dispute over scheduling arrangements.

title: U.S. Calls Soviet Refusal to Fund U.N. Force Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 7The State Department said today that the Soviet Union had acted illegally in refusing to pay its share for the mission of United Nations bufferzone forces created by the 1975 EgyptianIsraeli disengagement accord in the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Bird Poisoning Studied
description: Fred Ferrigno, leader of the Wetlands Ecology Project at the state's Tuckahoe Wildlife Management Area, said the number of birds poisoned in Lower Township of Cape May County last Monday may be twice the 1,155 bodies of redwing blackbirds and other species his crew found in a cornfield. He said residents as far as five miles from the field have reported additional dead birds since the count was made Wednesday.

title: Country Music Of Puerto Rico By Yomo Toro
TwoYear Package of $30 Billion Aims for 800,000 New Jobs
description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 7Presidentelect Carter and Democratic Congressional leaders said today that they were in general agreement on an array of programs to stimulate the economy by increased spending to create jobs, changes in the income tax system to, lower payments by persons of low and moderate income and for businesses and by a oneshot tax rebate for all taxpayers in 1977.

title: 3to6Inch Snow Disrupts Travel And Shuts Many Suburban Schools
description: A blustery winter storm frescoed the New York City and suburban landscapes with 3 to 6 inches of snow yesterday, closing hundreds of schools in outlying areas and generating scattered but occasionally lenghty delays for highway, rail and airline travelers.

title: Heinz Baby Food Plant In Pennsylvania to Close
description: The H. J. Heinz Company will close its baby food plant in Chambersburg, Pa., May 1 because Of a longterm decline in consumption of processed baby food.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: PORTLAND, MaineBilly Duquette, Brockton, Mass., outpointed Ricky Burgess, Thomaston, Maine, 10 rounds, and won the New England junior middleweight title.

title: Dow Rises by 3.24 to 983.13 Close; Average Down 21 for the Week
description: The stock market's feeble rally continued to lift prices slightly yesterday after a string of sharp declines earlier in the opening week of 1977.

title: Books of The Times
description: The servant problem, among the powerful, rich and famous, at any rate, has come to include the likelihood that at least one member of the staff is making notes for a book. The Queen of England's butler, a White House kennel man, chef, housekeeper, a Rockefeller au pair girl, and a member of the crew of Aristotle Onassis's yacht are among those who in recent years have provided what turned out to be not very interesting glimpses of master and mistress with their hair down.

title: WILLIAM D. PAWLEY, FINANCIER, DIES AT 80
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 7 (UPI)William D. Pawley, world financier, philanthropist, ambassador and special envoy for several Presidents, shot himself to death at his exclusive Sunset Island home today, the police said.

title: Dance: Skillful
description: It takes rare conviction, not to mention courage, to carry German Expressionist dance to a Germanic audience. Annabelle Gamson did so successfully at the Graz Festival in Austria last fall, when she presented excerpts from Mary Wigman's dances in her own interpretation. While shaping her own dances, she continues to explore the early days of modern dance, and showed the Wigman extracts as well as Isadora Duncan solos on her program Wednesday evening at the Theater of Riverside Church.

title: DelBello Appoints Panel to Spur Business
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 7Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, today named the five members of his newly created Industrial Development Agency, which was established to promote business and industrial development in the county.

title: Nixon Asks High Court to Bar Distribution of Watergate Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI)Former President Richard M. Nixon asked the Supreme Court today to bar public distribution of the White House tape recordings used against his closest aides at the Watergate coverup trial.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: AbdulJabbar Wins Game for Visitors
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 7The New York Nets recovered some of their homecourt intensity but none of their winning ways tonight at the Nassau Coliseum. They dropped their seventh straight game, this one by 8582 to the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: F.B.I. Chief in New York Will Testily on Burglaries
description: J. Wallace LaPrade, the head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's New York City office, has been summoned to appear next week before a Federal grand jury in Manhattan looking into illegal activities, including burglaries and unauthorized wiretaps, by F.B.I. agents in recent years.

title: Murdoch Wins Magazine Fight As Felker Settles
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher who acquired The New York Post last week, gained control of the New York Magazine Company yesterday after reaching an outofcourt settlement with Clay S. Felker, the founder of the magazine.

title: Gypsum Price Convictions Upset
description: PHILADELPHIA, JAN. 7 (AP)  A Federal appeals court has reversed pricefixing convictions against four gypsum board manufacturers and three executives.

title: U.S. Talks in Soviet On Grain at Impasse
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 7 (AP)  Assistant Secretary of Commerce Robert J. Blackwell left Moscow today after four days of talks that failed to resolve a dispute over how American grain should be shipped to the Soviet Union, a United States official said.

title: Lebanon Deadline Set on Weapons
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 7A special Arab committee supervising restoration of peace in Lebanon has set midnight Wednesday as a final deadline for the collection of heavy weapons from the rival militia forces of the Lebanese Christians and the alliance of Lebanese Moslems and leftists and Palestinian groups.

title: Albany Democrats Switch 13 Posts In Assembly by Naming Chairmen
description: ALBANY, Jan. 7The Democratic majority in the State Assembly completed its reorganization today with the appointment of 13 new committee chairmen, while the Republican leadership of the Senate was reported ready to make some major changes in its committee alignments next week.

title: CostCutting Venture Brings Steel Cargoes Back to Port
description: ELIZABETH, Jan.7The first major shipload of foreign steel products to arrive at the New JerseyNew York port area in six years was at dockside here today as the result of an unusual venture in costcutting operations by labor and management in the shipping industry and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: ExC.I.A. Man May Be Prosecuted
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7Philip B. Agee, the former Central Intelligence Agency agent who described many of the agency's LatinAmerican operations in his book. Inside the Company: CIA Diary, has been told there is a possibility he could face prosecution on espionage charges if he returns to the country.

title: ETHIOPIAN GUERRILLAS FREE 4 BRITONS, HELD SINCE MAY
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Jan. 7 (Reuters)A British family of four, released by Ethiopian guerrillas after being held since last May, has described how they lived in the open for months on end and had to be wary of attacks by the Ethiopian Air Force.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Connecticut Appoints First Women Troopers
description: Four women troopers, the first ever commissioned by the Connecticut state police, graduated yesterday from the State Police Training Academy in Meriden. The women were in a class that included 48 male troopers and two state policewomen. The successful candidates originally applied with 5,000 other people, more than half of whom failed the first written test. The Connecticut state police force has included policewomen since 1942, but women troopers were never commissioned for highway duty. The women will be assigned initially to cruisers with experienced troopers, but later will make patrols alone on state highways. The women who completed the 19week training course are: Karen Hall, of Meriden; Kathleen M. Conroy of Seymour; Marjorie J. Kolpa of Watertown, and Sandra M. Perzan of Forestville.

title: Pentagon Acts in Missile Dispute
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 7The Defense Department sought today to make legal an illegally awarded contract by certifying that a controversial airplane missile meets the requirements of the Air Force and Navy.

title: Rozelle Warns Against College Signings
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7Cool it, Tony Dorsett. The pros will not be coming at you waving money in your face, not for a while.

title: Nuclear Reactors Breeding Problems
description: WASHINGTONThe nuclear power industry today appears to face almost as many serious questions as it did 25 years ago when an experimental reactor in Idaho for the first time in history began generating a small charge of electricity, enough to light four bulbs.

title: P.S.C. Is Urged To Open Doors To All Meetings
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8The Public Service Commission was bathed in the glow of the state's new sunshine law this week, but there were immediate complaints that the commission was not letting enough sunshine in.

title: Chemicals: Health Is the New Priority
description: Vinyl chloride, a gaseous plastics chemical used since the 1940's to manufacture thousands of products, is found to cause an invariably fatal liver cancer in exposed workers. Investigation revealed that hundreds of millions of pounds escaped annually into the general environment, and many household aerosols used the gas as a propellant. Product bans and a massive manufacturing cleanup ensued.

title: FORUM ASSESSES SCHOOL BREAKFASTS
description: The complexities of the fourmonthold free and lowpriced breakfast program for publicschool children were explored yesterday at a meeting in New York City of educators, school board officials, parents, bureaucrats and politicians.

title: There's Data, Data, Everywhere...
description: WASHINGTONFederal paperwork costs Eli Lilly & Company $15 million a year and theoretically adds 50 cents to the price of every Lilly prescription, Richard D. Wood, chairman, complained recently. A Lilly application for an arthritis drug ran 120,000 pages.

title: Jobs Move Faster than The Jobless
description: WASHINGTONWhere are the jobs? Americans move from place to place Its much as any people in the world, except nomads, and when they move, a's often as not it is to a job. But despite this mobility, the process of people and jobs getting together  particularly unemployed people and jobsis far from automatic.

title: Dr. Forrest A. Irwin, 88, Retired As Jersey City College President
description: Dr. Forrest A. Irwin, former president of Jersey City State Teachers College, died yesterday at the Ashbrook Nursing Home in Scotch Plains, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived at 538 Fairmount Avenue. Westfield.

title: Jones BeachYes, Now
description: JONES BEACH

title: Amnesty Is Urged for Illegal Aliens
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 8 (UPI)A committee of Cabinet officials said today that illegal aliens were flooding into the United States to get jobs and that massive deportation would not solve the problem.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in last Sunday's Times said erroneously that the House Select Committee on Assassinations was aware of the formal criticism of some actions of Richard A. Sprague, its general counsel, before he was hired. The committee was not aware of this background.

title: Selected Poems 19231975
description: At the age of 71, Robert Penn Warren can scarcely be described an obscure or unappreciated writer. Twice In a career of copious production and numerous awards he has won the Pulitzer Prizefor fiction, with All the King's Men, in 1946; and for poetry, with Promises, in 1957and few indeed are the official literary honors that have been denied him. a literary culture like ours, moreover, in which commercial success is often felt to be at odds with academic scruples, Mr. Warren has enjoyed the best of both worlds. Several of his novels have been major book club selections, best sellers, and the basis of popular movies. Yet for the college classroom where best sellers are scorned and only serious literature is studied, and where Mr. Warren himself has spent much of his life teaching, he has written (in collaboration with Cleanth Brooks and others) textbooks such as Understanding Poetry and Understanding Fiction that have influenced several generations of students, not a few of whom became writers themselves.

title: EMPTY SHOPS WORRY 207TH ST. RESIDENTS
description: A row of vacant stores on West 207th Street, once a prosperous shopping area in the Inwood section of Manhattan, has begun to worry neighborhood shopkeepers and residents.

title: Is a tax cut or some other economic stimulus needed now?
description: MR. WOOD: Yes. A cut in rates for lower income people and elimination of double taxation of corporate income [when dividend income, having been taxed as corporate profits, is taxed again as shareholder income].

title: The Legislature: Feisty Session Due
description: The Legislature: Feisty Session Due

title: ROSENKRANZ'S TEAM IS LEADER IN BRIDGE
description: The battle for the right to represent North America in the 1977 world team bridge championship continued in Houston yesterday afternoon with a quintet headed by Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City holding the advantage.

title: Seoul Is Seeking Quick End of Dispute With U.S. Over Bribery Scandal
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 8South Korean Government officials are seeking, both publicly and privately, to put a swift end to the diplomatic dispute over alleged Korean bribing of members of the American Congress, which has severely strained relations between the two allies and greatly embarrassed the Government here.

title: Births
description: Greenberg

title: Oaxaca, Home Of the Zapotee
description: In the Zcalo, the central square of Oaxaca, a softvoiced Indian holds up a serape for inspection. Amigo, he says, my friend, lookvery good price. Like so many of Oaxaca's inhabitants, he is probably descended from the Zapotec architects, mathematicians and astronomers who built, then abandoned, the ancient city of Monte Albn a few miles away. In fact, his graven facethicklipped, flatnosedis a replica of those carved on the mysterious stones, some 2,500 years old, standing in Monte Alban today. In Oaxaca and its environs the Indian heritage persists, perhaps more vividly than in any other center of comparable size in Mexico.

title: FILM VIEW
description: In no other aspect of movies are the industry's carnival roots more appealingly apparent than in the movie ads that proclaim, promise, dare, warn, urge, and, when the movie is very hightoned, invite. How can anybody be seriously offended by the $25million remake of King Kong when the new movie comes on describing itself as The most exciting original motion picture event of all time? That particular adlineuncluttered by commashas such brassy, mocking selfassurance that it suggests that perhaps the person who wrote it should also have written the screenplay. The movie might have been funnier.

title: Charles Frend Dies in London; Produced Film The Cruel Sea
description: LONDON, Jan. 8 (Reuters)  Charles Frend, a British film producer best known for The Cruel Sea, died in a hospital here today after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

title: 2 CREWMEN HURT IN BLAST ON TANKER IN ATLANTIC
description: An explosion aboard a Liberianregistered tanker some 300 miles east of Norfolk, Va., injured two crewmen and knocked out the vessel's navigational equipment, the Coast Guard reported yesterday.

title: The Ball Passes to a Democrat
description: WASHINGTONDuring the election campaign there were times when candidate Jimmy Carter fired the hopes of impatient liberals and aroused the fears of the business community with ambitious talk of Presidential activism and the compassionate rhetoric of populism that evoked Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy.

title: Sportswriters Back Raiders
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (AP)A majority of sportswriters and broadcasters covering the Super Bowl game favored the Oakland Raiders today. The results of a poll were 76 to 46.

title: Atlanta in Midst of Retrenchment After a Decade of Rapid Expansion
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 8Atlanta, which prides itself on being the South's queen city, is in the midst of a painful economic retrenchment after a decade of extraordinary expansion.

title: Walter Parker, Banker, Marries Adrienne Austin
description: St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Elizabeth Adrienne Austin, a former fashion coordinator for Harper's Bazaar, to Walter vanEps Parker, an assistant vice president with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company's special loan group. The Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay performed the ceremony.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Son in New Controversy Because His Company Is Sales Agent for Foreign Concerns
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 8Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's son Sanjay has gone into the agency business, with his automobile company acting as the sales agent for foreign corporations that want to do business in India.

title: The New Seed Catalogues Are Coming
description: PAGING through the 1977 seed catalogues which are arriving in the mails requires the same sort of discipline as buying food in a cafeteria. There are too many choicesdelightful to contemplate and there is never room for all. Oh to pick and choose with reckless abandon and let cares fall where they may!

title: Payoffs: Are They Stopped or Just Better Hidden?
description: WASHINGTONIn August 1974 the United Brands Company faced a dilemme.

title: What's Doing in CAMBRIDGE, England
description: THE TOWN  Cambridge University has dominated this town about 50 miles north of London for 700 years. It is the university of Byron and Tennyson, Milton and Wordsworth, Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin, Pandit Nehru and Bertrand Russell. From here John Harvard went to Massachusetts. Cambridge is a proud matriarch, often complacent in its rivalry with Oxford. Unlike Oxford, it is not overwhelmed by the pressures of industrial development in its suburbs. The peaceful villages of the Cambridgeshire countryside are less frequented than those surrounding Oxford. So, in the indignant words of a Cambridge student handbook, the colleges can maintain their 2,800 servants on rockbotton wages; tradition is preserved and the cameras keep clicking at the quaintness of it all. How long this romantic idyll or economic repression will continue is one of the town's greatest topics. For today's visitors it takes only 70 minutes by train from London's Liverpool Street Station to reach Cambridge's elegant courtyards and lofty bells.

title: SHOP TALK
description: THE Craft Concepts Gallery in Ridgewood selects works by 100 professional artists from all over the country and arranges them into shows that change every eight weeks.

title: Michael Gage Is Bride Of William Hellerstein
description: Michael Gage, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter P. Gage of Peekskill, N.Y., was married at her homein Manhattan yesterday afternoon to William E. Hellerstein son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Martin Hellerstein of the Bronx. State Supreme Court Justice Leon B. Polsky performed the ceremony.

title: Richard Holbrooke Weds Blythe Babyak
description: The Jan. 1 marriage of Blythe Babyak and Richard Holbrooke of Washington, managing editor of Foreign Policy magazine, has been disclosed. The ceremony was performed in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by Bishop Paul Moore Jr.

title: Beame Wishes a Deficit Away
description: Mayor Beanie has finally submitted his plan for ending the deficit in New York City's budget, and it includes proposal to cut the city's services still further, meaning dirtier and less well policed streets. But much of what Mr. Beame believes will put the city in the black seems to be, at least for now, in the area of wishful thinking: He says he expects a lot of money from people who have not yet said they would give it to him.

title: STAMPS
description: Action on three fronts of the American Revolution and other events of 200 years ago that influenced the nation's destiny, all continuing the observance of the American Bicentennial, form the dominant note of the stamps being issued by the United States during 1977.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Oaxaca, you can fly nonstop with Mexicana Airlines from Mexico City or take Aeromexico with one or more stops. The roundtrip fare is $39. Of the principal hotels, the Victoria, on the PanAmerican Highway outside the city, offers rooms at $18 double, $15 single, European Plan. For the modified American Plan add $6 a person and for the full American Plan, $10 a person. Mision de los Angeles (formerly Oaxaca Courts), Porfirio Diaz 102, about a mile from the Z6calo, is a motel with a small swimming pool, small rooms and a green setting. The rates are $16.50 double, $14.25 single, European Plan; breakfast $2.25, lunch or dinner $5.60. El Presidente, at Avenida 5 de Mayo at the corner of Plazoleta Labastida, five blocks from the Zcalo, is a new hotel converted from the Convent of Santa Catalina at a reported cost of $1.6 million. It covers an entire city block, has a swimming pool in the patio and enormous rooms. Rates for a standard room are $22.50 double and $19.50 single on the European Plan and $36.25 double with the American Plan and $33.25 single.

title: Miscellany
description: BACKSTAGE TOURS OF MET OPERAIn cluding prop shops. costume departments and dressings rooms. MonsFris., 3:45; Sats., 10:30. (For reservations, call 5827500.)

title: In Queens, A Blend Of Class And Crass
description: Urban archeologists always need new terrain. One of the most accessible and overlooked sites lies just across the East River in Long Island City, once a prosperous and promising community, now, to most New Yorkers, little more than Paragon Paints, indoor tennis, Sunshine Biscuits, or simply the brief interplay of yeast and varnish in the air in the course of transit to Queens. In fact, to all but those who live there, Long Island City, which shares a Dutch and English colonial heritage with Manhattan, and was once a hunter's and birdwatcher's paradise, is an unfathomable and undistinguished maze of industrial trappings. It needs investigation.

title: Article 9  No Title
Those Limousines Keep Rolling Along
description: Inauguration time is limousine time in Washington, and the plethora of long dark vehicles that will feature in telecasts from the nation's capital will focus attention anew on the curiously American preoccupation with big cars.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: MEYERSVILLE is an anomaly, a page out of a bygone, simpler age, when the condition of a man's barn was some index of his fortune. Situated about 30 air miles west of Times Square, immediately adjacent to the 6,000acre Great Swamp Wildlife Refuge, it is a Brigadoon of pastoral lands and rambling, porched homes that appear abruptly out of the mist of a tinseled suburbia.

title: Growth, Not Grits, Symbolizes the New South
description: ATLANTAThe South's time has come, Governor Reubin Askew of Florida says. Our region is the new economic frontier. We've still got some problems that need watching, like unemployment holdover from the recession and unplanned growth, but the wheel has definitely turned in our favor.

title: Tarkenton's Obsession
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 8He's no longer the Fran Tarkenton who was known as God's quarterback. In those years Joe Namath was the devil's quarterbackthe swinger, the long hair, the Super Bowl guarantee. But the world turns and Fran Tarkenton has turned with it. He's separated from his wife and three children, he

title: Canadian Company
description: When a Canadian steel company that the state has been wooing opens its factory in Perth Amboy, the Legislature's repeal of several state business taxes last year will be at least one of the reasons.

title: Business Morality Has Not DeterioratedSociety Has Changed
description: The rash of disclosures of corporate bribes and other illegal payments here and abroad has provoked a chorus of questions about ethics, morality, and the modern corporate executive.

title: Dance: Ballet Theater's Coppelia
description: There may be no originality at all about the repertory the American Ballet Theater is offering during its monthlong season at the City Center 55th Street Theater.
