Indeed there isn't it consists of two weeks of Copplia followd by two weeks of Giselle. This can rather grandly be thought of as less than adventurous. Indeed it is dismal.

title: Frazier Stars as Knicks Turn Back Suns, 10295
description: Walt Frazier, unable to cope with Paul Westphal defensively, staged lastquarter offensive show last night that provided the Knicks with a 10295 victory over the Phoenix Suns before Madison Square Garden crowd of 18,589.

title: For young readers
description: Most notably in Crow, a recent collection that celebrates violence of a scary, totemistic kind, Ted Hughes has become owner of a vision that escapes from the usual human values.

title: City Council Hearings For the Week Are Listed
description: The following public hearings will be held by New York City Council committees this week:

title: Hospital Nurses In a Poll Report Needless Deaths
description: Out of 10,000 nurses across the country who responded to a questionnaire, 3,800 said that they would not want to be a patient in the hospitals where they worked.

title: Sad in Greenwich Village, glad in Atlantic City
description: In contemporary writing we seem to be enduring a period when everything is coming out but nothing much is being faced or deeply understood. Everything gets told, especially the unspeakable, but the task of locating meaning is bungled, fudged or simply ignored. This development reflects the times. One notices a bumper sticker on a speeding van which proclaims: IF IT FEELS GOOD DO IT. But what does that mean? And who by the way is speaking? Manson? Blake? Lucifer? And who is supposed to feel good? Both the person who does IT and the person to whom IT is done, or merely the former? Answers to such questions do make a difference. But the van, speeding out of sight, won't stay for an answer. Could it be that these are the questions people are discussing over their new CB's?

title: $9.20 Whatsyourpleasure Triumphs in Paumonok
description: Just before yesterday's 67th running of the Paumonok Handicap, Menotti Aristone, who had , come to Aqueduct just to ride Mrs. Arnold. A. Willcox's Whatsyourpleasure, said he felt his 4yearold mount > had an outstanding chance of winning the $52,800 sixfurlong fixture.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Continued from page 1

title: St. John's Sets Back R.I., 8267
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 8Seton Hall took the lead at the start tonight and defeated Villanova, 9180. Greg Tynes and Glenn Mosley again paced the Pirates. Tynes scored 32 points, hid career high. Mosley, the nation's top rebounder, had 21 rebounds, 22 points and blocked seven shots.

title: Candidate for the Priesthood Says Jesuit Superiors Bar His Ordination Because He Is a Homosexual
description: A 36year old candidate for the Jesuit priesthood who otherwise completed the order's arduous requirements over a 13year period, says he has been told by his superiors that he will not be ordained because he is a homosexual.

title: ACCUSED SOVIET SPY KNOWN AS A DRIFTER
description: Ivan N. Rogalsky, a 34yearold Soviet immigrant arrested Friday night as Soviet spy, was portrayed yesterday by acquaintances as an unemployed drifter who eventually settled in a closely knit Russian community in central New Jersey and developed a reputation as a troublemaker.

title: COLUMBIA APPOINTS DEAN 4T UNDERGRADUATE SCHOOL
description: Dr. Ward H. Dennis, who has held a variety of faculty and administrative positions at Columbia University during the last 16 years, has been named dean of its School for General Studies, where he has been serving as acting dean since July 1.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FEDERAL RESERVE BOARD reported that consumer credit extended in November declined to seasonally adjusted $15.76 billion from October's adjusted figure $16.05 billion. . . . Manufacturers shipments climbed sharply in November while inventories remained virtually flat. New orders, rising $1.2 billion topped $100 billion for the first time. Manufacturers sales rose $2.8 billion in November $100.5 billion, the largest monthly increase since April 1975. lnentories grew less than $250 million to a total of $166.9 billion.

title: Assienment Pleases Mondale
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)Senator Mondale issued a statement from his office today expressing pleasure with his tour assignment.

title: POLITICS
description: NOW that the last strains of Auld Lang Syne have faded, the time is at hand for political leaders to forget some old acquaintances and pick up some new ones. In short, it is the time to take your best hold, as the old adage goes, and to remember to pick friends only from among those who can win.

title: Ticket Fees, Night Action, Glide Into Ski Tour Scene
description: ASPEN, Colo.In a season during which interest in crosscountry phase of skiing continues to mushroom, Ashcroft Ski Touring Unlimited, operating in the neighboring scenic Castle Creek Valley, had to open last month under wraps. we had no choice said Greg: Mace, manager of Ashcroft which is considered among America's plushest ski touring complexes. Just like those local .big downhill skiing giants at Ajax Mountain and Snowmass, we didn't have enough snow.. So we allowed skiers to use. few of our trails gratis.

title: The Delicate Lass With The Sensuous Flute
description: The photograph that adorns the cover of flutist Paula Robison's recent Vanguard recording, Flute Music of the Romantic Era, shows the artist in a sexy, slinky, bareshouldered red evening dress. A small, delicate red rose nestles in the fall of her soft brown hair. This image of sensual femininity is abetted by the elegant, balletic grace with which she holds her silver flute to her lips. Eyes lowered, and lost in concentration, she is seen in the act of performing that has recently brought Miss Robison extraordinary acclaim.

title: For Carter's Camp, It Wasn't as Easy as It Looked
description: WASHINGTONThe months between election and inauguration are a time when politicians traditionally find themselves coming face to face with reality, and Presidentelect Carter and the members of his transition team are no exception.

title: Meet the Impulsive Buyer
description: That's me. I'm impractical, laughs Jean Warner of Rockville, Md. I'd rather buy a new outfit than buy food.

title: Think Tanks Have Sprung a Leak
description: WASHINGTONFor the better part of this century Americans have been brought up to think of their country as the mother of invention, the fountainhead of technology. But in recent months scientists have been warning that the think tanks are running low.

title: PEOPLE
description: Dorothy Dinerstein is a professor of psychology and a Member of the Institute for Cognitive Studies at Rutgers University. She is also the author of a new book, published by Harper & Row, with the provocative title of The Mermaid and the Minotaur. The tome, a scholarly one, is an examination of the underlying reasons behind acceptance by people of gender roleplaying, and so it will probably be read with interest by feminists, psychologists, and social philosophers. Mrs. Dinnerstein says she began working ,on the book in 1970, but I am a slow, slow writer.

title: A Dentist Teaches Political Science
description: HAWTHORNE

title: Music Notes: The Pride of Kansas City Comes Home
description: Kansas City, which was very much in the news last summer as the site of the Republican Convention, is still trying to strengthen its image. One way it is doing this Is to send the Kansas City Philharmonic to the Kennedy Center in Washington and Carnegie Hall here for concerts. Appearing in Carnegie's International Festival of Visiting Orchestras. the organization will be making its first New York appearance in its 43year history. Nearly felled by deficit problems a few years ago, it is now in the major classification of American symphonic ensembles, which means that its budget is over $1.5 million.

title: Austrians In Sweep Of Downhill,
description: LES GETS, France, Jan. 8 (UPI) Patricia Emonet of France, 16 years old, skied to a surprise victory today in the women's special slalom event counting toward the women's European Cup. Miss Emonet, who edged Pamela. Behr of West Germany in the special slalom, previously registered a victory last Thursday in the La . Clusaz special slalom race, also counting for the European Cup.

title: Laura Ann Wicker To Be Wed in April

title: The Nation

Starting last Jan. 1 all dips, as the documents are called in the trade, must carry a fiveyear expiration date. Heretofore, for 60 years, the State Department regulars have quietly blocked all moves to limit diplomatic passports, like ordinary passports, to a fixed term.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: New year. San Diego. Key Biscayne. Puerto Rico. Palm Springs. Fort Lauderdale. The Dominican Republic. They're some of the sunny places where, not long before Christmas, major massmarket paperback firms conducted an ancient publishing rite, the seasonal sales conference. The weather. returnees report, ranged from good to lousy, In the Dominican Republic, Montezuma descended to inflict his revenge. Even in the balmiest spots, swimming and golf played second fiddle to the meetings real purpose  to give the inmates of the New York headquarters a chance to discuss with the men who distribute their publications across the country the shape of things to come.

title: Science & Technology
description: Although the point is seldom made clear in official or journalistic accounts, the space program is interesting not so much for what it tells us about space but for what it tells us about ourselves. This is true, par excellence, of the Skylab missions, in which men did not merely travel through space to get somewhere else but actually lived in spacefor periods of 28, 59 and 84 daysunder conditions of total weightlessness. In A ROUSE IN SPACE (Holt, Rinehart and Winston, $8.95), Henry S. F. Cooper Jr. who has been covering the space program for The New Yorker since the early Apollo flightsdescribes the effects on the human body and psyche of what he calls a suspension of natural laws familiar on earth. Our muscles, bones and circulatory system are products of two billion years of evolution conditioned by gravity. So, presumably, are our emotions and thought processes. Take a fish out of water and it drowns. Take away gravity and what happens to a man? The Skylab missions provided the first answers to this fundamental question. Reporting in depth on the astronauts adjustments and maladjustments to weightlessness, Cooper has written the one book about the space program that nonspacebuffs owe it to themselves to read.

description: South African principles

title: I.B.M. vs. A.T.&T.The Coming Struggle

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 8 (AP)Praphas Charusathien, a former military strongman, returned here from exile in Taipei today, his peaceful arrival contrasting with the bloody riots that greeted his previous attempt to return to Thailand last year.MURCIA, Spain, Jan. 8 (UPI)Thieves using a blow torch to cut through iron bars and chains today stole thousands of diamonds, rubies, sapphires and emeralds worth an estimated $4.4 million from the cathedral here police sources said.LIMA, Jan. 8 (Reuters)The Peruvian Government has ordered two generals. an admiral and a navy captain expelled from the country for leftist opposition activity, police sources said today.

title: The Subject Is Money
description: In fashioning his program for spurring economic recovery, Presidentelect Carter has produced a figure ranging from $25 billion to $32 billion, which is likely to satisfy political demands for a vigorous stimulus, and a method, dividing the stimulus over two years, that takes account of economic realities.

title: Chambers Voted Toughest
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (AP)Wally Chambers, defensive tackle of the Chicago Bears, received the Bulldog of the Year award today. The award voted on by the National Football's League offensive linemen, who select the man they feel was their toughest opponent of the season. The 6foot6inch, 260pound Chambers received trophy and bulldog puppy. A $2,500 scholarship, to be donated to a school or charity of his choice, was also included.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)The rate of growth in the economy this year will probably be slower than last year, the Commerce Department said today. But it added that the growth should be enough to reduce unemployment without stimulating inflation.

For now it is up to Congress, with its recently expanded and sophisticated budget machinery, to put its priorities in order.

title: Dark Songs by California's Eagles
description: Somewhere out there is Southern California, as far away as anyone can get in this country from the northeast, both in miles and mores. It is almost impossible to talk about the Eagles without mentioning Californiadream and realitynot just because the state figures in the title of their newest album, Hotel California, but because, more than any other group since the early Beach Boys, they ere so firmly rooted in that territory, exploring its myths, way of life, pleasures and perils. If the American population is inevitably heading south and west, as statistics indicate, the Eagles, in five albums over five years, have been sending out reports of the fantasies and realities that will be found there.

title: Two That Were Tough
description: The elderly owner of a declining gristmill shares his solitude with a wild gray rooster. In a series of anecdotal chapters that span several years both man and bird evade attempts at capture, the one by his concerned daughter who urges him to come live with her in Atlanta, the otherfrom chick onby a series of predators: farmer, fisherman, children, foxes. Both, though their wills are strong, gradually become less able to sustain their freedom. The climax occurs when Mr. Hilton, at last succumbing to the Atlanta entreaties, captures the neverbeforeconfined rooster in order to save it by taking it with him.

For Mr. Schultze is respected by many in Congress, the economic profession and private business. He is known as a liberal whose views have been tempered by Government experience, and as a formidable authority on the Federal budget.

All this training has produced a wellschooled technician, who has agile fingers and who produces a consistently fine tone. In her debut recital here in Alice Tully Hall on Friday night, she also gave honest, dependable readings of the music she played. Beyond that, however, she did not go.

Abzug, who gave up her seat in the House of Representatives to make a bidunsuccessfulfor the United States Senate. The post most often mentioned for Mrs. Abzug is the $42.000ayear chairmanship of the Federal Trade

title: Jimmy the OddsMaker
description: Like Jimmy the Greek, Jimmy Carter likes to figure the odds for us all and to risk very little of his own. We have now seen this pattern repeating itself in his approach to the big decisions and can fairly begin to make our own calculations about the sort of President we have chosen. The pattern emerged in his campaign, where he came on as a hybrid of George McGovern and George Wallace to unite his party. We saw it again in his choice of a Cabinet, where he ground out a brew of the safe and the brightest. And we see it confirmed now in his first economic plan, a program of stimulation that is liberal in impulse and conservative in size.

title: Carter and Aides Decided Economy Needed More Than Year's Stimulus
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Presidentelect Carter and his economic policy advisers decided on a twoyear program of economic stimulus, with a total price tag of $25 billion to $32 billion, because they feared that a oneyear program, even one costing up to $20 billion, might not be adequate to get the economy back onto a solid growth path.

Another organization, the Long Island Women's Coalition, has received one private grant and pledges of others for the purchase of a house that it wants to operate as a shelter for abused wives.

title: PEOPLE
description: ALOT of Suffolk County history is going into retirement tomorrow in the person of Dominick W. Chiuchiolo. After 35 years of police serviceduring which he rose from the rank of patrolman for the village of Patchogue to inspector on the county police force Mr. Chiuchiolo is ending his career. He became a sergeantin the Patchogue department after returning from service in World War II and succeeded Reynold K. Wicks as chief of the department in 1954. After the force was merged into the new county police force in 1960, Mr. Chiuchiolo became a captain, then a deputy inspector in 1963 and an inspector in 1974. He will be honored next Friday at testimonial dinner at Felice's of Patchogue; chairman of the event is F. Carley Johannsen, a retired inspector from East Patchogue.

title: State Department Under Vance Is Expected to Be Solid but Not So Colorful as Kissinger's
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  Cyrus R. Vance, the Secretary of Statedesignate, has just about completed putting together the new State Department high command. It promiseslike its leadersto be less controversial but less colorful than Henry A. Kissinger's State Department.

description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 8 (AP)The authorities held out little hope today that Frank Sinatra's mother or three other persons on a missing private jet might be found alive.

description: As pianists of quality go, Karen Shaw may not be famous, but she is far from being unknown. Her recital Friday night at Carnegie Hall was her second solo appearance there in as many seasons.

description: The football fan strikes me as an absorbing field for study. Every psychologist I know has examined his urges, and I've got a couple of theories of my own.

title: Documentary Melodrama Shown
description: It seems so totally narcissistic, a viewer commented during a screening of AKALQ, the documentary melodrama created by Michael Newman, the poet, Joan Schwartz, the video artist, and Benjamin Folkman, the composer. And it did. The work of Miss Schwartz, visually spectacular though it was, and the clever piano score by Mr. Folkman took a back seat to the antics of Mr. Newman, who read, mugged, played the guitar, and generally dominated the piece, which was shown on video monitors at the New School Cinema on Friday.

title: Baranello for Cunningham
description: Governor Carey Is expected to pick Dominic J. Baranello, the Democratic leader in Suffolk County, as the party's state chairman, primarily to pay off political debt: Mr. Baranello was the first important Democrat to support Mr. Carey's gubernatorial candidacy.

title: It's Becoming O.K. in America For Boys to Dance
description: Three years ago, the boys in the openingnight Party Scene of the New York City Ballet's Nutcracker were rimed Diane, Amity, Thera, Leslie and (the lone member of his sex) Michael. This year they were Michael, Kenneth, Adam, Jiro and Peter. The change from the customary use of prepubescent female ballet students, their long hair scooped up into berets, pretending to be boys, to the influx of young male students in the children's roles of this production is just a bit of evidence of a small but significant increase in the number of young boys presently studying ballet in America.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Dr. Varda Ganz Wed to Prof. George E. Backus
description: Dr. Varda Feller Ganz, a psychiatrist and clinical coordinator at the Cowell Student Health Center of Stanford University, was married yesterday at her home in Palo Alto, Calif., to George Edward Backus of La Jolla, Calif. He is a professor of geophysics at the Institute of Geophysics and Planetary Physics and the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California, San Diego. The Rev. Robert Hamerton Kelly, dean of the Stanford Chapel, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Tonight the New York Opera Orchestra conducted by Eve Queler is going to present a concert version of Bedrich Smetana's Dalibor, an opera whose time has perhaps come. It is not known to American opera buffs except through recordings, but in London the English National Opera staged Dalibor a short time ago, and everybody raved. There also was general surprise about the work's depth, richness and passion, a reaction that showed a certain navet. It should have stood to reason that the composer of The Bartered Bride, The Moldau and the other symphonic poems was not exactly an amateur. A composer so deified by his own people certainly should have something to say to others outside his own country.

title: Home Clinic.
description: Q: My house has wood shingles which were treated by painting them with linseed oil. Is it now possible to apply shingle stain over the linseed oil, or must I always continue to use the same treatment on these shingles?L.E.B., Bridgeport, Conn.

title: ART VIEW
description: Jim Dine belongs to the generation of American artists that carne to fameand thus to their first museum retrospectiveearly. (Has anyone calculated by how many years the Pop art movement changed the age at which artists were to be considered ripe for such retrospectives? My own impression is that Pop, combined with the general accent on youth in the 1960's, altered the very notion of what a museum retrospective ought to be, effectively separating it from the concept of artistic maturity.) When the Whitney Museum of American Art organized Mr. Dine's retrospective in 1970, he was 35an age at which Willem de Kooning, for example, had not yet had his first oneman show in a gallery. By 1970, the museum retrospective had become a showcase for young art, and Mr. Dine was one of the many artists to benefit from the new dispensation.

title: News of Realty; Dodge Estate Sale
description: The P.I.C. Realty Corporation, a subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company, has purchased 384 acres in Madison and Chatham Township, N.J., from the estate of Mrs. Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge for $9 million.

description: The political problems that diluted the track and field competition at the Montreal Olympics have been extended into the 1977 indoor season.

title: Rachel Grossman Is Engaged to Arnold M. Phillips
description: Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Grossman of Irvington, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Vicki Rachel Grossman, to Arnold M. Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Phillips of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: Talk With Robert Penn Warren
description: Robert Penn Warren and his wife Eleanor Clark, herself a writer of distinction, live on a back country road in Fairfield, Conn., in a pair of attached converted barns, spacious and elegant, 17thcentury masonry in the foundations. When the interviewer arrived, the couple was putting finishing touches on the planning of a monster holiday gala, involving a couple of dozen weekend guests among othersdiscussing fire extinguishers, for instance, with a home protection systems man. Things calmed after a bit. R.P.W., a leancheeked, livelyeyed man of medium build with an outdoorsman's complexion and an air of dependable, longrange, goodfortheduration sociability, laid more logs on the fire and mentioned the possibility of drink. This was nursued. Eleanor Clark, a slight, strikingly graceful, blondehaired woman in blue jeans, cardigan and sneakers, excused herself, seeking tea. A joke or two followed about the poet/novelist's adeptness with a tape recorder while he was doing the extensive interviews from which emerged Who Speaks for the Negro?. Then:

title: Gregg Is Back in Porsche Driver's Seat
description: Peter Gregg, the Harvard graduate who has become one of this country's premier roadracing drivers, has confirmed he will return to Porsche for the 1977 season after spending last year with BMW. It will be like going home

title: Dog Award Is Achieved By Charlie
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 8  Windy Hill's Makes Its Point, an 11monthold black and tan, went winners dog for a 5point major among ascob cocker spaniels last night at the American Spaniel Club's 600 specialty in the Holiday Inn Jetport.

title: BRIDGE
description: Conventionmakers who like to invent new meanings for opening bids have long found two diamonds a most attractive vehicle for their ideas. For almost two decades hardly a year has gone past without somebody inventing new one, since the bid has little value as a natural strong bid or a weak preemptive one.

title: Budgetary Hopes and Fears
description: In preparation for its final year of fiscal adolescence, New York City has submitted to its state guardians on the Emergency Financial Control Board an amended financial plan for the year beginning July 1. Under the emergency law that has kept the city out of formal bankruptcy, the board must approve the plan as satisfying the requirement that the city will not spend one cent more than it receives. It must determine the soundness of what is perforce a look into the future, a mixture of fact, hope and prayer. No easy task.

title: Gen. Kulikov, 55, Is Made Warsaw Pact Commander
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 8Gen. Viktor G. Kulikov, Chief of the General Staff of the Soviet armed forces, was named today as the new commander of the Warsaw Pact forces, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency. The former commander, Marshal Ivan I. Yakubovsky, died Nov. 30.

title: DINING OUT
description: COLLIGAN'S Stockton Inn has a reputation as a touristy kind of place where no one really expects much more than a bountiful relish tray. If a recent experience is in any way typical, nothing could be further from the truth. True, there are invitations to visit the centuryold wine cave, and to toss in coins in the well that allegedly inspired Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart to come up with the wishing well in There's a Small Hotel.

title: HoustonBooming Even by Sunbelt Standards
description: HOUSTONBehind the growth and prosperity of Houston is the ageold promise of the Westopportunity. Houston is an attractive city for people who want to work, says Louie Welch, former mayor and head of the Chamber of Commerce. Those who don't can get a better deal in New York or St. Louis.

title: USE OF ST. LAWRENCE FOR ALL YEAR SOUGHT
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8A sixyear, $17 million program to determine the environmental impact of opening the St. Lawrence River to winter commercial shipping has begun in a cooperative venture involving several United States Government agencies, Canadian groups and New York State colleges.

title: Electronic Deadline on Wall Street
description: A central market for trading securities, the longawaited national market system, is comingand coming fast. But the securities industry is grappling over what its shape will be.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: The Brief Career of Superman as a Pro Athlete
description: The big man loomed over the agent's desk: blond, broadshouldered, the huge S on his chest as unmistakable trademark as the cape around his shoulders.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: What could be easier than starting a new house plant from seed? Here is a delightful one to try, the silk oak (Grevillea robusta). The leaves are feathery and fernlike with a soft touch not unlike dusty miller.

title: Red Smith
Boa Constrictor in Flowerland
description: MELROSE PARK, Ill,, Jan. 8 (AP)A 4foot boa constrictor has been reported loose in Amling's Flowerland. A spokesman said the snake was missing from its glass enclosure since Wednesday. It may have left the store's pet department and slithered into the big display area of flowers and plants, he said. The make sells for $69.99 and can go four months without eating, the spokesman said. really can't hurt anyone, but it sure could scare someone bending over to smell flower.

title: James Barber Jr. Fiance of Miss Helmstadter
description: Lynda Dianne Helmstadter and James Laurance Barber Jr., graduates of Stanford University, plan to be married April 16 in Stanford's Memorial Chapel.

title: FREDERICK E. GIBSON, 69 A LONG ISLAND BUILDER
description: Frederick E. Gibson, a wellknown Long Island homebuilder, died yesterday at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore after long illness. He was 69 years old lived at 87 South Saxon Avenue in Bay Shore.

title: Torn Stoppard Tries On A Knickers Farce
description: The last time Tom Stoppard was in New York with a new play was in 1975 with Travesties. He was around to tinker with the second act. The second act of Travesties had a lot to do with Lenin, and Lenin wasn't very funny, at least to American audiences, and so Stoppard, who never stops rewriting his plays, was moving Lenin around the stage to see how he looked from different angles. To an interviewer at: that time, Stoppard confided that his next project would be a serious play about totalitarianism.

title: The Missing Persons League
description: Frank Bonham's latest novel centers on Brian Foster, a teenager living some 20 years from now. The atmosphere is dangerously thin, animals and vegetables are almost nonexistent, and the worst is yet to come. In the midst of this calamity, many people have mysteriously disappeared, including Brian's mother and sister. The authorities want to discover how and why the disappearances occur. So does Brian. And his search into the subsequent fate of his family becomes the key to his own fate as well.

title: Narcotics Suspect Shot to Death
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 8. (AP)Narcotics officers serving a search warrant shot and killed a man who the officers said jumped from a bedroom closet and aimed a shotgun at them. The dead man was identified as Roger Allen Smith, 22 years old, an electronic technician front Oneonta, N. Y. He Was shot six times on Wednesday.

title: Marines in Klan Openly Abused Blacks at Pendleton, Panel Hears
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Jan. 8A military court has heard testimony that troop commanders at this large Marine Corps base allowed enlisted men belonging to the Ku Klux Klan to flaunt their Klan insignia, wear nigger sticker knives and incite brawls with black marines.

title: Rose Bowl by Other Name Smells Sweet to Pasadena
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 8The Rose Bowl is the ultimate symbol of college football's postseason glory, the first and most historic of the New Year's Day festivals that have brought the term bowl game into the language so strongly that the National Football League's champion game was designated officially as a Super Bowl.

title: Sports. News Briefs
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Jan. 8 (AP)Earl Anthony of Tacoma, Wash., began the 1977 pro bowling season with a convincing victory today in the $80,000 Lite Classic tournament.

title: Winter's Fangs
description: Now comes the time of the Wolf Moon, as the Indians called it, when hunger drove the pack and the fangs were sharp and eager. Most of the wolves are gone, but fangs of the primal forces of winter persist, fangs of ice and cold.

title: American Dream or Nightmare?
description: NEW JERSEY, in its long, often glorious, existence as a state has had a goodly number of firsts to its credit, but, frankly, I can't remember one of them. Perhaps when my mind stops screaming for me to get these thoughts onto paper I'll look up some of those firsts. Perhaps they'll serve to remind me that hope for the equality inherent in the American Dream is not misplaced among this nationstate's people of color.

title: This Time, a Rail Tunnel
description: THE faltering economies of the Island and New England need an electric railroad tunnel that would piggyback cars and trucks the 19 miles between Wading River and New Haven, and connect the deadend Long Island Rail Road into the railroad system of the Northeast.

title: Jewish School in Buenos Aires Is Severely Damaged by a Bomb
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 9 (AP)Bombs exploded yesterday at a Jewish school in Buenos Aires and at the home of Jewish businessman, security sources reported. The school building and house were severely damaged.BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 8 (UPI)Dardo Manual Cabo, a guerrilla leader, died in an attempt by associates to free him from a prison van on Wednesday in Coronet BrantIgen, newspapers reported today. He hijacked an Argentine airliner to the Falkland Islands in September 1986.

title: Federal Judge in Texas Decides That Executions May Be Pictured for TV
description: DALLAS, Jan. 8A Federal district judge here has ruled that television stations may film executions at the state penitentiary, but the stations are not sure that they will ever show such events.

title: The Region
description: In Summary

title: I Tell You, You Get Tired of Doing Nothing
description: Yeah. I went up to Lexington and 63d looking a couple of times. But I didn't go into the stores. I just looked on the outside for Help Wanted signs. I didn't want to get rejected. You get tired of it happening all the time.

title: Ferry That Doesn't Move Helps Youths Get Ahead
description: The red ferryboat Maj. Gen, William Hart has run back and forth between despair and hope for four years. And it has never left its berth at the South Street Seaport Museum. The Hart is the home of the Pioneer Marine School. The school, started as an efNews fort to turn former drug addicts and hardcore unof employed youths into Boating skilled marine mechanics, nearly foundered in a morass of red tape two year ago. Now it has emerged as one of the city's top vocational schools.

title: Give Me Your Rich
description: New York City's main task, says Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, is to devrlop a program that adds a new slogan to the Statue of Liberty:

title: Missing for Years:
description: We're marching to a damn foolish drummer, says John W. Hanley, chairman of the Monsanto Company, referring to the nation's energy policy. We don't have a good one and the problem is serious.

title: A great success with the ladies
description: It is almost impossible to separate the legendary and the real Natalie Barney. To the proper Parisian of the period she was an oddity, locally famous, a landmark on the rues and boulevards; but to Americans she was a virtual unknown. Born to wealth and social position in Dayton, Ohio, in 1876, she belonged, like Gertrude Stein and Ezra Pound, to that generation of cultural expatriates who believed that society, in the sense of good company, could not be found in the United States. If it existed anywhere, it existed in the Paris of the Belle Epoqueand by the turn of the century Miss Barney had become something of a notorious figure in France. Her residence on The rue Jacob in Paris Left Bank provided the setting for an international salon attended by a number of the leading writers, artists and aristocrats of the day, including Stein, Pound, Colette, Cocteau, Gide, Valery, Anatole France, and Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald.

title: Is the Government Subsidizing Sexism in Film?
description: Arecent form letter Mini Congressman Fred Richmond of New York's 14th District asks me to support his Arts and Humanities Bill, HR 8274, and to contact the media in its behalf. The bill seeks to establish a checkoff system on Federal Income Tax forms permitting taxpayers to make direct contributions to the National Endowment for the Arts, or the National Endowment for the Humanities, or to both. I'll gladly support Congressman Richmond's bill if he'll support mine. My proposed bill would end Governmentsubsidized sexdiscrimination On programs supported by Arts and Humanities funds, particularly those related to the art of film, a field in which I have struggled for over 20 years.

title: The Nation
description: Presidentelect Carter has made known his administration's code for preventing conflicts of interest in government and, as he had promised; goes beyond present custom and statute in a number of significant ways.

title: Article 4  No Title
Elizabeth McCollum Wed to George Ray
description: Elizabeth Fisher McCollum of New York and George Lyon Ray of West Hartford, Conn., were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Hayes Rockwell, the rector of St. James Episcopal Church. The ceremony took place at the home of the bride's son, Gordon H. McCollum Jr. of New York.

title: The American Police State
description: It's easy to make fun of critics of the American irtelligence community. After all, they are free to publish their books. They can call up the policemen and spies they criticize and get interviews. The Freedom of Information Act gives them an awkward and timeconsuming but nonetheless genuine tool of discovery. No one steals their files, their Informants do not disappear, they do not get beaten up in alleyways at night. There are plenty of genuine police states in the world, places where people are secretly arrested, tortured, executed in prison basements with a small caliber bullet In the back of the head. The Bill of Rights may have taken a beating in 200 years but the United States is hardly a police state of that sort. How could it be, when even the most determined critics not only feel free to speak their minds, but can even make a profession of it?

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The emphasis on numismatics at the Treasury Department reached an alltime high last year with the Mint's many offerings a official Bicentennial coin and medal sets. The emphasis, admittedly, did pour millions of dollars into the Treasury's coffers, but the Department is evidently aware ofand appreciative ofthe collector as a numismatist, as well as a potential customer. Last month the. Department reported on the opening of the extensively renovated museum in the Old Mint in San Francisco; now it is reporting on an effort at its headquarters in Washington, D.C., which should prove of equally great interest to collectors in the eastern part of the country.

title: ART
description: AN EXHIBITION at the Monmouth Museum is a reassuring guarantee that watercolors are still one of America's favorite artistic media, That 112 artists contributed to the show would in itself suffice to prove the point, but the mind boggles to think that that number of entries was selected by a jury from a massive field of 309 artists who had submitted their works for consideration.

title: Foreman Feels Pact Is Not Super
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8About 80 players will participate in the Super Bowl game tomorrow and most of them will have a low visibility. One with high visibility, No. 44 in a purple jersey, will be Charles (Chuck) Foreman, a 26yearold bachelor who is discontented.

description: It's going to be the year of the consumer with 80 million American shoppers throwing off their inflationsensitive inhibitions.

title: Spring Nuptials For Jane Hadley, Paul W. Preziose
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gordon Hankey of McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hankey's daughter, Jane Houghton Hadley of Burlington, Mass., to Paul Warren Preziose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Jacques Preziose of Springfield, Va. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Mixed notices for the intelligence community
description: If you can get past the gate of the United States Central Intelligence Agency headquarters you might be able to pick up a copy of the C.I.A.'s contribution to the Bicentennial, a slick redwhiteandblue booklet about 200 years of American intelligence. A spokesman claims it was put together under pressure from the White House. Nevertheless, there it is, with your favorite alltime American spies, Washington, Jefferson, Hamilton and the Adams boys, and their political action groups, covert operations, and counterintelligence. The American Revolution as an exercise in espionage.

title: Christine Jepson Sets Wedding to a Banker
description: Christine B. Jepson, a model in Paris, and Pierre Rostand, general representative in Zurich for the French bank, Credit Lyonnais, will be married next May.

title: Imports Trigger Protection Demands
description: WASHINGTONOne day it is Amer ican turkey exporters complaining about unjust import barriers in the European Common Market. The next day may bring shoe or television makers petitioning for relief from import competition.

title: Woman Hired to Sharpen Skating Skills of Islanders
description: Barbara Williams was appointed skating coach of the New York Islanders yesterday, marking the first time that a woman has been hired in coaching capacity in the National Hockey League. Miss Williams is an instructor of power skating, Women in Sports a technique designed to yield the greatest efficiency from each effort in skating. She has taught at the Racquet and Rink Skating School in Farmingdale, Li., and is currently director of the Superior Ice Rink Skating School in Commack, L.I. She is also head powerskating instructor for the Suffolk County, South Shore and Beaver Dam youth hockey associations.

title: Barbara Maltby Achieves Squash Racquet Semifinal
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jam 8Barbara Maltby of Philadelphia, the topseeded defending champion, advanced to the semifinals of the New Jersey State women's open squash recquets championship at Jadwin Gymnasium today, defeating Joyce Davenport of Philadelphia, 159, 153, 155.

title: Capital Shortage? Not Today, Maybe Tomorrow
description: If there was a capital shortage last year, the banks and insurance companiestwo major sources of expansion moneydidn't feel it, nor did big business generally. But there is no consensus on whether a shortage is looming.

title: DR. HARRY W. MILLER, CHINA DOCTOR, DIES
description: Dr, Harry Willis Miller, a thyroid surgeon who began practicing medicine in China more than 70 years ago as a medical missionary for the Seventhday Adventist Church, died of a heart attack Jan. 1 in Riverside, Calif. He was 97 years old.

title: New Director Named By School Aide Unit
description: The appointment of Mildred E. Jones as director of the New York City School Volunteer Program effective Feb, 1 was announced yesterday by the program's trustees and the Board of Education's Division of Educational Planning and Support.

title: DINING OUT
description: THIS is a restaurant I would have loved to love. My informants had nothing but praise for the charming surroundings and food they described as imaginative and prepared with fresh ingredients.

title: REGENTS APPOINTS PANEL TO HELP FILL TOP POST
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8(UPI)  The State Board of Regents has appointed an advisory committee to aid it in selecting a successor to the Education Commissioner. Ewald B. Nyqaist.

description: Those two American standbys, denim and corduroy, are giving argument to the fashion experts who insist that the elegant look is back.

title: Birth Rate in New York City Is the Lowest Since 1936
description: The birth rate in New York City last year reached its lowest level since 1936. the Department of Health reported last week.

title: Nets Bow to Pacers, 8073; Victors Are Led by Knight
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 8 (AP)Billy Knight scored 14 of his 26 points in the fourth quarter tonight as the streaking Indiana Pacers defeated the New York Nets, 8073, in a National Basketball Association game at the Market Square Arena.

title: Philip Berrigan Taken Into Custody With 6 Others Near Carter's Home
description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 8 (AP)Philip Berrigan and six associates were taken into custody today within sight of Presidentelect Carter's home. They were protesting the nuclear arms policies of the United States.

title: Not Everyone Has Settled Into Mrs. Gandhi's Continuing Temporary State of Emergency
description: NEW DELHIEighteen months after Prime Minister Indira Gandhi changed the country's course with what she promised would be a temporary state of emergency, how much democracy is left in India? The answer depends upon who is asked. Even Mrs. Gandhi and her supporters concede that India has turned away from what they like to call a Westminsterstyle decocracy, an alien form of government grafted into India by the British. But they say that it has been replaced by a more disciplined form of government more appropriate to a huge, impoverished land in which twothirds of the people cannot read.

title: North. Wins Senior Bowl
description: MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 8 (AP)Steve Pisarkiewicz, the quarterback who helped engineer Missouri's season of upset triumphs and surprising losses, rallied theNorth for two fourthquarter scores today and a 2724 victory over the South in the Senior Bowl football game.

title: Rutgers Tops Connecticut In 3 Overtimes 84 to 77
description: HARIFORD, Jan. 8 (AP)Rooney Duncan, a freshman guard, sank eight free throws and a jump shot for 10 Points in the third overtime period today as Rutgers scored an 8477 victory over Connecticut at the Civic Center. Duncan finished with only those 10 oints. The game was decided at the four

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)President Ford underwent his last physical examination as President today and said afterward, I think I'm in better health now than when I came in.

title: Where the Money Tree Grows
description: Of necessity, a major doubt Is hidden in every governmental budget: The unpredictability of general economic conditions. If they are worse than anticipated, the government's expenses (for welfare and unemployment benefits, for example) will be higher than budgeted. If conditions are better than anticipated, those expenses will go down and revenue (from sales taxes and personal income taxes, for example) will be higher than budgeted.

title: Women Work and Men Change
description: Robert D., who is in his late 50's, is now engaged primarily in writing a cookbook for businessmen. A few years ago when he lost his executive job in a publishing house, he decided to stay at home and write. He was able to do this, rather than face the frequent humiliatiOns of jobhunting in late middle age, because his wife holds a wellpaying job in one of the city's top law firms.

title: With knife and compassion
description: The great questions are the nature of life and death, and because they are no easier to answer by shooting expeditions off to Mars than by a painstaking attentiveness at home, we can all have at least a sense of participating in the attempt. Lately the common bias has leaned toward an agnostic view that death and life are enemiesmortal enemies, no less. It's a mistake to hobble such a crucial quest with biases, however, and to forget that from another, older perspective there may be a dear kinship between the two, the sort of friendship that exists, for example, as we hear clearly, between trumpets and trom

title: Carter, Congress and the Ford Budget
description: WASHINGTON  Both the politics and the arithmetic of this year's battles over the national budget are beginning to become clear. The battles appear likely to be many, and lengthy. In fact. the whole budget issue appears likely to provide one of the first and most significant tests of Presidentelect Carter's ability to deal with Congress.

title: Mary Ellen Branca Becomes the Bride Of Robert Valentine
description: Mary Ellen Branca, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph T. Branca of White Plains, was married yesterday to Robert John Valentine, an infielder with the San Diego Padres.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Presumably, it was Michel Fokine who started it all. Before Fokine no one really cared about original choreography. But, nowadays, if you look at Les Syiphides, say, or even Petrushka, across the world, you will probably be surprised at how comparatively similar they all are. And this, in spite of the fact that Fokine himself made many slightly differing versions of his own ballets. With choreographers after Fokine the product is even more carefully controlled.

title: Yugoslays Report That Tito Rebuffed Brezhnev on Air and Naval Rights and a Role in the Warsaw Pact
description: Yugoslav diplomats have disclosed to United States officials in Washington and abroad that President Tito flatly rejected three requests from Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, for closer military cooperation between the two countries.

title: Article 6  No Title
The Tourist Boom
description: Neither crime, nor porn, nor dirty streets, nor gloom of fiscal crisis shall keep the tourists from New Yorkand if you don't believe it, the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau has the facts and figures. Last year was one: of the best ever for the tourist business in New York with hotel occupancy up to 73 percent from 66 percent the year before, surpassing a record set in 1969. There were more conventions and convention delegates than in any year except the World's Fair peaks of 196465. Which makes us wonder, what would it be like if New York had a convention center to match the modern facilities that other cities seem to pull out of their municipal hats with the greatest of ease?

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Insurance Department granted a rate increase averaging 14.8 percent to Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York. The increase affects 6.8 million subscribers, most of them in individual or smallgroup plans. The insurer had applied for a 23.5 percent increase last October.

title: MONDALE TO EXPLAIN CARTER AIMS ON VISIT TO EUROPE AND JAPAN

Mondale would visit West European and Japanese leaders to outline the new administration's foreignpolicy intentions. The Vice President will also discuss arrangements for a spring economic summit meeting to be attended by Mr. Carter.

The Rev. Richard S. Bauder performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Rockaway Hunting Club in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Cancer: Some Possible Causes
description: THE recent publication of Atlas of Cancer Mortality for United States Counties: 19501969 produced spasms in a variety pi New Jersey's state agencies, right up to the Governor's office. Suspicion also exists that this Atlas may have been the basis for Presidentelect Jimmy Carter's erroneous statement during the last of his three debates with President Ford that the United States has the highest rates of cancer in the world. How could it? Luxembourg holds that dubious distinction. The United States runs a not too close 19th. This is one list we have no interesi in heading.

title: The Banks Climb
description: The American banking industry has jumped out of the frying pan, but the next stop is in doubt.

title: Bureaucrat's Perspective
description: Mark D. Coler is a bureaucrat, a GS17, near the top of a system that runs from GS1 at $5,810 a year to GB18 at $39,600. He is part of tribe of 2.9 million Federal employees (there are an additional 10 million in state and local governments) that citizens curse, politicians run against and presidents constantly reform. Yet the bureaucracy survives and prospers and has made Washington, D.C., the only recessionproof city in America.

title: O'Neill Undergoes Treatment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)  House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill was under treatment and observation at Bethesda Naval Hospital today for a prostate inflammation but was expecting to preside over the House on Monday, his administrative assistant, Gary Hymel, said.

title: The Top 10 Percent May Not Be Rich
description: You might not guess it, but Ray and Patricia Dalke are part of the economic uppercrust.

title: Mrs. Grasso's Upbeat Greeting
description: With two years of austerity, political jousting and policy disagreements behind them, Democratic Governor Ella T. Grasso and the Democraticcontrolled Connecticut legislature met in relatively Rood spirits last week.

title: TV VIEW
description: On the morning of Jan. 14, 1952, a new network program offered the following assortment features: the front page of the San Francisco Chronicle, received by wirephoto two hours before the paper would reach West Coast newsstands; live earlymorning scenes of people going to work in Chicago, Washington and New York; two soldiers oncamera in Korea speaking with their families, who were brought to the TV studio for the occasion; an interview with Fleur Cowles, whose new book, The Bloody Precedent, was published that morning; weather reports telephoned in from the U.S. Weather Bureau, and, as a publicity release put it, the ten latest song records were played during the twohour period, giving it pace and varietyone number, Domino, was cued in from London.

title: A Black Middle Class in Dixie
description: MOBILE, Ala.A generation ago in Mobile, Bob Brazier might have worked as a deliveryman, as his father did. He would have lived in a plain frame house in a racially delineated neighborhood, sent his children to segregated schools and, for a night on the town, belonged to an allblack social club.

title: Answers/Questions
description: We are growing several Won cross begonias under fluorescent light. The plants are not overwatered and are permitted to grow somewhat dry. The edges of the leaves turn brown and brittle. What is wrong? S.L.R., Manhattan

title: Murdoch Names New Top Editors At Post and New York Magazine
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, named new top editors at The New York Post and New York magazine yesterday in moves to consolidate control over the group of publications he has acquired in the last 10 days.

title: Trying to Unban Books on L.I.
description: The banning of books from schools has been attempted periodically in the metropolitan region, but with infrequent success. Last spring, however. a Long Island school district did manage to remove nine books, on the ground that they contained material which is offensive to Christians, Jews, blacks and Americans in general. The ban now will be contested in court.

title: Cutting Out the Middle Man
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.What are Midwestern farmers doing drilling in the Amazon Basin or the Gulf of Mexico? Looking for oil to run their farm vehicles and huge fertilizer plants, as they have since 1940.

title: Carey Gives the Good News First
description: New Yorkers and their Governor Hugh Carey, would probably both be happier if his state of the state message last week represented the last word on where things stand as the new year begins. His televised address was filled with good news, including qualified proposal for a tax cut.

title: Nina Pomerantz Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Pomerantz of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nina Eve Pomerantz, to Jerry Lance Rosenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Rosenberg of Fairfield, Conn. A spring wedding is planned. Miss Pomerantz expects to graduate in May from Southern Connecticut State College. Her fianc has a degree in business administration from Boston University.

title: CAREY APPOINTS PANEL ON ABORTION CONSENT
description: NEW YORK, Jan. 7 (UPI)Governor Carey moved today to seek a constitutionally acceptable way to give parents a say in whether their underage daughters may have an abortion.

title: N.A.S.L. College Draft Set Wednesday
description: To comply with recent legal rulings, the North American Soccer League, will conduct its sixth annual college draft in three stages this year. The first stage will be held on Wednesday at the league office here. The St. Louis Stars

title: Judge Scores Placement of 2 Inmates in OneMan Cells of U.S. Jail
description: A Federal cour judge has ruled that new Federal prison that was hailed as model of its kind when it opened here 17 months ago may not confine two inmates in oneman cells.

title: New Yorkers Who Match From Head to Toe
description: People talk about double trouble, and sure, there are women who will walk out of a room if they see another woman wearing the same outfit. But some people think that dressing up like twins, or even triplets, is fun. Since New York is a city with an abundance of everything, why shouldn't it abound with people whose tastes coincide from head to toe? Who knows, maybe the people pictured here are harbingers of the lookalike look, or coucou couture.

title: Mr. Murdoch Keeps Right On Going
description: Rupert Murdoch, a wealthy Australian newspaper owner who recently bought one of the city's three remaining general circulation daily newspapers, has substantially enhanced his influence in New York's publishing world.

title: Princeton Trounces Dartmouth
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 8 The Princeton University basketball team romped over Dartmouth, 63.32, at Jadwin Gym tonight to notch their 24th straight Ivy League victory.

title: POLITICS
description: WHEN the Legislature opened in Albany last Wednesday, one of the freshmen in the rear row on the Demcratic side was Mary Rose McGee, the only woman in the 21member Nassau and Suffolk delegation in the Assembly.

description: As the year plunges on into heaven knows what, there is one thing I devoutly wish for each and every playwright: that he will be able to finish his Grinling Gibbons room.

ClarionLedger, and David Hardenbergh Crary, a reporter for The Associated Press in Jackson, son of the Rev, and Mrs. Stephen Trowbridge Crary of Lyme, N. H., were married yesterday afternoon in the Marquand Chapel of the Yale Divinity School in New Haven.

title: Must efforts to reduce unemployment add to inflation and vice versa?
description: MR. FORD: No. Both inflation and unemployment can be reduced by structural policiesprimarily business deregulation and tax reformthat would increase output or reduce costs or both. There is a tradeoff between unemployment and inflation only when the Government tries to reduce one or the other by stimulating or restraining overall demand through fiscal and monetary policies.

title: Farm Profits Depend on Where the Crop Goes
description: VAN METER, IowaThe trouble on the farm is that a good year for growing can be a poor year for selling. But a bad year for selling can be saved if the crop can be used as feed.

title: Suburbs Forcing Poor Back to Cities
description: HOUSING for lowincome and moderateincome families is an issue that is dividing suburban and rural communities in the state, and some communities in Southern New Jersey have been forcing poorer families into housing projects in the overcrowded cities and doing it with state funds.

title: Raiders Carry LeftSide Attack to the Vikings Today
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 8In tomorrow's Super Bowl game, to be played here on the soggy turf of the Rose Bowl, the Oakland Raiders are favored to defeat the Minnesota Vikings by 5 or 6 points, depending on which authority one asks.

title: CHESS
description: I think that, in defending against the classical Maroczy bind, it is especially important to decide early whether to look for simplifying exchanges and aim for a draw or to maintain complexity and seek out winning chances.

description: PARIS, Jan. 8 (AP)  Tomorrow's Argentine Grand Prix at Buenos Aires opens the 17race 1977 World Drivers Championship with James Hunt of Britain facing a struggle to defend his new world crown.

title: Most Analysts Set Profits Rising
description: Despite uncertainties, the odds favor higher corporate profits this year. The gains projected by economists vary from up just a shade all the way to as 18 percent increase. But the 1977 gain won't match the 27 to 30 percent jump to $83 billion in estimated net income in 1576, the recession recovery, froth 1975.

title: Court Proceedings Focus Attention on Howard Hughes's Lost Will of 1938
Tenants of the Manor
description: FOR centuries the North Shore of the Island has been one of the beauty spots of the world, a most desirable place to live. Stretching eastward from Great Neck along Long Island Sound, it is hilly by Long Island standards, wooded, green and open. Its glory time began toward the end of the 19th century, when scores of new millionaires chose it as a place to live and play.

title: RICHARD N. LARKIN
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 8 (UPI)Richard N. Larkin, director of communications for the National Steel Corporation, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in suburban Mount Lebanon. He was 61 years old.

title: Proposing One Energy Agency Will Trigger a Power Struggle
description: WASHINGTON  The Landsat II satellite circles 500 miles above the earth, sending back pictures that may yield clues to the sites of oil and mineral deposits.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT PAY TRIPPED CARTER AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Greg Schneiders, a campaign aide to Presidentelect Carter, was removed from consideration as White House appointments secretary because he became the subject of a Federal prosecutor's investigation, his attorney said today.

title: Puerto Ricans Disagree Sharply Over the Advantages of Statehood
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 6Puerto Rico's political status was once described by Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo as the single most passionately discussed topic of conversation among the island's three million American citizens.

title: A.H.S.A. Meeting Will Discuss Rule Changes
description: The 60th annual convention of the American Horse Shows Association will be held in Houston Thursday through Saturday, and it is expected to proceed in a peaceful, if not orderly, manner.

title: New Games for Speculators
description: The little speculatorsthose investors who are looking for a quick profit or even trying to protect their money against inflationare no longer tied to the stock market.

title: CENSUS SHOWS MAJORITY LIVE IN SOUTH AND WEST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)America's Bicentennial year marked the first time that the majority of the country's population lived in the South and West, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Marjory Oppenheimer Fiancee of John Judson
description: Elinor H. Oppenheimer of New York and Glion, Switzerland, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Marjory Ella Oppenheimer, to John Winthrop Judson of New York and Greenwich, Conn., scn of Mrs. H. Donald Harvey, also of Greenwich, and the late Winthrop Comey Judson. A wedding in the summer is planned.

title: Super Bowl Spectacle Today To Rivet Interest of Millions
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8For about three hours tomorrow afternoon, millions of Americans will join in the annual electronic communion called the Super Bowl, which after 10 years has been established as a national social spectacle as well as a major sporting event.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ONE of the most frustrating experiences any home handyman can encounter is trying to undo a threaded pipe fitting or other threaded connection on metal pipe, and finding that because of corrosion the fitting just will not unscrew. Using a wrench with a longer handle and more leverage is, of course, the first thing to try, but many home handymen do not have, the big wrenches that a professional has. One trick that pros often use to loosen threaded bolts, pipe fittings and similar joints that just won't budge is to heat the joint with a propane torch. Apply the heat to the bulkiest or heaviest part of the joint, twisting with the wrench simultaneous ly at intervals.

title: Paula Grossman Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred D. Grossman of East Brunswick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paula Toby Grossman, to Howard H. Joffe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Joffe of Union, N.J. The future bride is a senior at the University of Maryland. Her father is the editor of The Daily Racing Form. Mr. Joffe, an alumnus of Rutgers University; attends the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: AFEDERAL takeover of welfare; a big tax cut to help middle income families; a masstransit trust fund and a 10 percent rise in the Federalfunding share of masstransit projects to 90 percent; a much bigger publicworks program and jobs bill to aid the Northeast; a new national code on criminal justice; a national healthinsurance program.

title: Richard Pryor, King of the SceneStealers
description: Richard Pryor didn't want his picture taken in his shirt sleeves. Not that there was any danger of his looking less than elegant with his jacket off. The shirt, for starters, was perfectly starched and creaseless, and the cuffs were french. The cuff links had a certain gold air about them, the hands looked manicured, and what they held was a glass of Courvoisier. Nonetheless, when he was asked to take his suit jacket off, Richard Pryor said, almost testily, that he'd prefer to leave it on, and one had to admit, it was a beautiful jacket.

title: In Memoriam
description: ADMANLeah and Harry. Loving parents, always remembered.

title: Murdoch Names 2 Editors
description: Rupert Murdoch appointed Edwin Bolwell editor of The New York Post and James Brady editor of New York magazine, in moves to consolidate control over the publications. Page 37.

title: U.S. Agencies Accused of Resisting On Disclosure of Stock Ownership
description: Almost all the main Federal regulatory agencies have refused to take actions to let stockholders find out who are the real major owners of businesses in the United States, according to the chief aide of a United States Senate watchdog group.

title: Lipstick and Liberation
description: CONTEMPORARY women are a puzzle. Educated, we let others do our thinking. Liberated, we are slaves to the whims of experts and pressure groups. Given a crossroad, we take the path to selfdestruction.

title: Eliminating Banging and Squealing Noises in Home Plumbing Systems
description: Although water pipes that make banging, hammering or squealing sounds are often just a nuisance to occupants of the house, they can also be a sign which indicates that excessive vibration is being set up in the system. If ignored long enough this can sometimes result in leaks developing due to loosened or ruptured joints, or it can cause the mountings which support the pipes to work loose.

title: Pirates Plying Nigerian Seas
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 8The Bights of Benin and Biafra, the treacherous waters off the Nigerian coast that were prowled and plundered for three centuries by slave traders, seadogs and buccaneers, have fallen prey to pirates once again.

title: The Boardwalk
description: Most novelists begin with autobiography and, if they are blessed with the right kind of ambition, tenacity, and adventurous talent and intelligence, in time extend their wings beyond their own experience toward a larger and less private way of knowing. Robert Kotlowitz has reversed the customary sequence. His first novel, Somewhere Else, published four years ago, depicted with exceptional power and authority the life of East European Jews during the early decades of the century.

title: Niederhoffer Is Upset By Goldstein in Semifinal
description: Victor Niederhoffer, top seeded, was upset in the semifinals of the $1,500 Metropolitan open squash racquets tournament yesterday at the Manhattan Squash Club. Neiderhoffer, former fivetime national amateur champion, once national open champion and the current secondranked pro behind Sharif Khan, was defeated by Stuart Goldstein of New York, seeded fourth, 154, 1215, 1511, 1814, in a match marked by three wall nicks (killers) and long rallies.

title: Federal Election Agency Head Under Inquiry for Campaign Violation
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 8  Vernon W. Thomson, chairman of the Federal Election Commission, finds himself in the embarrassing if not disabling position of being investigated by the Department of Justice for a violation of the campaign law he is charged with enforcing.

title: Nassau's Ages of Architecture
description: BETWEEN the austere, saltbox huts that Dutch farmers built 300 years ago and the splitlevel development homes being erected today, a wealth of architectural styles flourished in Nassau County.

title: Blair Lee Martin Affianced To Preston Mackey Williams
description: Mrs. Smith Martin of Lexington, Va., has announced the engagement of her daughter. Blair Lee Martin, to Preston Mackey Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Twyman Williams 3d, also of Lexington. Miss Martin also is a daughter of Frank F Martin cf New York.

title: Revelations for Sale at East Side Psychic Fair
description: Surrounded by plants and paintings, several hundred guests milled about a remodeled East Side brownstone yesterday during what looked like a combined icecream social and large, noisy cocktail party.

title: Jewelry Worth $500,000 Stolen From the Vault of Chicago Store
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (UPI)Burglars used an electronic device to bypass an alarm system, opened two vault doors with blow torch and walked out of a Michigan Avenue jewelry store early today with three suitcases of jewels worth $500,000, the police said.

title: Songwriters Hall of Fame Opens Jan. 18 at 1 Times Square
description: The Songwriters Hall of Fame, devoted to the great musical tradition of andthenIwrote, will open its doors next week eight floors above Times Square, where so many of its heroes wrote their way into the hearts of their countrymen.

title: 2 Rescued From Raft in Atlantic
description: MIAMI, Jan. 9 (UPI)A Navy helicopter picked up today a young Chicago couple who had drifted on a life raft about 30 miles off Nassau in the Bahamas for nearly two days after their rented plane made an emergency landing in the ocean. The two, who appeared to be in good condition, were identified as Paul Bastion, 28 years old, the pilot, and Pamela Witz, 30. Both were taken to a hospital in Nassau.

title: Condition of Anthony Eden, Ill With Liver Failure, Is Said to Deteriorate
description: LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP)Anthony Eden. Prime Minister of Britain during the 1956 Suez crisis and Foreign Secretary in World War II, lay seriously ill in his Wiltshire home today after being stricken in Florida and flown to England by Royal Air Force jet.

title: Spanish Official Visiting Tunis
description: MADRID, Jan. 9 (UPI)Foreign Minister Marcelino Oreja flew to Tunis today on what he called the first step of a Spanish diplomatic offensive toward the Arab countries. Mr. Oreja said that his twoday official visit to Tunis would be followed soon by trips by King Juan Carlos and Premier Adolfo Surez to other Arab countries.

title: AXELSON IS EXPECTED TO GET NO. 2 POSITION IN TREASURY DEPT.
description: Kenneth S. Axelson, the J. C. Penney executive who was brought in by Mayor Beame to serve a oneyear term as Deputy Mayor for Finance, is expected to be appointed Deputy Secretary of the Treasury in the Administration of Presidentelect Carter.

title: Big Game Provides Slice of Americana, A Spectacle for Millions on Television
description: Super Bowl Sunday again taxed the limits of hyperbole yesterday.

title: A LowKey Weiss Is Set To Don Mrs. Abzug's Hat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9It didn't take any supersleuthing for Ted Weiss, a Democrat and Manhattan's only freshman Congressman, to sniff out something rotten during his first few days in the nation's capital. The bespectacled West Side Representative discovered a dead mouse and a colony of roaches under the rug in his suitetwo rooms and an oversized closetin the Longworth House Office Building.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A subcommittee of city and Patrolmen's Benevolent Association negotiators will meet in the next few days in an effort to iron out differences in a proposed contract agreement. Although top negotiators for both sides made progress in their bargaining Saturday, First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti said problems on work charts and wages still had to be resolved. The subcommittee is scheduled to report back to leaders of both sides at a meeting next Sunday at 10 A.M. in the George Washington Hotel.

title: Carter's Agenda: Africa II
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9  By the latest count, 499 South Africans were killed in the racial trouble last year. Most of them were black school children, and many died of police bullets in the hack: In terms of comparative population, it is as if several thousand American children had been shot.

title: ROBERT COYNE, EXAGENT IN TREASURY DEPARTMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI)Robert W. Coyne, an agent of the Treasury Department at the time of Prohibition who went on to head World War II Treasury bond drives and motion picture and liquor trade organizations, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Bail Denied Russian In Espionage Case
description: NEWARK, Jan. 9 (UPI)  A Federal magistrate has denied bail to a 34yearold Russian charged with conspiring to pass United States spacesecrets to a Soviet official.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an obituary in The Times on Saturday it was incorrectly stated that Oded Remba, professor of economics at the College of Staten island, died at the age of 64, He was 46 years old.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 10, 1977

title: The Raiders Organization Man
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 9Scrawled on a blackboard in the Oakland Raiders locker room today was, An Organization Never Deserved It More. Not far away, the creator of the organization, Al Davis, was talking about his reaction to the 3214 Super Bowl triumph over the Minnesota Vikings. Super, he said. They were magnificent. They tt really were super, magnificent. From an organization standpoint.

title: Books of The Times
description: We can now be certain of at least one respect in which the rich are different from you and me. When you and turn dotty, they take our toys away from us and ship us off to a safe place. But if you are richor as rich as the late Howard Hughes wasyou not only get to keep your toys, you also can turn the whole world into your safe place. This, at least, is the major item of news imparted by James Phelan's enterprising work of reportage, Howard Hughes: The Hidden Years.

title: 6 Are Reported Killed in Clashes At Pakistani PreElection Rallies
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 9 (UPI)Rival political groups clashed today at rallies in Pakistan's Northwest Frontier Province for the March general elections and at least six persons were reported killed.

title: Super Bowl XI Scoring

Going out Guide
description: MUNCH & WATCH The new lunchtime production at the midtown Quaigh Theater, a popular diversion where patrons can relax with their lunches, is a pair of oneact offerings by Hiram Taylor, scheduled for 12:15 P.M. today through Friday and repeating next week. The showcase is.on the mezzanine of the Diplomat Hotel, 108 West 43d Street, opposite Town Hall.

title: U.N. Parley Will Work on a Treaty To Assure Right of Political Asylum
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 9Six years ago a Soviet seaman who was Lithuanian tried to defect to the United States by jumping ship, but he was returned by the United States Coast Guard over his protests.

title: Madden Says His Team Played Tougher Games
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 9 (UPI)Coach John Madden of the Oakland Raiders said after his team's Super Bowl victory today that it had had tougher games during the regular season.

title: Tanner Wins Aussie Final From Vilas
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 9 (AP) Roscoe Tanner used a booming serve and powerful placements today that forced Guillermo Vilas into a tentative, defensive style and beat the Argentine lefthander in three quick sets for the Australian open tennis championship.

title: KEY MARKET REPORTS ON CENTRAL SYSTEM ARE DUE NEXT WEEK
description: The National Market Advisory Board is expected to issue two reports next week that will have a major effect on the future development of a national market system for trading securities.

title: STUDENTS BURN U.S. FLAG  IN CANAL ZONE PROTEST
description: PANAMA, Jan 9 (Reuters)Panamanian students today burned a United States flag in the Panama Canal Zone to mark the 13th anniversary of bloody clashes over American control of the waterway.

title: Article 5  No Title
Aqueduct Jockeys
Black Man Is Denied Membership in Plains Church By Unanimous Vote of Congregation, Carter Included
description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 9I think you ought to take down the sign that says you are God's Church and admit you're just a social club, said the bearded black man with rather wild prophet's eyes standing on the steps of the Plains Baptist Church as the congregation left the building today.

title: The Tip and Bobby Show
description: WASHINGTONThe two new stars of CongressHouse Speaker Tip O'Neill and Senate Majority Leader Bobby Byrdhave opened their show with couple of triedandtrue numbers: limiting debate and extending secrecy.

title: Women, Minorities Raised Proportion Of TV Jobs by 1%
description: The United Church of Christ, in its annual survey of televisionstation employment, reported that the proportion of minority and women workers increased last year by 1 percent for each group.

title: A Poison in Pesticides Is Found To Last in Earth and Aquatic Life
description: A toxic chemical compound used in pesticide products has been found to persist intact for long periods in the earth and to accumulate in unusually large quantities in plants, fish, shell fish and mollusks that come in contact with it in streams and ponds.

title: Fuel Squeeze Is Tightening In America's Northern Tier
description: ST. PAULFrom the control room at the Ashland Oil refinery glimpses of the Mississippi River, nearfrozen and steaming in the belowzero cold, poke through the trees. Nothing moves on the river during these frigid Minnesota days. But increasingly, in warmer weather, barges laden with crude oil from as far as Saudi Arabia travel north to unload at refineries along the river's banks. Fuel supplies from the south are becoming increasingly important.

title: City Hall Finally Getting a Lift
description: New York City Council members may be adding years to their lives, but they insist they are only trying to help the handicapped.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Motorist Is Made the Whipping Boy for Lagos's Tangled Traffic
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 9For more than a year the military Government has been embroiled in a war against the Lagos traffic jam, often said to he the worst in the;world. Recently it has seemed more likea war against the motorists.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: New Ballet by Peter Martins Among 9 Given in Flatbush
description: The odd, overly long but original program that Peter Martins of the New York City Ballet put together in Flatbush on Saturday night was as filling as a ninecourse meal.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESS IS URGED IN MATERIALS STUDY TO PUSH RECYCLING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The National Commission on Supplies and Shortages has ended a twoyear study with a recommendation to Congress to repeal the percentage depletion tax break for minerals producers and to take other actions to encourage recycling and conserve natural resources.

title: Article 4  No Title
ELDERLY FOUND PAYING ILLEGAL RISES IN RENT
description: Many elderly persons who live on rixea subsistence  level incomes are being forced to pay rent increases that they legally are exempt from because of long New York City delays in processing their exemption claims, the Legal Aid Society, charged yesterday.

title: Muzorewa Group Angered
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 9  A spokesman for Bishop Abel Muzorewa reacted angrily tonight to the decision of the frontline presidents to back the Patriotic Front, the Bishop's main opponent in the struggle among the black nationalist groups seeking power in Rhodesia.

title: Graphologists Have Carter Well In Hand
