description: CALDWELL, Jan. 9Presidentelect Carter was  psychoanalyzed over the weekend. So were President Ford and Governor Byrne. The analyses were done in a room with halfdrawn shades in a building hidden by trees on the quiet, rolling campus of Caldwell College here.

title: Squires Wins 10Mile Race
description: Peter Squires of the New York Athletic Club won a 10mile race sponsored by the Road Runners Club of New York yesterday In Central Park. Squires, 26 years old. covered the course in 50 minutes 42.4 seconds, finishing a minute ahead of Kevin McCrery of the N.Y.A.C.. who was second in the field of 337 starters.

title: A LowKey Weiss Is Set To Don Mrs. Abzug's Hat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9It didn't take any supersleuthing for Ted Weiss, a Democrat and Manhattan's only freshman Congressman, to sniff out something rotten during his first few days in the nation's capital. The bespectacled West Side Representative discovered a dead mouse and a colony of roaches under the rug in his suitetwo rooms and an oversized closetin the Longworth House Office Building.

title: Around the Nation
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 9 (AP)About 600 employees of General Dynamics Electric Boat division plants have been found to have potentially serious lung diseases directly relating to their work with asbestos, The Providence Journal reported today.

title: NEW EDITOR OF POST PLANS SOME CHANGES
description: Edwin Bolwell, the newly designated editor of The New York Post, said yesterday that he intended to introduce some changes and stir things up a little at the country's oldest continuously, published daily newspaper.

title: TANKER LOSSES SET RECORD IN '76 PERIOD
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9Records for oil tanker losses and the amount of oil spilled into the ocean were set in the first nine months of last yearwell before the wreck of the Argo Merchant and the current rash of tanker mishapsaccording to industry figures.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Raiders Crush Vikings in Super Bowl
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 9The Minnesota Vikings make a career of failure in the Super Bowl and have enjoyed howling success at it. Today they outdid themselves in full view of the biggest crowd that ever attended one of these postseason extravaganzas. Playing dead for the Oakland Raiders in Super Bowl XI, they failed again, 3214. It was the fourthtime they had played for the championship of professional football and missed. No other team on earth can make the same boast. Although the margin on the scoreboard was not the widest of the 11yearold series, this was the sorriest mismatch. The Raiders gained more ground than any previous winner, and the Vikings offered less resistance than any earlier loser.

title: Aussie Wins at Merion
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan. 9Geoffrey Hunt, the 29yearold Australian pro, won the 36th annual William White Memorial Cup open squash racquets tournament today at the Merton Cricket Club. He defeated Michael Desaulniers, a Harvard freshman, 1512, 1015, 154, 1511.

title: Baby Pilot Whale Dies
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP)  A baby pilot whale that washed ashore on New Hampshire's coast during the weekend snowstorm died at the New England Aquarium last night. The 10foot, 1,000pound whale had been rescued at Rye through the efforts of three divers, local residents and a group from the aquarium.

title: Banks Offer Hope on Borrowing, Two Key New York Aides Assert
description: Two key New York City officialsBudget Director Donald D. Kummerfeld, representing Mayor Beame, and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldinsaid yesterday that the major banks were holding out hope that the city could borrow on its own as early as this summer. The hope was based on the city's making constructive efforts to clean up its fiscal house.

title: Case of Man Who Stole for F.B.I. Is Closed but the Questions Linger
description: DENVER. Jan. 9Sometime in the summer of 1973. Timothy J. Redfearn save an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation a sheaf of documents that he said he had stolen from an office of the Socialist Workers Party here.

title: French Defense Chief in Cairo, Promises Technical Help in Starting Arab Arms Industry
description: CAIRO, Jan. 9The French Defense Minister, Yvon Bourges, winding up fiveday visit to Egypt, today promised French technical assistance in setting up an Arab arms industry.

title: Controversial Grand Jury Report Severely Strains Relations Between Two Miami Papers
description: MIAMI, Jan. 9Relations between this city's two daily papers, the morning Herald and the afternoon News, have been severely strained in recent days by series of developments that have raised major questions about press freedom and responsibility.

title: Body of Sinatra's Mother Found at Crash Site
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan 9 (AP)A crumpled fuselage and the bodies of singer Frank Sinatra's 82yearold mother and three other persons were found today on Mount San Gorgonio.

title: Hike! and Sled Dogs Race Over Frozen Hills of Upstate New York
Front Page 2  No Title
Topics
description: A dispatch in this newspaper the other day reported that refugees continue to flee by arduous passage from Communistcontrolled Indochina to Thailand. Culturally and politically, the Thais are uncomfortable with them, especially the 3,000 Vietnamese and 10,000 Cambodians. They might absorb many of the 63,000 Laotians if given some financial help.

title: Hubert Laws, Jazz Flutist, With a Combo
description: The routine ruts into which contemporary studio recordings fall have rarely been pointed up as clearly as they were in the Hubert Laws performance Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: Boaz Shattan Jr. Weds Jane  Neimark
description: Eugenie Beth Neimark, a senior at Vassar College, and Boaz Merritt Shattan Jr., a lawyer with Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, were married yesterday afternoon in Harrison, N. Y., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ira Neimark. Mr. Neimark is president of Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Teachers' Fund, Students Give To the Neediest
description: High school students in Connecticut and a teachers' insurance and retirement fund yesterday joined the list of supporters of the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: MISSION TO RHODESIA URGED IN U.S. STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9A Senate staff study recommends that the United States lift its diplomatic boycott of whitegoverned Rhodesia by sending an official mission to Salisbury, the capital, if the Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith accepts pending proposals to end racial discrimination in that country.

title: Richard Posen, Lawyer, Weds Sharri Silberglait
description: Sharri Silberglait, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Silberglait of Kings Point, L. I., was married yesterday evening to Richard L. Posen, a lawyer with Willkie, Farr & Gallagher, New York law firm. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman performed the ceremony in Temple Israel of Great Neck, L. I. Cantor Benjamin Siegel assisted.

title: THEODORE J. KLEMENS SR.
description: Theodore J. Klemens Sr., the head of an accounting firm bearing his name in Nutley, N.J., for more than 30 years, died Saturday of an apparent heart attack at his home in Lakehurst, N.J. He was 75 years old. Mr. Klemens leaves his wife, the former Dorothy Reckenbiel, and son, Theodore J. Jr.

title: Mae Carden, Creator of System For Teaching Reading, Dies at 82
description: Mae Carden, originator and developer of the Carden method of reading instruction, died Friday at Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N. J., after a short illness. She was 82 years old and had lived in Glen Rock, N. J., since 1949.

title: Zinck Takes Tokle Jump at Bear Mountain
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 9They were flying here before Lindbergh flew to Europe in 1927, said John Reid with a grin today. But only by a few months.

title: Lakers Late Surge Tops Pistons, 124118
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP)Cazzie Russell and Kareem AbdulJabbar combined to score 63 points today and Los Angeles overcame a 12point; fourthquarter deficit as the Lakers posted a 124118 National Basketball Association victory over the Detroit Pistons.

title: THE ECONOMICS OF STARVATIONI
description: We now have the rest of history in which to find out what happened in the NixonFord years. But there are some stories that need to be told at once. One is the story of what happened to United States food policy, and what the consequences were for poor and dying people around the world.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9A regiment of the Arab League's peacekeeping force took up positions today in mountainous areas some 20 miles south of here.

title: Savard's 3 Goals Spark Sabres to a 74 Triumph
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 9 (AP)  Andre Savard produced three goals in the first period to start the Buffalo Sabres on their way to a 74 National Hockey League victory over the Cleveland Barons tonight.

title: State Medicaid Recipients Getting 50% as Much Aid as New Yorkers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9New York State Medicaid recipients get nearly twice as those in New Jersey and nearly half as those in New Jersey and nearly half again as much as those in Connecticut.

title: Harry Wheatcroft, a Developer Of Roses, Dies in England at 78
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, Jan. 9 (AP)Harry Wheatcroft, whose muttonchop sideburns and colorful suits were almost as famous as the roses he developed, has died from a heart attack at the age of 78.

title: Dance:
description: Marion Rice, a Denishawn dancer for over 40 years, took an uncommonly long time to make a New York, debut with her company. Her moment, however, could not have been better chosen, because it came in the midst of what is being hailed as the Denishawn boom. Her company, based in Fitchburg, Mass., presented a program of dances choreographed by Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn that have been in the company repertory continuously at a benefit performance for Dance Perspectives Foundation in the Marymount Manhattan Theater on Saturday.

title: News Summary
description: A Palestinian nationalist suspected of having planned the attack on Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich was arrested in Paris by French intelligence agents. He is known as Abu Daoud, a member of the Revolutionary Council of Al Fatah, the strongest group in the Palestine Liberation Organization. The arrest was made after France received an international arrest order from Interpol, the international police agency, made at the request of the West German Government. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Sports Today
description: HOCKEY

title: Art Is a Cabaret at Top of the Gate In Fine, Unique Nightclub Cantata
description: The sound of people, and the sound of their love of life, suffuses the Top of the Gate on Bleecker Street. The music and the people come from Nightclub Cantata, revue by Elizabeth Swados that is the most original and perhaps the most pleasurable form of nightclub entertainment I have ever encountered. It opened last night, and the situation is not a usual nightclub. It is more in the pattern of the Jacques Brel show, but its accent, its manner and its atmosphere are quite different.

title: To Fashion a Blanket of Pardon
description: Jimmy Carter chose an American Legion audience last summer to promise that one of his first acts as President would be the granting of a blanket pardon to Vietnam War evaders. He took a risk on this still provocative issue and tried to minimize it by drawing a distinction between amnesty and pardon. Amnesty, he argued, would mean erasing or denying guilt; pardon, he held, was official forgiveness regardless of guilt or innocence. Throughout the campaign, however, Mr. Carter refused to remove the uncertainty about who might be finally covered by his blanket.

title: Yonkers
Market Place
description: The shares of Harman International Industries have soared since the announcement that Presidentelect Carter had nominated that highfidelity equipment maker's president, Dr. Sidney Harman, to be Under Secretary of Commerce.

title: Junior Leaguers Link Their Aims To Urban League
description: For the Urban League of Greater New York and the New York Junior League, 1977 is a time of new directions. And since the two organizations are, in some instances, going in the same direction, it seemed only natural for them to get together for a joint New Year's party.

title: The Fight to Shatter Realty Management's Male Mystique
description: Barbara Tillman, who heads the renting staff at a large New York City apartment development, tells of the ridicule that she and other real estate women have encountered from maintenence men when seeking to learn the workings of airconditioning or other complex building systems.

title: Brazilian Military Is Relaxing Curbs But Keeping Grip
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 7As the rightwing military regime in Brazil enters its 13th year in power, its supporters and opponents are intensely debating how far political liberalization here will go, how solid its foundations are, and how much political repression continues to exist this largest Latin American country.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Six Howell Township schools, which have been closed for a week because of fears of asbestos poisoning, will reopen this week. The schools were closed because a 13yearold student became sick, apparently after breathing airborne asbestos particles, which are believed to cause cancer. Workmen were ripping off asbestoscoated ceilings at the six schools, which were to reopen on Wednesday. Two other schools, which do not use asbestos ceilings, reopened last Thursday after a threeday recess.

title: EXMISSISSIPPI AIDE GUILTY IN EMBEZZLING
description: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 9E. L. Boteler Jr., former state highway director, was convicted in state court here last night of embezzling $100,000 in state highway funds that he asserted had been used in a clandestine plan to buy influence in Washington.

title: Miss Sterkel Sets Swim Marks
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (AP)  Jill Sterkel, a 15yearold Olympic goldmedal winner, set two American swimming records last night in an Amateur Athletic Union twoday qualifying meet. Miss Sterkel was timed in 1 minute 47.63 seconds in the 200yard freestyle and 23.10 seconds in the 50yard freestyle, bettering her previous marks of 1:48.29 and 23.70 respectively.

title: DAVID PARSONS, 67, DIES; PAN AM AIRWAYS OFFICER
description: David Taylor Parsons, a public relations officer for Pan American World Airways for 22 years and an avid yachtsman, died yesterday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I., after a lengthy illness. He was 67 years old.

title: MISSION TO RHODESIA URGED IN U.S. STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9A Senate staff study recommends that the United States lift its diplomatic boycott of whitegoverned Rhodesia by sending an official mission to Salisbury, the capital, if the Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith accepts pending proposals to end racial discrimination in that country.

title: Pate Captures Phoenix Golf, Beating Stockton in Playoff
description: PHOENIX, Jan. 9Jerry Pate and Dave Stockton played the AlphonseGaston act all day today, giving each other the Phoenix open, but when it came to a showdown Stockton gave it away for keeps by taking three putts and a bogey on the first hole of a suddendeath playoff.

title: SecondPlace Finisher Becomes Vermont Lieutenant Governor
description: MONTPELIER. Vt., Jan. 9The Vermont General Assembly has cast aside the slim popular vote victory given former State Senator John T. Alden, a Democrat, in the Lieutenant Governor's race last November and in a secret ballot elected the man who finished second, former State Senator T. Garry Buckley, Republican.

title: TANKER LOSSES SET RECORD IN '76 PERIOD
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9Records for oil tanker losses and the amount of oil spilled into the ocean were set in the first nine months of last yearwell before the wreck of the Argo Merchant and the current rash of tanker mishapsaccording to industry figures.

title: N.C.A.A. Announces Battle Plan Against Gambling
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 9The National Collegiate Athletic Association plans to monitor proposed gambling legislation in each of the 50 states as part of the association's drive to prevent legalized betting on amateur athletics.

title: North Shore Acres
description: GLEN HEAD, L.I.Bebe Redmond trying to scrape up some runnin'away money. She has big plans to disappear from North Shore Acres next February for a week in the sun with a guidance counselor named Frank, her husband of long standing.

title: ELINOR D. INGERSOLL, 68; SOUP COMPANY DIRECTOR
description: Elinor Dorrance Ingersoll, a director of the Campbell Soup Company and president of the Preservation Society of Newport County, R.I. died yesterday in New York Hospital, where she had been governor of the Society of the New York Hospital for 25 years. The wife of a retired vice admiral, Stuart H. Ingersoll, she was 68 years old and lived at 740 Park Avenue and in Newport.

title: Senate Reorganization Hindered By Power Struggle Over Turf
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9With their fiefdoms in jeopardy, a parade of Senate chairmen have sought to sidetrack plans to streamline the Senate by reducing the number of committees from 31 to 15, thus casting doubt on the outcome of the Senate's first major reorganization proposal in 30 years.

title: Viking Veterans Disappointed Under a Stoic Facade
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 9Jeff Siemon, the Minnesota Viking linebacker who made 15 tackles in his team's fourth straight Super Bowl loss, uttered the thought that others kept unspoken:

title: New York City Hall Getting a Lift at Last
description: After 165 years, New York's City Hall is going to get an elevator. It will cost $210,000 and carry up to a dozen passengers between the basement and second floor, where the City Council, the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate meet in ornate rooms.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
New York Medicaid Recipients Get Twice as Much Aid as Jerseyans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9New York State Medicaid recipients get nearly twice as much financial help on the average as those in New Jersey and nearly half again as much as those in Connecticut.

title: Nima Y. Farmanfarmaian Wed to Christopher Isham
description: Nima Yektai Farmanfarmaian, daughter of Mrs. Abolbashar Farmanfarmaian of Teheran, Iran, and Manouche Yektai of Bridgehampton, L.I., and New York, was married in PortauPrince, Haiti, Saturday to Christopher Eaton Isham, son of Heyward Isham, United States Ambassador to Haiti, and Mrs. Isham. Episcopal Bishop Luc A. Garnier of Haiti performed the ceremony in Holy Trinity Church.

title: Maryland Five Triumphs, 8780, Over N.C. State
description: COLLEGE PARK. Md., Jan. 9 (AP) Brad Davis, the Maryland guard, performed as expected today and scored a careerhigh 26 points as the Terns beat North Carolina State, 8780, in college basketball.

title: FINANCIER, NEW JOURNAL, SEES AN INCOMES POLICY
description: The incorporation of elements of an incomes policy that bears upon wages and prices appears to be a likely move by the incoming Carter administration, according to Financier, a new monthly journal of financial affairs.

title: Article 3  No Title
Music: Harps
description: Aristid von Wurtzler and his New York Harp Ensemble proved at least one thing at their concert Saturday night in Alice Tully Hall. That was that the harp itself, singly or in consort, is capable of a wonderful range of sounds that far transcend the watery glissandos one expects to hear from the instrument.

title: Shopping Spree in London Gives the Lie to Hard Times
description: LONDON, Jan. 9For 45 years, except during World War II, William Murphy has occupied the corner of Oxford and Portman Streets here, selling flowers. He deals mostly in roses, cellophanewrapped bunches of 10 that he displays in a nook against the wall of the Littlewoods store.

title: Bridge:
description: The final playoff match in the International team trials in Houston, designed to pick the 1977 American World championship squad, was aborted unexpectedly yesterday afternoon with 32 deals remaining to be played. After a day of rumor, bewilderment and protracted committee meetings, play was first disbanded and eventually terminated altogether.

title: Migration of Mayas In A.D. 250 Traced To Volcanic Blast
description: Anthropologists digging in early Maya sites in the highlands of El Salvador have found what may have set off the sudden and previously unexplained rise of classic Maya civilization in the lowlands of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula around A.D. 250.

title: Raiders Played a Game Within a Game in Huddle
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 9 (UPI)The Oakland Raiders played a game within a game among themselves today. As early as the third quarter of their 3214 victory over the Minnesota Vikings, they began amusing themselves in the huddle by trying to figure out who would win the mostvaluableplayer award and the automobile that traditionally goes with it.

title: A Salute to Originator of E.R.A. in 1923
description: Alice Paul, who has spent almost her entire life working for two Constitutional amendments, will celebrate her 92d birthday tomorrow, an occasion feminists are saluting and using as rallying point for ratification of the proposed equal rights amendment that Miss Paul drafted more than 50 years ago.

title: Aye, Again, for Court Reform, Please
description: Bit by bit, Governor Carey is hacking away at the political encrustments on the state judiciary. His first bill before the new Legislature was the proposal to amend the State Constitution, primarily to change the way we select judges of the Court of Appeals. The measure passed for the first time at the ragged end of last year's session. It must carry again and be approved by the electorate before it can take effect.

title: Opera: Smetana's Dalibor
description: Operas by Bedrich SmetanaThe Bartered Bride always exceptedare not exactly wellknown commodities on the American musical exchange. Thus a large audience availed itself of the opportunity, last night in Carnegie Hall, to sample Dalibor, a nationalistic opera highly regarded in the composer's homelandand also, as of last year, in London, where Dalibor was staged by the English National Opera and created something of furor.

title: British Airways Will Resume Its Flights From London Today
description: LONDON, Jan. 9 (Reuters)British Airways today promised full resumption tomorrow of its flights from London's Heathrow Airport after a threeday strike by baggage loaders that affected some 5,000 passengers.

title: Mrs. Carter Honored By Her Bible Class
description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 9 (UPI)Rosalynn Carter got a farewell gift today from her Plains Baptist Church Bible classand so did her blushing Secret Service agent.

title: Carter's Fiscal Strategy: Is It Confusing or Flexible?
description: The analytical mills will be running overtime this week on Wall Street, in Washington and all over the world, pouring out assessments of Presidentelect Carter's new fiscal plan. The plan is either complicated and confusing or diverse and flexible, depending on the critics points of view. Some see it as an effort by Mr. Carter to please everyone who is expecting some kind of benefit from the new administration. An earlier version of such criticism goes: Once upon a time there lived in the little village of Schlumpberg the good Burgomaster von Pleesemall. He was in truth the very model of an agreeable man. That is, he loved to have round him only men who agreed with him, while he, on his part, set an excellent example of this virtue by agreeing with all who came to him with advice.

title: Advertising
description: The other day at Leber Katz Partners, which has one of the most expensively and tastefully decorated offices in the agency world, the cofounder and president was talking about agency growth and its attendant problems,

title: More Coast Quakes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (UPI)For the second day a series of tiny earthquakes were recorded today in the San Francisco Bay area. University of California seismologists expect aftershocks for several days. The quakes began Friday night. The largest occurred at 1:38 A.M. yesterday, rattling dishes and awakening hundreds of thousands of people. It measured 4.6 on the Richter scale.

title: Oakland Runs to Left Side,. Gains Total of 429 Yards
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 9The shows at the Super Bowl today were better than the game. With shows? Pregame, halftime and postgame. These shows were unpredictable, spontaneous and efficient with the audience of 100,421, plus a resonant band from the Los Angeles United School District, serving as the actors in the Rose Bowl.

title: Sirius Trixon and the Motor City Bad Boys
description: Punk rock, the kind inspired by the Velvet Underground and Iggy and the Stooges, is hardly limited to New York, London and Los Angeles. This past Friday and Saturday, two bands from Detroit and Cleveland played in a double bill at Max's Kansas City.

title: 4 TeenAgers Die in Auto Accident
description: DUNLAP, Iowa, Jan. 9 (UPI)A car carrying seven teenagers left a county road near this western Iowa town last night, crashed through a fence and hit two trees, killing four of the occupants, the authorities said today. Two boys and two girls were killed The other three persons in the car, two boys and a girl, were taken to a hospital with injuries.

title: Week After Suicide, Israel Halts Inquiry
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 9 (UPI)Government legal experts decided today to stop the police investigation into charges that led to the suicide last week of Housing Minister Avraham Ofer.

title: Extension of Sewage Aid Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, said today that he would ask Congresss to extend Federal aid for sewage treatment plants, saying that 11 states would otherwise run out of money for such projects this year. He identified the states as Maine, New Jersey, Virginia, Hawaii, Alabama, Illinois, Texas, Missouri, Nebraska, Wyoming and Nevada.

title: Brazil Rejects a Price Freeze On Coffee Colombia Suggests
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 9 (Reuters)Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, has rejected a proposal by Colombia, the second largest, to freeze coffee prices at their present levels or at any other level considered adequate.

title: $40 Million Welfare Saving Cited
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt said lyesterday that more than $40 million had been saved in the last 18 months by the office of Welfare Inspector General Richand V. Horan, now part of his department.

title: Ugli, Rata, Rambutan, Itzama and Other Rare Fruits
description: We were absolutely enchanted to receive recently a copy of a newsletter whose existence we had previously not been aware of. It is published by the Rare Fruit Council International, and while we have no passionate interest in rare fruits, we became totally absorbed in a page labeled BuySellTrade.

title: TV: Tom Wolfe's Los Angeles Is on Public Stations Tonight
description: In the 1960's, Tom Wolfe MauMaued himself into journalistic prominence with a keen nose for telltale status smudges and an arsenal of exploding punctuation points. Look, ma, Mr. Wolfe is elipsing again! In the 70's, the writer in the creamcolored suit shifted from compiling catalogues of brandname absurdities to ridiculing certain impeccably smart targets: The New Yorker magazine, dumb liberals and clever `blacks locked in a waltz entitled Radical Chic, and the entire scheming world of modern art, its practitioners and its arbiters.

title: HAIG SAYS SOVIET BUILDUP IMPERILS WEST'S SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)The Soviet Union is building up its military strength and threatens the security of the Western nations, according to Gen. Alexander M. Haig, commander of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces.

title: Jody Scheckter Triumphs In Argentine Grand Prix
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 9 (AP) Jody Scheckter of South Africa, driving a WolfFord, sped to victory today in the Argentine Grand Prix, the first Formula One race of the year.

title: $311 Million Israel Bonds Sold
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)A total of $311.1 million was produced by the Israel Bond Organization in 1976 to help finance Israel's economic development, Sam Rothberg, general chairman, reported today at the organization's 1977 National Inaugural Conference.

title: 10 Firemen and Policemen in State Will Be Given Awards for Valor
description: NEWARK, Jan. 9Ten New Jersey policemen and firemen will be honored for valor tomorrow night at the Robert Treat Hotel here at the annual dinner sponsored by the 200 Club of Essex County.

title: Israelis Confer on Extradition
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 9 (Reuters)Israeli Justice Ministry officials conferred here today on the possibility of applying to France for the extradition of the Palestinian guerrilla leader Abu Daoud, who is being held by the French police.

title: Exotic Plants Thrive on Newark Campus
description: NEWARK, Jan. 9Pineapples, bananas, orchids, cotton and tobacco are growing in the heart of this city. There are also more than 300 varieties of cacti and other plant species filling a greenhouse on the campus of Rutgers University.

title: Article 6  No Title
STRIPMINE CONTROLS EXPECTED THIS YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Congressmen who for five years have strongly supported Federal controls on the strip mining of coallegislation that was twice vetoed by President Fordare bringing the idea back to life on Capitol Hill with the near certainty that Presidentelect Carter will sign such legislation this year.

title: Car Imports Have Leveled Off, Detroit Finds
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9It has taken almost 20 years, but American automobile manufacturers believe they finally have car imports under control. Independent auto analysts and the importers generally agree with Detroit executives that sales of foreign cars in this country have reached a plateau.

title: Raiders Crush Vikings in Super Bowl
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 9 The Minnesota Vikings make a career of failure in the Super Bowl and have enjoyed howling success at it. Today they outdid themselves in full view of the biggest crowd that ever attended one of these postseason extravaganzas. Playing dead for the Oakland Raiders in Super Bowl XI, they failed again, 3214. It was the fourth time they had played for the championship Sports of professional football and missed. No of other team on earth can make the same boast. Although the margin on the score board was not the widest of the 11yearold series, this was the sorriest mismatch. The Raiders gained more ground than any previous winner, and the Vikings offered less resistance than any earlier loser.

title: Groomers in Vans Go to the Dogs
description: LOS ANGELES. Jan. 9Honeyhun perched seductively, on the edge of a bathtub at the end of a custommade van. Her long red hair fell gracefully over shoulders that were being slowly massaged by strong hands. Mantovani music and cologne filled the air. Overcome with excitement, Honeybun barked.

title: ARMS SHIFT CALLED WAY TO CUT BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Congressional Budget Office suggested today that more than SI billion could be saved in the defense budget over the next five years if naval air power was committed to help fight a land war in Europe.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Haynes Sets Record With Leap of 26 Feet
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 9Tommy Haynes. fifth in the triple jump at the Montreal Olympics, set a West Point Field House record today when he leaped 26 feet and won the long jump at the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior field championships.

title: Marcia Reese Wed To Robert B. Hemley
description: Marcia Weiss Reese and Robert Benjamin Hemley were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club by Rabbi Joseph Weiss of Belle Harbor, Queens, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Consumer Confidence Rose In December After Declines
description: Consumer confidence, which has been depressed throughout most of 1976, advanced strongly in December, according to the Conference Board. The resurgence in confidence was reflected in the strong retail figures last month as reported by leading chain stores.

title: BusinessPolitical Scandals Are Disillusioning French
description: PARIS, Jan. 8A series of scandals involving prominent politicians and businessmen and millions of dollars in suspected international flimflams has erupted in France, and an apparent desire by the Government to minimize their importance has created a deepened atmosphere of skepticism and distaste for public affairs among the public.

title: $500,000 and Almost Year Later, Fugitive Writes of How It's Been
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9A former Brink's armoredcar guard who walked decided after more than 10 months of squandering it on women, race horses and cars that living the life of a nearly broke hippie is now the best way to live.

title: Brazilian Military Is Relaxing Curbs But Keeping Grip
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 7As the rightwing military regime in Brazil enters its 13th year in power, its supporters and opponents are intensely debating how far political liberalization here will go, how solid its foundations are, and how much political repression continues to exist in this largest Latin American country.

title: ROCKEFELLER TO RETURN TO ENTERPRISE SYSTEM
description: Vice President Rockefeller says, I am now, with the greatest possible enthusiasm, going back to the American enterprise system.

title: Tennessee's Show Goes On With King, Grunfeld as Stars
description: And now for the latest episode in the Bernie and Ernie Show.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of post positions

title: Five Black African Countries Back Patriotic Front in Rhodesia Dispute
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 9 (Reuters)Black Africa's frontline states today unveiled a new strategy toward Rhodesia's black nationalists, and gave an enigmatic response to British efforts to bring peace to the territory.

title: TurkishSoviet Detente
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union was supposed to visit Turkey in midNovember. Then the trip was put off to the end of November, and then to midDecember. Now it has been postponed until spring, and this indecision illustrates Turkey's cautious and ambivalent attitude toward its huge northern neighbor. Ankara is eager for economic support from Moscow and recently announced a deal that would provide $1.2 billion in Russian investment here over 10 years. In the past Turkey has lagged behind other Western countries in strengthening its political ties with Russia, but it wishes to improve these ties to show its allies that it cannot be taken for granted.

title: Bowl Game Delays NBC Film
description: A laterunning Super Bowl game delayed scheduling on the NBCTV network by 25 minutes last night, causing Channel 4's switchboard to light up when its television movie Raid on Entebbe, failed to come on as scheduled at 8 P.M. Although the delay had been announced for the preceding World of Disney show, the failure to alert viewers who tuned in for the movie at 8 o'clock caused 500 to 600 people to call the station, a spokesman reported last night.

title: Stephanie Gunther Bride Of Abram Shnay, Builder
description: Stephanie Gunther, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Paul Gunther of Convent Station, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Abram Shnay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Shnay of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Z. David Levy performed the ceremony at the Gunther home.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Ascob Cocker Spaniel Club's Best in Show
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 9Ch. Kaplar's Royal Kavalier, a 2yearold black and tan ascob cocker spaniel, owned by Almah De Bere of Cedarville, N.J., won the American Spaniel Club's 60th specialty tonight at the Holiday Inn jetport. A total of 765 dogs competed for the top award.

title: Garden State Farmers Turn to Midwestern Grains
description: VINELAND, Jan. 9New Jersey's farm belt: is turning away from fruits and vegetables to wheat, corn and soybeans because of shifting world demand and quicker financial returns, according to major producers in this part of the state.

title: Commodities
description: The current furor over soaring coffee prices brings to mind the outrage over the record prices of sugar just two years ago. At that time threats of boycotts, Congressional investigations and charges of manipulations of the market were hurled at the sugar trade.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an obituary in The Times on Saturday it was incorrectly stated that Oded Remba, professor of economics at the College of Staten Island, died at the age of 64. He was 46 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: PHILIP S. LASDON
description: Philip S. Lasdon, former president of the Reduction and Refining Corporation of Kenilworth, N.J., a producer of tungsten and molybdenum, died Saturday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: French Arrest Palestinian Aide Linked to 1972 Attack at Olympics
description: PARIS, Jan. 9French intelligence authorities disclosed today that they had arrested a Palestinian official widely suspected of having planned the attack on Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich in which 17 persons were killed.

title: Bond Prices Drop and Rates Rise; $2.1 Billion in Issues This Week
description: The credit market dropped sharply in price last week and interest rates climbed in the most dramatic setback for fixedincome securities since last May. The retreat, contrasting starkly to the strong advance only one week earlier, put the bond market on untested ground for this week's heavy schedule of $2.1 billion of new corporate and taxexempt securities for sale.

title: Morris Strunsky, 89, an Editor Of Several Major Newspapers
description: Morris Strunsky, who as a young man was city editor of The New York Call and later Tho Philadelphia Times and The Washington Post, died yesterday at his home, 7 Waverly Place. He was 89 years old.

title: In Memoriam
description: BROWNLEEJohn. Always remembered, sadly missed. BETTE and VALERIE.

title: Vikings Were Intimidated By Defense, Says Atkinson
Heidegger Captures Slalom For His First Cup Victory
description: GARMISCHPARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 9 (AP)Klaus Heidegger of Austria upset highlyfavored Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden today and won a giant slalom race for his first World Cup victory. The 19yearold Heidegger edged Heini Hammi of Switzerland by onehundredth of a second, clocking a combined time of 3 minutes 22.29 seconds for two heats.

title: Vandalism Spurs Juvenile Reform In Affluent Town
description: DEERFIELD, Ill., Jan. 9Deerfield is a suburban community of 20,000 where the median annual income is $27,500, where the mean cost of a single family house exceeds $80,000, where a bare 0.03 percent of the residents are at poverty level and unemployment is below 3 percentand where in one year 578 incidents of vandalism by Deerfield youngsters were reported to the police.

title: Sales Total $2,617,600 For Horses at Keeneland
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 10 (AP)A total of 277 horses were sold today for $2,617,600 as a twoday sale opened at Keeneland. Wonderful Gal, a 7yearold mare in foal by Judger, brought the highest price$72,000. The buyer was Seth Hancock of Paris, Ky., acting as agent. Ted Carr of Lexington, also acting as agent, was the seller.

title: About New York
description: Jogging across the slush of Seventh Avenue and clutching a tuna rye, R.B. roll, Grk sal., ban. split and two black no sugar, Wally Ceglarski was philosophic about things, With age, it was only natural that he should lose some of his speed as a griddleman and so have to work all the way on the other side of the counter, delivering lunches on stormy days to deskbound businessmen.

title: Eugene Levin, 47, Dies in Mexico; A Yacht Enthusiast and Importer
description: Eugene S. Levin, one of the founders of the Minuteman Yacht Club of Westport, Conn., and an active member of the boating community, died of a heart attack Saturday while swimming off the coast of Puerta Vallarta, Mexico. He was 47 years old.

title: Freshly Shorn Officers Fight CrewCut Chief's Beard Ban
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 10Beards came off in the Englewood Police Department today, and freshly shorn and shaven officers were bristlingbut only figurativelyabout Chief Jerome Trainor's new ban on beards and his demand for neatly trimmed hair and mustaches.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: As a means for dealing with the impact of inflation on profits, a proposed new method of accounting in Britain, to go into effect in July 1978, would do away with the present use of historical costs for equipment, for example, and substitute a new method using current costs.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Human Rights and the Single Standard
description: We shall soon have an Administration in Washington that is pledged to give human rights a central place in its foreign policy. We welcome that change from recent practice, understanding that it raises some extraordinarily difficult questions.

title: Expos Pick First Today In Winter Baseball Draft
description: The Montreal Expos, the team with the worst record in baseball last season, will lead off today's winter baseball draft. Their pick won't turn the franchise around. He won't even turn heads.

title: Canada Ousts 5 Cubans in Spy Case Reported to Have Rhodesia Links
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 10The Canadian Government has ordered the expulsion of five Cubans, including three members of the Cuban diplomatic and consular staff.

title: G.M. Extends Rebate
description: General Motors extends and broadens its $200rebate program until Feb. 28, Page 55.

title: College Results
50 Youths Backing Up at Spofford
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10About 50 youths most of them convicted of serious crimes, have been backing up for several months at New York City's Spofford Juvenile Center because the State Division for Youth has been unable to find appropriate places for them.

title: Mother Charged With Asphyxiating Daughter During Alleged Exorcism
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Jan. 10A Brooklyn woman shouting Hallelujah! was arraigned today on manslaughter charges after her 21yearold daughter died yesterday of asphyxiation while reportedly being ridden of demons.

title: G.M. EXTENDS REBATE ON SUBCOMPACT LINE
description: DETROIT, Jan. 10The General Motors Corporation announced tonight that it had extended until Feb. 28 its $200 rebate on three of its subcompact car lines and broadened the program to include other slowselling small cars and trucks.

title: Swedish Budget: More for Welfare
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 10 (AP)Sweden's first nonSocialist government in 44 year mixed austerity measures with continued growth of social welfare expenditures in its first budget, presented today in Parliament.

title: PARITY AGREEMENTS BY NEW YORK CITY ARE TERMED ILLEGAL
description: The New York State Public Employment Relations Board ruled illegal yesterday parity agreements by New York City that assured its uniformed workers of relatively equal wage and benefit improvements in their contracts.

title: Stockton, Pfister Victors in Tennis
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 10 (AP) Dick Stockton and Hank Pfister of the United States scored firstround victories today in the $75,000 Adelaide tennis tournament, a Grand Prix event.

title: PocketSized TV Set Is Introduced in Britain
description: LONDON, Jan. 10 (UPI)A British electronics company today introduced what it called the world's first, pocketsized television set and said it would go on sale next month in the United States and Britain.

title: Arrest of Palestinian: A Prize of Close FrenchIsraeli Teamwork
description: PARIS, Jan. 10Careful coordination between France and Israel led to the recent arrest by French counterintelligence agents of a Palestinian leader widely suspected of responsibility for the killing of members of the Israeli team at the 1972 Olympics in Munich, according to diplomatic and intelligence sources here and in London.

title: Mutual Distaste Separating Briton and Top Rhodesians
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 10If the BritishAmerican peace initiative secures a peaceful transition to majority rule in Rhodesia it will come about despite the personality conflicts between several key participants, particularly Ivor Richard of Britain and Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia and his Foreign Minister, Pieter K. van der Byl.

title: Canadiens 4 Stars Sweep N.H.L. Midseason Honors
description: The Montreal Canadiens already have begun to collect bonus money for their scoring and defensive feats this season. The powerful team swept the National Hockey League's halfseason statistical race with Guy Lafleur and Steve Shutt taking the scoring awards and Ken Dryden and Michel (Bunny) Larocque capturing the goaltending honors. Lafleur was the firsthalf scoring leader with 31 goals and 64 points in 40 games, netting him $500 in prize money. Shutt, the leading goal scorer wih 32 at midpoint, received $250 as runnerup to his linemate with 55 points. Marcel Dionne of the Los Angeles Kings also had 55 points but placed behind Shutt because he had fewer goals.

title: Snow, Rain, Thaws And Flooding Beset Much of Northeast
description: Rain early in the day and a 41degree January thaw of the remaining snow turned the New York City area yesterday into a land of slushy lakes dotted with stalled cars, squishyshoed pedestrians and saltypawed does.

title: RHODESIANS SEE A PACT OUTSIDE GENEVA TALKS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 10Officials here said today that they now saw some hope that moderate black nationalists might agree to negotiate a constitutional settlement for Rhodesia outside the Geneva conference.

title: Jockeys Balk at Weather
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP)Racing was canceled today after the third race at Washington Park when the jockeys voted 223 not to ride the remaining six races because of adverse weather conditions, a track spokesman said. The riders complained of the cold o weather, drifting snow on the backstretch and frozen clumps on the track surface.

title: The Super Bowl Needs a New Formula
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10In the hours after the Oakland Raiders and the Minnesota Vikings qualified two weeks ago for Super Bowl XI, Pete Rozelle was chatting with some newsmen about which teams would have created the most alluring story line.

title: MYLES EASON
description: Myles Eason, an actor, died of a heart attack Saturday while vacationing on Grand Cayman Island. He was 61 years old and a resident of Ridgefield. Conn.

title: Paula Lockheart Band Plays With Energetic Enthusiasm
description: On the surface, the Paula Lockheart Band, which plays on Saturday nights at a small bar called the Fugue, First Avenue at 16th Street, might seem to be one more in the growing number of musical echoes of the 1920's and 30's. But although Miss Lockheart's group borrows from sources as varied as Bessie Smith, Johnny Hodges and Brook Benton, it doesn't pretend to be anything but itself.

title: Supreme Court Refuses to Review Judge's Control of Boston School
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The Supreme Court refused today to consider whether Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. of Boston had exceeded his authority when he took over control of racially troubled South Boston High School in an effort to desegregate the school.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Center for Black Culture Is Given New Hope as Federal Aid Nears
description: Shortly after the news that the city would receive a Federal publicworks grant for 51 capital construction projects, Jean Blackwell Hutson pulled down from one of the cluttered shelves in her tiny office a large dusty book of plans.

title: Tanker Splits Off Coast 6 Rescued
description: BOSTON, Jan. 10A small, aging oil tanker split in half in gale force winds this morning in the Atlantic Ocean off Cape Ann, Mass. Six crewmen were rescued, and the Coast Guard was searching for the seventh, who plunged into the ocean as he attempted to jump into the rescue basket lowered by a helicopter.

title: RCA Weighs Closing
description: The RCA Records division of the RCA Corporation said yesterday it was still considering closing its New York recording studios. The division has recently closed similar operations at Nashville and Hollywood. A spokesman pointed out that in recent years, more and more recording artists, independent producers and outside labels have demanded more artistic and technical control over their recording projects. He added that this had required flexibility that made continued use of company studios no longer economically feasible.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK NET SHOWS DECLINE FOR 76
description: The Bank of New York Company, the first major New York City bank to report earnings for the fourth quarter and full year 1976, announced yesterday declines for both periods.

title: Article 4  No Title
Some Chinese Uneasy Over Peking Demonstrations
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 10The continued turnout of large crowds in Peking to honor Chou Enlai two days after the anniversary of his death, and the appearance of fresh wall posters, some attacking senior leaders, have begun to create a sense of uneasiness among some Chinese.

title: SCHULTZE EXPECTING RESULTS BY SUMMER FROM ECONOMIC AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Charles L. Schultze, the chairmandesignate of the Council of Economic Advisers, said today that he expected to be able to see some results from the Carter administration's economic stimulus package by summer, and possibly sooner.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Beatrice Foods Company of Chicago and Harman International Industries of Lake Success, N.Y. said yesterday that they were discussing a possible merger of Harman into Beatrice, but that no terms have been discussed.

title: Political Agitators Shoot 3 in Spain
description: MADRID, Jan. 10Gunmen distributing leaflets calling for a general strike today shot and wounded three guards at an aircraft factory south of Madrid and fled.

title: Vandalism Spurs Juvenile Reform In Affluent Town
description: DEERFIELD, Ill., Jan. 9Deerfield is a suburban community of 20;000 where the median annual income is $27,500, where the mean cost of a single family house exceeds $80,000, where a bare 0.03 percent of the residents are at poverty level and unemployment is below 3 percentand where in one year 578 incidents of vandalism by Deerfield youngsters were reported to the police.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Suspect Held Indigent

title: World News Briefs
At Last, Snow Blankets All Northeast Ski Areas
description: HUNTER, N. Y., Jan. 10For the first time this season, all ski areas in the Northeast are blanketed with sufficient snow covers. There were blizzard conditions today in upper New England and sizable falls in the Poconos of Pennsylvania. The Catskills, Berkshires and Lower Green Mountains had maintenance crews packing the new snow all day with heavy machinery. The storm was a windfall, in particular, for ski centers that had no snowmaking equipment or only minimal gear.

title: Only 6,376 at Aqueduct, But Bettors Average $183
description: More than 40 percent of the horseplayers at Aqueduct yesterday didn't get there in time to bet the daily double, but they made up later in the day for their tardiness. With snow, sleet and slush discouraging all but the diehards, percapita wagering at the Big A climbed to the remarkable level of $183. The crowd of 6,376, one of the smallest in the history of the New York Racing Association, wagered $1,167,060 on the ninerace card.

title: SCHULTZE EXPECTING RESULTS BY SUMMER FROM ECONOMIC AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Charles L. Schultze, the chairmandesignate of the Council of Economic Advisers, said today that he expected to be able to see some results from the Carter administration's economic stimulus package by summer, and possibly sooner.

title: Market Place
description: An analyst who follows the National Semiconductor Corporation has noted that the stock bounded to $55 a share in early 1976 from a low of less than $7 in late 1974.

title: THE ECONOMICS OF STARVATIONII
description: We goofed on Bangladesh, one senior official in the Agriculture Department said, and a lot of people died.

title: A Summary of Various Actions Taken by the U.S. Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: On U.S. Dealings With the Soviet Union
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by the American Committee on U.S.Soviet relations. Among those who signed are John Kenneth Galbraith, the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, Donald M. Kendall, George Kennan, Wassily Leontief, Eugene McCarthy, Edwin O. Reischauer, David Riesman, Robert V. Roosa, Terry Sanford, Thomas Watson Jr., Jerome B. Wiesner and Leonard Woodcock.

title: Berrigan and 6 Others Sentenced For Protest Near Carter's Home
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Jan. 10 (UPI)Philip F. Berrigan, the former Roman Catholic priest, and six other demonstrators were sentenced today to serve 30 days in jail or pay fines of $100 each for creating nuisance within sight of Presidentelect Carter's home.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: PRIVACY OF MAN AND WIFE UPHELD EVEN IN A COURT
description: DENVER, Jan. 10 (UPI)The Colorado Supreme Court ruled today that a man and wife have a right to keep their conversations private, even if their comments are made in a public courtroom.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Article 1  No Title
On Agenda for Carter: International Problems
description: Thomas E. Mullaney

title: New Drug Said to Have Advantages Over Methadone in Helping Addicts
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (Reuters)A medical expert today reported encouraging results in the treatment of heroin addicts with the experimental drug methadyl acetate, considered by some to be better in the treatment of addiction than the widely used methadone hydrochloride.

title: Dual Leadership Setup Is Said to Divert Funds From Programming
description: The annual budgets of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Public Broadcasting Service are cited by many broadcasters as evidence of how the dualleadership structure is causing money to be diverted from the product that appears on the television screen.

title: Badillo, in Shift, Assured of a Seat On the House Banking Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Representative Herman Badillo, Democrat of the Bronx, was assured a position on the important House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee tonight after losing on his first attempt a few days ago.

title: Baseball Executives Back Kuhn's Stand on Pacts
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (UPI)  Three members of major league baseball's executive council testified in United States District Court today that they believed Commissioner Bowie Kuhn has the authority to disappr assignment of player contracts.

title: Austria, France, Netherlands Join InterAmerican Development Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)Austria, France and the Netherlands joined the InterAmerican Development Bank today increasing to 37 countries the bank's membership. Finland and Italy are expected to join soon.

title: Derelict Wins Right to Refuse Leg Amputation
description: Over objections from physicians, a State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that a 58yearold derelict whose gangrenous leg had been scheduled for amputation had the right to refuse the operation.

title: Court Upholds Leary Conviction
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 (UPI)A Federal appeals court today upheld the 1970 conviction of Timothy F. Leary, a former LSD advocate, for attempting to smuggle three marijuana cigarettes into the United States from Mexico in 1965. A threejudge panel in the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit held Mr. Leary had lied to Customs Service agents when he told them he had nothing to declare before entering the country. Mr. Leary contended he would have violated his right to remain silent if he had declared the marijuana.

title: Florida Town Damaged by Winds
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., Jam 10 (UPI)Violent winds caused an estimated $200,000 damage today in this central Florida town, ripping off roofs, uprooting trees and damaging cars. Twenty families were left homeless at an apartment complex when winds of tornado force stripped roofs from three buildings. No injuries were reported. I was so scared I climbed under the mattress, said Chris Haines. I could hear the roof starting to rip and it was over in about a minute.

title: P.B.A. to Fight CrewCut Chief's Ban on Beards
description: ENGLEWOOD, Jan. 10  Beards came off in the Englewood Police Department today, and freshly shorn and shaven officers were bristlingbut only figurativelyabout Chief Jerome Trainor's new ban on beards and his demand for neatly trimmed hair and mustaches.

title: Sutton Names Two TeenAgers To Community Planning Boards
description: At least two community planning boards in Manhattan will have teenaged members this year to represent the youth of the community.

title: British Football
description: By Regulers

title: Tennis
Government Asked To Weigh Stockpile To Avert Shortages
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)The world is not in danger of running out of resources soon, but the Government should consider stockpiling some goods to protect against shortterm shortages, a Government commission reported today.

title: Ski Jump Gets a Lift For Lake Placid Games
description: LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP)Plans to stage the 1980 Olympic Winter Games at Lake Placid cleared a giant hurdle today when the Adirondack Park Agency approved a proposal to build a ski jump.

title: Dollar Up Sharply in Europe
description: LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP)The dollar rose sharply against major European currencies today, reaching its highest level against the West German mark since midDecember.

title: CZECH POLICE HOLD A DISSIDENT WRITER
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 10Pavel Kohout, whose play Poor Murderer closed recently on Broadway, was detained by the Czechoslovak security police today a few hours after his wife had been dragged into a police car outside their home.

title: MOTHER IS CHARGED IN DAUGHTER'S DEATH
PRISONER SAWS WAY OUT OF BERGEN COUNTY JAIL
description: A New Jersey man convicted last month of raping, kidnaping and threatening to kill a 17yearold girl escaped from the Bergen County Jail in Hackensack early yesterday morning by sawing through the bars on his cell window, according to police officials.

title: Article 2  No Title
Charles White, Former Chairman  Of Republic Steel, Dies in Florida
description: Charles M. White, former head of the Republic Steel Corporation and one of the industry's most militant and articulate spokesmen, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 85 years old and had been in failing health for a naumber of years.

title: Donations to the Neediest Top $800,000
description: Donations from 379 persons yesterday to the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund totaled $29,113.03, sending contributions over the $800,000 mark.

title: ROBERT PAUL STRANAHAN
description: WAHINGTON, Jan. 10Robert Paul Stranahan, a retired New Jersey business executive, died Friday of a heart attack in his home in Vienna, Va. He was 82 years old.

title: Colgate Rejects Rutgers On Bid to Alter Schedule
Cold in Midwest and Texas Causes Cutting of Natural Gas to Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)Arctic temperatures across the nation's midsection triggered a series of curtailments of natural gas to industry today, but except in one small Missouri town, it appeared that residential gas furnaces would keen on heating.

title: H.U.D. NOMINEE SAYS SHE IS ONE OF POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  A black woman who began life as the daughter of a dining car waiter spoilt this morning trying to persuade a panel of 11 male United States Senators that she sympathized enough with the poor and downtrodden to be the next Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Norway Seeks Meeting in Geneva To Break a Deadlock on Sea Law
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 10Norway has moved to reopen deadlocked negotiations for a treaty on the law of the sea, summoning a Geneva conference to work on the controversy over deepsea mining.

title: CZECH POLICE HOLD A DISSIDENT WRITER
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 10Pavel Kohout, whose play Poor Murderer closed recently on Broadway, was detained by the Czechoslovak security police today a few hours after his wife had been dragged into a police car outside their home.

title: Economist Foresees 2 Good Years
description: NEWARK, Jan. 10  Albert Sommers, senior vice president and chief economist of the Conference Board, a business research group, had the best kind of news for the business community today.

title: Rosenthal Opposes Naming of Zablocki As Committee Head
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10A contest over the chairmanship of the House International Relations Committee developed today with submission to the House leadership of a denunciatory 44page memo randum concerning the heir apparert, who promptly threatened to bring its, author before the House ethics committee.

title: School Results
Man Held on Drug Charge
description: EDISON, N. J., Jan. 10 (UPI)A Connecticut man was arrested on the New Jersey Turnpike today on charges of transporting $100,000 worth of marijuana. The suspect, William Mazziotti, 43 years old, of West Haven, was held on bail of $10,000 in the Middlesex County Jail. The state police said they had found 200 pounds of marijuana, as well as cocaine and amphetamines in his car, which had been rented in Florida.

title: Australia Establishing Biosphere Reserves to Protect and Facilitate Natural Evolution
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  A new concept of conservation that seeks to facilitate evolution, rather than merely preserve the status quo, is gaining momentum here and elsewhere in the world.

title: People and Business
description: Dent Bids Japanese Ease Quotas To Allow the Import of More Beef

title: High Court Rebuffs Longshoremen On the Right to Reload Containers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)The Supreme Court today let stand orders denying New York longshoremen the right to reload containers prepared elsewhere by cargo consolidators before the containers are placed on ships.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Silver and Gold Futures Drop; Coffee Falls Limit
description: Silver and gold futures fell sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, reflecting traders, reaction to the strong showing of the British pound.

title: Senate Creates Humphrey Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)The Senate honored Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, today by creating a new position for him, Deputy President pro tern of the Senate. The resolution, proposed earlier by Senate Democrats, was passed without objection and with no discussion.

title: Miss Longet Weeps at an Autopsy Report on Sabich
description: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 10Claudine Longet put her head in her hands and wept in court today as the autopsy report on her lover, Vladimir (Spider) Sabich, was read, describing how he died from massive internal bleeding as a result of a gunshot wound.

title: GRAND JURY REPORT ON I.R.S. IS RELEASED
description: MIAMI, Jan. 10A Federal judge released today an expunged version of a grand jury report that The Miami News had sought to suppress because the report was critical of the newspaper's handling of articles about a controversial tax investigation.

title: Corey Court Tennis Victor
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10Russell Corey of New York recovered from 34 in the third set and defeated Bill Vogt Jr. of Philadelphia, 86, 68, 85, in the first round of the United States open court tennis championship today at the Racquet Club. John Ward, an amateur from the Queen's Club in London, eliminated Tom Welsh, a Philadelphia professional, 86, 08, 85.

title: Throwing Money in the Proper Fashion
description: One of the successes of the Nixon Administration was that it gave trying a bad name: that is, it indiscriminately applied the slogan throwing money at problems  to efforts to attack the roots of poverty and urban decay. The slogan became clich, and the clich became shorthand for the dogma that the Great Society had failed entirely. But facts, such as the quiet but considerable accomplishments of the BedfordStuyvesant Restoration Corporation, have a way of intruding even on the most effective slander.

title: Around the Nation
description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 10 (UPI)Rosalynn Cater announced today that she would have a staff of 17 women and one man to handle her activities and that of the Carter family in the White House.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Zern Fans Now Savor Writer in Dual Role
description: The irrepressible Ed Zern, whose often wondrously mad phrases have delighted the readers of his Exit Laughing column in Field and Stream magazine for many years, has been named fishing editor of that publication.

title: Kissinger Says Idea of Supremacy Makes No Sense in a Nuclear Age
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that he was confident that no American president would ever allow the Soviet Union to gain strategic superiority over the United States and that the concept of supremacy made no sense in the nuclear age.

title: Miami Bank Halting BigAccount Interest
description: MIAMI, Jan. 10 (AP)Florida's largest bank said today that after Feb. 1 it will not pay inteerst on savings accounts larger than $150,000.

title: News Summary
description: Security police in Prague arrested Pavel Kohout, the Czechoslovak playwright whose Poor Murderer closed on Broadway last week, several hours after his wife had been dragged into a police car outside his house. These were the latest arrests by police seeking to intimidate signers of a petition for human rights in Czechoslovakia published last week in Western Europe. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Beame and Goldin Agree on a Plan As Prelude to Selling City Bonds
description: Mayor Beame and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin have agreed to a preliminary plan to comply with some of the strict demands laid down by banks for marketing future city bonds, but to resist the banks suggestion for an extension in the life of the State Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: LABOR SCORES CARTER ON ECONOMIC PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) A.F.L.C.I.O. leaders today criticized Presidentelect Carter's twoyear $15billion program for economic stimulus, describing it as a retreat from his campaign promise to cut unemployment.

title: Bishop Moore Ordains a Lesbian As Priest in the Episcopal Church
description: Ellen Marie Barrett, a doctoral student in social ethics and an avowed lesbian, was, ordained as an Episcopal priest last night. The rites were performed by Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York at the Church of the Holy Apostles in Manhattan.

title: OPEC TO LEND $111 MILLION TO 24 DEVELOPING LANDS
description: VIENNA, Jan. 10The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today concluded agreements with 24 developing nations to provide interestfree loans totaling $111 million. The largest amounts were scheduled for India, $21.8 million; Egypt, $14.5 million, and Bangladesh, $14 million. The loans are repayable in 25 years.

title: Stenmark Triumphs In Slalom
description: BERCHTESGADEN, West Germany, Jan. 10 (AP)Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden overtook three Austrians today with the fastest time in the second heat and won a World Cup special slalom. They raced over a treacherous; icy course that eliminated all but 29 of the 83 starters.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Jan. 10Governor Byrne will deliver his State of the State Message tomorrow and is expected to begin his campaign to win public acceptance of the new state income tax and recommend legislation to regulate casino gambling in Atlantic City.

title: The U.N. Today
Two Contemporary Designers for the Modern Generation
description: A fashion groupie who is a devoted follower of Sonia Rykiel and Kenzo was asked whether there was any American designer she admired.

title: HILDEGARDE HOYT SWIFT, CHILDREN'S BOOKS AUTHOR
description: Hildegarde Hoyt Swift, an author of children's books, died yesterday at a Redland, Calif., nursing home where she had been living for several years. She was 87 years old.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Shows $133,834 Surplus For 1976, the First One in a Decade
description: The National Association tor the Advancement of Colored People announced yesterday its first budgetary surplus in a decade in reporting that it ended a troubleplagued 1976 with a balance of $133,834.

title: Soviet Espionage Suspect Is Ruled Eligible for Aid by Public Defender
description: NEWARK. Jan. 10A magistrate ruled today that Ivan M. Rogalsky, charged with conspiring to commit espionage, was indigent and eligible for legal representation by the Federal Public Defender.

title: Cold and Lack of Moisture Seen Reducing Winter Wheat Crop 8%
description: WASHINGTON, JAN. 10 (AP)The winter wheat crop planted last fall was suffering from dry weather and severe cold in parts of the nation's breadbasket as of Jan. 1, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Companies List Sales and Earnings Reports
description: COMPANY REPORTS

title: HOW TO ASSIST THE FUND FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Bearded Argentines Face a Picture Ban
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 10 (UPI)The Argentine military Government has ruled that men cannot wear beards in their identificationcard pictures.

title: The Battle for CUNY's Future
description: For the City University of New York every past blow by the budget ax was a case of doublethetrouble and the pain. Under the old 5050 formula of city and state support, each slash inflicted by City Hall was automatically matched by an equal reduction in Albany's contribution. Although the matching requirement was scrapped last year, the immediate future of CUNY's senior colleges still depends on agreement between Mayor Beame and Governor Carey about their respective contributions to next year's operating budget.

title: PARITY AGREEMENTS BY NEW YORK CITY ARE TERMED ILLEGAL
description: The New York State Public Employment Relations Board ruled illegal yesterday parity agreements by New York City that assured its uniformed workers Of relatively equal wage and benefit improvements in their contracts.

title: ADM. B. HALL HANLON
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 10 (AP)Adm. B. Hail Hanlon, retired, former commander of the Atlantic Fleet Mine Force, died yesterday at a Charleston hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Miss van Hamel Invests Swanilda With Her Flair
description: Over the weekend, the American Ballet Theater continued with its glut of Coppelia performancesclocking in four in two days. It will resume tomorrow with seven performances more to the end of the week, after which the company offers two weeks of walltowall programming of Giselie.

title: H.U.D. NOMINEE SAYS SHE IS ONE OF POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  A black woman who began life as the daughter of a dining car waiter spent this morning trying to persuade a panel of 11 male United States Senators that she sympathized enough with the poor and downtrodden to be the next Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Recital: Ian Shapinsky's Chopin
description: Ian Shapinsky, who played a Chopin recital Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is one of those overreaching pianists who stress speed, big sonorities and momentum above all else. The young American musician's fingers served him well enough to sustain tension and continuity, even though his tendency to bang the keys and his unwillingness to let the music breathe often proved tiresome to this listener.

title: Suns End 5Game Slide On 9392 Defeat of Hawks
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 10 (AP)  Alvan Adams scored with 51 seconds remaining to put the Suns ahead as Phoenix defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 9392, tonight, snapping the Suns fivegame losing string in the National Basketball Association.

title: Retailers Hear '77 Holds Promise Of Good Year but Not a Boom
description: Predictions that 1977 will be a good year but not a boom year were made by principal speakers yesterday at the opening sessions of the annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association.

title: Judge Cuts Sentences of Couple In Housing Fraud of $200 Million
description: A Long Island couple, convicted of having defrauded the Federal Housing Administration of more than $200 million in a mortgage scheme that left thousands of houses boarded up in innercity areas of Brooklyn, had their sentences cut sharply yesterday even before they had been jailed.

title: Skiing
Islanders Defeat Flyers, 83, As Nystrom Scores 3 Goals
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 10They're No. 1, and we wanted to be No. 1.

title: Audit Says Nondrinkerson Trains Subsidize the Highballing Riders
description: Those Scotchescumsoda imbibed by rail commuters on their way home to Connecticut and Westchester have been paid for, in part, by abstinent fellow riders, according to a New York State audit released yesterday. The auditors suggested that food and beverage services on the trains be brought into the black or dropped as an unnecessary extravagance.

title: LILLIAN LUSTIG ROTHENBERG
description: Lillian Lustig Rothenberg, a former member of the executive committee of the Women's City Club in New York City and former community school board chairman for the east midtown area, died Sunday in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 64 years old, the wife of Dr. Robert E. Rothenberg, a physician and author, and lived at 35 Sutton Place.

title: U.S. Ends Its Case As Bechtel Agrees Not to Aid Boycott
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10The United States Justice Department today issued its first guidelines governing participalion by American companies in the Arab boycott with the filing of an agreement between the department and the Bechtel Corporation in a Federal District Court here.

title: Fire Fed by Winds Drives Hundreds From Their Homes
description: A fire fed by chemicals from a rubber plant swept through half of the tiny Columbia County village of Philmont last night, as snow and winds gusting up to 30 miles an hour hampered efforts by firemen to contain the blaze.

title: ARMY IS DISTURBED BY RECRUIT QUALITY
description: The Army is increasingly concerned with the reduced quality of recruits joining the allvolunteer force. The Navy and the Air Force report no such difficulty in this area. In fact, an Air Force spokesman said, we're turning them away.

title: College Basketball
description: WRITERS POLL

title: Ripley Believes He's Set For PoleVault Record
description: Now that he has survived the first test. of the season, getting his fiberglass poles to and from Saskatoon, Dan Ripley will try an endurance double across the United States this weekend that could wear him down before he begins recordhunting in earnest.

title: Retail Sales Rose Strongly in December
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Helped by a strong showing at Christmas, retail sales in December rose by 3.1 percent, the biggest monthly increase in more than four years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Mine Operators Oppose Passage Of StripMine Reclamation Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)  Appalachia coal mine operators today opposed passage of Federal stripmining reclamation laws as the 95th Congress began informal hearings on proposed legislation.

title: Goldin Charges Welsbach With Exorbitant Profits On StreetLight Repairs
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday charged the Wellsbach Electric Corporation with making exorbitant profits on New York City streetlight maintenance contracts.

title: Madden Discloses How Raiders Won
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10Football people like to say there is nothing new in their game, that Bud Wilkinson did this, or that at Oklahoma 25 years ago, that Pop Warner invented the water bucket at Stanford 50 years ago, that Walter Camp taught the Yale players how to tie their shoelaces 100 years ago. The contributions to the game by John Madden, the 40yearold coach whose Oakland Raiders won the Super Bowl yesterday, are new but they concern attitudes, psychological approaches.

title: High Court Voids New York's Ban On Public Works Jobs for Aliens
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 2 today that a New York law that gave citizens a preference over aliens in getting employment in state public works projects violated the Constitution's guarantee of equal protection of the laws. The Court acted without having heard arguments on the matter and without issuing an opinion. Instead, it merely affirmed, without comment, the 2to1 decision by a threejudge Federal Court in Brooklyn last March striking down the law.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES Islanders 8, Philadelphia 3. Washington 2, Detroit 0.

title: Books of The Times
description: Can one publish a heart? Richard Selzer asks in Mortal Lessons. Or a kidney, a liver, a bladder, a belly, a brain, a whole skinful of secrets? He gives it a good try in this diary of a working surgeon. Mr. Selzer has tried before: In 1974, he published a collection of short stories entitled Rituals of Surgery. While it was provocative, the book was not entirely successful, so this time Dr. Selzer has decided to eliminate the fiction, the sublimation, and go, quite literally, to the guts of the matter.

title: Bridge:
description: The mysterious and dramatic termination of the International Team Trials in Houston Sunday and the withdrawal of Dr. Richard Katz and Larry Cohen of Los Angeles left many questions unanswered:

title: Big Increase in U.S. Support Fails To Improve Quality of Public TV
description: Although the Federal Government has substantially increased its support of public television during the 197677 fiscal year, the larger appropriation has not significantly added to the system's ability to produce ambitious national programs of the scope and quality of those imported from the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 10, 1977

title: Beirut Christians Bid Palestinians Remove Arms From Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 10Christian rightists have demanded that heavy weapons in the hands of Palestinian groups be removed from Lebanon altogether.

title: LOREN W. SHORES
