The lives of programs are generally limited, and all things, even all good things, are brought to an end, perhaps, untimely, but eminently sensible. And so, Sunday evening at 9 on public television, we come to the fourth and final season of Upstairs, Downstairs, the series that has won enthusiastic American audiences and a collection of top Emmy awards.

title: Zablocki Is Nominated to Head House Foreign Relations Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13Representative Clement J. Zablocki, a Wisconsin Democrat, was nominated today for the chairmanship of the House International Relations Committee by a 16to8 vote of the steering and policy committee of the Democratic Caucus.

title: Help Sought for Children Used in Pornography
description: The magazines are expensive, but they sell briskly in Times Square pornographic bookstores for $3.50, $5 and $7.50. They have titles like Lollitots, Moppets, Brat and Tots, and children aged 3 to 16 are photographed in various lewd and suggestive poses.

title: National Panel of Doctors Reflects Optimism in New Guidelines for Treatment of High Blood Pressure
description: A new set of guidelines for the treatment of high blood pressure, reflecting optimism about recent advances in drug therapy, has been prepared by a national committee of physicians and published in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Trade Center TV Tower Agreed On
description: Tentative agreement on the placement of a 365foot antenna mast atop the North Tower of the World Trade Center, a move that would significantly improve reception for 20 million television viewers in the metropolitan area, was confirmed yesterday by a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: HOW TO ASSIST THE FUND FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Architect Back At La Mama AnneX
description: With a cast of two actors and one octopus, The Architect and the Emperor of Assyria by Fernando Arrabal will return to the La Mama Theater Annex in Greenwich Village this weekend.

title: CONFLICT IN U.N. ROLE IS DOUBTED BY YOUNG
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13Representative Andrew Young said today that as the first black appointed chief United States representative at the United Nations he wouldn't have any problem about vetoing a resolution to oust the white Government of South Africa from the United Nations.

title: Colored Girls Goes to Rikers Island and Hits Home
description: For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow is Enuf, which began Its journey to Broadway as a reading in a Lower East Side bar, traveled to the Women's House of Detention on Rikers Island yesterday.

title: PANAMANIAN LEADER HOPEFUL ON U.S. PACT
description: RIO HATO, Panama, Jan. 13Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, the Panamanian strongman, reclined in a hammock, his bare feet hanging over either side, and puffed contentedly on a long Havana cigar.

title: North Carolina Rally Overcomes Wake Forest Five, 7775, in A.C.C.
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., Jan. 13 (AP) North Carolina, trailing by 7 points with 16 minutes to play, rallied behind Tommy LaGarde and John Kuester and beat Wake Forest, 7775, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: 375,000 Expected to Visit Boat Show
description: With pennants flying and almost 500 boats on display, the 67th annual National Boat Show opens to the public tomorrow at the Coliseum. Show officials are anticipating a banner nineday run.

title: Signs Growing in China That Teng Has Been Reinstated to State Post
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 13There are growing indications that Teng Hsiaoping, the former Deputy Prime Minister who was ousted last spring, may now be working again in the State Council and that some senior Chinese leaders are mounting a drive to have him named Prime Minister.

title: Dow Gains 7.90 in Market Rebound Led by the EnergyRelated Issues
description: Energyrelated issues soared yesterday as the general stock market staged a brisk rally to produce its best overall performance of 1977.

title: Commodity Price Index Increases 2.9 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 206.1 from 203.2 last week.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Watts Electric is a program that will generate an evening of music, much of it played on an electronic synthesizer, tonight at 8 at the New School's May Theater. These are works by John Watts, head of the New School's Composers Theater Music Program. Mr. Watts will present pieces exploring the synthesizer's possibilities. Most will be accompanied by members of the Composers Festival Orchestra, a 17piece chamber group that includes some New York Philharmonic players. One work is for synthesizer and soprano, and another, a realization of 13thcentury Japanese court music, will be accompanied by a solo dancer. Admission is $4. At 66 Fifth Avenue, near 13th Street.

title: Rangers Scoring
description: Rangers 1 0 A5

title: Dollar Gains Broadly But Trails the Pound; Gold Prices Show Rise
description: LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP)The dollar declined against the British pound today but strengthened slightly against other major European currencies.

title: Kean Opens Drive for Governor; Says He'd Let Income ax Expire
description: LIVINGSTON, Jan. 13Thomas H. Kean, the 41yearold Republican leader Of the State Assembly, announced his candidacy for Governor today and said that, if elected, he would allow the state income tax to expire next year.

title: Suns 131, Pistons 101
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 13 (AP)Paul Westphal had 12 points as Phoenix exploded early in the third quarter and routed the Detroit Pistons, 131101, tonight.

title: Kissinger Protection Likely; Death Plot Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13Key members of the House of Representatives said tonight that Congress was almost certain to approve a White House proposal to give Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger Secret Service protection after he leaves office this month.

title: Easing of Emergency Buying by Pipelines Is Likely Today
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13The Federal Power Commission held an extraordinary allday hearing today on the wcrsening natural gas shortage and indicated that it would take emergency action within 24 hours.

title: From Principle to Principal
description: Borrowing money is never easy, unless you don't need it. New York City needs it to meet the final terms of settlement of the Flushing National Bank's successful challenge to the legislative moratorium on the payment of city notes. About $1 billion of the outstanding $1.8 billion in these notes will be presented for redemption. No redemption plan has yet been proposed by the city and no one knows when the patience of the court will expire. We have perhaps a month.

title: Wheat Reserve Program Is Proposed by Bergland
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13Bob Bergland, the Secretarydesignate of Agriculture, said today he planned to present as, early as March legislation to convert a growing surplus of wheat into a food reserve that would be held on the nation's farms for release only in the event of shortages and sharply rising prices.

title: Letters
description: Science: We Need a Calculus of Ignorance

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: The Marines Need to Be Told
description: Military rules permit members of the armed forces to belong to the Ku Klux Klan or anything else as long as they do not thus violate regulationsand, one would assume, the rights of others. But the information already produced in pretrial hearings in a military court at Camp Pendleton, Cal., suggests that a small and tightly organized group of Klansmen at that Marine base has in fact openly defied the regulations and violated the rights of black servicemen.

title: Daniel's Back in A New Den
description: ONE OF THE FIRST rave reviews of The Play of Daniel may still be seen in a 12thcentury manuscript, the Regularis Concordia of St. Ethelwold, which points to the successful use of the drama as religious instruction designed to fortify the faith of the unlettered, the vulgar and the neophyte. Whether it can still serve that noble purpose is a question best left to lettered theologians. Its modern entertainment value has been proved beyond question.

title: Advertising
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, beset by competitive and governmental pressures, is starting a network TV campaign Monday aimed at convincing consumers that its service is both low in cost and high in efficiency.

title: BRITAIN'S SECURITIES DRAWING INVESTORS
description: LONDON, Jan. 13 (Reuters)Investors are scrambling to buy British Government securities, attracted by high yields and expectations of a strong economic recovery by Britain in the 1980's.

title: PublicTV Partnership Modified
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13Committees of the two bodies that govern public televisionthe Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Public Broadcasting Servicedecided today to modify the partnership agreement that the two organizations drew up in 1973. The move was designed to make it possible for them to work together in the face of their recent bitter diagreements.

title: Music: Levine Conducts
description: Schumann's symphonies pose all sorts of problems. They can sound murky and texturally opaque, but if the instrumentation or the balances are fussed with too much, they lose the composer's characteristic sound. If too much attention is paid to Germanic tradition, the symphonies can sound slack and sentimental, but a toodriving, modern interpretation strips them of their charm and mystery.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Art: An Invitation From Robert Elkon
description: NOT MANY PEOPLE at any one time have genuinely and beyond question an eye for new art. Sometimes it comes early and quite soon goes away again, never to return. Sometimes it comes later and after a long period of thought and care and preparation. Sometimes it never comes at all, no matter how much we hope to have it.

title: CARTER WILL PURSUE EARLY PANAMA PACT AND CYPRUS ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13Jimmy Carter intends in the first weeks of his Presidency to press for a solution of the Cyprus dispute and to speed up negotiations for a new Panama Canal treaty, Congressional sources said today.

title: State and Pennsylvania Vie Over Arsenals
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13  The last salvos are being fired in Congress today and tomorrow in the nearly fouryearold battle of partisans of two venerable arsenalsPicatinny, near Dover, N.J., and Frankford, at Philadelphiawith 1,000 new jobs at stake for the Jersey installation.

title: Sabres Win on Late Goals, 75, After Rangers Erase 52 Deficit
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 13With his long blond hair cascading over his knee pads, Pat Hickey struck a typical Ranger pose of collapsed dejection in the locker room tonight after New York lost a 75 decision to the Buffalo Sabres. When he lifted his head, he said, You sure know Mother Goose isn't the author of our stories so far this year.

title: Tin Price Up $93.50 a Metric Ton  On News of Buffer Stock Depletion
description: LONDON. Jan. 13 (AP)The price of tin for delivery in three months increased $93.50 a metric ton today after the International Tin Council's secretariat announced its buffer stock had been exhausted.

title: Bond Prices Slip After Fed Report Of Big Rises in the Money Supply
description: Bond prices, after registering their only strong advance so far in 1977, early yesterday, were set back late in the afternoon after the Federal Reserve reported substantial increases in the money supply. The net result was a small loss for the day, the eighth this year. In the Goverment securities market, the actively traded 8 percent notes that mature in August 1986 were trading at 105 24/32 at 4 P.M., when the money supply increases were announced. An hour later, they had sunk back to 105 for a net decline of 6/32 from Wednesday's closing level.

title: Wilkinson Gains Semifinals
description: AUKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 13 (AP)Tim Wilkinson moved into the semifinals of an international tennis tournament today with a 61, 67, 63, 64 triumph over Ernie Ewart of Australia. Chris Lewis of New Zealand also advanced, beating Rod Frawley of Atrstralia, 62, 62, 63.

title: Pro Bowl Lets Players Mix Fun and Football
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan 13On the fishing trip yesterday, Brad Van Pelt's wife hooked a dolphin, which, in the subsequent turmoil beneath the boat, tangled up everybody else's lines. So go the fun and games here this week among the 80 best players in the National Football League who are leisurely preparing for the N.F.L.'s annual Pro Bowl game to be held in Seattle on Monday night.

title: Shiek Yamani in Talks With Arab Emirates
description: Shiek Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, arrived in Abu Dhabi yesterday for consultations with Dr. Mana alUteiba, oil minister of the United Arab Emirates.

title: CARTER WILL PURSUE EARLY PANAMA PACT AND CYPRUS ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13Jimmy Carter intends in the first weeks of his Presidency to press for a solution of the Cyprusdispute and to speed up negotiations for a new Panama Canal treaty, Congressional sources said today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: StripMine Leases on Indian Lands In Montana Overturned by Kleppe
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13The Secretary of the Interior, Thomas S. Kleppe, who will leave office in a week, overturned today a series of large corporate leases of coal land on the Crow Indian reservation in southern Montana. It is believed that his decision will block for years the planned strip mining of billions of tons of Montana coal.

title: Precipitation May Be Heavier Than Usual in Most of Nation
description: The harshest weather in five winters, which has already caused some home heating bills to double, created havoc in Great Lakes shipping and sent consumers shopping for warm clothes, is not going to ease in the next 30 days, according to the National Weather Service.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State Farm Insurance Company, New Jersey's second largest auto underwriter, sued the state, saying a freeze on rate increases was unjustified and prejudged them before they could state their case.

title: White Plains Plans to Reorganize Its Entire Public School System
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 13The Board of Education here today proposed a major reorganization of the city's public school system to meet the problems of a steadily declining enrollment and rising costs.

title: CarterFukuda Talks Planned
description: TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 14Presidentelect Carter agreed in a telephone comersation yesterday to meet with Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda before another economic meeting of the leaders of industrialized countries is held.

title: Q.P.A. Sources Say Agency Ended Efforts to Cut Auto Smog in Cities
description: A major element of the Federal air pollution abatement program, mandatory measures to reduce auto traffic in New York and most other big cities, is being largely abandoned, according to authoritative sources in the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Musical Philanthropist Makes a Gift of Mozart
description: There are probably two reasons why Charlotte Bergen's baton looks half as long as she does. One is that the spry, whitehaired conductor, who is at least in her 70's, is uncommonly small. The other is that her baton, which she next wields at an allMozart concert at Carnegie Hall at 2:30 tomorrow afternoon is uncommonly largenearly two feet long, and half an inch wide at the base.

title: Carter to Announce Staff Today; Jordan to Stay as Principal Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13Hamilton Jordan, the 32yearold Georgian who has been Presidentelect Carter's principal administrative and staff assistant since 1970, will apparently retain that status in the White House staff, which will be formally announced tomorrow.

title: Despite Skeptics, Energy From Water Stirs Interest
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11Two new companies have been established to exploit the commercial potential of a controversial machine that its inventor asserts can derive cheap energy from ordinary waterdespite continuing skepticism over the concept by the nation's scientific community.

title: Reduced Household Utility Rates Proposed in Legislative Measure
description: TRENTON, Jan. 13A major energy plan requiring utilities to cut electric and gas rates for New Jersey homes while being reimbursed through an energy relief fund has been introduced in the Legislature.

title: City Clerk Dinkins to Run For Borough President If Sutton Tries for Mayor
description: David N. Dinkins, the City Clerk, will run for Borough President of Manhattan if his friend Percy E. Sutton, the incumbent, holds to his plan to seek the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

title: Anniversary Prompts Gift Of $50 to Aid the Neediest
description: For Joseph David Abrahams of Manhattan, 1976 proved a special occasion for celebration and, in turn, also helped the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Case Fund.

title: Labor Nominee and Carter Differ On How to Stimulate the Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13  Presidentelect Carter's nominee as Secretary of Labor, F. Ray Marshall, said today that he disagreed with the composition of Mr. Carter's program to stimulate the economy, saying that more money ought to be spent to create jobs and there should be less of a tax cut.

title: Weekend Gardening: Hanging Cactus
description: Maybe it's lack of room on the windowsill, or maybe it's pets nibbling on the potted plants spread out like a holiday smorgasbord on the pebble trays. Whatever it may be, something is creating a minicraze for hanging greenery. I find hanging plants a bit of a nuisance anywhere but in a greenhouse, a building of which I'm yet sorely deprived. The problem is watering. The water runs either down my sleeve or onto the floor, except where I have strategically placed the suspended plants above more firmly footed ones: Then the dripping excess merely moistens the lower level.

title: Rockies 4, Red Wings 2
description: DENVER, Jan. 13 (AP)Jim McElmury, a defenseman, scored his first goal of the season early in the third period and Nelson Pyatt added an insurance tally, as the Colorado Rockies posted a 42 N.H.L. victory tonight over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Molloy, Riding High With Harty in Middle, Faces Loughlin for First Place Tomorrow
description: Jack Curran is slipping. After all, his Archbishop Molloy teams have not swept the Catholic Schools basketball and baseball titles since 1974. But his coaching luck may be about to change. With the tallest player Curran has ever coached showing the way, the Stanners basketball team has won 11 of its first 12 games and has a showdown scheduled for tomorrow night against Bishop Loughlin for first place in its Brooklyn Queens Division.

title: Brazil Sets Fuel Surcharge
description: BRASILIA, Jan. 13 (UPI)President Ernesto Geisel announced today a series of petroleum economization measures to help reduce the nation's almost $4 billion foreign oil bill. The measures include the institution of a gasoline and diesel fuel surcharge,

title: HenriGeorges Clouzot, 69, Dies; French Master of Suspense Film
description: HenriGeorges Clouzot, the French master of suspense films, died of a heart attack Wednesday night in Paris. He was 69 years old.

title: Easing on Emergency Buying by Pipelines Is Likely Today
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 13The Federal Power Commission held an extraordinary allday hearing today on the worsening natural gas shortage and indicated that it would take emergency action within 24 hours.

title: Bruno, With 213, Leads By Shot in Stroke Play
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Jam 13 (AP)  Bob Bruno of Pelham Manor, N. Y., turned in a fourunderpar 68 today for a threeround total of 213 and a oneshot lead in the Professional Golfers Association's national strokeplay championship. Bruno had scores of 74 and 71 during the first two rounds.

title: Notes on People
description: The White House announced yesterday that President Ford had been elected a visiting Chubb Fellow at Yale University and would spend Feb. 68 there in classes and informal meetings with students and faculty members.

title: French Minister, Ending Visit to Canada, Promises Economic Aid for Quebec
description: QUEBEC, Jan. 13  Andr Rossi, France's Minister of Foreign Trade, concluded a fourday visit to Canada last night with a promise of more economic help for Quebec but with a notable lack of specific endorsement for the independence aims of this Frenchspeaking province's new government.

title: Music: Boulez Work Has Premiere Here
description: Unlike some composerconductors one could mention, Pierre Boulez has been altogether circumspect when it comes to programming his own music with his own orchestra. But last night he led the New York Philharmonic in his Rituel, a long (27 minutes), complicated and aurally difficult work dedicated to the memory of the Italian composerconductor Bruno Maderna. Maderna, a friend of Mr. Boulez, died in 1973 at the age of 53.

title: A Conversation With Mr. Sorensen
description: The man who is Presidentelect Carters choice to head the Central Intelligence Agency is a selfconfessed, cardcarrying moralist whose principal task is to rehabilitate the C.I.A. in the publicand Congressionalmind.

title: Anniversary Prompts Gift Of $50 to Aid the Neediest
description: For Joseph David Abrahams of Manhattan, 1976 proved a special occasion for celebration and, in turn, also helped the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Case Fund.

title: Lawyers Making Last Bids Today To Save Gilmore
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 13The countdown to the execution of Gary Mark Gilmore by a firing squad has now been reduced to a long weekend of waiting.

title: Article 1  No Title
Federal Reserve Statement
description: * As reported; not adjusted for transfers of loans to affiliated companies.

title: I. T. T. IS SETTING UP $79 MILLION RESERVE
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, in reporting yesterday a preliminary unaudited report for 1976, said it was setting up aggregate reserves approximating $79 million as an extraordinary charge to income, equal to 64 cents a common share for the fourth quarter of 1976.

title: Broadway
description: THE DREAM, which was only a twinkle in the eye of the producer Joel Schenker when he tdok an option on a book with that title two years ago. will finally arrive on Broadway on March 9. The Dream was a book by Lucy Freeman that has been rewritten as a play by Richard Lortz. It is about a detective and an analyst who work together to solve a murder. I commissioned the play. I don't know that I'd ever do that again, but I fell in love with the idea, and so I did, Mr. Schenker said. Bizarre characters, Kafkaesque, moving in and out of time, entering the murky shadows of the heart and mindit works. As producers frequently do, Mr. Schenker sounded enthusiastic.

title: Callaghan Expands His Role on sterling
description: LONDON, Jan. 13Prime Minister James Callaghan has startled the publicand apparently Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healeyby letting it be known here that he has decided to assume Government's socalled industrial strategy.By industrial strategy, the Government means measures to encourage greater investment by British industry, to stimulate industrial exports, to shift resources from the public to the private sector and, as one official puts it, to clear away dead wood to allow industry to blossom.

title: People in Sports
description: Shirley Babashoff, who won a total of seven medals in the 1972 and 1976 Olympic swimming competitions, announced her retirement yesterday at the age of 19. Miss Babashoff, who earned two gold medals as a member of the women's 400meter freestyle relay team at Munich and Montreal, is junior majoring in business at the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: The Dance: Broadway Festival Opens
description: THE BROADWAY Dance Festival, a series that had its first season last summer, opened new engagement this week at the Bijou Theater that will run through Jan. 30.

title: Article 5  No Title
French Prime Minister Rejects Criticism of Abu Daoud's Release
description: PARIS, Jan. 13Prime Minister Raymond Barre, in a move to defend the honor of France, rejected today all criticism of the official decision that freed a militant Palestinian leader suspected of having planned the attack on members of the Israeli team at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich.

title: Hussein and Sadat Meeting in Egypt On Arab Strategy
description: ASWAN, Egypt, Jan. 13King Hussein of Jordan arrived here today and began talks with President Anwar elSadat aimed at closing the circle of Arab leaders in preparation for peace talks with Israel.

title: Carter Spends Much of the Day on Military Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13After a round of meetings on national defense and telephone conversations with several world leaders, Presidentelect Carter headed back to Georgia today where he plans to remain until his inauguration here next week.

title: S.E.C. IS URGED TO FOSTER COMPANY FORECASTING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13An advisory committee to the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today that the agency design procedures to encourage companies to make forecasts of their economic performance.

title: At the Movies
description: GOOD FILMS, like good wine, improve with age, said King Vidor, who began his distinguished movie career in 1919 with The Turn in the Road. Soon the 82yearold director of such films as The Big Parade, The Crowd, Hallelujah, Street Scene, The Champ, Our Daily Bread, Stella Dallas, The Citadel. Northwest Passage, Duel in the Sun and The Fountainhead will have a chance to test his theory about the survival of celluloid treasures. On March 1820, the U.S.A. Film Festival at Southern Methodist University in Dallas will pay him tribute by screening a halfdozen of his personal favorites.

title: Uzbek Jew, Deprived of Passport, Gets 3 Years for Not Having One
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 13A kind of Soviet Catch22 ended in Uzbekistan today when a young Jew who was once on the verge of emigrating to Israel was sentenced to three years in prison for failing to have an internal passport, which the authorities themselves had taken away, and for failing to have a job, which he could not get without the passport. He was also charged with hooliganism, as the Soviet judicial system calls disorderly conduct.

title: Beame Cuts City CoffeeBuying by a 3d
description: The soaring price of coffee has added to the city's fiscal headache. Mayor Beame yesterday ordered a onethird cut in the purchase of coffee ordered by the city for its hospitals, prisons and other institutions.

title: Henry Ford's Bristly Farewell
description: The announcement by Henry Ford 2d that he had resigned as a trustee of the Ford Foundation after 33 years of service would ordinarily call for little more than acknowledgment of his extraordinary contributions to American philanthropy. It was, after all, during the years of Mr. Ford's maximum impact as board chairman, from 1950 to 1956, that a moderatesize family fund grew into the nation's largest foundation. Mr. Ford not only presided over this growthdisbursements since then have totaled $4 billionbut he was also midwife to the creation of a national board and an international program, independent of the Ford family and of the automobile company that produced the foundation's great endowment.

title: Screen: 'The Goalie's Anxiety':Lonely Madness
description: WHEN WE FIRST see Josef Bloch (Arthur Brauss), the goalie, he is isolated in a long shot at the far end of the soccer field. The frantic activity of the game at the other end of the field has no apparent relation to him. He walks around impatiently. He wipes his hands. He is a lean man, all tendons that have been tense so long that even the most ordinary gesture seems to be a kind of tic.Suddenly the game closes in on him and Josef Bloch, who has been waiting for this moment, fails to prevent the score. He displays no impatience with himself, no bitterness, no visible emotion whatsoever. For, as we learn in Wim Wenders's superlative screen version of Peter Handke's novel "The Goalie's Anxiety at the Penalty Kick," Josef Bloch has been disconnected.This precise and beautiful German film, directed by Mr. Wenders and written by him and Mr. Handke, was originally shown in New York at the Museum of Modern Art's 1972 New Directors/New Films series, but it is only now having its commercial premiere at the Film Forum, where it opened yesterday. It will be seen there at 7:30 P.M. today through Sunday, and at the same time next weekend, Thursday through Sunday.Like the Handke novel, the film will be describedincorrectly, I thinkas dispassionate, which is not to see the film, or the book for its style, which is about as self-effacing as a style can be without disappearing entirely. However, "The Goalie's Anxiety at the Penalty Kick" is seething with feelings that are so ambiguous, so terrifying, that like Josef Bloch, the film can recognize them only obliquely, as if trying to put a good face on things by refusing to make a fuss."The Goalie's Anxiety at the Penalty Kick" is a carefully composed, unhysterical record of one man's coming-apart. At the end of his last game. Josef Bloch wanders aimlessly around a Vienna that is both familiar to him and as strange as the inside of a beehive. He drinks. He plays the jukebox. He sleeps. He gets mugged. He picks up a girl and goes to her apartment at the edge of an airfield. They make love. The next morning they have breakfast. He thinks he sees ants in the teapot. He strangles her. He leaves. He buys a newspaper and gets on a bus. . . .Those sentences suggest the tempo of the film, but not its impact on the viewer who, by being required to fill in explanations the film makers resolutely refuse to give, becomes drawn into Josef Bloch's madness in a way that leaves one breathless and high. It's as exciting as any conventionally successful and high suspense film.Mr. Handke's novelshe is perhaps better known here as a playwrighthas been associated with France's nouveau roman and the work of Alain Robbe-Grillet. The methods are similar, but there is a major, crucial difference. Mr. Robbe-Grillet's novels and films seem bent on demonstrating the boredom of alienated man by turning their backs on the reader and boring him into a stupor. "The Goalie's Anxiety" is also about disconnection, but the novelist's impulse is furious, rather than bored. His work has the vigor of a revolutionist.Since "The Goalie's Anxiety" was first shown in New York, Mr. Wenders has been represented by two later films seen at the New York Film Festival, "Alice in the Cities" and "Kings of the Road," but because neither has had the force and cool beauty of this film, I would assume he needs a collaborator of Mr. Handke's discipline and intellectual enthusiasm."The Goalie's Anxiety" doesn't contain one redundant shot or unnecessary camera movement. For the most part, the camera seldom moves. It is content to record the actors walking into and out of a frame, more or less in the passive manner of Josef Bloch as he regards the odd behavior of himself and of the strangers in the world around him.This simplicity, as opposed to the fancy photography and the modish fragmentation of time and image favored by Mr. Robbe-Grillet ("L'Immortelle," "The Man Who Lies"), has the effect of making us see people, objects and bits of action with a clarity so stunning that they come to have for us as much menace and mystery as they have for the mad Josef Bloch."The Goalie's Anxiety at the Penalty Kick" is a remarkable, fascinating film, one that suggests, among many other things, that the nouveau film, if indeed there is to be such a thing, will be plain, unadorned, direct, not an accumulation of fashionable mannerisms.

title: Two Accused of War Crimes Face Loss of Citizenship
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13The Federal prosecutor in Philadelphia has moved to revoke the American citizenship of two Ukrainian brothers who allegedly concealed their roles in war crimes against Polish Jews in 1941 and 1942, the Justice Department announced here today.

title: Majors and Dennison Are Voted College Coaches of Year by Peers
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 13Johnny Majors, who directed Pittsburgh to the unofficial national collegiate football championship last season before taking over as head coach at Tennessee, was named University Division coach of the year today by his peers in the American Football Coaches Association.

title: About Real Estate
description: WASHINGTONDeep in the recesses of the Department of Housing and Urban Development officials are at work on new Federal regulations tat may significantly arrest housing deterioration in the cities.

title: Stephanie in Nutcrackerland
description: Stephanie, the reallife heroine of A Very Young Dancer, is neither very young nor a dancer. She is a 10yearold of some privilege who takes ballet lessons at the School of American Ballet and spends each summer ponyriding in Wyoming. She has been seen in the leading child role in the New York City Ballet production of The Nutcracker.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Some lonely young children neither run away from friendship nor enter into it. They stand at the edge of an activity, watching, pacing, perhaps rocking quietly or whining. If the other children are asked whom they like and whom they dislike, these lonely children may not even be mentioned at all. They're virtually invisibleciphers on the periphery.

title: Article 2  No Title
Restaurants
description: A North Italian Find And 2 That Lose Out

title: UNIONS IN BRITAIN CALLING BOYCOTT OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: LONDON, Jan. 13Union leaders said today that many British workers would demonstrate against South Africa's racial policies all through next week disrupting communications and trade.

title: Likud Leader Derides Report
description: JERUSALEM, Friday, Jan. 14  The leader of the Israeli opposition bloc, Likud, today ridiculed a report that extreme rightwing members of his organization had contracted for the murder of Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Bridge:
description: Players from the New York Metropolitan area dominated the opening day of the tristate regional championships at Grossinger's, N.Y., Wednesday. Winners of the two major events were:

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: IF, AS THE HISTORIANS tell us, the North Shore of Long Island was once part of Colonial Connecticut, there is probably no better example of New England influence on the Island than in the ThreeVillage area.

title: Antiques
description: THE PUBLIC was never told. But those in charge of Boscobel, the superb Adamstyle historic restoration in Garrison, N.Y., have planned for years to revamp the interiors of that residence completely.

title: Sue Barker Advances
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP)Sue Barker of England defeated Renata Tomanova of Czechoslovakia, 60, 6.3, today and reached the quarterfinals of a $100,000 Virginia Slims tournament. The match was the only singles contt.st on the afternoon card.

title: HOW TO ASSIST THE FUND FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Chicago Election Set for June 7
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (Reuters)  The Chicago City Council today set June for a special election to pick a successor to serve out the unexpired term of the late Mayor Richard J. Daley. April 19 was chosen as the date for primary elections.

title: UMass 81, UConn 80
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 13 (AP)Derick Claiborne banked a 10foot jump shot off the glass with two seconds remaining and gave Massachusetts a tense, 8180 victory over Connecticut tonight.

title: E.P.A. Sources Say Agency Ended Efforts to Cut Auto Smog in Cities
Sweet &
description: SWEET PAPA STOVEPIPE, a 79yearold blues and gospel singer and exprizefighter from North Carolina, was throwing a few right hooks, the other: clay, ducking and (lodging, as light on his feet as ocinet dancer. Go on and hit me, try it, he urged and as tne punch was thrown he simultaneously threw up an elbow in front of his face, sidestepped, and raised a fist to strike a counterblow. I used to get em with that one, he said, and then he smiled sweetly, as if he had just remembered that he had a stage name to live up to.

title: GIBSON RESIGNS JOB AS A DEPUTY MAYOR
description: Paul Gibson Jr., the highestranking black official in the Beame administration, announced yesterday that he would resign as Deputy Mayor for Planning to return to private business. He is to be replaced today by Lucille Rose, the New York City Commissioner of Employment.

title: The Attica Pardons
description: Through due process of law, eight criminals were convicted of committing murder and other crimes during the 1971 Attica prison riot. Governor Carey has pardoned seven of them (and commuted the sentence of the eighth) on the grounds that there is insufficient evidence to prosecute the police.

title: BROCK TAKES LEAD FOR G.O.P. CHAIRMAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13The Republican Party, seeking new leadership after its losses in the 1976 election, appeared today to be heading toward the selection of Bill Brock, the former Senator from Tennessee, as national chairman.

title: Kaiser Aluminum
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Company reported yesterday a fourthquarter loss of $2.3 million after nonrecurring charges of $33 million, and earnings of $30.7 million or $1.52 a share before such charges. In the final quarter of 1975 a profit of $11.7 million, or 57 cents a share was reported. Sales were $439.9 million, up from $367.1 million, lifting the annual volume 18.8 percent to $1.9 billion from $1.6 billion.

title: Dissident Group Splitting Italy's NeoFascist Party
description: ROME, Jan. 13Georgio Almirante, the leader of Italy's neoFasclst party, works out of an office where bits of the 16thcentury ceiling sometimes fall on his desk. Now, his critics say, the roof has caved in on him.

title: World Oil And Finance
description: Some three years after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries dramatic quadrupling of oil prices, uncertainties and dangers are still threatening the prosperity and stability of both oilimporting countries and OPEC alike.

title: Bell's Club Ties Decried at Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP)Griffin B. Bell's continued membership in three social clubs that exclude blacks demonstrates his insensitivity to racial minorities, critics charged at his confirmation hearings for Attorney General today.

title: Books of The Times
description: KINGSLEY AMIS seems to have enjoyed himself hugely, as always, writing his latest novel, The Alteration, and there are a couple of things that reader, too, can enjoy. One of them is the novel's premise. The time is 1976 in a world where the Protestant Reformation never happened. England is the crown jewel of a Roman Catholic empire whose spiritual and secular leader is Pope John XXIV, a Yorkshireman, whose only enemy is the Moslem Turk, kept at peace by the spirit of detensione. North America consists of Louisiana, Qubec, Florida, Mxico, New Muscovy and the small territory of New England, a refuge for heretics and outlaws whose capital is Arnoldstown and over which fly passenger pigeons by the millions.

title: Trade Center TV Tower Agreed On
description: Tentative agreement on the placement of a 365foot antenna mast atop the North Tower of the World Trade Center, a move that would significantly improve reception for 20 million television viewers in the metropolitan area, was confirmed yesterday by a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Brig. Gen. Wm. BesseII, ExProfessor and Dean At West Point, Dead at 75
description: Brig. Gen. William W. Bessell Jr., who retired in 1965 as dean of the United States Military Academy, died yesterday at the Army hospital at West Point. He was 75 years old and lived in CornwallonHudson. N.Y.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Where Krazy Kat Lives
description: If you don't want to give away your age, try not to stand too long in any one place among the displays at the Museum of Cartoon Art, an absorbing repository of memories that has been established in an elegant old stone mansion in Greenwich, Conn. People will know you by your fascination with the funnies you grew up with.

title: Miller Falls 7 Behind on Poor Putting
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 13In 1974, 1975 and 1976 Johnny Miller won the Tucson open with respective scores of 14, 25 and 16 under par. In 1974 and 1975 he won the Phoenix open at 13 and 24 under par. Last week in the Phoenix open, the King of the Desert finished at three over par. And today, in the first round of the 1977 Tucson open, Miller shot a dismal 74.

title: News Summary
description: Resolving the Cyprus dispute ana acceleration of. negotiations for a new Panama Canal treaty are among foreign policy matters that will be given priority by the Carter Administration, according to members of Congress who participated in daylong discussions with Presidentelect Carter, Secretary of Statedesignate, Cyrus R. Vance and other Carter aides. The new Administration will also consider ways to alter the ineffective JacksonVanik amendment of 1974, which bars trade concessions to the Soviet Union until there is assurance of liberalized Soviet emigration, and will seek a new strategic arms limitation agreement with Moscow by next October. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: Making Do With More Doctors
description: The Congress further finds and declares that there is no longer an insufficient number of physicians and surgeons in the United States such that there is no further need for affording preference to alien physicians and surgeons in admission to the United States under the Immigration and Nationality Act.

title: CARTER PICKS BLACK AS AIDE ON INTERAMERICAN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13  Presidenteledt Carter has chosen a black career diplomat, Terence A. Todman, as the new assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs, despite opposition from liberal groups involved with Latin America.

title: Corruption Charges Against New York Police Decline
description: Corruption charges against New York City police officers continued to decline last year, but a highlevel police study has warned that the freeze on police salaries could spawn questionable and corrupt practices.

title: Vlinnesota 83, Illinois 69
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 13 (UPI)Mike Thompson scored 25 points and Osborne Lockhart, 19, tonight as they led unbeaten Minnesota to an 8369 Big Ten victory over Illinois.

title: AvantGarde Rumanian Novelist Given Passport and Bum's Rush
description: PARIS, Jan. 11Virgil Tanase's novels and stories are difficult to understand, capable of diverse interpretations and clearly nonpolitical. That, he believes, is why the Rumanian Government gave him a passport and made it clear it expected him to use it for a oneway journeyout.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The Times on Jan, 7 concerning a wifebeating case, Flioghan Kirchner was incorrectly identified as a lawyer who represented the wife. Miss Kirchner notes that she not a lawyer, but a legal assistant.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Jan. 13 (Reuters)  The House of Commons started its debate tonight on the question of giving limited home rule to Scotland and Wales.LONDON, Jan. 13The printers of The Tknes of London refused to produce today's issue because an article in it said they used sabotage, sudden union meetings and other editionstopping tactics in disputes with management.VIENNA, Jan. 13 (Reuters)Czechoslovak authorities today ordered the playwright Pavel Kohout, the writer and human rights activist, to leave his Prague apartment within three weeks.MADRID, Jan. 13 (AP)A gathering of Basque mayors planned for Sunday in Navarre Province has been forbidden on the ground that it was politically motivated and might result in disturbances, the Interior Minsistry announced today.BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 13 (UPI) Vietnam admitted today that crime, unemployment and subversion against the Communist Government were still the nation's worst problems.

title: RADIO
description: Music

title: Brown Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AJ)Harold Brown, who headed the Air Force at the height of the Vietnam War was approved by the Senate Armed Services Committee today to be Secretary of Defense.

title: Precipitation May Be Heavier Than Usual in Most of Nation
description: The harshest weather in five winters, which has already caused some home heating bills to double, created havoc in Great Lakes shipping and sent consumers shopping for warm clothes, is not going to ease in the next 30 days, according to the National Weather Service.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Around the Nation
description: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 13 (AP)The defense and prosecution rested their cases today in the Claudine Longet manslaughter trial after less than a week of testimony in which the entertainer swore she shot her lover by accident.LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (AP)A judge: has declared unconstitutional a part of the 1964 Civil Rights Act that requires employers to make reasonable efforts to respect worker needs based on religious preferences.SANTA FE, N. M., Friday, Jan. 14 (AP) A Brinks guard described by the police as possibly the greatest ripoff artist of all time after he vanished with a halfmillion dollars in California nearly a year ago was arrested Thursday in New Mexico, the Federal Bureal of Investigation reported.

title: Jacqueline Onassis Makes a New Debut
description: Set in the Versailles Room of the Carlyle Hotel, with the seven guests seated around a linencovered table with a dazzling arrangement of tulips, roses and gerbera in the center, and handlettered place cards at every brocadeupholstered seat, this was hardly the usual bookpublication news conference.

title: Rockefeller Says He Will No Longer Play An Active Role in State Republican Affairs
description: Vice President Rockefeller, who has dominated the Republican Party in New York State for nearly 20 years, has told leading Republicans that he will no longer play an active role in the party.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The Times on Jan. 7 concerning a wifeheating case, Rioghan Kirchner was incorrectly identified as a lawyer who represented the wife. Miss Kirchner notes that she is not a lawyer, but a legal assistant.

title: The Sounds of Jelly Roll Live Again
description: Jelly Roll Morton, the legendary New Orleans jazz pianist, composer of King Porter Stomp, Wolverine Blues and Doctor Jazz, band leader and raconteur, never played at Carnegie Hall. But tomorrow night his music will take over the auditorium in a program inspired by a group of Danish musicians, implemented by a Japanese cornetist on a visit to New Orleans and organized by a pianist and a onetime radio documentary writer whose life is now devoted to the study and presentation of Mr. Morton's music.

title: Yanks Shut Out as Finley Case Closes
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 13Even if they still want him, which they may, the Yankees apparently won't get Vida Blue through Charles O. Finley's legal battle with Bowie Kuhn.

title: PETROLEUM DISTILLATES SET PRODUCTION RECORD
description: Production of petroleum distillates, used primarily for home heating oil, reached record levels for the week ended Jan. 7 and stocks for the period declined, as cold weather continued across most of the nation, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute, the oil industry trade association.

title: Gold
description: Seelected world gold prices Thursday.

title: Acadian Schools Giving Up Religion
description: ST. AGATHA, Me.,  The dominant building in each of the little towns along the upper St. John's River Valley in this remote, farthest northern corner of Maine is a Roman Catholic church. In Frenchville, just down the road, it is St. Luce, built of multicolored stone; in fort Kent it is St. Louis, with a lacy wroughtiron steeple; in Lille, it is Mount Carmel, with twin spires, each topped by a trumpeting angel. And here, amid the trackless, snowcovered, gently rolling hills of the back settlements, it is the plain, solid St. Agatha's.

title: French Prime Minister Rejects Criticism of A bu Daoud's Release
description: PARIS, Jan. 13Prime Minister Raymond Barre, in a move to defend the honor of France, rejected today all criticism of the official decision that freed a militant Palestinian leader suspected of having planned the attack on members of the Israeli team at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich.

title: Questions on Farm Policies For the Incoming Secretary
description: WASHINGTONOf the several hearings conducted here this week by various Senate committees in the confirmation process for Presidentelect Carter's Cabinet appointees, the one that attracted the least political attenion and public fanfare was the session that considered the nomination of Representative Bob Bergland, Democrat of Minnesota, as the new Secretary of Agricul

title: HENRI LANGLOIS, 62, HISTORIAN OF FILM
description: PARIS, Jan. 13Henri Langlois, founder and director of the French Cinematheque, which, with its estimated 50,000 films, is one of the world's great movie collections, died of a heart attack at his home here last night, it was announced today. He was 62 years old.

title: Censorship Points Up Anxiety Among the Lebanese In Crucial Period of Transition From War to Peace
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 13Lebanon is living through a crucial period of transition between war and uneasy peace with the news of developments there heavily censored.

title: Bullfight Promoter Locks Horns With the Law
description: He tried mightily and almost prompted a little slice of Fifth Avenue into la plaza de toms yesterday before he was arrested, and this disappointed John Hoffman, because what I was doing was good for New York.

title: Theater: Mix of The Last Resort Fails to Jell
description: The Last Resort is like a hen that appears to be on some mysterious zigzag journey, but actually is detouring for crumbs. The fourcharacter play, sporadically bright and always talky, promises ideas, but is only after motions.

title: Sir Henry d'AvigdorGoldsmid Dead at 67
description: LONDON, Jan. 14 A memorial service will be held on Feb. 8 at the West London Synagogue for Sir Henry d'AvigdorGoldsmid, a member of a prominent British family.

title: Smith Terms Talks On Rhodesia Dead
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 14Prime Minister Ian D. Smith today called the Geneva conference on Rhodesia's future a dead duck, and said that he expected the Carter administration to give his Government full diplomatic support in seeking an accord with black groups outside the framework of the conference.

title: Dr. Mary Jane Watkins, a Dentist
description: DETROIT. Jan. 14 (AP)A funeral is scheduled for tomorrow for Dr. Mary Jane Watkins, a retired dentist who was the first black woman to serve in the Women's Army Corps. She died Tuesday at the age of 74.

title: U.S. Vows Continued Cooperation With France Despite Daoud Case
description: PARIS, Jan. 14American officials have advised the French Government that the United States will continue to seek close cooperation with France, despite Washington's expression of dismay over how Paris handled the Abu Daoud case.

title: Hesburgh Named Rockefeller Foundation Chairman
description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, was elected chairman of the Rockefeller Foundation yesterday. He replaces Cyrus R. Vance, who resigned from the foundation board when he was named Secretary of State.

title: SAKHAROV SUSPECTS POLICE IN MOSCOW SUBWAY BLAST
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 14 (AP)Andrei D. Sakharov said today that he suspects that the Soviet security police set off the explosion that killed several persons in a Moscow subway last week to discredit Soviet dissidents.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Calihan of Detroit Resigns
description: DETROIT, Jan. 14 (AP)Robert Calihan, the director of athletics for the University of Detroit, resigned from his post yesterday, citing health reasons. A university spokesman said Calihan's post would be filled on an interim basis by Dale Tucker, director of administration. A committee will conduct a search for a permanent successor to Calihan.

title: A National Health Insurance Proposal
description: CHICAGOAny sensible national health insurance plan must be fiscally possible and administratively manageable, politically feasible and likely to improve America's health without further inflating the already disastrous rate of medical inflation, which was 14 percent in 1975.

title: END TO FLUSHOT BAN IS FAVORED BY PANEL
description: ATLANTA, JAN. 14A committee of experts concluded today that the current moratorium on influenza vaccinations should be lifted, although the committee commented that the flu shots did entail some additional risk of the rare Guillain Barre paralysis that halted the national flu program last month.

title: Gallant and Tragic Figure
description: Anthony Eden was a tragic and gallant figure. Tragic, because after a brilliant career as Foreign Secretary he became Prime Minister only to leave that office after two years beset by illness and enemies. Gallant, because he bore the ruin of his political career with that grace under pressure that was Hemingway's definition of courage. In nearly 40 years of friendship I never saw him unintentionally rude to anyone, although he could be brutally tough on political enemies. From 1938 until he died he maintained faith in the ultimate triumph of reason,. kind a democratic society and that nd of society's ability to defeat any other.

title: U.S. GIVES NEW YORK $50 MILLION TO SPEED BIG SEWAGE PROJECTS
description: A grant of almost $50 million and an agreement to provide an additional $225 million in Federal funds for New York City were announced yesterday to expedite the construction of huge sewagetreatment facilities in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Staten Island.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JANUARY 15, 1977

title: Property Tax for Schools, Is Ruled Illegal on Coast
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Jan. 14 (AP)Washington's system of financing schools with special property tax levies is unconstitutional, a state court judge ruled today.

description: Special to The New York Times

title: Sugar Futures Reverse Their Downward Trend To Post a Sharp Rise

NEWARK IS WARNED ON BUSINESS TAX RISE
description: NEWARK, Jan. 14The head of the Greater Newark Chamber of Commerce warned today that Newark would accelerate the flight of both industry and homeowners if business taxes, were increased.

title: Right Time for Learning
description: The road to the Ph.D. used to be regarded as too exclusive to be sullied by the tracks of parttime scholars with the muck of everyday life on their boots. Social and economic change have made that monastic view of graduate education obsolete and untenable. Young people, eager to get into the real world, increasingly are turning to parttime graduate studies. Liberated women claim the right to divide their time between family and advanced studies. Professionals, aware of the speed of change their fields, want to come back to the campus for periodic refreshers.

title: Financial Affairs Are Under Study For Universal Money Order Case
description: The financial affairs and condition of a primately held money order concern with headquarters in New York, the Universal Money Order Company, has been keeping banking departments in New York, California and several other states busy all week.

title: Koch and Badillo Condemn a Fake Letter
description: In an unusual joint news conference, two prospective mayoral opponents. Representatives Herman Badillo and Edward I. Koch, disclosed and denounced yesterday a fraudulent letter that represented Mr. Koch as warning Mr. Badillo that a black Mayor could turn New York into a ghost city.

title: Calling Into Question Mrs. Gandhi's Economic Achievements
description: An ambivalence has marked Western reaction to developments in India. Liberal democracies have a cultural dislike for authoritarian regimes; insofar as Mrs. Indira Gandhi has confiscated the political and civil liberties of the population, there have naturally been expressions of anguish and disquiet.

title: U.S. Officials Expressing Concern About Rising Israeli Arms Expoits
Woman Describes Friend's Killing on Mexico Road
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14The young man with the pistol was like a mad dog; he just fired shot after shot; my fianc was shot down in cold blood, right in front of me; there were four shots in his body and they found nine bullets at the scene.

title: Bridge:
description: A questionandanswer panel show, with questions far outnumbering answers, is scheduled this morning at Grossinger, N.Y.

title: Joe Hill's Execution Just a Memory in Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 14He was tall and thin, and he was the focus of national attention as the date of his execution by the firing squad drew near.

title: Jogging Past the Glass, Darkly
description: It is 6 A.M. The guards at the Federal Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe, West Germany, tug at the straps of their machine guns as I run around them.

title: Prison Aides Held in Drug Incidents
Pro Freestyle Ski Tour Set to Begin 3d Season
description: Marion Post remembers the good old days of freestyle (don't call it hotdog) skiing. Marion Post, the women's world freestyle (don't call. it hotdog) skiing champion, is 21 years old.

title: DieselPowered Model of Rabbit Makes Its Debut at Volkswagen
description: DETROIT, Jan. 14Volkswagen of America today unveiled its diesel powered Rabbit model and said it would be priced at no more than $300 above the gasolineengine Rabbit.

title: EDWARD J. ECCLESTON
description: Edward J. Eccleston, retired controller of the Hackensack Water Company of Weehawken, N. J., died Thursday at his home in Hasbrouck Heights, N. J. He was 54 years old. Mr. Eccleston, who joined the company in 1940 and retired last month, had also been controller of its subsidiary, the Spring Valley Water Company. He leaves his wife, the former Marie Ferolie; two sans, Kevin and Edward Jr.; a daughter, Karen Stapleton, and a brother, Raymond.

title: PRICES OF TIN IN LONDON CLIMB TO NEW LEVELS
description: LONDON, Jan. 14 (Reuters)The price of tin climbed to new heights on the London Metal Exchange today, after the International Tin Council announced yesterday that buffer stock supplies were exhausted.

title: Smith Terms Talks On Rhodesia Dead
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 14Prime Minister Ian D. Smith today called the Geneva conference on Rhodesia's future a dead duck, and said that he expected the Carter administration to give his Gov. ernment full diplomatic support in seeking an accord with black groups outside the framework of the conference.

title: CURB ON COMPETITION LAID TO DENTAL GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The Federal Trade Commission accused the Ameri, can Dental Association today of price fixing and other unlawful practices that it said prevented patients from benefiting from competition.

title: Defense and Injuries Keep Rangers in Troubled State
description: Bill Goldsworthy, the New York Rangers left wing, will complete his suspension for a stickswinging incident by sitting out tomorrow's game in Chicago. Clarence Campbell, the league president, announced yesterday that Goldsworthy had been given a threegame suspension resulting from a scuffle between periods of the RangerLos Angeles game last Sunday in which Goldsworthy's stick came down on the head of a linesman, Malcolm Ashford

title: Gail Blackburn and McLeish Win in CanAm Skiing
description: CARRABASSETT VALLEY, Me., Jan. 14 (AP)Gail Blackburn of Brunswick, Me., and Robin McLeish of Kanata, Ontario, shared firstplace honors today and captured top places in the CanadianAmerican downhill ski races at Sugarloaf.

title: Miss Longet Is Guilty on Lesser Count of Homicide
LISBON IN ECONOMIC STEP, TO REOPEN STOCK EXCHANGE
The Shadow Over the Vikings
description: The Minnesota Vikings are still wondering why they lost four Super Bowl games, but The Shadow knows. The Shadow is the ghost of Harry Wismer, one of the founding fathers of the American Football League, who were deserted by Max Winter when the National Football League offered a Minnesota franchise for 1961 to a group that included the onetime partowner of the Minneapolis Lakers basketball team. Over the last decade the Vikings have been one of pro football's most successful teamsexcept in the Super Bowl, when The Shadow always gets even for the treason of the Viking owners. Perhaps you didn't notice The Shadow on your TV set last Sunday when the Oakland Raiders humiliated the Vikings, 3214, but he was seen by those who remember Harry. Wismer's wisdom. When the Vikings Brent McLanahan fumbled at the 2yard line, Phil Villapiano of the Raiders was credited with having jarred the ball loose. But The Shadow hit him first. And when Fran Tarkenton had Ahmad Rashad in the clear near midfield, the Vikings receiver didn't drop the pass. The Shadow knocked it away. And all the while The Shadow also was broadcasting the playbyplay for the big TV audience in the sky.

title: About New York
description: The power of the press is a flaming sword! Use it justly! Hold it high! Guard it well!

title: People in Sports
Transit Service Cuts As Planned by M.T.A.
description: Following are transit service cutbacks approved yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A story on the President's Commission on Olympic Sports yesterday incorrectly listed Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska as Democrat. He is a Republican.

title: The Fans Rock Imaginatively On Impressive Instrumentals
description: Anybody who still thinks of the lower Manhattan rock scene as exclusively punk rock would do well to check out the Fans, who are opening the bill for Talking Heads at CBGB's through tonight and who will also be there tomorrow night. This is a quartet from Atlanta that owes its primary allegiances to John Cale, Roxy Music's Be Bop Deluxe and the whole range of AngloEuropean progressive rock. When asked, ironically, for Brown Sugar on Thursday, the lead singer responded with an obscenity.

title: Giants Sign Montefusco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 (AP)The San Francisco Giants signed John Montefusco, their top pitcher of the last two seasons, to a fiveyear contract today. No other details were announced by the National League baseball team, but it was believed that the contract put the righthander well over the $100,000 annual salary mark for the coming season.

title: Court Overturns Federal Death Penalty
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14 (UPI)A Federal appeals court declared the Federal death penalty statute unconstitutional today, saying it failed to meet United States Supreme Court standards.

title: Directors Overdo Bizarre Entrances
description: I guess there's a certain midseason madness that overtakes our stage directors, though I don't quite see why it should take the particular form it has these last few weeks. During these last few weeks it has been the inspired notion of good directors and trueI mean that, because the directors at hand were Vinnette Carroll and George Abbottto have one or two members of the acting company first appear, for no reason whatsoever, from either the orchestra pit or the front row of the auditorium.

title: Obscure Satra Got a Soviet Plum
description: The Satra Corporation, a publicly owned United States trading and manufacturing company, has purchased close to a billion dollars worth of materials and products from the Soviet Union during the last 25 years. But to most Americans, Satra has never been a household word.

title: FREE ACCESS BY STAFF TO CARTER IS PLANNED
World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Watch on the Nile
description: CAIROHaving officially launched a multiparty system in Egypt and having outlined a plan for economic development, President Anwar elSadat hopes shortly to apply for Egyptian membership in the Socialist International, he told me in the course of a lengthy conversation. The Socialist International is that to which ruling Western Socialist parties in Britain, Federal Germany, Portugal, Austriaand Israelas well as Sweden's and France's powerful parties belong.

title: Top Arms Aide Disputes Carter On Deadlock in Talks With Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14Fred C. Ikl, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, disagreed today with Presidentelect Carter's view that the Ford Administration was at fault for the failure to conclude a treaty with the Soviet Union last year that would limit each side's strategic bombers and longrange missiles.

title: EnergyRelated Stocks Advance as Dow Declines 3.99
description: Oil, natural gas and drilling issues continued to move higher yesterday, while the stock market generally declined.

title: North Shore Acres: Trouble With the Neighbors
description: GLEN HEAD, L. I.The people of North Shore Acres may see each other at parties or on walks on a nice afternoon, but they are not used to getting together over legal matters on a chilly night in January.

title: Louise McDonough Is Married to A. S. Hatch
description: Louise McDonough, daughter of Mrs. John Francis McDonough of South Orange, N.J., and the late John McDonough, was married in New York yesterday to Alfrederic Smith Hatch, son of Mrs. Francis MacCoy Jr. of Summit, N.J., and the late John Ruggles Hatch of Montclair, N.J.

title: U.S. PROPOSES PLAN TO MEET 1990 NEEDS OF TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. put forward today a 400page planning docu.ment predicting that. with prompt and, proper national choices. transportation, demands in 1990 could be met without, increased consumption of energy.

title: No Bomb Found in Capitol Search
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (Reuters)A bomb threat led to a police search of the Capitol today, but nothing was found. The police said that they received word early this morning that a package of explosives had been hidden in the historic building.

title: November Business Inventories Up Only 0.1% Despite Major Sales Gain
20Day Miami Hotel Strike Settled
description: MIAMI. Jan. 14The 20day strike of about 5,000 hotel workers, which has affected nine of this area's largest hotels, was settled late today.

title: CZECHS CRACK DOWN ON DISSIDENTS AGAIN
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 14To ascertain the addresses of Czechoslovak citizens living in Prague, contact the public security police, this month's official city guide for foreign tourists advises.

title: First Woman Deputy Mayor
Amex in Accord With 5 Members Linked With Becker Securities
description: The American Stock Exchange has made a settlement with five members associated with the Becker Securities Corporation, the first such action stemming from its investigation of fictitious options trades on the floor. The penalty, agreed to by all parties, is a $5,000 fine and a onemonth suspension for each of the members.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Custodial employees at the city's schools have called oft the strike they had threatened for Monday, according to Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board. The custodial employees, represented by Local 74 of the Service Employees International Union, are employed by custodial engineers, who, in turn are represented by Local 891 of the Operating Engineers.

title: 3to6Inch Snow Is Accompanied By Respite From Extreme Cold
Help Directed From Overseas To the Neediest
description: Overseas friends of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fundfrom France, Australia and Venezuelaare among those contributing to the 65th annual appeal.

title: DR. MYRA LOGAN, 68;
description: Dr. Myra Logan, a surgeon who served the Harlem community for more than 35 years, died Thursday night at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 9th Setback in Row Ties Club Mark
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 14  The nightmares of their first season in the National Basketball Association continued tonight for the Nets in a bizarre, librarylike hush at Nassau Coliseum, where a heavy snowstorm held the crowd to 1,404 largely silent fans. The silence of the onlookers was entirely appropriate, as the Nets suffered a 120101 defeat to the Atlanta Hawks.

title: FORD SENDS CONGRESS STATEHOOD MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 14 (AP)President Ford sent to Congress today legislation beginning a long process that could lead to statehood for Puerto Rico if the island's people approved it in a referendum.

title: New Economic Slump for Industrial Nations Is Feared
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  Presidentelect Carter's program for economic stimulus has failed to dispel fears of many international financial experts that the industrial countries may be sliding into a new slump even before they have fully recovered from the deepest postwar recession. These analysts say Mr. Carter is stepping too lightly on the accelerator with his $30 billion pacakge of tax cuts and job orientation programs stretched over two years. But they are also worried about the reluctance of West Germany and Japan to prod their domestic economies into faster growth.

description: Southern District
