Aeros Triumph, 53
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 14 (AP)Morris Lukovich and Cam Connor scored quick goals for Houston following a first period freeforall and Mark Howe added the clinching goal in the second period tonight to lead the Aeros to a 53 World Hockey Association victory over the Birmingham. Bulls.

title: McNamara Asks for Poverty Group
Cauthen Rides 5 Winners at Aqueduct
description: Steve Cauthen still isn't old enough for an automobile driver's license, but there's no stopping him as a horse chauffeur.

title: The Loosening Grip
description: Martin had sensed that the world was getting away from him, but he had kept a shaky grip on himself until last Thursday morning. That was when he made one of his rare forays into the financial pages of the paper and saw the advertisement.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reported in The Times over the last week.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the American Electric Power Company and four of its operating subsidiaries that would settle a 1971 antitrust action filed by the American Electric Power units in Federal Court in New York.

title: EUGENE DUKLAUER DIES
description: Eugene Duklauer, a retired plumbing contractor who installed the plumbing in some of New York City's most prominent buldings, died yesterday at a nursing home in Purchase, N.Y. He was 88 years old and a resident of Purchase.

title: Patents
Helms Informed That He Is Target Of Federal Jury Inquiry on Chile
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 14The Justice Department has formally notified an attorney for Richard Helms that the former Director of Central Intelligence and Ambassador to Iran is a target of a Federal grand jury's investigation, Justice Department sources said today.

title: Captain of Tanker In Oil Spill Given His Passport Back
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14A Federal judge ordered the Government today to return the passport of a Greek ship captain whose Liberianflag tanker spilled 134,000 gallons of oil in the Delaware River on Dec. 27.

title: Sonics Rout Knicks
description: Special to The New York Times

title: REPUBLICANS SELECT BROCK AS PARTY HEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14Bill Brock, a 46yearold conservative from Tennessee, elected chairman of the Republican National Committee today, winning a spirited fiveman competition that required three secret ballots to resolve.

title: 2 City Center BoxOffice Workers Acquitted in TicketSwindle Case
U.S. Officials Expressing Concern About Rising Israeli Arms Exports
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14State and Defense Department officials are watching with rising concern the emergence of Israel as an exporter of sophisticated military equipment, much of it derived from American technology.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
GAF Announces a Loss Of $3.5 Million in Silver
description: The GAF Corporation reported yesterday an apparent shortage of silver valued at $3.5 million and said it might hurt its fourthquarter earnings.

title: Anthony Eden Is Dead at 79
description: LONDON, Jan. 14Sir Anthony Eden, who won renown as Britain's Foreign Secretary for his stand against fascism in the 1930's but whose career as Prime Minister was wrecked by the Suez invasion of 1956. died in his sleep today at his home in Wiltshire. He was 79 years old.

title: Officials Consider Child Pornography Hard to Prosecute
description: The Manhattan District Attorney, the United States Attorney and the deputy commissioner of the Police Department's Morals Division said in various ways yesterday the same thing: They are limited by existing laws in what they can do to discover, arrest and prosecute adults who make films of children for pornographic purposes.

title: Hills Urges 30Stock Competition
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Roderick M. Hills, In an address that had the ring of a valedictory, suggested tonight a radical experiment that might overcome obstacles to the creation of a competitive national market for securities trading.

title: 3,000 TOP PENTAGON JOBS ARE CUT BY RUMSFELD
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 14 (AP)Donald H. Rumsfeld, Secretary of Defense, ordered today a cut of more than 3,000 senior military and civilian jobs, including 43 generals and admirals. His action came less than a week before the Carter administration takes power.

title: Portugal's Elderly Organize Drive To Improve Starvation Pensions
description: LISBON, Jan. I4Man doesn't live on liberty alone; he's got to have bread, too.

title: Scott, Ronaldson Reach Open Court Tennis Final
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14Gene Scott, a New York amateur, reached the final round today in defense of his United States open court tennis championship. He defeated Tom Burke, a local professional, 36, 63, 61, 65, at the Raquet Club.

title: Poor Nations Handling Debt Load
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The Treasury reported to Congress today that there is no indication of widespread debt servicing difficulties' on the part of lessdeveloped countries that do not export oil despite their big buildup of debt in the last three years.

title: CURB ON COMPETITION LAID TO DENTAL GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The Federal Trade Commission accused the American Dental Association today of price fixing and other unlawful practices that it said prevented patients from benefiting from competition.

title: Kissinger Is Said to Take A Visiting Professorship At Georgetown University
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)Administration sources said today that Secrefary of State Henry A. Kissinger would become a visiting professor of diplomacy at Georgetown University here after he leaves office.

title: Issue and Debate
description: A drama is about to reach a climax in New York City's theater district involving two 45story apartment buildings, the city and Federal governments and a vocal and highpowered array of business, real estate, community and entertainmentindustry interests.

title: Lorna Forde Sets a 440Yard Record
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 14I know you're ready and up for it, Fred Thompson, the coach of the Atoms Track Club, told Lorna Forde before the 440yard run tonight. Go ahead and run.

title: Israeli Arms Industry Has Grown Fivefold Since '73
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 14Israel's arms industry, which has grown rapidly since the 1973 war, has increased fivefold its export of armaments to foreign countries, with total sales in 1976 of $320 million. Before the war, sales averaged about $60 million a year.

title: Peter Finch Is Dead on Coast at 60
description: Peter Finch, the British actor and star of the widely acclaimed recently released movie Network, died yesterday at a hospital in Los Angeles, after collapsing in the lobby of the Beverly Hills Hotel. He was 60 years old.

title: INTRUDERS BEAT TO DEATH 70YEAROLD BRONX MAN
description: A 70yearold Bronx man was beaten to death and his wife bound and gagged during an apparent robbery last night, in their apartment at 2122 Valentine, Avenue in the East Tremont section.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DOUBLEHEADER Dances enthusiasts calf see a program combining ballet and tap specialists this weekend as the Neubert Ballet Company and the Jerry Ames Tap Dance Company join the current Broadway Dance Festival at the midtown Bijou Theater, 209 West 45th Street (west of Broadway).

title: RIGHTS GROUPS DIFFER ON BELL'S SUITABILITY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 14 (AP)As Griffin B. Bell's confirmation hearing stretched into a fourth day, the Senate Judiciary Committee today heard more conflicting views from civil rights groups on whether Mr. Bell was fit to become Attorney General.

title: Blast in Building On E. 47th Street Hurts 5 Persons
description: An explosion, believed by the police to have been accidental, ripped through a sixstory office building under renovation for the Algerian Mission to the United Nations early yesterday afternoon, hurling shards of glass hundreds of feet along East 47th Street between Madison and Fifth Avenues and injuring five persons.

title: I.B.M .'s Profits Rise 14.5% as Its Sales Of Computers Gain
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday a 14.5 percent increase in earnings in the fourth quarter, paced by a strong showing outside the United States and an increase in outright sales of computers rather than rentals.

title: 3 Appeals in Gilmore Case Denied
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 14Federal District Judge Aldon J. Anderson denied tonight a restraining order that would have stayed the Monday morning execution of Gary Mark Gilmore.

title: Cancer Group Opens Drive To End Tobacco Subsidy
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 14 (AP)A fiveyear program aimed at ending Government subsidies to tobacco growers and extending the regulation of sales and promotion of cigarettes was announced today by the American Cancer Society.

title: Personal Investing
It Was One of Those Loud Parties and So Very Russian
6Inch Snowfall Is Accompanied By Respite From Extreme Cold
description: Snow, about six inches of it, swept into the New York metropolitan area yesterday, bringing hazardous driving conditions but also at least a temporary respite from almost a week of biting icy winds and mercury readings in the teens or lower.

title: New World Slump Feared
description: Many international financial experts fear that the industrial countries may he sliding into a new slump. Page 29.

title: Emergency Sales of Gas To 2 Pipelines Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)  The Federal Power Commission unanimously approved today emergency sales of natural gas by the Houston Pipe Line Company to two pipelines serving states in the East and on the Gulf Coast where supplies are short.

title: P.B.A. and City Reach a Tentative Pact on Schedules
description: Toplevel negotiating committees for New York City and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association have worked out a tentative formula on work schedules that they hope will pave the way for settlement on a new contract.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday. Prime rate 66.

title: First Woman Deputy Mayor
description: A black woman who worked as a welder on a battleship during World War II and who, studying at night, earned a degree in economics from Brooklyn College in 1963, became New York City's first woman Deputy Mayor yesterday.

title: Teacher Burned in Class
description: CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Jan. (UPI)A grade school teacher was burned critically yesterday while showing her secondgrade pupils how to cook Japanese food on a hibachi. The police said that the teacher, Patricia Stumbaugh, 44 years old, was burned over 30 per cent of her body when she tried to start a fire by dousing paper with a cleaning fluid.

title: General Van Deusen Is Dead at Age of 88
description: Maj. Gen. George L. Van Deusen, who was the commanding officer of the Signal Corps Replacement Training Center at. Fort Monmouth, N. J., during World War II, died Wednesday at Patterson Army Hospital, Fort Monmouth. He was 88 years old and lived in Monmouth Beach, N. J.

title: Dr. C. H. Hochman, Bronx Pathologiit, Dies at Age of 83
description: Dr. Charles H. Hochman, a pathologist and former deputy chief medical examiner in charge of the Bronx, died Thursday at Union Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 65 West 246th Street, the Bronx.

title: U.S. WILL FILE NO CHARGES IN MAIL OPENINGS BY C.I.A.
Episcopalians Opposed To Women Priests Unite
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 14 (UPI)A new church body made up of dissident Episcopalians opposed to women priests has been formed to continue the church as we knew it, an Episcopal traditionalist leader announced today.

title: Books of The Times
description: In Jefferson's Nephews, Boynton Merrill Jr. takes an elaborate historical journey to reach the causes of a single eventthe murder of a slave in Kentucky in 1811 by two nephews of Thomas Jefferson. The kinship between the murderers Lilburne and Isham Lewis, and the third President, a man who was the epitome of reason, science and democratic thought, made the murder noteworthy, but it was only sketchily reported at the time and has come down to us muffled in tendentious accounts and legends constructed well after the fact.

title: Letters: On Social Security
description: Washington's Invitation to Live in Sin

title: Syrian Sees Stalling in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 14The Syrian representative to the Arab peace commission for Lebanon was reported today to have demanded that there be no more stalling in the surrender of heavy weapons by the rival Lebanese factions and Palestinian groups.

title: Abu Daoud's Release Protested With Calls for Boycott of France
description: The protest over France's release of the Palestinian suspected of planning the attack on Israelis at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich widened yesterday with calls for boycotts of French goods and travel to France, angry statements by members of Congress and Jewish leaders and the withdrawal of pledges to a new French cultural center.

title: Small Increases Shown For Dollar and Sterling
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 14 (UPI)The dollar and sterling closed higher on European money markets today, ending the week with small overall gains against all continental currencies.

title: Consumer Confidence Falls
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 14 (Reuters) Consumer confidence declined in the final months of last year, a University of Michigan survey said today.

title: Transit Cuts Approved by M.T.A.
description: Most of the controversial cutbacks in city. transit service, proposed last month to meet a $30 million budget shortage were summarily approved yesterday by the, Metropolitan Transportation Authority at its first open meeting under the state's new sunshine law.

title: Notes on People
Brezhnev Warns That Arms Race Threatens International Peace
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 14 (AP)The Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, warned today that the easing of international tensions is endangered by the continuing, the evergrowing arms race.

title: A Fast Run Up to New York for a Carter InLaw's Inauguration Wardrobe
SEA POLLUTION CITED IN $250 MILLION SUIT
description: CAMDEN, Jan. 14A $250 million classaction suit was filed today in Federal Court on behalf of clammers, lobstermen and fishermen, charging New Jersey, New York and Federal environmental officials with negligence for permitting the alleged pollution of the Atlantic Ocean and the resultant destruction of marine life over a wide area last summer.

title: Tenants Appall Pension Fund
description: The New York City Employees Retirement System has invested in an apartment building that allegedly houses massage parlors and promotes prostitution, the trustees of the retirement system said yesterday.

title: FORD TO ASK PAY RISE FOR MAJOR OFFICIALS, CONGRESS CHIEFS SAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14Congressional leaders said today that President Ford told them at a morning meeting that he would propose substantial pay increases for the Vice President, members of Congress, Cabinet members, Federal judges and other high Government officials.

title: FACTIONALISM HURTS OPPOSITION IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 7The New Democratic Party, South Korea's sole remaining opposition political force, appears to be on the brink of renewed factional fighting that could further divide it.

title: MARSHALL CLARIFIES VIEWS ON ECONOMICS
Impector Clousseau Wins Florida Yachting Race
description: KEY WEST, Fla. Jan. 14 (UPI)Winds that provided speeds of more than 10 knots brought a fleet of 56 International Offshore Rules racing yachts zipping into Key West eight hours ahead of schedule today in the second annual Fort LauderdaleKey West race, won on handicaps by the smallest boats in the class.

title: New York City Gets 17 More Days To Evolve a Plan to Redeem Notes
description: The State Court of Appeals in Albany yesterday gave New York City an extra 17 days to come up with a plant to redeem nearly $1 billion in outstanding shortterm notes, but it emphasized that payment of the notes must be prompt.

title: Chicago, Under Pressure, To Hire Minority Firemen
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP)The City of Chicago, spurred by a Federal discrimination suit, agreed yesterday to hire more than 200 firemen from minority groups.

title: Dance: Chromatic Luise Wykell
description: The Riverside Theater Dance Festival, directed by James Van Abbema, has offered a consistent level of interest at the Riverside Church Theater this autumn and winter.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Scanlon Beats Nastase
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 14 (AP)Bill Scanlon, the National Collegiate tennis' champion, handed secondseeded Ilie Nastase a surprising 76, 64 defeat today in a World Championship Tennis tournament. The triumph moved the 20yearold Scanlon, a twotime allAmerica from Trinity University, into the semifinal round.

title: RALPH GLASSCOCK
description: CLINTON, Mo., Jan. 14 (AP)Ralph Glasscock, 48 years old, of Clinton, Mo., president of Optimist International in 197475 and a founder of the Optimist International Foundation, died at a hospital here after suffering a heart attack.

title: Lance Predicts Bigger '77 Deficit
CLAM BEDS TO REOPEN OFF SOUTH SHORE OF L.I.
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation Commissioner, announced pening of 2,115 acres of clamfishing beds on Long Island's South Shore and the closing of 1,180 acres nearby because of growing pollution from nearby housing developments.

title: I.R.S. Abandons Proposal To Tax Free Tuitions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service said today that it was withdrawing a proposal that would have required college and other school employees to pay taxes on free tuition granted their dependents. The move ended a broad attempt by the agency to expand taxation of fringe benefits for college employees and workers in other areas.

title: Palestinian Expects Israeli Threats
description: PARIS, Jan. 14 (AP)The Palestinian leader who was freed by France after his arrest as the suspected organizer of the attack on Israelis at the 1972 Olympics in Munich said today in Algiers that he would soon return to fighting Israelis and Zionists.

title: FORD TO ASK PAY RISE FOR MAJOR OFFICIAIS, CONGRESS CHIEFS SAY
Approval of U.F.T. Pact Withheld
Blazers Spoil Star's Return, 107 to 92; Trail Blazers Spoil Return Of Cowens
Music: Creative George Crumb
description: The power of George Crumb's music to transfix an audience, a power as real as it is ultimately inexplicable, has rarely been more evident than it was in a performance of his Music for a Summer Evening on Thursday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A.

title: Byrne and Shapp Spar in a Battle of Delaware
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14What did the Governor of New Jersey say to the Governor of Pennsylvania that, broke up a Senate subcommittee hearing this afternoon?

title: WILLIAM GARNET HOLLY, A RETIRED CHEMIST, 77
description: William Garnet Holly, a retired chemist, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 25 West 132d Street.

title: 3 Hughes Associates Deny Guilt in Air West Case
The Court's Purpose  and Effect
description: In the early 1960's, they used to tell the story in the South about an old black man who tried to register vote and was given, for his literacy test, a Chinese newspaper. What did it say? That's easy, he replied. It says, No black folks are going to vote here this year.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, Jan. 14, 1977

title: U.S. GIVES NEW YORK $50 MILLION TO SPEED BIG SEWAGE PROJECTS
description: A grant of almost $50 million and an agreement to provide an additional $225 million in Federal funds for New York City were announced yesterday to expedite the construction of huge sewagetreatment facilities in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Staten Island.

title: North Shore Acres: Trouble With the Neighbors
description: GLEN HEAD, L. I.The people of North Shore Acres may see each other at parties or on walks on a nice afternoon, but they are not used to getting together over legal matters on a chilly night in January.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Yamani Says Saudis Can Raise Output of Oil by 50%
description: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 14 This country's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said yesterday that Saudi Arabia was capable of producing 14 million barrels of crude oil a dayan increase of more than 50 percent over the present, vast production of lowpriced Saudi crudes.

title: New Copyright Law Celebrated At Award Ceremony in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14In a ceremony marking passage of a major revision of the archaic copyright law of 1909, and in a private meeting with the Librarian of Congress, representatives of the two major professional writers organizations in the United Statesthe Authors Guild and the Dramatists Guildprojected programs to provide for greater economic security and recognition for creators of literary and dramatic works in the legislative and administrative halls of Washington.

title: UPI Accuses Police in Leningrad Of Tampering With Reporter's Car
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 14 (Reuters)United Press International filed a protest with the press department of the Soviet Foreign Ministry today over an incident involving its correspondent in Leningrad, the wire service's Moscow bureau said.

title: C.A.B. Grants Airlines A Fare Increase of 2%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)The Civil Aeronautics Board today granted a 2 percent fare increase to the nation's domestic airlines.

title: Article 1  No Title
Public Broadcasting Corporation Reverses Some Disputed Moves
description: In a series of actions designed to ease tensions between the two administrative organizations of public television, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting has reversed several of its recent program decisions that have been bitterly disputed by the Public Broadcasting Service and its member stations.

title: Lietzke Leads Tucson Golf By Shot at 136
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 14  Gary McCord has a couple of new problems this seasonhow long he can make it on the pro golf tour after losing his sponsor, and how long officials of the PGA Tour will permit him to keep that bushy Mustache. Both answers are matters of conjecture.

title: ExBanker and a Policeman Among 66 Male Volunteers at Hospital
description: PASSAIC  A former banker, an accountant, a probation officer, a businessman and a policeman are among an unusual group of male volunteers at the Beth Israel Hospital here.

title: Knicks Playoff Chance: Different Set of Tactics
description: With 44 games to play, and a 1919 wonlost record, what are the legitimate expectations of the New York Knicks and their followers?

title: A Lucky 6, and Fashion Star Is Born
description: This is just another Seventh Avenue success story. Once again, at the wave of a White House wand, fashion unknown has become a star.

title: Suspect Held in S. I. Murder of Woman, 73,
description: A 28yearold man was arrested yesterday by the Housing Authority police and charged with the murder last month of the 73yearold mother of a New York City policeman.

title: Michigan School Offers Baths
description: ONTONAGON, Mich., Jan. 15 (AP)  People in Ontonagon's school district can take free showers at the high school starting next week. Many wells in the area are dry because of a lack of rain last summer and fall, and any water in them now is frozen. Cliff Koivisto, the principal at the Ontonagon Area High school, said Thursday that the 6,000 residents of the district could make appointments to use the showers after school hours and on weekends.

title: Abu Daoud Declares Willingness to Face A Court on Killings
description: PARIS, Jan. 15 (AP)Abu Daoud, the Palestinian guerrilla recently arrested here and then freed amid controversy, said today he would be willing to testify before a West German court that he was innocent in the 1972 massacre of Israelis at the Munich Olympics. But he said his safety must be guaranteed and arrangements must be made through the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Elisabeth Ballin Wed. To John A. Hobden
description: Elisabeth Mary Bailin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Bailin of New York, was married yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church to John Andrew Hobden, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Hobden of Geneva. Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan, retired Bishop of New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Law Clerks: Paradise Gained
description: Dwight Cramer, a second year Columbia Law School student, recently telephoned the huge Wall Street law firm of Cravath, Swathe & Moore and accepted its offer of a summer job. Then he called John Connally's law firm, Vinson, Elkins, Searls, Connally & Smith, and accepted its offer of a Job in Houston. Mr. Cramer, a Kent scholar and a member of the Columbia Law Review, has decided to split his summereight weeks in New York and eight weeks in Texas.

title: CONGRESS EXPENSES SHOW A SHARP RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15The cost of Congress and its supporting services has more than trebled in the last decade, from a budget of $276.8 million in 1968 to $943.5 million this year, and Congressional experts expect a supplemental appropriation to increase the current cost to nearly $1 billion.

title: Lietzke Leads by 2 Strokes at Tucson
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 15Youth will be served, as the saying goes, but the graybeards are not going to do it with any enthusiasm.

title: Board of Estimate and Council Near Choice for New Budget job
description: The twomonth search for a $50,000a year budget expert to lead NeW York City's new Legislative. Office of Budget Review continues, but the field of applicants is to be narrowed shortly.

title: Parcel Service Gets Rate Rise
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Washington Still Can't Decipher Carter
description: WASHINGTONIcecovered snow crunched noisily beneath the feet of pedestrians on Pennsylvania Avenue. In McPherson Square, a young woman struggled to lift a snowman's torso. On Capitol Hill, a few citizens ventured crosscountry on skis.

title: Fire Destroys Theater
description: The Towne theater in Wrightstovvn, N.J., largely patronized by military personnel from Fort Dix and the McGuire Air Force base, was destroyed by a fire. Authorities said that firemen from Wrightstown and six other Burlington and Ocean County towns had fought the blaze for one hour before bringing it under control.

title: There Are Many Choices
description: While you're shopping the boating market, one thing's certain, you'll have a choice. Boating Magazine's annual industry survey shows there are 3,357 different stock models to choose from in 1977, ranging from a 6foot inflatable to an 81foot sailboat and 90 foot cruiser. And you'll have a choice in price, too, with sales tags ranging from $25 to $711,300.

title: One DivorceTwo Houses
description: The housing industry, which has been in a sorry state for the last two years, is due for a strong recovery, according to a recent study. Divorce is helping.

title: Matthew Zale Fiance Of Thora K. O'Keefe
description: Mrs. Robert G. O'Keefe of Wyckoff and Loveladies, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Thora Kathryn. O'Keefe, to Matthew Ivan Zale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Zale of West Hempstead, L.I.

title: Boat Show Begins Run Of 9 Days at Coliseum
description: The soft snow turned to slush and melted, but not fast enough for people to dig out and arrive early at the National Boat Show, which opened yesterday at the Coliseum for a nineday stand. Instead of the traditional lines of people waiting for the doors to open, perhaps 50 queued up for a brief wait.

title: TAXEXEMPT CHURCH TARGET OF CRITICISM
description: The State Board of Equalization and Assessment has threatened to take legal action against the assessor In the Ulster County Town of Hardenburgh if he goes ahead with plans to grant more than half the taxpayers exemptions on their property taxes because they have been ordained ministers.

title: The rebirth of Eldridge Cleaver; The old Cleaver wanted to overthrow the American nightmare. The new Cleaver is promoting the American dream. Is he a convert or an opportunist?; Cleaver
description: Hi there! Welcome home to America, says the blond stewardess as she pours Eldridge Cleaver another complimentary plastic cup of champagne. A young black woman a few seats away passes him a note wishing him well. Two young men walk by him twice, looking him over but saying nothing.

title: America in Our Time
description: Godfrey Hodgson has been among us so long as a student and then correspondent for the Sunday Times and the Sunday Observer that it seems not much more appropriate to treat of him as a British journalist than it would be to think of Secretary Kissinger as an exchange student from a German gymnasium.

title: Some Choice Recipes for Fish From a North Carolina Guide
description: Outer Banks surf, guide Ken Lauer of Buxton, N.C. has ample opportunity to get fresh fish. Occasionally he cooks for special guests and customers. His way with deepfried fish is a bit unusual, but it sends everyone back for seconds. Lauer prefers to use weakfish, either of the species, for this, but the recipe works very well with any fish large enough to filet.

title: Housing Agency Builds a Reputation
description: WHEN the New Jersey Housing Finance Agency offered $72 million worth of bonds to New York and New Jersey banks and other institutions this month, it brought its total commitment to more than $500 million.

title: Blank Lottery Ticket Draws Fraud Charge
description: Blank Lottery Ticket Draws Fraud Charge

title: Religion's Difficult Subject
description: Several recent events serve as reminders of the fact that in most religious groups, the issues of clerical homosexuality and celibacy have yet to be resolved.

title: A Journey For Hussein
description: King Hussein of Jordan has traveled to Egypt to confer with President Anwar elSadat on establishing a united front to present when and if Arab countries sit down with Israelis at peace negotiations in Geneva. But, from the communiqu issued following the meeting, it is clear that achieving that unity will be difficult.

title: Tappan and Its Sister Have Long Memories
LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Hams Are Good Buddies

title: New York Area Residents Slush Through Worst Snow in 2 Years
description: Lured outdoors by a dazzling sun and for this frigid wintercomparatively moderate temperatures, New Yorkers and their suburban neighbors yesterday dug out of the season's biggest snowstorm with surprising ease.

title: BEAME IS REVAMPING THE REAL ESTATE UNIT
description: New York City's muchcriticized Real Estate Department, the Subject of five separate investigations, is undergoing the start of what the Beame administration says will be a reorganization and revamping of the entire department.

title: Hughes Rides Herd On Lawyer Ethics
description: EVER since he took over the State Supreme Court in 1973, Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes has sought to assure the public that improper or unethical conduct by New Jersey lawyers would not go unexposed or unpunished.

title: The Politician and the Courts
description: New York City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. has been accused of a crime again, this time in a grand jury indictment in Queens, and an immediate question is whether his colorful political career can survive. The Queens Democrat has been free for only a month: he served 55 days in a Federal detention center last fall on a guilty plea to a taxevasion charge. This time, Mr. Troy was accused in State Supreme Court of having stolen $30,000 from two elderly sisters whose estates he had been handling as a lawyer. Because the new charges are felonies, he will, if convicted, automatically lose his Council seat, a penalty he escaped in the tax case because that charge, a felony in the Federal courts, is a misdemeanor under state law.

title: Once again, with feeling
description: To write convincingly about the Vietnam war, its effect on Vietnam and its effect on the United States, to move the reader, to instruct him to break through the carapace of familiarity and tired indifferencethe task former New York Times Vietnam reporter Gloria Emerson set herself, when she set out to write this book, was enormous. She has, however, a

title: Music: Osipov's Balalaikas Hum
description: The remarkable thing about the way the Osipov Balalaika Orchestra of Moscow plays Glinka's Russian and Ludmilla Overture is that it sounds so much like the conventional symphonic version.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Judge Frank J. McGarr, at the end of testimony in Charles O. Finley's suit against Commissioner Bowie Kuhn: It's been a very interesting trial. I've enjoyed it. It's drawn the biggest crowd this courtroom has ever seen. If we had either tickets or the popcorn concession. we could have cleaned up.

title: Article 1  No Title
Florida's Rivers Are Often Overlooked
description: Like moths to the flame, boating enthusiasts are attracted to Florida's coastal perimeter, its beaches, procession of bays, the close presence of the Gulf Stream and the string of keys on its coastal charm bracelet.

title: The Host Who Gets No Pie
description: THE latest squabble in the Republican battle for the County Executive nomination over who is to be Nassau's Acting County Attorney is the best indication so far that no matter who is finally chosen as the G.O.P. nominee, the taxpayer will suffer.

title: Productivity Drive in Vietnam
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 15 (Reuters)The second session of Vietnam's Sixth National Assembly ended in Hanoi today with e call to the people to step up production, the Vietnam. News Agency reported. In a report monitored here, the agency said that the assembly adopted a resolution calling for an increase of 18 percent in the gross national product and 16 percent in national income during 1977.

title: So What's Wrong With Learning?
description: LEARNING is a dirty word. Never, under any circumstances, may we let our children know that they are learning. Never may we ask them to learn something.

title: Article 4  No Title
Dance: Moroshita at Swanilda
description: We accept, very easily, Japanese cameras, television sets and cars. Soon, and happily enough, we are going to be accepting, welcoming and loving, Japanese ballerinas. Last summer Yoko Morishita danced Aurora in The Sleeping Beauty and OdetteOdile in Swan Lake. Friday night at the 55th Street City Center Theater, she made her debut as swanilda with the American Ballet Theater in Enrique Martinez's staging of Coppelia. It was all sugar, spice and expertise.

title: BRZEZINSKI REVAMPS SECURITY UNIT STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  Zbigniew Brzezinski has reorganized the White House's National Security Council staff to eliminate most signs of Henry A. Kissinger. He has hired a team of experts with the accent on youth and Ph.D's. And he has gone out of his way to promise that unlike his predecessors he will cooperate and not clash with the Secretaries of State and Defense.

title: Divided shepherds of a restive flock
Spy Case Clouds a Russian Holiday
Operator of a GetRich Scheme Given 5 Years for Mail Fraud
description: Ernest Tucker of Los Angeles was sentenced to five years In prison Friday in New York City for masterminding a fraudulent getrichquick scheme that involved the sale of mink bow ties, cufflinks and flowers.

title: And Now, Pocket TV
description: Of all American households that are wired for electricity, 99.9 percent have at least a black and white television setmore than have a toaster, washer or coffeepot. Whether television certifies reality or merely serves as an escape from reality, reality is certainly mediated by television for many millions of Americans.

title: In Bermuda, Winds of Pleasure Nearly Unfailing
description: HAMILTON, BermudaThe Bahamas have more places to sail and the Virgin Islands have more boats to sail in. So why do so many people come to Bermuda for pleasure boating?

title: G.O.P. Has Picked Brock
description: The Republicans have chosen former Senator Bill Brock of Tennessee as their national committee chairman, and in the process have managed to avoid a contest between moderates and conservatives for control of the party.

title: The American Connection
Patrick Scatuorchio And Jean N. Gallatin Wed in Manhasset
description: Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L. I., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Jean Nissen Gallatin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Gerry Gallatin of Stuart, Fla., and Manhasset, to Patrick Scatuorchio, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominic N. Scatuorchio of Spring Lake, N. J.

title: Celebrating a Quiet Tradition
description: LOCUST VALLEY JEFF PILL remembers feeling alone in a crowd. As long as there was movement and sound he was comfortable with himself, but at Thursday Meeting, when his school would sit quietly for half an hour, he felt the gaping selfawareness that many teenagers experience.

title: Deaf Athlete's Plight: Little Hope After High School
description: Danny Sellick and Craig Brown are outstanding high school athletes, but because they are deaf they can count the colleges that recruited using only their thumbs.

title: Owning Offshore Racing Yacht an Expensive, Dream Come True
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  As the owner of a 49foot offshore racing sailboat in the big leagues of this expensive sport, I am living a real cametrue, wideawake dream. I have to pinch not only myself but pennies to believe it.

title: Famous Tears
The EverWidening Oil Slick
description: EVERY year, hundreds of tankers unload petroleum products at either Port Newark or Delaware River oil depots. The recent rash of tanker mishaps raises a serious question: Just how safe are the tankers that dock in New Jersey's. harbors?

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: The Kissinger Legacy
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Men become myths, not by what they know, or even by what they achieve, but by the tasks they set for themselves, Henry A. Kissinger wrote almost a quarter of a century ago, at the end of his study of the Congress of Vienna.

title: Hartford Prison Quiet
description: Connecticut State Prison in Hartford was quiet following a night in Which three inmates who had held a hostage were overcome by a dozen guards armed with clubs. Two of the inmates, one awaiting trial on a murder charge, were transferred to other prisons. The third was taken to a hospital for treatment of head injuries.

title: $241,455 WILL, BE.SAVED ON CITY'S SCHOOL TESTS
Economic Indicators Needed Overseas
description: Each month the latest figure on the United States index of leading economic indicators is headline news. Usually described as the Government's foreshadowing statistic because of its tendency to anticipate changes in economic trends a few months ahead of such measures of performance as the gross national product, industrial production or employment, the index achieved great prominence during the recent election campaign. It declined in August and September after rising for 17 straight months. Thus it dramatized the recent slowdown in economic growth.

title: Gucci's Imitators
description: In an acquisitive society, it is logical that acquisitions of value and quality be recognized so they can be admired, and therein probably lies the importance of the internationallyrecognized doubleG monogram of Giulio Gucci.

title: Great Rubbernecking in Great Neck
description: THERE is usually a charm about stores along a town street that eludes me in shopping centers. Shopping centers are probably marvelous if you are a shopper, but for a stroller they lack the flavor, no matter how ornately designed, that you get sauntering down a street.

title: The Israelis of New York
Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Great Dane Club of America match. Green Chimneys School, Putnam Lake Road, Brewster, N.Y.; entries from 10 A.M.; judging noon.

title: Lydia DeBarbieri Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James E. DeBarbieri of Pearl River, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lydia Madeline DeBarbieri, to Arthur H. Pomerantz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Pomerantz of Wethersfield, Conn. The prospective bride is a senior at Marymount College. Her fianc graduated summa cum laude from Yale University. He is a biomedical fellow of Rockefeller University.

title: BRIDGE
description: The laws of bridge, and the application of them, are perhaps more complex than those of any other game or sport. In serious play the area that causes most problems, both to players and administrators, is the hesitation in bidding which might be thought to convey information to partner. If partner's actions appear to have been influenced by the hesitation and the opponents can demonstrate that they have been damaged in consequence, the score may be adjusted by a director or a committee.

title: Anniversaries
description: Eckstein

title: King Relays Reflect Cuts, In P.S.A.L.
description: The Public Schools Athletic League honored the memory of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. yesterday, his birthday, by staging the sixth annual King relays at the 102d Engineers Armory, but the severe budget cuts in the New York school system continue to prove a hardship for its track and field activities.

title: Hiding out in America
description: Survivors of Nazi death camps have been called collectors of justice. They seek something beyond economic or social restitutionsomething closer to acknowledgment of crimes committed against them and punishment of those responsible, In order to reestablish at least the semblance of a moral universe. Their feelings can of course include hunger for revenge, but I think the more fundamental impulse Is toward a reconstruction of meaning, toward a sense of justice.

title: The Era of Kissinger
description: Henry Kissinger has not been President of the United States for the past eight years; it only seemed that way much of the time. From the White House and then from the sumptuous top of the Department of State, this immigrant professor projected a mind of wit, style and power that commanded the attention of the world. Richard Nixon, who launched, led and finally leaned on him, has been destroyed. Gerald Ford, who could not do without him, has been defeated. And so the remarkable, tormented years that end this week must also be seen as the end of the era of Kissinger.

title: STEPHEN R. WATSON DIES
description: Stephen R. Watson, an associate of the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, died Friday night of cancer at his home at 445 East 80th Street in Manhattan. He was 31 years old.

title: Coping With a Snowfall
description: THERE are various ways of deal ing with snow I have found, since moving to the New Jersey suburbs from the New York urbs. Actually, in. New Yorkparticularly if you happen to live in an apartment, as we did for awhileit's not so much a question of having to deal with snow as it is not dealing with it.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Trees bear the brunt of most ice storms. Certain varieties are more susceptible to damage than others. Black locust is often the hardest hit because its wood is brittle and older trees are often weakened by the ravages of locust borer. Other trees that are fast growing are usually damaged particularly poplars, willows, elms and maples. The sturdier trees are the mighty oaks, sycamores and beech.

title: Reactors: He Votes Aye
description: IN Debate, 1977: Is Nuclear Power Safe? (Jan. 2) Martin Waldron made extensive reference to a study made by. Mr. P. R. Davis of Idaho. In that study, after a very simplified analysis, Mr. Davis concludes, in a preliminary draft report, that Oyster Creek has a greater probability of a core meltdown than the reference boilingwater reactor studied in great detail by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: 475 Boats On Display At Coliseum Event
Socialism Goes On in Sweden
description: The defeat last fall of the Swedish Social Democratic Party. after 44 years in power, clearly did not represent a national decision to change the welfare state at home or the Socialists foreign policies.

title: Rhodesia Peace Mission Hits New Difficulties
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, Jan. 15 (Reuters)The faltering Rhodesia peace mission of the British negotiator Ivor Richard hit new difficulties today when a meeting with black nationalists from the country was postponed indefinitely.

title: APPROVAL IS RESTORED TO ANCORA, N.J., HOSPITAL
description: WINSLOW TOWNSHIP, N. J. (AP) Downgraded in 1976. Ancora State Psychiatric Hospital here has been given high marks by a survey team from the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals.

title: FullCruising Boats Are Gaining in Favor
description: Each year, among visitors who have seen many National Boat shows in the past, there is a tendency, at the first glimpse of the boats and crowds in the Coliseum, to say that it's just another boat show and that they all seem to be alike.

title: LanceRun Bank Criticized in 74 In Federal Study
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15A bank controlled by Bert Lance, who has been named by Presidentelect Carter to head the Office of Management and Budget, was criticized by bank examiners two years ago for what they called a perrnissive policy on overdrafts, according to people familiar with the examiners report.

title: Rockefeller Says No More
description: In a statement that put a period to Nelson Rockefeller's Presidential ambitions but not necessarily to his political influence among New York State Republicans, the Vice President said last week he had come to the conclusion that ...after 36 years, now is the time to really return to private life. On Jan. 20, he said, he will be leaving not only public office but active political involvement.

title: EUGENE DUKLAUER DIES
description: Eugene Duklauer, a retired plumbing contractor who installed the plumbing in some of New York City's most prominent buildings, died Friday at a nursing home in Purchase, N.Y. He was 88 years old and a resident of Purchase.

title: Ten Trip Tips
description: 1. If you want social life, sit in the back. The rest room and smoking area make this a meeting place.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: There's some pretty interesting stuff here, even though it may not exactly send you. I mean, it is a museum, and most kids don't go to a museum unless their parents drag them there. But in this one, the whole show on part of the second floor is made up of things done by children, and since there's so much to see, I guess you could say everyone is bound to find something to like.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Energyrelated stocks boomed last week, but the broad market averages moved downward as 1977 continued to prove a disappointment to Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 10.97 points to finish at 972.16. This followed a decline of 21 points in the initial trading week of the new year.

title: Lawyer Fiance Of Miss Nichols
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl Wheeler Nichols, of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine McClave Nichols, to Esteban Angel Ferrer 3d, son of Mr. Ferrer Jr. of Miami and the late Ofelia Ferrer.

title: Recital: Gidon Kremer, Violinist
description: Gidon Kremer arrived in Fisher Hall for his New York debut recital Friday night armed with an impressive sheaf of credentials. Not only has he won a number of prestigious European competitions, including first prize in the 1970 Tchaikovsky Contest, but Herbert Karajan, no less, has flatly proclaimed the 29yearold Soviet musician.as the ereatest violinist in the world.

title: He Was Once The Most Idolized Opera Composer
description: When the Metropolitan Opera stages its new production of Meyerbeer's Le Prophete on Tuesday, it will be reviving an opera that has been out of its repertory for about 50 years. It also will be focusing attention on a composer who was by far the most popular, most imitated, idolized concocter of operas through most of the century after 1831, when he sprang Robert le Diable on the world. There had been nothing like the Meyerbeer craze, not even the Rossini craze in his day, and Heinrich Heine observed that Meyerbeer's mother was the second woman in history to see her son accepted divine.

title: Dr. E. Joseph L. Wasserman Is Fiance of Dr. Carla R. Ross
description: The engagement of Dr. Carla Ruth Ross to Dr. E. Joseph L. Wasserman has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Ross of Hampstead, Quebec, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Maksymilian Wasserman of Brooklyn, where his father is a physician.

title: Red Smith
The Other Options for Catterson
description: I DON'T feel that I've been shot out of the saddle and that I've got to start licking my wounds, said James M. Catterson Jr. I came in there from a good law practice and I knew I was only going to be there for a certain length of time. It just happened to be a little shorter than I thought.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: Can a conservative 60yearold investor, who wouldn't dream of selling stocks short, become a. successful trader in stock options, seven. to the extent of selling naked options? Here's the report of my first two years in this fascinating business.

title: Court Insists Intent Be Shown As Test of Bias
description: The United States Supreme Court has reaffirmed, in a case involving suburban zoning, a principle that could restrict the Federal judiciary's ability to provide remedies for segregation in housing and schools. The principle is that an official policy having a disproportionately adverse effect on one racial group is not unconstitutional unless discrimination can be shown to be the motive for the policy.

title: NO SITE FOR SPENT FUEL UNTIL 1985, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 15 (UPI)The Federal Government hopes to have a place to dispose of nuclear wastes by 1985, but that will be a very difficult schedule to meet, an official of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission testified Tuesday at a hearing by the Oregon Energy Facility Siting Council.

title: The Professor and the C.I.A.
description: A Brooklyn College professor of political science faces possible dismissal because his departmental colleagues have charged him with , covert intelligencegathering for the Central Intelligence Agency, an activity that they say violates academic standards and casts doubt on the professor's credibility as a teacher, scholar and professional colleague. Prof. Michael Selzer has denied the charge of secret spying and said, This is McCarthyism of the left. Professor Selzer's colleagues said in explanation that a faculty member who secretly gathers intelligence for the Government impedes the free flow of ideas and information among colleagues, and that Such behavior also violates the faculty member's responsibility to students, who must not in doubt about their teachers commitment to scholarship and to free and open discussion in the classroom.

title: Article 15  No Title
description: SHOP TALK

title: ART VIEW
description: There can rarely have been two figures in the history of American culture more dissimilar in temperament and more distant in personal experience and esthetic conviction than Henry James and Rube Goldberg. Yet it was Henry Jamesor at least a particular passage in one of his essaysthat came to mind the other day as I was looking at and laughing over the Rube Goldberg show the Truman Gallery, 38 East 57th Street (through Feb. 5). In his essay on Daumier, written in 1890, James speaks of the irony, skepticism, pessimism that flower most aggressively in the art of the newspaper caricature. He doubted that American journalism, although even then flourishing, as James said, on a humorous and irreverent basis, was ready for a graphic art that vigorously satirized American manners and morals He was wrong, of course. There was soon to be a deluge of such satire in the American papers of the next generation, and the young Rube Goldberg would be an important contributor to it, but that is another matter.

title: Chacun  Son Goo
description: THIS Tuesday, the 18 Suffolk County legislators must decide whether to override my veto of a resolution they passed late last month establishing a committee whose ostensible purpose is to review offshore oil drilling as it relates to the Island.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Why should the I United States shell out up to $1 billion to help solve the seemingly esoteric problem of Britain's sterling balances? Does the problem make any difference to Americans?

title: Jule Styne Gets Into The Act (His Own); Styne Gets Into the Act
Desks Without Chairs Fill Hartford Capitol
INVESTING
description: When the average, company announces a stock split, the shareowners let loose a few hurrahs and, generally, the price of the stock goes up. But when the International Business Machines Corporation splits its stock, staid men on Wall Street turn cartwheels. The effect throughout the investment world is like an electrical charge.

title: Market for Sailboats Keeps Expanding
description: The sailboat fleet at the National Boat Show has increased over that of the last few yearsand at least 13 new craft are on displayin all sizes and price ranges.

title: My college essay...
description: This year for the first time many American colleges and universities are accepting a standardized application form and a common essay. The applicant is asked to describe in detail some special interest . . . or anything else you would like us to know about you . . . and to feel free to submit . . . samples of writing, or other examples of your creative work. Several contributors to this Magazinethough admittedly somewhat beyond college agewere asked to compose their own personal statements.

title: The Dissidents Of East Europe
THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE multifaceted package of tax and spending proposals put forth by Presidentelect Jimmy Carter a week ago to stimulate the economy and create additional jobs has encountered a rather mixed reception so far.

title: BowersWolf Duo Plays Flute, Harpsichord.
description: The formal New York debut of the BowersWolf Duo Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall was not very successful. The reason was, quite simply, the Bowers half of the duo.

title: Legislative Hearings Scheduled This Week
description: The following public hearings will be held in the New York metropolitan area by state legislative committees this week:

title: At 84, She's Still Busy at Law
description: NEWARK

title: David Rockefeller Confers in Peking
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 15 (Reuters)Deputy Premier Li Hsiennien of China had talks with David Rockefeller, president of Chase Manhattan Bank, in Peking today, the official Chinese press agency reported. Thomas Gates Jr., chief of the American liaison office in Peking, Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China and other officials were also present at the talks, it added, but no details were given.

title: STAMPS
description: It is, of course, coincidence that there should be a spate of new issues devoted to archaeology and artifacts just at the time when the news is full of great new finds in Italy and the Middle East. Nevertheless it underlines once again the neverending timeliness and timelessness of philately.

title: MILITANTS IN ULSTER EXTENDING CONTROL
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 15 (AP)Security chiefs in Northern Ireland believe that terrorist organizations are taking over legitimate businesses in Belfast and now exert strong Mafialike influence in housing, transportation and bars.

title: The Problem With Amateur Sports in the U.S.: Athletes Rights Are Overlooked
description: Last September, Tim Guelker competed on the official United States team in a World Cup junior soccer tournament in Puerto Rico. Upon returning home, the 17yearold Guelker was declared ineligible for his senior year of soccer at St. Louis University High School because of his participation in the international event.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: ART

title: Nancy O. Scranton Plans Fall Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. William M. Scranton of Keene, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Orne Scranton, to Don Jeffrey Sporborg, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Sporborg of Chappaqua, N. Y. A wedding in the fall is planned.

title: Staubach and Houston Chosen
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 15 (AP)Roger Staubach, quarterback of the Dallas Cowboys, and Ken Houston, Washington Redskins safetyman, were named cocaptains today for the National Football Conference squad in the Pro Bowl game in Seattle on Monday night, The N.F.C. squad will meet the American Conference team.

title: SPOTLIGHT
Armed Fireman Arrested
description: A New York City fireman has been arrested for carrying a loaded .22caliber automatic with a silencer and telescope along with a paper bag containing 52 shells. Police Officers Joseph O'Shea and Charles Dunbar of the 110th Precinct were off duty in a tavern at 9330 43d Avenue in Elmhurst, Queens, when another patron told them that the firemanTerrence Cullen, 27 years old, of 8034 Cornish Avenue, Elmhurst, who is assigned to Ladder Company 138had just left the bar with a gun in his possession. The police officers followed him outside, identified themselves, and searched him and reportedly found the gun and ammunition. The fireman told that that he had recently taken the gun away from a mugger in Brooklyn.

title: Chairmanship Lost for Lack Of Vital Vote
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15The dumping of the chairman of a committee is not frontpage news, but it is, if only because it happens so rarely, a significant legislative event. Speaker Stanley Steingut's decision to remove Armando Montano as chairman of the Assembly Housing Committee reveals a few things about the way the Legislature works, the relationship between leaders and members and perhaps about Mr. Steingut himself as he starts his second term as Speaker.

title: Connors, Scanlon Gain Final of W.C.T. Tourney
The Playwright and the Police
description: Miguel Pinero, who wrote a prizewinning play, Short Eyes, while serving a sentence for armed robbery in Sing Sing, was indicted last week for armed robbery and possession of heroin and cocaine, his third alleged offense since his play won the New York Drama Critics Award in 1974. In June of that year, Mr. Pinero was arrested for harassing a subway token booth agent and possessing a marijuana cigarette; in November, 1975, he was accused in a $200 street robbery. In the latest incident, Mr. Pinero and two companions are alleged to have robbed a taxi cab driver and his woman passenger. At the height of his success, he told interviewers he had been in and out of jail since he was 11 years old.

title: Dr. Mary C. Harris To Be Wed in March
description: Mrs. Ernest G. Harris of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Mary Catherine Harris, to Eric Forsythe, son of Henderson Forsythe, the stage and television actor, and Mrs. Forsythe of Tenafly; N.J. The prospective bride, also is a daughter of the late Ernest G. Harris, who was vice president of Durlacher & Company.

title: New Effort Under Way to Dismantle U.S. Information Agency, Giving Voice of America Independence
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The United States Information Agency, which is charged with advancing understanding of this country abroad, may face another of its many struggles for survival early in the Carter Administration.

title: Hospital Unit Urges Some Closings
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15 (AP)An association made up of hospitals that do about 95 percent of the surgery in the state recognized the fiscal facts of life this week by recommending that some beds be eliminated and some hospitals be closed.

title: New Ski Hazards: Liability, Energy
description: Skiarea operators who once feared the effect of a snowless winter are now facing a new threat to their survival. The rising costs of insurance and energy may drive many of them out of business.

title: 22 ARE KILLED AS PLANE CRASHES IN STOCKHOLM
Criminals At Large
description: Meet two new characters: a farmersheriff from rural West Virginia, and a Los Angeles private eye. The former is the central character in STALKING BLIND by Steven Ashley (Dial, $6.95); the latter is the investigator in WHO'D WANT TO KILL OLD GEORGE? by Robert Upton (Putnam's, $7.95). Of the two, the sheriff is much the more Interesting.

title: A Star Called Squint
description: In the empty gloom of Madison Square Garden, the blades of her White figure skates crunched along the ice. As she soared, there was no sound. When she landed, the crunch was heard again. Dorothy Hamill was practicing. But there was no spotlight on her, no lights at all. She can't see anyway, somebody said with a smile. She's nearsighted. She was wearing purple football jersey with the word Squint above 95 on the back. When she finished practicing, she sipped water from a mug, turned off the music she had been skating to, put on fashionably oversized bluetinted eyeglasses and draped a blue bathrobe over the purple jerk sey.

title: VICTOR D. SOLOW, 59, DOCUMENTARY MAKER
description: Victor D. Solow, a documentary film maker who headed his own concern, Solo Productions, before becoming associated with Francis Thompson Inc. in New York City, died Sunday morning after a heart attack in his home, 525 Cortlandt Avenue, Mamaroneck, N. Y. He was 59 years old.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Jan. 23Long Island Sports Car Club 125mile T.S.D. rally; start at Howard Johnson's (exit 64, Long Island Expressway), Medford, L.I. Registration: 9 A.M., first car off 10:30. Information: Lou Kairys, phone (212)2977674

title: Klammer Captures 4th Race in Row
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 15 (AP) Franz Klammer of Austria posted his fourth consecutive downhill ski victory today and recaptured the point lead for the World Cup. The Olympic champion covered the course, slowed somewhat by fresh snow, in 2 minutes 9.71 seconds, well off his track record of 2:03.22.

title: Farnhan Wins Twice In Bear Mt. Ski Jumping
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 15A Fort Dix soldier, Pvt. Jon Farnhan of Hanover, N.H., was a double skijumping winner today. Farnhan leaped 129 and 121 feet to finish ahead of a West Point cadet, Brad Zuehlke, in the Swedish Club tournament.

title: Better Weather Predicted
description: MONROE, Mich., Jan. 15 (AP)If you believe the ducks and geese on DeIhert Theeck's farm in rural Monroe, the state of Michigan is in for an easy winter or an early spring, Mr. Theeck based his predictions on activities of his 20 Pekin ducks and six geese. He said they have. started laying eggs well in advance of the usual time. Mr. Theeck said that oldtimers have long believed that early egg laying means better weather later.

title: Article 5  No Title
Boating: A Sport for the Masses
description: In casting off last year, more than 50 million persons using 10 million boats spent upwards of $5 billion dollars.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON

title: Purse for Stock Cars Will Exceed $4 Million
description: The 11month chase for the Winston Cup Grand National championship starts today in Riverside, Calif., and before it's over, the good ol boys from the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing (NASCAR) will have competed in 11 states for purses totaling more than $4 million. The NASCAR series was the bestattended auto racing series in the world last year, outdrawing the globespanning Grand Prix circuit, and there's every reason to believe the American stock cars will play to record crowd.s again this season.

title: It Happened on the Way Downtown
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELD

title: Thai Retains Ring Title By Stopping Brooks
description: CHIANG MAI, Thailand, Jan. 15 (AP) Saensak Muangsurin of Thailand survived a thirdround knockdown and scored a 15thround technical knockout of Monroe Brooks in this northern Thai city today to retain the World Boxing Council's junior welterweight title.

title: INTERVIEW
description: THE other day, at that satisfying hour when he likes to relax and sip what he calls the ultimate martini  undiluted gin, Edward J. Bloustein, president of Rutgers, the State University, reflected on what it's like to have survived a heart attack.

title: Rowdie's Sign South African
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jn. 15 (AP)The Tampa Bay Rowdies signed Steve, Wegerle, South Africn League winger, today to a contract for the upcoming North American Soccer League season. Wegerle, 23 years old, was South Africa's player of the year in 1974.

title: Study Finds Functional Literacy Holding Steady Among Students
description: The functional literacy of 17yearold high school students held steady at 87 percent from 1974 to 1975, according to the National Assessment of Educational Progress.

title: Panama Canal Treaty, a Latin Test Case
A.C.L.U. WOULD ALLOW LICENSING FOR ALIENS
description: Repeal of laws that bar aliens from getting New York State licenses in at least seven occupationsas physicians, chiropractors, dentists, pharmacists, landscape architects, certified shorthand reporters and masseurs or masseusesis being urged by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: Saudis Step Up Oil Production
description: Saudi Arabia has done what it promised to do a month ago after breaking with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and raising its oil prices for 1977 by only 5 percent: It has announced that it will increase oil production.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
W.H.A. Saints Suspend Operations, Sell Players
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 15 (UPI)  Bob Brown, president of the Minnesota Fighting Saints, said last night that the World Hockey Association franchise had sold seven of its top players to Edmonton and would not play the remainder of its weekend games because of financial difficulties.

title: A Welcome Routine
description: A transfer of Presidential power will take place Thursday in the manner that is normal but under circumstances that are not.

title: The Guest Word
description: Could not this outrage be averted? There sprang from my lips that fiery formula which has sprung from the lips of so many choleric old gentlemen in the course of the past hundred years or more: I shall write a letter to The Times.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)Attorney General Edward H. Levi announced today new restrictions on the use of informers in Federal narcotics investigations.
