description: For periods ended Dec. 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (0) over the counter.

title: W.H.A. to Decide Fate Of Fighting Saints Today
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 17What was to have been an agenda of mere housekeeping chores for the World Hockey Association trustees has become one fraught with franchise and player contract decisions at the meetings preceding tomorrow night's fifth annual allstar game.

title: Benin Closes Borders and Pushes Hunt for Invading Mercenaries
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 17A curfew has been imposed in Benin, the borders and airports are sealed off and foreigners have been warned to stay indoors while government vigilantes conduct houseto house searches.

title: Highlights of Ford's 1978 Budget
description: Following are the highlights of President Ford's budget:

title: An American Punishment Again
description: On July 20, 1976, Bennie Bushnell, a 25yearold Brigham Young University student, who was managing a Provo, Utah, motel was shot twice in the head while lying face down on the floor during a robbery of the motel. Gary Mark Gilmore, who admitted committing a similar murder of David Jensen, a 24yearold law student, was convicted of the murder of Mr. Bushnell in a Utah court in Provo on Oct. 7, 1976, and, under state law, was sentenced to be executed by a firing squad at sunrise on Nov. 15, 1976. What follows is a chronology of the high points of the balance of Mr. Gilmore's life.

title: Donations Made To the Neediest Pass $900,000
description: A gift of $38,290.60 from the trust fund of Sophia Louise Miller has helped the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to pass the $900,000 mark. There were 67 donors listed yesterday and they gave a total of $41,680.10, to bring the overall amount received from 8,895 donors to $914,480.32.

title: Weather Underground Splits Up Over Plan to Come Into the Open
description: The radical Weather Underground movement, struggling to maintain momentum in the postVietnam era, has split apart over a plan to come into the open.

title: Life Improving, Slowly, for India's Untouchables
description: MAU, India, Jan. 13Shivli Lal, a 55yearold untouchable farmer who lives in a oneroom mud house here, has no money, no prospects and very little land, but he remembers when things were worse.

title: Ford Asks 10Year Land Program For Parks and Wildlife Refuges
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)President Ford asked Congress today to start a 10year, $1.5 billion Bicentennial land heritage program to upgrade and maintain America's national parks and wildlife refuges.

title: 2 BIG BANKS RESTORE PRIME RATES TO 6% AFTER BRIEF 6% MOVE
description: The First National Bank of Chicago, closely followed by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, yesterday raised their prime lending rates back to 6 percent only a few weeks after they had been the first to lower them to 6 percent.

title: Waldheim Initiative Planned
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 17Secretary General Kurt Waldheint opened his own Middle East peacemaking initiative today, announcing that he planned a twoweek mission to the major Arab capitals and Israel to prepare for a reconvened Geneva peace conference in the spring.

title: Cold Around Nation
description: New York City yesterday shivered through its coldest Jan. 17 in the 108 years since records have been kept, with a 1 below zero reading.

title: Text of the President's Budget Message to Congress for the Fiscal Year 1978
The Growing Women's Studies Movement Gets Organized
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. I7 A sense of historic purpose pervaded deliberations at the University of San Francisco this past weekend as more than 500 women from throughout the United States met to found the National Women's Studies Association.

title: Ballet Cancels Season as Musicians Reject Mediator Plan to End Strike
description: The balance of the New York City Ballet's winter season was canceled last night and the company's spring season was jeopardized when the ballet's striking musicians unanimously rejected a compromise contract settlement that had been accepted by management early yesterday morning.

title: Kentucky Tops Florida, 7371, On 2 Foul Shots
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP) Jay Shibler hit two free throws with 4 seconds to play tonight to give secondranked Kentucky a 7371 Southeastern Conference basketball victory over Florida.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: EYEFUL TOWER Something new in the way of exotica has been added to Nirvana, the picturesque Indian restaurant occupying the penthouse at 30 Central Park South. Regular patrons are familiar with the restaurant's tentlike decor, the sweeping park panorama visible from the terrace tables and the music indigenous to India, now supplied by Shyam Yodh and Badal Roy on the sitar and tabla.

title: Opponents of Death Penalty Fear Psychological Effect of Execution
description: Opponents of the death penalty were apprehensive yesterday that the execution of Gary Mark Gilmore might have psychological impact on other cases, but they expressed hope that it would not weaken their legal position.

title: Market Place
description: After years of waiting, the Atlantic Richfield Company may soon begin to collect on its Alaskan investment.

title: L.I. Bus Drivers Protest
description: About 70 bus drivers in the Three Village School District on Long Island refused to work because they were not paid last Friday. The drivers were given their paychecks at about noon, but they refused to go back to work pending a resolution of grievances against the Three. Village Bus Corporation.

title: Yields on Weekly Treasury Bills Up
description: Yields rose on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91 day and 180day maturities.

title: Marketplace for the Evolving Gourmets
description: Food is part of a fashion image these days and the really withit person has to be interested, said Edward Finklestein, the president of Macy's New York.

title: Crosland Says Britain Has New Rhodesia Plan
description: LONDON, Jan. 17 (UFI)Britain has some rather definite and rather positive new proposals to put forth in its flagging Rhodesia peace mission, Foreign Secretary Anthony Crosland said late today.

title: Concert: Eastman Nova and Jazz
description: The Eastman School of Music struck a resonant blow for musical ecumenism Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall with a joint concert by its Musica Nova Ensemble and Jazz Ensemble, made all the more telling because the two groups share many of the same players.

title: SORENSEN WITHDRAWS, BOWING TO RESISTANCE TO C.I.A. NOMINATION
WQXR TO OFFER NORMA LIVE FROM LA SCALA TODAY
description: Through an arrangement with RAI Corporation, which operates Italy's radio and television networks, WQXR and WQXRFM today will broadcast a live performance of Bellini's Norma direct from La Scala Opera House in Milan. It will be the first transoceanic broadcast of an operatic performance transmitted by satellite.

title: 5 Named in Conspiracy
description: Five businessmen were indicted in Manhattan on a Federal charge of conspiracy to buy $6 million in counterfeit United States Treasury bills. One defendant, James G. Ryan, lives at 302 East 57th Street. The others are Charles W. Hilliard, David Hoover and John Osorio, all of Dallas, and Dean House of Canyon, Tex. United States Attorney Robert B. Fiske Jr. said the indictment resulted from a continuing investigation by his office's organized crime unit and the Secret Service into the manufacture and sale of counterfeit Treasury bills.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17The state senate unanimously passed today a bill that would require the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to hold public hearings before increasing any tolls or fares on tunnels and bridges or on mass transit facilities under its jurisdiction.

title: What Judge Bell Promises
description: After five days of hearings, the Senate Judiciary Committee is moving rapidly toward a vote on the nomination of Judge Griffin Bell to be Attorney General of the United States. The hearing record, like the record of Judge Bell's utterances since his nomination, has been marked by admissions of past mistakes and reconsiderations of past positions.

title: Violence Among Refugees Is Reported in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 17 (AP) Rioting between factions inside a Vietnamese refugee camp in northeast Thailand has resulted in injuries to about 15 people, provincial officials said today. Other informed sources, however, said dozens had been injured and one person had died of an apparent heart attack in the violence last Wednesday.

title: 24 U.S. Servicemen Die in Collision Of Navy Launch With Ship in Spain
Pigeon Taken on Flight to Fancy
description: When all about was freezing, a street pigeon found himself occupying a room at the St. Regis Hotel, at East 55th Street at Fifth Avenue.

title: 2 Murder Victims Had Much in Common
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 17 (AP)The two men Gary Mark Gilmore said he murdered last July had much In common. Both were descendants of Mormon pioneers. Both were students at Brigham Young University in Provo. Both worked for two years for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints. Each left a wife and a small child.

title: Wittmann of the Toledo Museum, Director for 18 Years, Retires
description: Otto Wittmann, director of the Toledo Museum of Art for the last 18 years, has retired. His successor is Roger Mandle, the museum's associate director since 1974.

title: High Court Agrees to Hear Dayton's Challenge of Busing Order
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a challenge by the school board of Dayton, Ohio, to a broad, courtordered desegregation plan now in effect in the Dayton public schools.

title: Giscard Angrily Assails Criticism Of France for Freeing Abu Daoud
description: PARIS, Jan, 17President Valry Giscard d'Estaing today laid the basic responsibility on West Germany for the release last week of the Palestinian terrorist suspect Abu Daoud.

title: Tanker Breaks Up in the Pacific
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 17 (UPI)A Liberianflag oil tanker carrying a crew of 31 broke up in the Pacific. Ocean 204 miles southeast of Midway Island, the Coast Guard reported tonight.

title: Jack Goes To Paris
description: Inspector Dupin was irritated. That afternoon he had spotted Jack the Ripper buying chestnuts in the Tuileries and had trailed him to his hotel, which turned out to be the Ritz. Ah ha! he had said to himself, now I've got problems. (Mon Dieu! voila la tristesse.)

title: GILMORE IS EXECUTED AFTER STAY IS UPSET
She'll Never Forget
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 17It'll never be over for my sister, said Bonnie Knieriem, whose brother  in  law, Mr. Bushnell, was killed by Mr. Gilmore. She watched the whole thing happen; it's something she'll never be able to forget.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Chesimard Trial Starts
description: The murder trial of Joanne Chesimard began yesterday at the Middlesex County Courthouse in New Brunswick with lawyers arguing about pretrial publicity, tight security and a number of housekeeping items while chanting pickets marched outside, despite the cold; urging her acquittal. The trial of the 29yearold woman, who was reputed to be a leading figure in the socalled Black Liberation Army, is expected to take four to six weeks after a jury is selected, and that could take two to three weeks. Mrs. Chesimard is charged with murder and assault in connection with the death of State Trooper Werner Foerster and one of her companions and the wounding of another trooper in a gunfight on the New Jersey Turnpike on May 2, 1973.

title: HIGH COURT PUTS OFF EXECUTION IN TEXAS
COLD WAVE CAUSES ENERGY SHORTAGES AND PLANT CLOSINGS
description: Tens of thousands of workers were sent home yesterday as factories and offices across the eastern half of the United States were forced to close because of increasingly acute shortages of natural gas and electricity brought on by record cold weather.

title: New Rules Proposed by F.E.A. For Negotiations on Foreign Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The Federal Enemy Administration made public today a proposed regulation that would require oil companies to notify the Government in some cases of negotiations under way with foreign governments for oil supplies.

title: Amaya Wins First Pro Tennis Final, Beating Brian Teacher at Adelaide
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 17 (AP)Victor Amaya, 6foot6inch player from Holland, Mich., capitalized on his booming serve and defeated Brian Teacher of San Diego in the allAmerican final of the $75,000 South Australian grass tennis tournament today, 61. 64. 62.

title: SUSAN SAXE ADMITS ROLE IN BANK KILLING
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17Susan Saxe, the militant feminist and antiwar activist, pleaded guilty today in. Suffolk Superior Court to manslaughter and two counts of armed robbery in the 1970 Boston bank robbery in which a police officer was killed.

title: A Partial Transcript of Remarks By Witness to Gilmore Execution
4 Tiremakers End Some Warranties, But Extend Others
description: Four major United States tire manufacturers are no longer guaranteeing the tread life of their tires or their resistance to punctures or other damage from road hazards. They have, however, extended their warranty protection against defects in materials or workmanship.

title: Xerox Net Up 5.1% For '76 and 26.4% In Fourth Quarter
description: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday a 26.4 percent advance in profits for the final quarter of the year.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Cheeks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York. N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: King Is a Naval Hero for Tourney
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Jan. 17Overnight temperatures had dipped near the 20degree mark, making the palmetto palms here shiver, but Bobby Cassidy of Levittown, L.I., didn't feel the cold.

title: Southern Reception Leaves Eagles Cool
description: SAMBURG, Tenn., Jan. 17 (AP)American bald eagles found an icy reception after flying south for the winter at fishrich Reelfoot Lake, and many have left in search of food.

title: Basques, Madrid Official Are Expected to Meet
description: MADRID, Jan. 17 (Reuters)Interior Minister Rodolfo Martin Villa of Spain has agreed to meet with mayors from the northern Basque country to hear demands for regional autonomy and an amnesty for political prisoners, Basque sources said last night.

title: Amnesty Issue Blocks Agreement On New P.B.A. Pact in New York
description: The insistence of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association on amnesty for officers charged with misconduct during recent P.B.A. demonstrations blocked final agreement yesterday on terms of a new contract with New York City.

title: Dow Falls 4.91 in Slow Trading As 2 Big Banks Lift Prime Rates
description: Increases in the prime lending rate by two major banks sent the stock market lower yesterday in slower trading.

title: 12 Are Killed as Train Rams Bridge Near Sydney
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 18 (Reuters)More than a dozen persons were known dead today when a commuter train derailed in a suburb of Sydney and crashed into a bridge, which then collapsed onto the train's cars, a police spokesman reported.

title: School Results
Vance Reported Planning Early Mideast Peace Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Cyrus R. Vance, the Secretary of Statedesignate, intends to fly to the Middle East next month to discuss ways of resuming peace efforts in the area, highranking diplomaticand State Department sources, said tonight.

title: Jay Rockefeller Is Sworn in West Virginia
Bruins Down Canadiens 3d Straight Time
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP)The Boston Bruins, sparked by the acrobatic goaltending of Gerry Cheevers, struck for four goals in the second period and whipped Montreal for the third time this season tonight, scoring a 73 National Hockey League victory over the Canadiens.

title: Philip Likens Britain To Case of Dry Rot
description: LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 18 (AP)Prince Philip said today that Britain was like a building deteriorating from dry rot.

title: News Summary
description: At least 24 American servicemen were killed in a collision between a Navy launch loaded with sailors and Marines and a freighter in Barcelona harbor. The launch was taking the men back to ships of um United States Sixth Fleet from weekend leave. The Navy reported that 30 men were injured and that 26 were unaccounted for, but it had not been determined if they were all on the launch. [Page 1, Cols. 23.]

title: Ford's Proposals Reflect Republican Perceptions and Priorities
Meadowlands Drivers
DECLINE CONTINUES IN PRICES OF BONDS
description: The credit markets, which have been heading toward lower prices and higher interst rates this year, continued their slump yesterday. However, tnheir decline yesterday, which followed news that the First National Bank of Chicago and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company had raised rates on commercial loans, was not so large as some of the downward moves last week, and trading activity was light. The continued drop took place in widely separated parts of the credit market. Threemonth Treasury bills were sold at an average rate of 4.67 percent, up from 4.61 percent last week and the highest rate since Nov. 15.

title: Judge Orders Lawyers to: Report In 60 Days on Hughes Will Search
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17A Probate Court judge warned Howard R. Hughes's relatives and their lawyers today that they must within 60 days report fully on their search for a will of the industrialist.

title: Courthouse Is Picketed as Chesimard Trial Starts
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 17The murder trial of Joanne Chesimard began today at the Middlesex County Courthouse with lawyers arguing about pretrial publicity, tight security, and a number of housekeeping items while chanting pickets marched outside despite the cold, urging her acquittal.

title: Cauthen Finally Cools Off On a Hot Day for Long Shots
description: On the coldest day of the winter racing season, Steve Cauthen cooled off and longshot bettors warmed up. Cauthen, the 16yearold apprentice jockey who rode a New York record 23 victories last week, won only two races yesterday at Aqueduct and they were the shortestpriced winners of the day.

title: Texas Father Placed on Probation In Killing of Son Who Used Drugs
description: ORE CITY, Tex., Jan. 17 (UPI)Forrest Grigg was a father worried about his 20 yearold son's involvement with drugs.

title: Bernbach and Ogilvy Joining Hall of Fame
description: The American Advertising Federation will this year induct William Bernbach and David Ogilvy into their 27yearold Advertising Hall of Fame. The only question is, what took them so long?

title: Industrial Production Ends 76 With Impressive Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Industrial production and personal income finished 1976 with good gains, two Government reports disclosed today.

title: A.F.C. Wins By 24 to 14 In Pro Bowl
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 17 (AP)Mel Blount, the Pittsburgh Steelers' cornerback, intercepted one pass that killed a scoring threat, then stole another that set up Ken Anderson's second touchdown pass of the game, helping lead the American Conference to a 2414, Pro Bowl victory tonight over the National Conference.

title: GILMORE IS EXECUTED AFTER STAY IS UPSET
description: POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN, Utah, Jan. 17The 10year suspension of capital punishment in the United States ended today when four .30caliber bullets ripped through the chest of Gary Mark Gilmore, the convicted killer who had asked the State of Utah to execute him.

title: Pro Bowl Scoring
description: A.F.C.Simpson, 3, run (Linhart, kick).

title: Air Siam Grounded It Has No Planes
description: BANGKOK, Jan. 17 (UPI)Air Siam has become an airline without an aircraft.

title: Article 2  No Title
Earth Tremor in Greece
description: ATHENS, Jan. 17 (UPH)An earth tremor cracked walls in a church, a school and several homes in villages in the Corinth area, about 50 miles west of Athens, yesterday but there were no reported injuries, the police said today.

title: DEMOCRATS PREPARE FOR COUNCIL CONTEST
description: The customarily contentious Democrats on the West Side of Manhattan have agreedso far, at leaston how to fill the City Council seat left vacant by Theodore S. Weiss's election to Congress.

title: Lyrics and Lyricists Series Opens With Mitchell Parish
description: In the six years since the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. began inviting lyricists to appear on Sunday evenings to discuss and illustrate their craft in the Lyrics and Lyricists series, the most consistently interesting presentations have been made by lyric writers who, to some degree, work in the musical theater. Because they have to write for a variety of situations, they produce all kinds of songsromantic, witty, philosophical, comedyalmost anything that can be done in musical terms in relation to a story line.

title: Aircraft Industry Found to Retain Excess Capacity
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17An Administration study has concluded that the United States aircraft industry currently re tains an excess capacity that is costing the Department of Defense about $400 million a year to sustain.

title: Indian Claims Deadline Delayed
description: PORTLAND, Maine, Jan. 17 (AP)A Federal judge today gave the Justice Department six more weeks to decide how to press claims by two Maine Indian tribes to 60 percent of the land in the state. It was the second extension of the court's deadline. Justice Department officials asked for additional time past March 1 to permit Congress and the incoming Carter administration to determine whether to seek a congressional solution to the Indian claims case.

title: Desegregation Guides Set For Colleges in 6 States
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)A Federal district judge ordered the Department of Health, Education and Welfare today to work out guidelines within 45 days for the desegregation of state college systems in Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, Oklahoma and Virginia,

title: Pro Transactions
description: CALIFORNIA (AL)Signed Robert Healy, pitcher, winter draft choice.

title: Record 1 Cold Disrupts Travel, Closes Some Schools in Suburbs
RABBI ALBERT MINDA, 81
description: Rabbi Albert G. Minda, a past presiddent of the Central Conference of American Rabbis and former international vice president of the World Union for Progressive Judaism. died Saturday in Minneapolis where he had been the spiritual leader of Temple Israel from 1922 to his retirement in 1963. He was 81 years old.

title: Cold Wave Turns One Postman To First Pair of Long Johns
description: Pushing his 75pound cartload of mail around the northwest corner of Greenwich Village yesterday, Charles L. Brown wore his first pair of long johns. He bought them last Saturday, the 39yearold letter carrier said, when the cold spell toppled his lifelong belief that such comforts were only for old people.

title: Budget Office Finds That Welfare Reduced Poverty Rate 60 Percent
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17A study by the Congressional Budget Office has concluded that Federal social welfare programs reduced the rate of poverty in the United States by 60 percent in the last decade.

title: Advice Is Offered On Ways to Cope With Cold Wave
description: Bundle up with layers of clothing to ward off frostbite and, if you must travel, first tune in to allnews radio stations and give yourself plenty of time to get there because there may be delays on the way.

title: Bridge:
description: Regional championships in the Northeast attract very strong fields, and it is very rare, indeed for a player to win both the prestige events, the open pairs and the Swiss teams.

title: Black College in Atlanta Plans Medical School
description: The nation's third black medical school will be established at the 110yearold Morehouse College at Atlanta University in the fall of 1978. The school is to train physicians especially for poor urban and rural American communities as well as for thirdworld nations.

title: COLD WAVE CAUSES ENERGY SHORTAGES AND PLANT CLOSINGS
TV: Voyage of Hokule'a, Geographic Show, Traces Tahiti Trip
description: Voyage of the Hokule'a, the National Geographic documentary on public television at 8 this evening, is one of the most peculiar, and thereby one of the most intriguing, productions connected with the distinguished society. The Hokule'a is a 60foot sailing canoe constructed as the official 1976 Bicentennial project of the State of Hawaii. Using no navigating instruments, it was navigated 3,000 miles from Hawaii to Tahiti. One purpose of the project was to generate pride of a heroic past in native Hawaiians. By journey's end, however, the organizers and crew were hardly speaking to one another.

title: Stage: Doubles
description: With two superlative performances, some beautifully employed music and an intelligent skirting of the gaps in its talents, the Equity Library Theater production of Twelfth Night grows steadily through the evening from bare adequacy to a moving radiance.

title: Taiwan Weapons Request Is Refused by Britain
description: LONDON. Jan. 17 (Reuters)The British Government has turned down a request from Taiwan for a substantial number of surfacetoair missiles, the British Aircraft Corporation said today.

title: U.S. Supreme Court Refuses to Hear Zoning Case Brought by Blacks in Westchester
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The United States Supreme Court refused today to consider the contention by several black residents of Westchester County that they should be allowed to challenge Federal grants to a largely white suburb grants that the blacks said had helped maintain residential segregation in Westchester County.

title: STEEL OUTPUT IN WEEK OFF 0.8% TO 2.11 MILLION TONS
description: Steel production in the week ended Jan. 15 slipped 0.8 percent behind the previous week's level, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Scientists at Pole Run For Fun at 100 Below
description: SOUTH POLE STATION, Antarctica Most of those who go south for the winter bask in the sun, play golf and tennis, or swim. But there is a small coterie who go all the way (south), and for them the chief sports are tobogganing down a geodesic dome and sprinting nude to the South Pole.

title: Advertising
description: Yesterday Ogilvy & Mather, the country's eighth largest agency, sent invitations to about top 25 agencies to send representatives to a meeting Friday morning at which the muchtalkedabout fourth TV network could well be conceived.

title: News Summary
description: At least 24 American servicemen were killed in a collision between a Navy launch loaded with sailors and Marines and a freighter in Barcelona harbor. The launch was taking the men back to ships of the United States Sixth Fleet from weekend leave. The Navy reported that 30 men were injured and that 26 were unaccounted for, but it had not been determined if they were all on the launch. [Page 1, Cols. 23.]

title: Campus Where Victims Studied Finds Justice in Gilmore's Death
description: PROVO, Utah, Jan. 17When it was over, they thought justice had been done.

title: Saypol Indictment Is Dismissed
description: A State Supreme Court justice, as expected, dismissed a bribery and perjury indictment yesterday against Justice Irving H. Saypol of State Supreme Court on the ground of insufficient evidence.

title: Protecting Your Heart In the Cold Weather
description: Frigid, snowy weather is usually accompanied by a fair share of injuries and accidents, including falls on the ice, skidding cars, skiing, skating and sleighing accidents and, for those who remain outdoors too long with too little on, frostbite.

title: TAX REPEALER AIMS TO FOSTER ECONOMY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17Governor Byrne signed today a bill repealing the state tax on business personal property, and business leaders said the new law would enable New Jersey to compete with Southern states for new industry.

title: Belgians, in Error, Hold Zairian Guard As Mobutu Lands
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 17 (Reuters)Belgian police officers seized a young African at Brussels Airport today when he pulled out a submachine gun as President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire rode past him in a car, but the man turned out to be a Mobutu security guard.

title: Frank Gifford Remembers Lombardi
description: In the babble of dialogue surrounding him in the ABC television booth, it's understandable to forget that Frank Gifford was a majestic football player for the New York Giants during their majestic seasonsa runner, a pass receiver, a competitor. But the Pro Football Hall of Fame selection committee did not forget. Frank Gifford was in Seattle to broadcast the Pro Bowl last night when his election to the Canton, Ohio, shrine was announced along with that of Gale Sayers, Bart Starr, Forrest Gregg, each chosen in their first year of, eligibility,, and Bill Willis, a middle guard with the Cleveland Browns in their formative seasons. Of the five, three will be inducted in July with a Made by'Vince Lombardi stamp on them Bart Starr as the quarterback and Forrest Gregg as the offensive tackle on the Green Bay Packers. when Vince Lombardi was the coach, and Frank Gifford as the halfback when Vince Lombardi was the Giants' offensive coach.

title: Policy Setter, K. M. Cahill, M.D.
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17There is one fact about Kevin M. Cahill, M.D., on which virtually everyone here is agreed: that in the area of health care, he is the single most important policymaker in New York State.

title: She's Got a New Outlook on Life
description: I've matured a little and grown up, Cynthia Gregory said, summing up the year since she quit American Ballet Theater and drove off to Los Angeles to rethink her life.

title: The U.N. Today
Books of The Times
description: A FRINGE OF LEAVES. By Patrick White. 404 pages. Viking. $10.

title: Injured Fireman Dies
description: Fireman Donald Averse died yesterday morning in Long Island Jewish Hospital of internal injuries suffered while fighting a fire Jan. 3 at 6791 223d Place, Alley Pond, Queens. Fireman Averse, who was 40 years old, was thrown to the street when the roof on which he was standing collapsed. His death was the first of a fireman in line of duty this year. He had been a member of the Fire Department for 16 years, and leaves a wife and three children.

title: Ford Criticized for Cutting Public Jobs in Northeast
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  President Ford's new budget will have some very drastic effects on New York City and the Northeast urbanized area unless changed, Representative Robert N. Giaimo, Democrat of Connecticut and chairman of the House Budget Committee, said today.

title: On the Coldest Days, the Gayest Summer Fashions
Qualms
description: WASHINGTONOn March 30, 1976, the Senate established a committee to examine committee reorganization and related matters. The panel, chaired by Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, held more than 40 meetings and issued three staff reports. Its recommendations are now being considered by the Rules Committee, which is chiefly responsible for reviewing proposals for institutional reform

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Moscow Artist Says Police Are Blocking Attendance At Leningrad Exhibition
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17 (Reuters)One of Moscow's leading nonconformist artists said today he had been detained by the police last night to prevent him from attending an unofficial art exhibition in Leningrad.

title: Similarity Noted in Such Areas As Health and Welfare Reform
O'Leary in Line for Energy Post
Yonkers Results; (OTB payoffs subject to 5% tax)
description: FIRST RACE$4,000, Pace, mile.

title: Worsening Cold Spell Disrupts Life In the Midwest, South and Northeast
description: DETROIT, Jan. 17When the doors of the modern downtown office of the Detroit Bank and Trust Company opened this morning, ice covered most of the glass in large windows, the temperature inside was below 60 degrees, bank tellers and officials were wearing their overcoats and transacting business under lights that had been dimmed.

title: Dollar Eases in Europe
description: BRUSSELS. Jan. 17 (UPI)The dollar eased on European money markets in what dealers said appeared to be a technical correction after last week's sharp gains.

title: Most Members of Carter Transition Team Find Themselves With No Job Assignment in Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Most of the bright new faces who came to town to run Jimmy Carter's transition team are sitting and waiting, three days before inauguration, with no job and no immediate prospect for a job in the new administration.

title: Portugal, Ending Long Opposition, To Allow Production of CocaCola
description: LISBON, Jan. 17Portugal announced today that it would allow the manufacture of CocaCola after years of opposition to the soft drink.

title: Orioles' Net Loss $102,531
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 17 (UPI)The Baltimore Orioles showed a net loss of $102,531 for the year ending Oct. 31 despite the highest home attendance in seven years. General Manager Hank Peters said almost all costs were higher but the most significant increase was in playing expenses, $308,000 higher than in 1975.

title: Drug Dealer Is Guilty
description: A Newark drug dealer pleaded guilty to conspiring to run a $1.2 million yearly heroin business. The defendant, Al Green, 52 years old, pleaded guilty to conspiring to violate the narcotics laws by distributing heroin. His wife, Lois, 27, pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges.

title: N.B.A. Game in Buffalo Postponed to Save Fuel
description: PHILADELPHIA. Jan. 17 (AP)The scheduled National Basketball Association game at Buffalo tomorrow night between the Braves and Philadelphia 76ers has been postponed because of extreme cold weather.

title: Giscard Angrily Assails Criticism Of France f or Freeing Abu Daoud
description: PARIS, Jan. 17President Valery Giscard d'Estaing today laid the basic responsibility on West Germany for the release last week of the Palestinian terrorist suspect Abu Daoud.

title: Shady Business Ways Face Curbs
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17The Assembly leadership joined with Carey administration officials today to form a task force aimed at eliminating such unlawful but pernicious business practices as bribery, price fixing, cigarette smuggling, pilferage and profiteering by middlemen in the commercial pipeline.

title: Big Board Seat Price Off $6,000
description: A membership seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $69,000, down $6,000 from the previous sale of Jan. 11, the Big Board reported. Seats are quoted at $65,000 bid, $75,000 asked.

title: Senate Panel Ends Bell Hearings By Returning to Civil Rights Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Attorney Generaldesignate Griffin B. Bell, called back before the Senate Judiciary Committee for more questioning about his civil rights record, ended his testimony today the same way he began it last Tuesdayby insisting he had been a voice of moderation in the past and promising to restore confidence in the Justice Department in the future.

title: New York Agencies Offer Advice On How to Cope With Cold Wave
description: Bundle up with layers of clothing to ward off frostbite and, if you must travel, first tune in to allnews radio stations and give yourself plenty of time to get there because there may be delays on the way.

title: William Jacobson, 86, Played For Browns From 1915 to 1926
description: ORION, Ill., Jan. 17 (AP)William C. (Baby Doll) Jacobson, a former star center fielder with the St. Louis Browns, died yesterday at the age of 86.

title: Adams in Satisfactory Condition
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan, 17 (UPI)Former Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire underwent successful surgery for removal of a blood clot in his brain and was listed in satisfactory condition today at Mary Hitchcock Hospital. Hospital officials said that the 78yearold former chief of staff and confidant to President Eisenhower had a routine operation Friday for a head injury suffered when he fell on ice two weeks ago.

title: Smokebombs and Sorensen
description: The first thing to be said about Theodore Sorensen's withdrawal yesterday from designation as Director Central Intelligence is that he deserves full personal vindication against a subterranean stream of accusations made against him. For the most part, they were unjust or irrelevant and, as one Senator observed, smacked of conviction without a trial.

title: Deputy to Head C.I.A. Pending Carter Choice
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  In the absence of a designated director, the Central Intelligence Agency will be run by a deputy after the outgoing director, George Bush, leaves office Jan. 19, C.I.A. officials said today.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Role of the Pope Is Key to Study With Anglicans
description: ROME, Jan. 17 (AP)A joint commission of Catholic and Anglican scholars is scheduled to publish a document Thursday proposing that the Pope be recognized as overall patriarch as a way to end the 443year schism between the churches.

title: FORD'S BUDGET SEEKS SPENDING SLOWDOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  President Ford today sent Congress his last budget, a document that embodied his conservative philosphy by proposing a slowdown in the rate of growth in Federal spending and a longterm policy of continuously declining income tax rates.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Viacom International Inc. yesterday turned down an offer of the Storer Broadcasting Company to buy all Viacom shares for $55.7 million in cash. In a letter to Willard A. Michaels, chairman of Storer Broadcasting of Miami, Ralph M. Baruch, Viacom president, said that directors of Viacom, after considering the economic aspects and potential legal problems of the combination, unanimously rejected the offer.

title: Teachers Strike Ended
description: Teachers in Waterbury, Conn., voted overwhelmingly to accept a contract settlement reached over the weekend, and the Board of Education unanimously approved the agreement. The votes ended a 10day strike, and the city's 17,000 students are due back in their classrooms today.

title: ANDRUS INDICATES SUPPORT FOR CURBS ON STRIP MINING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  President elect Carter's nominee as Secretary of the Interior, Cecil D. Andrus, testified today that he would give priority attention to legislation to control strip mining of coal and offshore oil drilling as soon as he took office.

title: LongTerm Income Tax Reduction Urged as a National Commitment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  President Ford's budget proposed for the first time today that the nation commit itself to a longterm program of individual income tax reduction to offset the impact of both inflation and increases in real incomes in pushing people into everhigher tax brackets.

title: 1,000 Flee After an Electric Blast In Cliffside Park Housing Complex
description: CLIFFSIDE PARK, Jan. 17At least 1,000 people fled safely from a 31story apartment house today after an electrical explosion and fire sent clouds of thick, choking smoke rolling through most of the highrise building on a frigid bluff overlooking the Hudson River.

title: Beirut Banks Resume Full Activity
Cold Around Nation
description: New York City yesterday shivered through its coldest Jan. 17 in the 108 years since records have been kept, with a 1 below zero reading.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Weekend Boxing
description: Chlang Mai, Thailand  Saensak Muanguarin, 139 Pounds, Thailand, knocked out Monroe Brooks, 139, Los Angeles, 15th round, retaining the World Boxing Council Junior welterweight title.

title: Tanzania's Official Capital Dodoma, Is Still Just a. Magnificent Dream
Ford's Economic Legacies To the New Administration
description: Starting Thursday, the world's center stage will be occupied by Jimmy Carter and rightfully soas he finally assumes the powers of the American Presidency for which he so long and earnestly prepared and campaigned. But these final days of his short stewardship as the nation's chief executive still belong to President Ford.

title: Naval Air Station Spared
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (Reuters)The Navy announced today that it had decided not to close down operations at the Naval Air Station in Key West, Fla. Last March, the Navy said that it was studying relocating all aircraft squadrons at Key West and reducing the naval hospital there to a regional clinic.

title: Boon Times for Road Runners Club
description: The weather outside may be frightful for joggers, but life suddenly has become delightful for the New York Road Runners Club.

title: Soviet to Get Marlboros
description: Philip Morris Inc. announced yesterday that it had signed a license agreement with Licensintorg, which represents the Soviet Union's tobacco industry, for the manufacture and marketing of Marlboro cigarettes in the Soviet Union.

title: Burroughs Net Up 19%
description: Net income of the Burroughs Corporation rose 19 percent in the fourth quarter of 1976 and 13 percent for the whole year.

title: Charges Against Mardian In Watergate Are Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)Charles F. C. Ruff, the Watergate special prosecutor, today formally dropped Watergate coverup charges against a former Assistant Attorney General, Robert C. Mardian. The move came in papers filed with Federal District Judge John S. Sirica asking that the charges be dismissed.

title: New York State Audit Uncovers Medicaid Cheating
description: A state audit of a nursing home run by an upstate county disclosed yesterday that the home had overbilled Medicaid by some $2 million over an 11year period, including claims for salaries of public employees unrelated to nursing homes.

title: Yuri Soloviev, Ballet Star, Dead
description: Yuri Soloviev, one of the world's great dancers, was found shot to death, apparently by his own hand, at his country home outside Leningrad on Sunday. He was 36 years old.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: School District in Suffolk Told to Release Records Of Its Hispanic Students
description: A Federal judge has ordered a school district in Suffolk County to produce the records of its Hispanic pupils to determine whether its bilingual education curriculum and teaching personnel are adequate to overcome the children's Englishlanguage difficulties.

title: Vance Appoints Nodding Carter As State Department Spokesman
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Secretary of Statedesignate Cyrus R. Vance today announced the selection of Hodding Carter 3d. editor and associate publisher of The DeltaDemocrat Times of Greenville, Miss., as the new spokesman for the State Department.

title: Florida Hotel Employees Refuse to Return to Jobs
description: MIAMI. BEACH, Jan. 17 (UPI)The end of a hotel workers' strike hit snags at five of the nine major resort hotels today and workers refused to return to their jobs.

title: Yonkers Drivers
Queen of Spades Picked to Open Spoleto Festival U.S.A. May 25
description: Three operas, a set of Strindberg plays, ballet, chamber music and choral concerts will be presented at Spoleto Festival U.S.A. 1977, the new American counterpart in Charleston, S. C. to the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy. It will open on May 25 with the same production of Tchaikovsky's Queen of Spades that was given at the Italian festival last summer.

title: Nyquist Rescinds His 1975 Order To Integrate 5 Schools in Brooklyn
description: Ewald B. Nyquist, the New York State Education Commissioner, yesterday rescinded his 1975 order calling for the integration of five junior high Schools in the East Flatbush and Canarsie sections of Brooklyn.

title: Eight Black Nationalists Convicted of Terrorism Are Hanged in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 17 (AP) Eight black nationalists convicted of terrorism and sabotage were hanged here today.

title: Shipping Problems Cut Saudi Oil Production by 20%
description: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 17Despite strong demand for lowerpriced Saudi Arabian oil, shipping problems held the Arabian American Oil Company's oil production in the first half of January to only 80 percent of last year's level, an Aramco executive said here today.

title: About New York
description: There is a part of the brave new sexual world of consenting adults that requires pictures of naked children for its satisfaction. Some of the pornography stalls of Times Square, specializing in varied produce from the rich, damp loam of human imagination, have been selling sex magazines showing undressed youngsters simulating what adult customers consider the poses of love.

title: If National Debt Had to Be Paid, Each of Us Would Be Billed $3,511
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)If the bill collector carne to the door in the next fiscal year to call in the national debt, each of America's 215 million citizens would have to Pay $3,511.

title: Animal Feed Lag May Hurt Harvest
Free Seminar on Income Taxes
description: A freeoneday seminar for the general public on changes in the Federal individual income tax has been scheduled by the Internal Revenue Service at 26 Federal Plaza, Room 305, Thursday from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. A similar seminar for tax practitionerswhich, however, requires registrationhas been scheduled there Thursday, Jan. 27

title: Ballet Cancels Season as Musicians Reject Mediator Plan to End Strike
MONSIGNOR BAYER DIES
description: Msgr. Karl Bayer, a founder and first secretary general of Caritas Internationalis, the Roman Catholic welfare organization, died Sunday of an apparent heart attack in Rome. He was believed to be in his 60's.

title: Notes on People
description: The Times of London normally prints three editorials a day, but yesterday the newspaper's entire editorial space was devoted to a single subject, outgoing Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger. He has been one of the most remarkable men ever to hold high office in the United States, said the editorial. Almost singlehanded he has managed American foreign policy through eight years of turbulence and demoralization, through the withdrawal from Vietnam, Watergate, the Middle East war, the oil crisis, a worldwide recession, the resignation of Mr. Nixon, and the defeat of Mr. Ford. He was the point of stabiiity when all else was disintegrating around him. For that alone, he would deserve to be judged well by history.

title: Odometer Fraud Cited
description: A New Jersey man admitted in Federal Court in Newark yesterday that he was a freelance odometer fixer, hired by hundreds of auto dealers to set back mileage counts on cars foisted on unsuspecting bargain hunters. The defendant, Frank Caulfield, 30 years old, of River Vale, pleaded guilty to charges he altered mileage readings on 1,000 cars a year between 1973 and 1976, earning a total of $60,000 from 150 separate usedcar defilers, garages and private citizens. Mr. Caulfield agreed to pay $15,000 in civil penalties.

title: Opportunities Opening for Young Defector
description: Things are going well again for Ivan Brixi. He even has figured out the city subway system.

title: U.S. Accepts Israeli Explanation Of JetEngine Sales to Honduras
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)The State Department said today that it considered the case closed on an Israeli sale of American airplane engines to Honduras with the required permission from the United States.

title: STATE SENATE TO STUDY SATRA PACT ON OLYMPICS
description: The New York State Senate Committee on Consumer Protection will investigate the agreement between the Soviet Union's Olympic Organizing Committee and the Satra Corporation involving broadcast and film rights of the 1980 Games in Moscow.

title: Policy Setter, K. M. Cahill, M. D.
British Football
description: Second Division

title: Britain Improves Payments Balance
President Ford's Final Account
description: A President's budget may look like a sober, factfilled document but it actually makes an unpredictable flight somewhere between stony hard ground and wishing on a star. The hard ground is composed of interest on the national debt, veterans benefits, Social Security pensions, Medicare payments and other expenditures that cannot be altered. The wishing enters in when the budgetmakers try to guess what may be the size of business activity or the rate of inflation a year from now. If business booms and inflation creeps, tax revenues will rise agreeably and disagreeable expenditures like unemployment compensation will decline,

title: New Math Tests Give Pupils Instant Results
description: BROOKLINE, Mass.Brian Griffin, who is in the fifth grade at the Lawrence Elementary School, was filling out a blue sheet with a series of multiplication problems. In the empty box opposite 6 X 10.3 he wrote 6.24. Brian then tore the blue sheet off its yellow backing, where the correct answers were printed along with a carbon impression of his own responses.

title: OPEC Leader Urges Meeting
description: VIENNA, Jan. 17 (AP)  The chief executive of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that he hoped OPEC oil ministers would meet, the sooner the better, to deal with problems arising from the twotier oil price system.

title: 4 IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA HELD IN CRACKDOWN
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 17 (AP)Czechoslovak authorities, stiffening their crackdown on human rights activists, announced four arrests today on charges of serious, criminal activities directed against the foundations of the republic.

title: Last Year's Corn Crop Set Record Estimated at 6.22 Billion Bushels
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)Last year's corn crop, an important factor in 1977 consumer food prices, totaled a record of almost 6.22 billion bushels, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: In Memoriam
description: GOLDSTEINEdna H. January 19, 1941. In loving memory of our mother.

title: Carey's Experience Showing
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18The budget Governor Carey sent to the Legislature today is his third, and his experience shows.

title: A Homey Inaugural With a Southern Flair
description: Susan Mary Alsop will never forget when President Kennedy unexpectedly slogged through kneedeep snow at 2 A. M. after his 1960 Inaugural Ball to get to Joseph Alsop's glowing Georgetown salon for a warming drink and some companionship. Mrs. Alsop, now an author of books and divorced from the former columnist, remembers it this way:

title: A Former U.N. Aide Sentenced to Teach U.S. Prison Inmates
description: Dr. John G. Stoessinger, a Hunter College professor and former high official of the United Nations, received a suspended sentence in Manhattan yesterday from a Federal judge who ordered him to use his teaching talent to help prison inmates for an average of two hours a week during the next 18 months.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: All it takes is a couple of minutes and a couple of hundred dollars and, if such is your desire, you, too, can have a sculpture of yourself  or your husband, wife, roommate or child. True, the whole thing is not like sitting for an artist, but then computers don't work that way. How the special process that does the sculpture actually works is beyond casual description but, in brief, it starts with a twosecond photography sitting and from then on, your part (other than forking over the cash) is finished. The camera records and codes, for processing into sculpture, every essential dimension of the subject's face. The computer then directs a replicator to sculpt a wax master, and the master is used to cast the final piece, which takes about two weeks. The sculpture can be finished in a number of materials, including bonded bronze, bronze, brass, Lucite, a plaster substance and even gold and silver. There's a choice of full size, threequarter or half size, and the prices start at $180. There's an extra charge if you want the surface of your face smoothed, but it's still cheaper than plastic surgery. The place to go is the Studio for Solid Photography at 551 Madison Avenue (55th Street). The telephone number is 7520044.

title: Sweaters de Rigueur In a Chilly City Hall
description: It was earlaps and extra sweaters inside City Hall yesterday morning following an inexplicable slowdown in the steam heat supply to the 165yearold seat of local government.

title: Books of The Times
description: THERE WERE TWO Robert Frosts: One was the poet and public personality, the other the man behind that persona. In Robert Frost: The Later Years, the second competes with the first to an extent that made even the authors of this official biography uncomfortable. There is no doubt that Frost was a firstrate poet. It is equally certain he could be a remarkably petty and selfish man. Some of his sympathizers may feel that such indulgences are among the prerogatives of old age, that as death closes in on a man, so does his concern close in on himself.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Jan. 18  William J. Hamilton Jr., the new Speaker of the Stale Assembly, wants to look over Governor Byrne's shoulder this year to make sure he is doing a good job.

title: Music: Women's Work
description: MONDAY EVENING'S sparsely attended gala concert celebrating the Decade of Women at Carnegie Recital Hall led off with three mostly a cappella (there was a bit of percussion) choral pieces by Alice Parker, Merle Montgomery and Julia Smithall very brief and all run together, almost as they were one piece. Which they might have been, given the pleasant but similarly conservative idiom they shared.

title: Former H.U.D. Aide Is Cleared In Conflict of Interest Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Justice Department has completed an investigation into possible conflict of interest violations by H. R. Crawford, a former Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, who was forced to resign his post last year as a result of the alleged violations.

title: Pacifist Governor of Tokyo Balks British Ship Seeking Sales of Arms
description: TOKYO, Jan. 18A British proposal to tiring a Royal Navy ship into Tokyo Harbor as a showroom for the products of the British arms industry is being torpedoed by the Governor of Tokyo, a wellknown pacifist.

title: Cold Deepens Natural Gas Shortage
description: The extreme shortage of natural gas that has idled thousands of workers across the eastern United States worsened yesterday, although some factories reopened by switching to alternative fuels.

title: Republic Steel's Earnings Gained In Fourth Quarter but Fell in Year
description: Fourthquarter earnings of the Republic Steel Corporation increased 9.6 percent to $9.2 million, or 57 cents a share, the coMpany said yesterday. But for all of last year it reported a 9.6 percent profit decline to $65.9 million. or $4.07 a share.

title: Kansas City Star Sale Proposed
description: Capital Cities Communications Inc. yesterday offered to buy for cash the Kansas City Star publishing company for $125 million.

title: Tolls on East River Bridges Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that New York City, to clean up its air, must carry out a controversial transportation control plan that includes imposing tolls on bridges across the East and. Harlem Rivers.

title: City Sounding a Call for Tennis Pros at 30 Centers
description: If you want to be a tennis pro and earn $14 an hour, get your bid in early to New York City's Parks Department.

title: GOVERNOR PROPOSES A CUT IN SCHOOL AID
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18Governor Carey's budget, while continuing to allot nearly half of New York State's total expenditures in the coming fiscal year to education, would cut direct aid to local school districts by $150 million and would strike hardest at communities in the older suburbs that have experienced declining pupil population. .

title: Islanders Top North Stars, 72, With 4523 Advantage in Shots
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 18Building up steam slowly, the Islanders burst their boiler with four goals in the final period tonight and trounced the Minnesota North Stars, 72, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: YVONNE PRINTEMPS, FRENCH SINGER, DIES
description: Miss Printemps was for many years one of the most sparkling ornaments of the French theatrical scene, and her marriage to Sacha Guitry, the dramatist and actor, constituted one of the most famous partnerships in modern stage history until, it was terminated by divorce in 1934.

title: U.S. Nationalists in Panama Canal Zone Resist Turnover of Control
description: MARGARITA, Panama Canal Zone, Jan. 17American residents here who work for the Panama Canal Company include a hard core of United States nationalists opposed to giving Panama any effective, rights over the waterway.

title: Meminger Returns to Knick Team
description: Dean Meminger, unwanted for almost half the National Basketball Association season, has come home again.

title: Wine Talk
Carter Campaign Aides Leading Democrats' Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Kenneth M. Curtis. the incoming Democratic national chairman, said today that he expected to handle some of the political activity that's been in the White House in past Administrations.

title: About Real Estate
Soybean Futures Ris
SouthWest Africa Charter Drafted
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 18South Africa's plan to grant independence to SouthWest Africa by the end of next year has moved a step closer to realization with the preparation of a draft constitution for the territory, also known as Namibia.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Are green onions and scallions one and the same? A. Yes. In some sections of the United ed States, however, notably the South, some regional cookbooks specify shallots when they actually meanscallions or green onions. Shallots are similar to scallions or green onions only in that they both have an onion flavor and belong to the onion family. Shallots have a brownish, translucent skin. They are said to be a cross between an onion and. garlic, but that is a vague description at best. Shallots are marvelously subtle. In their never, and they are essential to much fine. French cookery. When shallots are ab. solutely unavailable, scallions or green onions (one and the same) may be substituted, but they are a poor substitute.

title: Bail for Lynch Weighed
description: Justice Joseph Suozzi of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn reserved decision on an application by Mel Patrick Lynch to be allowed to go free on bail pending the appeal of his conviction on extortion charges in connection with the alleged kidnapping of Samuel Bronfman. Mr. Lynch's lawyer, Walter J. Higgins, had argued that his client should be granted bail because he needed expert surgery. But Assistant District Attorney Janet Cunard said that Mr. Lynch, Who had made two escape attempts and who was a citizen of Ireland, was a poor bail risk. Justice Suozzi said he would rule in a day or two.

title: CITY IS TOLD TO SHIFT SOME RIKERS INMATES
RADIO
description: Music

title: Jewish Group Cancels Travel Program to France
description: The American Jewish Congress, a human rights organization, has announced the cancellation of its members travel programs to France.

title: Books of The Times
description: JIMMY CARTER and his aides have lots of urgent things to do on the eve of Inauguration Day, but their understanding of what they are getting into may be vastly enlarged if they take time out to read this intimate account of Franklin D. Roosevelt's first year by the liveliest and most assertive member of his original braintrust.

title: All About: Henna, for Hair With a Shine
description: WE SEEM to be heading for a year of redhaired wornen. At a recent fashion show, four out of five of the professional models had hair ranging from light copper to mahogany. Dress designers like red hair because it sets off the creamy colors promised for spring and summer.

title: PROFIT UP SHARPLY FOR 3 MAJOR BANKS IN THE 4TH QUARTER
description: The holding company parents of three major. New York banksCitibank, Chase Manhattan and Bankers Trustyesterday reported sharply, higher earnings for the fourth quarter of last year.

title: SOVIET JEWS CHARGE BORDER HARASSMENT
description: MARCHEGG, Austria, Jan. 16Soon after the travelers from the Soviet Union were on Austrian soil, one of them, Lev Perel, borrowed a piece of paper and, his brows knitted, jotted down some addresses and phone numbers.

title: COLD WAVE CONTINUES TO GRIP EASTERN U.S.
description: Recordbreaking cold struck the entire eastern half of the country again yesterday, with New York City going through seven consecutive hours of 2degree temperatures and the rest of the metropolitan area enduring similar freezes.

title: Proposed Relief Cuts Aimed at least Needy of Needy
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18In proposing welfare and Medicaid spending cuts of nearly $200 million today, Governor Carey and his Social Servides Commissioner, Philip L. Toia, said they were trying to concentrate the hardship on the least needy of a needy population.

description: Capital Cities Communications Inc. has offered to buy the Kansas City Star, publishing company for $125 million. The purchase, if approved, would end 50 years of employee ownership of the company. Page D13

description: WASHINGTON. Jan 19  By the rough index of street addresses in the telephone directory, about twothirds of the 600 odd Carters who already live in the District of Columbia are black.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Federal scientists believe that they have discovered the cause of the mysterious legionnaires disease that killed 29 persons who were in Philadelphia during an American Legion convention there last July.

title: Swiss Wins Cup Downhill As Mrs. Moser Takes a Fall
description: SCHRUNS, Austria, Jan. 18 (AP) Bernadette Zurbriggen of Switzerland wen the World Cup downhill ski race today as the favorite, Annemarie ProellMoser, had a spectacular fall.

title: Cypriot Guilty in Assault
description: A 29yearold Greek Cypriot was found guilty in United States District Court in Manhattan of attempting to kill Bulent Ecevit, a former Turkish Prime Minister, during his appearance at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last July. The jury deliberated less than one hour in finding Stavros Sykopetrides, who called Mr. Ecevit the butcher of Cyprus, guilty of assault and possession of a firearm when he attempted to shoot the minister with a, 25caliber semiautomatic pistol. A State Department agent subdued Mr. Sykopetrides and no shot was fired. Sentencing is scheduled for Feb. 24.

College Basketball

title: INCLUDES $40 MILLION IN ADDED CITY U. AID
description: Governor Carey's proposed $11.3 billion budget is designed to give New York City $68 million it was not expecting to balance its own budget next yearincluding a $40 million increase In state support for the City University of New York.

title: Peter Finch Eulogized at Funeral For Professionalism in Film Roles
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP)More than 220 persons gathered at a funeral service today for Peter Finch, the actor.

title: BREZHNEV APPEALS TO CARTER ON ARMS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18Leonid I. Brezhnev today urged that Presidentelect Carter join him in taking new steps, to further SovietAmerican accommodation, with top priority to winding up the deadlocked strategic arms limitation agreement.

title: Picasso's Heirs Reported In Accord on Division Of $240 Million Estate
description: PARIS, Jan. 18After nearly four years of negotiations, the heirs to the estate of Pablo Picasso, now valued at $240 million, have agreed on how to divide it, according to a reliable source.

title: Living Up to a Legend
description: French cuisine has many grand old men, but it has only one grande dame. She is MarieLouise Point, who prefers to be known as Madame Fernand Point and thus to remain in the shadow of her late husband, the great chef.

title: $3 Billion in Surcharges is Proposed To Help Airlines Reduce Jet Noise
description: President Ford sent to Congress yesterday proposed legislation that would earmark about $3 billion in aviation surcharges to help the airlines replace or modify the 1,600 jets that exceed Federal noise standards.

title: Pro Transactions
description: CALIFORNIA (AL)Signed Mike Cuellar, pitcher.

title: Carey Reassures South on Plans For Aiding Northeast Economy
description: Governor Carey has sent personal letters to all the Governors of the Southern States reassuring them that recent moves to organize the political power of the Northeast to help revive its economy would not be made at the expense of other regions as the South.

title: GREENWICH REJECTS NEW TEACHERS' PACT
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 18The Representative Town Meeting, the local legislative body, last night decisively rejected a teachers contract that had been negotiated after a strike last November. The vote was 118 to 80 with two abstentions.

title: Caso Says Gulotta Relayed Offer of a Judgeship
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 18Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, today identified Frank A. Gulotta, the presiding justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, Second. Department, as the highly placed judge who relayed an offer from the Republican county chairman of a nomination for State Supreme Court if he dropped out of the County Executive race.

title: Sutton, Testing His Mayoral Drive, Asserts Crime Is the Major Problem
description: Coping with crime will be the main test for the next Mayor of New York, Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan said yesterday as he tried out his tobeannounced campaign for the job before directors of the influential Fifth Avenue Association.

title: CREDITPRICE DROP CONTINUES UNABATED
description: The credit market's pronounced drop in prices and rise In interest rates continued unabated yesterday despite the Federal Reserve's decision to purchase Treasury notes and bonds. The climb in interest rates caused the Republic Steel Corporation to postpone $125 million bond sale that had been scheduled for tomorrow. The one brighter spot in the credit markets, from the point of view of investors and bond dealers, was the taxexempt sector. Oregon, Wisconsin and Georgia sold $215 million of highgrade bonds at higher yields, and almost 75 percent of them were reported sold, either to investors or to other dealers.

title: No Conflict Seen in Trips By Vance and Waldheim
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18State Department and United Nations officials said today that they saw no conflict in the fact that both secretary of Statedezignate Cyrus R. Vance and Secretary General Kurt Waldheim planned diplomatic missions to the Middle East next month.

title: It Hurts More After the Crisis
description: Governor Carey's budget message reflects a turn from a lifethreatening emergency to the chronic ache longterm illness. New Yorkers won't know how sick they have been until the medicine starts to hurt.

title: Meadowlands Drivers

title: Zanzibar Is Intent on Preserving Its Autonomy
description: ZANZIBAR, TanzaniaOn Feb. 5, the single political party of this island will merge with the single political party of the Tanzanian mainland in an act intended to symbolize the Integration of the two component parts of the United Republic of Tanzania.

description: PHOENIX, Jan. 18One of Arizona's richest menan archetypical Westerner who made a fortune from the raw land and budding civilization of this frontier stateis in seclusion after being accused in a court document of being the mastermind of a plot to kill Don Bolles, a Phoenix reporter.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Carter administration was authoritatively reported today to be preparing a number of early actions to deal with the deep and worsening fuels shortage, particularly the shortage of natural gas.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Vice President Rockefeller said farewell to the Senate today and received the sentimental accolades at which that body excels.

description: Presentelect Carter yesterday filled three key Treasury jobs in his new Administration and appointed two more members of his Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Memorial Services
description: MELOY  Daniel J. Memorial service Wednesday, January 19th at 4 P.M., St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square, N.Y.C. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Daniel J. Meloy Memorial Fund, Oberlin College, Oberlin, Ohio 44074.

title: Attica Figure's Bid For Parole Denied Despite Clemency
description: Governor Carey's clemency proclamation on Dec. 30 to firmly and finally close the book on the 1971 Attica prison uprising ran into a snag yesterday with the disclosure that the State Board of Parole had denied parole at this time to John Hill, now serving a 20yeartolife term in the fatal beating of a prison guard, William Quinn.

title: 15Member Panel Named To Draft Ethics Code
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)The Senate today established a special 15member committee to draw up a code of ethics for senators.

title: On Disks: Remembrance of Boris Past
description: For those of us who did not hear Chaliapin in the opera house and know his Boris Godunov only from the recorded excerpts, Boris Christoff s demented Czar has been the unchallengeable interpretation. This recording, thrillingly faithful image of the Bulgarian basso's stage performances, was one of the glories of the mono catalogue. When stereo came along in the late 1950's Mr. Christoff rerecorded Boris,for Angel, with Andre Cluytens conducting. The earlier version, now about 20 years old, reappears in amazingly good sound, at about half the price of Angel's stereo album, and proves that remembrances of records past occasionally may be trusted. Mr. Christoff, taking the three bass roles of Boris, Pimen and Varlaam, makes the recording a personal tour de force.

title: EQUAL RIGHTS CHANGE RATIFIED BY INDIANA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Indiana, which refused on two previous occasions to ratify the equal rights amendment to the Constitution, ratified it today. Supporters of the amendment said that the action signaled a break in the long logjam over its adoption.

Mrs. Chisholm Named First Black Woman on House Rules Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Representative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn today became the second woman in memory and the first black woman ever named to a seat cm the influential House Rules Committee.

title: New Yorkers, etc.

Or, as Louise Smith explained the annual auction of the Lenox Hill Neighbor. hood Association: I think a good description is bidding, buying and having a ball. Mrs. Smith, whose husband, Edward Byron Smith, is chairman of the board of the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, was certainly one of those having a good time.

title: Court Asked to Free Man Held in Hearst Inquiry
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Jan. 18The Government made an aboutface in Federal court here today by filing a motion stating that it no longer wanted Phillip Shinnick, 34 years old, of Livingston, N. J., held in prison and in contempt of court in connection with an investigation in the Patricia Hearst case.
