title: Fire Destroys Terminal At Manila Airport
description: MANILA, Wednesday, Jan. 19 (Reuters) The terminal building at Manila's domestic airport burned to the ground during the night. The Philippine Civil Aviation Administration said.; that the blaze; which disrupted domesticflight schedules today, caused at least $3 million'in damage.

title: Oil Barge Freed in Chesapeake
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Jan. 17 (UPI)The Coast Guard Monday freed a barge that ran aground earlier with 840,000 gallons of oil aboard in the Chesapeake Bay northeast of Quantico. The Coast. Guard said no oil leaked from the barge, which appeared to be undamaged.

title: The Sight of Meyerbeer Music
description: The revival of Meyerbeer's oncepopular Le Prophete last night at the Metropolitan Opera is a sign of, the times. In recent years, forgotten operas have, been restaged. Just after World War II, the bel canto operas of Rossini, Donizetti and Bellini came in for a good deal of attention. Now it seems to be the turn of longforgotten Romantic operas.

title: Solar Heating Gets Real Test At New Center
Technology
description: The world's largest ocean liner, the Queen Elizabeth 2, has at least one thing in common with the world's largest semisubmersible offshore oildrilling rig.

title: ENTRIES
House Democrats Elect 21 Chairmen For New Session
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI)House Democrats today elected 21 chairmen for committees of the new 95th Congress. Unlike two years ago, all steering committee nominees were elected.

title: Film: Muscles Galore:Bulging Mystique
description: LIKE THE HUGE LIPS grown by Ubangi women, the startlingly overdeveloped musculature of professional body-builders is apt to seem more of a deformity than an achievement to outsiders.At the least, the body-building mystique as well as its physical results have a good deal of the bizarre about them. As Arnold Schwarzenegger, the best-known of the champions, puts it, "Some people look at you and think it's kind of strange."Mr. Schwarzenegger is the central figure in "Pumping Iron," an interesting, rather slick and excessively long documentary about the small but intensely competitive world of body-building. It opened yesterday at the Plaza Theater.In the picture's first section we see Mr. Schwarzenegger, a handsome man with a body as knotted as an especially lumpy vegetable soup, training, giving exhibitions and talking about his profession.As they practice swelling their muscles and striking posesall the time looking at themselvesthe body-builders have the self-absorbed look of fashion models. In some casesparticularly with one contender, Louis Ferrignothe mournful expression peering out of all those deltoids, triceps and latissima dorsi calls up an image that skitters around a while before it is pinned down.It is, in fact, that of the 90-pound weakling to whom the body-building ads were directed. It is not so much as if the body-builders had become muscular, but as if they had put on great muscle overcoats. The hungry face protrudes from the collar.Or, in the case of Mr. Schwarzenegger, the pleased face. The Austrian-born athlete has become rich from his profession and its spin-offs, is perpetually surrounded by beautiful women, and to cap it all, is a witty if not always convincing exponent of the body-building philosophy.The first thing the outsider realizes, watching the film, is that the object of all that weight-lifting is neither strength nor prowess, but appearance. Mr. Schwarzenegger calls himself a sculptor of his own body. "You look in the mirror and see you need a little more deltoids to make symmetry. So you exercise and put more deltoid on. A sculptor will slap stuff on."The second part of the film is about the world championship contest, held in South Africa, to choose Mr. Olympia.It concentrates particularly on Mr. Schwarzenegger, the titleholder, and Mr. Ferrigno, a principal challenger.The desperate intensity of Mr. Ferrigno, drilled with ferocious concentration by his father, contrasts with the more urbane attitude of the Austrian champion. At one point, Mr. Schwarzenegger practices weightlifting, using two women as barbells.But the appearance is deceptive, Mr. Schwarienegger explains with a candor that seems more appealing than it really isonce you think about ithow he "messes up his opponents." He talks to them. He uses the guarded camaraderie that precedes the competition to play all kinds of one-up games.One of his stories is about the advice he gave to a novice who was competing with him at Munich. He told him that the judges set great store by a theatrical delivery. He suggested that the man scream while doing his poses. Higher screams when the arms were raised. Deep screams when they were lowered."After about four poses they dragged him off," Mr. Schwarzenegger recalls, laughing.Obviously, in the body-building trade it is a question of mind over muscles.The movie is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). There is an occasional expression of the kind one might expect to hear in a weightlifter's training camp or practically anywhere else.

title: News Summary International
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1977

title: Award Is Overturned
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn has set aside a $500,000 medical malpractice award won by Joanne Ward, a 24yearold waitress of Fire Island. Miss Ward had charged that a local physician had failed to treat a slight cut on her finger properly and had thereby caused her to lose parts of several fingers and the use of the hand. The Appellate Division overturned the jury verdict on the ground that the trial judge had excluded testimony about the woman's use of drugs, including LSD, which might have caused the infection to spread, and that he had made errors in his charge to the jury.

title: Plane Scatters Gilmore's Ashes As Utah Begins Return to Normal
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 18Gary Mark Gilmore's ashes were scattered today over the section of Utah where he had arrived as a stranger nine months ago, committed murder and was sentenced to die.

title: Moving Right Along With the Mondales
CARL ZUCKMAYER, 80, SATIRIC PLAYWRIGHT
description: Carl Zuckmayer, a leading Germanborn playwright and author who lived in the United States during World War II, died last night in a hospital in Visp, Switzerland. He was 80 years old and lived near the Swiss village of SaasFee.

title: Ford Links Jobless Cut to Business Spending Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  President Ford told Congress in an economic report today that he was leaving to his successor a reaccelerating economy, but he warned that the country needed faster growth of business spending if unemployment was to be cut.

title: Absence Of War And Peace
description: CAIROAt this stage of prenegotiations, Egypt's President Anwar elSadat takes the line that the expected Middle East conference must produce Israel's withdrawal from the entire area it occupied in the 1967 SixDay War but Israel cannot expect in exchange more than initial acknowledgment of its territorial inviolability (within shorter frontiers).

title: Misconduct by ExMayor Is Alleged in Shanghai
description: SHANGHAI, Jan. 18 (Reuters)Former students in China's largest city are demanding en interview with municipal leaders to discuss their charges of persecution by the purged mayor, Chang Chungchiao. The students have pasted up posters throughout Shanghai describing their ordeal in the northern province of Heilunekiane.

title: Cunningham Dancers
description: EVERYONE GOES Broadway sometime, and last night at the Minskoff Theater it was the turn of Merce Cunningham and, of course, his dance company. He is going to be there only a week, so go quickly or you will not be able to go at all. He is offering evenings of gentle beauty and adventure.

title: Dismal Labor Situation Awaiting Carter
description: Although John T. Dunlop never got his roundtrip ticket from Harvard University back to his old desk as Secretary of Labor in Washington, the Carter administration's structure for restraining wageprice inflation is likely to bear a Dunlop trademark. The incoming Labor Secretary, Ray Marshall, strongly favors an industrybyindustry approach to working out stabilization targets. The mode almost surely would be the joint labormanagement committee that Professor Dunlop used with considerable effectiveness to put a lid on runaway wage increases in the construction industry during the NixonFord years.

title: Coach Goes on Offense
description: NORMAL, Ill., Jan. 18 (AP)John Rauschenberger, defensive line coach at Illinois State University the last two seasons, was named offensive line coach at the school today.

title: RESULTS
description: By The Associated Press

title: Market Place
H.E.W. POSTS INDICATED FOR 2 MINORITY WOMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Two minority group women will be appointed to assistant secretary posts in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, it was reported today.

title: Bias Against Homosexuals Is Outlawed in Miami
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18  The Dade County Commission today gave its final approval to an ordinance that prohibits discrimination against homosexuals in housing, public accommodation and employment. The law takes effect in 10 days.

title: TV: Benny and Barney Stalk Starsky and Hutch
description: ON THE EVE of the inauguration, television, as is its wont, offers a very little something for what broadcasting executives like to think is nearly everybody. The inauguaration will be honored at 9 P.M. with a twoandahalf hour entertainment special carried live and on a delayedtape basis from Washington's John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The incredibly mixed roster of talent includes Lily Tomlin. Stevie Wonder, Clanuna Dale, the National Symphony Orchestra, Chevy Chase. James Dickey and Henry Aaron.

title: DOUGAL HASTON, ALPINIST, DIES IN SWISS AVALANCHE
description: LEYSIN, Switzerland, Jan. 18 (AP)Dougal Haston, a Scottish mountain climber who had scaled some of the world's most formidable peaks including Mt. Everest, died in an avalanche near this Swiss town, the police said today.

title: Balanchine Not Leaving New York City Ballet
description: George Balanchine, artistic director and cofounder of the New York City Ballet, denied yesterday that he was planning to work in Europe because of a musicians strike that closed down the company's winter season.

title: COLD WAVE CONTINUES TO GRIP EASTERN U.S.
News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1977

title: OPERA: Le Prophete Is Revived
description: ON THE PROGRAM it was listed as the 57th Metropolitan Opera performance. Which is accurate, but the. 56th took place about 50 years ago, in 1928. The opera in question is Meyerbeer's Le Prophete, and it was revived last night in a new production by John Dexter, with sets and costumes by Peter Wexler, and conducted by Henry Lewis.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times on Monday about alleged improprieties at a bridge tournament stated that William Eisenberg noticed that a player named Lawrence Cohen seemed to lean forward toward the screen, which was placed diagonally across the bridge table. Mr. Eisenberg declares that, in fact, he did not observe such an action and had no criticism of Mr. Cohen's behavior at any time during the match.

title: Article 1  No Title
Southerners Feeling New Influence in the Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Washington, a Southern town that has always seemed embarrassed about its origins is abruptly embracing its past. There are even cheese grits and candied apples on the luncheon tables of Gaorgetown.

title: Turner, Kuhn Meet on Suspension
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)Ted Turner and a group of Atlanta civic leaders met with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn today to discuss the oneyear suspension imposed on the Braves owner. No decision on a possible change in the suspension will be forthcoming until early next week.

title: 5,000 Are Delayed As 3 Cars on Train Derail in Scarsdale
description: Five thousand rushhour commuters were delayed for three hours last night after the last three cars of a Brewsterbound train derailed at the Scarsdale station shortly before 6 P.M.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: LET IT NOT go unchronicled that on Saturday night the grave gray granite of the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was the scene of great merrymaking. Where learned bishops and theologians ordinarily debate such .weighty matters as intercommunion with the Orthodox Church, the ordination of lesbian priests and reports of heresy, in Westchester, the sounds of lute and recorder and bagpipe were heard, and dancers and tumblers and jugglers performed.

title: One More Pirouette, Please
description: The refusal of the striking orchestra members of the New York City Ballet to accept the settlement proposed by the State Mediation Board has forced the company to cancel its winter season and to consider canceling its spring season, too. If it came to that, this strike could well bring down the curtain on 30 years of struggle by which Lincoln Kirstein and George Balanchine created one of the finest companies in the world in a country with no classical dance tradition.

title: Personal Finance: Buying Homes
description: FOR MANY young couples Just getting started in life, housing prices are absolutely out of sight.

description: SAILING TODAY

title: Navy's Trident Missile Passes 1st Flight Test
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 18The Trident, the Navy's thirdgeneration, submarinelaunched missile, successfully passed its first flight test here today.

title: Vietnam Tiger Cages To Be Tourist Center.
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, Jan. 19 (AP)  The Vietnamese press agency said today that authorities in the southern part of the country were turning the former prison colony of Con Son Island into a center for Vietnamese and foreign tourists.

title: People in Sports
description: Chris Dundee, who held exclusive rights to promote fights in Miami Beach for the last. 25 years, was fined $500 by the Miami Beach Boxing Cont mission yesterday and agreed to give up those rights. Dundee's permit was originally revoked last Nov, 25, but that action was overruled because Dundee was not notified and was not present at that hearing He was no present at yesterday's meeting either, but was represented by au attorney Dundee is the brother of Angelo Dundee, the trainer of Muhammad Ali.

title: Careers
description: An increasing number of helpwanted advertisements bear the cryptic abbreviations EDP, EDP program management and MIS. At least, these are cryptic to persons not familiar with computer technolony.

title: S.I. Transit Workers Return After Walkout
description: The Staten Island Rapid Transit system returned to full operation yesterday afternoon as workers returned to their jobs following a walkout that had shut down the line Monday morning. All trains were reported running on schedule during last night's rushhour, a, welcome relief to the 9,000 commuters who had been forced to use crowded busses and car pools.

title: 3 Missing in Breakup of Tanker
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 18 (AP)Three crewmen were reported missing today following the breakup of a Greekowned oil tanker, Irenes Challenger, about 220 miles southeast of Midway Island in the Pacific.

title: Bridge:
description: When bridge experts register for tournaments, they often use the familiar forms of their given names by which they are known to other players.

title: Winter's Epicurean Bargain
Thousands of Coastal Waterfowl Starving to Death in Cold Wave
Child's World
Article 5  No Title
7 South African Miners Killed
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 18 (AP)Falling rock caused by an earth tremor yesterday killed seven black miners and trapped 48 others nearly a mile underground, officials said today. Black and white workers formed a chain to free the 48 men at the Hartebeestfontein gold mine about 100 miles west of Johannesburg. Two miners are still missing.

title: Modular Seating Is a LUVely Way to Conserve Space
description: Modular seatingthose big, deep, squooshy, squarish single units of upholstered funiture that you string together to form seating arrangements has soared in popularity in the few years it's been in stores.

title: Old Hand With New Power
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18When Jim Delaney first took his seat in Congress, Franklin D. Roosevelt was preparing to go to Yalta, the atom bomb was still to be dropped on Hiroshima, and Archie Bunker, like television itself, was something for the future to reckon with. That the was in January 1945. Today an eon later, through the slowgrinding mills of the seniority system, New Yort's James J.Delaneywho will be 76; years old in Marchwas elected by the Democratic majority, 187 to 46; to the powerful chairmanship of the Hou e Rules Committee.

title: Neediest Gifts Given a Boost By a Tradition
description: Several letters received yesterday and also on Dec. 18 in the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund made reference to a significant Jewish tradition.

title: Dollar More Stable In European Trade
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 18 (UPI)The dollar firmed on most European money markets today, apparently influenced by increases in United States shortterm interest rates. The pound gained on the dollar, despite Bank of England intervention that held the rate of gain down.

title: Audits in Jersey Confirm State Made DayCare Overpayments
21 Soccer Coaches From Brazil Giving 2 Weeks of Advice in U.S.
description: Twentyone professional soccer coaches from Brazil started a twoweek tour of the United States on Monday, giving clinics and offering technical advice to coaches and players in 11 regions.

title: Sharif Khan Is Upset
description: Sharif Khan of Pakistan was upset by Heddy Jahan of Pakistan, 79, 108, 79, 109, in a Boodles International Challenge squash racquets match at the Uptown Tennis Club yesterday. In the other challenge match Victor Niederhoffer defeated Mohibullah Khan of Pakistan, 1510, 1115, 1513, 1816.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures.
description: Tuesday, January 18, 1977

title: PAUL NORDOFF, COMPOSER AND A MUSIC THERAPIST
description: Paul Nordoff, American composer and music therapist, died yesterday of cancer in a clinic in Herdecke, West Germany. He was 67 years old.

title: Corporation Affairs
Richard and Vorster Hold Crucial Talks On Rhodesia Today
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 18Ivor Richand of Biitain, chairinan of the Geneva conference on Rhodesia, flew to Soyth Africa tonight for a meeting with prime Minister. John Vorster that is widely viewed as a makeorbreak attempt to revive the stalled negotiations for a transition to black majority rule in Rhodesia.

title: HIGH COURT IN ALBANY BACKS PAYTOILET BAN
description: The constitutionality of a New York State law banning pay toilets was upheld yesterday by the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

title: Carter Nominees Reassure Mayors About Concern for Urban Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The mayors of more than 125 major American cities, convening here in the capital just two days before Jimmy Carter's inauguration, received strong assurances today that urban problems would get top priority from the new administration.

title: TERUYOSHI TASAKA
description: TOKYO, Jan. 18 (AP)Teruyoshi Tasaka, president of the Nippon Steel Corporation, died today in a Tokyo hospital at the age of 68. He had been president of the company, the world's largest steel producer, since last June.

title: Busing Plan for Cleveland Sent to Federal Court
description: COLUMBUS; Ohio, Jan. 18 (UPI)The state Board of Education sent to Federal court today a proposal for desegregating the schools of Cleveland, the nation's eighthlargest city, by busing. The board said it neither embraced nor opposed the plan.

title: High Court Grapples With 2 Views In Dispute on Lawyer Advertising
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Justices of the Supreme Court, lawYers all, struggled with obvious concern and occasional humor today to decide. whether lawyers should be allowed to advertise: For the Justices it was a complicated question; involving the First Amendment, free competition and the possibility that some lawyers might produce ads that mislead the public.

title: Moynihan Backs 3 G.O.P. Officials
description: Breaking with tradition, Senator Daniel P. Moynihan announced yesterday that he would recommend that three Republicanappointed United States attorneys in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Buffalo continue in office under the Carter Administration.

title: The U.N. Today
Pentagon Orders Development of 2 Cruise Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Defense Department today authorized development of two strategic versions of the cruise missile in an action that could influence the next round of strategic arms talks with the Soviet Union.

title: GAS COMPANY'S VIEW ON TANKERS OPPOSED
description: SALEM, Jan. 18The New Jersey Public Advocate challenged, at a Nuclear Regulatory Commission hearing today, a contention by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company that groundings of liquefiednaturalgas tankers in the Delaware River could not spill flammable gas near the huge nuclear power plant utilities building here.

title: Income Tax Credits Proposed in Budget
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18Following is table showing the credit that taxpayers would receive on their state income tax under Governor Carey's budget proposal. The income figures reflect total adjusted gross income. The repeal proposed by the Governor of the 2.5 percent incometax surcharge would affect all taxpayers regardless of income.

title: Outlays Proposed For Top Agencies
description: Following are Governor Carey's proposed appropriations (in thousands of dollars) for state departments that spend in excess of $1 million:

title: SCRANTON CONFIDENT U.N. HAS MELLOWED
description: UNITED NATIONS,N.Y., Jan. 18William W. Scranton left the United Nations today, apparently confident that his 10 months as the United States representative coincided with a reversal of fortunes for American diplomacy in the international organization.

title: Carter Son Ousted by Navy in 1970
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Jan. 18Presidentelect Jimmy Carter and Pentagon spokesmen today confirmed reports that his oldest son, Jack Carter, was discharged from the Navy in 1970 for smoking marijuana.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Now, Kissinger Woos His Critics
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18As Henry A. Kissinger's term expires, he has been closing out the public record with a round of farewell lunches and dinners. He has used these usually routine affairs to say some unusual things, trying to make peace in the last days with some of the groups with which his relationship has been most uneasy during his tenure as Secretary of State.

title: Budget Rise Lowest Of the Last 12 Years
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18 (UPI)Goyernor Carey's proposed $11.345 billion state budget for the 197778 fiscal year, a $324 million increase in state spending, is the smallest rise in state budgets in 12 years.

title: COURT UPHOLDS EVIDENCE FROM ILLEGAL WIRETAP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)The Supreme Court ruled today that some evidence gathered from a secret wiretap that is technically illegal can be used in criminal trials.

title: Columbia's Winning Streak Ended at Five by Lafayette
description: Columbia University's basketball team was beaten last night by Lafayette, 9174, in Levien Gymnasium, ending the Lions' fivegame winning streak.

title: Carter Said to Choose Linowitz as Canal Negotiator
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Presidentelect Carter will appoint Sol M. Linowitz, former ambassador to the Organization of American States, to the United States team negotiating a new canal treaty with Panama, Latin American diplomats reported today.

title: Utilities Face New Cutbacks in Natural Gas
description: TRENTON, Jan. 13The major supplier of natural gas to New Jersey informed the state's major utilities today that gas supplies, which were cut back 35 percent yesterday, leading the Governor to declare a gas emergency, would be reduced an additional 10 percent tomorrow.

title: Ford, G.M. Agree To Install Air Bags In Some 1979 Cars
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)William T. Coleman Jr., Secretary of Transportation, said today that two Detroit auto makers had agreed to sell air bags on half a million cars in a twoyear period starting in late 1979.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
Handicapped Woman, 84, Robbed, Man, 68, Assaulted by 2 in Queens
description: Two armed youths, after breaking into a house in Queens on Monday and robbing an 84yearold handicapped woman of $35, went upstairs, robbed a 68yearold man of $60 and his watch and, before leaving, pushed his head into the toilet bowl and flushed it, according to the police and court reports.

title: Beame Reportedly Intends to Ask Hospitals Board For a No Confidence Vote Removing Holloman
description: Mayor Beame intends to ask the board of directors of the Health and Hospitals Corporation to vote no confidence in Its president, Dr. John L. S. Holloman, Jr., a Beame aide said yesterday.

title: 200 Performers Hold A Rally for Housing At Manhattan Plaza
Fighting Saints Again Fighting Time
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 18The future of the Minnesota Fighting Saints remained uncertain today after trustees of the troubled World Hockey Association franchise asked for time to sell the club to local interests in St. Paul. They were given until 11 P.M. Thursday, Eastern standard time, to find a buyer.

title: Washington, a Black City With Problems, Awaits Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 19  By the rough index of street addresses in the telephone directory, about twothirds of the 600odd Carters who already live in the District of Columbia are black.The demography of the old Carters is a message to the new ones, the 39th President and his family. Their homes are in the predominantly black neighborhoodsnever seen by tourists and only peripherally noticed by commuters to white Maryland and Virginia suburbsthat sprawl over about threefourths of this city's 61 square miles, making it the most black metropolis in the Northern Hemisphere.

title: Hot Boy on the Coldest Day
description: In the first race Steve Cauthen was on a mare named Passa a Nice Day, who hadn't passed many horses recently. The hottest apprentice jockey New York has seen in years had set a record by riding 23 winners last week, five on Wednesday, five Friday and five Saturday. Now it was Monday, the coldest day of the year, and in subfreezing weather 7,467 immortal souls attended devotions at Aqueduct. Nobody could say exactly how many had come to pray for Master Cauthen, but the number was big enough to bet four of his eight mounts into favoritism. In the stretch, Cauthen brought of Passa a Nice Day out of the pack into third place but she tired and was beaten for show by Sweet Dixie Darlen. The winner's time of 1:15 for six furlongs told something about the racing conditions and the class horges racing.

title: New York City's Schools Accused Of U.S. CivilRights Violations
description: The United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare charged yesterday that the New York City school system had violated Federal civilrights laws by discriminating against minority, female and handicapped pupils.

title: Mr. Nixon's 1977 Farewell Message On the Accomplishments of 2 Terms
description: IGHT YEARS ago, on a freezing cold day, I stood outside this chamber and took the oath of office as your President. That was a proud moment for me, the beginning of an attempt to scale what General Eisenhower called the windy and dangerous slopes leading to excellence. Today, as I take my leave, is also a proud moment, as I report to you on the State of the Union, as I see it. It is a proud moment because I can sum up the most important accomplishments of this Administration in two magnificent words: peace and freedom. America is at peace with herself and with the world, and that is a legacy that I am proud to leave my successor.

title: The Question Of Judgment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The main question about the Sorensen affair is why Mr. Carter chose him for this particular job in the first place. It is a question not of Ted Sorensen's character but of Mr. Carter's judgment, and this remains a puzzle though Mr. Sorensen has made a characteristically eloquent and graceful withdrawal.

title: 2 Men Found Dead in Icy Rooms Of a West Side Residence Hotel
description: Two elderly men were found dead from exposure to cold yesterday afternoon in their icy rooms in a residence hotel on Amsterdam Avenue, just a block north of City College on the Upper West Side.

title: Lowly No More The Time of the Peanut
HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York limes Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: CAREY'S BUDGET URGES MAJOR WELFARE CUTS, SOME TAX REDUCTIONS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18Governor Carey proposed an $11.345 billion New York State budget today that calls for major cuts in welfare and Medicaid, along with a revised formula that would reduce local school aid to many districts.

title: THOUSANDS IN EGYPT RIOT OVER PRICE RISE
description: CAIRO, Jan. 18 (Reuters)Thousands of Egyptian students and workers stormed through central Cairo and other cities today in an outburst of anger over price increases ordered by the Government on a wide range of goods.

title: Dayton Is Freezing to a Halt
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 18By early this afternoon, the downtown streets of this weatherlocked city were as empty of cars as the sidewalks were of people.

title: PRODUCTION GROWTH IN U.S. IS QUESTIONED Ford's Economic Advisers Find Output Capacity Has Been Less Than What Was Figured
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  President Ford's Council of Economic Advisers, in a new analysis, decided today thatthe nation's capacity to produce has been growing less than had been believed.

title: Cold Wave? It's Simply Lack Of Variation in Fluctuation
description: CAMP SPRINGS, Md., Jan. 18When Dr. Donald L. Gilman was late to work the other day because his car would not start in the subzero cold, he was not as displeased as many other motorists were when they encountered the same problem

title: Train From France Burns in Spain
description: ZARAGOZA, Spain, Jan. 18 (AP)A FrancetoMadrid train caught fire at dawn today as it passed through a tunnel. Four coaches were destroyed, but the 149 passengers and the crew escaped unhurt, railroad officials reported.

title: 3 Alarm Fire in Far Rockaway
description: A threealarm fire heavily damaged the Century Supermarket, the Coastline Pharmacy and Mr. Harry's French Cleaners at Beach 49th Street and Beach Channel Drive in Far Rockaway, Queens, last night. The fire followed an explosion of unknown cause in the drugstore, the police said. No injuries ware reported.

title: American Motors Renewing Loans
description: DETROIT, Jan. 18The financially troubled American Motors Corporation will have its $63 million in shortterm loans renewed by the end of this month, Roy D. Chapin Jr., the company's chairman, said today.

title: Gold
description: By The Associated Press

title: Personal Health
description: THE FEELING is familiar to most everyonenothing seems satisfying, things don't work out, you can't get yourself to do much of anything and your mental landscape is bleak. It's called depression, add few of us get through life without experiencing it at one time or another.

title: Moynihan Backs 3 G.O.P. Officials
People and Business
description: Thatababy! exclaimed Aristotle [Telly] Savalas. Bofflor put politelyconservative clothes with a flair, he added. That's what we'll be offering.

title: Monday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press

title: Verbal Agreements Cited by Catcher
description: Thurman Munson, the American League's most valuable player, and the Yankees have become embroiled in a contract dispute that could have a devastating effect on the team's chances to repeat as league champions next season.

title: RIGHTS PANEL RAISES JOB SENIORITY ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Declaring that the recent recession has played havoc with the economic gains of minorities and women, the United States Commission on Civil Rights called today for Federal guidelines that would end the last hired, first fired practice that employers traditionally follow in laying off workers.

title: Fashion Puts Legs Out in Open Again
description: Fashion's leg show, which was abruptly canceled when the women of the world took to pants, is on its way back. The miniskirt or dressofficially banished from high fashion circles is 1970has been considered the property of airline stewardesses and middle America.

title: Excerpts From the Message by Governor Carey in Presenting the 197778 Budget
Dow Falls 4.82 in Heavier Trading On News of Slower G.N.P. Growth
Handicapping the Arms Race
description: Speaking of the C.I.A. (as we were yesterday in connection with the affair Sorensen) we are still perplexed by the manner in which that once proudly independent agency allowed itself to be drawn into an open debate about the size and shape of the American strategic defense effort.

title: Wherein Britannia Finds Something to Hail
description: American reporting about Britain's economy is reflecting a new optimism about our prospects. World confidence in Britain has been shown by the International Monetary Fund's decision to help the country over its shortterm. difficulties and by the agreement among central banks on sterling balances. These were only possible because Britain could convince the world that it has a stable, prosperous and free future.

title: Article 3  No Title
Living Abroad: West Berlin
Article 8  No Title
description: FRISTY AND FRIEZE Tessie O'Shea, of Britain's music halls and recently Broadway's Something's A foot, singsand plays the banjotoday in the weekly Interlude program at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The bar opens at 5 P.M., showtime is 5:45 P.M., with a $3 admission.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The International airport nearby was not affected and there were no reports of casualties.

title: Witnesses Warn Against Any Cuts In Mail Service as Hearings Open
A TurnipCabbage in One
description: Perhaps one of the least recognized hut most interesting vegetable now in local markets is kohlrabi, the waxy, fadegreen bulb topped with its flurry or cabbagelike leaves.

title: S.I. Bank Held Up
description: Four bandits held up the First National Bank branch at 2239 Forest Avenue, Mariner's Harbor, S. I., and escaped with $28,000. They were armed with a rifle, shotgun and two handguns. While two of the robbers held employees and customers at bay, their two accomplices took the money from cashiers drawers.

title: Soviet Signs a Contract With Philippines to Buy 600,000 Tons of Sugar
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (AP)The Soviet Union has signed a contract with the Philippines for delivery of 600,000 metric tons of sugar in the first six months of 1977, Soviet officials said today.

title: Private Lives
description: WE GAVE a dinner party. It was for a distinguished artist in his middle years, a refugee from marital wars, suddenly displaced and wanting companionship. The idea of the dinner party was to introduce him to several intelligent and charming women who happened at the moment to be unattached. It was probably a stupid idea, but most of my friends in this city are intelligent and charming women who happen at the moment to be unattached, and I can only marry one at a time.

title: Soviet Opens Olympic Door To 3 Networks
description: An official of the Soviet Union's Olympic Organizing Committee said yesterday that his nation was ready to resume talks with the three major American networkt over the sale of broadcast rights to the 1980 Summer Games in Moscow.

title: Article 7  No Title
Bijedic, Yugoslav Prime Minister, Is Killed in Crash of Executive Jet
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 18Prime Minister Dzemal Bijedic was killed with his wife, Razija, today when the executive jet in which they were flying crashed near Sarajevo.

title: State U. at Stony Brook Receives Campus Construction Assurance
description: STONY BROOK, LI., Jan. 18The State University chancellor, Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, today gave John S. Toll, president of the university's Stony Brook campus, what he wanted mosta commitment for the eventual completion of the university center on Long Island's North Shore.

title: England Leads Cricket Test
description: MADRAS, India, Jan. 18 (Reuters)Derek Underwood, a leftarm spinner finding a successful streak In the final overs of the day, left England firmly placed for victory, over India in the third cricket test, and for an unbeatable 30 lead in the fivematch series here today. Underwood took three wickets in 10 balls without conceding a run to leave India with virtually no hope of saving the match or the series. Earlier in the day, England declared its second innings at 185 runs for nine wickets with one day to play, India had 45 runs for three wickets after being set 284 to win.

title: Article 9  No Title
Satellite Business Approved by F.C.C
description: A new type of satellite data network that could alter the structure of the nation's communications industry was approved yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Chess:
description: The two Middle East countries that have recently made the most progress are Israel and Iran. Israel has benefited from the influx of emigres from the Soviet Union, principally Grandmaster Vladimir Liberzon and International Master Roman Dzindzikashvili, formerly Viktor Kprchnoi's match second. Moreover, Israel now boasts a homegrown grandmaster, Yair Kraidman, who was confirmed at the International Chess Federation meeting in Haifa in September.

title: 4 New TV Networks Being Discussed
description: Efforts are under way on several fronts to create limited national television networks this year to compete with ABC. CBS and NBC in prime time. The proposed new program services would operate on parttime schedules and would use as their foundation the stations not affiliated with an existing commercial network.

title: Tolls on East River Bridges Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that New York City, to clean up its air, must carry out a controversial transportation control plan that includes imposing tolls on bridges across the East and Harlem Rivers.

title: Hialeah Slated to Open March 8 After Florida Approves of Sale
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Jan. 18Across the. streat from the palmlined entrance to Hialeah Park, an unfinished condominiurn displays a sign that reads: Coming Soon! Lack of capital halted construction on the project in 1975, and no work has been done on it since then.

title: Who's Being Roasted?
description: An unfortunate fringe effect of the oil price crisis that it has given devil theories a good name. Let there be an imagined shortage in toilet paper or a real jump in the price of sugar and we have been schooled to assume, darkly, a conspiracy. Now we have the Great Coffee Crisis and with it, an instant supposed villain, profiteering in Brazil, which produces half the world's supply.

title: 60 Minute Gourmet
description: ONE OF THE best, most easily made and least costly of fine dishes is the one known in France as escalopes de veau viennoise. Escalopes de veau are simply scaloppine of veal. Viennoise means in the style of Vienna, and the dish is the French version of wiener schnitzel.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times on Monday about alleged improprieties at a bridge tournament stated that William Eisenberg noticed that a player named Lawrence Cohen seemed to lean forward toward the screen, which was placed diagonally across the bridge table. Mr. Eisenberg declares that, in fact, he did not observe such an action and had no criticism of Mr. Cohen's behavior at any time during the match.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHTS GAMES

title: Seton Hall Trounces Fordham
description: Glenn Mosley, the mainstay of the Seton Hall Pirates, thought maybe he tried a little WO hard last night in his team's easy 7257 victory over Fordham at the Rams Rose Hill gymnasium.

title: ENTRIES
description: Horses listed in order of post positions

title: Inaugural Events Open on a Cold but Happy Note
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18As icy winds knifed through the capital, the fiveday inaugural celebration for Presidentelect Jimmy Carter began this morning on a quietly ebullient note.

title: Agent's Know how a Key In Cauthen's Successes
description: If you're selling garbage cans, you've got to have the best garbage cans, said Lenny Goodman. That's the way I look at it.

title: Toms River School Band Is on the March to Washington
2 Makers of Citrus Concentrates Bar Orders as Cold Hurts Crop
description: Two of the nation's major citrus juice producers yesterday halted all new orders for orange and grapefruit juice concentrates as subfreezing temperatures continued to cause serious damage in Florida's citrus belt.

title: People in Sports
description: Kenny Stabler, the quarterback who led the Oakland Raiders to victory over the Minnesota Vikings in Super Bowl XI, and Tony Dorsett, the allAmerica running back for the nationalchampion University of Pittsburgh, were in Philadelphia yesterday to receive Maxwell awards as the outstanding pro and college football players of the Year.

title: Mrs. Kreps to Encourage Business To Stress Contributions to Society
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Juanita M. Kreps, the Secretary of Commercedesignate, will try to use her new position to create a new era, in which corporations would boast of how much they had spent on socially desirable activities and corporate executives would be esteemed by shareholders and their peers for the same reason.

title: Haig Says Soviet Retains Hope of AWar Victory
description: BRUSSELS. Jan. 19 (AP)Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., commander of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in Europe, says a reported emphasis by the Soviet Union oncivil defense means that the Soviet leadership has not abandoned the concept of Victory in .a nuclear war.

title: Only 1% of Birds Killed Were Harmful to Crops
description: MILAN, Tenn., Jan. 19 (UPI)Starlings, which are responsible for 99 percent of crop damage and seedtheft, made up only I percent of the 500,000 to 1 millions birds killed in a massive spraying last week, a Government expert said today.

title: Parents to Sue L.I. School District Because Son, 18, Is Barely Literate
description: LINDENHURST, L.I.The parents of a 1976 graduate of Copiague High School plan to sue the local school district for $5 million because, they charge, their son can barely read or write, even though he was awarded a diploma.

title: AUTO OUTPUT IS EXPECTED TO RISE 1.7% IN WEEK
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Move to Acquire Pickwick Is Made By American Can
description: The American Can Company announced in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday that it was proposing to acquire Pickwick International, a leading distributor of records, tapes and accessories, for about $101 million. American Can said that it would pay $23 a share for Pickwick's 4.4 million out standing common shares. It said also that it would operate Pickwick as a separate subsidiary with Pickwick'ts present management.

title: For Summer, the Soft Touches That Add Up to a Gentle Look
description: A delicate edge of scalloping around a camisole. A tiny silver border on tiered pants. An embroidered eyelet ruffle on a madras plaid skirt.

title: England Defeats India In Cricket Test Match
description: MADRAS, India, Jan. 19 (Reuters)England clinched its cricket series against India today by taking the last six Indian wickets in 80 minutes to win the third test match by 200 runs. The victory gave England a 30 lead in the fivematch series after earlier victories by an innings and 25 runs in New Delhi, and by 10 wickets in Calcutta. It is the first time that England has won three test matches in India and only the second time it has won a series here.

title: Dock Idled by Strike
description: Watchmen went on strike yesterday at the passenger ship terminal at 55th Street and the Hudson River to protest a reduction in jobs by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Longshoremen refused to pass the picket lines of the Independent Watchmen's Association.

title: CAIRO EASES PRICES, BUT RIOTING GOES ON
description: CAIRO, Thursday, Jan. 20President Anwar elSadat, after a second day of widespread rioting and increasing casualties, canceled price increases yesterday for food, cooking fuel and other products, which had touched off the violence.

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTONThe chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee initiated this week the always difficult task of fashioning a new farm bill with a conciliatory gesture aimed at the many conflicting interests that must find a common ground before any such measure can be enacted.

title: Smallpox Outbreak In Somalia Hurts Eradication Effort
description: GENEVA, Jan. 18A smoldering outbeak of smallpox in the East African country of Somalia has set back the World Health Organization's program to eradicate the viral disease from the world, but an official of the health agency here today expressed optimism that the disease would become extinct this month.

title: U.S. Jewish Leader Tells Of Planned Trip to Cairo
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 19 (Reuters)Philip M. Klutznik, an American Jewish leader, said here today he would head a delegation of wellknown Jews to Cairo for talks with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt.

title: 10 Million Hindu Pilgrims Bathe In Holiest Spot of River Ganges
description: ALLAHABAD, India, Jan. 19Ten million Hindus bathed in the holiest spot of the holy River Ganges here today, in joyful celebration of what the Indians say is the largest religious festival in the world.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Surprise Call for Elections
Tug's Crew Scrambles Ashore As Ice Sinks the Boat in L.I. Sound
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 19 (AP)A tugboat being used in a dredging operation in icecluttered Long Island Sound sprang a leak and sank early. today.

title: International Tin Agreement Reported Near Collapse
description: LONDON, Jan. 19  A harmonious model for protecting developed and third world countries from the feastandfamine perils of sharp price changes of raw materials is near collapse.

title: Young American String Quartet Plays With Energy
description: When the American String Quartet walked out on the stage of the Mannes College of Music's concert hall on Tuesday night, it looked as though Mannes might be introducing a student group, rather than its quartet in residence. The players are in their 20's and, at a distance, looked younger than that.

title: Spanish Government Will Grant Some Concessions to Basques
description: MADRID, Jan. 19 (AP)The Government said today it would make some concessions to the two Basque provinces of northwestern Spain, restoring privileges taken away by Generalissimo Francisco Franco because they fought against him in the Spanish Civil War. But it will leave decisions on other demands made by the provinces to the new parliament that will be chosen in elections in June.

title: Water Detected Outside Earth's Galaxy, Hinting Life
description: BONN, Jan. 19 (UPDAstronomers have found the presence of water outside the Earth's galaxy for the first time, indicating the possibility of life in outer space, the Max Planck Institute of Astronomy said today.

title: 1976 INFLATION RATE LOWEST IN 4 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Consumer prices, up a modest fourtenths of 1 percent in December, showed the lowest rate of inflation in 1976 of any year since 1972, the Labor Department reported today.

title: A Federal Jury Indicts Immigrant From Russia On Two Counts of Spying
description: NEWARK, Jan. 19Ivan N. Rogalsky, the 34yearold Russian immigrant who was arrested two weeks ago on spy charges, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here this morning on two counts of espionage and one count of obtaining national defense information for transmittal to the Soviet Union, according to Jonathan L. Goldstein, the United States Attorney.

title: Trippe's Progeny Carry On For RecordSettingBeagle
description: The story of Trippe. the nation's highest winning breed dog the greatest beagle in history, had its start when a girl of 11 decided to show a Kerry blue terrier in Winetka, Ill., a number of years ago. But Marcia Foy's territorial horizons spread far beyond her hometown and by the early 70's she was exhibiting at 125 shows coast to coast each year. However, the long hours on the road paid off handsomely for the amateur handler when her No. 1 beagle, Ch. King's Creek Triple Threat, went best of variety 396 times, eclipsing the record of 323 set by Radar, a white bull terrier champion.

title: PowerLine Project Has Man North Country People Boiling
description: FORT COVINGTON, N.Y., Jan. 18Here in the bitter cold of the North Country, Where people have traditionally tended to Republican conservatism, to obeying the rules, to trust in government and to not rocking the boat, the residents gather angrily now in taverns, and in bookshops, before kitchen stoves in remote farmhouses and sometimes in the swirling snowfarmers, engineers, teachers, pensioners, shopkeepers, housewives and even Indians from a nearby reservation. They gather to vent their anger against the Power Authority of the State of New York.

title: Grant Engineers Success at Manhattan
description: Steve Grant was nothing more than a skinny kid who plays fair basketball, according to one Columbia scouting report on the 6foot4inch senior at Bronx High School of Science, So Columbia coaches filed their Grant report and forgot him.

title: Sittler Sidelined 24 Weeks
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Jan. 19 (AP)The Toronto Maple Leafs' captain, Darryl Sittler, has been told by doctors he will be out of action from two to four weeks with torn rib cartilage, a Leafs' spokesman said today.

title: Black Mississippi Town Asked to Take Grant Cut
description: Officials of the allblack, Mississippi Delta town of Mound Bayou are balking at a request by a lameduck Assistant Secretary of Commerce to reduce an approved public works grant from $4.9 million to $2.8 million.

title: 1976 INFLATION RATE LOWEST IN 4 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Consumer prices, up a modest fourtenths of 1 percent in December, showed the lowest rate of inflation in 1976 of any year since 1972, the Labor Department reported today.

title: AutoTrain to Continue Service Over Route Canceled by Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)The AutoTrain Corporation said today that it would continue to offer service between Louisville, Ky., and Sanford, Fla., even though Amtrak, which hauls the AutoTrain cars, has temporarily halted service on the route.

title: Federal Government Grants $2.9 Million to Build Fulton Street Mall
description: The Federal Mass Transit Administration granted $2.9 million yesterday for the construction of the first phase of the Fulton Street mall project along Brooklyn's major shopping thoroughfare.

title: Another Beautiful Day for Mr. Cub
description: In his 19 seasons with the Chicago Cubs, the phrase never changed. It's a beautiful day for a ball game, Ernie Banks would say. It's such a beautiful day, let's play two. Or when a doubleheader was scheduled, let's play three. Even on a cold foggy night at Roosevelt Stadium during a postseason barnstorming tour, he said, It's a beautiful night for a ball game. And for Ernie Banks, yesterday was beautiful. Especially yesterday. Outside, the midtown temperature at 11 o'clock in the morning was 17 degrees, almost a heat wave by comparison with the recent weather. But inside, under crimson drapes and in front of a crimson backdrop, Ernie Banks stood behind a lectern on a small stage in the Royal Ballroom of the Americana as the newest member of Baseball's Itall of Fame. Tall and straight and slim, Ernie Banks was wearing a beige glen plaid suit, a blue shirt, an orange and brown tie and his best smile. When he wakes up in the morning, Ernie Banks always puts on that smile before anything else.

title: Legion Disease Microbes Studied For Links to Pneumonia Outbreaks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Federal scientists are beginning to explore the possibility that the strange microbes linked to legionnaires disease are a more general although hitherto unknown cause of pneumonia in humans.

title: N. Texas Seeks League Bid
description: DENTON, Tex., Jan. 19 (AP)The athletic council of North Texas State University unanimously approved a resolution today to seek admission to the Southwest Conference. There are currently nine S.W.C. member; including Houston, which joined the conference five years ago.

title: Latest Vermont Ski Report Says All Lifts Are Excellent
description: PERU, Vt., Jan, 19Fred Harvey, one of Vermont's two liftsafety inspectors, disclosed a surprising statistic today at sunny Bromley Mountain. Few skiers even suspect how safe ski transportation actually is, said Harvey, a former construction superintendent and craneoperating engineer who has been inspecting lifts in the state for 10 years. Last winter, ewe had 260 accidents in the state in connection with our lifts and, tows. But we probably had more than 95 million exposures to the rides during that time, he continued. That means our accident percentage came to approximately an infinitesimal thiee tenthousandths of 1 percent. Remember, some of those accidentsand I'm not talking about injuries suffered on slopesincluded all the sprained ankles or perhaps ropetow hand burns.

title: ADM. DANIEL GALLERY, LED UBOAT CAPTURE
description: BETHESDA, Md.; Jan. 19 (AP)Rear Adm. Daniel V. Gallery, U.S.N., retired, who commanded aircraft carriers and wrote eight books on Navy life, died Sunday at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center. He was 75 .years old and lived in Oakton, Va.

title: Police Pact Still at Issue
description: Douglas D. Weaving; president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, met with Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd, but they failed to resolve the amnesty issue that has become a block to a contract agreement with the city.

title: PRAYER GATHERINGS GREET INAUGURATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Ruth Carter Stapleton, sister of the incoming President, stood quietly today among 50 worshipers from various faiths. on the west steps of the Capitol for a service of prayer that was indicative of the deep religious aspects of this inauguration.

title: Laura Hunt Waldron Wed To Peter Stevens, Student
description: Laura Hunt Waldron and Peter Heise Stevens were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Waldron of Hightstown, N. J. The Rev. Wallace M. Alston, pastor of the Nassau Presbyterian Church, in Princeton, N. J., performed the ceremony.

title: Hopeful Carter in Capital, Ford Busy To The End
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Jimmy Carter arrived today in Washington to become the 39th President of the United States tomorrow, saying he hoped to achieve greatness not through war or crisis but through steady, exciting progress for the country.

title: N.C. State 75, North Carolina 73
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 19 (APKenny Carr scored on a lob pass from Charles Whitney with 19 seconds remaining, then blocked a shot by North Carolina's Phil Ford in leading North Carolina State to a 7573 upset of the fourthranked Tar Heels tonight in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: Christen Says U.S. Report Citing School Bias May Be a Disservice
description: The president of the New York City Board of Education, Dr. Robert J. Christen, yesterday criticized as a disservice a Federal report charging the school system with discrimation against minority, female and handicapped pupils.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on conflicts of interest in sports on Jan. 8 incorrectly reported that Teleprompter had lent money to Roy Boe, owner of the New York Nets, to help save his basketball franchise. The money was lent by Home Box Office. William Jennings, president of the Rangers, was incorrectly identified as a Teleprompter board member rather than as a former board member.

title: MIDWEST FEELS BITE OF A FROZEN MONTH
description: CHICAGO, Jan. I9Nearly a month of record low temperatures throughout the sprawling industrial crescent around the Great Lakes has brought pain and disComfort to thousands, disrupted their living patterns and cut cruelly into their spending power.

title: BOND PRICES CHANGE DIRECTION AND GAIN
description: Bond prices rose for a change yesterday in a fairly brisk recovery that stemmed partly from the Federal Reserve's purchase of notes and bonds on Tuesday and partly also to news that the Consumer Price Index showed Its smallest DecembertoDecember rise in tour years. In this,atmosphere the Treasury sold $2.5 billion of twoyear notes at an average rate of 5.97 percent, sharply higher than the 5.37 percent it accepted only one month ago but slightly lower than the 6 percent dealers expected late Tuesday afternoon.

title: Excerpts From Interview With Kissinger: Eight Years in Washington Evaluated
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Following are excerpts from an interview with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger:

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS TO GET $730 MILLION IN U.S. LOAN SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Commerce, announced today that the Government would issue $730 million in loan guarantees to help the General Dynamics Corporation build seven ships to carry liquefied natural gas between Indonesia and Japan.

title: South African Plane Seized
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Jan. 19 (Reuters)Madagascar authorities today held the pilot and three passengers of a South African light plane intercepted after entering this country's air space without permission, the Government said. A communique said the plane; a Cessna 402, was intercepted at Mananjary, in the southeastern part of the island.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
description: WHOLEBALE ONLY

title: Celtics 112, Rockets 102
description: HOUSTON. Jan. 19 (UPI) Jo Jo White scored 24 points and John Havlicek added 20 tonight to lead the Boston Celtics to a 112102 victory over the Houston Rockets in an N.B.A. game.

title: Wimbledon Spirit Grips Mrs. King
Expert on AirSea Power
description: As commander of the carrier Guadalcanal in World War II, Admiral Gallery led a task force that boarded and captured the German submarine U505 off French West Africa. It was the first foreign warship captured at sea by the United. States since 1815. The coup yielded valuable military secrets, including a German radio code and a new type of torpedoes.

title: Poland Softens Stand on Critics
description: WARSAW, Jan. 15Poland's Communist leadership has decided to tackle its domestic dissidents by what it calls political means, ruling out arrests, police harassment and outright repression, according to highlevel officials.

title: Downhill to Miss Dirren
description: LENK, Switzerland, Jan. 19 (UPI)Eveline Dirren of Switzerland won the second European Cup downhill race today, beating Sigrid Totschnig of Austria by eighthundreths of a second. Miss Dirren was clocked in 1:53.80 for two runs while Miss Totschnig was timed in 1:53.88. Gretl Langer of Austria was third in 1:54.97.

title: Wet or Dry, the Carter White House Inherits Some Instructive Customs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19At the first reception given by a President of the United States at 10 Cherry Street. in the then capital of New York City, guests were served tea and coffee and small cakes, a teetotal soire that set no precedent at all for later Presidential entertaining.

title: TRUCKS AND 23 CARS COLLIDE ON FOGGY ROAD
description: LIVERMORE, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI)Seven trucks and 23 passenger vehicles were smashed on icy, fogshrouded I580 yesterday in accidents that killed two motorists and injured 10.

title: Poland Softens Stand on Critics
description: WARSAW, Jan. 15Poland's Communist leadership has decided to tackle its domestic dissidents by what it calls political means, ruling out arrests, police harassment and outright repression, according to highlevel officials.

title: 11 Guerrillas Are Reported Killed In Two Clashes in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 19 (UPI)Security forces were reported to have killed, at least 11 leftist guerrillas in two clashes today.

Of Presidents and Pyramids

Perhaps as they ride together in pageantry today they will jointly resolve to rescue the Presidency from the rite of the pyramids. We have in mind those Presidential libraries that are being implanted across the land at great cost to us all with only questionable benefit to scholarship.

He beat John Teague of Moretown, Vt., who was timed in 1:30.98, and Peter Dodge of St. Johnsbury, Vt., timed in 1:31.32.

description: Tthe Environmental Protection Agency yesterday ordered the ban of the direct discharge of PCB's, a highly toxic industrial chemical, into United States waters.

title: Screen: 'Holes' Is Full of Vacuity
description: "The Holes," the 1974 French movie that opened at the Eastside Cinema and other theaters yesterday, is a comedy that pretends to defend individualism and eccentricity even though it seems clearly designed for people who eat junk food while watching sit-coms on television.It's a facetious tale about a nutty aristocrat (Philippe Noiret) who lives in the catacombs of Paris and the ravages of modernization going on upstairs. His adversary is the progress-obsessed Minister of Public Works (Charles Denner), who, among other things, plans to relieve traffic congestion by paving over the Seine and painting a white line down the middle.Pierre Tchernia, reported to be something of a French television personality, wrote the screenplay and directed the cast that includes Grard Depardieu in the small role of a mailman. It's one of those films the French don't usually export, for very good reason."The Holes" has been rated PG (Parental Guidance Suggested"), though the only possibly offensive thing about it is a failure of imagination.

title: Books of The Times
JAMES G. WHITE
description: James G. White, manager of personnel and office, services of the Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation of Stamford Conn., died yesterday at Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 52 years old and a resident of Scarsdale, N.Y. Mr. White, a graduate of Columbia University, is survived by his wife, the former Louise Schindel; a son, James G. Jr. a daughter, Nancy G., and a brother, Robert.

description: Anthony Edward Santasiere, a New York City public school teacher who won the United States Open chess championship in 1945, died last Thursday in Hollywood, Fla. He was 72 years old and had lived in Florida since his retirement from the school system 12 years ago.

description: UNIONDALE, Jan. 19After a series of disheartening games, the Nets played a tough one tonight against the Portland Trail Blazers, but the result was familiaranother loss, New York's 11th in a row.

title: Freighter Sinks in Gulf of Mexico
description: MIAMI, Jan. 19 (UPI)The Panamanian freighter Ukola snappcd in two and sank in a gale in the Gulf of Mexico today. and rescuers saved only three of the 23 crew members aboard before darkness fell.

title: An EnergySaving Device On Subway Cars Lauded
description: Two energysaving subway cars equipped with experimental flywheel units have completed a year of testing in the city's subway system, and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority reported yesterday that it was pleased with the results. The flywheels store some of the energy the subway cars normally lose in heat when breaking. The saved energy is then applied when the car accelerates.

description: NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 19Hilary Hilton of Pacific Palisades, Calif., and Louise Gengler of Locust Valley, L. L, the topseeded team, won their quarterfinal match in. the Tribuno women's platform tennis . event today from Nancy Dickson of Little Silver, N. J., and Julie Reinmund of Tenafly, N. J., 64. 63.

CORRECTION
description: An article on conflicts of interest in sports on Jan. 8 incorrectly reported that Teleprompter had lent money to Roy Boe, owner of the New York Nets, to help save his basketball franchise. The money was lent by Home Box Office. William Jennings, president of the Rangers, was, incorrectly identified as a Teleprompter board member rather than as a former board member.

description: Saying sh,e is tired of fighting the bureaucracy, the 49yearold former tennis champion Althea Gibson has resigned her post as New Jersey State Athletic Commissioner.

title: Medical Tests Expanded At Embassy in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 19 (UP1)The United States Embassy will expand its blood and water tests to study why onethird of the American diplomats and their families living in Moscovy have abnormal blood counts, an embassy official said today.

title: A TopsyTurvy Winter.Florida Gets Snow, While Alaska Basks.
description: In this zaniest of winters you can't tell where you are anymore. Ice is melting into gullies of slush in the 40degree warmth of Alaska, and a meteorologist in Miami, Albert Hill, announces with some wonderment, I'm sure it snowed.

description: Thurman Munson and George Steinbrenner, the principals in a feud that threatened to rip the Yankees apart before they had a chance to defend their American League pennant, met for several hours yesterday and worked out a peace agreement.

title: Mix Stars As 76ers Top Hawks
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 (AP)  A reserve forward, Steve Mix, scored 27 points tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers routed the Atlanta Hawks, 11494, in gaining their fifth consecutive National Basketball Association victory.

title: Accident Suit Settled
description: A State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan awarded $1.5 million to a Bronx woman who lost a leg two years ago in a bus accident. The woman, Judith A. Bishop of 499 East 142d Street, a nurse's aide and divorced mother of two, had been on her way home after a day's outing near Poughkeepsie, N. Y., when the accident occurred. Charles Kramer, Mrs. Bishop's attorney, said that the bus driver, who was employed by the Westchester Street Transportation Company, had been speeding at the time.

title: Easing of Rules on Testing Drugs for Cancer Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The scientific director of the American Cancer Society said today that the group may in the near future seek a loosening in the stringent Federal regulations for drug testing to allow experimental forms of treatment to be made more easily available to sufferers from cancer.

title: Apprentice Rides 191 Shot For First Stakes Victory
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP)Mark Sellers, an apprentice who had never won a stakes race, brought home the 191 Woodsome today at Santa Anita in the $45,450 El Encino Stakes. Sellers, the 17yearold son of John Sellers, a former national riding champion, guided the Englishbred filly to a fourlength victory over Lucie Manet, ridden by Bill Shoemaker.

title: Letters
description: Defense: There Is Room for Sizable Cuts

title: NEW YORK HIGH IS 26 AS THE SOUTH SHIVERS
description: The bitter cold weather relented in the New York City area yesterday, with midafternoon temperatures rising to 26 degrees. But the chill winter pattern struck farther southward, with snow in many parts of Florida for the first time and gas fuel supplies tightened everywhere.

title: Sunday Sales Bring Fines of $45,000
description: Vornado Inc., the parent company of Two Guys, was ordered yesterday to pay $22,000 in fines for keeping its New Jersey stores open Sundays during the Christmas shopping season. Judge James J. Petrella of State Superior Court in Hackensack fined the company $45,000, but suspended pays m'ent of $23,000 of it. He said the $22,000 Vornado had to pay represented one and a half times its net profit on sales of restricted items during the three Sundays its stores remained open. Financial records for Vornado's 26 New Jersey stores showed a net profit of $14,226. Three stores recorded losses for the three Sundays.

title: Special Train Bears, Joyous Carter Neighbors North
description: ABOARD THE PEANUT SPECIAL, Jan. 19After an emotional sendoff by Presidentelect Carter, this 18car train pulled out of Plains, ea., early this afternoon and headed, north toward Washington with a cargo of 300 joyous south Georgians.

title: WALTER HOUMERE
description: Walter Houmere, an artist and inventor, died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 10 East Eighth Street.

title: U.S. Indicts 2 for CB Offenses
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 (UPI)A. Federal grand jury has indicted two man in the Philadelphia ,area on charges of using obscenities and making threats over a citizens band radio. Kenneth O. Thompson. of Upper Darby and Stuart M. Herbets of Overbrook Park were charged yesterday in separate indictments. United States Attorney David W. Marston said the indictments had rpsuited from an investigation, by the Federal Bureau. of Investigation and the Federal Communications Commission into the unlawful use of CB radio equipment.

title: 3 in the Bronx Plead Guilty To Beating Young Woman Who Fled to Puerto Rico
description: Three 21yearold members of a Bronx street gang's socalled Gestapo squad pleaded guilty yesterday to assault charges after their frightened victim, 20yearold woman, was persuaded by an offduty detective to return from Puerto Rico to testify against them. ,

title: Parents Boycott School
description: Parents kept their children out of Public School 81 in the Bedford'Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, seeking assurances that the building was safe after a fire Tuesday afternoon. Two vacant kindergarten classrooms were damaged by the fire, which was of undetermined origin, according to a Board of Education spokesman.

title: Cincinnati Suffers First Loss, 8377
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan.19 (AP)Darrell Griffith, a freshman, started a secondhalf rally with a 7point contribution to lead Louisville to an 8377 upset victory over previously unbeaten Cincinnati in a Metro7 Conference basketball game tonight. Cincinnati had won 12 straight before the loss.

title: Medicaid Curb On Surgery Aid Upset by Court
description: A United States District Court judge ordered New York State yesterday to resume Medicaid reimbursement for surgery deemed not urgent.

title: 'Shoot' Misses Mark as Film On Gun Usage
description: One wintry afternoon, when Rex Jeanette (Cliff Robertson), a well-to-do appliance merchant, and several of his friends are out hunting unsuccessfully, they come upon another party of hunters who emerge from the woods just across a small river. "It's funny," says a colleague of Rex's "they look just like us." Suddenly one of the strangers shoots at Rex's group, whose members return the fire and apparently kill one of the attackers. Both parties retire from the field.Does anyone call the police or get a doctor or do anything rational? Of course not. If anyone had, there would be no movie called "Shoot," the miniminded, bloodthirsty, supposedly antigun movie that opened yesterday at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters."Shoot," a Canadian film directed by Harvey Hart, written by Dick Berg and based on a novel by Douglas Fairbairn, apparently hopes to be making a statement about the mayhem that can be caused by easy access to weaponry, but most of the time the film doesn't believe in itself. When one character says to another, "I can't believe it really happened," it's as if the film makers were trying to disassociate themselves from the melodramatic nonsense they've concocted.Rex and his pals, including Lou (Ernest Borgnine), are portrayed as right-wing gun nuts. You can tell this because they have American flags in their dens, tell dirty stories and treat their wives badly. When Rex prepares to go hunting, he gets great pleasure slowly lubricating the barrel of his shotgun. Rex has problems all right, but passing a gun-control law isn't going to solve them.It's the conceit of this film that instead of reporting the riverside confrontation, Rex and his friends, as well as their unknown enemies, would decide to fight it out in earnest the following weekend with high-powered rifles, machine guns and bazookas, all borrowed from the National Guard. "We're trying to prevent a slaughter," says Rex, "not to start one," which is meant to identify Rex with various ludicrous foreign-policy statements.The overstuffed point of the film is that certain men need to fight to express themselves and that in this need there's a lesson for mankind. Perhaps, but it's a very simplistic point and a drearily foolish movie in which everyone does badly, including Kate Reid, who has a briefly embarrassing scene as the whisky-soaked, sex-starved widow of the murdered hunter.

title: Boyer, State U. Head, Named U.S Education Commissioner
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Dr, Ernest L. Boyer, chancellor of the State University of New York, was named today to be the next United States Commissioner of Education.

title: Papers Ease Transfer Of Military Command
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI)Jimmy Carter signed documents tonight to ensure that there will be no instant during the transfer of Presidential power tomorrow when the United States armed forces are without a Commander in Chief.

title: The Definitive, AllInclusive, And Most Totally Historical Inaugural Address Possible
description: I am certain that my fellow Americans expect that on my induction into the Presidency I will address them with a candor and a decision which the present situation of our Nation impels. This is preeminently the time to speak the truth, the whole truth, frankly and boldly. Nor need we shrink from honestly facing conditions in our country today. This great Nation will endure as it has endured, will revive and will prosper.1

title: TV Stations to Cover Inaugural Activities
description: The three networks, ABC, CBS and NBC, and their local stations, Channels 7, 2 and 4; will telecast live the inauguration ceremonies and the inaugural parade starting at 10 N.M. and continuing throughout the morning and most of the afternoon.

title: Helstoski Conviction Upheld
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 (AP)The tax fraud conviction of Robert Helstoski, brother of former Representative Henry Helstoski of East Rutherford, N. J., has been upheld by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit here. Mr. Helstoski was convicted in December 1975 on 22 counts of filing false personal and corporate incometax returns. He was sentenced last April to an 18month prison term and fined $10,000, but has remained free pending appeal.

title: Chesimard Trial In Murder Case Halted by Filing
description: TRENTON, Jan. 19The murder trial of Joanne Chesimard was halted today when her lawyers filed a petition here to have the case removed to United States District Court because they said she could not receive a fair trial in Middlesex County Court in New Brunswick.

title: ROBERT C. HEYDA
description: Robert C. Heyda, who was a founder of the Advertising Club of Westchester in 1968 and its president in 1972 and 1973, died Monday in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. He lived at 121 North Broadway, White. Plains, and was 67 years old.

title: SOME FACTORIES GAIN BY POLLUTION CURBS
description: CHICAGO, Jan.19A new chapter in the quest for environmental quality has been unfolding here as industrialists and Federal officials conferred for the first time on ways in which pollution abatement can be made to yield profits, instead of financial losses.

title: Carter's Deep Roots in Hometown Make Leaving an Emotional Thing
description: PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 19One day this week, as a frosty dawn eased its way across the South, a stream of gray smoke curled upward from the chimney on the big house at 1 Woodland Drive, mixing its hickory scent with the brisk smells of the morning.

title: Last of 80 Bodies Are Removed. From Commuter Train in Sydney
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 19 (UPI)Rescue workers today removed the last of 80 bodies from a commuter train flattened yesterday by the collapse of a 500ton concrete and steel bridge.

title: WALTER V. BURKE
description: PROVIDENCE, R. L, Jan. 19 (AP)Walter V. Burke, a church organist and choirmaster whose Burke Family Singers had national recognition in the 1960's, died yesterday at his home here.

title: Kramer to Direct Film Of Raise the Titanic!
description: Stanley Kramer has signed contracts to produce and direct the film Raise the Titanic! for the ITC Entertainment Company, it has been announced by Abe Mandel, the company's president. The film, a Martin Starger production, is based on Clive Cussle's suspense novel.

title: Gilmore's Agent an Entrepreneur Who Specializes in the Sensational
description: OREM, Utah, Jan. 19The man who gave the public the last nude photos of Marilyn Monroe, the first prison interview with Susan Atkins, the Charles Manson follower, the heritage of Lenny Bruce, an account of the final days of a cancer victim and the photonegative of Jack Ruby shooting Lee Harvey Oswald is now presenting the death of Gary Mark Gilmore.

description: To some New Yorkers, yesterday's weather seemed like a tropical heat wave. Ski masks were shed, coats were worn unbuttoned, and smiles returned to frigid faces as the temperature clmbed to a high of 26 after Monday and Tuesday's recordbreaking cold.

description: I MOSCOW, Jan. 19 (Reuters)A Soviet general today rejected charges made in the West that the Soviet Union's precautions against nuclear war could undermine the strategic balance between East and West.

description: The administrator of the State Energy Office, Burt Ross, has vowed not to shave until the state's natural gas emergency, caused by the severe cold spell is over.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The Justice Department, faced with a draft of a Government legal position holding that Indians own nearly twothirds of Maine, has appealed for Congressional action to solve the thorny issue.

Beame's Inaugural Visit To Be Followed Next Week By Pressing City's Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Sporting a tie decorated with red Big Apples and taking a cool attitude about the grimly cold weather, Mayor Beame joined the swirl of inaugural social activities today before getting down to the serious business of the city's legislative program here next week.

He stands out front in the crowd on that alwayscold January day, experiencing a mingling of pride and anonymity shared by not one of his countrymen.

title: Briton Voices Hope Of Help by Vorster On Rhodesia Accord
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 19Ivor Richard of Britain, chairman, of the adjourned Geneva conference on Rhodesia. emerged from a twoandahalfhour meeting with Prime Minister John Vorster today and said he had hope that South Africa would assist in persuading Rhodesia's ruling white minority to accept British. terms for a peaceful transition to majority rule.
