Bonefishing in Bermuda Is a Sporting Proposition
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda  The man from upstate New York knew what he wanted.

title: World Cruises an Endless Task For Housekeepers on Board Ship
description: World cruises may be fun to passengers and crew but to those who have to take care of the housekeeping for them, they are an endless task.

title: An Open Letter to Mr. Carter
description: SAINT PAUL DE VENCE, FranceI have a thing to tell you, but with a heavy heart, for it is not a new thing.In North Carolina, as I write, nine black men and one white woman are under sentences of a total of 282 years in various prisons on various charges, including arson. The Rev. Ben Chavis, who was 29 years old yesterday, is the best known of the Wilmington 10.

title: Public, Nursing Homes, Too
A Fact of Life Again: Capital Punishment
description: The execution of Gary Mark Gilmore has brought an end to the 10year suspension on capital punishment in the United States but left the fate of 358 other convicts on death row still in doubt. Lawyers said that the effect of Gilmore's death on the status of the condemned inmates would be more psychological than legal. But opponents of capital punishment feared a wave of executions.

title: Federal Judge Admits Evidence In Maine Trial of Bomb Suspect
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 22 (AP)  A Federal district judge ruled today that evidence, including a machine gun and an alleged target list of potential bombing sites, could be used in the trial of Richard J. Piccariello. a bomber suspect.

title: Susan Thorndike Is Married
description: Susan Thorndike, daughter of Mrs. John Beverly Thorndike of East Bridgewater, Mass., and the late Mr. Thorndike, was married yesterday afternoon to Louis Basil Dotti Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Dotti of Briektown, N. J.

title: Campaign for the Presidency of the New York City Council Is Stirring
They hate what they ate
description: This book about food in America is a catalogue of distastes, an accumulation of bittemesses, a presentation of thousands of charges. John L. and Karen Hess must he relieved finally to have it off their chests.

title: Can Salsa Escape The Cultural Ghetto?; Can Salsa Escape the Cultural Ghetto?
description: Latin music, a popular hybrid rooted in Cuba which has become the basis of a thriving music industry in New York, touches the mainstream of American pop periodically. Xavier Cugat with his rhuntbas, Dizzy Gillespie with his AfroCuban jazz, and Carlos Santana with his Latin rock have all captivated substangal nonLatin audiences, but these have been isolated phenomena. The movers and shapers of Latin music, and the performers whose names are familiar in every Latin household, have rarely tasted the advantages which come with major record label affiliations airplay on pop and progressive radio, and exposure in other media. Contemporary Latin music, which is often called salsa, is one of the last truly, underground popular musics in North America, but lately several of salsa's superstars have begun reaching out toward a broader pop audience,

title: Where the Power Lies at the S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON  Speculation abounds these days about whom President Carter will pick shortly to become chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and whether he will press for confirmation of Patrick J. Delaney, a Democrat twice nominated to the S.E.C. by President Ford.

title: Fraud in Research Is a Rising Problem in Science
description: The existence of scientific fraud, evident in a number of examples in recent years, is leading some scientists to question openly the integrity of some of their colleagues.

title: Article 7  No Title
Suburbanites, Too, Get By With Less Space
description: Many suburban families are also moving into less space. It is not that houses are being built smaller but that families can't affordor don't wantas much room. In Long Island, couples with incomes below $17,000 are priced out of singlefamily housing altogether. Many others, who can still buy a home, are making spatial tradeoffs.

title: Bridge Is More Than a Game
description: It came as something of a shock earlier this month, though probably it shouldn't have, when two of the leading players in a major bridge tournamentclearly about to win places oil the American team headed for international competitionsuddenly dropped out amid charges of improprieties.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN the conventional claw hammer is used for pulling out long nails, pulling the first inch or two is easythere is still plenty of leverage left. But after the nail is about halfway out of the wood, things may get tougher (especially In hard wood or if the nail is quite rusty). As the handle of the hammer comes back, much more pull is required. Also, the head starts to dig into and dent the wood, and also, the nail inevitably gets bent into a curve.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that he had accepted the resignation of Ivan E. Irizarry as the city's finance administrator, effective on Feb. 15. The announcement said that Mr. Irizarry, who was appointed to the post on Jan. 27, 1974, would leave to become senior vice president of the Government Development Bank of Puerto Rico. It was said that he would be in charge of the bank's United States and international operations.

title: Legionnaire's Disease Solved
description: More than six months after the Philadelphia legionnaire's disease, which killed 29 persons and sickened 180, was recognized as an unexplained epidemic, Federal scientists believe they have discovered the cause, a bacterium never before known.

title: Moynihan's First Stand
description: Daniel P. Moynihan, ever the maverick, has begun his career as Democratic Senator from New York in an unorthodox manner: He has recommended that three Republicanappointed United States attorneys in Manhattan. Brooklyn and Buffalo complete their terms under the Carter Administration. Normally, Federal prosecutors expect to be replaced. and are, when their party is voted out of the White House.

description: Today  K9 Obedience Training Club of Essex County obedience trial, Upsala College, Prospect Street, East Orange, N.J.; 9 A.M.

description: Organized Jewry in New York City, acknowledging that alcoholism among Jews is a growing problem, has initiated a new program to combat it.

title: Juvenile Crime: Hard Line Due
description: A SPECIAL task force appointed by Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes of the State Supreme Court is expected to recommend a series of changes, perhaps this week, that would toughen the criminal proceedings against juveniles accused of violent crime.

description: CAIRO, Jan. 22Arab oilproducing countries eager to see a moderate government remain in power in Egypt appeared today to be rallying to the help of President Anwar elSadat.

description: A LOT of people in New Jersey got left out when the Federal Government started awarding publicworks projects to stimulate activity in hardhit unemployment areas. That is the conclusion of the state's Washington, office following an analysis of the 56 projects approved for New Jersey since the Public WorkS Act was passed last year.

description: Tokyo Rose Is Pardoned

title: Memoirs of a Piano Man
description: LIVING in Levittown in the 50's was like walking through an episode of Happy Days, complete with pompadours, black leather jackets and petty crime. Billy Joel remembers exactly how it felt.

title: The Free Press and the Campus
description: THERE were fighters for freedom of the press long before there was a press to free. Some of today's fighters for that freedom are college students, and the press is the campus newspaper.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
An Ethics Test for Congress
description: Now that a new President, a new Administration and a new Congress are all pretty much in place, the dreary business of governanceas opposed to the pyrotechnical business of politics or the headysad business of transitionwill soon again become the Order of the day in Washington. Few issues will be larger, at this turn of the wheel, than whether Washington can impose the kinds of ethical restraints on official conduct that will regain the damaged confidence of the American people.

title: YOUTH DIVISION EASES TASK OF FINDING JOB
description: The temperature outside was near zero, but when he learned that he had gotten a muchneeded parttime job as a messenger on a bicycle, Kevin Washington broke into a wide grin.

title: Snow Farming Grows as Trade Trick
description: BONDVILLE, Vt., Jan. 20  When skiers began approaching New England farmers some four decades ago about purchasing their land, there were two aspects that puzzled the farmers.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Theater It is important that Mr. Stoppard take more care with the doodles he chooses to let us see and hear. (Walter Kerr)

title: Nancy Sullivan Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Sullivan of McLean, Va., formerly of Ridgewood, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Louise Sullivan, to Sherrod Emerson Skinner 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Cameron Skinner of Santa Monica, Calif. The bridetobe is a senior at Radcliffe College. Her fiance is a Woodrow Wilson Teaching Fellow at ChoateRosemary Hall School in Wallingford, Conn.

title: ...And the East Finds Helsinki Uncomfortable
description: The East had to pay a price for Western acceptance of the consecration of d00E9;tente and the European status quo contained in the Helsinki accord of 19752014;a socalled third basket dealing with human rights and international contacts. But three things have happened since then that have made the Eastern bloc nations wonder whether the price was higher than they thought they were paying.

title: Congressmen Also Must Campaign In Congress
description: WASHINGTONThe politicking never stopped. One day they were campaigning for Congress, pressing the flesh supermarkets, speaking to the P.T.A. The next day they were campaigning for committee assignments, working the telephones and the corridors, in a more personal style the success or failure of which could prove crucial to their careers.

title: 1976 Israel Bond Drive Raised $50 Million in New York Area
Henry O. Clutsam 3d And Cheryl A. Neely Set Wedding in June
description: The engagement of Cheryl A. Neely to Henry O. Clutsam 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clutsam Jr. of Summit, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Neely of Scotch Plains, N.J. A June wedding is planned at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon, N.J.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Numismatics continues to rear its handsome head at the Treasury Department. Earlier this month the Department opened an extensive yesterday and today display of the nation's coins and currency in the new exhibit hall of the main Treasury Building in Washington. Late last year the Department and its Bureau of the Mint announced the opening of a colorful, comprehensive exhibition of Western numismatics in the authentically restored Old Mint in San Francisco.

title: Figures Impossible to Determine
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22A Justice Department spokesman said today that was impossible to determine how many Americans would be affected by President Carter's pardon of draft evaders because no Government agency had any figures on those who simply never registered for the draft.

title: In Suffolk, Democrats Seek Gains
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY politicians are going around noting that 1977a county election yearwill be a watershed for the party of John F. Kennedy, Jimmy Carter and Floyd S. enson. It will be the year Suffolk Democrats will try to do at the county level what they managed last year at the state and national level when they returned their firstterm United States Representatives and State Assembly members to office.

title: William Lilley 3d Is the Fiance Of Eve La Grange Auchincloss
WorldClass Milers Have Slipped Out of Sight
description: It has always been track and field's most glamorous event. The Mile. The Wanamaker Mile. The Dream Mile. The Super Mile. The Mile of the Century.

title: Fashion
description: The star shoe for 1977 looks as if it just stepped out of the boudoir, or off the stage. It's backless and simply slips on or off, without any fuss or bother. Heels are pancakeflat or towering and spikey, and materials are clear vinyl or shiny metallic leather. Some of the highheeled styles look like those sexy mules the Petty calendar girls wore, but in fact these shoes are meant to be worn, both day and evening, with all the new romantic warmweather clothes.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: There are few theatrical experiences more painful than that of sitting with an audience that is desperately determined to laugh and that is slowly strangling on the effort. There is, it happens, every reason why an audience should try to laugh at Torn Stoppard's Dirty Linen. The playit is really two short plays, one tucked with cavalier Irrelevance inside the otherhas been publicizea as what the British call a knickers farce, meaning that girl's panties, slip and dress are all apt to be snatched froim her in a manner that apparently did not go out with Getting Gertie's Garter. The snatching, as we'd been informed by many a charming and intelligent advance interview.. with the author, was to take place during meetings of a House of Commons committee investigating sexual immorality in the Government, a subject not entirely unfamiliar to our own body politic. Given the two promises, chuckles ought to have started rising along with the curtain (although there isn't any curtain, and the chuckles are bard to come by).

description: Special to The New York Times

title: Refusal of Examination or Publication of 126 Sean O'Casey Letters Owned by N.Y.U. Stirs a Literary Dispute
description: Sean O'Casey, the Irish man of letters, left 126 of them, and they are now the center of a literary dispute.

title: 2 HUGHES OFFICIALS AT ODDS OVER ESTATE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22Sharp conflicts between William Rice Lummis, administrator of the late Howard R. Hughes Summa Corporation, and Chester C. Davis, Summa's chief counsel, have created tensions that could lead to an open break and possibly to Mr. Lummis's dismissal of Mr. Davis, according to information made available this week.

title: Ballet: Gregory Masters Giselle
description: It was a privilege to see Cynthia Gregory and Ted Kivitt appear in Giselle with the American Ballet Theater on Friday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater.

title: Watson Has Shot Lead With 67202

title: Musicians End City Ballet Strike; Short Season May Open Tuesday
description: Union musicians last night reversed an earlier rejection and accepted a mediator's recommendation to end their 40dayold strike against the New York City Ballet. The company said it would try to reopen Tuesday for the final three weeks of its winter season.

title: CHESS
Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Knoll Farms, Suffolk Avenue, Brentwood, L.I. Special and children's working hunters, novice jumpers, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Criminals At Large
description: P.N. Gwynne's FIRMLY By THE TAIL (Putnam's, $8.95) is a book that does not fall into an easily determined category. The locale is one of those new African republics, and the hero is a diamond buyer for a big British syndicate. So there is a great deal about diamonds. And, well into the bookabout twothirds throughthere is a diamond hijacking. So this is a crime novel.

title: W. A. Lobb Fiance Of Maureen O'Hagan
description: The engagement of Maureen Ver. onique O'Hagan to William Atkinson Lobb has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Dermott S. O'Hagan of Washington. Mr. Lobb is the son of Col. Anthony William Lobb, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Lobb of Delaplane, Va., and a grandson of the late William A. Lobb, who was executive vice president of the Chelsea Bank and Trust Company in New York.

title: Palomino Stops Muniz, Keeps Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22 (AP)Carlos Palomino survived a firstround knockdown and went on to stop Mando Muniz in the 15th round tonight to retain his World Boxing Council welterweight title. The Mexicanborn boxers are close friends who live in the Los Angeles area.

title: Where the Power Lies at the S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON  Speculation abounds these days about whom President Carter will pick shortly to become chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and whether he will press for confirmation of Patrick J. Delaney, a Democrat twice nominated to the S.E.C. by President Ford.

title: Linda K. Koch And a Student Marry at Yale
description: Linda Katharine Koch and Ernest McFaul Lorimer, seniors at the Yale Law School, were married yesterday in the Marquand Chapel at Yale University. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Rowan Greer of the Yale Divinity School.

title: Letters
description: On Strengthening Global Human Rights

title: An Accounting Of Accounting Practices
description: The adequacy of an important element in the Federal Government's system of regulating the securities market, audits by private accounting firms, has been challenged in a Senate report.

title: Sadat's Troubles At Home
description: Rioting over higher food prices, the worst social unrest he has faced since taking office in 1970, has emphasized President Anwar elSadat's domestic political and economic troubles and, at the same time, made it more imperative for the Egyptian leader to pursue a Middle East peace settlement.

title: Cost, Fashions, Equipment and Robert Redford
description: Generally, there are two kinds of people in the world: those who ski and those who don't. Those who don't ski may not because they hear so much contradictory information about skiing. For their benefit, here are some of the myths they hear and the truth behind the myths:

title: Robin M. Geist Engaged to Calvin Skinner Jr.
description: Robin Meredith Geist, youth coordinator and photographer for the recent campaign of Gov. James Thompson of Illinois, plans to be married Feb. 19 to State Representative Calvin Skinner Jr. of Crystal Lake, Ill.

title: Dr. Albert C. Herring Dies at 84
description: Dr. Albert C. Herring, a retired internist, died of a heart attack Thursday while vacationing at Barranquilla, Colombia. He was 84 years old and lived in Lawrence. L.I.

title: French Wealth Fails to Reach SubProletariat
description: HERBLAY, France  Alfred Ratel, a 65yearold miner who has been out of work and living on state welfare and private charity for nine years, sat at his kitchen table and Bald that life had been even tougher when he and his. wife and five children had to live for two year in an abandoned mushroom cave.

title: A $200 million Erector Set
description: Andr Malraux was not merely a great man but a great Frenchman. Great Frenchmen are different from great AngloSaxons. Great AngloSaxons excel in the world of action, or of thought, or of artistic creation, but they rarely conquer all these worlds. Ernest Hemingway wrote good, fished good, drank good, fought good, but eventually he had to kill himself: His system could not accommodate the dance of incompatibles. In England T. E. Lawrence, whom Malraux so much admired, turned from scholarship to action to the writing of a great book, but he had to end by embracing a new and lowly personathe humblest rank in the Royal Air Forceand dying young in a motorcycle crash. Malraux, being a Frenchman, managed to sustain a balance of action and creation and, being a great Frenchman, got into government as de Gaulle's Minister of Culture without compromising his philosophical and esthetic ideals. His political ideals were a different matter, but politics is all compromise anyway.

title: Four Die in Virginia Fire
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Jan. 21 (AP)  Four persons were killed this morning when fire raced through a townhouse in this northern Virginia suburb about 20 miles from Washington, D. C. The victims were identified by city police as Ronald Grovers, 39 years old, and his wife, Pamela, 41, and her parents, John F. and Winfred Jones, both 73, who were visiting from London, England.

title: NotSoGrand Alliance
description: ATHENSWith astounding ineptitude the United States has managed to win for itself a position of equal unpopularity with those reluctant allies, Greece and Turkey. And although posters which until recently adorned Athens newspaper kiosks, naming Henry Kissinger as wanted for the death of 10,000 Greek Cypriots, have now vanished, little else has so far changed.

title: POLITICS
description: ONE of the important ingredients in the smooth operation of many oldline political machines was a friendly prosecutor, one who would take care of the public's business without becoming too curious about how the machine raised its money.

title: Cry the Beloved City A New Newark Is Taking Form
description: WITH Anthony Imperiale casting covetous eyes at the Governor's chair (who would ever have thought he would make State Senator?), who radical in Newark today? The only apostle of startling change is Amiri Baraka. Bakara's power rests in his pen, a fearful weapon; it deflates egos at City Hall and raises hackles at the Chamber of Commerce. Recent Newark has known no one who could needle pompous bureaucrats, fraudulent politicians or tunnelvisioned businessmen as deftly as Baraka.

title: Death in Yugoslavia
description: The death in a plane crash of Prime Minister Dzemal Bijedic has cost the Tito regime a valuable figure who, because of his Moslem background, stood outside the bitter rivalries that mark the Yugoslav Government; Mr. Bijedic ignored the bickering and concentrated on economic and administrative duties. In a country where Serbs, Croats and Slovenes are the main rivals for political power, Mr. Bijedic played a role that has been compared with that of Aleksei N. Kosygin in the Soviet Union. Although he was a veteran Communist functionary, he was better known as an administrator than as a politician. No decision is likely to be taken on a successor until President Tito returns from a tour Egypt and Libya.

title: ...And What Congress Proposes
description: The newspapers have been filled with reports on what steps the advisers to President Carter have decided to take to stimulate the nation's economy. It is to be hoped that these decisions are not yet graven in stone and that, before becoming totally committed, Mr. Carter and his counselors will examine carefully the bold, innovative proposal to deal with unemployment put forward in the last Congress by Representative Jack Kemp, Republican of New York, and Senator James A. McClure, Republican of Idaho.

title: Whether or Not Beame Runs, Some Key Officials Plan to Quit
description: Whether or not Mayor Beame seeks reelection, it has become apparent that Some key. players in the cast of characters at City Hall will not be around next year. First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti, for example, is expected to return to private life even if Mr. Beame stays in office. Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, says he intends to resign from that post and from his membership on the Emergency Financial Control Board by next summer. And Stephen Berger, the controversial executive director of the Control Board, says he also intends to leave his job before long.

title: Late Penguin Goals Inflict A 32 Defeat on Islanders
The New Wall Street Of Jersey City
description: WHEN nine securities companies moved from Wall Street across the Hudson to Jersey City last spring, some felt as fearful as fledglings being nudged out of the nest. Almost a year has passed since most settled in the modern, 15 story Ukrainian National Association Building to escape a 25 percent increase in the New York stocktransfer tax and a new levy on bonds of 25 cents for each $1,000 of value traded.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: The best thing you can co for your golf this winter is look in a mirror. A fulllength mirror is a valuable learning aid. With it you can make rapid improvement particularly in your setup position and putting.

title: The Cast Is the Thing In This Play
description: NEW BRUNSWICK MAN OF LA MANCHA opened here this weekend, starring Paul Smilow, a physician; Joseph Vasta, a salesman, and a business woman, Suzanne DoBosz. The cast includes a stockbroker, a housewife, clerical workers, students, attorneys and a myriad of Central Jersey residents who believe that the play's the thing and are willing to spend 200 hours rehearsing to prove it.

title: Dealing With Terrorists Has Already Distorted the Legal System
description: BONN2014;The French decision to frie Abu Daoud set off a wave of righteous indignation in West Germany, which was getting ready, a little too ponderously, to request his extradition on murder charges connected with the massacre at the Munich Olympic Games in 1972. But there were some officials here who were relieved they didn't get him

title: What Kind of Leader?; The Man From Plains and The Imperial Presidency
description: WASHINGTON2014;A few days after his election in November, Jimmy Carter boarded the airborne palace called Air Force One for a flight to a vacation hideaway and declared with obvious relish: This is the one I've been waiting for.

description: Jan. 26Motor Sports Club of North Jersey meeting at Barcelona's, Harrison Avenue, Garfield, N.J., 8:15 P.M. Interested persons welcome. Information: Joyce Grott; phone (201)3850862.

title: TOURO COLLEGE FACES LOSS OF STATE FUNDS
description: New York State authorities have ordered Touro College to establish selective admissions procedures and make other changes in a special degree program for adults that allegedly enrolled unqualified elderly persons so the college could obtain state and Federal tuition grants.

title: 11 Dead as Spanish Plane Is Found
description: VALENCIA, Spain, Jan. 22 (AP)The wreckage of a Spanish Mr once transport plane missing since Wednesday was found today in a mountainous area southWest of Valencia, and rescue parties said that there were no survivors among the 11 occupants.

title: The Economy and Emergency in India
description: Let's get on with the job, said Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. That was in mid1975 when, citing the threat of economic chaos and collapse, she declared a state of emergency, suspended civil liberties and began locking up political opponents.

title: The Many Faces Of City Fireplaces
description: They come in handy for harboring vagrant crickets and disposing of last year's phone books, but they have other uses as well.

title: A $200 Milliion Business Built on Aching Feet
description: CHICAGOIf you are traveling, almost anywhere in the world, and feel a need for something familiar to remind you of home, look around and the odds are good you'll the name Dr. Scholl, especially if your feet hurt.

title: A Correction
description: In an article on the State University Center at Stony Brook last week on Page 4 of the Long Island Weekly, the captions for the pictures of Dr. Ernest L. Boyer and Dr. John S. Toll were inadvertently transposed.

title: Mexico City Search for Guerrillas Is On
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan, 22 (Reuters) Mayor Hank Gonzalez of Mexico City said today that security forces would use helicopters and heavy arms in the hunt for members of the Communist League 23d of September.

title: Mondale Expected to Get Conflicting Economic Appraisals and Suggestions From Rich and Poor Allies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22As Vice President Mondale visits Europe and Japan this week, he is expected to receive conflicting appraisals of the Western world's economic prospects from the leaders he sees and conflicting advice on what the Carter Administration should do to restore prosperity among its allies.

title: Theodore A. DuBois, 79, Founder Of Uniform Manuacturers Group
description: Theodore A. DuBois, founder and former president of the National Association of Uniform Manufacturers and president of the uniformmaking concern of A. DuBois and Son, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 201 East 66th Street in Manhattan.

title: Broker Fiance Of Miss Rusack Bridal in June
description: Bishop Robert Claflin Rusack of the Episcopal Diocese of Los Angeles and Mrs. Rusack of Pacific Palisades, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Morrison Rusack of New York, to Richard Waycott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Waycott Jr. of Los Angeles.

title: CARTER AIDES AIMING FOR 1976 TAX REBATE OF UP TO $11 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Tan. 22  President Carter's economic advisers, working hard to complete by next week a program to expand employment and achieve a faster growth for the nation, are aiming for $10 billion to $11 billion in rebates on 1976 income taxes.

title: Midshipman to Wed Pamela Ruth Smith
description: Mr. and Mrs. Layton F. Smith of Basking Ridge, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Ruth Smith, to Midshipman David Michael Schubert Jr. of the United States Naval Academy. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Schubert of Fort Wayne, Ind. A summer wedding is planned.

title: His Name Comes Up
description: The name of one of Arizona's wealthiest and most politically powerful figures, Kemper A. Marley Sr., has been connected to the inquiry into the bombing death of Don Bolles, an investigative reporter for a Phoenix newspaper. The connection was made by John H. Adamson, who has pleaded guilty to second degree murder in the Bolles death. Authorities say Adamson alleged that the man who hired him to kill Bolles said the order had come from Mr. Marley. The authorities have not issued any warrants for Mr. Marley; they say there is no evidence to corroborate the Adamson statement. Mr. Marley was a member of the Arizona racing commission, but resigned after publication by Mr. Bolles of a news story detailing Mr. Marley's past business associations. Mr. Marley has remained in seclusion since the Adamson allegation concerning Mr. Bolles's death.

Two Key Officials Say Basic Changes Are Needed in New York City School System's Administratibn
description: Two key figures in the fate of the New York City school systemAssemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky and Stephen Berger, executive director of the state's Emergency Financial Control Boardsuggested yesterday that fundamental changes were required in the administration of the city schools, but that those changes would have to await resolution of the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Cost of Independence Cited in Challenge By Quebec Liberals
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 22The Liberal Party opposition has started a campaign charging that Quebec is having to pay a high price for independence even before, the new government achieves it.

title: Free Makes Celtics Pay As 76ers Romp by 10994
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (AP)The Philadelphia 76ers, paced by Lloyd Free's 36 points, rolled to a 10994 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight, their sixth straight National Basketball Association victory and ninth in 10 games.

title: Residents of Ft. Greene Protest Possible Rescue Company Loss
description: At Engine Company 210 in Brooklyn yesterday, the firemen were gathered in a small room off the kitchen enjoying a lunch of homemade chili and several loaves of Italian bread.

title: New Novel
description: When Sybil Matherson's father dies, she discovers from little Mr. Bealby, the family solicitor, that she has a halfbrother living in France. He is fortyish, a painter who signs himself Felix Forbain. Why didn't Professor Matherson tell Sybil about Felix before this? A good question, which we will gloss over along with a few others.

title: Race and Court Involvement
description: The United States Supreme Court has taken action in two cases, dealing with schools and housing, that raises the question of the proper extent ? Federal judicial remedies for racial segregation.

title: R. E. Price Jr. Fiance Of Marianne M. Bond
description: Marianne Mumford Bond and Robert Edmunds Price Jr., seniors at Dartmouth College, will be married in August in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in WinstonSalem. N.C. Their engagement has been made known by the bridetobe's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Vernard Franklin Bond Jr. of WinstonSalem. Mr. Price is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Price of Dover, N.J.

title: The hunger didn't go away, the hero didn't go mad
description: This brief and moving novella, first published in 1955, seems strangely remote in time now that the memory of horror has faded into nostalgia. But it is a powerful reminder of what Bll brought to postwar German writing luminous decency and lucid prose. Priceless gifts in those early years, when the language itself had to be brought back to life.

title: Crusaders Create Easy Jazz Mood
description: The Crusaders, formerly the Jazz Crusaders, left their native Texas for Los Angeles more than 25 years ago, and the core of the band has stayed together ever since, dispensing a bluesy but essentially lightweight brand of popjazz. There have been changes, brought about by the trend toward increasing amplification and the growing popularity of funk rhythms, but the group's product remains basically the same.

title: FOOD
description: THE midwinter months are the citrus season. Although we can count on oranges, grapefruit, lemons and limes all year round, the greatest variety is available from December through March, including the easytopeel tangerines and table oranges. Produce bins are banked with shining yellow, orange and vermilion spheres. Not only are supplies plentiful, but also quality is at its peak and prices are low.

title: INTERVIEW
Letters
description: Good guys

title: Does TV Have Room For Serious Writers?

Food
description: It is, without question, one of the finest and most soughtafter desserts in Manhattan. One of the first places we ever encountered it was at the distinguished Coach House on Waverly Place. One of the restaurants where we've most recently sampled it is the Windows on the World at the World Trade Center. The name the dessert is dacquoise, and the origin of the name is elusive. It is not listed in any of the food dictionaries and encyclopedias that grace our kitchen bookshelves. One of the finest dacquoises we've ever sampled was prepared by our good friend and master pastry chef, Albert Kumin, of the Culinary Institute of America, in Hyde Park. His recipe as prepared in our kitchen in East Hampton is outlined on this page. A dacquoise is a layered meringue dessert made with hazel or other nuts, the layers put together with a rich butter cream.

title: Margot S. Dewey To Be Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs Benjamin H. Dewey Jr. of Port Washington, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margot Stilwell Dewey, to William James Hust 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hust Jr. of Manchester, Conn., and Harrison. Me. An April wedding is planned.

title: Article 10  No Title
Opera: Teresa Kubiak Is Tosca
description: Teresa Kubiak, the latest of the Metropolitan Opera's sopranos to take on the role of Tosca, turned in one of her best performances in New York in the presentation of the Puccini opera Friday night. Always a good actress but an erratic singer, she held her own vocally on this occasion in producing a wellrounded characterization.

title: A New Day Is Dawning for American Composers
description: A funny thing hapened to American music on the way to the graveyardit turned out it wasn't dead after all. Like the Irishman in the old ballad, Finnegan's Wake, with a little stimulationin this case not whisky but a dose of Bicentennialthe corpse arose, shouting, singing, and dancing, lusty as ever.

title: T. W. Murphy, Kathleen Sanial Married on L.I.
description: Kathleen Frances Sanial, daughter of Mrs. Thomas G. Sanial of East Setauket. L.I., and the late Mr. Sanial, was married at noon yesterday to Thomas William Murphy, a senior law clerk in the Appellate Division of the Public Defender's Office of Cook County, Ill. He is the son of Circuit Court Judge James E. Murphy of Cook County and Mrs. Murphy of Chicago.

title: E P A IS SAID TO LACK RESOURCES FOR TASK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The newly departed administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Russell E. Train, says the agency does not have the resources necessary to carry out its mission of protecting the nation's land, air and water.

title: Seven Shopping Days to Higher Costs
description: THE move to sevendayaweek retail openings in the metropolitan Long Island area was mainly triggered by two or three of the major stores. Other larger storesand defensivelyreluctantly followed suit. They were followed by mediumsized and then many of the smaller stores who refused to allow their normal share of the day's business to be lost through default.

title: Mr. Vance Has at Least the Advantage of Experience With the Cypriots
description: ATHENSIn testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said: In the weeks ahead we will be involved in the search for new ideas which might bring meaningful progress to the Cyprus problem. Vice President Mondale is expected to discuss some of those ideas during his European trip this week.

title: Great Golf Courses: How Britons Suffer
description: Few duffers have ever thought much about golf architecture, but every duffer willingly carries on about the wonders. of his own course. Ask the average golfer to explain the principles of strategic design and he will humbly disavow all such knowledge; tell him that he doesn't know the difference between a good course and a bad one, and he will knock your block off.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN the conventional claw hammer is used for pulling out long nails, pulling the first inch or two is easy. But after the nail is about halfway out of the wood, things may get tougher (especially in hard wood or if the nail is quite rusty).

title: COAST COLLEGE TESTS INNOVATIVE PROGRAM
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22Fred Oyle, an 18yearold Californian only a few months out of high school, was growing increasingly restless in his community college classes at this time last year. He Was wondering why he was in college and what he wanted to do with his life.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: CHICAGOLife hasn't always been easy for J. Roderick MacArthur. The son of John D. MacArthur, the eccentric billionaire who built his fortune on insurance, real estate and banking, Rod did not face the ordinary concerns of the scions of the superrich.

description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Face the Nation Robert J. Lipshutz, counsel to President Carter.

title: New President and Old News
description: Jimmy Carter, the man from Plains, Georgia, set a welcome theme of simplicity for his inaugural. Dressed in a business suit rather than formal attire and speaking in soft tones, Mr. Carter delivered one of the shorter inaugural addresses and one which consciously moved away from the grandiose. I have no new dream to set forth today but rather urge a fresh faith in the old dream, he said.

title: Women's Studies Get Organized
description: Five hundred women from scores of American colleges have met and established a National Women's Studies Association to lobby for feminist causes and try to legitimize women's studies, one of the newest, fastestgrowing and most controversial, field's of academic study.

title: Carol Webster Is Bride of Henry McCormack
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Carol Webster to Henry A. McCormack. The Rev. Peter E. Camp performed the ceremony.

title: A writer to be watchedin both senses; The Life and Extraordinary Adventures Of Private Ivan Chonkin By Vladimir Voinovick. Translated by Richard Laurie. 316 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.; Private Chonkin
description: In 1956, a young construction worker from the Crimea wrote away to the famous Gorky Literary Institute in Moscow. Though he had grown up on a state farm during World War II and had only five years of education, he had been writing in his spare time in the army, at night schobl, and after the day's work as a carpenter. I felt a great need to say somethingwords that could serve as the motto of Russian literature generallybut I didn't yet know what that was. So he pressed on, writing a poem a day for a year, and when a couple were accepted by the local newspaper he applied to the Institute, which trains Soviet writers. When he was turned down, he replied with a telegram in verse:

title: France's new culture palace
description: When, a century ago, Victor Hugo pontificated that henceforth the nations unanimously recognize Paris as the leading city of the human race, there may have been a stray politician or moralist somewhere who disagreed, but so far as the transAtlantic art world was concerned, Hugo was only trumpeting an obvious truth. Other cities  Rome, Munich, Londonremained bustling art centers, of course, attracting not only artists but also the indispensable ranks of connoisseurs and collectors who supported them: yet, in the last decade of the 19th century, Paris emerged unchallenged as the artistic capital of the Western world. It retained this position of esthetic eminenceand the commercial rewards that go with ituntil well into the 20th century.

title: Janice Sacco Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Sacco of Winchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janice Marie Sacco, of Beverly, Mass., to Jerome Lewis Ablon of New York, son of David Ablon, also of New York, and the late Julia Ablon. The future bridegroom's marriage ended in divorce.

title: MONDALE OFF TODAY ON TRIP TO 6 NATIONS
THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Back in midNovember, well before much of the nation fell into the grip of its recent severe and prolonged spell of exceedingly frigid winter weather, a visitor to a Pennsylvania steel plant noted several wheelbarrows filled with coal near the doors of one of its fabricating mills. It was apparent they contained the fuel supply for the adjacent bonfires in used oil drums.

title: GARDENING
description: FEW if any perennial plants go through life without at least one resting period each year. New Jersey's indoor gardeners must take this fact of plant life into consideration if they want healthy. freely blooming species. Some common house plants do not have a long or obvious resting season, and gardeners need keen eyes to determine when growth stops and the plants relax, as it were.

title: Engaging Songs By Tom Rush At Bottom Line
description: Tom Rush, who's at the Bottom Line through tonight, may not have the commercial success or the cultural relevance he once had. But he still offers a most pleasing, relaxed and musical performance.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Sniping between Thurman Munson and George Steinbrenner broke out last week before an armistice was quickly arranged. But the New York Yankees have not yet begun to fight among themselves.

description: WEST POINT, NY., Jan. 22Beating an Army basketball team in the cavernous West Point Field House is an almost impossible tasksomething like assaulting Fort Knox with beebee guns.

description: WHILE the snow this winter may have created problems for pedestrians and commuters, it is not without its benefit to the gardener.

description: Governor Carey of New York has submitted his new budget, and its message is what he said it would be: that it is time for Government at all levels to reverse the trend of decades and do less, rather than more, governing.

title: TRAVEL
$1 Million Brown Lung Suit Filed
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 22 (UPI)A $1 million Federal suit coordinated by the Brown Lung Association charges three manufacturers of textile equipment with creating conditions that cause brown lung disease with their equipment. The suit was filed on behalf of Omry Glenn of Gaston, who worked in the Olympia mill in Columbia for 25 years. Platt Saco Lowell, Bahnson and M. Lowenstein & Sons were named in the suit. The suit contends that the three concerns designed or modified equipment in such, a way as to create dust which would be harmful to the plaintiff's body, lungs, respiratory system, skin and health.

title: Around the Nation
description: CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., Jan. 22 (AP) A carbon dioxide leak, first noticed when a basketball player collapsed, sent more than 50 players and fans from a high school game to the hospital.

title: Gas Allotment Bill Planned This Week By the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Carter Adminstration energy officials said today that they hoped to have ready for introduction in Congress early next week emergency legislation authorizing the Government to allocate natural gas supplies among pipelines. Final passage within days was seen as a possibility.

title: Lucy A. Jones to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Jones of East Islip, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Ann Jones, to Robert Soha, son of Susan Soha of West Islip, L.I. and the late Emil Soha.

title: Pedaling Like Mad And Going Nowhere
description: All over the city, a dedicated band of bicyclists pedals away, coatless and content, oblivious to snowstorms and Arctic temperatures. No, they're not masochists; they simply refuse to let the weather interfere with their normal exercise. So they ride inside their homes, thanks to an ingenious accessory known as. rollers.

title: Southern Africa Is Waiting
description: Ivor Richard, the British chairman of the adjourned Geneva conference on Rhodesia, has sought the assistance of the South African Prime Minister, John Vorster, to try to revive the talks. But Mr. Vorster appears unlikely to adopt a new initiative toward his white neighbors until the policies of the new United States Administration toward Rhodesia become known.

title: Legislative Hearings Scheduled This Week
description: The following public hearings will be held in New York City by state legislative committees this week:

title: Solzhenitsyn Is Planning to Start A Nonprofit Publishing Company
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 22Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the exiled Soviet author, will start a nonprofit publishing business in Vermont that will distribute works on Russian culture, history and religion in the United States and abroad.

title: Preparing for Geneva
description: No one believes Mr. Sadat's regime is in danger of falling; he retains the strong support of the military. But last week's serious disturbances may convince wealthier Arab nations, and perhaps some in Washington, of the validity of his claim that he really wants a peace settlement to turn to domestic problems.

title: Article 6  No Title
New York State's Population Shows Slight Rise in Last Census
description: New York State had a population risebut a minor one of 8,000 personsin the year up to last July 1, according to newly released Census Bureau estimates.

title: For political ends
description: These books are part of a rapidly growing literature about the use of violence for political ends, or ostensibly for political ends. Both books range widely in time and space, and they overlap to a considerable extent There may be a conceptual distinction between terrorism and guerrilla though I confess it still, eludes me after reading these two volumesbut in practice the two are so often found to be mixed up that differences between them become blurred.

title: LastMinute, But Large, Loan
description: The Federal Government has Issued $730 million in loan guarantees to help the General Dynamics Corporation build seven superships that will carry liquefied natural gas from Indonesia to Japan.

title: Anarchist Labor Movement Being Revived in Spain
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Jan. 22A oncepowerful labor movement that the bulk of Spain's working class has barely heard of is regrouping and resuming its uphill pursuit of the perfect, stateless society.

title: Interference by C.B. Radios Causing a National Earache
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 22  Citizens band radio, that Southernborn phenomenon that has a sizable part of the country saturating the air waves, is now causing a great national earache. Because of an electronic quirk, Rubber Ducky is no longer talking only to receptive listeners like Jelly Belly and Dragon Lady, who talk back on C.B.'s of their own; he is also talking to vast numbers of people who never wanted to listen.

title: Saypol Cleared
description: As expected, a bribery and perjury indictment brought against Justice Irving H. Saypol of the State Supreme Court by Maurice H. Nadjari, the former Special Prosecutor, has been dismissed on the ground of insufficient evidence, The case is one of several indictments brought by Mr. Nadjari that have been thrown out. Robert IW. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, who is currently handling the Saypol case, said he would not appeal. Mr. Morgenthau had publicly criticized Mr. Nadjari's methods of gathering evidence in the case.

description: Stanley Steingut, the Speaker of the New York State Assembly, accused commercial banks yesterday of financial coercion and arrogant political moves in trying to influence the decisions of the state and New York City governments in the current fiscal crisis.

description: Robert Williams Dunn, founder of the Labor Research Association and a cofounder, with Roger Baldwin, of the American Civil Liberties Union, died of cancer Friday night in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 2 Jane Street in Greenwich Village.

title: GOV. ASKEW DECLARES CROP DAMAGE DISASTER
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP) Gov. Reubin Askew declared Florida a disaster area today after receiving preliminary reports on the extent of crop damage from last weeks freeze.

title: Dayton Case Raises Question of the Supreme Court's Direction
description: WASHINGTONWhen the nation's public schools opened last September for the new school year, the general counsel for the N.A.A.C.P. was decidedly cheerful. He and some of his colleagues sensed a changed atmosphere, an increased public acceptance of school desegregation. There was still a lot desegregating to do, but there were some good new signs: a new school desegregation plan for the Dayton, Ohio, schools, put into effect without violence; a drop off in the push for antibusing legislation. There is more optimism today, he said, than there has been in a number of years.

title: New Products
description: A portable but powerful compact heater which is ideal for heating garages, outbuildings, or home workshops has recently been introduced by Koehring, Atomaster Div., Bowling Green, Ky. 42101. Called the M30 Reddy Heater, it is a miniature oil burner that is designed to run on kerosene when plugged into a standard household electric outlet. The heater consumes only about onequarter of a gallon per hour while delivering up to 30,000 BTU's more than enough to warm an average twocar garage or sizable home workshop and storage area at a cost of approximately 11 cents per hour. An efficient high capacity blower circulates clean hot air that is filtered as it flows through the unit, and a solid state flameout protection device automatically shuts everything down when there is any kind of. malfunction. A smaller version of larger, commercial units that have been in use for years on building sites and factories, the M30 is priced at $126.95 with combustion chamber and other key components made of stainless steel.

title: A Gospel Show Makes a Joyful Noise on Broadway
Memoirs of a Trotskyist
description: Not long ago, I passed through the Loeb Student Center, at New York University's Washington Square campus. It is a modern and luxurious buildingto my eyes, definitely poshwith comfortable sofas and chairs, ample space and light and all those little amenities that correspond to our middleclass notions of gracious living.

title: Neediest Aided By Archbishop
description: Archbisbop Iakovos, Primate of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America, sent a check for $100 last week to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Club Med: Not for Everyone
Smuggled Guns From U.S Are Common in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 22One Mexican Cabinet minister always removes a pistol from his belt and bands it to his chauffeur when he enters his limousine. Another top official avoids the customary Mexican embrace because of the gun he carries. And one state governor is so proud of his silverdecorated pistol that he says he feels undressed without it.

title: Underlying the School: Anthroposophy
description: This subtle word and philosophy gives even its adherents trouble when they try to define it. Literally defined by the Random House Unabridged Dictionary of the English Language, it means a philosophy based on the teachings of Rudolph Steiner which maintains that, by virtue of a prescribed method of selfdiscipline, cognitional experience of the spiritual world can be achieved.

title: Strother Sets a Record In Dash Thompson Wins
description: The sprinters took over the spotlight yesterday at the 28th annual Cardinal Hayes Games in the 102d Engineers Armory. Steve Strother of New Rochelle, who set a meet record of 31.5 seconds in the 300yard dash, headed the list.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22With a bit of Irish drollery and lots of oldfashioned drive, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, New York's freshman Democratic Senator, is going about the political business of trying to get himself named to the Senate Finance Committee.

title: Fire Kills Mother and Child
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (UPI)  Fire officials said that a mother and her daughter were killed today in a blaze of undetermined cause that heavily damaged their apartment in the city's Kensington section. Identities were withheld pending notification of relatives.

Potdevin of Ridgewood, became the bride of Robert Stephen Curry Munier. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emile H. Munier 2d of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Lake Winnipesaukee, N.H. The rector, the Rev. Richard B. Andersen. performed the ceremony.

title: A woman of transcendent intellect who assumed the sufferings of humanity
description: Simone Weil, one of the most brilliant, and original minds of 20thcentury France, died at the age of 34 in a nursing home near London. The coroner issued a verdict of suicide, due to voluntary starvationan action undertaken at least in part out of wish not to eat more than the rations given her compatriots in France under the German occupation. The year of her death was 1943.

title: Judee Mader Fiancee Of Donald Roberts Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Maximilian A. Mader of New York and East Hampton, LI., have announced the engagement of their daughter Judee Mary Mader, to Donald Hargreaves Roberts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roberts of Summit, N.J. N.J. A wedding in April is planned.

title: Article 5  No Title
PASCUAL PEREZ
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 22 (UPI)Pascual Perez, former flyweight boxing champion, died today at age 54 of a liver ailment. He had been in a coma in a clinic for the last week. Perez was the Olympic flyweight champion at the 1948 London Games and turned professional in 1952. He beat Yoshio Shirai of Japan in 1954 in Tokyo, to give Argentina its first world boxing title.

title: Italy's Abortion Bill
description: The Italian Chamber of Deputies has approved legislation to legalize abortion, ending a battle for reform of the laws dating back to the era of Benito Mussolini, and indicating the further decline of the Roman Catholic Church as an influence in Italian politics.

title: 90 Reported Killed In Soviet Air Crash
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 2 (UPI)  A Soviet TU104 airliner exploded in the sky and crashed last week as it tried to land in the Central Asian city of AlmaAte, killing at least 90 persons, unofficial sources said today.

title: Coat, But Not Fine, Forfeited
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (UPI)Barbara S. Johnson will have to forfeit her imported $1,750 ocelot coat to the Federal authorities, but she can have back her $10 fine, says Federal District Judge Bernard Decker. Court records, made public Thursday, said Judge Decker found the coat had been imported in violation of the 1972 Endangered Species Act. He ruled Mrs. Johnson must give up the coat, which slipped by customs agents at O'Hare International Airport.

title: Environmental Quality Held Down
LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: A LOT of people in New Jersey got left out when the Federal Government started awarding publicworks projects to stimulate activity in hardhit unemployment areas. That is the conclusion of the state's Washington, office following an analysis of the 56 projects approved for New Jersey since the Public WorkS Act was passed last year.

title: STAMPS
description: They are now played by millions instead of just a few, and the attire is noticeably different, but no British sportsman would today have any difficulty recognizing the racket sportstennis, squash, badminton and table tennis that originated in substantially their present form in England roughly a century ago.

title: John B. Henrich Dies at 64, Former Head of N.L. Industries
description: John B. Henrich, vice chairman and past president of N.L. Industries, formerly the National Lead Company, died Friday at St. Joseph's Hospital, Stamford, Conn., after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived on Georgian Lane, Darien.

title: The Cold and the Gas Shortage
description: Two predictions, one that the winter would be abnormally cold and the other that natural gas stockpiles and production were too low to meet heavy demand, have come true, and the result is also as predicted.

title: A Coalition That Speaks Up
Consignment Store
Understanding Crime's Victims
description: NASSAU COUNTY has no lack of volunteer and professional organizations that are involved in the county's criminaljustice system and how it affects the victims, offenders, their families and their communities. But until two years ago, when the Nassau Coalition for Safety and Justice was formed, these groupsmany of which had common concerns and goals  operated virtually independently of one another.

title: Beautiful Days
description: Torn away from the care of a childless woman, Roll suddenly found himself transplanted in an alien world.... From the very beginning the events around Roll caused him great confusion inside. So begins an extraordinary semiautobiographical novel by a young Austrian writer, a valorous fiction about childhood, brutality, the birth of a shocked sense of what the world is like, the struggle for a self, the decision, against all tyrannical events, not to go mad.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Walter. E. Koons, a nice old gentleman who has been in music all his lifeas critic, editor, and supervisor for the National Broadcasting Systemhas come up with something of an oddball book. For some 40 years he has been asking musicians and those interested in music to give their definition of music, and he has published the, results of his longtime survey in a little volume named The Mystery of Music (Vantage Press, $7.50).

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The tragic death last week of Yuri Soloviev is yet another disaster for Leningrad's once mighty Kirov Ballet, which nowadays seems to have fallen on hard times. Since 1961, when it first visited the Westappearing initially in Paris (where Rudolf Nureyev defected), then in London and finally in New Yorkit has lost, one way or another, almost all of its most celebrated dancers. And the mood in Leningrad, according to reliable reports, seems to be gloomy.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: AS WE all know, this is one of those years when New Jersey will elect a Governor again. Now this is not as easy as it sounds. In the past, it has been sort of a chore for the state because very often people didn't wont to be New Jersey's Governor.

description: MARION, Mich., Jan. 22 (AP)Roger Britt and Dan Hayes rode to their second consecutive snowmobile race victory today in the fifth annual Marion 150 Enduro.

title: Businessmen Assail Head of P.S.C.
description: The Owners Committee on Electric Rates, an organization of New York City business executives, has announced an allout effort to have Alfred E. Kahn removed as chairman of the state's Public Service Commission.

description: New York City's efforts to maintain racial integration in a school system that is steadily losing its white pupils have provoked sympathy from the state but a charge of discrimination from the Federal Government.

title: New York State's Tuition Aid Plan Faces a Revamping as Costs Rise
The case against capital punishment
description: I believe that most Americans, even those who feel it is necessary, are repelled by capital punishment; the attitude is deeply rooted in our moral reverence for life, the JudeoChristian belief that man is created in the image of God. Many Americans were pleased when on June 29, 1972, the Supreme Court of the United States set aside death sentences for the first time in its history. On that day the Court handed down its decision in Furman v. Georgia, holding that the capitalpunishment statutes of three states were unconstitutional because they gave the jury complete discretion to decide whether to impose the death penalty or a lesser punishment in capital cases. For this reason, a bare majority of five Justices agreed that the statutes violated the cruel and unusual punish.

title: The Gamesman  Tom Sawyer in the Executive Suite.

description: More and more the shortage of revenue in the metropolitan region is making liberal Democratic politicians sound and act like conservative Republicans. Democratic governors in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are approving, or making plans for, cuts in business or personal income taxes and continued retrenchment in government services.

title: As Rates Fall, Money Funds Become Parking Lots
description: During the money crunch of 1975, when interest rates soared to historic highs, a new breed of mutual fund made its appearance and almost immediately achieved spectacular success.

description: President Carter's repeated references to human rights abroad have given American authors and activists in the cause of freedom new hope that their protests on behalf of harassed and imprisoned writers in Czechoslovakia and elsewhere will be followed up by moral suasion from the White House and Federal agencies.

description: EVERY month or so a diner on my commuterbus route is decorated with colorful bunting heralding its Grand Opening. The flags and banners are barely taken down when they go right up again. Many other stores along the way have similar ephemeral lifespans. The same flags wave periodically for them.

title: ExCongressman, a Bitter Critic of Emprise, Now Comes to Its Defense
description: In a startling political reversal, a former member of the House of Representatives who was the bitterest critic of the sports concession concern popularly known as the Emprise Corporation has jumped to the company's defense,

title: Poor little rich man
description: The old man died in a condition so wretched he might have been taken for one of The New York Times Neediest Cases. Naked, almost unable to hear, one leg atrophied, riddled with bedsores, unable to eliminate his own wastes, starving, Howard Hughes brought himself to his miserable end while worth more than a billion dollars and he died as he did surrounded by aides who were supposed to isolate him from the world and tend to his every whim. However well those aides had served him, they also wound up constructing one of the tightest, most powerful bureaucracies ever conceived, an organization that protected Howard Hughes from the outside world, but not from himself.

title: Albany Aides Get Increases in Pay
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22 (UPI)The Assembly has released its first payroll list for the 1977 session, with, most staff members receiving raises over last year.

title: ALBERTA FURCOLO
description: BOSTON, Jan. 22 (UPI)Alberta Furcolo, mother of former Gov. Foster Furcolo, died Thursday on her 80th birthday. She had resided in New Haven and Longmeadow, Conn. The former governor is now a United States administrative law judge in Boston. His mother is survived by another son, Charles L. of Woodland Hills. Services were scheduled today.

title: Mexico City Search for Guerrillas Is On
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan, 22 (Reuters) Mayor Hank Gonzalez of Mexico City said today that security forces would use helicopters and heavy arms in the hunt for members of the Communist League 23d of September.

description: A legalservices group estimates that a $3.7 million administrative outlay could bring as much as $306 million more in Federal foodstamp funds into New York State's economy, generating an overall $1 billion in new business.

description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22After two days of rest and recreation in San Diego following a stretch in which they had won, just one of their last seven games, the New York Rangers worked hard tonight against the Los Angeles Kings in the Forum. Doug Soetaert, the rookie goalie, was in the New York net for the third consecutive game.

title: An Open Letter to Mr. Carter
description: SAINT PAUL DE VENCE, FranceI have a thing to tell you, but with a heavy heart, for it is not a new thing.In North Carolina, as I write, nine black men and one white woman are under sentences of a total of 282 years in various prisons on various charges, including arson. The Rev. Ben Chavis, who was 29 years old yesterday, is the best known of the Wilmington 10.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Portuguese community in Mineola now has a new restaurant to try, and the rest us have the opportunity to add some variety to our dining out. The newcomer, Estoril Granuda, combines the cooking of both Spain and Portugal. It is basically peasant food; rich stews and casseroles, their many ingredients simmered together and sharing flavors, are the mainstay.

title: For young readers

description: New York will have a new professional team this fall, and women will have a new pro sport open to them. The Women's Basketball Association was formed last week, a 12team professional league that is scheduled to open a sixmonth, 62game season in October. The W.B.A. is the brainchild of Jason Frankfort, a New York restaurant owner and former stockbroker who will serve as chairman of the board of the new league.

description: The venereal Infection called gonorrhea is the most common bacterial disease of humans on earth. There are an estimated 100 million cases each year throughout the world, probably more than 2 million of them in the United States. The numbers have been rising year by year.

title: A writer to be watchedin both senses; The Life and Extraordinary Adventures Of Private Ivan Chonkin By Vladimir Voinovick. Translated by Richard Laurie. 316 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.; Private Chonkin
description: In 1956, a young construction worker from the Crimea wrote away to the famous Gorky Literary Institute in Moscow. Though he had grown up on a state farm during World War II and had only five years of education, he had been writing in his spare time in the army, at night school, and after the day's work as a carpenter. I felt a great need to say somethingwords that could serve as the motto of Russian literature generallybut I didn't yet know what that was. So he pressed on, writing a poem a day for a year, and when a couple were accepted by the local newspaper he applied to the Institute, which trains Soviet writers. When he was turned down, he replied with a telegram in verse:

title: The Economy: Room for Improvement
description: The latest set of economic statistics shows that President Carter has taken office when the state of the nation's economy is still not good, but shows signs of getting better.

title: The sexless orgies of morality
description: Had security guard Frank Wills not noticed a taped door lock at the Watergate Office Building on June 17, 1972, we might never have known that there were those in the inner circle of the Nixon Administration who lived by a code alien to the values most of us cherish. Who can say where the abuses of power might have led had there been no opportunity for these abuses to emerge into public view?

title: Nets Halt 13Game Slide, 9586

title: Briton's Accused as Spies In Czech TV Program
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 23 (AP)Czechoslovak television broadcast a program today in which several British diplomats and a British journalist were accused of being spies. The accusation was promptly denied by the British.

title: Leonard Silk
description: BONNVice President Walter F. Mondale and his advisers are scheduled to arrive here tonight, and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is looking forward to explaining to the Americans why he thinks the Carter Administration will be making a big mistake if it tries to put pressure on West Germany to adopt more stimulative fiscal and monetary policies. In an interview here on Friday, during a break from parliamentary debates, Mr. Schmidt said, The German economy is in good shape. He emphasized that he was opposed to any tax cuts even to spur business investment. He indicated disbelief that cutting taxes was a way to cure unemployment.

title: A Refreshed and Newly Confident Schmidt Resumes Active Role
description: BONN, Jan. 23Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has come out of a preChristmas depression with his health, his political selfconfidence and his combative spirit all apparently restored.

title: Leader of Rhodesia Faction Consoles Nkomo on Aide
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Monday, Jan. 24 (Agence France Presse)Bishop Abel Muzorewa, a moderate black Rhodesian leader, yesterday sent his condolences to the family of Jason Moyo, a military leader in a riyal group headed by Joshua Nkomo. Mr. Moyo was killed by a parcel bomb Saturday.

A fire official said that the four had been blown into the street by the blast but that none were believed to be hurt seriously.

title: Foreign Stake in U.S. Rises
description: Foreign companies announced 250 investments in United States manufacturing facilities during 1976, The  Conference Board said over the weekend. This was the highest figure in the nine years that the board has compiled figures of this kind.

title: GOING OUT Guide

(no Sunday) once again provides balletomanes with a rare opportunity to. look in on a training ground that has yielded dancers to every major company in the Western world. For a taxdeductible fee of $10, visitors can watch apprenticeship sessions that have produced over half of the members of the New York City Ballet, including Suzanne Farrell, Edward Villela, Jacques d'Amboise and Patricia McBride.

title: Miss Navratilova Victor
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 23 (AP)Topseeded Martina Navratilova defeated Sue Barker of England, 76, 75, today In the final of the $100,000 Houston women's pro tennis tournament.

title: Wanted: Sharks to Eat Evel Knievel
description: The refined and discriminating taste of the American television viewer has been the subject of more than one treatise by students of behavioral science. It accounts for the enduring success of such classics as Twilight Zone, As The World Turns, Guiding Light and many others. A milestone in theatrical history was passed a couple of summers ago when thousands bought tickets for a closedcircuit TV show on the promise that if all went well they would see Evel Knievel disemboweled on the rocks at the bottom of the Snake River Canyon. That entertainment was a failure. His makeshift space buggy didn't make it across the canyon and Knievel didn't get killed. Naturally, many viewers felt cheated, so now CBS is making it up to them. The network promises that if they tune in on Evel Knievel's Death Defiers a week from tonight, they may get to see the star torn into canapes by sharks. The show is a 90minute special to be broadcast live from 8:30 to 10 P.M.

title: A Center for Widows Guides Them Gently Over Stages of Grief
description: Marilyn Spadaro thought about staying home from work the other morning, and several times she reached for the telephone, knowing that her supervisor would understand. It was the fourth anniversary of the day her husband was stabbed to death by a mugger outside their Brooklyn home.

title: SugarCoating School Aid Medicine
description: In theory, New York State's allocation of school aid is supposed to equalize the amount each district spends for its children. In practice, each district wants at least as many dollars as every other district. And so, whenever the state comes up with a formula to take away from the rich districts to give more to the poor, the affluent majority in the Legislature kills the entire idea. The device that has strangled every recent attempt at reform is a virtually universal hold harmless doctrine, which means that even the richest district shall get no less than the year before and which leaves only crumbs to boost aid for the needy.

title: Books of The Times
description: It's become a clich of sportswriting that for every black basketball player who makes it out of the ghetto to star on the college or professional level, there are dozens, perhaps hundreds, of equal talent who don'twho disappear instead into a syringe or a wine bottle, or simply dissipate their gifts making moves that no other players can blend with. It's a clich, but Rick Telander doesn't just repeat it in his first book, Heaven Is a Playground; he illustrates and elaborates it. He shows us why basketball is as important to the black urban ghetto child as the three R's are to Middle America; why some youths make it while most of them don't; why, in short, one young player Mr. Telander got to know was prompted to observe, If the ghetto didn't do something to black people there wouldn't be much use for white folks in basketball, would there?

title: The Rights Standard
description: WASHINGTONA consistent and singleminded invocation of the human rights standard in making United States foreign policy decisions would serve neither our interests nor the cause of freedom. We believe our Government should uphold the full range of human rights and that peoples everywhere should enjoy them. With freedom under siege throughout the world, we should by precept and example continue to hold high the torch of human dignity, but ironically the human rights standard is a singularly confusing guideline for responsible statecraft. It has become chic to talk of morality and foreign policy, but there is little awareness of the pitfalls in these noble words. Making human rights the chief, or even major, foreign policy determinant carries dangers.

title: 'The Day That Shook World' A Quaint Film
description: Despite an awesome title, "The Day That Shook the World," which arrived at the Festival yesterday, is more quaint than explosive. As a dramatization of the fulminating events leading up to and including the royal murders that triggered World War I, it is a fragmented revival of the past that evolves largely as a picturesque adventure rather than portentous, persuasive history.Filmed well over a year ago on authentic Yugoslav locations, this "Day That Shook the World" appears to have been cut somewhat confusingly, for all of the obviously good, serious intentions of its little-known director, Veljko Bulajic, and his American scenarist, Paul Jarrico.Although they focus in captivating color on the June 1914 assassination in Sarajevo of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne, and his morganatic wife, Sophie, their plotters, the burning nationalistic issues and the regal machinations that led to that fateful day are touched on in a succession of brief, fuzzy intrigues. The hatred of Bosnian, Serbian, Muslim and other nationalities of Hapsburg dominance is merely indicated. And the backgrounds of the seemingly educated, mostly youthful student-conspirators are also glossed over.If memory serves, photographs of the Archduke and his spouse were portraits of a rather heavy-set, mature couple, but in the persons of Christopher Plummer and Florinda Bolkan they are a strikingly photogenic, regal and loving pair. Mr. Plummer not only adores the equally loving, stately, brunette Miss Bolkan and their three children but also carries off official duties at military maneuvers and dinners with the same brashness he evinces in a mild clash with Franz Joseph, the irascible, octogenarian emperor.Maximilian Schell plays the role of the tortured, eventually ill-fated, bearded revolutionary who trains the callow assassins, with simple, glum determination. Among the largely Yugoslav supporting cast, Irfan Mensur plays Gavrilo Princip, the young conspirator who fired the fatal shots. Like his colleagues, he is simply a harried type more involved in a series of escapes from detection by the police than in character delineation.In guiding his fairly large cast, Mr. Bulajic has succeeded in creating a good deal of melodrama, some tension and a few tepid romantic interludes. And Jan Curik, his cinematographer, has captured the scenic charms of an operetta-like countryside and the visual qualities of vintage automobiles, colorful uniforms and sham battles with toy-like soldiers in maneuvers. Unfortunately, their "Day That Shook the World" is a footnote to history that is rarely moving.
