description: LYNDONVILLE, Vt., Jan. 23 (AP)Tim Caldwell, a 22yearold member of the American Olympic team, won the men's 30kilometer race today, the opening event of the national Nordic crosscountry ski championships.

title: Dancers at City Ballet Eager to Work After Strike
description: Christine Redpath started training her dog, PigaIle, which she got after the New York City Ballet's fall season in Paris. Daniel Duell put up shelves in his apartment and pegboard for Kyra Nichols, a fellow dancer.

title: Talks By Bangladesh and India Fail to Resolve Dispute on Ganges
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 23 (AP)Talks between India and Bangladesh on the issue of sharing water from the Ganges River collapsed today, leaving relations uncertain between the two neighbors.

title: ENTRIES
description: Horses listed in order of post position Letter designates OTB listing

title: Cairo Assails Criticism by Moscow
description: CAIRO, Jan. 23Egyptian newspapers reacted sharply today to criticism of President Anwar elSadat's policies by Pravda. the newspaper of the Soviet Communist Party.

title: 500 RABBIS ASSESS MORAL STATE OF U.S.
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, Jan. 23Alarmed by what many of then describe as the most disturbing breakdown of moral values in the nation's history, 500 Orthodox rabbis tonight opened a threeday special convocation here on Jewish life and mores.

title: Many Call to Confirm The White House Chill
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 23It was frosty day in Washington, with temperatures from 17 to 31 degrees, and throughout the day curious, or perhaps skeptical, persons telephoned the White House to ask what the indoor temperature was.

title: A NearDisaster By Kennedy Jet Brought to Light
Southern Blacks Shift Goals From Rights to Economics
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23A group of tough, publicityshy black Mississippians has built a $10million business that runs lour manufacturing plants and a Delta plantation. It operates without finfare and shuns dogooders because, the president says, we're not in the sympathy market.

title: Nights Are Long and Liquid at Key West
description: KEY WEST, Fla.Clay McDaniel is no partypoop. But 31 bashes in 60 days?

title: Opposition Accuses Mrs. Gandhi Of Murdering India's Democracy
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 23India's political opposition formally opened its election campaign against the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today with blistering attacks on the authoritarian rule of the last 19 months.

title: Skiing
description: AT LYNDONVILLE. VT.

title: My Life Sifts Through the Past Blindly
description: Eddie Howe, a successful young physicist, is swimming in memories, traveling in time from his adulthood back to his adolescence. He sees figures from his pasthis mother and father, a girl he loved who died, a grandfather he never metand he sees himself as a Younger man.

title: Chirac Facing Fight With Giscard in Effort to Revive Gaullists
description: PARIS, Jan. 23Former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, who took over and relaunched the old Gaullist party and is now running for mayor of Paris to reinforce his political base, said today that the Socialist  Communist opposition would win power in France if he did not take the initiative.

title: Violin Recital by Hart Is Forthright and Secure
description: Alfred Hart's violin recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall was one of those occasions in which demonstrable lack of internationallevel quality didn't preclude a most enjoyable program. Mr. Hart is not about to challenge the great reigning virtuosos of his instrument, nor will Abbott Ruskin, who accompanied him, perforrh similar oneupmanship on other pianists. But both men play strongly and securely, despite awkwardnesses of bowing or the passing missed note, and both were able to communicate the music.

title: Topics
description: The Gold Lust

title: Platform Tennis
description: AT SHORT HILLS, N.J.

title: TV: Code R Wins an I for Inane
description: Code R, which CBS has slipped into schedule Friday nights at 8, is the kind of weekly series that reflects network desperation. Mindless formula has been reduced to the ultimate absurd. CBS seems to have examined the competitionSanford and Son on NBC, Donny and Marie on ABCand decided that if it has to go down, it might as well go down with a genuine clinker.

title: Beame Getting Personal Briefing From Bankers on the Fiscal Crisis
description: The bankers who met with Governor Carey last week to escalate their deblends in connection with New York City's continuing fiscal crisis will meet with Mayor Beame this afternoon, the Mayor said yesterday.

title: Yonkers Results
description: SUNDAY

title: LOUIS B. GNAEDINGER, 78, RETIRED JOURNALIST, DIES
description: Louis Beverley Gnaedinger, a retired journalist who had worked for several metropolitan publications, including The New York Times, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: More than 50 persons were left homeless last night when a fouralarm fire swept through a sixstory apartment building in the South Bronx. There were no reported injuries in the blaze, which broke out shortly after 9 P.M. at 600 East 141st Street. The fire was declared under control at 11:30 P.M. Victims were being lodged by the Red Cross at a Manhattan hotel.

title: Carey Proposal to Cut Relief Roll Raises Fears at Welfare Centers
description: This was the comment of Earl Jamison, a jobless Vietnam veteran, when he was told about Governor Carey's proposal to cut from the relief rolls, after 45 days, anyone who is childless and able to work. He was more baffled than angered by the Governor's proposal last week, which will be considered for the first time today by legislators in Albany.

title: Article 3  No Title
Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT LANDOVER, MD.

title: New York State Still Faces Lawsuits Despite Carey's Attica Clemency Stand
description: Despite Governor Carey's move last month to firmly and finally close the book on the 1971 Attica prison uprising, the state is still faced with defending itself against dozens of lawsuits asking millions of dollars in damages.

title: Opposition Accuses Mrs. Gandhi Of Murdering India's Democracy
description: NEW DELHI, Jan.. 23India's political opposition formally opened its election campaign against the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today with blistering attacks on the authoritarian rule of the last 19 months.

title: Sadat Asks Economic Changes
description: CAIRO, Jan. 23 (AP)President Anwar elSadat called for drastic changes in Egypt's economic structure today in the wake of riots last week that left at least 77 persons dead.

title: Homosexuals Among the Clergy
In Memoriam
description: ADELAAREmll. So lovingly remembered, so sadly missed, Beloved wife, Sandra.

title: New York State Could Lose $37 Million in U.S. Welfare Aid by Failure to Locate Runaway Fathers
description: New York State's federally mandated program to track down runaway fathers who abandon their families is plagued by several major deficiencies that threaten the state with the loss of $37 million to $50 million in welfare aid to families.

title: Pakistani Accuses Government Of Having a Role in Kidnapping
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan, 23 (Reuters) An opposition politician told a rally of about 100,000 people here today that he had been kidnapped to prevent him from opposing Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto in next month's general election.

title: Briton Says Rhodesian Proposal Would Prolong the Guerrilla War
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 23 (UPI) Ivor Richard of Britain said today that the guerrilla war in Rhodesia would continue if Prime Minister Ian D. Smith tried to keep militant nationalists out of an interim government leading to black majority rule.

title: Freeze and Thaw Produce a Thumper Crop of Potholes
Letters
description: Community Financing: A Federal Alternative

title: Beame Very Serious About That 2d Term
description: A week ago Mayor Beame began the customary electionyear mayoral teasing about his possible plans to seek a second term by telling a television audience that he was seriously considering running.

title: Cathy Leinoff Is Married
description: Cathy Lynn Leinoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Leinoff of Paterson. N. J., was married yesterday to Edward Kenneth Newman, an offensive lineman for the Miami Dolphins football team. The ceremony was performed at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N. J., by Rabbi David H. Panitz of Paterson. The bride is a hostess with Victoria Station Inc. in Miami, a restaurant chain. Mr. Newman's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Newman of Woodbury, L. I.

title: Illicit AfterHours Drinking Clubs Costing State $10 Million a Year
description: It is 6 A.M., and in one of New York City's plush but illegal East Side afterhours bottle clubs, 200 customers sip quality Scotches and brandies, welldressed couples dance to soft music and gamblers bet as much as $50 on a roll of the dice.

title: Protests on Rescue Unit Disrupt Golden's Swearing In
description: Howard Golden, the interim Brooklyn Borough President, welcomed some 700 Brooklynites to an open house at Borough Hall yesterday, but not all of them had turned out to wish him well.

title: PARKING RULES
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will be in effect in New York City today after a weeklong suspension because of snow and icy roads.

title: Bullets 119, Pistons 108
description: LANDOVER. Md., Jan. 23 (AP)The streaking Washington Bullets won the 11th of their last 13 games tonight defeating the Detroit Pistons, 119108. Elvin Hayes scored 30 points for the victors.

title: Delinquents Friends Held To Have Big Influence
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)A teenager's friends have more influence than his parents in determining whether he will become involved in serious juvenile delinquency, researchers said in a report issued today.

title: Chess
description: Kim Commons of Los Angeles triumphantly marched through Bulgaria taking first prize in three successive international tournaments and, while he was at it, gaining the rank of international master.

title: Two Boys Rescued in Icy River
description: CLAYMONT, Del., Jan. 23 (UPI)A ride aboard an ice floe in the Delaware River almost led to disaster for two Delaware youths, who were swept downriver and fell into the freezing water before being rescued by a Coast Guard cutter. The youths, James Pabst, 15 years old, and Lee Richards, 14, both of Claymont, said that they climbed aboard a fivefootwide ice chunk yesterday afternoon and began to pole their way along the river bank. But gusting winds and high waves carried them away from shore.

title: Marion Post Clinches Victory in Colgate Trophy Skiing
Dance: At the Riverside Festival
description: Joan Lombardi and Vic Stomata, two moderndance choreographers, presented a joint concert with the same dancers Saturday night at Riverside Church's Riverside Theater Dance Festival.

title: Greece Is Facing an Uphill Fight For Admission to Common Market
description: ATHENS, Jan. 19Negotiations have begun to make Greece the 10th member of the European Economic Community, but a series of economic and political problems could prolong the talks for several more years.

title: Warren Page, 67, ExGun Editor Of Field and Stream Magazine
description: Warren Kempton Page, the former gun editor of Field and Stream magazine and a member of the Hunting Hall of Fame, died Saturday in New Canaan, Conn. He was 67 years old.

title: Article 4  No Title
Industry Using Other Fuels To Cut Dependence on Gas
description: When the Scovill Manufacturing Company's new plant in Rantoul, Ill., was designed, a special boiler that can burn surplus sawdust was included and in these gasshort days, it generates virtually all of the factory's steam. At Universal Studios near Los Angeles, where natural gas exclusively is used for heating, fewer portable heaters are being put on stages and building temperatures have been reduced to 68 degrees from 72. In Ohio, a halfdozen companies, including General Motors, are drilling for their own

title: Sir Andrew Humphrey Dies at 56
description: LONDON, Jan. 24 (Reuters)Britain's defense chief, Sir Andrew Humphrey, Marshal of the Royal Air Force, died today of pneumonia, which he contracted during freezing weather on a visit to British forces in West Germany. He was 56 years old.

title: Egyptian Riots Have Seriously Hampered Sadat's Freedom of Action at Home and Abroad
description: CAIRO, Jan. 24Even if no new violence occurs in the near future, it is now taken for granted by foreign observers her that last week's riots transformed the political landscape of Egypt and seriously impaired President Anwar elSadat's freedom of action at home and abroad.

title: EARNINGS OF E.F. HUTTON INCREASED BY 16.9% IN '76
description: Earnings of E. F. Hutton & Company, the brokerage firm, rose 16.9 percent to $23.3 million, or $3.88 a share, in 1976 frOm $20.1 million, or $3.39 a share, in the preceding year. Revenues also inCreased to $314.7 million from $253.1 million in. 1975.

title: Taxes &
description: A week after publication of the intensely critical Metcalf report on The Accounting Establishment, it is an open question just how seriously accountants and businessmen will take the 1,760page document, the product of a year's inquiry.

title: W.H.A. Player Suspended
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 24 (AP)  The Indianapolis Racers Kim Clarkson, defenseman, has been suspended by the World Hockey Association for three games for spearing Pierre Roy of Quebec on Nov. 25 and Frank Beaton of Edmonton on Jan. 15, the Racers announced today.

title: Care on Ice Urged
description: The state marine police advised the public to be careful on frozen tidal rivers and bays, which may have dangerous soft spots. Capt. B. Russell Henry, chief of the marine police, said that salt ice did not freeze evenly and that dangerous weak spots might not be apparent but could pose a danger to anyone venturing out onto rivers or bays.

title: All Worlds and All Experience Are Fit Subjects for the Stage
description: Whether you think John Bishop's The Trip Back Dovm an extremely promising piece of work, as I do, or whether you find it a less than vigorous showcase for the bravura talents of the actor John Cullum, there is one rap the play shouldn't have to take. I've read in half a dozen pldhes by this time the suggestioneven the judicial pronouncement that The Trip Back Down doesn't belong on the stage, or to the theater, at all. Why? Because it's about stockcar racers, a subject only films could possibly hope to cope with.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: NEW STEPPE When young Robert de. Gaetano gave his first New York recital two years ago, Allen Hughes of The New York Times referred to his remarkable pianistic control and uncommonly seductive playing in a variety of musical styles in a program ranging from Bach to Samuel Barber.

title: Energy Companies Profits Increased by Intense Cold
SENATE STREAMLINING VOTED BY RULES UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Senate Rules Committee cut through delicate issues of jurisdiction and power today and unanimously approved a compromise mea4ure to streamline the Senate in its first major reorganization in 30 years.

title: PARKING RULES
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations are suspended in New York City today because of snow and icy roads. All other parking rules remain in effect.

title: Judge Rules Against Prosecution Of Husband for Rape of Own Wife
Plan for 8th Ave. Amusement Park Is Formally Unveiled to the Public
Report Alleges Welfare Fraud Of $25 Million
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman estimated yesterday that there were 6,600 phantom children on New York City welfare rolls, enabling families to collect fraudulently $25 million a year in benefits. His estimate was challenged later by both the city Human Resources Administration and the State Department of Social Services.

title: Lifemobile Program On
description: A special program to provide hometohospital emergency treatment for heart patients was begun by five Mercer County hospitals. The Lifemobile program will provide 24hour ambulance service with a nurse and paramedics trained to treat cardiac patients.

title: Business RecordsBANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT
description: Monday, Jan. 24, 1977

title: Fire Ruins Vermont Resort Hotel
description: CHITTENDEN, Vt., Jan. 24 (AP)Most of one of Vermont's most exclusive resort hotels burned to the ground overnight after a candle apparently set fire to some drapes, officials said. The fire at the Mountain Top Inn sent 35 guests fleeing into the subfreezing temperatures outdoors the authorities said.

title: Fordham Beaten for 8th Straight Loss
description: Columbia's 9277 victory over Fordham at Levien Gym on Morningside Heights last night will not go down as an artistic basketball achievement. It was, however, a case of scrappy basketball in a game that was supposed to be an easy triumph for the Lions but was far from a walkaway.

title: From a Quiet Seminarian To Homosexual Spokesman
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24Five years ago, a young man who grew up in Houston and had wanted to join the church since he was 17 years old, was ordained a minister here at the United Church of Christ, or, as it is also called, the Congregational Church.

title: Barbara Lilly Keefe Dies at 58, Founded Bronxville Service Unit
description: Barbara Lilly Keefe, formerly of Bronxvine, N.Y., the wife of William C. Keefe, chairman of the board of the Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company died of cancer Sunday in Houston. She was 58 years old and had lived in Houston since 1968.

title: Article 7  No Title
HEALTH TEAM FIGHTS DEADLY  AFRICAN VIRUS
description: GENEVA, Jan. 22Teams of doctors have flown to two remote areas of Africa in a mission to collect blood from the few survivors of a deidly new viral disease. The doctors hope transfusions of the blood plasma portion will save lives in future epidemics.

title: Market Place
description: The hottest current takeover candidate in Wall Street is the Milgo Electronic Corporation, which yesterday received a revised bid from Applied Digital Data Systems following on the heels of a $26ashare cash bid by Milgo's British partner in a joint venture, Racal Electronics Ltd.

title: ONE OF TWO INDICTMENTS AGAINST JUDGE DROPPED
FED IS ALLOWING BANKS TO NEGOTIATE PLACEMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 24The Federal. Reserve Board has in effect told commercial banks they may continue to negotiate private placements of securities, a practice strenuously opposed by investment bankers.

title: Joyce Bryant Is Singing at Cleo's
description: Ten years ago, Joyce Bryant gave up a singing career that had made her a cafe headliner to do missionary work in Africa and South America. Now she has reversed her field and is singing once again, currently at Cleo's, Broadway at 63d Street. One can only conclude that she must have been a singing missionary, because her voice is a remarkably compelling instrument.

title: BANKS LEND BRITAIN $1.5 BILLION TO ADD TO FOREIGN RESERVE
description: LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP)Britain received a $1.5 billion bank loan today to bolster its reserves of foreign currency.

title: CARTER IS CALLING FOR A PROMPT HALT TO ALL ATOM TESTS
Coal Mine Union Is Facing A Deficit of $4 Million
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Jan. 24 (UPI)The United Mine Workers, which finished $4.1 million in the red in 1976, faces deficit projections of from $4 million to $5 million this year, the union controlled Robert Ward, said today.

title: Times Literary Supplement Twits Overrated Fame
description: With a shattering of reputations, The Times Literary Supplement of Gray's Inn Road, London, has just come out with its 75th anniversary issue. The reverberations should keep the Oxbridge dons and erudite readers firing off letters to the editor, the mildmannered John Gross, for the rest of 1977.

title: Princess Rosemary Colonna, 45
description: ROME, Jan. 24 (UPI)Princess Rosemary BarrettMurphy Colonna committed suicide early today by jumping from a window of her luxury apartment near the Roman Forum, the police said. The Princess, 45 years old, was said by the police to have been suffering from depression.

title: Cutback in Pennsylvania
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania said today because record cold temperatures resulted in abnormal use of natural gas for home heating it will increase curtailment of supplies to industrial users on Feb. 1.

title: Unfair Practices Charged
description: MIAMI BEACH. Jan. 24 (UPI)Unfair labor practices were filed today against five resort hotels and their bargaining agent by a hotel service employes union that recently went on strike for three weeks. The complaint named Miami Beach's Deauville, Doral Beach and Carillon hotels and Miami's Dupont Plaza and Doral Country Club, along with the Southern Florida Hotel and Motel Association. The attorney for Local 355 of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes and Bartenders Union, charged that since a strike settlement was agreed upon Jan. 14, almost 200 union members at the five hotels had been laid off.

title: KHALID SUGGESTS ROLE FOR FRANCE IN TALKS
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 24King Khalid suggested today after weekend talks with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing that France could play an erninent role in the search for a Middle East settlement.

title: A Fresh Start And No Tears For Betty Ford
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Jan. 24Gerald Ford had barely entered the ranks of the retired last week when he got the word from his wife.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York. N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Episcopal Priest, Seeking A Divorce, Loses 2 Posts
description: A wellknown Episcopal priest on Long Island has been stripped of his parish duties and his position as dean of the Diocesan Seminary by his superiors who objected to his stated intention to get a divorce from his wife and to remarry.

title: Article 2  No Title
Huge Rivals: Hughes and G.T.E.
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company, a privately owned company of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, does not build aircraft; it specializes in the design and manufacture of sophisticated electronic equipment and components.

title: YOUTH IS CONVICTED OF SLAYING IN PARK
description: After eight hours of deliberation, a sixman, sixwoman jury late last night found Oswaldo Diaz, 18 years old, guilty of stabbing to death a young woman in Central Park last Sept. 11 in an attempt to steal her purse.

title: Ballet: Tomasson's Apt Albrecht
description: It is an ill wind that brings nobody any good. I must say that I have never understood that phrase, but if we only try to deal with what we understand we never expand our knowledge. In any event the now happily suspended strike of musicians that hit New York City Ballet made available Helgi Tomasson to make his guest debut with American Ballet Theater at the City Center 55th Street Theater.

title: Article 4  No Title
CORRECTION
description: The film Les Galettes de Pont: Aven, which was reviewed yesterday, did not open at the 68th Street Play. house, which is showing The Marquise of O . . . indefinitely. Les Galettes, which The Times's critic saw at a pre view, may open at a later data.

title: London Daily Express Adopts Tabloid Form
description: LONDON, Jan. 24 (Reuters)The Daily Express, faced with falling circulation, today became the third Fleet Street newspaper in recent years to switch to the smaller tabloid format. The Mail became a tabloid six years ago, following the example of The Daily Herald, now renamed The Sun.

title: Malaysian Is Sentenced
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Jan. 24 (Reuters) A powerful Malaysian politician was sentenced to six. months in jail today on forgery charges involving the company that promoted the 1975 world heavyweight championship fight here between Muhammad All and Joe Bugner.

title: Transit Authority Halves Number Of Subway Cars in OffPeak Hours
description: Moving with unexpected speed, the Transit Authority yesterday cut the number of cars by half on many offpeak subway trainsweeks before the service cuts were scheduled.

title: ASSASSINATION PANEL FACING BUDGET TRIM
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Representative Jim Wright, the House majority. leader, Predicted today that the House Assassination Committee would be continued but that its budget would be considerably curbed below the grandiose figures that have been bandied about.

title: Cranston and Carter Seek to Pick Nonpartisan Judges in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 (AP)Senator Atan Cranston's office and aides to President Carter are working to establish a panel to recommend people for appointment as Federal judges and prosecutors in California in an attempt to remove partisanship from the selection process.

title: ORDERS INCREASED ON DURABLE GOODS BY 6.6% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24New orders for durable goods placed with the nation's manufacturing industry last month rose by a substantial 6.6 percent in one of the biggest increases of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MONDALE PLEDGES U.S. WON'T CUT NATO FUNDS
description: BONN, Jan. 24Vice President Mondale, citing increased Soviet military strength in Europe, said today that the Carter Administration was prepared to increase defense spending in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: How Wheels of Justice Turned For 8 Cogs in Traffic of Drugs
description: Four years ago, the intelligence section of the Police Department compiled a list of 100 major narcotics violators. Among them were eight men considered important cogs in the city's narcotics traffic.

title: Jersey Egg Production Reported Down 15%
description: TRENTON, Jan. 24 (AP)New Jersey's egg production has dropped about 15 percent statewide due to the cold weather, and consumers can expect higher prices as a result, state agriculture officials said.

title: Skiing
description: AT ADELBODEN, SWITZ.

title: $200,000 in Furs Stolen
description: Ten thousand mink, coyote and raccoon fur pelts valued at a total of $200.000 were stolen in Brooklyn by three armed robbers wearing ski masks. According to the police, the robbers forced a truck carrying the furs to the curb on Morgan Avenue near the BrooklynQvems Expressway. Two robbers forced Irving Brodsky, the driver, and Richard Kazas, his helper, into the rear of the van, while the third man drove off with the truck, the police said. The two deliverymen were dropped off several miles away after being driven around for more than two hours. The furs belonged to the Brooklyn Dressing Corporation, which operates a plant at 207 Starr Street.

title: Teachers Voting on Pact
description: The South Brunswick school board reached a tentative agreement on a contract with teachers and other employees, opening the way for an end to a threeWeek strike. A board spokesman said that the schools would reopen today for 4.000 students if the agreement was ratified by the employees.

title: Reward for Killer
description: A group of concerned citizens posted a $5,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of the person who hurled 8yearold Miriam Malave to her death Sunday from the roof of a sixstory housing project building at 390 Georgia Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn. The police, who reported the reward offer, asked for public help in finding the killer. A special telephone number2870311was set up to take calls, and homicide detectives said all information would be kept confidential.

title: Gypsies of Hungary In Prancing Concert
description: The Rajko Hungarian Gyspy Orchestra and Dancers pranced onto the stage of Carnegie Hall for performances Saturday night and Sunday afternoons The troupe is a young one, average age 19, and judging from yesterday's show it possesses boundless reserves of energy.

title: Lawyer Named to Cable TV Post
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24 (UPI)  Governor Carey today announced the appointment of Malcolm Fein, a Brooklyn lawyer to the State Commission on Cable Television. If confirmed by the Senate Mr. Fein would serve in the $5,000ayear post until Jan. 1, 1982. He would succeed Edward Wegman of Grand Island, whose term expired. Mr. Fein, 45 years old, is active in civic and charitable organizations in Brooklyn, the Governor's office said.

title: Italians Lead Auto Rally After Surge by Amateurs
description: MONTE CARLO, Jan.24 (AP)The Italian favorites, Sandro Munari and Silvio Maiga, driving a Lancia Stratos, unofficially led the Monte Carlo rally today. But freakish weather earlier helped some unknown amateur private teams embarrass the powerful factorybacked professionals.

title: Miss Smith Wins Florida Golf
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. Jan. 24 (UPI)A par 4 on the 37th hole today gave Lancy Smith of Snyder, N. Y., first place in the 45th Doherty Challenge Cup golf tournament at the Coral Ridge Country Club. Miss Smith defeated Debbie Raso of Cape Coral, Fla.. in sudden death at the 5,942yard course.

title: A Global Effort Starts to Identify Biological Areas
description: A program aimed at identifying and delineating the world's different kinds of biological areas ranging from Alaska's tundra to Africa's deserts has gotten underway in the United States and other countries.

title: MONDALE PLEDGES U.S. WON'T CUT NATO FUNDS
description: BONN, Jan. 24Vice President Mondale, citing increased Soviet military strength in Europe, said today that the Carter Administration was prepared to increase defense spending in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: A Fresh Start And No Tears For Betty Ford
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Jan.. 24Gerald Ford had barely entered the ranks of the retired last week when he got the word from his wife.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP. NET DECLINED IN 4TH QUARTER
description: Fourthquarter net of the First Chicago Corporation before securities transactions dropped to $17.37 million, or 44 cents a share, from $24.55 million, or 62 cents a share, the year before. Profits after securities transactions rose slightly to $26.30 million, or 67 cents a share, from $26.06 million, or 66 cents a share.

title: Top Executive Quits The Parent Concern Of Washington Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The president of The Washington Post's parent cornpany.will resign effective Feb. 1, apparently, after losing the confidence of Katharine Graham, The Post's publisher and the principal owner of the diversified communications corporation.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter is urging an instant and complete halt to all testing of nuclear weapons as a step toward curbing their spread and ultimately banning them, he disclosed in his first White House interview. He said he had received an encouraging message front the Soviet Union. He was hopeful also of fairly rapid ratification of a new treaty with the Soviet Union limiting strategic arms. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Sanjay Gandhi Suggests He'll Run for Parliament
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 24 (AP)Sanjay Gandhi, son of India's Prime Minister, said today he might run for Parliament in the general elections in March and predicted his mother's Congress Party would win by a huge majority.

title: Turkey Is Withdrawing 1,000 Men on Cyprus
description: ANKARA, Jan. 24 (Reuters)The Turkish Government announced today that it was withdrawing 1,000 troops from Cyprus. The withdrawal will apparently reduce its forces there to about 27,000 men.

title: DAVID KAVINOKY
description: David Kavinoky, a Buffalo lawyer and civic leader, died there on Sunday. He was 73 years old.

title: Millrose Games to Feature Latest RunIn Between Mrs. Lutz and Jan Merrill in 1,500
description: The way Rory Kotinek tells it, Francie Larrieu Lutz was seated with some friends in the bar of the Hilton Inn in Philadelphia last Friday night, drinking nothing more than hot chocolate, when Jan Merrill's coach, Norm Higgins, walked by.

title: Profit for Company First in 3 Quarters
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24The financially troubled American Motors Corporation reported today that it had halted its recent accumulation of heavy losses by earning $1.2 million, or 4 cents a share, during the three months that ended last Dec. 30.

title: JOHN EDWARD HOLTZINGER
description: ALTOONA, Pa., Jan. 24 (UPI)John Edward Holtzinger, publisher of The Altoona Mirror and Pennsylvania Mirror in State College, Pa., died yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY. JANUARY 24. 1977

title: Group Agrees to End Bias
description: An organization of white residents of Rosedale, Queens, charged with violating the Fair Housing Act, have signed a consent decree that orders it to halt any practices that could lead to discrimination in the sale or purchase of homes in the community. Under the terms of the decree, the organization, called Restore Our American Rights, has agreed to halt all discrimination based on race, religion or sex in connection with the rental or sale of housing. Before undertaking the present action, two men accused by the Federal Government of bombing a Rosedale house bought by a black couple were acquitted.

title: Nuggets Topple Braves As Issel Stars, 127102
description: DENVER, Jan. 24 (UPI)Dan Issel scored a gamehigh 32 points, including 19 in the last half, and grabbed 18 rebounds to lead the Denver Nuggets in a 127102 victory over the Buffalo Braves tonight. It was the Nuggets 23d homegame victory.

title: SNOW FALLS WITH RAIN EXPECTED IN ITS WAKE
description: Salt spreader and temperatures hovering around freezing helped to clear the city's streets of falling snow, which reached an accumulation of up to one and a half inches in parts of the five boroughs last night.

title: Group Wants Carter Ousted From Legion
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24 (UPI)The state adjutant of the Wisconsin American Legion said today that his organization planned to spearhead efforts to have President Carter ousted from the organization because of his pardon of Vietnam War draft evaders.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Pregnancy and Discrimination
description: A company provides incomereplacement payments to temporarily disabled employees for all disabilities that both men and women incur, such as lung cancer, alcoholism and skiing injuries, and all disabilities that only men incur, such as prostatectomies. There is one exception: disabilities arising from pregnancy or childbirth.

title: SADIE PULLMAN
description: Sadie Pullman, president of Hadassah in Brooklyn from 1958 to 1960, and of the Queens chapter from 1971 to 1973, died yesterday in Peninsula General Hospital, Rockaway, Queens, after a lingering illness. She lived at 1015 Dickens Avenue, Far Rockaway, and was 62 years old.

title: Beame and Banks Meet on Budget And Find a Broad Agreement
description: Mayor Beame and a group of leading bankers met yesterday and later declared themselves in broad agreement on steps to meet New York City's debt and budget problems  but they appeared to be no oloser than ever on the key issue of outside controls of the city's finances.

title: Belfast Sniper Kills Soldier, 19.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 24 (Reuters)A 19yearold British soldier was shot to death by a sniper in a Roman Catholic area of Belfast last night, a British Army spokesman reported. A bullet from a highvelocity rifle struck the soldier, who was on patrol, as he stood beside two young children, the spokesman said.

title: But Now the Wolf Is at the Door
description: For three years the Federal Energy Administration has been warning of dangerous shortages of natural gas, on which the country depends for a third of its energy. Little heed was paid. The F.E.A., in fact, was accused of crying wolf during a succession of unusually warm winters. But now the wolf is at the door.

title: Mr. Sadat's Path to Recovery
description: If we read the news from Cairo correctly, President Sadat seeks now to turn a time of domestic turmoil and weakness into something of a foreignpolicy advantage. He seems to feel that the United States and others owe him an extra measure of support, and perhaps in our own interest we do.

title: Excerpts From the White House Transcript of Carter's First Interview as President.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)Following are excerpts from the official White House transcript of President Carter's first interview as President, conducted yesterday in the White House with two reporters from The Associated Press and two from United Press International.

title: Shutt Bows Out
description: Steve Shutt, the Montreal Canadiens right wing, will be replaced on the Wales Conference allstar team by Bob Gainey of the Canadiens. Shutt's wife is expecting a baby soon, and he said he preferred to remain at home. .. Jan Turnbull of the Toronto Maple Leafs will substitute for Toronto's Darryl Sittler, who recently tore rib cartilage.... Bob Nystrom of the New York Islanders is replacing the Islanders Clark Gillies on the Campbell Conference squad. Gillies has a viral infection of the spleen.

title: WILLIAM FOSTER HOPKINS
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 24 (UPI)William Foster Hopkins, defense counsel in more than 700 murder trials in 50 years, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Bond Prices Off Despite Action By the Reserve
description: The credit markets, nervous about the growth of the nation's money supply and the strength of the economy, declined fairly sharply yesterday even though the Federal Reserve injected reserves into the banking system early in the day. Longterm bond prices generally dropped a halfpoint. The bond market had declined late last Friday afternoon after the Federal Reserve disclosed that the narrowly defined money supply had contracted by $700 million in the week ended Jan. 12 a smaller decrease than some money market analysts had expected.

title: Westchester Areas Get Offer of Change To Cheaper Power
description: The New York State Power Authority agreed yesterday to sell electricity to 27 local governments and school districts in Westchester County that have been seeking to withdraw from using the Consolidated Edison system. The sale is contingent upon approval by Governor Carey.

title: Smith Rules Out British Proposal On Rhodesia Pact
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 24Britain's attempt to achieve a settlement between Rhodesia's white minority and the black majority failed today.

title: Life on Women's Satellite Tennis Tour: Practicing at 6 A.M., Cookies and Soup
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I.In Portland, Ore., practice time was 6 to 8 A.M., if you were lucky enough to get a court. At the Hiawatha Hotel in Halley, Idaho, where Ernest Hemingway was supposed to have written several novels, there were communal bathrooms and showers. At the bar were freshly scrubbed cowboys and sheepherders.

title: People and Business
description: The Federal Reserve System is facing potential serious problems because many smaller commercial banks have been leaving the central banking system, Paul A. Volcker, president of the Federal Reserve. Bank of New York, said here Yesterday.

title: A Lesson in Prison Life, Taught by Experts
description: RAHWAY, N.J., Jan. 24Imagine being buried alive and knowing that there was no way out, the sternfaced prisoner told the 11 obviously frightened teenagers who sat almost motionless on a long bench in front of him.

title: Heini Hemmi Defeats Stenmark For 3d Victory in Giant Slalom.
description: ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 24 (AP)Heini Hemmi of Switzerland, an Olympic champion, posted his third giant slalom victory of the season today. He beat the runnerup, Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden. the World Cup holder, by threequarters of a second.

title: Financial Woes Confront N.H.L. At Its Meetings
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 24Unable to ignore any longer a general financial weakening throughout its circuit, the National Hockey League opened its annual meetings here today with somber talk of realignment of the teams and a fear that the Cleveland franchise might have to fold.

title: Carter Cancels Chauffeur Service For His Staff as Economy Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Jan; 24  President Carter presided over his first Cabinet meeting today and immediately sounded as the opening notes of his Administration his campaign themes of simplicity, frugality and candid discourse.

title: $50 TO THE NEEDIEST LEADS TO SECOND GIFT
description: A New York couple now living in Caracas, Venezuela, said they wanted to remember the destitute here and several weeks ago sent $50 to the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 3 Admit Fraud Scheme
description: Three defendants pleaded guilty yesterday in Newark to conspiring to drain $4.3 million from the State Bank of Bloomfield through a series of fake commercial leasing and loan agreements. The defendants, Dominic Troiano, 45 years old, of Monsey, N.Y.; James Lanzone, 50, of Coral Springs, Fla., and Winfield Scott, 53, of Jacksonville, Fla., admitted in Federal Court that they had submitted a series of bogus commercialloan applications to get money from the bank. The three men said they had conspired with Robert J. Prodan, former president of the bank, to purchase and discount commercial financial agreements. Mr. Prodan, charged with masterminding the scheme, is the only defendant who has not pleaded guilty to the Federal bankconspiracy charges. He is scheduled to go on trial today in Federal District Court.

title: Six in Family Die in Fire
description: GRANTS PASS, Ore., Jan. 24 (AP)While a man and one of his sons were out chopping firewood, fire leveled their primitive mountain cabin and killed his wife and his five other children yesterday. The victims were identified by Josephine County sheriff's deputies as Joyce Fay Strickland, 34 years old; and her children, Randell, 11; Tamatha, 9; Stephen, 6; Connie Sue, 3, and Matthew Gregory, 1.

title: About New York
description: It is hard to weep for a Fifth Avenue matron who can afford to invest by the tens of thousands of dollars. But Gertrude S.  no last name here because she is as conservative in print as she thought she was in financesis holding some of the city's funny money, the now famous moratorium debt that turned a whole faceless group of relatively smallerbore capitalists from the, idle to the agitated rich.

title: $109,397 Track Payoff
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 24 (AP)Five brothers and their father won $109,397.25 with a $2.50 combination yesterday atthe El Nuevo Comandante race track. Each one of the six made his own cuadro and one of the combinations picked the five winners with one race canceled.

title: Music: Rwnpal Essays the Baton
description: In the first of a threeconcert series Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall (the others are Feb. 13 and March 27), JeanPierre Rampal was bent on proving that he is more than merely the world's most popular, acclaimed flutist. He wants to be known as a conductor, too. On Sunday, he made a rather contradictory case for his ambition.

title: Leaders of Miami Beach Beginning to Concede City Has Problems
Barazzutti Is Defeated By Nastase
3 Reds Killed in Office at End of Violent Day in Spain
description: MADRID, Tuesday, Jan. 25At the end of a day of provocative violence, two gunmen burst into a Communist labor office last night and murdered three men, following the kidnapping earlier in the day of a prominent general.

title: Jaspers 6th in Row Sinks St. Francis
description: The St. Francis College basketball team threw a scare into streaking Manhattan last night, but the Jaspers hung on to win, 6963, before 1,800 fans at the St. Francis court and stretched their winning streak to six games. They now have won nine of their last 10.

title: State Senate Passes Bill Allowing Municipal Courts Define Obscenity and Asks U.S. Abortion Action
description: TRENTON, Jan. 24The State Senate passed today a bill giving municipal courts the authority to define obscenity and another measure asking Congress to call a convention to amend the Federal Constitution so as to outlaw abortions.

title: Olga Morozova Advances
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 24 (UPI) Olga Morozova of the Soviet Union didn't decide until late today to play South Africa's Marise Kruger, then beat Miss Kruger, 75, 63, in the first round of the $100,000 Virginia Slims Tournament of Minnesota. In the past, Russian players and teams have refused to play South Africans because of political considerations.

title: Front Page 1
$140 MILLION I.M.F LOAN FOR EGYPT LIS REPORTED
description: CAIRO, Jan. 24 (Reuters)The International Monetary Fund has agreed to lend Egypt $140 million to help boost the country's ailing economy, the semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram reported today.

title: How Wheels of Justice Turned For 8 Cogs in Traffic of Drugs
description: Four years ago, the intelligence section of the Police Department compiled a list of 100 major narcotics violators. Among them were eight men considered important cogs in the city's narcotics traffic.

title: 18 on School Bus Injured
description: JACKSON, Tenn., Jan. 24 (UPI) A school bus transporting 32 childreh slid on an icecovered downhill curve, grazed a bridge railing and overturned in a waterfilled ditch today, injuring 18 children.

title: Human Rights Charter Criticized in Prague
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 24 (Reuters)The Government today called a press conference in which workers, artists and Communist Party officials rejected a Czechoslovak humanrights document published recently in the West.

title: $540,000 Mail Theft in Germany
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Jan. 24 (AP)Two men stole Italian and Dutch currency worth $540,000 from a West German postal truck today. The police said the cash, from a bank in Milan, was insured for only $830. The thieves struck while the truck's two drivers were delivering packages. As they returned to the truck they, saw two, men running away with the loot, the police said.

title: 2 Philadelphia Inquirer Reporters Win Award of Newspaper Guild
From the Police Blotter:
description: Ronald Satchel, 27 years old, a community center director at the Marble Hill Houses at 1047 Summit Avenue, the Bronx, was arrested as one of the four men involved in a fatal shooting of David McLean, 24, of 1750 Sedgwick Avenue in the Highbriclge section of the Bronx. . . . A 27yearold Bronx. man was stabbed fatally in the chest by an unknown man during a dispute reportedly over money in front of 314 West 127th Street in Harlem. He was identified as David Bond of 1349 Webster Avenue. . . . Two men forced their way into an apartment at 47 Sickles Street in the Fort Tryon section looking for Vernon Bagby, 26, who was visiting there. Shots were exchanged and one of the intruders, an unidentified man about 20, was killed. Mr. Bagby was shot in the leg. The arrested.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Rice Five's Coach Quits
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)Bob Polk, the Rice University basketball coach, hired three years ago to rebuild the school's program, announced his retirement today.

title: Books of The Times
U.S. 1977 Trade Deficit Expected
description: Although both imports and exports will show increases, the United States will have an $11 billion trade deficit this year, or a rise of $2 billion from 1976, as measured in a balance of payments basis, according to the National Foreign Trade Council.

title: Rise in Public Works Spending Would Not Affect Jobless This Year, Congressional Budget Expert Asserts
Article 3  No Title
description: A VIEW OF STARS ABORNING: Ballet students practiced yesterday at the School of American Ballet, but with a difference. It was the first day of open house for visitors contributing $10 or more. Open house will continue through Feb. 5, from 10:30 A.M. until 7:00 P.M. on weekdays and on Saturdays from 9:30 A.M. until 3.30 P.M. The School of American Ballet is located at Lincoln Center's Juilliard Building, 144 West 66th Street.

title: JOHN LAGATTA, ARTIST, A LEADING ILLUSTRATOR
description: John LaGatta, a leading magazine illustrator of the 1920's and 30's, died Friday in Santa Monica, Calif., where he had lived for many years. He had taught at the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena.

title: DuPont's 4th Quarter Earnings Dropped 34%
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that its fourthquarter earnings fell 34 percent behind the yearearlier level despite an increase of 5.1 percent in sales. Net income for the year rose 70 percent higher than in 1975 as sales increased by 15.8 percent.

title: Pawtucket Farm Club Given a New Owner
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., Jan. 24 (AP)Officials of the International League named today a Lincoln, R.I., businessman, Ben Mondor, as the new owner of the Boston Red Sox's Pawtucket farm club.

title: Challenge on Accounting
description: A week after publication of the critical Metcalf report on The Accounting Establishment, serious acceptance of the report by accountants and businessmen is being questioned. Page 57.

title: NEW SHOPPING MALL PUSHED FOR FLUSHING
Energy Crises Ripe
description: Energy crises mounted in Ohio, Pennsylvania and other states yesterday in one of the bitterest and most unrelenting winters on record. The Federal Government took, action to keep homes warm.

title: Music: Talented Oberlin Singers
description: Currently on its annual East Coast tour, the Oberlin College Choir arrived in Alice Tully Hall Sunday night for a varied concert of choral music covering a wide range, from late Renaissance (Lasso) through the Classical (Mozart, Haydn) and Romantic eras (Mendelssohn, Bruckner) to the 20th century (Poulenc, Earl George, James Fritschel and Knut Nystedt).

title: Manila Expels a Fourth American
description: MANILA; Thuesday, Jan. 25 (AP)For the fourth time in four monts the Philippine Government has expelled an American on grounds of internal security.

title: Topics
description: A Slight Omission Since the peccadilloes of the puritanical offer greater entertainment than the felonies of the fallen, everybody has enjoyed catching the city's Department of Consumer Affairs in a slight case of mislabeling. Radio scripts prepared for the agency's busy commissioner, Elinor Guggenheimer, failed to note that the narratives she related to her audience had been somewhat doctored to increase their verisimilitude. Truth is not always enough for the home audience, and one can hardly blame the commissioner for spiking it just a little to make her points. Unfortunately, the nature of the adulterant was left off the label. This is precisely the sort of offense on the part of others to which the department responds with siren and bells.

title: Conviction of Black Youth Upheld in White's Slaying
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24(AP)The Louisiana Supreme Court upheld today the conviction of Gary Tyler, a black teenager accused of killing a white schoolmate after a racial disturbance, at Destrehan High School.

title: Defining What the Knicks Are Not
description: If the National Basketball Association playoffs were start tonight, the New York Knicks would not have qualifiedthe Knicks with all their superstars, the Knicks with their payroll of more than $2 million, the Knicks who appeared so spectacular only three weeks ago. At that time the Knicks were challenging the Philadelphia 76ers for first place in the Atlantic Division but now they're challenging the memory of Cleveland Buckner and Paul Hogue and Dave Budd when the Knicks had horrible teams. Now the

title: Amy Is Late for School But Gets Warm Welcome
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)Amy Carter completed her transition to Washington today by arriving late for her first day of classes.

title: John Vincent, Composer, Headed Music Department at U.C.L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 (UPI)John Vincent, composer and former chairman of the music department of the University of California at Los Angeles, died on Friday. He was 74 years old.

title: Dollar Shows Gain On Most Markets
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 24 (UPI)The dollar rallied on European money markets today and in a sharp reversal of early morning declines closed higher on all markets except London and Brussels.

title: House Leader Expects Congress Will Prevent Default by New York
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Representative James C. Wright, the House majority leader, said today that Congress would do whatever is necessary to keep New York from defaulting on its obligations even if it means renewal of the emergency loan program grudgingly approved last year.

title: Teacher's Puppy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)Amy Carter matched her father's famous grin after school today when she first saw Grits, a black and White 12weekold puppy that was born the day Jimmy Carter won election as President.

title: Rites for Toots Shor Set for Tomorrow
description: Funeral services have been scheduled for Bernard (Toots) Shor, the celebrated New York saloonkeeper who died of cancer of the colon Sunday night at the age of 73.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Books for Outdoorsmen
description: Wrapped in the embrace of the bitterest winter in more than a decade, the anticipated pleasures of dawdling along a June trout stream seem more intense than unusual, particularly when they are described by one of the most accomplished and articulate fly fishermen in America.

title: Civil Rights Activists, Saying Impetus for Change Has Shifted From Court, Look to Carter Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Concerned that the Supreme Court is no longer providing the impetus toward further racial integration in the country, many civil rights lawyers and lobbyists feel that the burden of leadership toward an integrated society has Shifted to the new Carter Administration.

title: Test Decision Pending
description: A Federal judge in Newark reserved decision on a request to ban Jersey City from administering psychological tests to applicants for jobs as firemen. Judge James A. Coolahan said in United States District Court that he would review the case before ruling if the mandatory tests violated a job candidate's right to privacy when he was asked questions about his religion, sex and politics. Marilyn Morheuser, an attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union, argued on behalf of five men who sued Jersey City for requiring the tests as part of a job application. The tests include a wideranging series of questions about political ideas, religious beliefs, social attitudes and familial relationships. They are administered after a job applicant has been certified by Civil Service.

title: Eviction Appeal Denied
description: A large wholesale produce dealer, Goodie Brand Packing Corporation, lost yet another appeal against eviction from the cityowned Bronx Terminal Market by its operator, the Arol Development Corporation.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, JAN. 24The Legislature today completed action on a bill easing the point system covering the suspension of drivers licenses. Governor Byrne is expected to sign the bill into law.

title: TV: Exquisite General's Day
description: Public television's Piccadilly Circus is a monthly series of imports from Britain, and its mixed assortment of programs, while generally attractive, is undeniably curious.

title: An Apparent Divergence On Consumer Confidence
description: Earlier this month, within a few days, two leading private institutions that regularly track the level of confidence among American consumers issued what seemed to be directly conflicting reports on the public's recent mood. Economists and other anti lysts who follow such things were considerably puzzled, and some began to wonder about the value of the reported data. First there came the Jan. 10 statement by the Conference Board, the prestigious nonprofit organization funded by many leading American corporations, that there was a sharp rise in consumer confidence during December, when its latest bimonthly poll of 10,000 households was taken. Its index (196970=100) moved up 11 points since October to 91.2, but it was up only by 4.4 percentage points since August.

title: Article 8  No Title
South African Area Will Be Declared Free
description: MAFEKING, South Africa, Jan. 24 (AP)Bophuthatswana, one of South Africa's eight remaining black tribal homelands, will he declared independent next Dec. 6, it was announced here today.

title: Conference Standings
Bridge:
One G.M. Strike Ended And a Second Delayed
description: DETROIT. Jan. 24 (UPI)The United Auto Workers ended one potentially crippling strike against General Motors today and extended the deadline on negotiations to avert a second one.

title: Book Linked to C.I.A. AntiAllende Effort Sold in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24A book that has stirred controversy in Britain because of reports that it was commissioned by a propaganda vehicle for the Central Intelligence Agency was also published in the United States and has been on sale here since 1974.

title: Duvillard Scores Again
description: BIG BEAR LAKE, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) Henri Duvillard triumphed yesterday 4 in the $40,000 Dodge Cup dual challenge slalom. The 29yearold Frenchman earned $5,400 for the victory over Wilfried Muxel of Aspen. Colo., in the final. Duvillard increased his leading moneywinnings on the world pro ski tour to $33,883.

title: North Korean Premier in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24 (UPI}Prime Minister Pak Sung Chul of North Korea arrived today for talks expected to coordinate strategy toward the Carter Administration on Korean issues. It is the first official visit by a toplevel North Korean leader to the Soviet Union since 1972.

title: Panel Says Dam Collapse Could Have Been Averted
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)The head of an independent panel that studied the collapse of the Teton Darn in Idaho told a Senate hearing today that engineers could have foreseen factors that led to the structure's failure.

title: After the Sorensen Debacle
description: The rejection of Theodore Sorensen as director of the C.I.A. has left Wesident Carter little choice as to another nominee. He must find a director as committed as Mr. Sorensen Viag to controlling the agency and keeping its operations, covert as well as overt, within the strict limits of the lily and Administration policy.

title: HILARY OLIVER
description: Hilary Oliver, a retired investigator for the Immigration Division of the United States Department of Justice and brother of the late Webster J. Oliver. senior judge of the United States Customs Court, died Saturday in Methodist Hospital, Brooklyn, after a lingering illness. Mi.. Oliver, who lived at Madonna Residence. 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, was 79 years old. He left no immediate family.

title: Notes on People.
ExAide to Gov. Edwards Tells of Koreans'
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)  A former aide to Gov. Edwin Edwards of Louisiana said today that he had told a Federal grand jury that the Korean businessman Tongsun Park had given thousands of dollars to Mr. Edwards, when he was a member of Congress and to Representative John B. Breaux, Democrat, of Louisiana.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO SHOW

title: Senator, in Report on Europe  Tour, Sees New Threat From Soviet Bloc
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The North Atlantic Treaty Organization must redeploy its fighting units and increase its firepower to meet a heightened threat of short war from Sovietbloc forces, according to a study made public today by Senator Sam Nunn. Democrat of Georgia.

title: Issel Gets Star Spot Over Jabbar
description: Kareem AbdulJabbar of the Los Angeles Lakers lost a popularity contest yesterday.

title: Welfare Rent Cuts Said to Hurt Needy And Not Landlords
description: The burden that would result from adopting Governor Carey's budget proposal to lower rent payments to welfare recipients would apparently be borne by the needy rather than by landlords and institutions, according to state and city social services agencies and a civic organization concerned with housing.

title: Hughes Aircraft Faces Allegation That It Used Bribery in Indonesia
description: An unpublicized dispute between two of America's largest electronics corporations over allegations of largescale bribery of Indonesian officials has again raised questions about the lack of Federal controls over such payoffs and the need for international cooperation to end them.

title: Two Democratic Leaders Say They Favor Keeping Rep. Sikes as Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Disclaiming any attempt to influence the outcome, the two top Democratic leaders of the House said today that they would vote in their party caucus Wednesday to retain Representative Robert L. F. Sikes of Florida as chairman of a key appropriations subcommittee.

title: STEEL OUTPUT OFF IN WEEK 6.3% TO 1.97 MILLION TONS
description: Steel production for the week ended Jan. 22 fell 6.3 percent to 1.97 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
People in Sports
description: Ken Stabler, the 31yearold. lefthanded quarterback who led the Oakland Raiders to their finest season, topped by a victory in the Super Bows, yesterday was named the winner of the 27th annual S. Rae Hickok Award as the professional athlete of the year.

title: RIGHTS GROUPS PLAN MOVE AGAINST SPYING
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 24A plan to establish a legal resources center to assist in the court actions many civil liberties groups are initiating against police spying was agreed upon here this weekend at a conference on government spying.

title: Advertising
description: A concerned newspaper industry, aware of growing competitive pressures and a decline in reading skills, is preparing a massive program to counter the trends.

title: Beame and Banks Meet on Budget And Find a Broad Agreement
description: Mayor Beanie and a group of leading bankers met yesterday and later declared themselves in broad agreement on steps to meet New York City's debt and budget problems  but they appeared to be no closer than ever on the key issue of outside controls of the city's finances.

title: Quebec Premier Visiting City
description: Ren Lvesque, the premier of Quebec, arrived yesterday for a twoday visit to New York City.

title: Eli Lilly Dies at 91
description: Eli Lilly, retired president and chairman of Eli Lilly & Company, the drug company founded by his grandfather, died yesterday in Indiana University Hospital in Indianapolis, his home and the headquarters of the company. He was 91 years old.

title: Rio Rancho Estates And 4 Top Officers Convicted of Fraud
Arms Talks Stalled Since March
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)Negotiations on a new treaty to limit strategic arms have been deadlocked since last March when the Soviet Union rejected a proposal to bypass two major obstacles to an accord and proceed with the signing.

title: Washington Protest Denied
description: WALNUT CREEK Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) The University of Washington's formal protest of its Jan. 13 Pacific8 Conference basketball loss to University of Oregon has been disallowed, the conference executive director, Wiles Hallock, said today.

title: POLICE CHIEFS SAY KELLEY SHOULD KEEP F.B.I. POST
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 (UPI)Clarence M. Kelley should be retained by President Carter as head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to maintain stability within the nation's law enforcement community, according to many of the nation's police chiefs.

title: At Paris Shows, the Latest Wrinkle in Haute Couture Is Pleats
description: PARIS, Jan. 24Some fairly strange things are happening here in the name of haute couture. A model In a white pants suit wearing a white leather flask on a thong around her neck paused in her whirl around the JeanLouis Scherrer salon to pretend to take a drink from the flask. And there we all were, back spiritually, at least, in the days of Prohibition.

title: Prague Urges Carter to Offer Aid in Exchange for Better Relations
description: PRAGUECzechoslovakia is letting it be known that if the Carter Administration wants to improve the icecold relations between Washington and Prague, the United States will quickly have to give this country gold, credit and advanced technology.

title: The City's Delicate Balance
6.6% Upturn in Factory Orders Prods Dow Ahead 1.17 to 963.60
description: A Government report of a sharp increase in new factory orders for durable goods in December helped the stock market post a small gain yesterday in slower trading.

title: I.Sy Seidman Dies at 85
description: I. Sy Seidman, a photographer and a collector of old photographs, memorabilia and Americana whose archives became a resource for movie makers, magazines and newspapers, died Saturday in Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 85 years old.

title: Long Betting Lines Anger Big A Fans
description: Hundreds of bettors filed angrily out of Aqueduct yesterday without waiting to get even. They were disgusted by the mob scene in the clubhouse as a result of the race track's closing of its grandstand betting windows for economic reasons.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Lane Bryant Inc., which entered the discountstore field 16 years ago by acquiring the Town and Country chain, announced yesterday that it would terminate that division within three months because of continuing losses from its operations.

title: Cotton Futures Rise $10 on Reports China Is Buying
description: Reports that China was buying cotton in both Central and North American markets caused cotton futures prices to rise to the daily limit of $10 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

title: Front Page 2
Miss Carillo Advances
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 24 (AP)Chris Penn upset fourthseeded Mary Struthers, 64, 62, today in the first round of the $20,000 Avon Futures women's tennis tournament. Mary Cerillo, a local player, beat Sue Stap, 76, 64.

title: Michigan Gets Last 12 Points to Win, 9281
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 24 (AP)Phil Hubbard and Dave Baxter helped secondranked Michigan score the last 12 points of the game tonight as the Wolverines added to their Big Ten basketball lead with a 9281 victory over Ohio State.

title: Battles in South Lebanon And Beirut Strike Reported
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 24 (UPI)Israelibacked Christian militiamen battled leftists and Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon today and other Christians went on a general strike to protest against the presence of Arab peacekeeping reinforcements in East Beirut, according to reports reaching here.

title: Article 6  No Title
New Securities Group Drawing Opposition While Still Aborning
description: The Public Securities Association, an organization linking the dealers and dealer banks that buy and sell municipal and government securities, was officially established yesterday.

title: Coaches of Garden Classic Entries Create Hoopla Over Their Teams
description: Four of the outstanding college basketball teams in the East will participate in the third annual Madison Square Garden Classic this week, and the four head coaches agreed yesterday at a news conference that picking the winner would be a very difficult assignment.

title: JEAN HAYES TAYLOR
description: Jean Hayes Taylor, organist and choir director of the Bethany Memorial Reformed Church, 400 East 67th Street, from 1941 to 1951, died Sunday in the Devon Manor Home, Devon, Pa., after lingering illness. She lived at 464 Riverside Drive, New York City, and was 80 years old.

title: Opting for the Critics
description: My friends are going to. Washington to work for Jimmy Carter's Administration, or hoping to, or thinking about it. They are in their early 30's, bright and energetic. This is their first Demo cratic Administration. They were too young to work for John F. Kennedy or Lyndon B. Johnson and would not work for Richard M. Nixon or Gerald R. Ford. But now a Democrat is entering the White House, and my friends are the right age. There is much talk of job titlesDeputy Assistant Attorney General, special assistant to the under secretaryall middlelevel positions full of qualifying adjectives.

title: Senate Backs Nomination Of Califano for H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Senate approved on a vote of 95 to 1 today the nomination of Joseph A. Califano Jr. to be Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare despite minor opposition to his views on abortion.

title: Man Held in BogusMoney Sale.
description: A 38yearold Queens man was arrested last might a Secret Service agent after he allegedly tried to sell theagent counterfeit money. The man, Louis Osario of 11512 223d Street, charged with the possession and sale of counterfeit money. A pistol, a shotgun and approximately $2,000 in counterfeit bills were confiscated from his apartment, officials reported.

title: Consumer Advocate Seen in Line To Head New Agriculture Division
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The head of a leading consumer organization is one of four new assistant secretaries of agriculture expected to be nominated soon by President Carter, according to a source close to Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Government took two emergency actions today to increase fuel supplies and, in a separate action, President Carter rescinded former President Ford's order to end gasoline price controls.

title: CHAIN STORE SALES SHOW A RISE OF 13.6%
description: Chain store sales in December rose 13.6 percent over the level of December 1975, according to Chain Store Age magazine. The gain was the fifth best of the year, exceeded only by an 18.3 percent increase in April, 17 percent in January, 14.7 percent in October and 13.7 percent in February.

description: By the Associated Press

title: Jazz Des Femmes Belies Cliches
description: Le Jazz Des Femmes, a concert featuring women in jazz that took place at Town Hall Sunday evening, offered proof that some wellknown critical cliches are in need of revision. First there is the use of the adjective masculine to describe a firm touch on the piano, a big tone on the saxophone, or an aggressive sense of swing on the drums. The first group on the program, the Jazz Sisters, demonstrated that these qualities are not male prorogatives.

title: Kilmer Case Resolved
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Jan. 24 (AP)  A drunk driving charge against Bill Kilmer, the Washington Redskins quarterback, has been resolved with Kilmer agreeing to enter a counseling program in New Orleans, according to the Fairfax County Commonwealth Attorney, Robert F. Horan.

Turner was notified of the oneyear suspension in a threepage letter from Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, who also denied the Braves their No. 1 pick in the June freeagent draft

title: Rag Doll Shenanigans
description: The old rag doll isn't what it used to be. These days, could be you, or friend, or foe. A shop called Shenanigans at 384 Bleecker Street is offering madetoorder personality dolls by Mary McVey for prices ranging from $10 for a 4inch size to $200 for a 32inchhigh version. The dolls are completed about a week after receipt of a clear photograph of the subject (and any additional information that would be of help). Miss McVey also does lifesize dolls, for lots more money, or trapuntofinished dolls for something under double the usual price. It's also possible to order a miniature versionhead onlyto use as a piece of jewelry. A pin is attached so that it can be worn as a brooch, and the addition of a ribbon makes it a necklace. That's $12. A telephone call to Margie Stern at 9249284 will get you a mailorder form, if that's handiest for you, or you can visit the shop itself between and 10 P.M.

title: About Real Estate
description: The city's annual assessment ritual is about to begin., Starting next Tuesday, the assessment books in each borough office will show the 197778 assessment for each parcel of private property. The land will be assessed at one figure, and the structure at another.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 25Leaders of the medical profession today Issued guidelines setting up a procedure whereby lifesupport systems could be withdrawn from patients, such as Karen Anne Quinlan, who are in a vegetative, comatose state and for whom there is no hope of recovery.

description: DMITRI IS different from Eric, and I am different from both of them. Dmitri acts before thinking. Eric thinks so much he seldom gets around to acting. And I am perfect. It follows that someone like Dmitri is no stranger to remorse. The world punishes his sort. of enthusiasm. The other Sunday night was a good example.

description: Dr. Emmanuel G. Mesthene resigned as dean of Livingston College, a division of Rutgers University that has special programs for underprivileged studentS. Dr. Mesthene said he would leave the post June 30 to return to, teaching and research. He was named to the dean's position in 1974.

title: News Summary
Movie House, Yes, The Movie, No:Fake Feathers
description: IT IS DARK but the moon is stage-bright. The camera moves elegantly through very expensive foliageeven oak leaves shine like gardenia plants. We could be back in "Rebecca" on the road to Manderley, but no such luck. That might be fun. We are in the drunken, anxiety-ridden fantasies of Clive Langham (John Gielgud), a second-rate, 78-year-old English novelist who is having a bad night while thinking he is dying and jotting down a few notes for his next book.We are also at the start of Alain Resnais's disastrously ill-chosen comedy, "Providence," the French director's first film in English that yesterday opened atand openedRugoff Theaters' beautiful new Cinema 3 on the lower level of the Plaza Hotel. Cinema 3, which has been done entirely in soft golds, beiges and grays, and is so comfortable one would like to nap there, Cinema 3 would be an unqualified smash without the picture."Providence" is based on an original screenplay by David Mercer, the English writer ("Morgan: A Suitable Case for Treatment") who is better known as a playwright, and, indeed, in spite of all of the film's brisk, desperate cutting around among old Clive Langham's fantasies, the film has the static manner of an easily mountable but fatally empty play script.The shock of "Providence" is how Mr. Resnais ("Hiroshima, Mon Amour," "La Guerre Est Finie," etc.) could have fallen for such windy pretensions. Is it because English is not his first language or could it be that he's echoing a statement made within the film by Clive Langham to the effect that "style is feeling"?If so, the feeling of "Providence" is the kind of cold chic that can be easily purchased by hiring the right cameraman, set designer, composer and actors who, in addition to Mr. Gielgud, include Dirk Bogarde, Ellen Burstyn, David Warner and Elaine Stritch.To say that they are miscast would be to suggest that other people might do better, which I doubt. Each performance is as bereft of real style (meaning, point) as the material.This material is what may have you swatting an innocent Cinema 3 usher as you leave. Most of the film is composed of old Clive's "notes" for his new novel, which involves his son (Mr. Bogarde) who is a priggish barrister, his long - suffering daughter - in - law (Miss Burstyn), another young man (Mr. Warner) and his son's mistress (Miss Stritch), a character created out of whole cloth by Clive in the image of his own dead wife, who committed suicide.As the old man tosses and turns in his bed, drinking white wine and complaining of pains in his rectum, we see his "characters" as he imagines them and as they sometimes refuse to do his bidding. The old man, it's soon obvious, has imposed on these perfectly decent folk all of his own fears and guilts about a lifetime spent in philandering, selfishness, disinterest in his family, while he enjoyed a reputation as a writer he never really deserved. The structure is complicated but sadly un-complex.The setting of Clive's "novel" is one of those unidentified countries that, in meaning to be anywhere, is actually nowhere. Clive wants his daughter-in-law to have an affair with Mr. Warner, but she balks. The country they inhabit seems to be in a stage of seige, which could be a cheap reference to Allende's Chile, or to the death that Clive awaits.There are so many references to other films in "Providence" ("Rebecca," werewolf movies, Terence Rattigan potboilers, Hollywood films, good and bad, for which Miklos Rozsa, the composer for "Providence," also did the score), that one suspects that Mr. Renais and Mr. Mercer might have some thoughts about the state of popular entertainment, though nothing emerges except a dreary demonstration.At one point, Clive says of his fantasies, "Oh, well, if one has led a fatuous life, one might as well have fatuous nightmares," but the movie makers can't sidestep their own responsibilities so easily. Aside from the true feeling and intelligence that Mr. Gielgud, a magician as well as a great actor, occasionally can bring to a line, Mr. Mercer's method is to have his characters toss wanly sardonic aphorisms back and forth, while Mr. Resnais's is to make everything look alternately menacing and posh. "Providence" is a lot of fuss and fake feathers about nothing.

title: People and Business
description: An administrative reorganization of Paine, Webber. Jackson & Curtis Inc., the brokerage house, an operating division of Paine Webber Inc., the holding company, was announced yesterday.

title: High Court Bars Scheduling Action In U.S. Trust Suit Against A.T. &
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI)The Supreme Court refused today to schedule a quick decision on whether the Government could go ahead with its efforts under antitrust law to dismantle the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Dollar Gains While Mark And Swiss Franc Slip
description: LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) The dollar gained value today against Europe's strongest currencies, the West German mark and the Swiss franc, and lost against the weakest, the British pound and the Italian lira.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Harold Brown, the Secretary of Defense, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that he wanted to make some changes and reductions in the defense budget for the fiical year 1978, and Senator John G. Tower said that he would fight any major changes.

title: Accused by Judge of Lying on Will, Alleged Hughes Heir Stands Firm
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 25Melvin Dummar, a 29yearold manual laborer from Ogden, Utah, refused under intense pressure today to denounce as a fraud a handwritten will that would give him onesixteenth of the estate of Howard R. Hughes.
