Wolfson was having with the agency, according to The Washington Post.

title: Cook Industries Sued For NonDisclosure
description: Cook Industries Inc. announced that a shareholder has filed suit against it in Federal Court in New York alleging that the company and its directors approved or passively acquiesced in the nondisclosure of material information last year when the company announced its intention to become a private company.

title: Korean Solicitors Curbed by Albany
Books of The Times
description: WHEN THIS REVIEWER was a boy and simpleminded, he used to wonder why they had bothered to hold the Nuremberg warcrimes trials. Germany was bad. We had beaten her in a war. What was there left to be settled, except to cut off her head? Then when this reviewer got older and cynical, he found an answer to his question that was equally simpleminded. Germany was bad, but so were the nations that had beaten her. (He now knew of Katyn, Dresden, Hiroshima, My Lai, and the Gulag Archipelago.) Therefor what was left to be settled by the Nuremberg Tribunal was the legal formalization of Germany's defeat. To the victors the right to frame international law!

title: Cattle. Growth Hormone Is Found By Panel to Pose No Cancer Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25A team of agricultural scientists, toxicologists, physicians and lawyers said today they had been unable to find any evidence of a cancer risk to humans resulting from the use of the controversial DES hormone as a growthpromoting agent in cattle.

title: Justices, 63, Restrict Miranda Rights of Suspects
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Supreme Court ruled today that a suspect who goes to a police station voluntarily and who is not under arrest can be questioned without being given the Miranda warning about the right to remain silent and to have a lawyer.

The conviction was actually on the grounds of assault and possession of a firearm, as the article later said.

description: BUFFALO, Jan. 25 (AP)  Tates Locke, in his first year as a National Basketball Association coach, was dismissed today by the Buffalo Braves soon after returning home following four straight road losses.

title: Fordham Coach Sees Rebound in Future
description: It will take five or six years of hard work to get Fordham basketball back into top form, according to the Rains coach, Dick Stewart, who is struggling through a dismal first season on Rose Hill. But there is just enough life remaining in the Fordham program to make the young coach sound enthusiastic about that distant future. Reports that Stewart will throw in the towel at the end of his first headcoaching campaign are put down by the former Rutgers player. Stewart said, That's an unfounded rumor for one simple reason. It isn't true.

title: TV: At 90, Rubinstein Plays On
description: N FRIDAY, Arthur Rubinstein will observe his 90th birthday. Tonight at 9 on WNET/13 the occasion will be anticipated with a 90minute Great Performances presentation called Rubinstein at 90, in which the pianist performs and is interviewed by Robert MacNeil. For those demanding better sound reception than can be found in the speaker system of the average television set, the program is being simulcast on radio station WNCNFM.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)President Carter today reserved a ambassadorial position, at $46,800 a year, for Elliot L. Richardson, Ambassador to Britain under President Ford and then Secretary of Commerce.

title: All About: Choosing Ice Skates
description: WHEN it comes to buying ice skates, the time to have a fit is before money changes hands, not after. Whether the skates are for hockey, racing or cutting figures, whether the skater is an adult or a child, fit is cited by experts as the single most important factor in fostering enjoyment, ease of learning and avoidance of injury.

title: Union Carbide's Profit Up by 29.6%
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's second largest chemical producer, reported yeterday, a 29.6 percent rise in fourthquarter net income.

title: Worse Than the Draft?
description: Richard Nixon's promises to end the draft helped him win two Presidential elections. It was only natural, therefore, that his Administration and President Ford's, after the December 1972 induction of the last draftee, would express assurance that the Volunteer Army was working well. And they did, repeatedly. Doubts expressed by former Defense Secretary James Schlesinger in his first annual posture statement were quickly explained away. All of which stirs our interest in the Pentagon's acknowledgement, in transition papers for the new Administration, of serious trouble in recruiting volunteers, trouble which raises a hard question for Washington and for the country: Can we afford a mass army without some form of conscription?

title: L.I. Parks Aide Indicted
description: Thomas Candreva, a parks supervisor for the Town of Hempstead, has been indicted on charges of using town employees to do his personal chores. District Attorney Denis E. Dillon of Nassau County said Mr. Candreva had been charged with petty larceny, falsification of business records, theft, of services and official misconduct.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It is a commonplace that the Democrats tend to stay on in Georgetown in between Administrations, while the Republicans usually pack up and go home. Henry A. Kissinger is a Republican, although in curious way he is never quite thought of as one and his social and political style has been peculiar unto itself. Unlike the other Republicans, he is staying on in Washington, at least until this summer, but what he will do after that is a secret. Mr. Kissinger will not talk about it, even though his friends do, and they wonder aloud how he will ever decompress. Considering the possibilities, it is hard, to imagine Mr. Kissinger ever settling down and decompressing anywhere but here.

title: Personal Health
description: LIGHT, no sugar ... Regular . . . Black. . . . Few who have grown up in the Eastern part of this country need to be told that these orders refer to the allAmerican drinkcoffee. The average adult American consumes 18 pounds, or approximately 800 cups, each year of this brown, nonnutritive liquid extracted from the beans of Coffee arabica and related species.

title: Best Buys

In a week when the ravages of weather on crops and of time on stockpiles make truly mouthwatering bargains few and far between, frozen beef liver and red radishes make the odd couple for those who cannot bring themselves to say farewell to a good buy.

title: Eavesdropping on Calls Ruled Out by Vance
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, in one of his first official actions, has prohibited any telephone conversations from being monitored or recorded in the State Department or in missions overseas without the express consent of all parties involved in the call.

title: The Rhodesian Stalemate: Parties Look to New Rale for U.S.
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 25The apparent collapse of Britain's attempt to resolve the Rhodesian dispute has left many of those involved hoping for intervention by the United States, but it is far from clear how Washington can unravel a tanglethat has foiled seven efforts since 1965. Rhodesia and South Africa want the Carter Administration to take up where Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger left off in the fall. The black African states, though wary of American intentions, are also likely to welcome a United States role.

description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Jan. 25 (UPI)Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike indicated today that she might follow the example of India's Prime Minister, Indira Gltndhi, in using emergency powers when necessary to protect the people.

title: BType Flu Is Reported In 10 States and in Capital
description: Although officials in 10 states and the District of Columbia are reporting confirmed cases of Influenza B, the National Center for Disease Control says there is no significant flu outbreak in the nation.

title: Cardinal Cooke Feted At Lotos Club Dinner
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke was the guest of honor last night at a Lotos Club state dinner that drew such notables as Mayor Beame and Robert Moses to the elegant club at 5 East 66th Street.

title: Vintage Duets Lively as Ever
description: ScottMartin Kosofsky, who plays recorders, and Tom Pixton, harpsichordist, first played together in 1968, when they were both 14 years old. The following year they made a wellreceived appearance in Carnegie Recital Hall, and Monday night, after study in Europe, they came down again from their Boston base for another recital.

title: CBS Out Of Talks OnGames
description: CBS announced yesterday its unequivocal withdrawal from the negotiations with the Soviet Union for the 1980 summer Olympic Games from Moscow. The action was surprising in light of the fact that for much of, the last year CBS was intensively bidding for the rights and had made friendly overtures to Soviet officials in the form of special programs in this country featuring the Bolshoi Ballet and Nadia Comaneci, the young Rumanian gymnastic star.

title: Weekly Award to Copeland
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Jan. 25 (UPI)Hollis Copeland, the Rutgers forward, has been, named player of the week in the Eastern Collegiate Basketball League because of his performances in victories over George Washington and Lafayette.

title: Borowiak Topples Okker, Alexander Escapes Loss
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 (AP)Tom Dicker was upset by Jeff Borowiak,63, 36, 63 at the $200,000 United States Pro. Indoor tennis championships in the Spectrum today. It was a grueling victory for the unseeded Californian.

title: Widow, 84, Is Slain in Coop City
description: An 84yearold widow was fatally stabbed during a robbery yesterday in her apartment in Coop City in the northeast Bronx, and last night a 16 yearold Brooklyn youth was charged with her murder.

title: THOUSANDS IN SPAIN STRIKE TO PROTEST POLITICAL VIOLENCE
description: MADRID, Jan. 25Tens of thousands of workers struck today in Madrid and Barcelona to protest a wave of violence that has taken seven lives in the Spanish capital in the last 48 hours and spread a mood of deep fear. An alliance of leftist labor unions called for nationwide work stoppages tomorrow.

title: Article 1
Two Killed as Houses Blow Up
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Jan. 25 (AP)Two persons were killed and 20 others injured today when separate explosions blew up two houses and damaged dwellings in a threeblock area of Old Lycoming Township about one mile north of here. Firemen suspected that leaking gas was the cause. Those killed were Anthony J. Kohler and John Raymond Lundy.

title: Many Poles Say the Unrest Is Far Deeper Than Economics
Hospital Appoints President
description: Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn announced yesterday that Harold L. Light had been appointed president and chief executive officer of the voluntary, 567bed institution. Mr. Light succeeds William K. Klein, who will continue to serve as a consultant.

title: News Summary
description: Spanish workers struck by the tens of thousands in protest against a wave of violence that has taken six lives in Madrid in the last 48 hours. There is a growing conviction that a violent rightwing campaign is seeking to undermine Spain's progress toward representative institutions. The police reportedly arrested 24 rightists in connection with the killing of four Communists in a labor office Monday night. [Page A1, Column 4.]

title: Bridge Free at Night
description: Beginning Feb. 1, there will be no charge at night to motorists using the financially troubled $116 million Betsy Ross Bridge connecting Pennsauken and North Philadelphia. A spokesman for the Delaware River Port Authority, which operates the Betsy Ross along with the Benjamin Franklin and Walt Whitman Bridges, said the toll collectors would be taken from the bridge from 10 P.M. to 6 A.M. every night, a move that would result in a loss of $50,000 computed over a oneyear period.

title: First Night'
description: Like the soaring temperature of a surprise thaw, the curtain rose on the New York City Ballet last night, ending a sixweek deep freeze brought on by a strike.

title: St. John's Is Defeated By Villanova, 65 to 63
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Jan. 25 (UPIKeith Herron scored a gamehigh 20 points tonight to lead Villanova's basketball team to a 6563 triumph over St. John's.

title: CarterArtis Sentencing
description: Sentencing for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, the former boxer, and John Artis has been postponed to Feb. 9 at the request of the defense attorneys. Mr. Carter, 39 years old, and Mr. Artis, 30, were scheduled to be sentenced today for murdering three persons in a bar in Paterson, N.J., on June 17, 1966. They were convicted in a retrial that ended Dec. 2]. Judge Bruno L. Leopizzi of Superior Court also will rule Feb. 9 on a motion for a new trial. The defense attorneys, Myron Beldock and Lewis Steel, had sought the postponement to allow them more time to prepare the motion that testimony and evidence presented in the retrial did not warrant a guilty verdict..

title: OPEC SAYS IT MAY CONVENE MEETING ON OIL PRICE WAR
description: VIENNA, Jan. 25Officials at the secretariat of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that there was speculation about a forthcoming special meeting of its ministers conference, but that no decision had yet been reached.

title: Innovative Florida College .Saved From Bankruptcy by ExTrustees
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 25Former trustees of New College here raised $866,870 last month to assure that the formerly private institution will continue to operate as a college within the state university until well into 1978.

title: Amy Makes School on Time
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)Amy Carter, late for school on her first day, made it on time today. The President's 9yeurold daughter, accompanied by her Secret Service guard, slipped in a side door at Washington's Thaddeus Stevens elementary school just as the bell sounded for classes.

title: Assassination Action Delayed by House Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The House Rules Committee postponed today until next Tuesday a decision on a resolution to reestablish a special committee to investigate the assassinations of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: UsedCar Dealers Are Sending In Payments on Fines for False Ads
description: NEWARK, Jan. 25Thomas Roselli, a supervisor in the automobile section of the State Consumer Affairs Division, opened a letter in his office here today, and out droped a check for $100.

title: Merrill Lynch 76 Net Up
description: Earnings of Merrill Lynch & Company rose 16 percent in the fourth quarter of 1976 and a record 11.4 percent for the full year, the securities concern announced yesterday. For 1976, moreover, the company's revenues exceeded $1 billion for the first time.

title: Lawyers Try Out a Trial by TV
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 25The scene S an appellate courtroom, but besides the blackrobed jurists and battery of learned counsel there were cameras and lights and the kind of barrcom television set that projects lifesize color images onto a huge glittering screen.

title: Lens Enterprise Set
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said it would form an ophthalmic pharmaceutical operation for the development, manufacture and marketing of solutions and other accessory products for use with its Soflens contact lens and lenses from new materials as they become available. The company said the first new pharmaceutical product would be a sterile preserved saline solution. It is expected to reach the market by midyear.

title: Trial of Justice Tyler on Perjury Charges Is Delayed
description: The start of a trial of a New York State Supreme Court justice on perjury charges was delayed, possibly for several weeks, yesterdayone day after another indictment against the justice was dismissed.

title: New Chairman of Hospital Agency Calls for Abolition of Corporation
description: The new chairman of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that the quasiindependent agency should be abolished and replaced by the kind of city department it succeeded in 1970, a move that would restore the Mayor's direct authority over the municipal hospitals.

title: Yonkers Racing
2 Held by Police In Bronx Assault On Elderly Couple
description: Two men who the police say tied up an elderly couple in their Bronx apartment Monday and threatened to kill them with a hammer if they did not turn over their valuables, were arrested last night by members of the Bronx Senior Citizens Robbery Unit.

title: Raccoon Chutists May Face Charges
description: BARNEGAT, Jan. 25 (AP)The State Humane Society is considering lodging criminal complaints against Ocean County workers who allegedly dropped a live raccoon in a makeshift parachute out of a countyowned helicopter.

title: College Basketball
description: AT GARDEN, 7 P.M.

title: Byrne Tells Oil Group That Jersey Is Eager to Develop Offshore Fields
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 25Governor Byrne of New Jersey bought lunch for two dozen Houston oil executives today and told them that his state was eager to cooperate with them In developing Atlantic offshore oil and natural gas fields.

title: Living Abroad: Israel
description: IF YAEL MATALON had her way, no wellheeled Israeli woman would slip into a fashionable dress shop on Dizengoff Streetwhich is to Tel Aviv what Fifth Avenue is to New Yorkand buy an expensive imported dress. Instead, this fashionconscious purchaser would assuage all of her ambitions to be with it by wearing an Israelimade dress, bathing suit, raincoat or any of a number of the new fashions being turned out by Israeli designers.

title: 3 Arab Countries Modify Demand On Role of P.L.O. at Geneva Talks
description: CAIRO, Jan. 25In an apparent shift of position, Egypt, Syria and Jordan are understood to be willing to start negotiations on a Middle East settlement without the presence of a Palestinian delegation in the early stages.

title: CrossCountry Ski Star Sheds Light on Absence From Championships
Sakharov Gets an Official Warning About Statement on Moscow Subway Explosion
Snowfall Is Good Excuse for Fun
description: Monday night's snowfall proved a nuisance for some but a source of pleasure for others. Jessica Schwarting, 2 years old, enjoyed the snow outside City Hall.

title: New Chapter for Lesley Gore
description: It was Lesley Gore's party, and she could cry if she wanted to. That was during the early 1960's, and Miss. Gore, with her bouffant hairdo and her baby fat, was the universal teenager. Her records were chapters in a continuing saga. She lost her boyfriend to Judy in It's My Party, got him back in Judy's Turn To Cry, and finally declared her independence in what sounds today like a precursor of women's lib, You Don't Own Me.

title: CAREY PLAN TO ALTER SCHOLARSHIP SCORED
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25A proposal by Governor Carey to change procedures for awarding state Regents scholarships, which each year go to nearly 20,000 graduating high school seniors, drew sharp criticism today from New York State education authorities.

title: Bond Prices Off as Traders Await U.S. Financing. Plan
description: The credit markets continued in their slump yesterday as they waited for the Treasury's announcement today of its February financing plans. Trading activity was light, but fixedincome prices slipped again and new issues of corporate and taxexempt bonds sold slowly. There was no new news development to account for this move toward lower prices and higher interest rates. Rather the move seemed to reflect concern that the Carter Administration's program of fiscal stimulus might be more than the economy needs and might revive inflation and provoke the Federal Reserve to tighten credit.

title: Paths to Survival on the Party Circuit
description: The man whose life work it is to go go to partiesSinan A. Korle, chief of protocol at the United Nationssurvives them by never drinking anything alcoholic until the last stop every evening. The only alternative, the Turkish diplomat say; is cirrhosis of the liver.

title: Another Processor, Another Price
description: Another new lowcost food processor is now on the market. The manufacturer's suggested retail price is $99.99, and the advertisements state that the new machine grates, grinds, shreds, chops, slices, blends [and] minces. The advertisements add that It's the U.S.A.'s answer to the $225 foreign importonly better.

title: CON ED LIFTS PAYOUT 25% TO A RECORD $2, IF RATE IS CONTINUED
description: The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday increased its quarterly dividend by 25 percent, to 50 cents a share. if continued at that rate the annual dividend would be a record $2 per share.

title: Closed End Funds
Books of The Times
description: I BELIEVE IN GOD, Jesus, Life Eternal, people, luck, my voices, myself. Pan me, don't give me part, publish everybody's book but this one, and I will still make it! Why? Because I believe I will. If you believe, then you hang on.

title: N.H.L. Offers Assistance To Barons
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 25In a reversal of previous sentiment, the National Hockey League this afternoon offered assistance in the amount of $250,000 to the financially troubled Cleveland Barons franchise, according to a source who attended the meeting between the Board of Governors and Mel. Swig, the Barons owner. The aid would be in the form of suspended assessments rather than in money.

title: Profits in Picture at Freedom National
description: The Freedom National Bank, New York's only blackcontrolled commercial bank, which two years ago as a result of $1.7 million in losses came dangerously close collapse, has significantly reduced. those losses, and, for the first time in four years, realized a modest monthly profit, according to its management.

title: VLADIMIR V. SINITSYN
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (UPI)Vladimir V. Sinitsyn, a journalist and Communist Party official in Tadzhikistan, has died, according to a report reaching here yesterday.

title: Albany Rent Bills Seek to Continue Stabilization on 450,000 City Units
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25The State Legislature reopened Its perennial battle over rent regulations today when Democratic members of the Senate and Assembly introduced bills that would continue the stabilization program for 450,000 apartments in New York City and nearly 145,000 in the suburbs and elsewhere in the state.

title: Money
description: Tuesday, January 25, 1977

title: A.H. Raskin
description: Inflation has sharpened the line between haves and havenots in the American labor force.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: A SERIES of inquiries from readers about a dish of Italian origin, hitherto unknown to me, was the inspiration for today's column. The name of the dish is chicken scarkariello, which I learned from Italian friends means chicken shoemakerstyle. It is an interesting name because the lowest compliment you can pay a French chef is to say, He cooks like a shoemaker.

title: No Ruling on Ohio Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)The Supreme Court declined today to decide what statute of limitations should apply to private suits brought under the antifraud nrovisions of Federal securities law.

title: EARNINGS FOR EXXON ROSE 6.9% IN QUARTER
description: The Exxon Corporation, the nation's largest industrial corporation, yesterday reported a modest increase of 6.9 percent in fourthquarter earnings, which brought the rise in profits for the year to 5.5 percent.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Jan. 19 Stated incorrectly that Stavros Sykopetrides had been convicted of attempting to kill Bulent Ecevit, a former Turkish Prime Minister. The conviction was actually on the grounds of assault and possession of a firearm, as the article later said.

title: Gas Cited in Pittsburgh Blast
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 (UPI)Gas was the likely cause of an explosion that wrecked a University of Pittsburgh science lecture hall and killed two women, officials said yesterday

title: Young Says U.S. Still Hopes for Accord on Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Representative Andrew Young, President Carter's choice as chief delegate to the United Nations, said today that the United States still hoped for a negotiated solution in Rhodesia despite rejection of the latest British proposals by Rhodesia's white minority Government.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Finley Is Convinced Only One Baseball Team Can Survive in the Bay Area
Governor Edwards Denies He Accepted $20,000
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 25 (UPI)Gov. Edwin Edwards made a pointbypoint denial today of a report by a former aide that he had accepted $20,000 in cash for his 1972 gubernational campaign from the South Korean businessman Park Tong Sun.

title: Airline Flying High
description: Airlines haven't been shy about using superlative advertising claims, but can you remember any that has gone this far: The most luxurious airline the world has ever known?

title: JERSEY ADOPTS PLAN ON PATIENTS IN COMA
description: TRENTON, Jan. 25Leaders of the medical profession today issued guidelines setting up a procedure whereby lifesupport systems could be withdrawn from patients, such as Karen Anne Quinlan, who are in a vegetative, comatose state and for whom there is nohope of recovery.

title: Millionaires and Celebrities Will Be Neighbors of Fords
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Jan. 25Helen DeWare looked worried.

title: Personal Finance: Tax Time
description: THE Internal Revenue Service, for all its bureaucratic deadlines of purpose, is not without a mordant sense of humor. The address of the big Holtsville, N.Y., center that processes all returns from New Jersey and most of the New York metropolitan area is 1040 Waverley Avenuea play on the tax form which this year is more complicated than ever.

title: Brooklyn College Officials Deny Budgetary Influence on Grading
description: The president of Brooklyn College, Dr. John W. Kneller, vehemently denied yesterday that budgetary considerations had influenced the grading of a controversial English writing examination given to 1,600 sophomores in the last several weeks.

title: PARKING RULES
description: All normal parking and standing regulations will be in effect throughout New York City today.

title: Youth Finds Some Frustrations At Community Board Meeting
description: A bit of clockwatching, a little notetaking, one raising of his hand, a lot of serious attentiveness with his chin poised on his thumb, and one trip to the candy machine occupied 16yearold Scott Stringer last night as he attended his first meeting as a member of Community Planning Board No. 12 in Washington Heights. More than 40 members were present.

title: Paris: It's Haute Kitsch
Increased Demand For Executives Seen
description: Go West, young man, go west. That was good advice a century ago, but today's good advice centers on finding specific industries where job opportunities are flourishing.

title: Beame Bows to Demand by Banks For New Monitor of City Finances
description: The Beame administration, bowing to a major demand of the city's banks, has agreed that a new outside monitoring agent for the city's financesto remain in existence after the expiration of the state's Emergency Financial Control Boardwill be necessary if the city is to raise money in the municipalbond market.

title: 15th Regiment Armory Is Far Cry From Old Days of Indoor Tennis
description: When indoor tennis was played in armories many years ago, the lighting was terrible, the wood Surface so slick that the ball came at you like a blur and the locker rooms carried a threat of pneumonia.

title: People in Sports
description: Christy Elliott, the middleweight champion of Ireland. dropped by Madison Square Garden yesterday and met his boyhood hero; Emile Griffith, whom Elliott will fight next Wednesday in the featured 10rounder of a tripleheader.. Griffith will be 39 years old Feb. 3.

title: The Highest Award
description: If not unprecedented it is rare for the operating head of an association to get the organization's highest award. This happened yesterday, however, to Stephen E. Kelly, president of the Magazine Publishers Association, and the eventa lunch at the Plaza Hotel brought out a record number of big names from publishing, the agencies and advertiser companies. Over 600 of them jammed the grand ballroom, just about double the number who attended the 12 previous presentations of the Henry Johnson Fisher Award.

title: THOUSANDS IN SPAIN STRIKE TO PROTEST POLITICAL VIOLENCE
description: MADRID, Jan. 25Tens of thousands of workers struck today in Madrid and Barcelona to protest a wave of violence that has taken seven lives in the Spanish capital in the last 48 hours and spread a mood of deep fear. An alliance of leftist labor unions called for nationwide work stoppages tomorrow.

title: Nixon Asks Supreme Court For Control of Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)Lawyers for former President Richard M. Nixoh asked the Supreme Court today to strike down a threeyearold law that gives the Government control over his Presidential papers and tape recordings.

title: Article 2
Senate RollCall Vote Approving Bell, 7521
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 25 (UPI)Following is th 75to21 rollcall vote by which the Senate confirmed today the nomination of Griffin B. Bell as Attorny General.

title: Budget Bomb
BANKS REPORT RECOVERY IN 4THQUARTER PROFITS
description: Fourthquarter profits at the nation's banks are rebounding from depressed levels a year ago.

title: Market Place
description: Investors generally were stunned on April 23, 1974, when Consolidated Edison's board of trustees announced that the company was omitting its quarterly dividend of 45 cents a share, citing the Arab oil embargo, soaring interest costs and inadequate rate relief.

title: Chess:
description: . It was Wilhelm Steinitz, world champion from 1866 to 1894, who first inveighed against attacking for the sheer sport of it, a practice that was still popular in his day and one that he had given up begrudgingly in the face of logic quite late in his development, long after he had become a master.

title: Levesque, in City, Asks Business To Support Separation of Quebec
How About an Appraisal?
description: It's always possible that the desk you inherited from your grandmother is worth a fortune, but even if you know that it's haute junque, it's not a bad Idea to have household effects appraised. For one thing, it's handy if you ever have dealings with an insurance company or, even though we'd prefer not to remember it, the Internal Revenue Service. J. Lee Drexler, who heads Esquire Appraisals and is a senior member of the American Society of Appraisers, not only appraises but also has all kinds of Ideas on buying, selling and insurance procedure. Her charge is $60 an hour, with a minimum of $100 and she says most jobs average three hours or $175. Esquire Appraisals is at 241 East 75th Street ,telephone 5350671 and 210 Guion Drive, Mamaroneck, telephone 9146986665.

title: SADIE PULLMAN
description: Sadie Pullman, president of Hadassah in Brooklyn from 1958 to 1960, and of the Queens chapter from 1971 to 1973, died yesterday in Peninsula General Hospital, Rockaway, Queens, after a lingering illness. She lived at 1015 Dickens Avenue, Far Rockaway, and was 62 years old.

title: Three Killed as Cars Collide in the Bronx
description: Three persons were killed and two others injured, one critically, in an automobile accident shortly after midnight this morning on a bridge in the Pelham Bay Park area of the Bronx, the police reported.

title: Details Given on Vance Mideast Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The White House announced today that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance would make a weeklong visit to six Middle East countries starting Feb. 14 to lay the groundwork for efforts by the Carter Administration to promote further ArabIsraeli accords.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: U.S. STEEL EARNINGS DROP AS SALES RISE
description: The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its fourthquarter earnings declined 27.9 percent despite a 4.2 percent increase in sales. The nation's largest steelmaker also showed a drop of 26.7 percent in net income for all 1976 although sales rose 5.3 percent.

title: Nuclear Agency Approves, Power Plant Continuation
description: CONCORD, N.H. Jan. 25 (AP)The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission has allowed construction to continue temporarily at the site of the proposed $2 billion Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: Music: Of France and America
description: Hear America First investigated American composers who have lived in France and French composers who have lived in America in the concert given at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church on Monday night.

title: N.H.L. AllStar
description: FIRSTPERIODI, Campbell, Vail (D. Pot. yin), 2:54. 2, Wales, McDonald (Gainey, McNab), 6:22 PenaltiesCampbell bench, served by Gilbert, (15:32); Lapointe, (16:24); Dornhoofer, (16:24).

title: Jazz: Danny Stiles Band.
description: When Bill Watrous, the virtuosic jazz trombonist, moved to California last fall and gave up his big band, Manhattan Wildlife Refuge, Mr. Watrous's partner and lead trumpet, Danny Stiles, organized a band of his own, which has been playing on Wednesdays for the last three months at the Office in Nyack.

title: Child's World
description: The metric system comes marching on like an invading army that many of us are determined to Ignore to the last. But in classrooms the system already has its captive audiences. There, teachers are attempting to make metrics at least as enjoyable and comprehensible as, say, math.

title: TELEVISION TODAY
description: Morning

title: SUPREME COURT VOIDS A PLAN TO BUS BLACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Supreme Court today vacated on a 6to3 vote a lower court ruling upholding a broad desegregation plan for public schools in the Indianapolis area under which numerous black children from the city were to be bused to schools in predominantly white suburban districts.

title: Syrians Close to Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 25Syrian troops in Lebanon were today reported to be closer to the Israeli border than at any time since they intervened in the civil. war.

title: Pacifists Unite
description: Vincent and Fred Nardi, who are hairdressers, claim that they observed a new fad on their recent visit to Italy. Some members of the chic set, they say, are now using pacifierspacifiers, that's rightas a substitute for smoking, eating and nail chewing. The Nardis, who have salons at 29 West 57th Street, 318 East Kingsbridge Road. Bronx, and 455 Central Avenue, Scarsdale Plaza, now provide pacifiers in all of them for clients who may have traumas about changing hair styles. Some people will prefer smoking, eating, chewing nails and the old hair style.

title: Liv Ullmann: Actress, Mother and Now Author
description: You might think it an unfairness, Liv Ullmann said, coloring slightly. You know there are real writers who have great trouble getting their hooks published. I know I'm privileged. Because if somebody not of my profession got a part, maybe a part I'd like, I would not he so happy.

title: Wine Talk
description: The trend to lighter drinks and the phenomenal success of white wine have been well documented by now. A glass of white wine is as common a phrase around bars now as scotch on the rocks.

title: Nursery Desserts: Ambrosial Fare of Childhoods Past
Uncommon Touches For Everyday Floors
Letters
description: On Enjoying the Grippe

title: Saving Heat Could Mean The Cooler
description: Before landlords who are moved by patriotism or less exalted motives ritsh to drop their tenants heat from 68 degrees in line with President Carter's request that thermostats be set at 65, they should know that they are risking a fine and imprisonment.

title: MIG NOW SAID TO HAVE ADVANCED EQUIPMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 25United States Air Force specialists, after further analysis of the Soviet MIG25 that became available for Western inspection in Japan last autumn after its pilot defected, have revised some of their earlier critical appraisals and have concluded that it contains some components of highly advanced technology.

title: Carter Set to Name Black To Head. Manpower Post In Department of Labor
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Ernest G. Green, one of nine black children who integrated Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., under the protection of Federal troops in the 1950's, will be named Assistant Secretary of Labor for Manpower.

title: Raincheck on a Rose
description: Almost everyone, at one time or another, has received flowers just as they're about to go out of town for a few days, or when they already have a lot of posies around. Take heart. Apparently an increasing number of flower senders are asking their florists to telephone the recipient firstto find out whether they'd like the flowers that day, the next day or even a week or month in the future. Jim Goslee of The Fernery says it's happening a lot and loves the raincheck gift idea. James Preuss at East River Florists and Michael George at Fellan Florists are also finding such requests not uncommon and wish it would happen even more. A few florists believe it detracts from the surprise and thrill of receiving flowers. You may too, but it probably depends on whether you have a practical or romantic temperament.

title: Patterns of the Winter Season
description: It may be a bane and a bother to motorists and pedestrians, but cold weather shapes water into beautiful forms of ice and snow. The round object is a stubborn quince. Photos were taken in Bergen County.

title: ABC's Roots Garners A Top Nielsen Rating
description: The first episode of Roots, ABC's weeklong serialization of the Alex Haley book on the genealogy of a black family, drew one of the highest ratings of the television season in the Nielsen overnight reports for New York, Los Angeles and Chicago.

title: SUPREME COURT VOIDS A PLAN TO BUS BLACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Supreme Court today vacated on a 6to3 vote lower court ruling upholding a broad desegregation plan for public schools in the Indianapolis area under which numerous black children from the city were to be bused to schools in predominantly white suburban districts.

title: Tips on Finishes And Coatings
description: Evan Janovic, the president of Janovic Plaza (1292 First Avenue and 159 West 72d Street), suggests that polyurethane be used on colored fabrics or papers, and Flecto 2000 white surfaces, as polyurethane has a slightly amber cast and can give white a yellowish tone.

title: Radio for Computers
description: Radio certainly isn't your favorite daily medium for selling computers, but Sperry Univac is going to give it a try in behalf of its new BC/7 system for small businesses.

title: School Results
description: BOYS BASKETBALL

title: Education Aid Campaign
description: Doremus & Company, working as the volunteer ad agency, has prepared a multimedia Advertising Council campaign for Financial Aid to Education.

title: Proxmire Investigates Bribery in Indonesia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, called today for a complete report from the ExportImport Bank on its handling of bribery allegations in connection with the financing of a $160 million satellite communications system for Indonesia.

title: College Basketball
description: COACHES' POLL

title: Forms to Be Offered In MoneyOrder Case
description: Elinor Guggenheimer, the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, said last night that her agency was preparing a short, easily understood form on winch people who bought U.S.N. Company money orders could file claims with the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York. She said an announcement on where and how the forms would be distributed would be made in a few days.

title: Le Plat Du Jour Is Power
description: AS a book publisher, I am in that growing company of people (growing not only in number but very often in weight as well) for whom the expense account lunch is an essential tool of the trade, like a carpenter's adze. Not for us a quick baconcheeseburger at the counter, or a pleasant lunch in one of those mythical little French restaurants where everything is perfect and the bill is never more than $20 for two. Powerlunchers would rather eat yogurt at their desks than be seen eating an unpowerful meal in a restaurant full of nobodies. Businessmen who once felt they lived, like Roman warriors, by the sword, now live by the forkand live so well that not a few of them probably die by the fork as well.

title: Letters
description: Transit Cutbacks: The Federal Burden

title: MIDJANUARY SALES OF AUTOS UP BY 15.3% WITH 220,922 UNITS
description: DETROIT, Jan. 25American new car sales climbed 15.3 percent in midJanuary. Analysts called it a strong performance and in line with expectations.

title: Notes on People
description: THE American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters announced last night the election of nine new members, chosen for their creative contributions in art, literature and music. This is the first time that three women have been elected in the same year; they are the novelists and short story writers, Hortense Calisher and Elizabeth Hardwick, and Ada Louise Huxtable, architecture critic and member of The New York Times editorial board. Other new members, to be inducted May 18, are Lennart Anderson and Kenneth Noland, painters; Charles Eames and Roma do Giurgola, architects; Joseph Heller, novelist and playwright; and Alan Hovhaness, the composer. Although Mr. Eames is an architect, he was elected to the AcademyInstitute for his contributions in the field of design.

title: CarterArtis Sentencing
description: Sentencing for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, the former boxer, and John Artis has been postponed to Feb. 9 at the request of defense attorneys. Mr. Carter, 39 years old, and Mr. Artis, 30, were scheduled to be sentenced today for murdering three persons in a bar in Paterson on June 17, 1966. They were convicted in a retrial that ended Dec. 21. Judge Bruno L. Leopizzi of Superior Court also will rule Feb. 9 on a motion for a new trial. The defense attorneys, Myron Beldock and Lewis Steel, had sought the postponement to allow them more time to prepare the motion that testimony and evidence presented in the retrial did not warrant a guilty verdict.

title: Soybean Supplies Decline On Mildly Bullish Report
description: Grain and soybean traders devoted most of yesterday covering positions as they awaited the Government report on stocks of these key foodstuffs after the close of trading.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: TREASURE HUNTING How to Identify & Collect American First Editions (Arco Publishing), a new book by Jack Tannen, is also the subject of his free lecture, tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. at the New York Public Library's Donnell Center, 20 West 53d Street. Budding and professional bibliophilesand New York abounds with bothwill hear an expert discussing his 48 years of experience in tracking down printed rarities.

title: Corigliano's Concerto Tests Pianist's Skills
description: WHEN LISTENERS of an elder generation get together, someone eventually gets around to asking, in querulous tone, why they don't write music the way they used to. Well, in fact, they do.

title: The Rhodesian Stalemate: Parties Look to New Role for U.S.
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 25The apparent collapse of Britain's attempt to resolve the Rhodesian dispute has left many of those involved hoping for intervention by the United States, but it is far from clear how Washington can unravel a tangle that has foiled seven efforts since 1965. Rhodesia and South Africa want the Carter Administration to take up where Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger left off in the fall. The black African states, though wary of American intentions, are also likely to welcome a United States role.

title: More Subway Confusion
description: Crowded, shorter subway trains that stopped in the middle of the station in offpeak hours continued to confound riders as the Transit Authority went through a second day of curtailed service to help close a $30 million budget gap, The authority reported that crowding and some confusion caused fiveminute delays, mainly on the IND division's E and F trains to and from Queens.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
3 Die as Plane Crashes Into Store
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP)A twinengine plane crashed today into golf cart showroom and exploded into flames, killing two persons in the plane and an employee in the store. The victims were Buck Shaw, a builder from Indianapolis; his flight instructor, Don Verboncoeur, 40 years old, of Fort Myers, and a bookkeeper at B&W Golf Carts, whose name was not immediately released.

title: Avondale Navy Contract
description: Avondale Shipyards Inc., a unit of the Ogden Corporation, has received a $63 million Navy contract to build a fleet tanker.

title: Rabbis Told How to Fight Missionary
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., Jan. 25More than 100 Orthodox rabbis went to school today to learn some distinctly unorthodox ways to combat the Jews for Jesus movement and other groups seeking to brainwash and evangelize young Jews.

title: Tanker Carrying 6 Million Gallons Of Gasoline Aground at Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 25 (AP)A tanker filled with almost six million gallons of gasoline ran aground today in an approach channel to Baltimore's iceclogged harbor.

title: Quebec's Challenge to the U.S.
description: The Premier of the Canadian Province of Quebec, Rene Levesque, was in New York yesterday explaining to the Economic Club why he thinks Quebec should be an independent nation and a good investment for U.S. money. He suggests some scary problems.

title: GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST GO PAST $1 MILLION
description: A bequest of $52,012.13 from the Madge D. Miller trusts has enabled The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to go over the $1 million mark for the seventh consecutive year.

title: AllisChalmers Buys Holding Fiat Shares
description: The AllisChalmers Corporation announced in Milwaukee that it has purchased from Internazionale Holding Fiat S.A. 1,102,700 shares of its stock in exchange for a portion of AllisChalmers interests in a FiatAllis construction machinery joint venture near Lecce, Italy, far about $27.2 million.

title: Lawyers Try Out a Trial by TV
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 25The scene was an appellate courtroom, but besides the blackrobed jurists and battery of learned counsel there were cameras and lights and the kind of barroom television set that projects lifesize color images onto a huge glittering screen.

title: Japanese Makes Major Advance In Combatting Sleeping Sickness
description: GENEVA Jan. 22A Japanese researcher working in a laboratory in Africa has taken what World Health Organization officials say is a major step forward in the battle against sleeping sickness, one of man's oldest and still most devastating disease.

title: The New Yorker Thaws Out
description: Many advertisers consistently use the same media from year to year. Not so The New Yorker magazine, which believes the element of surprise (Dear me, what is The New Yorker doing here?) gives additional impact to its relatively small budget.

title: MAN FOUND IN CAR TRUNK SAYS HE WAS KIDNAPPED
description: Raymond Marquez, a numbers racketeer who was released two years ago from a Federal penitentiary where he had served five years on gambling charges, was kidnapped yesterday morning and freed after the payment of an $8,100 ransom, according to what he told the police.

title: CARTER WIDENS PLAN TO AID THE ECONOMY TO $31 BILLION TOTAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  President Carter has decided to give the economy a $31.3 billion stimulus over the next 20 months by aiding both big business and individuals.

title: Emergency Bill On Gas Offered By White House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Carter Administration .completed emergency legislatioh today that would authorize Federal allocation of natural gas supplies and temporarily suspend Federal price ceilings for extra gas sold to interstate pipelines. The emergency bill was to go to Congress tonight or tomorrow. Final passage could come next week but could easily take more time.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Waiting For the Squeeze
description: NICOSIA, CyprusJust as Egypt acknowledges that the United States controls Israel's fate through economic and military aid and hopes the Carter Administration will squeeze that little country, forcing it to accept boundaries approximating those prior to the SixDay War, so do Greek Cypriots pray for a similar U.S. squeeze on Turkey to settle the protracted crisis here.

title: Robert Evans Dead at 76
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Jan. 25 (UPI)Robert Evans, a retired court reporter for United Press. International, died yesterday at Huntington Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: Toots's Guys Were Waiting for Him
description: Toots Shor wept for so many guys we can all spare a tear for him now. Though it is not quite true that if you told him, Chester A. Arthur is dead, he would break down sobbing, it is true that his capacity for affection was limitless and his sentimentality unabashed. His family and friends were his life. If God told me I could have anything and do anything I wanted in life, he often said, I would say I wanted to be a saloonkeeper, because where else could I make the friends I've got? Grantland Rice was deeply touched on his 70th birthday when he received 70 red roses from Toots Shor. That was generous and considerate of you, Toots was told, You don't know how Granny appreciated it. The fat paw made a brushoff gesture. Whisky, Toots said. That's all you need in this worldwhisky and heart.

title: Califano Is Sworn to Head H.E.W., Becoming 9th Member of Cabinet
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25In brief ceremonies today at the White House. Joseph A. Califano Jr., a chief architect of former President Johnson's Great Society programs, became Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, the ninth member of President Carter's Cabinet to take office officially.

title: Technology
G.I. in South Korea Shoots 4 Men in Unit
Dow Up 2.32 as Utilities Stand Out After Increase in Con Ed Dividend
description: Utility issues stood out yesterday in an otherwise lackluster stock market as the Dow Jones utility average, sparked by a dividend increase at Con Edison, rose to its highest level since 1973.

title: Dunlop Backers Call Him Victim Of Unfair Action
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Accusations that John T. Dunlop was opposed to Federal efforts to promote equal employment opportunities for women and members of minorities, made at the time he was being considered for Secretary of Labor, have left a residue of bitterness among some of his supporters who believe he was unjustly attacked.

title: McAdoo Sparkles as Knicks Crush Bulls in Homecoming
description: Perhaps it was a return to the home court or maybe the caliber of the Chicago Bulls, the worst offensive team in the National Basketball Association. but last night the Knicks hardly looked like a team that had lost eight of its previous 10 games.

title: Secondary Beneficiary
description: The Big Apple is a secondary beneficiary of an advertising campaign for Sitmar Cruises, a West Coast outfit that has begun running South American cruises out of New York.

title: Odds Called Good for Aspiring Actuaries
Happy Birthday Pals
description: If you have a child between 8 and 14 years of age, know one or are one, all you need is $1 to embark on what could be an interesting experience, or you may prefer to call it an experiment. The idea is that the child's name, birthday, month and year are sent to Birthday Pals of America and, in a short length of time, back comes a card with a name on it. The name is that of another child, who has the very same birthdate, but lives somewhere around 2,000 miles distant. The hope, of course, is that with the same birthday, the children will have an incentive to correspond with one another, to expand their experience and knowledgeand maybe finally prove they've learned how to write. As you may have guessed, the matching is done by computer and if, by chance, the pen friend doesn't work out, well let's hope that $1 won't lower your standard of living. The address Mark M. Klein, Birthday Pals of America Inc., P.O. Box 335, Englishtown, N.J. 07726.

title: Seaver's Nose Broken
HEAD OF INDIA SOCIALISTS AGREES NOT TO QUIT POST
description: NEW DELHI, Jan 25 (Reuters)The leader of the Socialist Party, George Fernandes, today withdrew leis resignation from the party chairmanship, tendered two days ago in protest over the decision of his colleagues to contest the forthcoming general election.

title: Mondale Parleys Exclude Envoys
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25American ambassadors in countries being visited by Vice President Mondale have generally not been invited to participate in official discussions if they were political appointees of the Ford Administration, State Department officials said today.

title: First Night
description: Like the soaring temperature of a surprise thaw. the curtain rose on the New. York City Ballet last night, ending a sixweek deep freeze brought on by a strike.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME Wages 4, Campbell 3.

title: Tenneco's Case Unit Plans to Buy Poclain
description: Tenneco Inc. announced in Houston that a subsidiary, the J. L. Case Company, had signed a letter of intent for Tenneco's acquisition of 40 percent of Poclain, S.A., a French machinery manufacturer, through the purchase of newly issued shares. Also, Tenneco would directly acquire certain assets of Poclain. The aggregate purchase price of the shares and the assets is estimated at $65 million.

title: College Basketball
description: AT NEW HAVEN

title: Lisbon Moves to Quiet GasolinePrice Unrest
description: LISBON, Jan. 25Portugal's Socialist Government, disturbed by signs of defiance in Madeira and the Azores, summoned the islands resident ministers to Lisbon today.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: CARTER WIDENS PLAN TO AID THE ECONOMY TO $31 BILLION TOTAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  President Carter has decided to give the economy a $31.3 billion stimulus over the next 20 months by aiding both big business and individuals.

description: By Reuters

title: Poor Are Victimized as Money Orders Fail
description: Tens of thousands of people in New York and seven other states may lose millions of dollars because of the financial difficulties of two littleknown companies that sold them money orders to pay their rent, electricity, insurance and other basic bills.

title: A REGULAR DOUBLES GIFT TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Better late than never, but I've doubled my usual donation in honor of our country's 200th birthday, wrote Emily A. Stanley of New York City.

description: 8,WMCA, WGBB: Hockey. Islanders vs, Toronto.

title: Lefkowitz, Citing Earlier Suit, Plans Action to Enjoin Korea Foundation
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz, the New York State Attorney General, said yesterday that he already had a lawsuit pending against the Korean Cultural and Freedom Foundation, but that he expected to seek an injunction against the group in response to action by the state's Board of Social Welfare.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Homestake Mining Company announced yesterday that it had completed a number of contracts with a group of major electric utility companies for the sale by Homestake of about 7.1 million pounds of uranium.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times on Monday stated incorrectly that the Bereavement and Loss Center was originally called. the Widows Consultation Center. The Widows Consultation Center was legally dissolved on Jan. 31, 1976, and its clients were referred to the Jewish Family Service. The supervisor of the Widows Consultation Center later opened the Bereavement and Loss Center and continued to serve some of thesame clients.

title: Democrats Oust Sikes as Chairman of a House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Democratic representatives, heeding warnings that the ethical integrity of the House was at stake, ousted Representative Robert L. F. Sikes of Florida today as chairman of a key Appropriations subcommittee.

title: Senate Confirms Appointment Of Young to United Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)The Senate today confirmed the appointment of Representative Andrew Young to be the chief United States delegate to the United Nations.

title: Byrd, Hinting Strained Relations, Says Carter Fails to Seek Advice
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, sent message of discontent to President Carter today, signaling the first suggestion of strained relations between the White House and Congressional Democratic leaders.

title: Woody Guthrie's Widow: Carrying On the Fight the Folk Singer Lost
description: The obituary of Woody Guthrie says he died a divorced man. It is true, and it is wrong.

title: A Detective Agency Defends Using Data On Political Opinion
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)A top officer of the nation's thirdlargest private detective agency defended today the agency's use of information gathered by an organization that says it monitors political activists.

title: 3,000 Demonstrate in Mexico City
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26 (AP)More than 3,000 youths blocked rushhour traffic in downtown Mexico City for four hours tonight with a demonstration for more liberal education policies. The demonstrators demanded free university education and automatic admission to the University of Mexico for high school graduates.

title: Hussein Says He May Meet Arafat
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 26King Hussein of Jordan said today that contacts were under way for a meeting between him and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, but that no date had been set.

title: Briton Consulting U.S. on Rhodesia
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 26 (UPI)Britain and the United States have been in contact over the failure of the latest peace plan for Rhodesia, the British negotiator, Ivor Richard, said today.

title: U.S. Summons 350 In 2Coast Inquiry On Pier Kickbacks
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation served some 350 subpoenas yesterday on persons in the East and Gulf Coast shipping industries in an investigation of what one source described as wholesale kickbacks by shipping companies to the International Longshoremen's Association.

title: The Cast
description: THE CRAZY LOCOMOTIVE by Stanislaw lunacy Witkiewicz translated by Danicl C. Gerould and C. 5. Durer. Directed by Des McAnuff; setting by Douglas Schmidt; costumes by Carol Odttz; lighting by Burl Hash; electronic music and orchestration by Pril Smiley; makeup by Claudia Kaneb; production stage manager, Divvy Freedman. Presented by the Chelsea Theater Center. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue.

title: The Cost of Appalachian Prosperity
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va. Hope is an active dream. It does not exist unless there is also the possibility of that dream coming true.

Big Board Issues Its Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
Article 5  No Title
Metropolitan Briefs
Hospital Joins in Coffee Boycott
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (UPI)Mount Sinai Hospital and Medical Center has announced that it will stop serving coffee in its cafeteria one day each week to protest the continuing rise in coffee prices. We believe it is in the interest of all of us to join this national campaign to boycott the purchase of coffee one day each week, Steve Stefanski, director of facilities and supportive services at the medical center, said.

description: (Reports supplled by resort owner.)

title: Leonard Silk
description: FRANKFURTThe Arthur F. Burns of West Germany is Karl Klasen, president of the Bundesbank, the country's central bank. The similarities between the two men are striking: both are courteousand conservative in style and thought. of course, there are differences: Dr. Klasen is somewhat softer in manner, while Dr. Burns is more professorial, more given to specific diagnosis of the numbers and more acerbic in response to intellectual challenges. However, both are consummate politicians, highly skilled at capturing the support not only of bankers, businessmen and legislators but also of presidents and chancellors.

title: Libel Suit Raises Questions on Press Confidentiality
description: An order by a Federal judge in a libel suit that CBS turn over to him a producer's notes about a CBS documentary has raised new questions about the confidentiality of the editorial process.

title: Britain Considers Voice for Workers in Management
Wake Forest 67, N. Carolina 66
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Carter Orders White House Ban On Secret Monitoring of Calls
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)President Carter today ordered a ban on any secret monitoring of telephone conversations in the White House.

title: Beame Takes City Proposals to Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  Mayor Beame arrived at the Capitol today lugging a 120page Federal legislative program for New York City for 1977. It calls for a massive increase in Federal spending and responsibilities.

title: Books of The Times
description: Mr. Kong, the celebrated simian, has waited 44 years to tell his story. Countess Ciano, Il Duce's daughter, has waited only 30 years to tell hers. On the whole Mr. Kong is more credible.

title: Scale Insect Is Ravaging Red Pines in Metropolitan Area
description: CROSS RIVER, N.Y.. Jan. 26The tall red pine trees stood gaunt against the sky on the snowcovered banks of the reservoir here, their limbs devoid of the bright evergreen needles that are the telltale signs of healthy, normal pine trees.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Bills on Right to Die Seem to Have Only Slim Chance
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26Bills that would establish a legal definition of death in New Jersey and empower individuals to refuse futile medical treatment appeared today to have only a slim chance of passage this year folloWing a legislative hearing.

title: Charles P. Heidt Is Dead
description: Charles P. Heidt, a Broadway producer who was a World War I combat pilot, died in Philadelphia on Monday. He was 82 years old.

title: Dollar Up a Bit Against Pound on Expected Cut in British Lending Rate
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 26 (UPI)The dollar eased on most European money markets today but inched upward against the British pound, which weakened on the expectation the Bank of England might again lower interest rates.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A oneyear moratorium was established on the installation in five New Jersey counties of new computerized Xray devices criticized by Blue Cross and state officials as too expensive for widescale use. Seven devices, already installed or approved, will not be affected by the ban.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MOZART SCOREBOARD The St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, proud to be the nation's second oldest orchestral unit, also wants it recalled that it's softball team beat that of the touring New York Philharmonic in the Missouri city last June. The Missourians hope to have another winner tonight at 8 o'clock at Carnegie Hall, when the St. Louis group makes one of its infrequent local appearances to perform Mozart's Mass in C minor.

title: Carter, Putting Leadership to Test, Again Asks Saving of Heating Fuel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26In renewing today his plea for the public to accept discomfort and chilly rooms by conserving heating fuel, President Carter was embarking on an early test of his personal leadership. It was a test that conformed to his own views of the Presidency. Repeatedly in his long political campaign he had said that only the President could speak for the Government with a clear and simple voice and that in the absence of Presiidential leadership, there is no leadership.

title: Syrian Moves Worry Israel
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Girl, 15, Is Held In Strangulationi Of Her Mother,
description: A 15yearold girl who has been in ant; out of centers for difficult juveniles was accused yesterday of having killed he 50yearold mother by strangling her with a pair of panty hose.

title: Stern Heads Advisory Council Of New York Board of Rabbis
description: Max Stern, a Jewish civic leader and business executive, has been elected president of the advisory council of the New York Board of Rabbis.

title: Margaret Hayes, Actress, Is Dead
description: Margaret Hayes, stage, television and screen actress, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Medical Center in Biami Beach. A resident of Palm Beach, Fla., she was 63 years old.

title: Municipal Unions Warn Beame On Continuing Outside Controls
In a Pinch, State U. Trustees Say, They Would Weigh City.U. Merger
description: Trustees of the State University of New York, which is smarting from its own budgetary wounds, said yesterday that it would prefer to remain a system separate from the financially crippled City University, but would consider merger if the state's financial position worsened.

title: SUIT AGAINST ALLEGED NAZI ASKS END TO CITIZENSHIP
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP)The United States Department of Justice filed suit today to revoke the citizenship of a suspected Nazi war criminal accused of beating and killing civilians in Poland in World War II.

title: Article 4  No Title
U.S. Confirms Syrian Move
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The State Department confirmed today that Syrian troops of the Arab, peacekeeping force ocoupied two towns in southern Lebanon close to the Israeli border.

description: AT BUFFALO

title: CARTER ENERGY BILL GOES TO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Asserting that the natural gas shortage and cold weather had caused unemployment for 400,000 persons, President Carter submitted emergency legislation to Congress today and again called on the public to help ease the crisis by turning down thermostats to 65 degrees.

title: Michigan Drops $69Million Road
description: DETROIT, Jan. 26The Michigan Highway Commission today canceled a 20yearold plan to build a 24mile stretch of highway that would have saved drivers eight minutes but would have cost $69.5 million and cut through a state park.

title: BETHLEHEM NET OFF 47.5% IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday a decline of 47.5 percent in fourthquarter net income as sales edged ahead by 1.6 percent. This contrasted with the United States Steel Corporation's fourthquarter decline of 27.9 percent in net income on a sales gain of 4.2 percent.

description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Seoul Regime Is Urged To Loosen Controls
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 26An opposition political leader charged today that continued enforcement of an emergency decree by President Park Chung Hee would weaken national unity. Lee Chol Sung, speaking at a news conference, said the twoyearold decree, which prevents free political activity, should be abolished.

title: Saint Laurent's Peasant Flourishes On and Off the Runway
Museum of Modern Art Picks Architect for Tower
description: The Museum of Modern Art has decided to recommend Cesar Pelli, the Los Angeles architect who became dean of the Yale School of Architecture this month, as architect for its proposed $40 million condominium apartment tower and gallery addition.

title: School Results
description: BOYS BASKETBALL

title: Greek Cypriot Newsman Charged With Supporting Coup Attempt
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 26 (Reuters)A Greek Cypriot journalist, Eleftherios Papadopoulos, was charged today with having supported the 1974 coup attempt against Archbishop Makarios.

title: News Summary
description: Recent arrests in Czechoslovakia of human rights activists drew a State Department charge of violation of the 1975 Helsinki agreement. It was the department's first public accusation against any government of noncompliance. The Carter Administration has pledged more attention to foreign failures to observe human rights. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: TRUDEAU DISPUTES LEVESQUE COMMENTS
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 26Like many other Canadians, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau reacted sharply today to the remark of Premier Rene Levesque in New York last night that independence for the Frenchspeaking province of Quebec was inevitable.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Slip
Soviet Skaters Sweep European Pairs Event
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 26 (AP)Irina Rodnina and Aleksandr Zaitsev of the Soviet Union won the European pairs figureskating championship today. For Miss Rodnina it was the ninth European title; it was Zaitsev's fifth.

title: Iona 92, Fairfield 87
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Hochberg, Assemblyman, Is Given. One Year in Jail in Bribery Case
W.H.A. Fines Clackson
description: TORONTO, Jan. 26 (AP)Kim Clackson, the Indianapolis Racers defenseman, has been fined $1,000 as a result of two spearing incidents earlier in the season, the World Hockey Association announced today. He currently is serving a threegame suspension imposed by the W.H.A. president, Bill MaeFarland. as a result of the same incidents.

title: JAPAN WANTS PILOTS TESTED FOR ALCOHOL
description: The Japanese Government, responding to evidence that the American pilot of a Japan Air Lines cargo jet was intoxicated when the plane crashed in Alaska Jan. 13, took steps yesterday to have pilots of all its airliners undergo preflight alcohol checks.

title: Parole for E. Howard Hunt Linked to $10,000 Fine
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)E. Howard Hunt Jr., who pleaded guilty for his role in planning the Watergate breakin, will be released from prison Feb. 25 if he pays a $10,000 fine still pending against him, the Federal Parole Commission said today.

title: L.I. Doctor Gets 25 Years to Life For Calculated Murder of Wife
description: MINEOLA, L.L Jan 26Dr. Charles E. Friedgood was sentenced today to the maximum. 25yearstolife imprisonment by a Nassau County Court judge who told the physician that he had committed a cold,. calculated and deliberate act of murder in killing his wife.

title: Ruckelshaus Reports
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 26 (UPI)William D. Ruckelshaus, head of the Environmental Protection Agency. under President Nixon, said that he was approached about a job in the Carter Administration but had declined.

title: Atlanta Rhythm Plays Finer Brand of Rock
description: The Atlanta Rhythm Section has been toiling along in the second acheIon of Southern rockandroll bands for quite a few years now. Its members are much too good to be relegated to the rank and file, but so far they have not been able to find a hit that would put them over the top. This is too bad; musically speaking,: they are the best the South has to offer.

title: CHARLES PATTERSON, EXAUTO AIDE DIES
description: DETROIT, Jan. 26Charles Hume Patterson, who served as the No. 3 man at the Ford Motor Company from 1963 to 1967, died Monday in a nursing home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 74 years old.

title: Japan's Top Party Convenes, Ignoring Lockheed Scandal
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26The LiberalDemocratic Party, a governing party of many rival factions that is still numbed by the shocks of the Lockheed scandal and its subsequent defeat in the December parliamentary election, met today. for its annual convention and acted as if nothing had happened.

title: French Girl, 16, Defeats Miss Morerod in Slalom
description: CRANSMONTANA, Switzerland, Jan. 26 (AP)The French women's team, led by Perrine Palen, a 16yearold newcomer, staged a World Cup comeback today in a slalom race marked by unusual snow and weather conditions.

title: U.S. Summons 350 In 2Coast Inquiry. On Pier Kickbacks
Syracuse Wins, 7667, as Bouie Stars
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26Syracuse University's basketball coach, Jim Boeheim, believes, with some justification, that he has the best pure center in the East. This is Roosevelt Bouie, a 6foot11inch coordinated freshman from Kendall, a little town in the upstate New York snow belt.

title: News Summary
description: Recent arrests in Czechoslovakia of human rights activists drew a State Department charge of violation of the 1975 Helsinki agreement. It was the department's first public accusation against any government of noncompliance. The Carter Administration has pledged more attention to foreign failures to observe human rights. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Bridge:
description: In the last 20 years in the United States and Europe there have been many experiments, some successful, some less so, with computer scoring. Some of these plans have been combined with the Swedish idea of a barometer, which allows players to know round by round how they are faring.

title: City Ballet: Bravos for George, Boos for a Pending Price Rise
Tennis
11 Banks Reportedly Link City Business To AffirmativeAction Rule Exemption
description: The New York Clearing House, which represents the city's major banks, has reportedly demanded as a condition for doing further. business with the city that the banks be exempted from the municipal affirmativeaction program that calls for written commitments from them or any other city contractors to provide an equitable share of jobs to members of minority groups and women. They have called for abolition of the entire program as duplicative and unnecessary in view of Federal and state efforts in the field.

title: Notes on People
description: Joseph Segars, a black member of the American consular staff in Johannesburg, South Africa, yesterday was reftfsed service at Chez Andre, a French restaurant reserved for whites. An American in Mr. Segars's party said that the restaurant manager would not let them be seated, saying he needed Government permission to do so. William M. Johnson, the American Consul General, said, This is the first such experience he has had; he has gone to other white restaurants and has generally been met with nothing but courteous treatment. The incident will be reported to United States Embassy officials in Pretoria.

title: Big Board Seat Price Unchanged
description: A membership seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $69,000, unchanged from the previous sale of Jan. 17, the Big Board reported. Seats are quoted at $66,000 bid, $77,000 asked.

title: Schmidt May Modify Rio Atom Pact
description: BONN, Jan. 26Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has begun talks with the new United States Government on ways to modify a controversial West German treaty to supply Brazil with nuclear technology, according to American and West German officials.

title: .Utilities Backing a $7.6 Million Effort to Develop New Batteries for Use in Electric Autos
description: The electric utility industry's reaserch organization and two energy companies announced yesterday that they planned to spend $7.6 million over the next three years to spur development of zincchlorine batteries. The batteries would be used in electric cars and as an energystorage system for utilities.

title: Letters
description: Bridge Tolls: Prelude to a New Exodus

title: 25% Con Ed Dividend Is Defended by Luce
description: The tone was friendly enough. The salutation was Dear Abe and the signature was Chuck, a persona that Charles F. Luce, chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company sometimes takes on when he is dealing with city officials.

title: Charlie Byrd Mixes 3 Styles for Jazz Bill
description: Twenty years have passed since Charlie Byrd made the first significant crack in the solid ranks of jazz guitarists who were following in the wellworn steps of Charlie Christian. Using a classical Spanish guitar instead of an electric guitar, Mr. Byrd began to develop a repertory that at first was split between jazz and classical works but, within a few years, with his introduction to the United States of the Brazilian bossa nova, added Latin American music as a third element.

title: Adelphi Player's Death in Game Still Remains a Puzzle
description: The sudden death of Marshall Williams, 21yearold starting center on the Adelphi University basketball team, in Tuesday night's game at Southampton College may cause the postponement or cancellation of Saturday's AdelphiNew Hampshire game, and may also result in the cancellation of the remainder of Adelphi's basketball schedule.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The State Department affirmed today that the Carter Administration intended to work for normal relations With Vietnam but said progress depended onclearing up a nuni ber of issues, including information about Americans still listed as missing from the Vietnam War.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The State Department said today that the United States would not support any negotiations initiated by Prime Minister Smith for a solution in Rhodesia that excludes the black nationalist leaders of that country.

title: No Hear No See, No Read
description: Discerning visitors to the State Department used to find a touch of squalor in the hushed, cherrypaneled elegance of the executive offices: each telephone carried a button marked MON. By pushing the button when officials took phone calls, stenographers would listen in, silently, without the callers knowledge, take furious shorthand, and later provide typed transcripts.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)Folfollowing is the 74to20 rollcall vote by which the Senate confirmed F. Ray Marshall today to be Secretary of Labor.

title: Archbishop Trifa Answers Questions on Role in War
description: DETROIT, Jan. 26 (UPI)  Federal prosecutors said today that Archbishop Valerian Trifa, accused of participating in a proNazi movement in Rumania in World War II, had answered all questions at a meeting with Government attorneys yesterday.
