description: ROME, Jan. 26Vice President Mondale arrived in Rometoday after a visit to the Berlin Wall to reaffirm a United Sta,tes commitment to use whatever means may be necessary to preserve the freedom of the divided city.

title: FUTURES MARKETS AWAIT CROP REPORT
description: The news in the key commodity futures markets came after the close of trading again yesterday.

title: Medical Discharge Is Cited for Figure in Hughes Will
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 26Melvin Dummar, a beneficiary in the socalled Mormon will of Howard R. Hughes and a central figure in the attempt to establish the document's authenticity, was dismissed from the United States Air Force after six months because of emotional problems, it was disclosed in court today.

title: LAND DEVELOPER SETS $4 MILLION REFUNDS UNDER F.T.C. ACCORD
Former DuffyMott President Gets Prison, $20,000 Fine, on Taxes
description: Donald M. Klock, former president of the DuffyMott Company, received a oneyear. prison sentence on taxevasion charges yesterday from a Federal judge who said that wealthy defendants should not receive special treatment.

title: U.S. ASSERTS PRAGUE VIOLATES COVENANTS ABOUT HUMAN RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The State Department charged Czechoslovakia today with having violated the provisions of the 1975 Helsinki agreement by a series of arrests and harassment of humanrights activists. It was the first time that the State Department, had publicly accused a government of failure to live up to the Hel sinki accord, which was signed by the United States and 34 other states, including Czechoslovakia. The State Department has generally avoided commenting on other countries internal affairs.

title: Nastase, Borg and Orantes Upset in Tennis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (AP)Bill Scanlon of Texas, a newcomer in the playformoney ranks, upset thirdseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, 26, 61, 64, tonight to reach the third round of the $200,000 United States pro indoor tennis championship.

title: Southern Africa Begs to Know
description: Even while we debate the range of our concernand stake inhuman rights abroad, events crowd in upon us, most poignantly this week from southern Africa. The United States has now been cast as the last hope of moderate forces throughout that region as they seek to, avoid a vicious racial conflict whose poison would quickly spread to our own multiracial society. The struggle touches our humanity and our domestic harmony, interests that far, transcend the objectives of also containing Soviet influence.

title: FRED I. ARCHIBALD, 83, A HEARST PUBLISHER
description: Fred I. Archibald, former publisher of The Baltimore News American, died Tuesday at Johns Hopkins Hospital. He was 83 years old and was a resident of Baltimore.

title: Parts of Latest Work By Petr Kotik Played
description: Petr Kotik has been composing music for instruments and voices using texts by Gertrude Stein since 1971. His latest work, Many Many Women, is too long for a conventional concert presentation, but a portion of it was performed Tuesday night by two flutists, two trombonists and four singers from the S.E.M. Ensemble at the Paula Cooper gallery, 155 Wooster Street.

title: Dr. Sydney Mark Kanev Is Dead
description: Dr. Sydney Mark Kanev, an osteopathic physician in New York City for 45 years, died yesterday in his home at 530 Park Avenue. He was 73 years old.

title: Unwanted Animals Present Nationwide Social Problem
description: While Deborah Lawson believes that a number of humane societies have evolved into huge bureaucracies, the Philadelphiabased radio talk show commentator made it equally clear recently to members of the Dog Fanciers Club that these agencies are not responsible for the nationwide social problem of unwanted animals. The speaker cited some sad situations.

title: Madrid, Faced By Strife, Bans Demonstrations
description: MADRID, Jan. 26  Confronting a menacing wave of political violence, the Government announced tonight that it was banning public demonstrations, expelling foreigners with extremist sympathies and restricting the use of private arms while at the same time continuing with its plans to hold general elections.

title: Hechinger Will Head The Times Foundation
description: The election of Fred M. Hechinger, a member of the editorial board of The New York Times, as president of The New York Times Company Foundation was announced today by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and president of The New York Times Company.

description: Pledging to liberate the city from the banks and from Governor Carey and the Emergency Financial Control Board, Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan announced his candidacy for Mayor yesterday.

title: CARTER ENERGY BILL GOES TO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Asserting that the natural gas shortage and cold weather bad caused unemployment for 400,000 persons, President Carter submitted emergency legislation to Congress today and again called on the public to help ease the crisis by turning down thermostats to 65 degrees.

description: BEENEYJanot L. Died on January 18, 1977. In memoriam.

title: Houston H. Wasson, 65, Lawyer Associated With Tanker Concerns
description: Houston H. Wasson, a lawyer, died yesterday at his Waccabuc, N.Y., home. He was 65 years old.

title: De Gaetano Displays Pianism
description: Robert de Gaetano's recital at Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Stfeet Y.M.Y.W.H.A. Tuesday night reaffirmed his reputation as a pianist of formidable technical equipment. In works as different in their demands as Shostakovich's Scnate No. 1 (Op. 12), Ravel's Jeux d'eau and three pieces by Chopin, the young product of the Juilliard School played with impeccable fingers. Beethoven's Sonata in E (Op. 109), while not the most challenging of the late works, nonetheless calls for impregnable technique and solid musicianship. Mt. de Gaetano did not come up short anywhere.

title: U.M.W. Halts Payments Of Political Action Unit
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 26, (AP)The secretarytreasure of the United Mine Workers announced today that all payments and checks for the union's political action committee had been stopped as of 9 A.M.

title: Let's Do It
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26In the early morning of Nov. 13, 1849, Charles Dickens came upon a crowd outside Horsemonger Lane Jail in London. People were waiting to see a Mr. and Mrs. Manning hanged for the murder of their lodger. Dickens watched through the hours until sunrise, as the crowd screamed and laughed and sang Oh Mrs. Manning to the tune of Oh Susannah. Later that day he wrote a letter to The Times of London.

title: Carter Is Reported To Weigh Moyers As Head of C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  Bill D. Moyers, a former aide to President Johnson, was reported today to be among those seriously under consideration by President Carter as the Director of Central Intelligence.

description: PARIS, Jan. 26In France, it appears that haute couture and Communism are compatible.

description: Buoyed by strong domestic petroleum earnings, the Mobil Corporation, parent of the Mobil Oil Corporation, yesterday reported a fourthquarter earnings gain of 33.5 percent. Earnings for the year were up 16.3 percent.

title: EVELYN FOLKS ORTON
description: Evelyn Folks Orton, wife of Lawrence M. Orton, former vice chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, died in Denver on Jan. 19 after a long illness. She lived in Denver and was 75 years old.

title: Maurice Rubin, 78, an Engineer
description: Maurice Rubin, a lawyer, author and engineer who worked on a phase of the atomic bomb project, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He lived at 1 Plaza Street, Brooklyn, and was 78 years old.

title: Human Rights The President's Promise
description: Throughout his long campaign for .the Presidency, Jimmy. Carter said that he would give the enhancement of human rights in other nations a central place in his foreign policy. Thus it was no surprise ,that he emphasized human rights in his Inaugural Address and also his subsequent message to citizens of the world. And it is consistent with his intention that the State Department yesterday took note of the latest repressions Czechoslovakia.

title: Theater: The Crazy Locomotive
description: The gradual yet careful exploration of the lesserknown reaches of European drama continues apace in Brooklyn, where the Chelsea Theater Center yesterday gave us the American premiere of Stanislaw Ignacy Witkiewicz's play The Crazy Locomotive. It was certainly crazy  even loco  but not uninteresting.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times on Monday stated incorrectly that the Bereavement and Loss Center was originally called the Widows Consultation Center. The Widows Consultation Center was legally dissolved on Jan. 31, 1976, and its clients were referred to the Jewish Family Service. The supervisor of the Widows Consultation Center later opened the Bereavement and Loss Center and continued to serve some of the same clients.

description: BONG KONG, Jan. 26China regards defense against the Soviet Union as its most important problem and believes the Tglwan question is a secondary issue, tliat can wait, according to a speech purportedly given by a senior Chinese official last summer.

description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP)A movie producer and director, Laurence Merrick, maker of the documentary film Manson, based on the Charles M. Manson cult, was shot to death today at his film school in Hollywood by an unidentified assailant, the police said. The gunman escaped.

The Missourians hope to have another winner tonight 8 o'clock at Carnegie Hall, when the St. Louis group makes one of its infrequent local appearances to perform Mozart's Mass in C minor.

This foreclosed mainstream Republican opposition to the way the war was conducted until 1967.

title: About New York
description: The rule this political season is not to pick directly on Abe Beame, widely perceived as a decent grandfather of a man, even when a challenger yearns not just to turn him out of City Hall but also to ceremoniously strip him of his bookkeeper's gray buttons on the doorstep. Percy E. Sutton, in declaring yesterday for Mr. Beame's job as Mayor, successfully followed the rule until the very end of his news conference when the Manhattan Borough President's vivid talent as a speaker happened on a manhood metaphor.

title: Article 3  No Title
Music: Rudolf Serkin's Metier
description: It was Rudolf Serkin's kind of program last night in Carnegie Hall. The celebrated pianist settled for three Beethoven sonatas. Mr. Serkin really does have an extensive repertory, from Bach through Bartok but, more and more, he concentrates on Beethoven, his greatest love. At this stage of his life he is obviously willing to let the younger generation explore the repertory. He is going to for the unsearchable in Beethoven.

title: 500 Attend Service for Toots Shor
description: Bernard (Toots) Shor, who died Sunday night at the age of 73, was eulogized yesterday at Temple EmanuEl as the world's greatest saloonkeeper who also was a warm, generous and religious man.

description: CHAMWINO, TanzaniaAmid recurrent reports of shortages and unemployment in the cities, this rural cooperative village and others like it sustain the vision of a socialist, egalitarian and selfSufficient Tanzania.

title: Music: Catchy
description: There were two encouraging aspects to the program of music by Neely Bruce presented in Town Hall on Tuesday night. The composer's interest in musical Americana seems to have rubbed off on him; his best work has a maverick humor. Also, the more recent his music, the better it gets.

description: Following is the text of Charter 77, a Czechoslovak humanrights manifesto cited by the State Department yesterday as evidence of rights violations. It was translated by and published in the current issue of The New. Leader, dated Jan. 31.

title: Bruce Hungerford, Pianist, Is Dead
description: Bruce Hungerford. concert pianist and Egyptologist, was killed early yesterday in an automobile accident in the Pelham Bay Park area of the Bronx. He was 54 years old. Also fatally injured in the accident were Mr. Hungerford's mother, Anna Hungerford, and Mr. and Mrs. Sal Azriel. Mrs. Azriel was Mr. Hungerford's niece.

title: Cairo Prohibits
description: CAIRO, Jan. 26 (Reuters)The Egyptian Government today banned demonstrations and strikes but said there would be no going back on political and economic liberalization measures introduced by President Anwar elSadat.

title: Becton Takeover Set On National Medical
description: Becton, Dickinson & Company and National Medical Care Inc., announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement in principle to merge National Medical Care into Becton, Dickinson in a stock transaction valued at $143 million.

title: 2 Religious Sects Banned, By Argentine Government
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 26 (AP).The military Government banned two religious sects today on the ground that they flouted the principles of Argentine nationhood, morals and customs.

title: Big Measles Outbreak on Coast Threatens Serious Complications
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26Los Angeles is experiencing a widespread outbreak of measles that has already claimed the life of an 18monthold child and threatens to leave hundreds more victims with complications ranging from pneumonia to encephalitis.

title: Longet Attorney Says No Delay Is Expected in Sentencing Date
description: ASPEN, Colo, Jan. 26 (AP)  A defense attorney for the entertainer Claudine Longet, who was convicted Jan. 15 in the shooting death of her lover, said today that he would not try to delay her sentencing, set for Monday.

title: Glamour Stocks Under Pressure As Dow Jones Average Falls 7.39
description: Glamour stocks, once the market's favorite group, came under renewed selling pressure yesterday as prices generally gave ground across a broad front in active trading.

title: Tanzania Hunts Dog Packs After Rabies Kills 50 People
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 26 (UPI)A major dog hunt is under way in two jungle regions to stamp out rabies epidemic that has killed more than 50 persons, the Health Ministry said today.

title: New Debt Managers at Treasury Map Bigger Urban Affairs Role
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Treasury's new debtmanagement team, announcing terms of a February refunding package, appeared today to have charted a course that envisions no radical departures from policies of the Ford Administration.

title: U.S. CAR OUTPUT IN WEEK EXPECTED TO RISE BY 17.7%
description: DETROIT, Jan, 26American auto production is scheduled to total 191,408 this week, an increase of 17.7 percent from 162,681 last week and a 13.6 percent rise from the 168,481 units built in the yearearlier level, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

title: People and Business
description: Roger E. Anderson, chairman of the Continental Illinois Corporation, said he expected bankingindustry profits to continue to improve in 1977 as the large loan losses and provisions of the last two years wind down, though the situation, he said, will vary greatly from bank to bank. Mr. Anderson, speaking at a news briefing here, sees the competition for loans that developed in the last half of 1976 becoming most intense in the first half of this year and moderating as the economy picks up in the second half.

title: $1.3 Billion Is Sought to Aid 200,000 Idle
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Secretary of Labor F. Ray Marshall announced today a plan to create 200,000 jobs for unemployed Vietnam veterans, a $1.3 billion proposal designed to complement President Carter's pardon of Vietnam draft resisters last week.

title: Cold Comfort on Heat
description: The long cold winter has already devastated the lives of thousands of New Yorkers who have no heat in their apartments. What can be done  and who should do it? In the short run, there is more  though not muchthat the city can and should do. But there can be no fuller response until it is understood that the cold is only part of the problem. The heat crisis has been intensified by the weather, but the underlying cause is economic.

title: Action on Carey Nominee Deferred
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27The Finance Committee of the State Senate, which must pass on all of Governor Carey's nominees for state jobs, this week again put off considering the nomination of the man whom. the Governor named 17 months ago to head the Workmen's Compensation Board.

title: Carter's Tax Package Raises Questions
description: Although the formal tax package presented by the Carter Administration on Capitol Hill yesterday contained some tax breaks for business, many industrialists believe it was still not clearly focused enough to achieve the Administration's economic goals.

title: Music: The Graffman Flair
description: GARY GRAFFMAN was piano soloist with Musica Aeterna Orchestra in a concert at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night under the direction of Frederic Waldman.

title: About Real Estate
Draft Charges Dropped
description: A Federal judge in Newark has dismissed indictments against 49 New Jersey men charged with draft evasion during the Vietnam War. Judge Lawrence A. Whipple dismissed the charges after the United States District Attorney's office moved to comply with President Carter's pardon of draft evaders. There are no other cases currently pending against draft evaders in New Jersey. In the last nine years, six men have been prosecuted in New Jersey for draft evasion, according to United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein.

title: ShotPut to Pyka
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 27  Emmitt Berry, a junior from the University of Texas at El Paso, and Ian Pyka, a sophomore from the University of Maryland, capturedthe Millrose Games 35pound weight throw and shotput events tonight at Yale's Cox Cage.

title: Big and Powerful Computer Is Introduced by Honeywell
description: Honeywell Inc. yesterday introduced what it called the largest most powerful computer in its 20year history in the dataprocessing field.

title: Meter Maid Wins Fine
description: A Bronx real estate agent who was arrested on charges of breaking a meter maid's nose because she attempted to give him a $10 parking ticket was fined $665 yesterday in Criminal Court. The agent; Leon Allen, 48 years old, of 2082 Ryer Avenue, was ordered to pay the money to Nancy Bonds to cover her medical bills and loss of salary. Mr. Allen handed over the money in $5 and $10 bills. It is estimated that one in every five of the city's parking agents is assaulted in the course of a year.

title: O.A.U Asks a Military Force
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 27 (AP)William Eteki Mboumoua of Cameroon, the Secretary General of the Organization of African Unity, told reporters today that his... grouping of 42 black African countries should set up a panAfrican military force to protect against raids across borders of black nations by South Africans or Rhodesians.

title: Namath Expresses Hope For a Place in the Sun
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Jan. 27  Joe Namath, deeply tanned, smiling and relaxed after his proam competition today in the American Airlines Golf Classic, had an even bigger smile when asked whether he would like to continue his fading football career with the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Windows on the World
description: World Trade Center, 107th floor, 9381111. Monday through Friday, noon to 3 P.M., this is a membershipclub restaurant. Nonmembers must pay a cover charge of $10 for the host and $3 for each guest.

title: Carter Appointment Of Two Republicans Upsetting to O'Neill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  He was upset, the Speaker of the House said today, because the first two Presidential appointments in his home state had gone to Republicans.

title: NATHALINE FRACKMAN
description: Nathaline Fraclunan, who wrote The Complete Book of Entertaining, Nata Lee's Guide for Every Hostess, under the name of Nata Lee, died yesterday in her home, 36 East 36th Street, after a brief illness. She. was 74 years old.

title: Aqueduct to Reopen Grandstand Monday
description: Steve Cauthen and the New York Racing Association both had losing days yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: RADIO
description: 69 AM, WNCNFM. Grand Tarantelle for Piano and Orchestra, Gottschalk; Rondo in G, Beethoven; March from Tsar Sultan, RimskyKorsakov; Flower Song from Carmen, Bizet; The Fencing School, Schmelzer; Mazurka No. 32, Chopin; Overture to Luisa Miller, Verdi.

title: U.S. Sends Carrier Force To the Indian Ocean
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP)The Navy has sent a nuclearpowered aircraft carrier task force into the Indian Ocean for the first time in nearly 12 years. The voyage of the task force, comprising the carrier Enterprise and the guidedmissile cruisers Long Beach and Truxtun, was described a routine deployment.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLINDERMeredith (Zaretzki). Died January 28, 1974. We toys and miss you more & more each passing day.

title: The Dance: Wholesale Debuts at City Ballet
description: THE HIGHLIGHT of the New York City Ballet's performance Wednesday night at the State Theater was definitely George Balanchine's Stravinsky Violin Concerto, led with panache and pungency by Kay Mazzo, Peter Martins, Karin von Arnoldingen and JeanPierre Bonnefous,

title: Women Resume Races Today
description: ST. GERVAIS, France, Jan. 27 (AP)Twentyyearold LiseMarie Morerod of Switzerland begins the second half of the World Cup ski series here tomorrow with a commanding 19point lead over her chief rival, Annemarie Proell Moser of Austria. Mrs. Moser is a fivetime World Cup champion.

title: Roots Getting a Grip on People Everywhere
description: My children and I just sat there, crying, said a black public relation director in Nashville. We couldn't talk. We just cried,

title: Carter Looks to New Arms Talks With Russians Within 3 Months
Foss Leads Concert of 5 Moderns
description: Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonia Orchestra are celebrating American music in their current Meet the Moderns series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and what finer Americans to present tonight than Bartok, Hindemith, Schoenberg, Stravinsky and Varse?

title: Kallman Ousted From Top Posts At Gimbels Unit
description: Matt Kallman, who only last July was named chairman and chief executive officer of Gimbels New York, was relieved of those posts yesterday and has been succeeded by Elliott J. Stone, the president and chief operating officer of Gimbel Brothers Inc., the parent company.

title: Management
description: The soaring cost of product liability insurance has produced real horror stories among small businesses, according to the National Federation of Independent Business.

title: Tanaka, on Stand, Denies Accepting  Bribe by Lockheed
Clause to Will Put in Vault
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 (UPI)A codicil to a purported will of Mr. Hughes has been sealed in plastic and stored in special vault pending the outcome of litigation over the Hughes estate.

title: SUSPECT IN ROBBERY CAUGHT AFTER CHASE
description: No sooner had three tellers at a Chemical Bank branch on Madison. Avenue handed more than $60,000 to a holdup man yesterday. than one of the bank's tellers chased the suspect.

title: Bigger, Not Better
description: President Carter's fiscal stimulus proposals, as presented to Congress by Budget Director Bert Lance, have been expanded to an investment of $31.1 billion over a 20month period. The plan does not, however, emphasize employment programs as much as Mr. Carter had seemed to suggest that it would, and it seems unlikely to have much impact on the most crucial economic problemyouth unemployment.

title: Jazz: Kirk Nurock at Keyboard
description: Kirk Nurock, a composer for theater and dance groups and director of Natural Sound workshops for singers and audience participation, performed as a jazz pianist at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday. His style welded classical techniques onto the structures of jazz compositions through the medium of a rather remarkable facility.

title: Friday
description: In the early 1960's, you could hear Bob Dylan, Judy Collins, Simon and Garfunkel and Peter, Paul and Mary at Folk City before they became household names. The Greenwich Village nightspot still occasionally showcases unknowns and this weekend is one of those times. Tonight through Sunday at 9 P.M., six aspiring acts will take turns in the spotlightFrank Caraskuillo (comedian), Sue Greenwood. Sonny Boy Robinson, Van Rozay and Rick Wyatt (all singers and guitarists), and the duo Ellen Mandel and Michael Lydon (she sings and plays piano; he sings and plays guitar and harmonica). For the price of admission ($3 tonight and Saturday, $2.50 Sunday), you might be lucky enough to witness the start of yet another big career. 130 West Third Street. Information: 2548449.

title: Some  Catholics Are Critical. of Vatican Statements
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 American Catholic spokesmen here emphasized today that the question of ordaining women was a closed matter now that the Vatican had affirmed its opposition.

title: BOND PRICES SHOW SOME SHARP DROPS
description: The bond market declined sharply yesterday in the wake of the Treasury's announcement of its plans to refinance $2.1 billion of publicly held 8 percent notes and to raise $3.7 billion of additional cash. The Treasury's plans, although in line with what bond dealers had said they expected, apparently was not fully discounted in the marketplace. The Treasury said it would sell threeyear notes, sevenyear notes and 30year bonds next week.

title: The Pop Life
description: BONNIE KOLOC, who was at the Bottom Line last weekend, is a singer in her late 20's who has been a fixture in Chicago for some years. She is just now beginning to make an impact on the country as a whole. The reason for the delay is probably simple enough. Up to now, she's been on a Middle Western label, Ovation, that apparently lacked the promotional clout to call much attention to its artists. After four Ovation albums, Miss Koloc spent a year and a half negotiating a new deal and recording a new album for Epic. And although she played the Bitter End four years ago, she is just now beginning to tour nationally in a serious way.

title: Article 1  No Title
A Rare Visit From Mr. Soprano Sax
description: The soprano saxophone, which Is straight, not curved like the other members of the saxophone family and looks something like a slightly swollen clarinet, was considered an archaic instrument during the 1950's. It was played by a few oldtime jazz musicians, notably Sidney Bechet, but modem jazz and classical players would not touch it. It was too unreliable, they said, too difficult to play in tune.

title: INDICTMENT CHARGES 9 OF DEFUNCT FIRM IN STOCK CONSPIRACY
Nigeria Evoking a Lost Past For U.S. Black Performers
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 27You have blacks in America who live there and die there and never get a chance to see the land where their ancestors came from, said Omar Kali, a 48yearold trapeze artist from the Watts area of Los Angeles.

title: Insurance Company Heats Building With Computers
description: CLINTON, N.J., Jan. 27Officials of the New York Life Insurance Company are using their mechanical brains to beat the record cold weather.

title: WILLIAM F. DOSCHER
description: William F. Doscher, who retired last summer as president and chief executive officer of USLIFE Mutual Funds Management. Corporation of Manhattan, now known as Sentinel Advisors Inc., died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 56 years old and lived at 17 Anondale Drive in Huntington, L.I.

title: Blue Jays Start Farm in Utica
description: TORONTO, Jan. 27 (AP)The Toronto Blue Jays, one of two new expansion teams in the American League, said today they would place a Class A New YorkPenn League farm team in Utica, N.Y. The new franchise will be known as the Utica Blue Jays.

title: EDGAR J. JOHNSON
description: Edgar J. Johnson, director of avionics licensing and social programs for RCA Corporation, died Wednesday in Ann Arbor, Mich., while on a business trip. He was 58 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: High Tides Around New York
178,040 Contracts, A Record, Traded On Chicago Board
description: An historic volume of trading was reported yesterday by the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's largest commodity futures exchange.

title: Renaissance Music Flourishes in a Gothic Setting
description: The earlymusic concert being given Sunday afternoon at 2:30 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by Calliope: A Renaissance Rana, is just one instance of the burgeoning interest and activity in the field. There are annual festivals and seasonlong series at the cathedral, regular performances at Alice Tully Hall, the Metropolitan Museum and the 92d Street Y, and even, cocasionally, special, staged versions of medieval mystery plays, such as the recent revivals of the old New York Pro Musica productions of The Play of Daniel and The Play of Herod.

title: Stage: A Strindberg Repertory
Table of Tax Shifts in Carter's Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Following is a table prepared by the Treasury Department that shows the tax changes for various categories of taxpayers under the proposals of President Carter, starting in 1977.

title: Charles F. Grisham Dies at 86
description: Charles F. Grisham, an enlisted Navy man who rose from the ranks to become a captain and flagship commander for several admirals, died Wednesday at the Veterans Hospital in New Orleans after being stricken while on vacation. He was 86 years old and lived at 56 Willard Avenue, Old Saybrook. Conn.

title: Pedestrian Mall on Times Square Will Be Tested With U.S. Funds
description: New York City has won a $500,000 grant from the Federal Government to create an experimental pedestrian mall in Times Square this summer that would become permanent if it proved successful.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 28, 1977

title: Roots Getting a Grip on People Everywhere
description: My children and I just sat there, crying, said a black public relation director in Nashville. We couldn't talk. We just cried.

title: Mondale Flies to London After Meeting With Pope
description: LONDON, Jan. 27Vice President Mondale arrived in London today after an hourlong meeting with Pope Paul VI, who strongly endorsed President Carter's call to curb the spread of nuclear weapons and who likened President Carter to President John F. Kennedy.

title: 30Day Jail Sentence Urged for Miss Longet
description: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 27 (UPI)A probation officer recommended today that Claudine Longet serve no more than 30 days in a county jail for the slaying of her lover, Vladimir Sabich, the skier.

title: 2 Albany Units to Study Protecting Patients Against Medical Abuses
description: The problem of protecting the public from incompetent and unethical doctors will be investigated by two committees of the New York State Legislature, Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut announced yesterday.

title: Black Rights Chief Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP)Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has chosen a black lawyer from the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. to take charge of enforcing Federal civil rights laws, Justice Department sources said today.

title: OHIO SCHOOLS CLOSE
U.S. CAUTIONS SOVIET ON SAKHAROV CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The State Department said today that if the Soviet Union tried to silence Andrei D. Sakharov, the political dissident, it would be in conflict with accepted international standards of human rights.

title: Mr. Sutton's True Picture
description: A word of welcome and of caution to Percy Sutton as he sets forth to seek the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York. He is an intelligent and articulate man, with a shrewd grasp of political reality and a genuine concern for the human condition. After ten years as Borough President of Manhattan, he is qualified to contribute to an understanding of the most difficult issues. Mr. Sutton is also black; the city should be proud that he fudges it ready to elect him.

title: Makarios and Turkish Cypriot Meet
RICHARD F. CORKEY DIES
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 27Richard F. Corkey, a former assistant state attorney general and State Senator in Connecticut, died yesterday at Lawrence Memorial Hospital in New London, where he had been admitted earlier in the day. He was 72 years old.

title: The Court Ruling on Zoning
description: TRENTON, Jan. 27The New Jersey Supreme Court's latest zoning ruling, handed down yesterday, left unanswered a major question: Who is going to build suburban housing for the poor? The court reaffirmed in a 4to3 ruling that New Jersey suburbsreferred to by the justices as developing areas  must be preAnalysis pared to take a fair share of the state's poor, and must rearrange zoning regulations so that housing developments for poor and lowincome families are not precluded.

title: Another Ethics Test for Congress
description: We have been concerned, for fairly obvious reasons, with the ethics of our Congress and the necessity of a code of conduct to govern our legislators now that they are about to get a deserved raise in pay. There is a further problem, affecting Congressional elections, that also requires the attention of both Houses.

title: 4 More Upset But Connors Beats Fibak
New York Drafting a Plan To Aid Those Who Bought Unpayable Money Orders
Queries on Hughes Will Continue
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 27 (UPI)An attorney for Howard R. Hughes's relatives accused Melvin Dummar today of researching material for the socalled Mormon will that would leave millions of dollars to Mr. Dummar. He also accused Mr. Durnmar's wife, Bonnie, of writing the document.

title: ENTRIES
description: Horses listed In order of post positions

title: Austria Would Take Dissidents
description: VIENNA, Jan. 27 (Reuters) Austria has told Czechoslovakia that it is ready to accept dissidents but does not wish to concentrate on a certain number of names.

title: Tenzer Appointed To Head the Board Of Social Welfare
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27Governor Carey today appointed Herbert Tenzer, a former Congressional colleague, to head the State Board of Social Welfare. The appointment is part of a major reorganization of the agency that Mr. Carey is seeking to achieve this year.

title: GRUMMAN SAYS NET HIT BY NAVY CLAIMS
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that the settlement of its longstaning claims with the United States Navy for F14 fighter costs will reduce the company's fourthquarter earnings for 1976.

title: MORE WALKOUTS IN SPAIN PROTEST POLITICAL STRIFE
description: MADRID, Jan. 27 (UPI)Strikes spread throughout Spain today on the third day of protests against the rightwing violence that has claimed seven lives since Sunday.

title: Opposition Party in India Charges Government Still Holds Thousands
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 27The opposition Janata Party charged today that thousands of its sympathizers were still being held in jails in India, despite Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's announcement last week that normal political activities could be resumed.

title: Excerpts From Vatican's Declaration Affirming Prohibition on Women Priests
description: For some years now various Christian communities stemming from the 16thcentury Reformation or of later origin have been admitting women to the pastoral office on a par with men. This initiative has led to petitions and writings by members of these communities and similar groups, directed toward making this admission a general thing; it has also led to contrary reactions.

title: Gengler Duo Triumphs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Yonkers Drivers
description: (Thru Thursday, Jan. 27)

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (millions of dollars)

title: Fordham Loses 9th Game in Row As Favored Army Five Wins, 6752
description: Fordham University lost its ninth straight basketball game last night. The Rams, playing on their home court on Rose Hill in the Bronx, bowed to Army, 6752. The result was expected.

title: Fireman Saves Life After Just Finishing FirstAid Training
description: On Wednesday morning, Fireman Robert DiFiore was graduated as an emergency medical technician after spending more than 100 hours of his own time learning how to save lives through first aid procedures.

title: Paris Has 3 Hits, With One of Them The New Givenchy
Weekend Gardening: The Virtues of Shrubs
description: Winter dreams can be the seeds of spring gardens. And there is no time like right now to start planning this year's greenery.

title: SixthGrade Class Sponsors Fair That Earns a Gift for the Neediest
Sheila Hawkins Harris, 50, Dies
description: Shelia Hawkins Harris, a civic leader and former advertising executive, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. She was 50 years old and a resident of Princeton. N.J.

title: ABC Took a Gamble With Roots and Is Hitting Paydirt
description: ABCTV has hit the jackpot with its gamble in scheduling Roots over eight consecutive nights beginning last Sunday. That pattern of presentation is rare in primetime television and risky, since ABC's ratings for an entire week would have been seriously damaged if the program had failed to capture the fancy of the viewers on the first night.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE TITLE of Earl Thompson's new novel, Caldo Largo which literally means abundant souprefers to a Mexican bouillabaise that keeps simmering day and night in a fishing boat's galley and is called by its cook the soup of life. The novel is wellnamed, for it brims with boisterous vitality and fairly bubbles along. Stripped to its bones, it's about a free spirit named Johnny Long who is trying to make as an independent shrimp fisherman working the Gulf of Mexico from his home port near Brownsville, Tex. The fishing turns bad for a stretch. Johnny falls behind on his boat payments. So he has to accept a proposition from some Castro supporters to smuggle arms for their leader's final, to Havana. The results of the smuggling prove as catastrophic as they are predictable.

title: Adelphi Cancels Game
description: The Adelphi University basketball team, mourning the death of its starting center, canceled its game tomorrow against New Hampshire College. The Adelphi players will hold a team meeting today to decide whether to continue playing this season. The Panthers next scheduled game is Wednesday night at Brooklyn College.

title: Council Replaces Miss Costanza
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Music: Judas Maccabeus, Flowers in the Desert
description: MANY OF HANDEL'S oratorios are admired with hardly a reservation. Judas Maccabeus has its proponents, but it has its strong detractors as well. Heard in Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night in a performance by the choir and orchestra of Musica Sacra of New York, one could see why.

title: Notes on People
RESULTS
description: By The Associated Press

title: Saturday
description: Pete Seeger, who always seems ready to sing for a cause, will sing for two in Brooklyn on Saturday. , night. He is giving a concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music at 8 P.M. to benefit the Magnolia Tree Earth Center and the Weeksville Society, a pair of community activities in the BedfordStuyvesant district. The Magnolia Tree Earth Center, first known about eight years ago for having rescued a beautiful magnolia threatened by urban renewal, is renovating three brownstones as a neighborhood horticulturalenvironmental center. The Weeksville Society, named for the 19thcentury AfroAmerican community in Brooklyn, is developing the only three remaining Weeksville buildings (official landmarks) as a museum of AfroAmerican history. Joining Mr. Seeger at the concert will be the Carriacou Big Drum Nation Dance Troupe, performers of late 18thcentury West Indian dances. Tickets are $10, $8, $6 and $4, available at the box office, at Bloomingdale's, Broadway's Edison Theater and Chargit (call 2397177). Information: 6364100.

title: Rhodesian Party Backs Smith Plan On Nation's Future
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 27 (AP)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith won the backing today of his governing party, the Rhodesian Front, for a plan that he said would end racial discrimination and in two years set up black majority rule.

title: Proliferation Oversell
description: LONDON  For the last two years or so, America has rediscovered the problem of nuclear proliferation, and in the Presidential election campaign it figured as the only concrete foreign policy prdposal of the successful candidate. This new attention has largely been healthy and productive. There is a greater appreciation of the limits of the nonproliferation treaty. And there are new and fresh attempts to stop, or at least to slow down, the dynamics of the spread of nuclear technology.

title: Ban on Women Priests Is Explained
description: ROME, Jan. 27 (UPI)The Vatican, affirming the refusal of the Roman Catholic Church to ordain women as priests, said today that they could not qualify because Jesus was a man and His representatives on earth must have a natural resemblance to him.

title: Chesimard Jurors Picked
description: Jury selection continued in the New Brunswick murder trial of Joanne Chesimard as 12 jurors were retained in preliminary screening process.

title: When Yusef Lateef Plays, Please Don't Call It Jazz
description: One of his albums is Gentle Giant, and that's an accurate description of Yusef Lateef. who plays alto and tenor saxophones, bassoon, oboe, flute, argul, shanni and bamboo flute, who has a doctorate in education, who teaches, writes, paints and who doesn't like to have the type of music he plays called jazz.

title: British Court Rules on Side of Individual Liberties
description: LONDON, Jan. 27A high British court broke new constitutional ground today in ruling that aggrieved private citizens were free to appear before it even when the Government's highest legal officer did not want them to.

title: Who Owns Maine?
description: Nobody expects twothirds of Maine to be given back to the Indians, but a lawsuit with that objective is causing officials of the state serious concern all the sameand with good reason.

title: Union Finds Miami Hotels Free to Reject Strikers
description: MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP)The contract that ended a threeweek hotel employee strike does not require hotel owners to rehire striking union members, a top union official said

title: Chirac, Rebuffing Giscard, Won't Quit Paris Race
description: PARIS, Jan. 27In open defiance of the will of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac bluntly rejected today a Presidential attempt to persuade him to withdraw as candidate for Mayor of Paris.

title: Restaurants
description: FEW ADDITIONS to the local scene have been so outright an affirmation of confidence in New York City's future as Windows on the World, the stunning and lavish restaurant atop the north tower of the World Trade Center. Open barely nine months, it has had such a steady backlog of reservations (one month in advance for weekday dinners and six to eight weeks ahead for weekend evenings) that it seemed time to take a second look.

title: Seatrain to Build Barges
description: The Seatrain Shipbuilding Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Seatrain Lines, said it had been awarded a contract from the Union Carbide Corporation to construct two ocean barges. The contract is valued at about $10 million. Delivery of the vessels is scheduled for the first and third quarters of 1978.

title: Move Is Begun in Senate to Replace Electoral College With Direct Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The recurrent campaign to replace the Electoral College with direct popular choice of the President was revived in the Senate today, with the prospects for success brighter than ever before.

title: Virginia Senate Rejects Equal Rights Amendment
description: RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 27 (UPI)The Virginia Senate narrowly rejected the equal rights amendment today, leaving the measure still three states short of ratification.

title: McKay Elected to Succeed Sikes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI)House Democrats today elected Representative Gunn McKay of Utah, to succeed Robert L. F. Sikes of Florida, who was ousted yesterday as chairman of the Military Construction subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee. The Democratic caucus, as expected, elevated Mr. McKay to the position by a vote of 157 to 2.

title: CARTER AIDES TO PLAN STUDY ON DESERTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Several of President Carter's key advisers are expected to meet next week to formulate guidelines for a study of how to handle the cases of military deserters of the Vietnam war era and other veterans who received lessthanhonorable discharges.

title: Full Use of Resources Produces Success for Beach Channel High
description: The classroom curriculum at Beach Channel High School In Queens is based on the maine resources that surround the school, which overlooks Jamaica Bay In Rockaway. The basketball team at the school is taking advantage of the athletic resources on the Rockaway Peninsula and has won 15 of its 16 games this season, including all 10 in the Public Schools Athletic League, Queens Division H. Two years ago, a dreadful 010 wonlost record inaugurated the basketball program at the school. Last season, the players from that 010 team became a 74 club with a playoff berth. This season, most of the same players again have brought the Dolphins to the surface.

title: Decrease Reported In the Prisoners Held A Year Before Trial
description: There has been a sharp decrease in the number of defendants who have been detained in jail for more than a year while awaiting trial, the statewide administrative judge said yesterday. But the judge, Richard J. Bartlett, said that while good progress had been made, the goal established by his office that no defendant be detained in jail for more than a year before coming to trial had not been met.

title: King Solomon With a Stopwatch
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board announced yesterday that in the last race on the last program of Roosevelt Raceway's summer meeting last July 17, a 4yearold pacer named Main Morris went a mile in 1 minute 59 3/5 seconds. This may strike some as a matter of less than cosmic significance, and it does seem that the N.Y.S.R. & W.B. took its own sweet time about making the announcement. If a dumb animal can get his end of the job done in less than two minutes, a smart clocker shouldn't need six months to decide how fast the horse was going. However, there is more to this than meets the eye, as Bertram D. Sarafan noted in a seven page opinion. It may not stretching the point to suggest that a touch of Solomonic wisdom was called for. When the first horse crosses the starting line at Roosevelt, breaks a beam of light that activates the Visumatic Timer, which records the time for each quartermile to the finish. Harness Rule 4110.1 requires that a guy with a stopwatch clock each race manually to check the accuracy of the electrical timer. Roosevelt also operates a second electrical timer to check up on the first, and as a further check the Visumatic operator times two or three races with his stopwatch.

title: ABSENTEEISM CALLED NO CAUSE FOR ALARM
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26Despite a reported high rate of absenteeism in at least seven counties as a result of an outbreak of influenza, state health officials said today there was no cause for alarm.

title: Conservative Start of Political Commitment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  President Carter today presented the Congress and the nation with a modest $31.3 billion package of stimulatory economic measures, whose size and composition has been influenced by a combination of conservative instincts and political calculations. The package will be worth $15.5 billion in the current year, a figure clearly at the bottom of the range of possible measures discussed over the past few weeks by those many private economists, politicians and businessmen who believed that some additional stimulus was needed.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 28, 1977

title: ExAide Says Korvette Dismissed Him for Refusal to Work Sundays
description: A former executive of the Korvette department stores has filed charges of religious discrimination against the retail chain, alleging he was dismissed because of his refusal to work on Sundays.

title: Investment Bankers Ask Fiscal Monitor For New York City
description: Investment bankers who underwrite municipal bonds are telling the New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, that they agree with the leading commercial banks in the city on the necessity of an outside agency to monitor New York's finances in order to market the city's bonds in the future.

title: Penguins Triumph at the Garden
description: The trouble with the Rangers is that they play worse at Madison Square Garden than the other team does.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE journey to the northernmost reaches of Manhattan each year to visit the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park, but only a handful make it across Dyckman Street to Inwood Hill Park, a virtual wilderness in the city.

title: Film Forum: Childhood Animated
description: THE CANADIAN ANIMATOR Caroline Leaf has devised a technique in which lines have a dreamy smudginess and seem to float out of one another. The effect is half comical, half poetic, and Miss Leaf used it triumphantly in a short film about the love of an owl for a duck, shown last year at the Film Forum.

title: People in Sports
description: In another attempt to strengthen their frontline, the New York Nets picked up Mike Bantom yesterday from the Seattle SuperSonics. The 6foot9inch, 210pound Bantom, who played college basketball at St. Joseph's in Philadelphia, is in his fourth season in the National Basketball Association.

title: Antiques
description: AMAJOR HIGHLIGHT last weekend, when the New York antiques world was busier than at any time in memory, was the third annual World Antiques and Fine Arts Market Conference at. the Pierre Hotel. Thirteen experts discussed sotne of the hottest topics in the business today: how to detect fakes, how far restoration on works of art should go, how much insurance is advisable to protect art works and how tax reform affects gifts of art and antiques. The event was also used to organize a treasure hunt

title: Article 2  No Title
description: and seek to involve the country's major companies in a drive to increase job and training opportunities for veterans.

title: 2 Englishwomen Gain
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 27 (UPI) Two Englishwomen eliminated two Californians today as topseeded Virginia Wade and eighthseeded Sue Barker advanced to the quarterfinal round of a $100,000 Virginia Slims tournament.

title: Carter and Byrd Vie to Get Laughs at Reception
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  An emerging rivalry between two Democrats new to the national spotlight, President Carter and Senator Robert C. Byrd, got a cheering, laughing reception from 1,200 members and guests of the Washington Press Club last night.

title: Crafts Show Spans the Generations
OHIO SCHOOLS CLOSE
description: The twoweekold naturalgas crisis bit more deeply for millions of Americans yesterday as the effects of the bitter, persistent cold were forcing shutdowns of stores and factories in Pennsylvania and causing school closings there and in Ohio, new layoffs for hundreds of thousands of people in a dozen states and warnings of possible further hardships.

title: Second Person Indicted In Edgar Smith Case
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 27 (UPI)A county, grand jury has returned a sealed indictment in the kidnapping for which former inmate of New Jersey's Death Row, Edgar Robert Smith, is to stand trial next month.

title: Discounts on Vehicles Set for G.M. Employees
description: DETROIT, Jan. 27In an effort to increase sales, the General Motors Corporation announced today a program whereby its 500,000 hourly employees and retiress in the United States would be able to receive cash refunds ranging from $200 to $500 on the purchase of new vehicles.

title: 60's Role of. State Dept. Appointee In Surveillance to Be Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27When Warren M. Christopher goes before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for confirmation hearings as Deputy Secretary of State, Senator Jacob K. Javits says he intends to raise the question of Mr. Christopher's role. in the Government's surveillance of citizens political activity in the late 1960's.

title: Part of Iranian Force Withdrawn From Oman
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 27 (AP)Iran is withdrawing some of its troops from Oman, a Government spokesman said today.

title: China Hopes to Develop Tibet Area
description: PEKING, Jan. 27 (Reuters)Chinese scientists who have completed a survey of the north Tibetan plateau say their data indicate that the vast, largely uninhabited region can be developed for agriculture and industry, according to Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency. A Hsinhua dispatch said the survey had proved foreign experts wrong in writing off the region as barren.

title: Madrid's March to Democracy Turns Bloody as Right Fights Back
description: MADRID, Jan. 27The Spanish political landscape has been marked by acts of violence, from the right and from the left, in the 14 months since Franco died. According to one count, there have been 48 political deaths since the disappearance of the Caudillo. who left an ambiguous legacy that itself was not a model of peacefulness. But the bloodiness and provocativeness of this week's violence the murder of a 19yearold leftist student, the kidnapping of a prominent general, the assassination of five Communists in a Madrid labor officehave shaken the Spanish political establishment more than at any time since Franco's death.

title: YOUNG NOTES THE PITFALLS IN TALKING ABOUT VIETNAM
description: SEWANEE, Tenn., Jan. 27 (AP)The new American representative to the United Nations, Andrew Young, suggested tonight that the Carter Administration might not have been happy with his stand on normalizing relations with Vietnam.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Fed Reports Money Supply Off And Loans to Business Decline
description: The nation's money supply declined in the week ended Jan. 19, according to data released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: A Price Jump in Sable Makes Queen of Furs Even More Regal
Vance Hints Better Ties If Cuba Frees Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP)Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance says the Carter Administration would regard the release of political prisoners by Cuba as an indication that it is seriously interested in restoring relations with the United States, according to testimony released today.

title: Article 4  No Title
Palmateer Excels in 2to1 Victory
Dow Off 3.99 as Selling Pressure Is Focused on Glamour Stocks
description: Selling pressure In the oncefavored glamour stocks commanded Wall Street's attention yesterday as the market generally continued to give ground.

title: $1.3 Billion Is Sought to Aid 200,000 Idle
Swiss Watch Exports Off 2.2%
description: GENEVA, Jan. 27 (UPI)Swiss watch exports dropped 2.2 percent in 1976 as competition increased from cheaper electronic timepieces made in the United States and Japan. Swiss exports amounted to $1.22 billion, against $1.25 billion in 1975, the Swiss Watchmaking Federation said.

title: Croatian Advocates In Hijacking to Get A Trial in Brooklyn
description: The five Croatian nationalists who have been accused of air piracy involving the hijacking of an airliner and the killing of a police officer last September can be prosecuted in Brooklyn, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday, reversing a lowercourt ruling.

title: State Energy Chief Quits, Assailing Byrne's Ideas And Lack of Consultation
description: TRENTON, Jan. 27 (UPI)Burt Ross unexpectedly resigned yesterday as New Jersey's energy czar, categorizing Governor Byrne's approach to energy mattersespecially in this time of crisisas inept.

title: Bayi, Wearied by Long, Rough Trip, Arrives for Millrose Games Tonight
description: His eyes were bloodshot, his body ached, his luggage was lost, and he hadn't trained in three days.

title: Sanders and I.B.M. Reach Computer Pact
description: Sanders Associates Inc. said it had entered into an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation whereby Sanders would develop advanced computerrelated products for I.B.M. and Sanders would withdraw its antitrust suit against the large computer company.

title: Who is the Originator?
description: The Appellate Division of State Su preme Court yesterday unanimously reversed a lower court decision and ordered a new trial to determine who discovered the use of monoamine oxidase inhibitor as a treatment for depression'. The lower court had ruled in favor of Dr. Nathan S. Kline, director of research at Rockland State Hospital, who was awarded the Albert Lasker Foundation Award and a $10,000 honorarium for its discovery in 1964. Dr. John C. Saunders has challenged the award, on the ground that the idea was originally his.

title: Shelley's The Cenci Is Revived
description: Stage rarities are not really that rare on the New York stage. The Bicentennial year turned up a number of Early American plays, and not too long ago, Broadway was host to Dion Boucicault's London Assurance and William Gillette's old chestnut, Sherlock Holmes. But tonight the Jean Cocteau Repertory will unveil a genuine rarity at the Bouwerie Lane Theater when it presents Percy Bysshe Shelley's verse drama The Cenci. The Cocteau people believe that there has never been a major production of it in New York.

title: Retail Store Sales Increase 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail store sales last week were an estimated $12.62 billion, up 7 percent from last year's level off $11.82 billion. Department store sales were about $964 million, up 12 percent from the yearearlier total of $859 million.

title: RESULTS
description: (OTB Payoffs subject to 5% municipal surtax)

title: Jersey Bank's Sue to Recover Funds Lent to Byrne Campaign
description: TRENTON, Jan. 27 (UPI)Five of New Jersey's largest banks have filed suit to recover $185,000 lent to the 1973 campaign of Governor byrne.

title: The U. N. Today
Louisiana Labor Leader Convicted
description: GRETNA, La., Jan. 27 (UPI)A Louisiana labor leader, convicted of planning a riot at a Lake Charles chemical plant, faces 22 years in prison and another trial on a manslaughter charge. Donald Lovett was found guilty yesterday on charges of aggravated damage to property and criminal conspiracy. He will be sentenced Feb. 2. Mr. Lovett, business manager for the Southwest Louisiana Building and Construction Trades Council, was accused of planning the Jan. 15, 1976, attack on the Jupiter Chemical Company.

title: WallaceMurray Seeks Hydrometals Stock
description: The WallaceMurray Corporation announced that it was offering $20 for any common shares of Hydrometals Inc. and $31.875 a share for the preferred shares. The total outlay, if all shares are tendered, would come to $48.3 million.

title: Article 3  No Title
Rail Freight Traffic Declines 11.7%
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Rate of Drop in Supplies Of Heating Oil Reported As Faster Than Normal
Anna M. Perper Is Wed to Irving L. Straus
description: Anna Meiranz Perper and. Irving Lehman Straus, both of New York, were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's brother and sisterinlaw, Mr. and Mrs. R. Peter Straus of Riverdale, the. Bronx.

title: WNEWTV Staging AllOut Promotion
description: On Monday in a fullpage newspaper ad WNEWTV (Channel 5) disclosed its new logotype that includes The choice. The following day a full page ad from WCBSTV (Channel 2) used the headline The viewers choice.

title: Theater: Musical Chairs With the Switch Between Curtains
description: CHANGING THE SET in full view of the audience is almost stage convention nowadays. But in the T. Schreiber Theater's production of Curtains by the British playwright Tom Mallin, it is disastrous.

title: Sunday
description: What could be lovelier than chamber music by candlelight? Chamber music by candlelight with champagneWhich is what they'll have Sunday night at 7:30 at the exquisite Burden Mansion, 7 East 91st Street. L'Ensemble, a sixyearold chamber group of toplevel professionals, will give a Russian programRachmaninoff and Tchaikovskyin the landmark building's rococo ballroom (which is reached via one of the most elegant marble stairways in town). Admission is $5 ($3 for the elderly). One more nice touch: The players join the audience during intermission for conversation and champagne (served by hostesses dressed as cossacks). Information: 7990625.

title: BRITISH NORTH SEA OUTPUT OF OIL IN 76 SHORT OF GOAL
description: LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP)Oil production from the British sector of the North Sea last year fell below expectations to about 12 million tons, the Energy Department said today.

title: Community Society Ousting Head
Yamani Says Talks Loom On Ending Dual Oil Price
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 26Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said today that individual talks would start soon with other oilproducing countries to seek an agreement that would end the twotier pricing system established in December.

title: Market Place
description: There are signs of growing frustration in stockholder circles over recent instances of management refusal to pass merger offers along.

title: Goodman Says City Hall Derailed Key Elements of Charter Revision
description: In a likely warmup for the mayoral campaign, State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the prospective Republican candidate, charged yesterday that the Beame administration had undermined key elements of the New York City Charter revision approved by the voters in 1975.

title: African Scholars at Lagos: A Sense of Disillusion
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 27A delegate from the tiny West African country of Gambia took the floor and suggested that a resolution be passed demanding total amnesty for all imprisoned African intellectuals. He was loudly applauded, but no such resolution was offered.

title: The Met's New Wotan Is a Mensch
description: Wotan may be the king of the gods. but he's just another wayward husband to Fricka, in Wagner's Die Walktire, which returns to the Metropolitan Opera tonight. Offstage, it's quite another matter.

title: Banks Deny Coercing City on AffirmativeAction Plan
description: Major banks in New York City denied charges yesterday that they were demanding in exchange for handling city banking that the city drop its affirmative action program requiring written commitments from anyone doing business with the city that an equitable share of their jobs go to minorities and women.

title: MunariMaiga Team Leads at Monte Carlo
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 27 (AP)Sandro Munari and Silvio Maiga of Italy, driving Lancia Stratos, retained their easy domination of the 45th Monte Carlo rally tonight as 60 crews started the final night of mountain speed trials. The Italian pair led what had become a private rally for the giant Fiat group, whose productsLancia, Fiat and Seatheld all the top places.

title: Flyers 2, Blues 0
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27 (AP)Ross Lonsberry rebounded Gary Dornhoefer's shot into the net at 12:35 of the opening period and helped the Philadelphia Flyers pin a 20 defeat on the St. Louis Blues in a tightchecking N H.L. game tonight.

title: Peking Units Quell Unrest In a Nearby City
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 27China has disclosed that army troops sent to the troubled city of Paoting near Peking have rounded up weapons, stopped fighting and conducted public trials.

title: Shearson Withdraws Its Offer to Orion
description: Shearson Hayden Stone Inc withdrew its offer yesterday to merge with the Orion Capital Corporation after Orion's directors unanimously rejected the proposal put forward by the investment firm.

title: Hopelessness
Profits Scoreboard
description: (Some of Major Corporations Reporting Yesterday)

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Federal Grand Jury Investigating Similar Bids for Processing Grain
description: A Federal grand Jury in Wichita, Kan., is investigating the possible submission of identical bids to the Federal Government by grain milling and processing companies.

title: Queens Man Killed on 1.80
description: BELLEFONTE, Pa., Jan. 27 (AP)A Queens man was killed today when his car skidded under a tractortrailer rig that had jackknifed on 180 near this Centre County community. He was Robert Marshall, 22 years old, of Flushing.

title: Professor Causes Furor by Saying  Nazi Slaying of Jews Is a Myth
description: EVANSTON, III., Jan 27A book by a Northwestern University professor that says the Nazi extermination of European Jews was nothing more than a Zionistinspired myth has caused a storm of campus and community protest and has embarrassed university administrators.

title: Citizens Parley Looks to Carter For Responsive Foreign Policy
description: Mrs. Roseline Gussman calls herself a dumb housewife from Oklahoma, but she talks knowledgeably about United States foreign policy.. Mrs. Joanne Cumming's dazzling smile frequently brightens the society magazines, but she is also a student of international affairs. Jeff Enderveit, the 34yearold president of a $100 million conglomerate, is sometimes known as the boy wonder.

title: Water Rationing Ordered North of San Francisco
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Jan, 27 (UPI) Because of California's drought, 169,000 people who live across the Golden Gate Bridge from San Francisco will be restricted to an average 47 gallons of water a day, half the current level of use. Commercial users must reduce their consumption by 52 percent.

title: Meadowlands Drivers
Czechs Are Expected to Deport Some of Their Leading Dissidents
description: PRAGUE. Jan. 27Czechoslovakia appeared to be moving today toward expelling some humanrights activists as four dissidents reportedly were asked to appear at the passport and visa office here tomorrow.

title: Dollar Declines Slightly in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 27 (UPI)The dollar closed slightly lower on most European money markets today in what dealers said was essentially a continuation of yesterday's trading.

title: U.S. CAUTIONS SOVIET ON SAKHAROV CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The State Department said today that if the Soviet Union tried to silence Andrei D. Sakharov. the political dissident, it would be in conflict with accepted international standards of human rights.

title: HorseLovers Revitalize State Agriculture
description: CHERRY HILL, Jan. 27The phone never rings when I'm on a horse, Addison G. Bradley said today.

title: Letters
description: Pardon: Disgraceful Act of Conscience

title: Meadowlands Results
Carter Aides Describe $31 Million Package
Cavs Win As Knicks Fold, 113111
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 27By making three pressure baskets in the final two minutes the Cleveland Cavalierswho trailed by 7 points with 4 minutes to playmanaged to beat the New York Knicks, 113111, tonight before a vocal crowd of 15,194 at the Coliseuni.

title: Pedestrian Mall on Times Square Will Be Tested With U.S. Funds
description: New York City has won a $500,000 grant from the Federal Government to create an experimental pedestrian mall in Times Square this summer that would become permanent if it proved successful.

title: BYRNE ISSUES ORDER
description: Confronted by dwindling naturalgas supplies and continuing bitterly cold weather, the Governors of New York and New Jersey declared states of emergency yesterday to cope with the worsening energy crisis.

title: Dunklee's Team Takes Ski Relay
description: LYNDONVILLE, Vt., Jan. 27 (AP)Stan Dunklee had the fastest lap time and led his Eastern team to victory day in the men's 30kilometer relay, and Bill Koch brought his team from eighth after two laps to a fifthplace finish in the national crosscountry ski championships.

title: GULF OIL PROFITS UP 28.2% IN 4TH PERIOD
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, one of the largest international petroleum companies, achieved a 28.2 percent Increase in fourthquarter profits. The results reported yesterday for the quarter and full year 1976 were in line those of most major oil companies.

title: Thruway Deaths Down
description: The Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway experienced its second lowest fatality rate last year since the 559mile system went into full operation in 1960. Fortynine deaths in 38 fatal accidents were recorded in 1976, a rate of 1.17 fatalities for each 100 million miles traveled. Gerald Cummins, chairman of the Thruway Authority, attributed the safety record to medianguide railing and other safety features and to enforcement of the nationwide 55mileanhour speed limit.

title: Bridge:
description: One might suppose that tournament victories are a product of skill with a small admixture of luck. But there is a third factor, an unobtrusive one that may tip the scales: the conditions of contest.

title: Look, Ma, No Egos
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Nothing seems to fascinate Washington more than the institutional conflicts between the White House and the Congress, and the personal struggles for influence and power among members of the Cabinet and the White House staff.

title: Art People
description: IT MAY NOT be your idea of Lucullan, but a farout feast will be spread today and tomorrow at the 112 Workshop (112 Greene Street, between Prince and Spring), the bareboards experimental space in SoHo partly supported by national and New York State endowment money.

title: Cold Likely to Stay In East and Midwest
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP)The National Weather Service says the harshest winter in at least five years shows no signs of releasing its frigid grip on the Eastern and Midwestern sections of the United States during the next two weeks.

title: ENTRIES
description: Horses listed in order of Post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Zender, Kite Are Tied at 65 For Golf Lead
TOP WEEKEND FILMS
description: FRIDAY

title: 2 Victories for Mollin
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Financial Writers President
description: Margaret A. Klein, financial services editor of Reuters North America, has been elected president of the New York Financial Writers Association, the first woman to hold this post. She succeeds Stanley D. Rosenberg, editor of Munifacts News Wire Service.

title: Art: A New Cast In Plaster by Segal
Commodity Price Index Increases 3.4 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 211.6 from 208.2 last week.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 27, 1977

title: Guggenheim Stages an Ensor Carnival
description: AS OF 11 this morning; the Belgian painter James Ensor (18601949) will be the hero a fullscale retrospective (paintings, drawings, prints113 items in all) at the Guggenheim Museum. Once again the Guggenheim has concerned itself with a European reputation that is not yet dead from overexposure and once again has given us the materials we need to make up our minds.

title: Energy Complaint Number
description: The Public Service Commission set up a tollfree telephone number last night to receive complaints on emergency situations arising over the allocation of limited gas supplies. The number is 8003423726.

title: Prague Seems Unfazed by Criticism of Its HumanRights Practices
description: BELGRADE, Jan. 27Mounting criticism of civilrights proponents at home and abroad seems unlikely to faze Czechoslovakia's leaders, who evidently feel that their political and economic base is secure and that Soviet backing remains strong.

title: Health Official Guilty
description: The president of the New Jersey Association of Health Care Facilities pleaded guilty to bilking the Medicaid program of about $40,000. The official, Richard F. Grosso, 46 years old, of Wayne, admitted filing a false cost study on behalf of the Lakeview Convalescent Center in ayne for Medicaid reimbursement by the Federal and state government for nursing home care from 1972 through 1975. Mr. Grosso was the principal shareholder and administrator of Lakeview.

title: Broadway
description: IF YOU CAN BELIEVE an English girls school, where the older girls discover that the headmistress is really a white slaver, fattening them all for shipment, and the younger girls are solemnly building .a BumpaCar Joy Ride for their history class, then you can believe The Utter Glory of Morrissey Hall. It is a musical, and Arthur Whitelaw, the producer, hopes to have it here by Oct. 1. The director will be Nagle Jackson, and the book, music and lyrics will be by Clark Gesner, Who once did the music and lyrics, for You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown. That was also produced by Mr, Whitelaw, and it was a great success. Mr. Whitelaw, in fact, has just gotten back from Paris, where he put together a company to do the musical there.

title: Investment Bankers Ask Fiscal Monitor For New York City
description: Investment bankers who underwrite municipal bonds are telling the New York City Comptroller, Harrison .J. Goldin; that they agree with the leading commercial banks in the city on the necessity of an outside agency to monitor New York's finances to market the city's bond; in the future.

title: Carter Aides Describe $31 Billion Package
Robert W. Molloy Dies
description: Robert Molloy, novelist, translator and newspaperman, died, yesterday at Bergen Pines Hospital, Paramus, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived in Paramus.

title: What Ever Happened To India's Great Adventure?
description: It was supposed to be a great adventure. Here was India, newly free of the British Raj, its downtrodden millions eager for a better lifea country with energy, with resources, most of all with the resolve to change from an impoverished, underdeveloped land into a nation of, if not prosperity like its Western counterparts, at least of economic stability, a land whose, people did not starve and who had decent housing.

title: Manhattan Orchestra To Play Stravinsky Work
description: Charles Wuorinen will conduct the Manhattan Orchestra at 8 P.M. tonight at the Manhattan School of Music in a program that will include Reliquary, a work based on the last sketches and fragments left by Igor Stravinsky. The premiere of the work, which was commissioned jointly by the Ojai Festival and the Buffalo Philharmonic, was performed in Ojai, Japan, in 1975.

title: G.T.E. Apparently Bribed City Officials, S.E.C. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation apparently bribed unidentified New York City officials from 1971 to 1973 to obtain contracts to supply equipment, a complaint filed against the company by the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

title: Transition Aide Expected Choice To Head E.P.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  President Carter will soon announce, according to Administration Sources, the appointment of Douglas Costle as adminstrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Roots, ABC's 12hour adaptation of Alex Haley's book, continues to be this week's most ambitious presentation, coming to a conclusion with its eighth consecutive daily episode Sunday at 9 P.M. As the dramatized black family moves on to its own piece of land in Tennessee, in the decade after the Civil War, Mr. Haley walks toward the camera to summarize briefly the real family's history that led to his own birth in Henning, Tenn.

title: Estelle Parsons Gets Into the Act
description: Someone is practicing a scale in the foyer. It is part belllike soprano, part firesiren wail. The vocalist, a small, rotindrfaced woman in her 40's, waits by the door. She is possessed, as Clive Barnes once put it, of a certain battared friendly charm. Her anklelength, flowered cotton skirt is faded and her lavender Tshirt is full of discreet but hardly unnoticable holes.

title: Magazine Is Banned Over Photo of Nude
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ore., Jan. 27 (AP)A special issue of Life magazine on the American woman has been banned from use as a high school text by the school board because it contains a photograph of a nude woman.

title: INDUSTRIAL CONSUMPTION OF SILVER ROSE 6% IN '76
description: Industrial consumption of silver in the United States rose by 6 percent in 1976 to an estimated 167.5 million ounces. according to the 61st annual review of the silver market released yesterday by Handy & Harman. This was the first increase in industrial usage since 1973 when such consumption hit a record high of 196.4 million ounces.

title: Sandman Backs Bateman
description: Former Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., a Republican, said he would support State Senator Raymond H. Bateman for the G.O.P. nomination for governor. Senator Bateman, who lives in Somerville, is one of two major candidates in the race this year. The other is Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean of Livingston.

title: Places Kids Can Take Parents to
15 BIDDERS SUCCESSFUL IN I.M.F. GOLD AUCTION
description: WASHINGTON, JAN. 27 (Reuters)The International Monetary Fund said 15 banks and dealers submitted successful bids at the auction yesterday of 780,000 ounces of gold.

title: Diligent, if Routine, Police Work Yields Suspect in Rape and Murder
description: The day after 73yearold Mary Kain was raped and murdered in her bed in the West Brighton Houses on Staten Island, detectives working on the case were raking through the garbage in the incinerator room. At about noon, a pair of bloodstained men's shoes came tumbling down the chute.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
Aqueduct Jockeys
description: * Apprentice.

title: Indonesia Investigating Report Aides Were Bribed
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 27 (Reuters) The Government is investigating a report that millions of dollars in bribes were paid to Indonesian officials in connection with a multimilliondollar domestic satellite system, a Communications Ministry spokesman said today.

title: 3 EXECUTIVES ARE CHARGED ON KICKBACKS AT HARTZ
description: A Federal grand jury in Manhattan indicted three business executives yesterday on charges that they had participated in a scheme involving secret kickbacks to defraud the Hartz Mountain Corporation.

title: G.E., With Record Profits, Favors Program to Stimulate Economy
description: A month after the General Electric Company consummated the largest merger in United States history, the company's chairman, Reginald H. Jones, appeared at a news conference in New York yesterday to announce record profits and support for, a program of economic stimulation.

title: Reports of Nearby Skiing Conditions
description: (Reports supplled by resort owners.)

title: Legion Won't Expel Carter
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 27 (UPI)The American Legion's national organization is not trying to expel President Carter from membership, William J. Rogers, Commander, said today.

title: Du Pont to Expand Plastics Plant
description: E.
