title: A London Scheme For Coping With Cars
Opera: Leinsdorf Raises Walkure to High Level
description: Wagner's Die Walkre returned to the Metropolitan Opera repertory Friday night, with some changes. This is the production originally conceived by Herbert von Karajan, and he did conduct Walkre and Das Rheingold in New York, but he never did finish the cycle. Nobody admired this Ring concept very much. It was dark, it had all the neoBayreuth clichs, complete with open and closed turntable, and it posed as many problems as it attempted to solve.

title: The Verdict in the Classroom
description: DR. SAMUEL H. SHEPPARD, who was convicted in 1954 of seconddegree murder in the death of his wife and served 10 years in an Ohio State prison, was acquitted of that charge last week at Northport High School.

title: Depoliticizing Federal Judgeships
description: It appears that the idea of nonpartisan and merit selection of Federal judges has reached its time. As a candidate, President Carter expressed the clear intention to diminish the role of politics in the selection process. Attorney General Bell has gone further and talked about the specific mechanismsome kind of state commissions for screening judicial prospects.

title: Busting Loose, Code R And Other Linoleum
description: It was a bloodless Sunday and, having with a patriotic spasm turned down our igloo's thermostat, we sat in shawls, consuming rotgut and beef jerky, watching the real television, The real television reminds us of discrepancies. The false television is mere distraction.

title: Home Clinic
Rhode Island Driver Sights Camel
Lawyer Is Indicted On Perjury Counts For '75 Testimony
description: A prominent North Carolina lawyer has been charged in Manhattan with perjury involving his testimony in a 1975 narcotics trial that ended in the acquittal of 13 defendants, including three men who were reputedly among the top narcotics dealers in New York City.

title: Criminals At Large
description: In POUR THE HEMLOCK (Random House, $7.95), A. J. Russell comes up with an interesting ideaespionage by psychological profile. In this kind of psychiatric spying, a team of experts gets into a man's mind  Khrushchev, Mao, whoever  on the basis of whatever is known about him. The idea is to determine how he will act under specific conditions. Russell postulates that this department was set up in the Kennedy Administration and is responsible to the President alone.

title: What's Doing in TUNISIA
description: LAND OF THE LOTUSEATERS  Tunisia's island of Djerba is said to have been the dwelling place of the Lotophagoi who, in Homer's Odyssey, lived a life of dreamy indolenceinduced by eating the fruit of the lotus tree. According to the tale, the sailors with Odysseus who sampled the fruit had no desire to return home, and presentday visitors to Tunlsia have been known to manifest the same symptoms after breathing the perfumed air of this northernmost country in Africa. Tunisia. a little larger than Florida, has hundreds of miles of Mediterranean beaches, magnificent ruins, colorful souks, isolated oases plus vast stretches of Sahara in the south. To this add modern attractions that the allseeing blind Homer could not have dreamed of: strings of airconditioned resorts fringing the shores of his winedark sea and resort hotels with swimming pools in the desert. Moreover, Tunisia today possesses a most favorable atmosphere for tourists: its 5.7 million people seem to bear no resentment against Westerners, there is practically no crime, and the country is politically stable and gives every evidence of remaining soat least as long as Habib Bourguiba. Tunisia's Presidentforlife, lives on.

title: W.H.O. to Cut Staff in Shift of Goals
description: GENEVA, Jan. 29The World Health Organization, in a major policy change imposed by the emerging countries of the third world, has begun to slash its staff and to divert the resulting savings to programs aimed at narrowing the health gap between the industrialized and developing countries.

title: In Taiwan, a Will to Compete
Saudis' Influence Is Growing
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 27Quietly but with increasing selfconfidence, Saudi Arabia is emerging as the dominant force in Middle East politics and probably the key power on the Arab side in future Israeli negotiations.

title: Helen Marie McNally And Richard Tufaro, Lawyer, Will Marry
description: Helen Duffy McNally of Fort Lauderdale. Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Helen Marie McNally, to Richard Chase Tufaro, son of Mrs. Frank P. Tufaro of Hartsdale, N.Y.. and the late Mr. Tufaro. A June wedding is planned.

title: Unions Spent Million for CarterMondale Ticket
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Labor unions, which are prohibited by law from making direct campaign contributions to candidates, spent more than $1 million last year to urge their members to vote for Jimmy Carter and Walter F. Mondale.

title: Drought Emergency in Colorado
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)President Carter today declared an emergency for Colorado because of the impact of a severe drought. The action will permit use of Federal funds in relief and recovery efforts.

title: Robert Allen Fiance Of Katheen Malloy
description: Mr. and Mrs. William P. Malloy of Los Angeles have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Patricia Malloy, to Robert Montgomery Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs Paul M. Allen of Long Island City. Queens.

title: For young readers
description: Unlike standard histories of American art, The Pantheon Story of American Art does not begin with the colonial limners, but with native American Indian art. This is a sure way to catch the attention of a young audience whose tastes are formed not so much by mu. seums as by movies and TV, which mythologize the cowboys and Indians whose images ere prominent, perhaps excessively prominent, in this survey.

title: Living With a Highway Is an Acquired Taste
description: Walter J. Zielenski Jr. lives next to the Long Island Expressway because 12 years ago his wife fell in love with pink shutters. He likes it there.

title: City's Island Debts
In Bangkok, Find A Street of Gold
description: BANGKOK, Thailand  Yaowaral Road isn't paved with goldit's lined with it.

title: Larry Houts Is Fiance Of Susan E. MacIntosh
description: Dr. John Aubrey MacIntosh, professor of business administration (marketing and transportation) at New York City Community College. and Mrs. MacIntosh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Macintosh, to Larry Robert Houts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Franklin Houts of State College, Pa.

title: Chamber Music Is Their Meat
The I.R.S. and Its Briefcase Caper
Spain's Fascists Are Few But Bitter ...
Budget Packages:
Smart Money Is Playing It Safe
description: Invest! exclaimed Maria Grazia Conti, a young civil servant from Siena, Italy. I'd much rather redecorate my home now. In just a year, the furniture I bought has almost doubled in price. This is the best investment I can think of.

title: Realty News
description: The Chrysler Building, faced with expensive rehabilitation work and sizable vacancies, is shedding its layers of ownership.

title: Rising Total of Absentee Workers Is Costing New York City Dearly
description: A growing number of New York City police and corrections officers, firemen and sanitation workers have been reporting sick, particularly on days. just before or after their normal time off, a trend that the Hearne administration says is costing the city millions of dollars in lost productivity.

title: Spoilage and Rats Ravage Crops, Too
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.Last year the first adequate sorgham and millet crops produced after the long African drought south of the Sahara were ravaged by hordes of rodents, despite the use of pesticides and even an offer of bounties for rat tails.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I ve had the Button Moulder on my mind all week. You probably remember the Button Moulder, at least if you've spent any time the company of lbsen's Peer Gynt. The Button Moulder is the mythical chap who suddenly appears through the mists above the Norwegian fjords to claim footloose souls for his melting pot. U, for instance, a man of some promise and potential charactor has wantonly squandered his equipment over an indifferent lifetime, if he has never taken the pains to becomehimself, then onto the boil he goes, along with the world's other nonentities, to be reduced to a kind of basic stew in a process that might be described as celestial recycling. As the Button Moulder says to Peer, Gynt toward the end of that careless fellow's adventures, You were meant to be a gleaming button on the world's waistcoat, but your loop was missing; so you've got to go into the scrap heap, to be merged into the mass. Peer, of course, was wily enough to stall the apparition off until he could get back to The Girl He Left Behind Him, whose love conquered all.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Steel Shot
description: Although there is still some doubt about how many waterfowl die each year as a result of accidentally ingesting spent lead pellets from shotgun loads fired at them by millions of hunters, there seems little justification, in most areas, for continued resistance to the substitution of nontoxic steel for lead.

title: Miss Tenney, Talton Embry Are Betrothed
description: The engagement of Marguerite Sedgwick Tenney to Talton R. Embry has been announced by Judge and Mrs. Charles H. Tenney of New York and Islip, L. I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of John W. Embry of New York and the late Dorothy L. Embry.

title: What They Are Saying
Yacht Racing Union Hails Shields, 81, the Gray Fox
description: He was known as the Gray Fox of Long Island Sound. By those who invariably followed his wake across the finish line, he was considered cunning. He was also devoted. A passion of sailing drove him to a lifetime of study, a mastery of the details that can make a sailboat sing. Cornelius Shields was a winner. Although the competition ended for the most part 21 years ago with a heart attack, the 81yearold veteran of America's Cup Races and innumerable club skirmishes still allows his mind to race over tactics and game plans, if only in dreams. And last week the Gray Fox again was a winner.

title: The Tennis Clinic
description: A tennis pro was asked by one of his pupils, Do you think I'm ready to play in tournaments? The pupil, man in his 30's, had been playing only for recreation and exercise. But now he felt he might be good enough to go into serious competition, and was wondering if he should give it a try.

title: Letters
description: The Hasty and Shortsighted Coffee Boycott

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: OBERLIN, OHIO The Allen Memorial Art Museum at Oberlin College, a Renaissance palazzo out of Brunelleschi by way of Cass Gilbert and the Beaux Arts (191517), is a gem of a building for a gem of a collection. It has turned a small Ohio town into an extraordinary place.

title: P.S.C. Getting A Flurry of Calls Related to Heat
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29At 3:20 this morning, the telephone rang In a large conference room on the 19th floor of one of the towers in the otherwise nearly deserted Albany Mall. A homeowner in Astoria, Queens, related in a tense voice that it was 50 degrees inside his house and that his threemonthold son was in danger because of the cold Could anything be done?

title: Joseph Donlan Fiance Of Patricia McManus
description: Mr. and Mrs, Michael A. McManus of Delray Beach. Fla., formerly of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia M. McManus, to Joseph P. Donlan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Donlan of Glen Rock, N. J. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Dr. Toskos To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Pasquale M. Toskos of Great Neck, L I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Karen Toskos, to Dr. William Scott Robertson, son of Dr. Donald S. Robertson of Scottsdale, Ariz. and Lac Brule, Quebec, and Mrs. Peter deRopp Wood of East Quogue L.I.

title: ITALIAN REDS IN VISIT TO SOVIET DISSIDENT
Endpaper
description: By John N. Cole

title: Gloria Fremont, 62, an Organizer Of Multiple Sclerosis Society Unit
Hard Times in Saigon
description: SEATTLELetters trickle slowly out of Vietnam. Guardedly, people left in warshattered Saigon attempt to tell refugee friends and relatives now in the United States of their plight during the 20 months since Hanol assumed power.

title: Crowding: Is It Always Harmful?; No, New Behavioral Studies Indicate, There Are Times When ItMay Even Be Good
description: As one young Manhattan couple in a small apartment agreed halfjokingly the other day, living in the city may be the most effective birth control method of all. Having a baby means needing more space, said the wife, which means we can't have a baby.

title: MUSIC VIEW
Kings Conquer Knicks, 112105, On 3619 Edge in Last Period
Truckers Plan National Slowdown To Protest 55M.P.H. Speed Limit
description: ROANOKE, Va., Jan. 29Despite three years of Federal and state efforts to slow highway traffic to the 55mileanhour limit imposed by Congress in 1974, the campaign has not only failed but has also inspired a type of Prohibitionera conspiracy to flout the law.

title: Chicago and Big Cars
Diane Pesce Is Engaged To Dr. Vincent Fietti Jr.
description: Miriam Pesce of Annadale, S.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Diane Lynn Pesce, to Dr. Vincent George Fietti Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Fietti of Franklin Lakes, N.J.

title: The Cautiousness Of Tom Courtenay
description: Washington, D.C. Tom Courtenay sat in a dimly lighted restaurant in the Watergate complex, looking very illatease, like a patient in a dentist's office waiting to have root canal work. His pale blue eyes darted nervously from side to side, his lips were pursed, and he gave the impression that if his tightly controlled exterior were suddenly scratched, some inner Mount Etna might erupt.

title: Yamanin Wins at Gulfstream
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP)Heavily favored Buena Shore faded to fourth in the last eighth of a mile today as Yamanin closed with a rush to win the $63,100 Sprint ChamPionship Han. dicap at Gulfstieam.

title: Westenburg and the Search For Choral Perfection
The World
description: Continued

title: Crowd Psychology and the Stock Market
SYRIA
description: Since President HAFEZ ASSAD of the Syrian Arab Republic took power in 1970 the Syrian economy has moved forward with vigor and vitality unprecedented in the modern history of the country. Any one who visits Syria today might think he is touring a huge workshop; throughout the country one sees factories under construction, roads and bridges being built, and a new network of roads linking all cities have been constructed and many new buildings are going up. The energy and vitality of the economy are also reflected in the main port cities, of Latakia and Tartous where scores of ships have to wait for days for their turn to unload their cargoes.

title: George Hussey Jr. Weds Nancy Grace
description: Nancy Erskine Grace of Oyster Bay Cove. L.I., widow of David R. Grace, was married yesterday noon to George Hussey Jr. of Niles, Mich, president of the National Standard Company in Niles, manufacturer of wire, other metal products and machinery.

title: Duran Retains Crown, Stops Fernandez in 13th
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 29 (AP)Roberto Duran caught up with Vilomar Fernandez in the 13th round today and scored a knockout to retain his World Boxing Association lightweight crown.

title: No One Admits Worry Over L.D.C. Debt
description: WASHINGTONHow dangerous a problem is the mounting debt of the less developed countries?

title: An Exhibit in the Case for Government Reorganization
description: President Carter will probably send to Congress soon his request for authority to plan a simplified organization of the executive branch of Government. He has said thatwhatever he proposes will be subject to Congressional approval. Together, Mr. Carter and Congress will be taking on no small task, as the chart below demonstrates. It is the organization chart of the education portion of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, and education is the least of the three subjects the departmenthandles. The chart Is as drawn by the Ford Administration's Office of Management and Budget, but hi order to fit on this page, it has been reduced by approximately onethird. That has made some of the smaller type difficult to read (the boxes describe various offices and functions) and made many thin lines nearly blend into seemingly large solid ones at the bottom of the chart. In the Government original, the lines were colorcoded, which made the chart more attractive but no more comprehensible.

title: Jill Bedrick Is Married To Jonathan Paul Silver
description: Jill Susan Bedrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon I. Bedrick of Woodsburgh. L.I., was married last night to Jonathan Paul Silver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin D. Silver of Bayside, Oueens.

title: Cities Buy Compacts and Save Money
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  When the City of Columbus went on recent shopping spree for 200 new cars, it looked only at compacts.

title: Lox Is Key to a School Sale
description: SOUTH HUNTINGTON THE fare at the little red schoolhouse here used to be reading, riting and rithmetic on hardwood desks with inkwells. Soon it will be nova or lox on bagels with cream cheese.

title: Long Live the King
description: I must confess that I expected to have some good mean fun at Lyn Tornabene's expense. For the title of her biography of Clirk Gable repelled me, her gush of gratitude to ancestors, babysitters and the management of Bell Telephone set my teeth on edge and her prologue (We can eveh find a nobility in the trivia of Gable's dentutes) affected me like the prolonged scratching of a fingernail on silk. Then, skipping.to the ap pendix, I started slogging with disbelief through a psychiatric profile of Gable, plus a copy of his 1933 contract with MetroGoldwynMayer, plus graphological analysis of his handwriting, plus his last will and testament. Threethree years of research, I told myself bitterly, yet she couldn't spare an hour or so to list his 70odd screen credits? And I got set for a lead along the lines of, Blessed with such biographers, Clark Gable doesn't need oblivion. . . .

title: Janet Baker Evokes Affection Anew
Charles Cayce, Psychologist, Weds Leslie Goodman in Rye
description: Leslie Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Goodman of White Plains and Amagansett, L. I., was married yesterday to Dr. Charles Thomas Cayce, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Lynn Cayce of Virginia Beach, Va.

title: Beame Finds Himself Back At the Brink
description: A sadly familiar script is being reenacted in the New York City financial crisis. For one thing, crisis appears to be the appropriate word: The city must go into court Thursday to say how it plans to pay $1 billion, relatively quickly, to creditors, and right now it has nothing to say.

title: Army Six Drops First
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Jan. 29 (AP)  Robin Robideaux scored two powerplay goals and added an assist last night as Air Force dealt Army its first college hockey defeat of the season after 13 victories, 63. Mike Smellie put Air Force, 134 for the season, on the scoreboard first with a goal midway through the first period.

title: This Week in Sports
description: James Papreck of Northbrook, Ill., heads the field of 13 in the first North American championships Saturday at the Grossinger Hotel Ice Arena, Grossinger,, N.Y. Two weeks ago, Papreck won his third world championship. The seven Americans and six Canadians will compete for $3,000 in prize money, with $1,500 to the winner.

title: Most '75 Soldiers Free, Hanoi Says
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 29 (Reuters)Vietnam's official daily, Nhan Dan, said today that more than 95 percent of the prisoners taken after the April 1975 fall of Saigon had been released, according to the Vietnam News Agency, monitored here. Those still in jail had committed serious crimes and must undergo prolonged reeducation, the daily was quoted as saying.

title: Congress and Carter: Who's in charge?; The old rules do not apply this year. What matters is not whether Carter gets along with Congress but whether he gets along with the country.
description: In Washington, where everyone knows just about everything, everyone knows that Jimmy Carter must get along with Congress. It is what they call a political axiom. It is in all the papers.

title: Spring Training: Baseball as It Was Meant to Be
SPEARING PERSONALLY
description: FOR 37 years I lived in New York, moving with the eddies of life to different apartments all in a 30block area. For most of those 37 years, I longed to live in the country.

title: Shirley Verrett gambles on superstardom
description: The gypsy Azucena, by brooding on the past, twists the present. In the production of Il Trovatore that opened this year's Metropolitan Opera season, Shirley Verrett, singing Azucena's role, seemed to carry the past around like an invisible baby; curved over, curling in on her burden. Restless, driven, beating her arms against the cold, she was a kind of singing vulture. circling to prey on herself.

title: Rockies Mining Town Strikes a Snow Lode
description: Tucked away in the San Juan Mountains of southwestern Colorado is a rare phenomenon: a relatively undiscovered ski resort. The town, a National Historic Landmark, is called Telluride; the ski area is simply known as the mountain. The Utes regarded the valley lin which the town lies as sacred. Some say they placed a curse on it when the gold and silver miners of 1877 drove them out, and Telluriders today fear the curse may be the arrival of hordes of skiers and greedy developers.

title: Book Ends
description: Censorship. The redhot center of book censorship action these days is in the schools and especially the school libraries. Incidents of books being removed from library shelves because some selfappointed group finds them objectionable are on the rise, although statistics are hard to come by, since so many cases are handled sub rose. A school superintendent, hearing an objection to a book, will simply tell the school librarian to take it out, rather than make a fuss that might waken further sleeping dogs in his community; the librarian, who is afraid of losing his or her job, accedes to the request. And so is the transaction of censorship consummated in the aseptic quiet please of the library.

title: Spread of Untaxed Land Stirs Resistance
description: Shout hallelujah, brothers and sisters, George McLain, a former plumber who is now bishop of the New York Universal Life Church, tells a chuckling audience of 800 Putnam County residents.

title: Ford Will Appear On NBC Programs About Presidency
Letters
description: Does Richard J. Margolis (National health insuranceThe dream whose time has come? Jan. 9) propose that the people now operating the Social Security system be chosen to administer national health insurance and bankrupt that system as they have done with their present charge? Or, better yet, why not turn it over to the U.S. Postal Service? Their record of efficiency has yet to be matched anywhere. Maybe he would be willing to allow the Agriculture Department to administer the system. That way we could then pay doctorsas we have paid farmers for many yearsfor performing no duties at all. Or, how about turning the entire operation over to the Defense Department and let them spend billions of dollars without anyone ever having any idea as to where the money was going?

title: If You Go .. .
description: . . . to Machu Picchu, remember that it's about 11,000 feet above sea level and the oxygen is very thin. Newcomers are welladvised to rest in Cuzco for a day until their systems adjust. A cup of hot coca or tea is usually provided by the hotels upon arrival to help the adjustment process.

title: Fashion
Dr. John P. North Dies in Dallas
description: Dr. John Paul North, professor emeritus of surgery at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical School, died Thursday at Baylor Hospital in Dallas. He was 76 years old and lived in Dallas.

title: Roy Jenkins' Task Rebuild the E.E.C.
description: BRUSSELS Roy Jenkins, who twice sold the dream of a united Europe to his own countrymen, now faces the task of reinstilling the committment to unity in a dispirited Europe.

title: Alice Faber Is Betrothed to Mark Fishman
description: Alice Faber and Mark Brian Fishman. graduate students at the University of Texas, where they are working for doctorates, will be married next month in Austin, Tex.

title: Malke Tenenbaum Fiancee Of Rabbi Hillel Moses Reichel
description: Malice Tenenbaum, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Hersh Tenenbaum of Chelsea, Mass., plans to be married in August to Rabbi Hillel Moses Reichel, son of Rabbi and Mrs. O. Asher Reichel of New York, where the prospective bridegroom's father is spiritual leader of the West Side Institutional Synagogue.

title: Meg Bowman To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gibson Bowman of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Elizabeth Bowman, to Steven Philp Mack, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Gerard Mack of Nichols, Conn. The prospective bridegroom's mother, Dr. Jane Andrews Mack, is a pediatrician for the Department of Health in Bridgeport, Conn., and his father is associate medical director of Traveler's Insurance in Hartford.

title: Man Is Killed in Brooklyn Shooting
description: One young man was shot to death and a second was wounded in Brooklyn early yesterday morning in what. the police described as an altercation between them and a detective investigator for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.

title: Terror Imperils Reform in Spain
description: A cycle of street demonstrations, extremist violence and mass strikes has emphasized the fragility and difficulty of Spain's transition to democracy after decades of authoritarian rule.

title: Police Recruits Get Special Instruction On Rochester Force
description: ROCHESTER You get up. about A.M. You shower. You shine your shoes. You usually dress in your sweats, because we have unarmed defense in the morning. and some physical training. Unarmed defense is, uh, trying to fight with your partner without getting your nose broken, or getting sent to the hospital. We had four people go to the hospital in the same day last week.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I HAD a crestfallen call from a good friend of mine the other Sunday, and it left me even more crestfallen than he was.

title: Rabbinical Student To Wed Judith Menin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Menin of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Carol Menin, to Jonathan Waxman, son of Rabbi Mordecai Waxman of Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I., and Mrs. Waxman of Great Neck.

title: Millrose: The Energy Crunch
description: There is no track and field meet in New York that brings out that ultimate effort, that wrenching of muscle and spirit, like the Millrose Games. These were some of the principals in the city's premier winter carnival at Madison Square Garden Friday night whose faces reflected that allout commitment. Above, at left, 33yearold Willie Davenport skims the60yard hurdles in 7 seconds to win what may be his final Millrose appearance. Below, on left, Dwight Stones clearing the bar at 7 feet 4 inches for a highjump victory and, in adjoining photograph, Steve Riddick hits finish line of 60yard dash in a winning 6 seconds. The fifthplace finisher in pole vault, Yuri Prokhorenko, at right, had more desire than height as Earl Bell of Akansas State set a meet record of 18 feet  inch. Prokhorenko, from the Soviet Union, vaulted 176. The record crowd of 18,235 also displayed an allout effort, braving freezing temperatures and the threat of a blizzard to watch the annual meet.

title: For Mexicans, The Fiesta Ends
description: MEXICO CITYAs a Mexican lawyer nervously perused the wine list in a chic restaurant here recently, his colleague leaned over and whispered shyly. I understand there are some quite good Mexican wines these days. The lawyer nodded readily and quickly ordered a domestic label.

title: A Murky Future For Smog Control
Williams Reports U.S. May Let Utilities Shift Gas Reserves to Jersey
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, said today that the Federal Power Commission was ccnsidering action that would allow New Jersey utilities to take reserves of their own natural gas to the state from wells in the Southwest.

title: Albany, Spurred by Attacks on Aged, Seeking Stricter Youth Penalties
description: ALBANY. Jan. 29New York State's new and stiffer penalties for serious crimes by youths will not take effect until Tuesday, but lawmakers herespurred by the extensive publicity on crimes against the elderlyare already looking into ways to further deal with juvenile del inn quency.

title: BRIDGE
description: All bridge players, apart from those few who have the patience and temper of a saint, feel a strong urge now and then to scream at their partners. How on earth could you bid (or play, or defend) like that? they cry. Have you gone mad? And so on, with variations.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Despite the tremendous improvements that have been made in today's highly automatic cameras and superb new lenses, many photographers still find it difficult to accurately record what their eyes see, and to produce the kind of pictures that they really had hoped for. That is because a working knowledge of the technical side of tits complete photographic process is still indispensable for the serious photographer who wants to produce better picturesand one of the best ways to acquire this knowledge at home is to accumulate a library of reference books on the subject.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Sitting kittycorner across the luncheon table from me at Sardi's, Stanley, my old filmproducer friend, seemed as fit as ever but somehow different, sort ofbow shall I put it?downhome. There was no discernable twang to his accent but his Cardin suit had obviously been bought right off a rack and his hair looked as if he'd done It himself, though with the best blowdry equipment that money can buy at the corner drug store. Gee, Stanley, I said, remembering that I hadn't seen hint since last spring, It's been a long time. It certainly has, said Stanley, almost seven years. Seven years? I said. Yes, said Stanley, that's when I made a vow to myself not to have lunch at Sardi's until we put a Democrat back into the White House. Good heavens, Stanley, I said and he looked almost shy. Show business must do its part, he said. It can't remain silent on the important issues of the day.

title: A Year to Negotiate
description: PARISThis will be a year of negotiations and of anxiety, too. West European leaders are eager for the new American Administration to settle down, study its briefs and meet them with answers to their questions about President Carter's policies.

title: Music in Review
description: Hans Jorgen Jensen. a Danish cellist who made his New York debut last Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, played with the wellschooled proficiency that marks a young professional with a solid career ahead of him. Lack of experience showed in his inability to adjust his rather nasal tone to the intimate acoustics of the hall, and at one point in Beethoven's Seven Variations on a Theme from Mozart's The Magic Flute, he suffered a breakdown in either memory or technique that he did not manage to disguise.

title: Marriage Announcement 3  No Title
description: Margaret Ribnick Betrothed

title: Three Images of Africa: East, South and West
Article 4  No Title
description: Regione Lombardia

title: Oil Riches Change the Mideast Landscape
description: TEHERANSunscorohed Saudi Arabia is investhig in solar heating. Earthquakeprone Iran plans to build quakeproof housing. Qatar is going into the fertilizer trade.

title: CARTER SEES CABINET
description: Nearzero and subzero temperatures continued to grip the snowbound Middle West and much of the Northeast yesterday, bringing activity to a standstill in many places and threatening supplies of natural gas for home heating.

title: Congressional Ethics and The Need for Basic Reform
description: WASHINGTONOne of the less impressive and less wellknown performances by the Senate Watergate Committee, which was instrumental in bringing down Richer Nixon, occurred on Nov. 14, 1973, long, after the daily television coverage had ended and public interest in the hearings had begun to wane.

title: A $3 Million Y
description: THE application of the United Jewish Y's for a special youth permit to convert the vacant Fern Place School in Plainview into the Island's first major Y.M.Y.W.H.A. community center brought 400 highly opinionated people to Oyster Bay Town Hall on Tuesday evening to voice support or opposition.

title: Town Calm About APlant
description: LACEY TOWNSHIP IT'S hard to find anyone in this Ocean County community who is opposed to the second nuclearpower plant being built by the Jersey Central Power and Light Company. The plant has been in the planning stages since 1969, when the first generating station went on line; it cleared the final hurdle in December, when David J. Bardin, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, ruled that work could continue, despite objections from the state's Attorney General and Public Advocate.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: Red Cross Appoints Head of Fund Drive
description: George H. Brown, a former director of the Census Bureau, has been appointed chairman of the 1977 community appeal of the American Red Cross in greater New York. This will be the second year that Dr. Brown has held the nost.

title: BROOKLYN NURSE SCHOOL HOLDS FINAL GRADUATION
description: The School of Nursing at the cityowned Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn held its final commencement exercise for 103 graduates last night at the Walt Whitman auditorium of Brooklyn College. The city's fiscal crisis necessitated closing the school, which has graduated more than 5,800 nurses since it was founded in 1897.

title: Connors and Stockton Gain Philadelphia Tennis Final
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29  No, it wasn't ever close. Never even remotely close. After a very few games, not even those who hold notions about such romantic things as knights in shining armor and maidens of virture could have held out any hope for Cliff Drysdale to beat Jimmy Connors tonight.

title: The patriot became an idiotes
description: Philip Deane was born Gerassimos Gigantes into a Greek military family with liberal political traditions. His uncle, Yanis, a Greek resistance leader during the German occupation, was cornered in an Athens apartment but fought back fiercely, killing six of the enemy before he fell. Philip's father, Lakis Gigantes, led the legendary Sacred Battalion that freed the Aegean islands at the end of the war. Although he was later forced to leave the Army because of his strong opposition to the monarchy, he struggled for what he believed until the end of his life in 1970.

title: And Cuba Tightens Its Belt
description: MIAMIThe Castro Government has a gloomy 1977 economic message for 9.5 million Cubans. The country was going through a critical period, it says, and things might get even worse before they get better.

title: Ambulance Is Stolen on Call
description: STOCKTON, Calif., Jan. 29 (UPI)Medics carrying a sick person out of a home on a stretcher yesterday discovered that their ambulance had been stolen. Another ambulance arrived on the scene a few minutes later. Police found the missing ambulance in a vacant field, but had no immediate clues on who took it.

title: Czech Town Becomes Giant Coal Pit
description: MOST, Czechoslovakia  Czechoslovak industry's growing need for cheap fuel is hastening the digestion of this 11thcentury Bohemian town by an enormous coal pit.

title: Marguerite Pool Engaged to Craig A. Phillips
description: The engagement of Morguerite Fustis Spruance Pool to Craig Arnold Phillips has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Newell Pool of Phoenix. Md., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Arnold Phillips of Tulsa, Chia. A June wedding is planned.

title: 6 Found Dead in Buffalo Blizzard
description: At least six motorists were found dead in their stranded cars around Buffalo yesterday, while thousands of other persons took shelter in public buildings, factories, supermarkets, hotels and anyplace else not closed by a blizzard.

title: MONDALE IN MEETING WITH FRENCH LEADER
description: PARIS, Jan. 29Vice President Mondale met today with President Valry Giscard d'Estaing and said later that the French leader had agreed to talks leading to a curb on conventional arms sales abroad.

title: Czechs Deny They Are Planning To Deport Political Dissidents
THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Despite the continuing array of bright statistics flowing out of the economic and business worlds, the nation's securities markets this month have become wary and somewhat pessimistic. Investors seem to be more worried than businessmen and economists about prospects for the American economy, inflation and the Federal deficit.

title: Wider Olympic Drug Abuse Is Seen
description: More devious drug. abuses are a certainty for the: 1980 Olympics at, Moscow, according to top inedieal advisers with the United States Olympic Committee.

title: LAND IN ARIZONA BOUGHT BY NATURE CONSERVANCY
description: LAKE HAVASU CITY, Ariz., Jan. 29The Nature Conservancy, a national organization devoted to the preservation of ecologically significant land, has bought 1,160 acres near here that are described as the most unique cottonwood and riparian habitat along the whole Colorado River.

title: 13 LONDON BOMBINGS ATTRIBUTED TO I.R.A.
description: LONDON, Jan. 29Northern Irish Roman Catholic extremists were widely believed responsible for a series of bombings early today along Oxford Street, London's renowned shopping thoroughfare, and in nearby stores and offices of the Soho district.

title: Play to Help SpenceChapin
description: SpenceChapin Services to Families and Children will benefit from the Feb. 15 performance of Otherwise Engaged at the Plymouth Theater. Tickets at $60, $45, $35 and $25, are available from the beneficiary, 6 East 94th Street.

title: Solving the mysteries of pain
description: She was attractive, highly intelligent, normal in every way except one: her insensitivity to pain. Among her friends, Miss C., daughter of an Alberta, Canada, physician, had learned to pretend to feel hurt when cut or bruised, but in fact her immunity to pain was so complete it often endangered her life, exposing her to sprains, infections, even broken bones. As a student at McGill University in the 1950's, she astonished experts at the Montreal Neurological Institute who found that experiments which would have been torture to anyone elseelectric shocks, sticks thrust up her nose, needles inserted into her body caused Miss C. absolutely no pain at all. Then, on Aug. 28, 1955, she was admitted to the University Hospital in Edmonton, suffering from a massive infection; for the first time in her life, she actually felt pain and was given analgesics to soothe it. She died two days later, at age 29, and an autopsy revealed a completely normal brain and nervous system.

title: Quebec's Economic Game Plan
description: MONTREALAn independent Quebec, if it ever comes to pass, would not attempt to isolate itself economically from its sister provinces in Canada or from the United States.

title: The Thrill Of Owning Luxury Cars
description: LOS\ ANGELESWhen Irving Osser,. a Beverly Hills lawyer, pondered the ourchase of a new car this year. he passed up RollsRoyce, Ferrari, MercedesBenz, Lamborghini and Maserati. He chose an Americanbulit Excalibur, a $22,700 convertible styled to resemble a MercedesBenz roadster of the 1930's, but with a running gear and engine, that ,are pure Chevrolet Corvette.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: In Memoriam

title: Police Drive Stalks Heroin Dealers in Harlem
description: When a squad car cruises along Eighth Avenue in Harlem now, it is as if a wind were moving through the sidewalk crowds. Young men who had been standing quite still quickly begin walking when a blueandwhite car comes into view, walking north, south or in any direction, stirred by the breath of fear.

title: From a Bracelet to a Business
description: ALL Anna Stigi wanted was simple little handmade bracelet, not a costumejewelry factory, for goodness sakes. How was she to know that when her husband, John, disappeared into the basement workshop of their house in Port Washington, she'd hardly ever see him again?

title: BLACK LEADERS MEET ON RHODESIAN ISSUE
Japan: Will the Meters Run on Nuclei?
description: There is a limit to the rise in taxicab fares. If oil prices, continue to go up as they have done. since 1973, the taxi industry in Japan will be put out of business in five Years, moans Akizo Kawanabe, chairman of the Federation of Passenger Cars Associations in Tokyo.

title: The Man Who Made Cousin, Cousine
description: The chilly lobby at Kennedy Airport is almost deserted. Runways are crusted with a vanilla icing of snow. But the VIP lounge, tucked away in a tiny culdesac, hums to the rattle of cocktail shakers, the popping of champagne corks and the aroma of spicy canapes. The Very Important People, who can't get anywhere because of foul weather, recline in leather chairs, trying to maintain an air of supercilious elegance and indifferent patience. One of the snowbound travelers is JeanCharles Tacchella, director of Cousin, Cousine, the biggest surprise French hit since Claude Lelouch's Oscarwinning A Man and a Woman. Tacchella's film, which has been nominated for an Oscar as the best foreignlanguage movie of the year, tells story of adultery among married couples and is presented as healthy adult comedy, without sentiment or anger.

title: North to home
MOSCOW REBUTS U.S. ON SAKHAROV PRAISE
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29The Soviet Government's press agency Tass said today that the State Department engaged in unsavory play on Thursday in issuing a statement in defense of Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and civil rights advocate.

title: At 72, Greenwald Resumes 1937 Coaching Post
description: At an age when most men are taking it easy or planning to, Tom Greenwald, 72 years old, is resuming a career he left 40 years ago.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 9:30 A.M. (Channel 4) Here and Now: Peter Berle, New York State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation.

title: The Yankees Go Home
description: Yankee go home, the cry once heard by American businessmen abroad, is becoming their own theme song. Increasingly United Statesbased multinationals are finding that the great growth  and earnings  opportunities lie not in foreign capitals but in their own backyard.

title: In Summary
description: The state of New Jersey and members of its medical bodies have adopted a new set of guidelines to aid families, doctors and hospitals in following state lay in future cases resembling that of Karen Anne Quinlan. The guidelines may affect as many as 200 persons a year, according to Jack Owen, president of the New Jersey Hospital Association.

title: In Ireland, Farmers Are the New Rich
description: DUBLINMick Quinn, who describes himself as a hardworking Irish hill farmer. leads a secure and comfortable life by Irish standards on his 220acre holding tucked into the County Dublin highlands below the Wicklow mountains. His 150 dairy cows graze the sloping fields about the farmhouse.

title: St. John's Whips Oregon At Its Own Game, 6151
description: On the West Coast they call it kamikaze basketball, the bangemup type of game that Oregon brought to Alumni Hall in Hillcrest, Queens, yesterday. But the rough tactics did the Ducks little good because St. John's met every physical challenge and played much better basketball, too, in achieving a 6151 victory.

title: Japan: Living With 6 Percent Growth Isn't Easy
description: TOKYOThis year Japan, which has forged the nonCommunist world's most powerful economy outside the United States, enters a new economic and political era.

title: In Summary
description: As expected, Percy E. Sutton has announced that he wants to preside over more than a single section of New York City: the Manhattan Borough President is running fora the Democratic nomination for Mayor, and he is the first black to do so with a reasonable chance of getting it.

title: DollarStability in a Monetary Storm
description: The American dollar has emerged as the dominant member of a small cluster of strong currencies, including the West German mark, the Swiss franc and the Jaoanese yen.

title: Legislative Hearings Scheduled This Week
description: The following public hearings will be held in the New York metropolitan area by state legislative committees this week:

title: Portugal's, Many and Going Legal
description: LISBON  Portugal's new democratic constitution bars fascist organizations, so the fascists are moving cautiously. Nevertheless, it is clear that they are reorganizing their forces, in the military and political circles, among the youth and in the press.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE is, it would seem, big dough in nostalgia. First, there was Williamsburg, then Sturbridge Village and then a veritable flood of recreations of the commercial hustle of an earlier age.

title: Birth Notice 1  No Title
description: Births

title: Tenure Issue Splits Two Bergen Towns
description: ORADELL THIS affluent and conservative Bergen County borough and neighboring River Edge have been split by a growing controversy involving the granting of tenure for the superintendent of the River Dell Regional School District, which serves students from both towns.

title: POLITICS
description: MAYOR Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City intends to make a courtesy call on Governor Byrne one day soon to tell him he plans to go after his job. The Mayor of the state's second largest city also will give Mr. Byrne the results of a new poll that reportedly will show that the Governor's chances of reelection are slim.

title: HOME CLINIC
State Cancer Toll Reflects U.S. Study
description: ARECENT national report that showed that more nonwhite Americans, proportionately, die from cancer than do white Americans is borne out by a similar study made in New Jersey.

title: POINT OF VIEW
BogdanovichWill Nickelodeon Be His Last Picture Show?; BogdanovichWhat Went Wrong?
Meet the New Partner in Latin America
Marilyn E. Perry Engaged to Charles L. Widney Jr.
description: Marilyn Edith Perry, who heads Marilyn Perry Associates, public relations consultants, and Charles L. Widney Jr., vice president of the First Crescent Corporation, consultants and project developers In the Middle East, plan to be married in Grace Episcopal Church on Feb. 26.

title: INTERVIEW
description: ACCORDING to Albany legend, if you really want to know what's going on in the Legislature, you find out from an elevator operator or a parkinglot attendant.

title: Jack Manders, 68, PlaceKicking Star Of Chicago Bears
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP)John A. (Automatic Jack) Manders, Chicago Bears football placekicking star, died yesterday at the age of 68.

title: Broker Weds Deborah Pigott
description: Deborah Dee Pigott, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John D. Pigott Jr. of Memphis, was married there yesterday to William R. Pundmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland T. Pundmann of St. Charles, Mo. The Rev. Dr. Roy Clark performed the ceremony in St. John's Methodist Church.

title: Shod in Style (in Italy)
description: Women who care about fashion and don't care what they pay to get it seem to be buying shoes made anywhere but in the United States.

title: Reliquary by Wourinen In Commemorative Mood
description: Charles Wuorinen's Reliquary, a 15minute orchestra work completed In 1975, received its New York premiere at the Manhattan School of Music on Friday night as part of a terse, tightly integrated program that also included Stravinsky's Variations (1964), Webern's Variations, Op. 30 (1940), and Stefan Wolpe's Chamber Piece No. 1 (1964).

title: Literate Stout
Gas Crisis Has Complicated Origins
description: The twoweekold naturalgas disruption that has idled hundreds of thousands of workers and inconvenienced millions across the nation was touched off by the intensely cold winter but reflected the slowly gathering force of years of declining production and lack of public concern.

title: ART
CORNELL ESTABLISHES MEDICAL PROFESSORSHIP
description: The New York HospitalCornell Medical Center has announced the establishment of a professorship in geriatrics. A hospital spokesman said it was believed to be the first such chair specifically endowed for the illnesses and disabilities of the aged in the United States.

title: Interest in Home Water Filters on the Rise
description: MAYBE it is because people are much more ecologyminded and conscious of their environment these days, or maybe they have been alarmed by reports indicating that some suburban water supplies have shown traces of potentially dangerous contaminants. But whatever the reasons homeowners and apartment dwellers are becoming increasingly aware of the quality and taste of the water that they drink.

title: NEW YORK STATE UPHELD IN NURSINGHOME BATTLE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29A State Supreme Court justice has ruled in favor of state officials who are seeking to revoke the nursinghome licenses of Bernard Bergman and others who have been convicted of felonies.

title: Susan Peet Fiancee Of Richard N. Miller
description: Susan Graves Peet of New York and Richard N. Miller of Bloomfield, N.J., plan to be married May 7.

title: NEW YORK IS CUTTING ITS WELFARE COSTS
description: New costcontainment programs more than doubled the number of ineligibles removed from New York City's welfare rolls in the last six months to 30,500 casesperhaps 82,000 personscompared with 14,060 cases, or 38,000 persons, in the first half of last year.

title: Marriage Announcement 6  No Title
description: Melanie L. Miller Is Affianced

title: Is the Air Inside Your House Too Dry?; Is the Air Inside Your House Dry?

description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Stichman of White Meadow Lake, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret C. Stichman, to Kenneth H. Haas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Haas of New York and White Meadow Lake.

title: The Ballet: Peter Schaufuss Flowers in Giselle Teams Wtih Miss Makarova in the Part of Albrecht
description: A sad injury and a now happily settled labor dispute led to an unexpected conjunction of stars at the City Center 55th Street Theater on Friday night, where the American Ballet Theater was reaching the last lap of its marathon performances of Giselle.

title: Squalor and Pollution Afflict the Growing Cities
description: The countryside is deceptively attractive to a touristit's full of local color. But you have to trust the millions who vote with their feet to know what's best for themselves. No matter how ugly the slums are, they can't be as bad as starving in the country. In the country, if a man has a farm that barely supports him, he can only leave it to one of his sons. The others usually go to the biggest city; at least there is a hope of finding a job there, says Prof. Daniel Dunham of Columbia University.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: IBM HAS OPPORTUNITIES FOR ELECTRICAL ENGINEERS AND PROGRAMMERS

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI)Next year, nearly seven million American families will have outofpocket medical expenses exceeding 15 percent of their income, according to a Congressional report released today.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. The Invisible Thread.

title: Gregory Whitmore Price Fiance of Virginia Seibert
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry I. Seibert of Far Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Anne Seibert, to Gregory Whitmore Price, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Price of New Vernon, N.J.. and Naples, Fla. Plans have been made for a June wedding.

title: Tucson, Dependent on Wells, Finds Itself in a Hole on Water
Economic Twilight In Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, RhodesiaThe stockbroker sat at the bar and looked dispiritedly at the empty beer glass in his hand. Let them say what they want, he said, referring to official forecasts of an economic upturn in 1977. Another year like the one gone by, and the terrs [terrorists] won't have to worry about me. I'll be over the border and gone.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE LIFE AND EXTRAORDINARY ADVENTURES OF PRIVATE IVAN CHONKIN, by Vladimir Voinovich. Translated by Richard Lourie. (Farrar, Straus alc Giroux, $10.) A funny satire pitting a wise simpleton against some manic Soviet types in the army and on the collective farm.

title: Explaining the British Dilemma
The Rains Came And India Eats
description: NEW DELHIThe rains came. They turned 1976 into a food bonanza. By design and luck, production exceeded targets. end for the first time officials in India are seized with what they call problems of plenty instead of recurring scarcity.

title: Wright, Miss Sears Gain Hall of Fame
How the Europe of 1500 became the Europe of 1600
description: One of Bernard Berenson's great pleasures in old age was his conespondence with a young Oxford historian lately released front service with British Military Intelligence: Hugh

title: Five Modern Works at Juilliard
description: Richard Dufallo assembled an unusually fine program of contemporary music for Juilliard's 20th Century Music Series on Friday night at the Juilliard Theater. One generally suffers concerts of this type, hoping for one or two substantial pieces at the best, but all four works performed by the school's orchestra were distinctive and individual.

title: Detroit's New European Adventure
Whatever Happened to European Recovery?; Recovery
Asia's LifebloodIts Commodities
description: BANGKOK, ThailandGoing south on the main highway out of Hat Yai, southern Thailand's commercial capital, and heading down the Malay Peninsula toward Kuala Lumpur, at first glance the scenery is fence after picket fence hung with drying laundry.

title: A Farewell To the Old Hotel Night Spots

description: The following public hearings will be held by New York City Council committees this week:

title: Miss Kaserer of Austria Ski Victor
description: MEGEVE, France, Jan. 29 .(AP) Monika Kaserer of Austria won the giant slalom race of the World Cup ski meet today, finishing only twohundreths of a second ahead of LiseMarie Morerod of Switzerland, the cup point leader.

title: Lots of Locks, but Car Thefts Continue
Officials to Start Gambling Nights Under Old Rules No Problems About Losses
description: New York City officials say, they are resigned to beginning the Las Vegas Nights program for charitable organizations on Feb. 1 Without changes in the state rules that they feel would generate enthusiasm and bring in considerable profit. These rules changes would permit poker games and an increase in the limit on prizes, which is now $1,000.

title: ENCOUNTER
He typed his way out of the pit
description: Imagine a man at the bottom of pit. 60 feet deep, with smooth, vertical walls and absolutely no way to get out. Can you imagine how you would get him into that pit? the head of the Bpicture unit at Warner Brothers asked Dalton Trumbo in his 1935 job interview. Yes, he could, answered Trumbo. Well, said the producer, if you can get him out too, we're in good shape.

title: E.P.A.'s Test Case in Ohio: Auto Maintenance the Issue
description: CINCINNATI  Robert Webster, a truck driver for a valve company, pulled his orange 1977 Ford van into a city inspection station, left the engine running and stepped out. He looked glumly toward the back of the van.

title: Legend or NotThe Ground Hog is Due
description: On Wednesday, attention will focus on the groundhog. Although this furry waddler, also known as woodchuck, does very little to inspire the volu minous news coverage, nevertheless it has its day.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: WE LIVE on a wooded hillside overlooking the Great Swamp. On three sides. we are surrounded by woods, and the fourth side is an open area with a lawn, a vegetable garden and fruit trees. Since the beginning of last summer, almost every afternoon and early morning as I look out into the garden from the kitchen window, there have been deer grazing on the grass.

title: Princeton Residents Fearful of Tests
M. E. Winston, Chemist, To Wed Ellen R. Krufka
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Krufka of Matawan, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Ruth Krufka, to Marvin Eliot Winston, son of James J. Winston of Amagansett, L.I., and the late Mrs. Winston. The wedding is planned for May 22.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Collectors on the whole are intelligent and perceptive enough to see through the many borderline schemes and outright fraudulent advertisements published by fastbuck operators, such as last year's infamous $20 gold piece (a tiny medal worth $4) and the new $2 bill firstday postmark ripoffs. (Such offers usually find their greatest success with the uninformed general public.) Collectors also show strong indications that they can be very reluctant about parting with their moneyas evidenced by an amazing outpouring of letters to this column.

title: Of human bondage, Australianstyle
description: Of human bondagethe major theme in Patrick White's fine, new novelis perhaps the oldest motif in Australian literature. From the earliest transportation ballads to the fiction of the 19th century, Lord Sydney's mournful penal colonies have had a lot of literary attention and have inspired at least two remarkable novels, Marcus Clarke's realistic For the Term of His Natural Life and William Hay's romantic The Escape of the Notorious Sir William Heans. And, even though modern, urbanized Australia has about as much connection with the desolate penitentiaryland of its origins as we have with the Conquistadors, the image and the theme seem to persist.

title: Miss Fowler Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Austen Fowler of Washington Depot, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Elizabeth Barth Fowler, to Stephen Garrison Solley, son of Nancy Farr Solley of Washington, Conn.. and John B. Solley 3d of Coventry, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Paper Firm Gives Land to Aid Ski Teams
description: STRATTON MOUNTAIN, Vt., Jan. 28 There's good news for the United States Ski Education Foundation. The International Paper Company has just donated more than 1,000 acres of this resort's ski terrain to the foundation.

title: FREDDIE PRINZE, 22, DIES AFTER SHOOTING
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29  Freddie Prinze, the television star, died today at the University of CaliforniaLos Angeles Medical Center, 33 hours after shooting himself in the head in front of his busines agent.

title: INTERVIEW
Ailing Australia Finds a Scapegoat
description: SYDNEYPerhaps no place else in the world do political cartoonists wield so powerful pen as they do here. Every newspaper has a staff cartoonist, even The Australian Financial Review. The Age, an otherwise conservative Melbourne paper. has five, one of whom works for the business pages.

title: ASBESTOS CONCERNS ARE SUED BY WIDOW
description: The widow of a sheetmetal worker who died last year of a fort,. of cancer presumably induced by the handling of asbestos, has sued 17 major asbestos companies for $3 million.

title: Washington Cathedral, Threatened by Bankruptcy, Is Cutting Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The soaring Gothic grace of Washington Cathedral, which sprang from George Washington's hope for a great church for national purposes, is threatened with bankruptcy. It is paring its staff, both clerical and lay, turning out lights and making other economies.

title: Intensive Care on Wheels
description: FOR THOUSANDS of Mercer County residents, many aspects of the popular television show Emergency have become real with the placing in operation of the county's first lifemobiles.

title: India's Outs Have Plans, Little Chance
Scraping to Meet the Oil Bill
description: An old axiom suggests that the anticipation of a major event, or the fears that arise over the potential impact of some startling development, are always worse than the reality turns out to be. Such has certainly been the case so far in the international oil drama that opened more than three years ago.

title: A Turning Point
Islip's 100% Solution
description: WHEREVER Town Supervisor Peter F. Cohalan speaks these daysat school board meetings,. at Chamber of Commerce functions, at the Kiwanis Clubpeople in the audience inevitably ask him about the same subject: the courtordered reassessment of all the property in the town.

title: Tightening the Ring
description: The Supreme Court appears to be tightening the ring of white suburbs around the black core of most major American cities. Two major decisions in just two weeks reinforced the pattern, aptly described by the Kerner Commission a decade ago, of two societies, one black, one whiteseparate and unequal.

title: They Hear Music, and It's Their Own
description: Sevenyearold Ladys Botello fell in the snow on her way to the Turtle Bay Music School on East 52d Street. She didn't hurt herself, but some snow got into her violin case.

title: A Yankee Fish Story
. . . And the Windmill on the Hill
Glenmalin Wins Jockeys' Cup
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 29 (AP)Lester Piggott, an English jockey, rode Glenmalin, his English mount, to victory in the $50,000 Hong Kong Jockeys Invitation Cup race at the Royal Hong Kong Jockey Club today. Glenmalin finished the 1,800meter race half a length in froht of Natural Vigour, ridden by Bill Hartack, a fivetime Kentucky Derby winner.

title: Miss Austin, 14, Is Learning Slims' Tour Ropes Quickly
description: Tracy Austin received a telegram from Chris Evert last week, welcoming her to the Virginia Slims circuit and wishing her luck. For the pigtailed 14yearold from Rolling Hills, Calif., it was a very special message. It came from the tennis player she says she most respects; and whose success she hopes to duplicate. Two weeks ago, Tracy became the youngest player to gain entry to the Slims tour, moving up from Avon Futures competition under the twoWeek feedin arrangement between the circuits.

title: Princeton Runs Home Mark to 70 With a 6956 Triumph Over Penn
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 29There was no place so comfortable and so cozy as home to the Princeton basketball team tonight, even though a New Jersey fuel emergency mandated a temperature reduction to 55 degrees inside Jadwin Gymnasium. The Tigers were hot as they ran away from Penn and whipped the Quakers, 6956, in the big rematch between the teams expected to fight to the wire for the Ivy League championship.

title: GARDENING
description: FEW Americans were aware of bonsai, before the late 1940's. Some collections existed in public, or private gardens, but it remained for postwar visits of tourists and businessmen to Japan to make us aware of this horticultural art form. A large display at the 1960 Expo in Osaka also attracted the interest of many American visitors.

title: TAX DEDUCTION SOUGHT FOR CHILDCARE COSTS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29The Republican majority in the State Senate introduced bill this week that would permit state taxpayers to continue claiming deductions for child care expenses on their 1976 state tax returns.

title: Miss Gary Fiancee Of Nicholas Young
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Edson Gary of South Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Hitch Gary to Nicholas Sible Young of New York, son of Woodbury Lew Young of Bradenton, Fla., and the late Mrs. Young.

title: Bergen Increases Aid for Delinquents
Vegetable Crops in Florida Are Almost Wiped Out by the Severe Weather
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Jan. 29The cold snap that brought snow as far south as Miami last week not only damaged Florida's famed citrus crop but also almost wiped out its vegetable industry, one of the East Coast's major winter sources of fresh tomatoes, potatoes, corn and beans.

title: Steven Bellock to Marry Emily E. Babin in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Babin of Shaker Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Elizabeth Babin, to Steven Bellock of Ann Arbor, Mich., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Bellock of North Miami Beach, Fla., formerly of Tenafly, N. J. A wedding in August is planned.

title: Vance Names Columbia Professor
HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE LEADING ECONOMIC INDICATORS ROSE 1.6 percent in December to 129.8 (1967 = 100) the highest gain in 18 months . . . the United States trade deficit declined to $551 million in December and for the year the deficit totaled $5.9 billion, compared with a record surplus of $11 billion in 1975 . Orders for durable goods in December rose by 6.6 percent to $56.1 billion, an increase of $3.5 billion. largest for the year .

title: U.S. IS TURNING OVER HOUSES TO NEW YORK
description: More than 200 small homes in Brooklyn and Queensall vacant and many of them decaying blightswill be turned Over to New York City by the Federal Government in an attempt to salvage them and find new occupants who can be nurtured into responsible homeowners.

title: Doing Business In the Mideast
description: TEHERAN, Iran Mr. Xhe's an American businessman who likes to keep a low profilemay have tired eyes after 10 years traveling in the oilrich countries of the Persian Gulf, but he also has a large personal nest egg.

title: Venezuela's Agricultural Ills
Israel Feels the Squeeze
description: JERUSALEMIsraeli workers are griping, and many are attempting to subvert the Government's fixed wage structure. Consumers, who were subjected to 35 percent inflation in 1976, are glumly looking ahead to more of the same in 1977. And the politicians, facing elections in the spring, are seeking a way to check inflation.

title: Bar Association Elects President
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29 (AP)Henry J. Smith, a White Plains lawyer, has been elected president of the New York State Bar Association. Mr. Smith was unanimously chosen at the group's recent annual meeting in New York City to succeed Edwin F. Russell of Brooklyn on July 1. Mr. Smith, a native of New York City, is a partner in the law firm of McCarthy, Fingar, Donovan and Glatther in White Plains.

title: 5 IN STERLING HOMEX CONVICTED OF FRAUD
Stepping Abroad for Shoes
description: WASHINGTONAt the K mart discount center in nearby Annandale, Va., rows upon rows of $4 to $6apair casual shoes, mostly made from plastic, attract budgetconscious shoppers.

title: A proposal for a Palestinian state
description: Is a Palestinian state possible, and desirable, of achievement? In recent weeks, YasJr Arafat and other leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization have declared that they will accept a state composed of the West Bank of the River Jordan and the Gaza Strip. They have intimated that they are preparing to strike a bargain. They seem to be headed, over tortuous paths and provided their adversary respondsto eventual recognition of Israel. The notion of a Palestinian state has long been mooted; now, for the first time, it is being taken seriously.

title: Life in the Hockey Minors: Buses, Beer and Leave It to Beaver
description: LENEXA, Kan.The thing of it is this: Everybody here wants to be someplace else.

title: The Natural Gas Shortage Was Only Partially ManMade
description: WASHINGTONThe natural gas shortage that has afflicted much of the country this winter has been a long time coming. How much time will be needed to cure it, or even whether it can be cured, is anybody's guess.

title: Canada Traumaic Change
description: OTTAWADramatic political and economic changes have robbed Canada of the reputation for stability that was once envied around the world.

title: Auto Sales in Canada: Outlook for' 77 Is Bullish
description: DETROITThis is the time of year. that Fred Henne, a Ford dealer in Canada's frigid Northwest Territories, has his new cars and trucks delivered to him over what is called the natural bridge across the Mackenzie River.

title: Dr. E. E. DePasquale to Wed Dr. Agatha Nody
description: Dr. and Mrs. Louis Nody of Peekskill, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Agatha Catherine Nody, to Dr. Eugene Edward DePasquale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DePasquale of Flushing, Queens, and Southampton, L. I. A wedding in July is planned.

title: Books, Bricks and Postal Rates
description: A book is about the same shape as a brick and, depending on the weight of the paper it's printed on, can weigh almost as much. No one who cherishes books or who understands the extent to which a free society requires the widest diffusion of knowledge would treat books and bricks the same. Yet that is the direction in which the Postal Service is moving. To reduce its operating deficit, one proposal under serious consideration is to abolish the separate class of mail that now exists for newspapers and magazines and the separate class for books.

title: Author's Query
description: I am seeking the letters of F. Scott Fitzgerald for a new edition of his correspondence.

title: South Korea's New Export: Cars
Korea Plans More Economic Gains
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThis year, each South Korean student studying overseas will be allowed to spend up to $1,000 a month. The previous foreignexchange limit was $800.

title: Sally Cohen Fiancee Of Larry David Swift
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald H. Cohen of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Gail Cohen, to Larry David Swift, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Swift of Cedar Springs, Mich.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: RUTH S. PILCHIK

title: Nurses and Abortion
description: NURSES have traditionally been thought to be the guardians of lifeto care for all human beings regardless of their age or condition. Yet, in abortion, they must stand by and watch a human life cease to be.

title: Prinze Dies of Wound
description: Freddie Prinze, comedian, died yesterday at a Los Angeles hospital of a selfinflicted gunshot wound in the head. Page 19.

title: Key to SuccessPlan Ahead for Spinach
In Summary
description: The possibility of meaningful reform in Congressional standards of behavior was enhanced last week when the House Democratic Caucus voted to remove a Representative reprimanded last year by the full House for financial misconduct, Robert L. F. Sikes of Florida, from the chairmanship of an important appropriations subcommittee.

title: Alexander V. Fontana Dies at 64
description: Alexander V. Fontana, chairman of Consumers Flavoring Extract Company and a member of the board of regents of Long Island College Hospital, died Friday night of a heart attack as he was leaving the hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 921 McDonald Avenue, Brooklyn.
