description: Carol Cohen Married

title: Oil Riches Unleash a Major Boom In Nigeria
Sumner Collins Dead at Age 73
description: Sumner Collins, a promotion executive for the Hearst newspaper chain, died yesterday at University Hospital in New York City. He was 73 years old and lived on lower Fifth Avenue with his wife, the syndicated columnist, Sylvia Porter.

title: The Adopted Seek Out Real ParentsJust to Know
description: One day last month a 41yearold, browneyed woman from Yonkers named Fran Miller placed a classified in the Public Notices section of The New York Times. It ran:

title: Hard Days Ahead for Mexico
description: MEXICO CITYAfter the hysteria that accompanied the final weeks of the Echeverria Government and the euphoria that greeted the inauguration two months ago of President Jose Lopez Portillo, Mexico has now settled down to the lengthy and mundane task of rebuilding its economy. The salad days of big speeches and big spending by the government are suddenly over and the technocratic era of administrative reform, wage controls and budgetary restraint has now begun.

title: Many Draw U.S. Pensions and Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)More than 141,000 retired military men and women are collecting pensions from the United States Government while receiving salaries for new Federal jobs.

title: Italians Live Well Despite Their Crisis
description: ROMEIn the Italian economy, bullets, window panes, 15 tubes of toothpaste, codliver oil and old fashioned pens have a lot in commonthey all contribute to the present crisis.

title: Warranty May Fail Acid Test if Your New Car Is a Lemon
description: Kate Fishlow of Biloxi, Miss., drove her new $5,516 car home last March and then noticed that the nameplate on one side of the automobile said Aspen, a compact model in the Dodge line. The one on the other side said Volare, a compact Plymouth.

title: Mayoral Race Concentrating On City Crime
description: With Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan attempting to make crime a major issue in the mayoral campaign, Mayor Beame reacted last week by proposing 4 corps of volunteer high school students to protect the einem. however, on another crime front, the Mayor has left vacant 12 Criminal Court and seven Family Court judgeships for periods ranging up to a year.

title: Political Race Lost by Boy, 4
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 29Ian Locklear received seven writein votes in this week's balloting for student government president at the University of South Florida, which would not be particularly newsworthy except for one thing. Ian is 4 years old.

title: Lecture on Cats, With a Cat
description: Cat lovers are invited to hear Peter Mehlin, a librarian, discuss Living With a Cat. Churchill, Mr. Mehlin's cat, will assist. The program is scheduled to take place at 2 P.M. at the Brooklyn Public Library branch, 280 Cadman Plaza West. Admission is free.

title: Polish Protests Go to Parliament
description: WARSAW, Jan. 29 (AP)Letters protesting alleged police brutality in putting down foodprice demonstrations last June have been sent to the Polish Parliament, dissident sources reported today.

title: Article 3  No Title
What Rock Opera Needs Is a Voice of Its Own
description: Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice, who wrote the music and the words respectively for Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat and Jesus Christ Superstar, were in New York recently to preside over a multimedia presentation of their latest rock opera Evita.

title: The Additional Reports of Bribes
description: The long list of bribes and political payoffs by international companies to officials nearly everywhere continues to grow: Information filed in a complaint by the Securities and Exchange Commission, has disclosed that the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and Uniroyal Inc. apparently made payments in the United States (New York City) and 28 other countries.

title: Capital Church Wants Carters To Feel at Home
description: WASHINGTON, Jan? 29Mildred New stood at the rear of the First Baptist Church here the other day and made a wish for the church's newest members, President Carter and his family.

title: Samuel T. Carpenter, 70, Dies
description: Samuel T. Carpenter, chairman of the department of engineering at Swarthmore College from 1963 to 1972, died at home Friday in his sleep. He was 70 years old and lived at 612 Ogden Avenue, Swarthmore, Pa.

title: STAMPS
Chilean Official Halts State DepartmentSponsored Tour of U.S. After Charges That He Tortured Prisoners
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29  A member of the rightwing Chilean military leadership who was touring the United States as a guest of the State Department has cut short his trip following accusations that he had tortured political prisoners.

title: DoItYourself Mechanics Cut High Cost of Repairs
description: Vince Losito of Long Island, a contractor who is the head of a sixcar family, used to take the family cars to neighborhood service stations for tuneups.

title: The Auto Industry's Biggest Comebacks
description: Of all business phenomena, probably none has more appeal than the stirring comeback of a oncegreat company, product, or entrepreneur. America's premier industry, automobile manufacturing, is replete with comebacks of companies and figures fallen upon hard times, then rising spectacularly. Among the 10 greatest comebacks in automotive history, three have involved Ford. two each General Motors and Chrysler, and one each WillysOverland, Auburn, and American Motors.

title: An Aegean Switzerland
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus  To my way of thinking, the only conceivable solution of the tragic Cyprus problem must be creation of a federal state in which Greekspeaking and Turkishspeaking communities each have considerable autonomous rights in their separate sectors but with a national government controlling Certain basic matters including foreign policy and defense.

title: Beware of the Most Dangerous Sport of All: Sitting and Watching
description: We are constantly being warned to check with our physicians before beginning athletics. Play and games evidently can be risky business, But we are not told the risks of not beginning athleticsthat the most dangerous sport of all is watching it from the stands or in front of the TV set.

title: 'Wait and See, Spanish Are Told
description: MADRIDA show of hands was called for at a recent gathering here of top European and American directors of multinational corporations.

title: Chamber Music Concert on Feb. 19
description: A program of chamber music will be presented at Brooklyn's Central Library on Saturday, Feb. 19 at 2:30 P.M. The Queens Festival Orchestra Chamber Group will present a program of works by Haydn, Borodin and Dvorak. Admission to the concert, at the Brooklyn Public Library building at. Grand Army Plaza, free.

title: Spreading the Gospel Of Contemporary Music
Marriage Announcement 4  No Title
description: Marion McDaniel Is Bride

title: Japan Lowers the Boom
description: TOKYOA few years ago near Kamo City, about 150 miles west of Tokyo. the driver of a bus carrying 105 sightseers fell asleep at the wheel. The bus plunged over the side of Route 41 into the Hida River, killing all aboard.

title: India's Unhappy Opposition
description: The opposition to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party has begun its campaign for general elections in March but, while many political prisoners have been freed and restrictions on political activity relaxed, Mrs. Gandhi's adversaries say their full democratic rights have not been restored.

title: Marvin W. Stober to Wed Maria Barbieri in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest J. Barbieri of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Barbieri, to Marvin W. Stober, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Stober of Brooklyn and Hallandale, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: Uniformity Scores on Coast
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 29 (UPI)Uniformity, with Fernando Toro riding, won the 40th running of the, $58,000 San Pasqual Handicap today at Santa Anita. Distant Land was second. and Pisistrato third, while the heavily favored Ancient Title was fifth in the field of eight.

title: In Summary
description: Rhodesia's white minority Government has rejected proposals for a transition to black majority rule under the AngloAmerican plan hastily negotiated last fall by Henry A. Kissinger, former Secretary of State. Unless a new peace initiative is put forward soon, the likelihood is that fighting In Southern Africa will increase.

title: Saudi Arabia's Sheik Yamani, Talleyrand of The Oil World
Miss Werner, S. C. Kratovil Plan Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Werner of New York of the engagement of their daughter. Barbara Werner, to Stephen C. Kratovil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil A. Kratovil of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I am planning to change butlers, but do not know how to break the news to Hudson, Last year, he started to become insufferable. I put it clown to advancing age. With those Sunday night pieties at the servants table downstairs and his highhanded Presbyterian harshness toward the footman, he was turning into a common scold. The sour effect on the servants was plain in the decline in Mrs. Bridges's cooking.

title: Marriage Announcement 2  No Title
description: Mimi McNamara Affianced

title: GARDENING
description: HOUSEBOUND New Jersey gardeners can amuse themselves rewardingly by delving into plant encyclopedias and such in search of a new group of easytogrow plants to try out in their gardens potentillas, for instance. They can fill a wide variety of garden needs.

title: Margaret Gottlieb Betrothed To Jack Aaker, Copywriter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gottlieb of New York and San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Gottlieb, to Jack P. Aaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Loren S. Aaker of New Ulm, Minn., and Sun City, Ariz. The wedding is planned for May 8 in Oyster Say. L.I.

title: CHESS
For Sugar Producers, a Bitter Taste
description: ILOILO CITY, PhilippinesWith times so bleak, we might as well enjoy the last of the brandy, said Mrs. Delores Solinap With resignation, as her husband, Raul, a 60yearold sugar planter, uncorked a bottle of Cardinal Mendoza for visitors to their comfortable bungalow.

title: Snow Doesn't Stop Meet, But Keeps Teams Apart
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Jan. 29 (AP)Miami of Ohio defeated Ohio University, 7518, in a MidAmerican Conference swimming meet, but neither team saw the other because of Ohio's bad weather. The Miami swimmers swam in their own pool at Oxford, while their opponents performed at their home pool in Athens, Ohio.

title: Weather Taking Its Toll On Schedule of Sports
description: Many sports evants, in the East and Midwest were postiioned or canceled yesterday because of snow and cold.

title: The Bird on the Dais
description: His blond curls usually complement a leather jacket, blue jeans and sneakers. But Mark Fidrych is expected to be wearing a tuxedo tonight. The Bird will be perched on the dais at the 54th New York Baseball Writers Dinner at the Americana Hotel to receive the Sid Mercer Award as the 1976 player of the year in the major leagues. After the Detroit Tigers legendary rookie smooths out the tablecloth and talks to his fork, he will make an acceptance speech. Without notes, of course. He exists extemporaneously.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Senator Franz S. Leichter, DemocratLiberal of Manhattan, said he would, introduce legislation in Albany to provide criminal penalties for owners who abandon apartment buildings. He said that the bill would also include a notification system where a landlord cannot maintain a building, so that immediate steps can be taken to avoid tenants having to move out. Now there are no penalties for building abandonment as such. However, housing officials say that an owner who has abandoned a building remains just as responsible for providing services to the remaining tenants, or for sealing up the building if it is vacant, as an owner who has not abandoned his property.

title: Watson Takes 2Shot Lead In San Diego Golf on 67200
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan, 29 (AP)Tom Watson birdied all the par5 holes for the second day in a row on a fiveunderpar 67, broke out of a threeway tie, and established a twostroke lead today in the Andy WilliamsSan Diego open golf tournament.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Otis Simmons, a 58yearold derelict, walked barefoot in bitter cold through the streets of Manhattan to reach Roosevelt Hospital shortly before last Christmas.

title: Education
R. B. Koegel Fiance Of Mary Murphy
description: Mary Murphy, who is with the trust department of the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, plans to be married April 30 to Robert Bartlett Koegel, who is with the New York law firm of Thacher, Proffitt & Wood.

title: Farmers Getting Whole New Deal
description: TALL, bright aluminum grain elevators rise high above the fertile land in Upper Deerfield Township, a few miles from the Cumberland County seat of Bridgeton and in the heart of one of the state's most productive farm areas.

title: DINING OUT
description: A STATELY grande dame, this large and elaborate white house presides over the onestory shops, filling stations and fastfood chains that stretch before it along Hillside Avenue. La Marmite commands considerable respect in the area. It looks elegant, and manages to keep up appearances, despite some cracks in the veneer.

title: Housing Scarcity Strains East Bloc
description: BUDAPEST  Crossing Vrsmarty Square here through an everthickening flow of new, Communistmade automobiles, a foreign visitor is struck by a patina of prosperity from the boutiques, appliance stores and food shops.

title: ITALIAN PANEL URGES 2 EXAIDES BE TRIED IN LOCKHEED SCANDAL
description: ROME, Jan. 29A legislative committee recommended to Parliament today that two former defense ministers stand trial on charges of having taken bribes in the scandals involving the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Nature Intrudes On Carter's Busy First Ten Days
description: Despite preinaugural hints that the Carter Administration would begin at a deliberately moderate pace, the new President's first 10 days in office have instead been characterized by a quite active pursuit of domestic and foreign policy objectives he set before taking office. Yet Mr. Carter's biggest and most immediate problem was an unpredictable one, created by nature.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The hand of Henri CartlerBresson Iles heavy on French photography today. At least, that is the impression created by the exhibition A Certain Image of French Photography, 19751976, at the French Cultural Services, 972 Fifth Avenue, through Feb. 7. The exhibition, which will travel extensively in the United States, was assembled by Pierre de Fenoyl, newly appointed director of the French National Foundation of Photography, and it says a lot about how differently they do things in France. In the United States the socalled photography boomthat is, the transformation of photography from an art of the mass media to an art of the gallery and museumhas been fueled by a wide variety of nongovernmental sources, ranging from commercial galleries and private collectors to privatelyfunded muscums, foundations and university art departments. Except for the odd grant from the National Endowment for the Arts or various state or municipal arts councils for projects planned and carried out privately, the government has had no part in it. In England the principal agent of the current photography boom has been The Photographers Gallery of London, a privatelyorganized nonprofit operation that proved itself in practice before it began to receive a small Arts Council grant.

title: Joan L. Burchenal Is Married
description: The First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Joan Littlefield Burchenal, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Holland Burchenal of Noroton, Conn., to Robert Scott Nycum Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nycum of Summit, N.J. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers performed the ceremony.

title: The Proposed Law for New York City Exceeds Detroit's Law, Which Was Upheld
description: Tawdriness and vice have been twinned in Times Square for the last 40 years at least, and in that period, every city administration has tried to clean up Times Square. Now it is the Beame Administration's turn. If its latest proposal can pass constitutional musterand that is not at all certainit could be the most promising approach yet.

title: The First Ten Days
description: Nothing, of course, has been irretrievably committed in these first ten days, but President Carter's sketch of an agenda is bold, even venturesome. Too much can be made of his slow and steady cadence, the symbolic gestures to downhome simplicity. There's no telling how the new President will fare, but he is leaving a trail of clues about what he will attempt: a lot.

title: A New Arts Center in Paris to Open Amid Raging Controversy
Returnable Problems
Canada Winces at U.S. Tax Law
description: OTTAWACanadian tourist officials, dismayed by a costly loss of convention business because of a restrictive new United States tax law, have mounted an intensive campaign in Washington to have North America exempted from the regulations curbing tax deductions for the expenses of attending meetings of business and professional organizations abroad.

title: The Arab Oil Boycott: What Did It Teach Us?
description: OUR wasteful society apparently has learned nothing from the Arab oil boycott of several years ago, Nor has it learned anything, it seems, from the hardships caused by the rising inflation and widespread unemployment attributable to subsequent pricefixing by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Consequently, the nation is now in a state of undeclared economic emergency.

title: Spanish Leader Asks Calm in Face of New Violence
description: MADRID, Jan. 29In a forceful and sometimes emotional televised address, Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez tonight appealed to Spaniards to remain calm in the face of an outburst of terrorism intended to upset our march toward civilized coexistence.

title: $75 for a couple of snorts
description: As an article of conspicuous consumption, cocaine stands alone. In New York an ounce costs at least $1,000. A gram, which is .035 of an ounce and scarcely enough for a couple of good snorts, goes for at least $75, and by then has been diluted 50 to 80 percent. Compared with cocaine, the best beluga caviar, at $10 an ounce. is Just fish eggs, and fresh truffled pt de foie gras flown in from Strasbourg is so much chopped liver.

title: Marianne Espinosa Is Planning Marriage With W. Michael Murphy Jr. for June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert O. Espinosa of Seaford, L. T., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marianne Espinosa, to W. Michael Murphy Jr., son of Mrs. Richard J. Hughes of Princeton, N. J., and Durham, N. C., and the late Capt. William M. Murphy, U.S.A.F.

title: Cabin Fever Sets In As Ohioans Adjust To a Bitter Winter
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 29Outside the temperature was plunging toward 11 degrees below zero, and a 40knot wind howled cruelly through downtown Cincinnati. Inside the gleaming DuBois Tower, a skyscraper just off Fountain Square, the temperature had been cut to 45 to conserve gas.

title: Auction Records Set by Bidders At a Sotheby Parke Bernet Sale
description: Several new auction records were set yesterday afternoon at Sotheby Parke Bernet's sale of Americana, with stunning prices paid for a chest of drawers, a shabbylooking wing chair and a pair of Queen Anne side chairs.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Weakness in the oncepopular glamour issues highlighted last week's stock ,market, which extended its 1977 decline.

title: Abortion Issue Flares Anew
description: TRENTON IT IS, as the other side said, much like water wearing away stone. Last Monday, RighttoLife demonstratorswho are using songs and red roses to wear down legislative resistancesat in the gallery of the State Senate and watched approvingly as their latest antiabortion bill slid through on a 27top6 vote.

title: Gene Research: Is It a Danger?; Gene Research A Danger?
IceboatingA Race for Champions Iceboating, Race for Champions
description: WHIZZING crosswind at speeds of better than a mile a minute, more than 100 iceboat skippers from as far away as the Soviet Union began warming up this weekend for the North American and World DNclass iceboat championships to be raced on the frozen Navesink and Shrewsbury Rivers in Monmouth County.

title: New York State to Give Bronx Zoo And Botanical Garden Added Help
Sports Editor's Mailbox: Big Space at the Big A
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Race for Arms Sales
description: WASHINGTONIn the coming year the United States, the world's leading purveyor of munitions, will ship $10 billion worth of arms to scores of other nations.

News Summary
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 30, 1977

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TuesdayNew Jersey Association of Corvair Enthusiasts meeting at Strike N Spare Lanes, Route 22, Greenbrook, NJ., 7:30 P.M. Information: Bob Marlowe, phone (201)4453463.

title: A Shopper's Guide: Tour Bundles From Britain
description: Here is a random list of vacation packages (and the addresses of the operators) being sold in London for this winter and the spring. The approximate prices quoted are per person, double occupancy, and include air fare from and to Britain. Single occupancy may call for a supplemental charge. In some cases, advance booking is supposedly required, but if there are places available, a travel agent can make arrangements up to a few hours before takeoff.

title: Portrait of Wallace Stevens as a young artist
DIETRICH VON HILDEBRAND OF FORDHAM DIES AT 87
description: Dr. Dietrich von Hildebrand, who retired in 1960 as professor of philosophy at Fordham University after teaching there for 18 years, died Wednesday in his home, 43 Calton Road, New Rochelle. His age was 87.

title: End of an Era at Lazard
Golf Clubs: No Longer Par For the Course
Buck Baker, 57, to Drive In Stock Car Races Again
description: Elzie Wylie Baker, mote commonly known as Buck, may go on forever, maybe even until he races against one of his grandsons. He's already raced against his son, Buddy, so that milestone is behind him. At age 57 (born March 4, I910), Baker is a stock car racing legend who retired once but now says he doesn't even want to think about it again until he's at least 60. Baker. in fact, Is working on putting together an ambitious program for 1977. He plans to run in selected Winston Cup Grand National races (maybe as many as 10 or 12) and he will compete in the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing latemodel sportsman division.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: The two most important factors influencing the growth of plants, indoors, are water and light. Watering should not seem difficult, but it is. The problem is that most novices, and even a few pros, overdo it.

title: 60 Million Americans Can't Be Right
description: WASHINGTONIt was more than 12 years ago that Americans were told by the Surgeon General that cigarettes might well be what they had been called jokingly for many more yearscoffin nails. But for 60 million Americans, it jtist doesn't seem to matter.

title: U.S. Boxers Lose Again To Soviet
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 29The national boxing team of the Soviet Union, which has never lost to the United States amateur team since their series began in 1969, made it nine straight today with a 74 victory at the sports pavilion of Caesar's Palace Hotel.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: NEW JERSEY'S official game plan for the current session of Congress, even in summary form, weighs in at nearly one pound and covers more than 150 pages. It is a souptonuts listing of legislation and appropropriations that the various state departments in Trenton want to see approved by Congress.

title: Home Style
description: What to buya city house, a condominium, a home in the suburbs? Or how about staying put and looking for a weekend place?

title: Shadows of Groundhog Day
description: THERE is an old proverb that says winter never rots in the sky. It is always doing something. So there is cause for weather prophets to make what we consider mistakes. Consider the groundhog.

title: Moving to Accentuate The Affirmative
description: IN a shining little book entitled Children's Letters to God, one Silvia inquires: Are boys better than girls? I know you are one, but please try to be fair.

title: Food
description: If we were asked to name various categories of dishes that appeal to us most, one of them would most certainly be terrines and pts and things of that ilk. We say things of that ilk, for meat loaves fall directly into the category. Most such loaves can be savored differently on two occasions: first, when they come from the oven hot, and later as leftovers, an unfortunate and unpoctic word. Sandwiches made with slices of yesterday's meat loaf, crusty pieces of bread, fresh mayonnaise and imported mustard can be sublime. There are two basic loaves hereone made with veal and the other with pork, spinach and liver. The third dish is more elegant. It is a terrine of chicken coated with aspic.

title: Car Styling Goes Continental, Too
description: DETROIT  American automobile companies are not only adopting such engineering approaches favored by Europeans as the frontwheel drive, but they are also being inspired by Conti,nental car styling.

title: Meadowlands to Enter Show Picture
FOOD
For the West, Energy Warnings
description: PARISAs the 197374 energy crisis recedes from the public memory, there is a tendency to believe the energy crisis is behind us. Nothing could be further from the truth, warns Ulf Lantzke, secretary general of the International Energy Agency, a grouping of 19 Western nations.

title: Suzanne Stallings To Wed in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Elias Stallings of Rumson, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Stallings, to James Walter Magee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert U. Magee of Media, Pa.. and Vero Beach, Fla. A spring wedding is planned.

title: P.S.C. Chairman Takes Approach Of an Economist
The China Trade: Hopes for Growth
The Third World's Clamor Grows
GALLERY VIEW
description: One of the brightest people around the American art world is a young woman named Eleanor Antin. What she does is difficult categorize. It has within it elements of writing, painting, filmmaking, photography, theatricals (both amateur and professional), autobiograghy and a daydream inspired by history. These elements may appear either singly or in combination, and the endresult may be either a little sheet of paper that we have to get up close to or an elaborate spectacle involviIng live actors, a spoken text, painted mannequins on rollers, a sufficiency of scenery and Mrs. Antin herself.

title: World Mark Is Broken In 60Meter Hurdles
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 29 (AP)Dedy Cooper of San Jose State set a world record in the 60meter high hurdles tonight at the Oregon indoor track and field meet. Electric timing devices caught Cooper in 7.54 seconds. The previous mark was 7.66 set by Anatolly Moshiashvili of the Soviet Union in 1974 and tied by Frank Siebeck of East Germany in 1975.

title: What if Luther had been Pope
description: By Kingsley Amis. 210 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $7.95.

title: Regents Adopt Plan For Small Colleges Facing Fiscal Ills
description: ALBANYThe New York State Board of Regents took steps last week to help financially troubled private colleges avert what the State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, described as potential disaster.

title: New U.S. Chief at U.N. Off to Africa Tuesday
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 29, (UPI)President Carter briefed the new United States chief delegate to the United Nations, Andrew Young, on foreign policy today and announced he was sending Mr. Young on a 10day trip to Africa Tuesday.

title: Natural Gas: From Well to Burner
description: Natural gas is big business. Nearly onethird of the nation's energy is supplied by gas and, excluding the gasoline and diesel fuel used for transportation, ges's share rises to half.

title: Jo Sullivan, Frank Loesser's Widow, Returns With a Program of His Songs at Ballroom
description: After seven years behind a desk making decisions about how the songs of Frank Loesser will be used, his widow, Jo Sullivan, this week is once again doing what she likes best with those songssinging them.

title: DiMaggioGraham Team First
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Jan. 30 (AP)Joe DiMaggio sank a fivefoot par putt on the second hole of a suddendeath playoff that gave him and his partner, Otto Graham, first place in the American Airlines footballbaseball golf tournament today.

title: Snowflake Run to Lubar
description: Steve Lubar of the Millrose Athletic Association finished first in a field of 236 runners in Central Park yesterday in the FourMile Snowflake Run sponsored by the Road Runners Club of New York. Lubar, 23 years old, covered the course in 12 degree temperature in 20 minutes 21.2 seconds, 19 seconds ahead of Remulo Mejia of the East Coast Athletic Club. Brenda Sauders, 17, of the Long Island Spikes was the first of 34 women to finish, placing 49th over all in 24:32.

title: Australia Having a Heat Wave
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 30 (UPI)The temperature dropped 23 degrees in one hour today and everybody was glad. That was after the temperature in Sydney reached 104.7 degrees Fahrenheit. Liverpool, 25 miles to the south, had a high of 108 degrees, for the hottest summer day in 13 years.

title: Tschudi Victor in Dual Slalom
description: MONT GABRIEL, Quebec, Jan. 30 (AP)  Otto Tschudi of Norway got a gift victory in today's dual slalom final on the world pro skiing tour when Doug Woodcock of Toronto fell on the second run.

title: School Results
description: BOYS BASKETBALL

title: TWO KEY BLACKS REBUFF BRITON ON RHODESIA PACT
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 30 (Reuters)Ivor Richard of Britain faced the final breakdown of his Rhodesia peace mission today when two key African nationalists refused even to meet him here.

title: Argentina: Death, etc.

description: Special to The New York Times

title: New Rochelle Greets Carter's Pastor
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 30The Rev. Bruce Edwards, the Baptist pastor of President Carter's church in Plains, Ga., preached on sin for 45 minutes today at an interdenominational, interracial worship service in a predominately black church.

title: Watson Wins by 5 Shots For 2d Straight on Tour
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 30 (AP)Tom Watson cruised in with a three underpar 69 and won the Andy WilliamsSan Diego, open golf tournament by five strokes today, making it his second consecutive recordsetting victory.

title: Bridge
description: The optimists in the New York bridge world are those who open duplicate clubs, since for every success there are perhaps five failures. One that succeeded better than most was the Gallerie, which was the chief center of duplicate play on the Upper East Side fiir five years until it closed its doors last year. The proprietor was Bob Tripp, and he and his wife, Judith, left many friends behind them when they left New York yesterday optimistically seeking new pastures  not bridge ones  in Lansing. Mich.

title: Bellino Takes 3d Straight In Paris Trot
description: PARIS, Jan. 30Not even old age, the only opponent his entourage had feared, could beat the 10yearold Bellino II as the trotter matched Roquepine's record today in the Prix d'Amerique.

title: Robert W. Dunn Memorial
description: A memorial meeting for Robert W. Dunn, labor economist and founder ofthe Labor Research Association, will be held Thursday at 12:30 P.M. at the Community Church, 40 East 35th Street. Mr. Dunn died Jan. 21 at 81 years of age.

title: Shura Cherkassky, an Example Of Romanticism, in Piano Recital
description: A breath of the oldfashioned style was wafted into New York with Shura cherkassky's piano recital Saturday night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium. Mr. Cherkassky, in his mid60's and a Hofmann pupil, is one of the few living examples of one phase of Romanticismthe perfumed, swooning kind In certain kinds of music he was able to get away with iteven triumphantly so. In others he was completely miscast.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Mondale Finally Gets Time For Eight Hours of Sleep on His Grueling Trip
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30It is an endurance test, a nineday wonder, a blitz through Europe, 36 hours in Tokyo, and then back to Washington in a 15hour plane trip.

title: PARKING RULES
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations are suspended in New York City today because of snow and icy roads. All other parking rules remain in effect.

title: ChinesePakistani Award
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 30 (Reuters)China and Pakistan today sighed a protocol on scientific and technical. cooperation for. 1977, today in Islamabad, Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, reported.

title: Sweet Sounds of the Brandenburg
description: Alexander Schneider's way of playing Baroque music is rooted in the Central European tradition, which means more strings than purists would permit and pianos for solo keyboard works. But within that context, yesterday afternoon's performances at Avery Fisher Hall by Mr. Schneider's Brandenburg Ensemble were simply lovely.

description: The accounting profession's rulemaking authorities on auditing have issued two pronouncements and a proposal that together amount to the profession's response to the scandals over illegal or improper corporate payments.

title: A Craving for Rights
description: BOSTON, Jan. 30Jimmy Carter's commitment to the support of human rights abroad was almost certain to produce a clash with Soviet authorities at some point. But it has come much sooner than could have been expected, in the affair of Andrei Sakharov.

description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Jan. 30 (Reuters)About 700 demonstrators paraded through Londonderry today to mark the fifth anniversary of Bloody Sundaythe day on which 13 persons taking part in a protest march were killed by British soldiers.

title: New Corporate Bonds
Congress May Give Carter Power To Reorganize but Balk at Its Use
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Despite the misgivings of the chairman of a key House committee, Congress appears to be willing to give President Carter quickly the general legislative authority he wants to initiate changes in the structure of the Federal Government.

title: Polish Bishops Appeal For Renewal of Faith
description: WARSAW, Jan. 30 (Reuters)Poland's Roman Catholic bishops called on the nation today to reaffirm its religious vows in the face of a deluge of godlessness and atheism.

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS INCREASED 88% IN 1976
description: Machine tool orders in 1976 totaled $2.23 billion, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend. This was a gain of 88 percent over the 1975 total when the industry was in the depths of the recession.

title: Snowmobile Driver Killed in Michigan Race
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Jan. 30 (AP)Jack Flynn snowmobile driver from Petosky, Mich., was killed today on the 79th lap of the TC 250 race He was 42 years old and the father of two children.

title: Ali Plays the Clown In 10Round Exhibition
description: BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP)The heavyweight boxing champion, Muhummad Ali. making his first public ring appearance since he successfully defended his title against Ken Norton last September, clowned through 10 exhibition rounds last night, to the delight of 5,000 fans at Hynes Auditorium.

title: Profit Gains Showing a ModeratetoStrong Pattern

Meany Asks Retention of Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 UPI)George Meany, President of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, urged the Senate today to reject efforts to abolish its Post Office and Civil Service Committee. In Mailgram to each. senator, Mr. Meany described the committee as the only forum available to Federal and postal employees.

title: Texas Keeping Much of Its Gas For Top Prices
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 30Antonio R. Sanchez Jr. sits in his Laredo office on top of enough natural gas to keep Northeast factories humming, schools open and homes warm. The gas may be the largest amount discovered domestically in 20 years. Precise figures are not known yet, but the find may amount to 10 trillion cubic feetenough to supply the entire nation for six months.

title: GAS SHORTAGE EASES, SAVING 71,000 JOBS
description: Federal officials said yesterday that the threat of gas shortages for homes appeared to be receding, and cancellation of a planned cutoff of service suddenly saved 71,000 jobs in New York City and Westchester. But the fierce winter cold kept more than 1.5 million workers idle nationwide and may force more from their jobs later this week.

title: Commodities
description: When commodity traders discuss contango or backwardation movements they are not referring to a new Latin dance or a mental health problem. Rather, they are discussing the two basic pricing systems in commodity futures trading.

title: Steelworker Candidates Trade Charges on TV
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)  Lloyd McBride, supported for United Steelworkers Union president by the retiring leader, I. W. Abel, said today that he wanted Congress to determine if the union's elections were vulnerable to takeover by monied interests.

Murray Director, One of the Earliest Of Money Brokers
description: Murray R. Director, head of Murray Director Affiliates, a money broker who was long active; in advertising and food marketing, died Saturday evening at Trafalgar Hospital after a brief illness. He was 70 and lived at 372 Central Park West.

title: Woman Dies in Mystery Shooting
description: A young Wall Street worker from Queens was shot to death early yesterday, for no apparent reason, while sitting with her companion in a parked car on a quiet Forest Hills street waiting for the engine to warm up, the police said.

title: Energy Is Becoming Popular Ad Theme
description: Who knows, maybe energy policy will take over from free enterprise as this year's favorite corporate advertising theme.

description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES Montreal 2, Islanders 1 (n.). Rangers 5, St. Louis 2 (n.). Chicago 9, Cleveland 3 (n). Los Angeles at Buffalo, postponed. Colorado 4, Minnesota 2 (g). Philadelphia 5, Washington 5. Pittsburgh 5. Bostoh 2.

title: Israel Detains 82 Arabs
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 30 (Reuters)Israeli security forces have detained 82 Arab guerrillas suspected of having been responsible for recent sabotage in the occupied West Bank, an army spokesman said today, He said that the guerrillas, organized in 10 cells, had nearly all received military trainingmainly in Syria and Lebanonand were found in possession of arms and sabotage equipment.

title: CQS, a New Electronic System, Speeds Multimarket Quotations
description: A new technological development went into operation last week that makes it easier and faster for brokers  and in. directly for their customers  to obtain quotation's for all New York Stock Exchangelisted securities from all markets wherever these stocks are traded.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: SENATE REFORM PLAN CLEARED BY CHAIRMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Two secret meetings at which all Senate committee chairmen were given virtual veto power, with a few exceptions, have helped pave the way for the Senate's first major reorganization in 30 years.

title: Groundhog Due Wednesday
description: PUNXSUTAWNEY, Pa., Jan. 30 (AP). Punxsutawney Phil, the groundhog, is supposed to poke his nose above ground Wednesday to tell the pundits whether spring is near or far away. If the sun is shining and his shadow frightens him back into his hole, spring is still six weeks off, according to legend.

title: Robert Paul Smith Is Dead at 61
description: Robert Paul Smith, novelist, coauthor of The Tender Trap on Broadway and a writer who argued that children should be allowed to lead unstructured lives, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 61 years old.

title: Finding a Find, Catching a Catch For Brooklyn's Orthodox Jews
description: Sarah is 20 years old arid feels it's time for her to marry. But she has formidable obstacles.

title: Stanley M. Douglas, Lawyer, 78, Once Assistant State Prosecutor
description: Stanley Moreland Douglas of Brooklyn, a former assistant state attorney general, died Thursday in Brooklyn Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: American Poetry Review Is Charged With Racism
description: American Poetry Review, published six times a year in Philadelphia, but with national influence on campus and in the community of poets, has been accused of being antifeminist, racist and antiyouth by a group of 50 wellknown poets led by June Jordan and Adrienne Rich. The accusation is denied by the editor, Stephen Berg, poet and translator, who founded the publication in 1971. The Review has a circulation of about 20,000, and this year received a grant of $8,800 from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Requiring Test to Get a Diploma Brings Wide Attention to Denver

description: Governor Byrne's orders to restrict business activity and cut back heat in all New Jersey homes during the deepening energy crisis ran into scattered but stiff resistance yesterday from. workers, homeowners, clergymen and a. number of community officials.

title: Boros Wins by a Stroke For 2d Senior Golf Title
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP)Julius Boros of Miami shot a steady part 72 in th eclosing round today and shook off the challenge of Fred Haas Jr. to win the $50,000 Professional Golfers Association's seniors golf championship.

title: Hamilton, Guard, Paces U.C.L.A. Rout of Tennessee
description: The U.C.L.A.Tennessee basketball game yesterday was supposed to have been a show of the nation's top forwardsMarques Johnson and David Greenwood of U.C.L.A. and Bernard King and Ernie Grunfeld of Tennessee. But someone forgot to tell a little sophomore backcourt man named Roy Hamilton, and he stole the show.

title: Concert: Violin and Guitar Duo
description: The combination of violin and guitar has not been explored by many important composers but enough of a literature exists to prove that the pairing makes good sense. Ruggiero Ricci, the violinist, and Ernesto Bitetti, the guitarist, gave a duo recital yesterday at Town Hall that left one regretting the paucity of works available to them.

title: New Mall in Albany Beginning to Catch On
description: ALBANYThe surprise hit of the new Albany season is, of all things, the Albany Mall.

title: Russi Ends Klammer Streak
description: MORZINE, France, Jan. 30 (AP)Bernhard Russi of Switzerland, a former world and Olympic champion, won a World Cup downhill race today, ending the seasonlong string of victories of Franz Klammer of Austria.

title: A Nostalgic Farewell to New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANSWalker Percy, the novelist, declared in a morose moment one time, There is no magical habitat anymore.

title: Gratton Minds Net in 52 Victory
description: The asceticlooking Gillet Grafton returned to the ice as a lion last night. had little to do except look fierce and benefited from a big Ranger attack in a 52 Victory over the St. Louis Blues.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. .30  President Carter said today that he had not known in advance that the State Department press office would issue a warning to the Soviet Union that it should not silence the political dissident Andrei D. Sakharov. But, he said, the statement was my attitude.

title: Gushiken of Japan Keeps Junior Flyweight Crown
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30 (AP)Yoko Gushiken of Japan overcame a thirdround knockdown today and retained his World Boxing Association junior flyweight championship, with a split 15round decision over Jaime Rios of Panama.

title: House Panel Will Get An Ethics Plan Today
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)Wideranging recommendations governing outside income, gifts and travel for House members will be unveiled tomorrow, Representative David R. Obey. Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

description: AT ST. MORITZ

title: Mondale, in Tokyo, Affirms U.S. Links With Japan
description: TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 31Vice President Mondale arrived last night in Tokyo and strongly affirmed the Carter Administration's political and economic links to Japan and the rest of Asia.

title: GEORGE Q. HERRICK, 61
description: George Q. Herrick, retired director of the network division (engineering) of Radio Liberty and a key figure in State Department campaigns to prevent jamming of American radio broadcasts to the Soviet Union during the cold war, died Thursday at his home in Bronxville, N. Y. He was 61 years old.

title: ISRAEL BENJAMIN ABELSON
description: Israel Benjamin Abelson, a former New York clothing manufacturer and longtime resident of Scarsdale, N. Y., died Saturday In Boca Raton, Fla. He was 78 years old.

description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Yonkers Results
description: SUNDAY

title: Of Ships and Contracts, With Envy
description: New Yorkers cannot help but look enviously upon the General Dynamics Corporation, which recently obtained $730 million in Federal loan guarantees for its shipbuilding program. The corporation received this generous support easily and in silence, with none of the political uproar and crisis talk that enveloped the efforts this troubled city to open a financial lifeline to Washington. Envy aside, this unusual transaction has some positive aspects, if only we could be sure of the whole story.

title: Isadora Duncan Well Portrayed In Drama at the American Place
description: What do you do if you worship someoneI mean really worship someoneand then decide to write a biographical play about the object of your adoration. You could, it you were particularly sensitive, be worried that your unquestioning adulation might glint through like a searchlight, destroying objectivity and even credibility. This, I suspect, was Jeff Wanshel's problem when he decided to write about Isadore Duncan.

title: Dozen Skiers Are Injured As Berkshires Chairlift Plunges Wildly Downhill
description: HANCOCK, Mass., Jan. 30A chairlift at the Jiminy Peak ski area in the Berkshires ran out of control downhill today, seriously injuring more than a dozen skiers.

title: Murphy Cautions Auto Companies To Improve Product and Service
Swiss Pairs Finish One, Two In World Title Bobsledding
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 30 (AP)Swiss teams swept the first two places in the world twoman bobsled championships today with Hans Hiltebrand and Heinz Meier, who had narrowly qualified for the title races, taking the gold medal ahead of favored Fritz Luedi and Hansjoerg Trachsel.

title: Dallas Paper Gets New Editor
description: DALLAS, Jan. 30 (AP)The promotion of Kenneth P. Johnson to executive vice president and editor of The Dallas Times Herald was announced today by the board chairman, James F. Chambers, and the publisher, Wyatt Thomas Johnson.

title: Linda Diamond Calder Tribute Is Impressive
UGANDA SAYS AMIN'S PLANE IS LOST WITH 18 BRITONS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 30 (AP)Eighteen Britons are missing on a flight in President Idi Amin's personal plane in northern Uganda, the Uganda radio said tonight.

title: New Mall in Albany Beginning to Catch On
description: ALBANYThe surprise hit of the new Albany season is, of all things, the Albany Mall.

title: Winds Hamper Search For Hotel Fire Victims
description: BRECKENRIDGE, Minn., Jan. 30 (AP) Searchers today found none of the 16 bodies believed buried in the scorched rubble of a hotel, despite a break from the weather after two days of battling subzero temperatures, severe winds and heavy smoke

title: Boxing Coach Has a Plan for Carter
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 30After the Soviet Union's boxing team had beaten the United States amateur team for the ninth straight year here yesterday, Doc Broadus, one of the two American coaches, expressed outrage at only one thing: the American boxers had been brought together for only one week to Prepare for the match.

title: Ice Is Crushing Piers Along Jersey Coastal Waters
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Jan. 30  The most extensive layers of ice to cover Jersey coastal waters in half a century are lifting, twisting and breaking hundreds of small docks, piers and boat slips with each succeeding high tide, officials said today.

title: Barshai Arrives in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 30 (Reuters)Rudolf Barshai, founder of the Moscow Chamber Orchestra arrived in Israel today and said he planned to live and work here. He said he had been offered the post of musical director of the Israel Chamber Ensemble The 52yearold Mr. Barshai, one of the Soviet Union's leading interpreters of Mozart, emigrated this month. He said he had left the Soviet Union because he could no longer tolerate the way he was treated by Soviet musical authorities.

title: French Archeologist Is Freed by Chad Rebels
description: PARIS, Jan. 30 (AP)The archeologist Franoise Claustre and her husband, held hostage by rebels in Chad for almost three years, have been freed, the presidential palace announced tonight.

title: Critical Fiscal Issues to Confront Beame and His Aides This Week
LISBON CHIEF FACING CHALLENGE BY LABOR
description: LISBON, Jan. 30A national congress of trade unions denounced Portugal's Socialist Government today for allowing a capitalist recovery and demanded an active role for labor in the drafting, execution and control of economic and social policy.

title: Program Provides City Jobs for Mentally Retarded
Truckers Cancel Protest Against the Speed Limit
description: BREEZEWOOD, Pa., Jan. 30With thousands of trucks snowbound on Midwestern highways, the Independent Truckers Association today postponed a demonstration against the national 55mileanhour speed limit that had been set to begin at midnight tonight.

title: GAS SHORTAGE EASES, SAVING 71,000 JOBS
description: Federal officials said yesterday that the threat of gas shortages for homes appeared to be receding, and cancellation of a planned cutoff of service suddenly saved 71,000 jobs in New York City and Westchester. But the fierce winter cold kept more than 1.5 million workers idle nationwide and may force more from their jobs later this week.

title: Cold Weather Solutions: Conservation and Conversation
description: Making ingenious if sometimes tentative efforts to do something about the postblizzard weather besides talking about it, frozen customers outfitted themselves In Arctic gear over the weekend and fell back on conservation as well as conversationwith an occasional resort to prayer or to the neighbors.

title: Waldheim, Heading for Mideast, Fears a New War in Two Years
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations said yesterday that he feared the outbreak of a new Middle East war in two years unless a negotiating breakthrough was achieved this year in the ArabIsraeli dispute.

description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 30 (AP) Martina Navratilova routed Sue Barker, 60, 61, today and wan her third women's professional tennis tournament in four weeks.

description: ROME, Jan. 30 (AP)Pope Paul VI today defended his stand against the ordination of women as priests, saying that Roman Catholic women, could still occupy first place in charity and social fields.

Denney Wins Canadian Title
description: THUNDER BAY, Ontario, Jan. 30 (AP)  Jim Denney of Duluth, Minn., captured the Canadian national ski jumping championship today on jumps of 85 and 86.5 meters from the 70meter hill. He collected 238 points today and, with his total from the 70meter competition yesterday, had a twoday score of 434.2 points which won the combined title and the Shell Cup.

title: Chess
description: The poisoned pawn variation of the Najdorf Sicilian is not dead after allit just needed a little fixing.

description: Cathy E. Loup, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Loup of Denver, was married in New York yesteiday to Roy H. Langbord, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton J. Langbord of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Howard Berman of Temple EmanuEl in his study.

title: Joint Chiefs Dispute View Soviet Has Achieved Strategic Superiority
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)The nation's highestranking generals and admirals, in a report released today, disputed the view of a former air force intelligence chief that the Soviet Union had passed the United States in strategic power.

description: PRAGUE, San. 30 (Reuters)The efforts of Czechoslovak authorities to suppress the rights movement known as Charter 77 appeared today to have taken a more subdued form as the issue began to affect the country's international standing.

description: Dr. Regine Benayoun, daughter or Mr. and Mrs. Paul Benayoun of Paris, was married yesterday afternoon to Michael Feuer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Feuer of Jamaica, Queens. Rabbi Isidoro Aizenberg performed the ceremony at the Conservative Synagogue in Jamaica.

title: Zabaleta Excels on the Harp
description: Between the music he has unearthed from the Baroque era and the works he has commissioned from contemporary composers, Nicanor Zabaleta could probably assemble 100 or more solo harp programs without ever repeating himself. The Spanish virtuoso gave his annual Alice Tully Hall recital Saturday night, and this year he devoted himself entirely to Spanish music from the 17th, 18th and 20th centuries.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)Andrew Young, a Democratic Congressman from Georgia and a leader of the civil rights movement in the 1960's, took the oath of office today as the chief United States representative at the United Nations.

description: Bonnie Beth Braunstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Braunstein of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Andrew Emery Grosz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emery Grosz of Flushing, Queens. Rabbis Robert Rothman and Fred Margolis officiated at the ceremony at the Community Synagogue in Rye. N.Y.

title: You'll Never Hear the Trees Complain
description: WASHINGTON Waste paper recycling has become something of a stepchild of the environmental movement. It ought not be. Recycling paper cuts the cost and the environmental damage of garbage disposal, and reduces the necessity of cutting forests. At the peak of the environmental effort, enthusiasm for this direct action was high; across the land, station wagons on a Saturday morning were filled with kids, old newspapers and Rood intentions.

title: Construction Contracts Show December Jump Of 34%, Dodge Reports
description: Contracts for all types of construction increased in December, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company, said over the weekend. The value of the contracts last month totaled $7.19 billion, up 34 percent from the yearearlier level.

description: The marriage of Diane Eve Chester, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Chester of Bayside, Queens, to Dr. James Ray Demicco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Demicco of Jewett City, Conn., took place yesterday at the Swan Club in Roslyn. L. I. Criminal Court Judge Harold Mayer performed the ceremony.

description: Decolonization committee meets at 10:30 AM., followed by meetings of subcommittees on small colonial territories and on petitions.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  President Carter dramatized his concern about the current weather and fuel crisis with an early morning helicopter ride today to the Pittsburgh area, one of those hard hit.

title: The Red Cross Ball Basks In the Glow of Many Crowns
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30The carpet in the Venetian ballroom of the Breakers Hotel looked like a giant red cross. The background for the band was a massive red cross of fresh carnations. Each piece of whipped dessert cake was decorated with a red cross. It had to be the International Red Cross Ball. The ball itself is 19 years old, but it has looked somewhat the same for the past six years, even to the dress that Ann Light, who was once Mrs. J. Paul Getty, saves especially for it. It is considered the major kickoff of the seasonal charity benefit goaround here.

title: Role in Cairo Riots is Denied by Leader Of Opposition Party
description: CAIRO, Jan. 30The policies of the Government are to blame for the two days of riots in. Cairo last week, the leader of the Leftist Party, Khaled Mohieddin, said today.

title: DriveUp Funeral Home Gaining Acceptance
description: NEW ROADS, La., Jan. 30 (UPI)It is the very last word in a society centered on the automobile: A 7by5foot window in the side of the gold and white Point Coupee Funeral Home allows mourners to pay their last respects without leaving their cars.

title: Protest Erupts in Djibouti
description: DJIBOUTI, Territory of Afars and Issas, Jan. 30 (Reuters)A soldier was shot and wounded today when security forces clashed with about 1,000 youths protesting France's decision to hold a conference in Paris on the future of this Red Sea territory. The demonstrators, members of the MarxistLeninist Popular Liberation Movement, want the. independence talks to be held in a neutral country under the auspices of the Organization of African Unity.

title: State's 2 Freshmen Congressmen. Are Taking Active Roles in House
Party Picks Lawyer To Fill Council Seat
description: Henry T. Berger, a lawyer and district leader, was chosen by Democrats yesterday to fill out, until the end of this year, the City Council post vacated by Theodore S. Weiss's election to Congress.

title: Levasseur Takes Trophy
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 30Mark Levasseur, the 16  year  old Shrewsbury, Mass., high school athlete, picked the right time to record his longest distances on the 50meter skijumping hill here. The junior jumper beat the entire field with flights of 149, 157 and 154 for a total of 304.8 points and won the Dwight D. Eisehhower Memorial Trophy.

title: Bucks Subdue Nets, 10092, With Rally in Final Period; Bucks Rally In 4th Period Subdues Nets
description: UNIONDALE, L.I, Jan. 30  All through the mounting disaster of their first National Basketball Association season, the New York Nets have had one piece of cold comfortbad as their record was, Milwaukee's was worse. After today's game against the Bucks at the Nassau Coliseum, even that piece of comfort is acme.

title: Personal Defeat Private Hell
description: We're all hypocrites, someone was saying the other day. When Gary Gilmore was executed, there wasn't a peep out of the RighttoLife people who are so steamed up about abortion being murder. Yet the people who support abortions are the same ones protesting so hard about capital punishment as murder by the state.

title: Horse Shows
description: AT MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I.

title: Stockton's Surge Upsets Connors in 5Set Final
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30They had been going at each other for something like two hours and 10 minutes, eyeball to eyeball, and now they were in the fourth set, and Jimmy Connors needed only one more set to win the $40,000 first,prize. On the other side of the net Dick Stockton was serving, leading 31 In the set, but down love40 in the game. If ever there was a chance for Stockton to be swept away, this was it. Remember, eyeball to eyeball for $40,000.

title: War Resisters, Meeting in Canada, Demand Unconditional Amnesty
description: TORONTO, Jan. 30In the first concerted response of war resisters abroad to President Carter's pardon of draft offenders, 345 evaders, deserters and sympathizers adopted a resolution today demanding that the pardon be extended to a universal, unconditional amnesty for all offenses committed during the antiVietnam War movement.

Las Angeles 101, New Orleans 99 (n.) Philadelphia 107, Denver 101. Portland 97, Phoenix 91 (n.). San Antonio 126, Seattle 118 (overtime).

title: Canadiens Win on Cournoyer's Goal
New Eruptions of to Soufriere
description: POINTEAPITRE, Guadeloupe, Jan. 30 (UPI)Fresh activity has been reported at the summit of La Soufriere, the volcano on the West Indian island of Guadeloupe. Rumblings could be heard in BasseTerre 20 miles away, and two small towns at the foot of the volcano, SaintCloude and MatoubaPapaye, were showered with cinders. However, experts said the latest disturbances, lasting only about 10 minutes, were not considered dangerous.

description: WASHINGTONSoviet authorities cannot diminish the effectiveness of their leading dissident, scientist Andrei Sakharov, in the same way they handled Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn  by sending him out of the country.

title: Israel Asks France to Defer Visit
description: JERUSALEF, Jan. 30 (UPI)Israel has asked France's Minister of Commerce and Economy, Michel d'Orano, to postpone indefinitely his visit scheduled for next month, a Government official said today. The decision followed France's release of the Patestinian leader Abu Daoud but was not directed at Mr. d'Orano personally, the official said.

title: Joyce Needleman, Editor, Wed to Ivens V. Stanton
description: Joyce I. Needleman and Ivens V. Stanton of Manhattan were married at noon yesterday in the Hampshire House by Rabbi Alexander Budin of Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: U.S. Said to Tell Beirut Israel Will Not Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 30The Lebanese Government was reported today to have received assurances from the United States that Israel would not attack southern Lebanon in response to the stationing there of Syrian troops of the socalled Arab peacekeeping force.

description: Governor Byrne's orders to restrict business activity and cut back heat in. all New Jersey homes during the deepening energy crisis ran into scattered but stiff resistance yesterday from workers, homeowners, clergymen and a number of community officials.

title: Stack Heads Baseball Hall
description: Edward W. Stack of Glen Head, L. I., was elected president of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum in Cooperstown, N. Y., yesterday at the midwinter meetings of the board of directors at the Hotel Americana. He succeeds Paul S. Kerr of Ridgewood, N. J., who retired after 16 years as president but continues as a board member. Stack, who was secretary or the Hall of Fame for 16 years, will be succeeded in that post by William T. Burdick of New York.

title: PARKING RULES
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations are suspended in New York City today because of snow and icy roads. All other parking rules remain in effect.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  Paul C. Warnke, a former highranking Defense Department official who has advocated that the United States seek reciprocal restraint with the Soviet Union to reduce each side's nuclear arsenal, has been chosen by President Carter to negotiate arms limitation with the Russians.

title: Topics
description: With his appointment as ambassadoratlarge, Elliott Richardson has clearly taken the lead in the race to become president of the Establishment in this generation.

title: DEGUSTIBUS
description: Some time ago. Ira Ashley of New York wrote recently, you ran an interview with a Spanish woman from Andalusia, then living in New York and printed a few of her recipes, including one for gazpacho, which is the only authentic one I have ever seen published in English (I lived for a while in southern Spain). Alas and alack, I have lost my copy. Could you provide?

title: Some School Closings Due Today Under Carey Order to Save Gas
description: Surprise vacations, transfers to other schools and other emergency moves will begin today for thousands of students as a result of a directive by Governor Carey on Saturday to close 1,319 gasheated schools for a week because of the coldinduced energy crisis. Most of the schools are in the western part of the state.

title: U. S. DISASTER AIDES ARE SENT TO NEW YORK
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 30Teams of specialists from the Federal Disaster Assistance Administration were sent today to areas of New York and Pennsylvania that have been stricken by snowstorms and freezing weather to begin implementation of President Carter's order making those regions eligible for emergency Federal relief.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Miss Longet to Be Sentenced Today
description: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 30 (AP)Ahdy Williams, the singer, plans to be with his former wife, Claudine Longet, when she is sentenced tomorrow in the shotgun death of her lover, Vladimir Sabich, according to Charles V. Weedman, lawyer. Miss Longet, 36 years old, faces up to two years in prison and a $5,000 fine on conviction of criminally negligent homioide.

title: Liberals in a Quandary Over Mayoral Race
description: Still trying to recover from the loss of the power and the prestige of the late Alex Rose, its longtime leader, the Liberal Party faces a predicament in the coming New York City mayoral campaign. Simply stated, the predicament is whether the party should support a Democrat other than Mayor Beame or a Republican mayoral prospect, State Senator Roy M. Goodman, or whether it should run its own candidate in what would be a futile campaign. Each of the choices has ramifications extending beyond the mayoral campaign. The wrong choice could be a severe setback to the party, which, under Mr. Rose's leadership, has had frequent access to the White House, the State Capitol and City Hall. The eventual) choice could also be a major factor in determining who emerges as Mr. Rose's successor.

title: Byrne Leads Team To Victory in Relays
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30Kevin Byrne ran on three winning teams and also participated in the high jump as Paramus Catholic took the parochialschool title at the New Jersey State interscholastic indoor relay championships today at Jadwin Gym.

title: A Landmark District Is Proposed On 5th Ave. Opposite Art Museum.
OPTIONAL TAX CREDIT PROPOSED BY CARTER AROUSES SKEPTICISM
description: The most novel element in President Carter's proposed tax relief for business an optional tax credit tied to an employer's Social Security tax payments is getting a skeptical reception from corporate executives and economists.

title: Baseball Writers Dinner: Satire, Song and Fidrych
description: From Mark Fidrych to the free agents agents, the 1976 season in the major leagues was saluted and satirized by New York's baseball writers last night at their 54th annual dinner and follies.

title: Richard Hugo Named As Yale Poetry Judge
description: Richard Hugo, director of the creativewriting program at the University of Montana, and author of four books of poetry, will succeed Stanley Kunitz as judge of the Yale Younger Poets Series, it was announced by Chester Kerr, director of the Yale University Press, which sponsors the series. Previous judges have included Archibald MacLeish, W. H. Auden and Dudley Fitts.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Watchdog Intelligence Committee For House Will Be Sought Again
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)With a watchdog panel already functioning in the Senate, a fresh effort is scheduled to be made tomorrow to give the House a role in overseeing Government intelligence operations.

title: Books of The Times
description: And now, at last, I have some perspective on all I have done. I mean, the work apart from me, the work which I did, apart from what I am ... and now I realize for the first time what an amazing gift I had: uneducated in every formal sense, without even very literate, let alone literary, companions, yet to have made the things I made. I don't know where it came from.

title: Housing Development Plan Perturbs Old Tappan
Yonkers Drivers
Gilmore Case Cost Utah $60,000 Before Death
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 30 (AP)It cost Utah more. than $60,000 to try Gary Gilmore, the executed killer, and keep him alive through two suicide attempts, a Salt Lake City newspaper reported, today.

title: 50,000 in New Delhi Attend AntiGovernment Rally, First in 19 Months
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 30Fifty thousand people gathered on a broad, dusty fairground today for the first antiGovernment political rally permitted here in 19 months.

title: A 4Alarm Bronx Fire Damages Four Stores and a Movie House
description: A fouralarm fire burned out of control for more than two hours in the South Bronx last night, destroying the interiors of four stores and of an abandoned movie theater on Southern Bouleyard between 163d and Aldus Streets. There were no injuries reported. Firemen hampered by temperatures in the teens, battled the blaze from shortly before 9 P.M. until just after 11 P.M.

title: Space Shuttle Is Going To Desert for Tests
description: PALMDALE Calif., Jan. 30 (AP)The stubby, dartlike space shuttle, half rocket and half airplane, is ready for a road trip to a converted desert dry lake to answer the question of whether it will fly.

title: Carter's Stimulus Plan Tries to Minimize the Biggest Risks
description: As in Goldilocks and the Three Bears, some people think President Carter's twoyear $31.1 billion package of fiscal stimulants is too big, some think it is too small and some think It is just right. In somewhat oversimplified narration, those who think it is too big are worried about regenerating inflation, creating an unnecessarily big budget deficit and high interest rates and imparting a hectic, gostop pattern to the economy. Those who think it is too small contend that it will not cure unemployment and will not lift consumption and investment enough to restore prosperity. Therefore it is a halfhearted, weakkneed political compromise, they argue. And those who think it is just, right are mostly people who work for President Carter.

title: Soviet Finds, Um, a Nessie Perhaps.
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30Reports of a mysterious serpentlike creature dwelling in a remote mountain lake in Soviet Central Asia are giving rise here to the kind of speculation long associated with Scotland's legendary Loch Ness monster.

title: Track Judge Named
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Article 1  No Title
Misery Strikes in the Coal Fields as Oil Runs Out
description: McCLELLANDTOWN, Pa., Jan. 30It was five below zero early this morning when Ada Newman's last drop of fuel oil gave out, and soon the night was sucking the warmth out of her rundown old miner's house in Hoover's Patch.

title: Abbatiello Joins the Sunday Drivers For a Whirl, 2 Winners at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, Jan. 30Carmine Abbatiello, skipped church this morning, gave up a Sunday with the wife, children and television set, and returned to Yonkers Raceway.
